HEADLINE: The Risks and the Benefits Of Letting Sick Banks Die

SERIES: Banks Under Stress - Fourth of five articles: Are Banks Dispensable?

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
When banks fail, the carnage horrifies most onlookers. Not so some colder-blooded bankers and economists. They say bank failures, even huge ones, do not necessarily hurt, and may even help, the economy.
One reason is that there are too many banks starving for profit. Letting the hungriest ones die is good for the survivors, some argue. Lawrence A. Kudlow, chief economist at the investment banking firm of Bear, Stearns & Company, said, "The end result will be a stronger, healthier banking system."
 
The Example of Texas
 Take one of the more spectacular basket cases, Texas. "If we looked at Texas, we'd see the future," Mr. Kudlow said. After oil and real estate prices collapsed in the mid-1980's, the Texas economy slumped, taking 7 of the state's 10 biggest banks with it. Two of the surviving three would have failed had an out-of-state buyer not rescued them. For all the pain, the Texas economy is stronger now than much of the rest of the country's, many economists say. 
 Some bankers themselves are not worried about bank failures. "You'd have to get an almost inconceivable rash of failures to take down enough banks to make a huge difference," John Rau, chief executive of LaSalle National Bank in Chicago, said in an interview.
This does not mean, however, that economists are unconcerned about the banking system. They are. But there are levels of concern.
They agree that some small banks can indeed be allowed to fail without far-reaching consequences. Most industrial countries have far fewer banks than the 12,926 that the United States has. Japan has 154; Canada, 66.
Economists do have strong disagreements about letting the big banks, even one big bank, fail. Some say those, too, should be allowed to go down in the flames of their own excess -- their making so many high-risk real estate loans, for example, or their financing of so many giant corporate mergers and acquisitions. Others say the punishment might be deserved, but that carrying it out could wreck the entire banking system.
They do all agree that the banking system itself must be preserved, even though many non-banking institutions -- investment houses and insurance companies, for example -- have invaded a portion of the money-lending business. Only the banks, they say, can really be in a position to keep the engines of the nation's economy humming: almost all American households and most of its businesses use banks to borrow money and, through checking accounts, to pay for what they buy. Without such credit and smooth flow of payments, the engines quickly halt.
Finally, though they find no evidence that the banking system is in any danger of collapse, virtually all agree that it has serious problems and that Congress must address them squarely in the weeks to come.
 
The Case for Attrition
 
Perils Seen In Protection
The arguing over the big banks is initiated by the "let 'em fail" school of thought, which contends that big-bank failures by themselves do not do permanent harm to the economy. To begin with, they say, the Federal Reserve can protect the economy from the fallout by regulating the supply of money. Milton Friedman, a Nobel laureate in economics, says the failure of a bank is no different from the failure of, say, Eastern Airlines. "So long as the quantity of money is kept from declining," he said, "bank failures have no greater effect than the failure of comparable commercial enterprises."
And it is clear that the banks, even the healthy ones, are not as important as they once were, or at least not as dominant in the money business. Borrowers and lenders have many more choices; funds supplied by life insurers, money markets, mutual funds, mortgage pools and checking accounts at brokerage houses have all ballooned. The banks' share of business lending has slipped from four-fifths, to two-thirds, since the early 1970's.
The failure of a large bank does create the risk that large uninsured deposits, especially money from other banks, will be lost, causing the other banks to fail. But some economists think the risk is trivial. "The short-run costs are quite minimal," said George G. Kaufman, a finance professor at Loyola University. He points out that most banks minimize their exposure by spreading their deposits around at several banks.
 
An Example From Chicago
 Take the case of the 1984 rescue of Continental Illinois, a Chicago bank that dealt mostly with other banks and businesses. A post-mortem of the rescue showed that only two of Continental's customer banks would have lost more than half their capital had the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation not taken over Continental and absorbed the losses that would otherwise have been borne by large depositors.
But what happens to money that big depositors begin to quietly pull out of a big but weakening bank -- making a so-called silent run? "They put it in some other bank or money market mutual fund," said George J. Benston, an Emory University finance professor, who added that the money market fund was likely to put the money back into a bank C.D. "The money stays in the banking system," he said. "Silent runs just redistribute money from risky to safe banks."
According to James Moynihan, a bank analyst at Advest Inc. in Boston, this is precisely what is happening now: "Depositors are looking at bank rankings and are going from weak banks to stronger banks."
The American Bankers Association, which represents thousands of small banks and argues that small and large bank failures should be treated alike, says that providing unlimited Federal protection only for deposits at the big banks would create perverse incentives for depositors to keep their money in risky institutions, ultimately increasing the likelihood of bank failures. David L. Littman, a senior economist at the Manufacturers National Bank of Detroit, said, "If everybody's safe, nobody's safe."
 
Too Big to Fail
 
Strong Support For Rescues
On the other hand, the "too big to fail" school contends that there are some banks whose failure would pose grave risks to the national economy. This line of thought is probably the majority view, at least among those with the power to do something about such things, and its adherents include the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, who told a Senate committee in the summer, "There may be some banks, at some particular times, whose collapse and liquidation would be excessively disruptive to the financial system."
To buttress their position they, too, cite the Continental Illinois case. The Federal regulators then could not be certain that a chain reaction would not occur if they failed to bail out Continental. At the height of the crisis, Continental had $9 billion in overnight funds in London and deposits from hundreds of other banks.
C. Todd Conover, the head regulator in the Continental takeover and now a managing director of KPMG Peat Marwick, recalled: "We didn't know what would happen if those deposits were not honored. We weren't sure we knew all the linkages. But we didn't think it was a great opportunity to find out."
 
The Role of Foreign Deposits
 The international nature of banking has become as important a factor as any. If foreign banks and investors were to lose faith in the safety of United States banks, for example, and withdrew some of the billions they currently have on deposit in commercial banks in this country, the result could be severely wrenching. Robert Hormats, a managing director at Goldman, Sachs, said, "If our banking problems intensify, foreign money becomes more reluctant and costs more."
The collapse of a mid-sized West German bank in 1974 provided ample evidence of how quickly and how far one bank's problems can spread internationally. Testifying before the House Banking Committee last year, E. Gerald Corrigan, president of the New York Federal Reserve, said the Herstatt Bank collapse "created a lasting impression of the grave dangers associated with the sudden and uncontrolled collapse of an important financial institution, especially one with significant international operations."
When it closed, Herstatt was in the midst of completing millions of dollars worth of foreign exchange deals. As a result, banks had $620 million frozen in short-term Herstatt accounts. Their inability to get their money produced a chain reaction of other missed payments. As a result, the daily volume of transactions that originated overseas and were cleared by American banks dropped by roughly 25 percent in the days after the failure, temporarily disrupting the flow of payments that keeps the global economy going.
So now, minute by minute, the Federal Reserve monitors the balances of large banks that process international payments, like Citibank, Chase Manhattan and J. P. Morgan.
And in early January of this year, as the crisis at the Bank of New England mounted -- nearly a billion dollars was withdrawn in two days -- regulators detected a surge in withdrawals from other banks in the New England region. It was at this point that L. William Seidman, chairman of the F.D.I.C., and his regulators moved in and took over the bank, simultaneously announcing that they would guarantee all deposits in total, regardless of the $100,000 limit on insurance.
Paul Samuelson, a Nobel laureate in economics, who was in downtown Boston when news of the bank's insolvency started to spread, said: "Nobody could know what was going to happen when the Bank of New England started to shake. There were honest-to-goodness runs."
As a practical matter, most economists believe that keeping big banks open should at least remain an option, and they support the F.D.I.C.'s decision to do so at the Bank of New England. Mr. Litan of the Brookings Institution said, "Any responsible person would have done what Seidman did."
 
The Need for Banks
 
The Only Source For Many Loans
So the primary reason to prop up a big bank is to prevent a chain reaction that would break the banking system. But if the big investment and brokerage houses, insurance companies and industrial corporations have indeed invaded much of the traditional banking territory, why should anyone care whether banks survive? Can't the non-banking institutions simply step into the breach?
In truth, a nation must have a rock-solid banking system, in which the banks perform two basic functions the other institutions are simply not equipped to do on the scale required. If you did not have the banks, you would have to invent them.
First, they act as conduits between savers and borrowers, who, it is hoped, are skillful entrepreneurs. The well-run banks help channel resources to productive uses, and help reduce the inherent risks. Second, but of equal importance, they provide consumers and businesses with a place (checking accounts) to keep money that they will need back quickly; in this way, the banks handle nearly everybody's financial transactions.
 
Serving the Middle Market
 Despite the presence of the other institutions, most borrowers cannot easily bypass the banks: Individuals seeking unsecured credit, small businesses, home builders, homeowners -- most of them need banks. To lend to these groups you have to know the borrower and it is really only banks that have the distribution systems and the contacts.
"There hasn't been much erosion of banks' role in the middle market," said Tom Hanley, a bank analyst at Salomon Brothers. After some bank failures, there has been anecdotal evidence that borrowers' lines of credit and commitments were blocked off, as other lenders pulled back. The borrowers least likely to find substitute sources of credit quickly are the small local businesses whose loans are too small to interest larger lenders.
Henry B. Ellis, former president of Mbank El Paso, said that in the late 1980's in Texas "the banking system completely stopped supplying capital."
"That eliminated liquidity within the Texas market," he said. "We had no access to other markets either." The key to the gradual recovery of the Texas economy was that the failed banks were bought by out-of-state banks.
Still, William C. Ferguson, president of Ferguson & Company, a Washington consulting company, said of situations in which another bank takes over one that has failed: "It's just extremely hard to replace those credits. The new loan officers don't know the company. Besides, acquiring banks are very cautious." Further, he added, failures encourage regulators to cast a colder eye on surviving banks.
 
Storehouses for Savings
 In addition to lending, banks provide a place for millions of depositors, small and large, to keep their money in insured accounts.
It is true that depositors have more choices than they used to; most money market funds allow shareholders to write checks on their accounts. But the fact is that 90 percent of all American households use banks or savings and loans for their checking accounts; the amount in money market funds is equal to about 10 percent of what is held in bank and savings and loans. And as the crucial links in a global payments' system, banks process most of the financial transactions that businesses, governments and households make. That makes the system vulnerable to disruptions.
Commercial banks clear nearly $2 trillion -- or 800 million separate transactions -- every day, by estimate of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Only a tiny fraction, perhaps 1 percent, of all payments are made with cash.
 
Assessing the Dangers
 
The Differences From the 1930's
Despite the very real problems of the banks, nearly everyone agrees on one point: The banking system is not teetering on the edge of a 1930's abyss. "This is a different environment," said Henry Kaufman, president of the consulting firm Henry Kaufman & Company and a critic of the heavy borrowing and easy lending of the 1980's.
For starters, even the gloomiest prognosticators do not expect to see a repeat of the bank panics of the 30's, when more than a third of the nation's banks shut their doors. Not only is there a safety net that helps keep banks operating, but there are also no signs of the kind of severe deflation that destroyed banking assets during the Depression and caused borrowers to default on nearly 50 percent of the value of all bank loans. In the first nine months of 1990, the banks charged off only 1.5 percent of their loans, though that was more than twice the rate at the end of the 1982 recession. And while it is true that real estate prices are falling in many parts of the country, prices over all are still rising.
And most borrowers' incomes are not greatly endangered. H. Erich Heinemann, chief economist at Ladenburg, Thalmann & Company, said, "The ultimate collateral behind the banks' asset base is that the nation's income is extraordinarily stable." He pointed out that since World War II, total real disposable income has fallen in only one year, 1974, and then by only 1 percent. "Consumers have $17 trillion to $20 trillion in wealth," he said. "Nothing has happened to destroy that wealth."
Finally, it seems clear that if the nation's money supply did start to shrink, the Federal Reserve could be expected to step in, something it did not do in the 30's. John P. LaWare, one of the Federal Reserve's governors, said, "I wouldn't want to prejudge the votes of my five associates, but we would try to avoid repeating that mistake."
Next: Solutions.

HEADLINE: About New York;
Haitians Talk Of New Pride And Going Home

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN

 BODY:
The usual crowd was coming and going at Augustine's Barber Shop at 172 Park Place in the Prospect Heights section of Brooklyn on Saturday morning. The shop looks like any barbershop with its striped poles and bathing beauty calendar, but a pile of French-language newspapers and snapshots on a mirror identify it as the Haitian meeting spot it is.
The photos show what happened to operatives of Jean-Claude Duvalier after the fall of his hated dictatorship in 1986. In one, a decapitated head sits in dirt. In another, one can barely discern that a pile of ashes used to be a human. 
 "Every 10 people I talk to, it seems like four or five are going back," said Sylvain Benoit, the barber who owns the shop. He recently bought it from the widow of Ferdinand Augustine. Mr. Augustine was shot to death by two youths for no apparent reason at 5:20 P.M. on Sept. 12 in front of the shop. The killers haven't been caught.
Mr. Benoit would rather have his friend than a barbershop. "That's not what he deserved. He was a hard-working person. He paid his taxes. He didn't bother anybody."
New York's Haitian diaspora is at a delicate point of transition. Most fled the bloody oppression of the Duvalier regime, then, brick by brick, built a new life here. They got a foothold, but, like all immigrants, live on the precarious margin where danger is greatest. And they face prejudice from both whites and native blacks.
So many feel they have never really belonged. With a new democratic government in Haiti, people talk and talk of returning.
A dinner dance at a Kennedy Airport hotel Sunday night suggested the dimensions of change. "100 Percent Haitian and Proud of It!" a banner proclaimed.
And there she was! Marjorie Judith Vincent, the Haitian American who reigns as Miss America, glittered in an elegant silver gown.
 There was other good news. Washington ended its ban on Haitian blood donors in December, admitting they are no more at risk of having AIDS than other groups. That followed a protest by tens of thousands of Haitians, suggesting to people who had long felt powerless that together they could exercise influence.
There was the shy presence of David Opont, who epitomized resistance to brutality by struggling to recover from the horror of being set afire in a robbery last March. The Haitian Americans, not used to having nationally admired heroes, clapped long and hard for him.
Others proudly mentioned that Pierre Toussaint, a Haitian American buried in New York, was moving steadily toward becoming the first black American saint.
Just getting together was cause for celebration. The dinner dance was the first gathering of the Greater Haitian Economic Development Corporation, a new group dedicated to addressing the community's needs.
By far the most important thing, though, was the sea change back home. The Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide was inaugurated on Feb. 7 as Haiti's President, suggesting the sun is rising after the 29-year darkness of the Duvalier dictatorship and the five years of violent confusion that followed it. "Rebirth of a Nation" was the celebration's theme.
Haiti never looked better. "My parents would love to go back," Miss America said.
Many at the barbershop -- where the sounds were of endlessly clipping scissors, a TV wrestling match and Haitian Creole -- felt the same way.
Michael Pardovany, a hospital floor waxer. said that he hoped to buy land and move back in five years. "Back home is a nice country," he said. "We don't have money, but people have respect."
Joseph Pierre, a cabdriver, wants to try to set up a business in Haiti. "Everybody loves his country," he said.
Fritz Darius, also a cabdriver, said he would return if he found work. He longs to return to Petite Riviere, a farm town of 4,000 north of Port-au-Prince. "This place is too fast for me," he said.
Wesner Jean, a clerk in a nursing home, was proud to show off the envelope of $5 bills he had collected from fellow workers to aid the Haitian Government. He too would like to return. But his children, two in American colleges, have never learned Creole.
The question for many is whether homesick Haitians who have built a life here, however imperfect, will throw away hard-won gains. "I really can't complain," allowed Rene Jeantine, a carpenter.
And going back to a new Haiti, still the hemisphere's poorest country, might not be easy.
At the banquet, Pierre Armand, chairman of the new group, said that he returned in 1979 to work on economic reform. But he came back in five years. "I couldn't take it," he said.

HEADLINE: Cases Under 'Sam' Law: Notorious but Few

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI

 BODY:
Their names conjure up memories of some of the most notorious crimes in recent New York history -- Jean Harris, Mark David Chapman, Jack Henry Abbott, to name a few.
In fact, there are only a few. Only 10 cases have come before the New York State Crime Victims Board under the so-called Son of Sam law since it was enacted in 1977, and the Son of Sam case itself was not one of them. In all, the board has taken $134,000 from criminals and handed out $71,450 to victims. 
 "This is small-time stuff," said Angelo Petromelis, a member of the victims board. By comparison, he said, it distributed $12 million in 1990 alone to 11,125 crime victims not involved in Son of Sam cases.
The real issue, he said, "is whether the principle in social justice -- that people who commit these crimes should not be able to enrich themselves -- violates freedom of speech."
"That's what the Supreme Court is going to decide," Mr. Petromelis said.
 
Five Years in Escrow
 Contrary to popular perception, the Son of Sam law does not prohibit criminals from reaping profits from their stories. "The money is not confiscated," Mr. Petromelis said. "We hold the money in escrow until a civil court determines whether the criminal owes money to a victim." If no claims are upheld after five years, the money reverts to the criminal.
Of the 10 cases handled under the law, said Lorraine Felegy, the board's general counsel, three have involved relatively unknown criminals. "But the other seven are major cases," she said.
The case the Supreme Court has agreed to hear involves Henry Hill, a mobster who was paid for his story in "Wiseguy," a book written by Nicholas Pileggi that became the basis for the movie "Goodfellas." In 1987, after Simon & Schuster paid Mr. Hill more than $96,000, the victims board ruled that the money should go to the families of Mr. Hill's victims if any appeared to claim it. None have.
Two other cases are being adjudicated. One involves Jean Harris, who was convicted of murdering her lover, Dr. Herman Tarnower, the "Scarsdale Diet" doctor, and who wrote about it in "A Stranger in Two Worlds."
 
Sicilian Who Was Poisoned
 The other involves Michele Sindona, the Sicilian financier who was involved in the collapse of several banks and who was found dead of poisoning in prison in 1986. He had cooperated on a book, "Power on Earth," agreeing that payments would go to his son.
In the case of Mark David Chapman, the man who killed John Lennon, the board has placed in escrow $8,626 that Mr. Chapman received for a magazine article. "The only ones that could get a judgment, I think, are Lennon's son or his wife," Mr. Petromelis said.
The board has collected $15,818 from Jack Henry Abbott, who was convicted of stabbing a young actor to death outside an East Village restaurant in 1981. Mr. Abbott, who spent much of his life in prison, became a celebrated author after he wrote a book about his life, "In the Belly of the Beast." After the killing of Richard Adan, an actor and waiter at the restaurant, Mr. Abbott wrote another book, "My Return." Mr. Petromelis said the board was awaiting a final determination on damages in a suit brought by Mr. Adan's family.
No one has sought damages against R. Foster Winans, the former Wall Street Journal columnist who was convicted of inside trading and who wrote a book about it, 'Trading Secrets." But the board is holding $20,029 of Mr. Winans's money.
 
'Dog Day' Case
 The only case in which any victims have been paid involves John Wojtowicz, the bank robber portrayed in the movie, "Dog Day Afternoon."
"This was the very first case we collected on," Mr. Petromelis said. "We got $75,062. Of that, $20,000 was paid out to Robert Barrett, the bank manager.
"Then there were two tellers: Maureen Tosto, she got $15,000, and Santa Morello, she got $19,500," Mr. Petromelis continued. "Then his ex-wife was paid $16,950." Mr. Petromelis said the board has collected $14,411 more from continuing showings of the movie.
Paradoxically, the law has not been invoked in the Son of Sam case. When the law was written, it covered only convicted criminals. But David Berkowitz, the suspect in a series of murders that gripped New York City in the late 1970's, was declared mentally incompetent to stand trial.
"There was a book and approximately $120,000 that was to go to him," Ms. Felegy said. "Eventually, in 1987, a court ended up distributing the $120,000 to a number of the victims.
"That's what would have happened if we could have applied the statute," she added. Since then, the law has been amended to cover such cases.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Bridgestone Cuts

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: AKRON, Ohio

 BODY:
Bridgestone/Firestone Inc. said it plans to lay off 500 salaried workers, half of them at the company's Akron headquarters, because of slumping tire sales. The company also said it plans to leave 300 vacant jobs unfilled. The layoffs will reduce Bridgestone-Firestone's salaried staff in Akron to 1,500, down 25 percent in the past 18 months. The cuts are scheduled to take effect by June 30. There are 11,000 Bridgestone-Firestone white-collar employees nationwide and some 20,000 hourly workers.

HEADLINE: Surprise Gain At Hewlett: Stock Jumps

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 19

 BODY:
The Hewlett-Packard Company today reported unexpectedly strong earnings, attributing the gain to sales of new products and cost-cutting efforts. Analysts said the quarter's strong results could mark the end of a malaise gripping the computer company that last year prompted the return of its co-founder and chairman, David Packard, to active management.
The numbers were well above Wall Street analysts' estimates and sent the company's stock soaring $5.50, or 13.7 percent, to $45.625, on the New York Stock Exchange. The stock was the Big Board's third most active, with a volume of 2.7 million shares, and the percentage gain was within the top 10 for the day.
 
New Machines Due
 Analysts said the stock move also reflected anticipation that new line of computer work stations to be introduced soon would be owerful and competitive. 
 For its first fiscal quarter, ended Jan. 31, Hewlett-Packard reported earnings of $205 million, or 83 cents a share, up 18.4 percent from $173 million, or 72 cents a share, in the comparable period a year ago. Its revenues rose nearly 10 percent, to $3.4 billion from $3.1 billion.
"If you'd asked most analysts on the Street, they were expecting flat-to-down earnings," said Robert Herwick, an analyst with Hambrecht & Quist Inc. in San Francisco. "This is at least a dime's worth of surprise."
Hewlett-Packard, based in Palo Alto, Calif., said its sales gains were strong across all its major product lines, including large multi-user computers, work stations, personal computers and printers. Orders grew 12 percent over the first quarter of last year, to $3.7 billion. Domestic orders grew 3 percent, while those from outside the country grew 20 percent.
Besides the sales gains, Hewlett-Packard's bottom line benefited from reduced expenses. The company shut down for the December holidays and cut employment by 1,000 positions during the quarter through hiring controls and attrition. As a percentage of net revenues, operating expenses totaled 37.7 percent, compared with 38.8 percent.
"Our backlog increased by $300 million during the quarter, but we remain cautious in light of continuing economic and political uncertainties, including weakness in the U.S. economy," said John A. Young, the president and chief executive.
 
Testing Sun and I.B.M.
 Next month, Hewlett-Packard is expected to announce a new line of work stations based on RISC, or reduced instruction set computing, which will significantly outperform comparably priced machines from Sun Microsystems Inc. and the International Business Machines Corporation. Analysts say the new machines, whose prices will start at $12,000, will do much to regain market share for Hewlett-Packard from its rivals.
The new work stations "will signal that Hewlett-Packard is back and they're mad," said Mr. Herwick of Hambrecht & Quist. "Everything one hears about the performance of these new systems is amazing."
Rather than compete directly with Sun for the lowest price, Hewlett-Packard is likely to challenge its rivals on the basis of price for performance, said Russell Crabs, an analyst with the Soundview Financial Group in Stamford, Conn.
"The performance of these boxes will beat even I.B.M.," he said. "On a price-performance basis, they're going to look very inexpensive."

HEADLINE: Trying to Economize, New York Creates Its Own Alcatraz

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PINE CITY, N.Y., Feb. 14

 BODY:
On a broad, flat tract of land here along the drably named Institution Road, New York State is transforming a modern maximum-security prison into its own version of Alcatraz.
While hardly as escape proof as the Federal penitentiary on an island in San Francisco Bay was, the New York prison, Southport Correctional Facility, has the same mission: to take the worst prisoners. They will include those who have dealt drugs behind bars, attacked guards, even murdered inmates. At Southport, they are being kept isolated, shackled at the waist and wrists when allowed out of their 6-by-10-foot cells and made to spend their daily recreation hour in newly built cages. 
 Troublesome inmates in New York's 66 other prisons have usually been moved to wings of Spartan "special housing units," where all but their most basic privileges are removed. But since the beginning of this year, about 300 of these prisoners have been sent to Southport, a three-story, 798-cell prison about 50 miles west of Binghamton.
More are on the way, and state officials expect the transformation of the prison to be complete by April 1. Among the inmates will be 126 who are in protective custody because they are considered at risk from other inmates. As the new inmates are moved in, Southport's other inmates are being transferred to other prisons.
Civil libertarians criticize the absence of rehabilitation and strict limits on inmates' movement, like the use of cages and shackles, that they say will make the inmates more intransigent. But prison authorities say that special housing has long been used and that Southport simply consolidates that practice.
 
Sharply Different Mission
 Consolidating unruly inmates in one prison will save about $3 million a year in salaries at Southport, said James Flateau, a spokesman for the Correctional Services Department. He also said it would relieve pressure on overcrowded special-housing wards in other prisons.
When Southport opened in September 1988, it offered extensive classes and clean hallways under one roof. Now the staff, faced with a sharply different mission, is wrestling with the logistical puzzle of confining special-housing inmates.
"We're looking at a much more complicated situation," said Robert J. McClellan, Southport's superintendent. "We have been here seven days a week working on this."
 
Meals in Cells
 Southport was suited for the new use because of its recent design and extensive security features, the superintendent said.
Special-housing inmates are let out of their cells infrequently. At Southport, they leave the cells for showers twice a week, a haircut every few weeks and an occasional visit from the outside. Meals are delivered to inmates' cells. In a corner of the prison yard used for recreation, workers have been building cages. Some of the pens, measuring 16 by 8 feet, are for individ ual inmates to exercise in. Larger ones will be for up to four inmates.
Guards are receiving special instruction, Mr. McClellan said. "Every day the corrections officers will have to deal personally with inmates," he said.
"There will be a lot of one-on-one contact, or should I say, two-on-one contact, and the officer has to relate well with the inmates."
Since the program began, there have been more than a dozen cases of special-housing inmates throwing urine and feces at guards and there have been a couple of fights in the recreation pens, Mr. McClellan said. But he said there had been fewer problems than he had anticipated. To protect the guards from being pelted and sprayed, workers are installing plastic to cover the metal-mesh doors of the cells.
Southport ended its vocational and academic classes on Feb. 1, and the instructional wing is now being emptied of chairs, tables, chalkboards. The equipment and most of the teaching staff of 25 are being moved to nearby prisons. Three senior teachers have stayed at Southport. They spend their days going from cell to cell, dispensing books and briefly conducting lessons through the locked cell gates, always remaining outside them.
 
'It Had to Be Done'
 "This place used to be as clean as a hospital," one teacher being transferred remarked recently. "Now it's all torn up. It's sad."
Many workers said they were upset about being transferred but understand that the system needs such a prison. "It had to be done some place in the state, but it's unfortunate we got picked for the job," said Mike Woodhouse, who teaches a vocational class and is being moved to another prison.
Like the prison teachers, the chaplains plan to visit inmates cell by cell.
"I am not sure what it's going to prove," said Sister Josepha Twomey, a nun who is the prison's chaplain for Catholic inmates, "locking somebody up 23 hours a day, particularly for six months or a year or two years."
When the prison is completely converted to its new purpose, by April 1, the staff will have shrunk to 350 from 450, officials say. About 44 of the staff reductions will be corrections officers, all of whom have been transferred. While the dangerous inmates remain isolated, Southport's 126 inmates in protective custody are being given relatively more freedom than they might receive in a less-secure prison, officials say. These inmates are the ones now doing the jobs traditionally reserved for prisoners, like working in the kitchen and laundry.
It is this last feature that has prompted prisoners' rights advocates to term the program a mixed blessing. They praise the increased security for inmates in protective inmates but question whether the dangerous inmates can be rehabilitated.
 
'The Traditional Technique'
 Ed Koren of the American Civil Liberties Union's National Prison Project said grouping these prisoners might lead to more tension and confrontation with guards.
"As a separate facility it may be something new," Mr. Koren said, "but it's the traditional technique to segregate and isolate your problems. If you lock up a person for long periods of time, without any programs, you're not going to change his mind. You're going to leave them more embittered than when they came in."
Prison officials say they wonder if they will have enough staff to handle the inmates when the program is fully operating. They say, for example, that it takes seven minutes to shackle an inmate when he leaves his cell. That has not been a problem in winter, when few inmates care to brave the cold outside. The question, said Melvin Hollins, the first deputy superintendent, is "what will things be like on July 4?"

HEADLINE: Gas Is Nearing Pre-invasion Price

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
The price of gasoline at the pump is within a penny of where it was before the Persian Gulf crisis began in August, not counting tax increases, according to a survey released yesterday by the American Automobile Association.
According to the association, the price fell 2.9 cents last week, to $1.135 a gallon for unleaded regular self-serve. That is 6 cents a gallon higher than last summer's pre-invasion price. But Federal taxes rose 5 cents a gallon on Dec. 1. 
 The nationwide average price is also affected by tax increases by individual states. For example, Massachusetts raised its tax by 4 cents a gallon on Jan. 1, Delaware by 3 cents, Arizona by a cent and many Florida counties also raised their taxes.
 
Price Drops Likely to Continue
 The association declined to say that the drop last week actually put the price lower than what it was before the invasion, when tax increases are excluded. But Jerry Cheske, a spokesman, said the price was down in 8 of the last 10 weeks, and would probably fall again, holding out the likelihood that gasoline prices may sink below August's level.
Since the invasion, the peak price measured by the association in its weekly survey of 1,250 stations around the country was $1.387 a gallon on Dec. 4. That was one-tenth of a cent under the all-time peak recorded by the organization, just before the Easter holiday in 1981, during the oil shock brought on by the fall of the Shah of Iran.
Mr. Cheske said the recent fall in prices "goes against the perception that gas prices go up quickly and come down slowly." He added, "They are going down fairly rapidly now." He noted that prices usually declined around this time of year, but not as rapidly as they were now.
John H. Lichtblau, president of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation, said if the price today was numerically equal to the price in August, it was lower in real terms because inflation was running at 4 to 5 percent a year.
Mr. Lichtblau said that for consumers, the impact of the crisis "has been over for practical purposes for the last three or four weeks." He added: "I get this naive question, How come the prices only go up, they never go down? All you have to do is watch the prices at the pump; they clearly do go down."
And the price may go lower, he said, because crude supplies were ample, and after the war, "some oil from Iraq and Kuwait might come into the market, but not instantly."
In trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange, crude oil closed yesterday at $20.07, down 81 cents. Oil had traded in that range in July, and went above $41 a barrel in October. In contrast, gasoline's maximum increase was only about 30 percent.
 
Touchy Issue for Consumers
 Gasoline prices have been an exceptionally touchy point with the public. Another sensitive point has been oil company profits, which jumped sharply in the last quarter of 1990, mostly because the crude oil pumped from company wells was suddenly worth substantially more.
But not everyone is happy that pump prices have almost returned to August's level because prices at intermediate levels, and market shares, have changed. James G. Daskal, the general counsel of the Service Station Dealers of America, said his organization's 60,000 members had been through "the worst period for service station dealers since decontrol, in 1982."
Mr. Daskal said, and autombile association numbers confirm, that dealers were not able to pass through all of the 5-cent-a-gallon Federal tax increase on Dec. 1. In addition, Mr. Daskal said, the markups of dealers had thinned as prices rose, and were still in the range of 1 to 3 cents a gallon of unleaded, compared with 2 to 4 cents when the crisis began. Worse, he said, dealers make 10 cents a gallon or so on premium grades, but those sales "have just gone out the window," as motorists switched back to less expensive lower-octane fuel.

HEADLINE: Skinner Testifies on Airlines

BYLINE: REUTERS

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19

 BODY:
Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner said today that the nation's airline industry, rocked by huge debts, low traffic, rising fuel costs and recession, would remain competitive.
Despite pressure from the Congress and the industry, Mr. Skinner, in testimony before the Senate Commerce Committee, appeared to rule out any significant bailout for the troubled carriers. "Of one thing we are confident, consolidation is no grounds for panic," he said. 
 Mr. Skinner said the industry's financial difficulties had produced almost desperate marketing strategies by carriers and "some incredible air fare bargains."
But he said that unrealisticaly low prices were bad in the long run and that airlines must cover their costs or eventually go out of business.
So far this year, Eastern Airlines ceased operating, and Pan Am filed for bankruptcy protection.
Continental Airlines Holdings also is operating under bankruptcy protection, and Trans World Airlines has said it may be forced into Chapter 11.
Mr. Skinner told reporters that the Administration opposed a plan by some industry members to allow airlines to retain a 10 percent ticket tax.

HEADLINE: Amherst Journal;
Candles in the Snow Honor Suffering

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: AMHERST, Mass., Feb. 19

 BODY:
The vigil began here barely an hour after a man carrying a cardboard peace sign strode to the center of the town common on Monday afternoon, doused himself with paint thinner and perished in a plume of fire seconds after striking a match.
All day and all night in a snow that turned to freezing drizzle, people laid flowers, fruit and candles where the man died, and hundreds of students and townspeople turned out for a memorial service on the common this afternoon, even before the police had released the victim's name. 
 The public self-immolation of 30-year-old Gregory D. Levey, the third American known to have burned himself to death in apparent protest of United States policy in the Persian Gulf, would probably produce pity and bewilderment anywhere else. But here in a university town that has been a focal point for antiwar activities and other protests, it generated instant martyrdom.
Even as some of their fellow students berated them for glorifying the sorry deed of a disturbed individual, many people at the vigil said they hoped that his death would bring some cohesion to a protest movement that has floundered.
"This man said the war was wrong, and he made the ultimate sacrifice," Jennifer Cannon, a 22-year-old junior at the University of Massachusetts, said of Mr. Levey.
Mr. Levy, who graduated from UMass in 1984 with an English degree, worked sporadically as a substitute teacher in nearby South Hadley and had no known links to any local antiwar groups. A Hampshire College student, Aaron Fincke, who along with Ms. Cannon and several other students stayed up all night keeping candles lighted at the death site, said Mr. Levey's suicide was "more than just a rash act of someone on the edge."
"It was a moral outcry," he said.
The vigil in the cold here quickly became a blend of mourning and protest. Candles were passed among the crowd, Buddhist chants were recited, and signs reading "Stop This Crazy War" and "Talks Not Troops" were held aloft.
"There's no question about it, this poor soul overnight became a kind of a cult hero," said Timothy Banks, the owner of a shoe store across the street. "Nobody seems to really know a thing about him, but these kids have turned this man's death into a rallying point."
The events began shortly after 1:50 P.M. on Monday, when Mr. Levey, several witnesses said, quietly walked to the center of the common and began stuffing his shirt and pants with newspapers.
After dousing himself with the thinner, which the police said he had bought shortly before at a nearby hardware store, he lighted one match that went out, then a second that quickly ignited the thinner. He raised his arms once, then fell into the fetal position.
"It was just a lot of billowing black smoke," said Jeffrey Kittay of Rye, N.Y., who was visiting Amherst with a high-school-age son. "Several people, myself included, tried to put the fire out with our coats, but it just wasn't possible."
A police officer arrived a few minutes later and put out the fire with an extinguisher, but by that time Mr. Levey's torso was horribly burned.
"At first, it looked like one of those trash fires," said Ernie Follansbee, the manager of the shoe store across the street. "Then I got over there and I saw legs sticking out with argyle socks and loafers, and I said, 'My God, there was a human being in there.' "
Mr. Levey, who was the son of Robert Levey, the restaurant critic for The Boston Globe, and stepson of Ellen Goodman, a Globe columnist, lived by himself three blocks from where he died. Both his landlord and a work associate described him as deeply reclusive. The associate, Cecilia Buckley, said he had worked intermittently as a substitute teacher at a nonprofit agency that provides special-education services.
Mr. Levey's act reminded some of a Life magazine photograph of a Vietnamese Buddhist monk burning himself in protest during the Vietnam War. "But I think it has Christian elements as well," said Elizabeth Ahearn, who at 2 A.M. was holding a candle against the wind and rain. "You take upon yourself the pain of the world."
Others paid respect to the victim but did not approve of what he did. "To have a sign that says stop the killing and then go kill yourself doesn't make a lot of sense, does it?" said Gordon Fletcher-Howell, a Vietnam War veteran.
The two other incidents involving self-immolation in protest of the gulf conflict occurred in Northern California. At least eight Americans burned themselves to death in the Vietnam War-era protests.
There has not been unanimity about the gulf war. Indeed, a small group of Amherst student lined up at the edge of the common early today, singing "God Bless America" and "The Star-Spangled Banner" and urging support for President Bush.
An economics professor at UMass, Samuel Bowles, recalled the departure of a student who had been called up for duty in Saudi Arabia. The day he left, Professor Bowles asked him to stand in a lecture hall. "There was just an explosion of applause for him," Mr. Bowles said. "And this was in a class where if you asked for people's opinion on the war policy, I think that almost all would say they were opposed."

GRAPHIC: Photo: "This man said the war was wrong, and he made the ultimate sacrifice," said Jennifer Cannon, right, in Amherst, Mass., where a man burned himself to death to protest the war. She and Lisa Nelson took part in a vigil at the charred spot where Gregory D. Levey died. (Brooks Kraft for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Limited's Net Climbs 12.5%

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 19

 BODY:
Limited Inc. said today its fourth-quarter profits rose by 12.5 percent from a year earlier as sales increased 10.2 percent.
The specialty apparel retailer said it earned $172.2 million, or 48 cents a share, in the three months ended Feb. 2. That compared with $153.1 million, or 42 cents a share, a year earlier. 
 Sales increased to $1.74 billion from $1.58 billion a year ago.
Limited has fared better than other retailers whose earnings were hit hard by the recession and the Gulf War. Uncertain consumers have sharply curtailed their spending for clothes and other non-essentials.
Leslie H. Wexner, company chairman, said improved performances by the Victoria's Secret store and catalog operations and the Lane Bryant division were responsible for the company's higher earnings.
For the full year, the company earned $398.4 million, or $1.10 a share, up 14.6 percent, from $346.9 million, or 96 cents a share, the previous year.
Sales rose 13 percent to $5.25 billion from $4.65 billion a year ago.
Limited operates 3,864 specialty stores through Limited Stores, Lerner New York, Lane Bryant, Express, Victoria's Secret, Structure, Limited Too, Abercrombie & Fitch, Henri Bendel, Cacique, Victoria's Secret Bath Shops, Bath and Body Works, and Penhaligon's.
It also distributes apparel through the Victoria's Secret, Lane Bryant Direct, Roaman's and Lerner Direct catalogues.

HEADLINE: French Company Makes Bid Of $1.8 Billion for Square D

BYLINE: By ERIC N. BERG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Feb. 19

 BODY:
The Square D Company, a big electrical-equipment manufacturer that has been the object of much takeover speculation in recent months, said today that a French company had proposed acquiring it for roughly $1.8 billion.
Square D, based in Palatine, Ill., outside Chicago, made its announcement after the close of trading on the New York Stock Exchange, where Square D shares rose $1.75, to $52, compared with the bid of $78 a share. The stock is expected to open sharply higher on Wednesday, but whether it actually rises to $78 will depend on investors' perception of the chances that the bidder, Groupe Schneider, another giant electrical-equipment manufacturer, will succeed. 
 That remained unclear tonight. In a letter to Jerre L. Stead, Square D's chairman and chief executive, Groupe Schneider's chairman, Didier Pineau-Valencienne, asked that Square D directors consider the bid by March 1. In a statement, Square D said it would respond "in due course."
But the initial indication from Square D was that it would resist. Mr. Stead said in a statement that it was in the best interests of Square D's shareholders "to operate independently" and for Square D "to pursue its long-term strategic plan." Mr. Pineau-Valencienne, meanwhile, in his letter to Mr. Stead, indicated that the two companies had been talking for nearly two years and it was only because the talks had been unsuccessful that Groupe Schneider was now proceeding with a takeover proposal.
It was also unclear whether the offer was hostile. On the one hand, the offer was made despite the wish of Square D's senior management to remain independent. But Mr. Pineau-Valencienne said in a statement that his offer was contingent on Square D board approval and that his company was prepared to discuss "all aspects" of the proposal -- including, presumably, price. In a telephone interview from Paris, Mr. Pineau-Valencienne said, "We have made our proposal in a friendly way and we hope that our arguments will be looked at in a positive way by the board."
Still, analysts said that Groupe Schneider's $78-a-share proposal, which came in the form of the letter to Mr. Stead rather than through a formal tender offer, might be hard for Square D's directors to turn down. The analysts noted that the proposed takeover price represented a 50 percent premium over Square D's closing price today and that the company's stock had traded as low as $33 in the last year.
In Groupe Schneider's favor, Square D has not been doing well of late. Its operating earnings fell 9 percent in the fourth quarter, to $41 million. Full-year operating earnings dropped 12 percent, to $178 million. And sales have been flat. The company's results reflect the general slowdown in economic activity. As the economy has sunk into recession, factories have ordered less of Square D's automation equipment, and orders from utilities for Square D's electricl distribution gear have also slumped.
 
Ideal Combination Is Seen
 But Mr. Pineau-Valencienne said in the telephone interview that Square D and Groupe Schneider would make an ideal combination given the two companies' similar product lines and geographic fortes. Square D is a leading player in the electrical-equipment business in this country, whereas Groupe Schneider is a powerhouse in the same product markets in Europe.
At a time of increasing globalization in the electrical-equipment business -- Siemens and Westinghouse, for instance, have announced various cooperative ventures -- a combination of Square D with Groupe Schneider would create the world's largest maker of medium- and low-voltage distribution equipment. A Square D-Groupe Schneider combination would also have the No. 1 position in control devices for electro-mechanical automation equipment.
"It is an industrial proposal, not a financial proposal," Mr. Pineau-Valencienne said.
Although not well known among consumers, both companies are giants. Based in Paris, Groupe Schneider employs 80,000 people and reported sales in 1990 of 50 billion francs, or about $10 billion, and net income is expected to be around 930 million francs, or $186 million. Square D employs about 21,000 people and has sales of roughly $1.7 billion.

HEADLINE: Youth Critically Wounded at School

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr.

 BODY:
A 15-year-old boy waiting for his brother outside a Brooklyn school was shot in the head and critically wounded yesterday, the police said.
The youth, Antione Robinson, was taken to Brookdale Hospital, where he was in critical but stable condition last night and undergoing brain-scan tests, a hospital administrator, Frances Sasso, said. 
 The police last night charged a 14-year-old with attempted murder, assault and criminal possession of a weapon. They said Mr. Robinson was shot at 3:15 P.M. at the corner of Hull Street and Saratoga Avenue in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section, outside Junior High School 271.
Lieut. Eugene Albright, commander of the 73d Precinct homicide squad, said "one member of one group fired into the other group" as they faced each other about half a block apart. He said the groups of youths had had confrontations before.
Lying with a blood-soaked bandage around his head in the emergency room at Brookdale Hospital last night, the teen-age victim said he was shot as he tried to stop several youths from harassing his brother. He said he had not seen who shot him.
 
Joking in Emergency Room
 The youth talked to a reporter who had entered the room without permission of the hospital but identified himself to the youth and an uncle, who stood at the side of the gurney. The youth fell asleep from time to time but when awake, he spoke calmly and coherently and even joked at times with his uncle. As he talked, he fingered his intravenous tubes. He said he had lost feeling on his right side,
Mr. Robinson, who attends Boys and Girls High School and aspires to be an actor, said he tried every day to pick up his 12-year-old brother, Shaliek, because of the dangers at the junior high school.
"Kids start trouble and I don't want my brother to be in any of it," he said. "I try to pick him up every day."
Yesterday, he said, he left Boys and Girls with two friends to pick up Shaliek to play Nintendo's Captain Skyhawk video game at the red-brick apartment house where he lives with his mother, a sister and two brothers.
 
'These Guys Started Trouble'
 "I met up with them at the school and all these guys started trouble," he said. "They didn't want to take anything; they just wanted to fight. When I got there they were beefing with my brother.
"I walk up and said what's the beef? Next thing I know I'm shot."
The uncle, Michael Robinson, 33, who is unemployed, described Antione as a headstrong but decent young man. He said Antione felt a special responsibility toward his family because he is the oldest male. Antione's father died of a stroke two years ago, Mr. Robinson said.
"He's very determined," Mr. Robinson said. "He knows what he wants out of life. He wants what's best for his family, his brothers and sisters."
"I know what he's going through, he added. "I've been in here under similiar conditions myself. I got into a knife fight during a gang war."
He continued: "I just don't know about this world anymore. They send all our brothers and sisters overseas to fight in this war and they got the biggest war right here."
The gun used was not recovered. A spent 9-millimeter shell was discovered near the scene of the shooting, and investigators said they believed a 9-millimeter bullet hit the teen-ager.

HEADLINE: New Age (Relax!) Comes to Turbulent Poland

BYLINE: By GABRIELLE GLASER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WARSAW, Feb. 19

 BODY:
Edward Mielnik took a long draw on his Marlboro, sipped a cup of sweetened black coffee -- his third in an hour -- and told the crowd gathered at the International Center for People and Earth Renewal that their biggest problem was stress. "You all need to relax, to breathe better," he said.
Although its forum would hardly be recognizable in Marin County, the new age is dawning in Poland. While Poland has few hot tubs, new-age "guides," as they are called here, see their inspirational mission as particularly essential in a country where many are worried about the turbulent transition to capitalism. 
 "It is in these troubled times that people seek us," said Mr. Mielnik, who instructs about 100 people in "united relaxation therapy" each week.
"People are worried about their health, their futures, the future of the country, the problems of the Earth," said Mr. Mielnik, who does not count cigarettes or caffeine consumption among the threats he sees. Sitting at his desk beneath a portrait of the planet Saturn, he reached for a plate of chocolate eclairs kept for visitors. "We are a contact center for these people," he said. "That's why I'm here."
In the last few years, holistic healing centers, massage-therapy studios, gyms, natural-food stores, "breathing clinics" and other establishments intended to promote well-being have sprung up throughout the country.
Many who visit such centers, as well as those who run them, say the clinics offer solace to Poles who have broken with the Roman Catholic Church but still long for spirituality in their daily lives. Many believe that the treatments are a natural outgrowth of folk medicine, long a tradition in Poland and other Eastern European countries. Some say the interest in nowy wiek, as new age is called here, is another example of the growing influence of the West. American movies are shown in almost every Warsaw theater. There are fan clubs for Cable News Network broadcasters, who are seen a few minutes a day on Polish television.
Whatever the reason, the spread of new age is part of a national search for a cultural and social equilibrium. If the drab ways imposed by Soviet-style Communism are dead and buried, what next? While few here see the new-age activities as threatening, many worry that democracy will lead to a cultural invasion, a McDonaldization of Poland. And so Poles are now trying on various styles. Some will undoubtedly persist; others will be as forgotten as Marxist-Leninist political theory.
Anna Skowronska, a 31-year-old massage therapist in Warsaw, said that she had sought alternative styles of living for a decade, but that she had been hindered by the Government and the church before settling into her current profession a year ago. "Under Communism, to be different was unthinkable," she said. "And the church does not encourage people to be independent, so it has been kind of difficult."
More than 90 percent of Poles identify themselves as Catholic. The Roman Catholic Church has often been seen as the country's strongest center of power, and ever since Poland's first democratic government took office in June 1989, the church has exerted force in a number of ways. Last summer, it put pressure on the legislature to introduce voluntary religious education in public schools, and it has urged lawmakers to ban abortions, the country's most common form of birth control, in a vote expected later this year.
"In Poland in my lifetime there have been two forces: the Communist Party and the Catholic Church," Mrs. Skowronska said. "There was never room for anything else. Now there is, and I want to be a part of it."
There are few resources to which Poles can turn to sort out the difficulties of life here: the average monthly wage is $100 and while many consumer goods are now available, their prices are out of reach to many Poles. Inflation has risen about 200 percent over the past year.
Poland's alcoholism rate is among the highest in the world, and doctors say depression strikes a great number of people. Psychotherapy has yet to achieve the wide acceptance in Poland that it has in the United States.
Mr. Mielnik blames both Poland's former Communist regime and the Catholic Church for causing "neuroses" among his countrymen. "We help people draw positive energy from their inner selves and their environment to help neutralize the negatives," he said.
Agnieszka Kaminska is among those who swear by the new treatments available in Poland, and goes twice a week to work out and take breathing instructions at the "harmonizing gym" in a fashionable Warsaw neighborhood. Mrs. Kaminska, who is 30 years old, gave birth to her third baby in three years last November and hopes not only to lose some of the weight she put on but also to gain some peace of mind.
"Since I have been coming here I have fewer worries," she said as she stretched to the rhythms of airy flute music in the green gym. "I have learned to breathe better, to exhale some of my stresses. With three babies there is a lot of noise in the house."
Many Poles -- Government statistics say one in three -- have relatives living in the United States, mostly in Chicago and the Northeast. But California, many say, is the golden state of their dreams.
"We understand life isn't perfect in California," said Agata Rychlowicz, 24, a doctoral student in American Literature at Jagiellonian University in Cracow. "There is crime and poverty and earthquakes. But it still seems like a sunny place of enlightenment where people are happy."
Others, like Mrs. Skowronska, the massage therapist, have another theory.
"The Earth is divided between plus and minus, negative and positive," she said. "Poland is in between. In India, for instance, people are more interested in spiritual things than they are in material goods. In New York I think people want money more than they want calm. I'm not sure where California lies, but it must be like Poland, in an in-between zone."

HEADLINE: FOREIGN AFFAIRS;
Falling Short of Victory

BYLINE: By Leslie H. Gelb

 BODY:
Moscow is trying to do to the U.S. in the Persian Gulf in 1991 what Washington did to Britain and France in the Suez crisis of 1956. Then, these U.S. allies did not have the power to rebuff American demands for a cease-fire in the war against Nasser's Egypt. Today, the U.S. can resist Soviet pressures, and apparently has -- and should.
 President Eisenhower and Secretary of State Dulles prevented their allies from gaining a clear-cut military success and capitalizing on it. Nasser was thus salvaged as an Arab champion and transformed imminent military defeat into political victory. 
 President Bush is rightly reluctant to surrender his decisive military advantages in return for a muddy political settlement. Mikhail Gorbachev's proposal would require Iraq's withdrawal from Kuwait, but it would also unacceptably preserve Iraq's existing military power and protect Saddam Hussein's political position.
 The parallels between the Suez and gulf crises are by no means exact, yet they are remarkable.
 After a series of U.S. diplomatic blunders, Nasser nationalized the Suez Canal. Britain and France argued that this threatened their vital oil link to the gulf. They conceived a plan for Israel to attack Egypt and for them to intervene between the combatants as a cover to topple Nasser.
 Mr. Eisenhower recounted a letter from Anthony Eden, the British Prime Minister, as "equat[ing] any exercise of allied restraint and patience to the arguments that had prevailed during the rise of Hitler during the years prior to 1939" and arguing that Nasser's plan was to expand his power until he could "hold the Western world for ransom".
 Mr. Dulles maintained that European worries about being denied oil were "exaggerated." Ike rejected the Hitler analogy and argued that Nasser was essentially an Arab nationalist who symbolized "the desire for slapping the white man down."
 Mr. Eisenhower and Mr. Dulles couched their public statements in the language of anti-colonialism and international law. But what they really worried about was Moscow's exploitation of Arab nationalism to entrench itself in the Middle East. When push came to shove, they posed as defenders of Arab nationalism and forsook their allies to achieve the larger goal of containing Communism.
 Through the U.N., they forced their allies into an immediate cease-fire and an unconditional withdrawal. Had the allies and Israel been given a bit more time for military victory, and had they and the U.S. followed up with offers to mediate Arab-Israeli conflicts and promote economic development, the Middle East might have been spared its tempestuous future.
 Now, the Soviets say they want to prevent further bloodshed and the political upheavals that might attend a bloody end to the gulf war -- and remove Iraq from Kuwait. Those aims coincide with Washington's. But Moscow also seeks to enhance its role in the region by trying to limit sharply what the U.S. and its allies can demand of Saddam Hussein.
 Mr. Gorbachev keeps faith with Mr. Bush by pressing for immediate, complete and unconditional Iraqi departure from Kuwait. But apparently he would allow Iraq to leave with all its arms and thus permit Baghdad to remain an imminent threat to its neighbors.
 Mr. Gorbachev's proposal also apparently calls for the partial lifting of the U.N. economic embargo against Iraq. This would do nothing to guard against a renewed long-term threat from Iraq.
 After a cease-fire, the sanctions represent the coalition's only instrument to insure that Baghdad will have to destroy its nuclear, chemical and biological facilities and stockpiles. It is the only tool to make more difficult Iraq's manufacture and purchase of better long-range missiles.
 The point here is not that Mr. Bush should appear bloodthirsty and reject the Soviet ideas out of hand; rather he should do what he apparently has done, privately press Moscow to demand much more of Baghdad.
 Nor is the point that he should immediately launch a ground attack. The games now being played by Moscow, Teheran and Baghdad demonstrate the effectiveness of the current effort to bomb supply lines and troops and continue the blockade.
 The message is this: At the last Middle East crossroads, at Suez, Washington failed to fathom the clarifying effects of decisive victory and thereby missed an irretrievable opportunity to work for lasting security. For all the flack he may take, Mr. Bush sensibly seems to be avoiding that same mistake.

HEADLINE: A Shabby French Sulk

BYLINE: By Flora Lewis; Flora Lewis is senior columnist of The New York Times.

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
In much of Europe, the war in the gulf is increasingly called "the American war," despite the coalition of 28 states against Iraq. The careful consultation that brought international consensus is frittering away amid charges that it was all a manipulation by Washington.
This is a sign that Saddam Hussein's political war is spreading beyond the Arab world to U.S. allies, including those taking part in the military war. President Bush played into the perception that the U.S. is dragging others to obey America's will by refusing to consider negotiations. If Baghdad accepts Moscow's peace proposal, it will sharpen European criticism of Washington. 
 Soon after the invasion of Kuwait, word was spread among Arabs that it was all an American plot to justify U.S. hegemony in the gulf by force and long-term domination of the world's oil supply. The idea was that the U.S. deliberately provoked the crisis, setting a trap for Mr. Hussein, to guarantee American superpower status well into the 21st century, despite declining economic strength.
Now the same tale is coming from Europeans, especially in France, and from all sides. For example, Didier Motchane, a Socialist who has taken to open criticism of Francois Mitterrand since the resignation of Mr. Motchane's close friend Jean-Pierre Chevenement, as Minister of Defense, said, "France has accepted to help the U.S. restore a world domination that its economic situation no longer assured."
On the right, Jacques Chirac, the former Prime Minister, says the same thing, if in private, specifying that President Bush foresaw a mighty European economic power and a mighty Asian economic power 20 years from now, both without oil. So he set out to make control of oil America's equalizer. No doubt Mr. Bush would be pleased to hear somebody thinks his vision stretches 20 years ahead.
The Communists and far-right nationalists scarcely go further in their criticism. Part of this is the old anti-Americanism rising again, the Gaullist obsession with proving independence and, as politicians are insisting once more, making "France's difference heard."
The day news broke that Baghdad would withdraw from Kuwait, some television commentators rushed to predict that President Bush would reject a cease-fire even before they heard Mr. Hussein's unacceptable conditions. "And, of course," one predicted, "Britain will align itself completely with the U.S., as usual." It wasn't until a French correspondent in Washington came on the air that there was a reminder that "nobody is aligning with anybody; all have accepted the same U.N. mandate."
Part of the French sulk is the result of belated and irritated recognition that Germany has eclipsed France as a European power, even if it too is showing a boisterously revived anti-American minority.
CNN has added to the sense that it's an American war, not only because American force predominates but also because an American network is the major purveyor of everybody's information, with perhaps an unwitting American slant.
Above all, it is Washington's talk of a permanent U.S. presence in the gulf and Secretary of State James Baker's suggestion of a Middle East NATO, withdrawn but not forgotten, which fed the notion of an oppressive Pax Americana lying ahead.
It is true that without America's lead, Saddam Hussein's ambitions would have succeeded with impunity. It is also true that the U.S. never wanted to go it alone, and a perverse fantasy to say it sought the war. The European argument that the U.S. will derive all the "benefits" because it supplied most of the force is even more disgusting than refusal or reluctance to contribute to the sacrifice, which serves Europe's interest.
Washington needs more of the skillful diplomacy it showed at the start of the crisis. Europeans need to reconsider whether they want to put relations with the U.S. at stake to pursue internal feuds. Even their own ability to unite is damaged by demeaning attempts to shift the blame for the war as well as the burden.

HEADLINE: Rights Report Doesn't Condemn Algeria

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"A Gang of 6 at the U.N." (editorial, Feb. 7) demands the following comments:
You have most certainly not read the Human Rights Watch report that you characterize as "devastating" toward Algeria, one of "six flagrant rights abusers." I strongly suggest you read the report first. Or, you can also ask Human Rights Watch. It has visited Algeria very recently. It knows, and we know.
You accuse Algeria of having opposed the application for consultative status of Human Rights Watch. This is a lie. And here is the proof: Algeria is not even a member of the United Nations committee involved. It is simply an observer (just like the United States, Britain and about 20 other countries) and, as such, cannot participate in the committee's decision making.
Indeed, your editorial, and its reference to Algeria, was disinformation pure and simple.
It seems that you have targeted Algeria, which condemned the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait on the very day it took place, because it opposed the presence of foreign troops in the Persian Gulf region and the recourse to war, convinced that the crisis could have been solved through political and peaceful means within an Arab framework.
How vocal were you in denouncing real violations of human rights, such as the destruction of the entire economic, social and scientific infrastructure of Iraq and the ruthless and savage bombing of residential areas, causing thousands of casualties among the civilian population (and euphemistically referred to as "collateral damage"); the intolerable lot of the Palestinians in the occupied territories, who have lived in fear and hunger during the last three weeks of curfew imposed by Israel; the cynical Israeli assessment that it will take months to distribute gas masks to the Palestinians?
Do you not denounce these out of fear of tarnishing the image of a "moral, clean and just" war? Is it out of fear of tarnishing the image of a "peace-loving and restrained" Israel, the very Israel that assassinates with impunity the children and the women of the Palestinian uprising?
How then could there be a just and equitable new world order, when flagrant bias and double standards continue to prevail toward all Arab causes?
 
KAMAL KHARCHI
Press Assistant, Embassy of Algeria
Washington, Feb. 8, 1991
