HEADLINE: Raytheon Is Looking Beyond the Pentagon

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: Lexington, Mass.

 BODY:
The Raytheon Company, the maker of the highly successful Patriot missile-defense system and other sophisticated military hardware, has proved itself to be one of the most technically proficient and profitable Pentagon contractors. But it has yet to prove that in can make sustained profits on its more mundane products, like Caloric stoves.
In the wake of the Persian Gulf war, Raytheon stands to benefit substantially from new orders for the Patriot. But as one of only a handful of big Pentagon contractors that have diversified to reduce their dependence on military work, the company and its incoming chairman, Dennis J. Picard, see the best opportunities for long-term growth in the company's nonmilitary businesses, where profits have historically lagged behind the high-technology weapons operations.
 
Hodgepodge of Businesses
 With the Pentagon's budgets expected to continue declining for years, Mr. Picard will be focusing more of Raytheon's resources on improving the performance of the hodgepodge that makes up the rest of the company, including the Amana, Caloric and Speed Queen appliance brands, the Beech line of small aircraft, engineering companies that build and modify electric utilities and other big industrial projects and even a textbook publisher. 
 Mr. Picard hopes to increase the nonmilitary businesses to 50 percent of Raytheon's sales, from 40 percent now, while continuing to wring some growth from the few new Pentagon programs available. But his real challenge will be to bring the profitability of the commercial divisions -- including the money-losing appliance lines -- up to that of military business. Aggregate operating profits in the nonmilitary divisions last year were just 20 percent of the companywide total, despite representing twice that much in sales.
Operating profits in the electronics segment, which includes Raytheon's military business, rose 12.2 percent last year, to $667 million, and accounted for nearly 80 percent of the company's total operating profits.
"Given the environment we are in today, it pays to be a diversified company," said Steven Binder, an aerospace and military electronics analyst at Bear, Stearns & Company. "The defense budget will continue to be under pressure and there will be a continued decline in outlays. For a company like Raytheon, it's good to be in commercial businesses as long as they're yielding a good return on assets."
Besides the Patriot, which accounts for 12 percent of sales and is its largest single project, Raytheon manufactures a host of other missiles and electronic systems, making it the nation's second-largest supplier of military electronics, behind the General Motors Corporation's Hughes Aircraft Company.
Yet the bulk of the growth in the company's sales, which increased 5.4 percent last year, to $9.3 billion, came from the commercial businesses the company acquired in the last 25 years.
Some of the nonmilitary businesses have proved to be disappointing, and some analysts criticize the company for what they see as a lack of focus. Raytheon executives do not even try to establish that there is more than a token amount of synergy in the company's welter of holdings, but they do point to their increasing success at squeezing more profits from the nonmilitary divisions after years of lackluster performance in that area.
Operating profits at the Beech Aircraft Corporation continued a three-year recovery last year, rising 82 percent, to $80 million, while the engineering unit earned $49 million, up 58 percent. The only part of the company not to show improvement was the appliance business, which was hurt by the downturn in consumer spending, high operating costs and a one-time charge for closing an old plant. The appliance unit lost $8 million last year after earning $41 million the year before. Raytheon as a whole, however, had $557 million in profits last year, up from $529 million in 1989.
Today Raytheon faces an economy in which the engineering units are likely to continue doing well, the small-aircraft business is likely to be flat and the appliance business will remain under severe pressure. The bottom-line result, analysts said, will be a steady, if unspectacular, flow of profits to balance the military business both on the bottom line and on Wall Street, where investors have been shunning all but a few of the pure military contractors.
"Basically Raytheon has been able to sustain earnings growth over the long haul at high single-digit rates because of being diversified, and that's pretty good," said Howard Rubel, an analyst at C. J. Lawrence Inc.
 
Patriot's Success
 Raytheon can probably afford to be patient with its nonmilitary businesses for a few more years because its military work is likely to hold up quite well despite the precipitous decline in Pentagon spending. The Patriot's success alone will help keep the company's order books jammed.
Mr. Binder of Bear, Stearns estimated that the backlog of Patriot orders could reach $5 billion by the end of the year, up from $2.3 billion at the end of 1990, because of likely orders from Saudi Arabia, Israel, Turkey, Greece and other nations.
The Pentagon is wrapping up a five-year program of Patriot purchases, but the budget proposals sent to Congress by the Bush Administration earlier this month included additional financing that could benefit Raytheon. The Administration wants to spend $88 million for software upgrades for the Patriot. In addition it is ordering $140 million in new spare parts for the system, and the budget for the Strategic Defense Initiative contains $170 million for the study of an advanced version of the Patriot.
The architect of Raytheon's diversification was Thomas L. Phillips, an engineer who will retire on March 1 at age 66 after serving as chief executive since 1968. His successor, Mr. Picard, who is 58, is also a former missile engineer. Mr. Phillips and Mr. Picard declined requests for interviews.
 
Microwave Pioneer
 The diversification effort started in the mid-1960's, when Mr. Phillips was looking for a way to find a commercial market for Raytheon's expertise in microwave technology, an offshoot of the company's longstanding work in radar. (Executives still like to tell the story of the Raytheon engineer who discovered the cooking properties of microwaves in the late 1940's when he stood too close to a device called a magnetron and a candy bar in his breast pocket melted.)
Mr. Phillips's first gamble was to buy Amana, a top manufacturer of refrigerators, and to team Amana's appliance engineers with Raytheon's scientists. The result was the first consumer microwave oven, the Amana Radar-Range, which dominated the market for seven years until the mid-1970's, when Japanese and other foreign manufacturers came in with lower-priced products.
Most attempts by Pentagon contractors to diversify away from military products have been disastrous, as when the Grumman Corporation tried to build city buses or when the Boeing Company tried to break into the business of selling subway cars. Among big Pentagon suppliers, the Rockwell International Corporation is one of the few that has made the transition to primary reliance on nonmilitary products.
Despite its promising start with Amana, Raytheon's diversification, too, has had its share of problems. Take the acquisition of Beech in 1980 for $800 million. The deal seemed promising. Beech was a leader in the general aviation market -- the business of making small civilian planes.
But soon after the deal closed, demand for small planes among private buyers and commuter airlines plummeted. The market did not begin a recovery for eight years. Beech's profits all but evaporated until the last two years. The company's engineering units also had a difficult period during the 1980's, partly because of the problems faced by their customers in the petroleum and energy industries. Attempts to break into businesses like word-processing flopped.
 
Strong Outlook for Engineering
 Most analysts think the engineering units will show the highest growth rates in the next few years. The company's United Engineers subsidiary is aggressively competing for contracts to help reduce emissions from electric utilities, a business that is expanding rapidly.
Beech is more of a question mark. Mr. Rubel said the general aviation market had softened again after its modest rebound, largely because fewer companies are buying corporate aircraft. Beech is being helped by a contract to supply the Air Force with 211 of its Beechjet 400 for use in training tanker pilots. But even with that lift, Mr. Rubel said he sees Beech's profits doing no better than remaining flat in the next few years.
The appliance business is the biggest problem facing Raytheon. The largest company within its appliance segment is Amana, which is generally regarded as healthy, but the money-losing laggard in the appliance division is Caloric, which primarily makes electric and gas ranges.
Spurred by sluggish demand and high costs, Raytheon closed one Caloric factory last year, taking a $17.5 million charge in the third quarter. Raytheon is trying to reduce costs at Caloric and throughout the appliance division by modernizing plants and combining the Amana, Caloric and Speed Queen units as much as possible.
Raytheon's combined appliance lines, however, are only the fifth largest in an industry where market share and profits are increasingly concentrated in the top two or three brands, like Whirlpool and General Electric, and some analysts think Raytheon may one day sell out. For now, however, the company insists that it is committed to the business.

HEADLINE: Food Notes

BYLINE: By Florence Fabricant

 BODY:
Two Major Tastings
 The weekend of March 9 will keep wine buffs busy: two major California tastings are scheduled in New York. 
 The first will offer a sampling from more than 30 wineries, with an emphasis on wines from the Stags Leap area of the Napa Valley and wines made in California in the Rhone Valley style. Bread, cheese and pates will be served.
The tasting will run from 1 to 4 P.M. on Saturday, March 9, at La Cite Restaurant, 120 West 51st Street. Tickets are $35 if orders are received by March 1, and $40 per person at the door. Proceeds will benefit Share Our Strength, a group that raises money to feed the hungry. Checks should be sent to Bon Appetit Wine-Tasting Panel, 231 West 29th Street, Room 210, New York, N.Y. 10001. Telephone: (212) 268-7517.
On Sunday, March 10, more than 200 wines will be poured for sampling at the sixth annual View From the Vineyards at the Hotel Pierre, an extravaganza that also offers samplings of food from 25 restaurants and purveyors. Each winery will pour a recent release and an older vintage.
Among the restaurants represented this year are some newcomers like Hamersley's Bistro in Boston, Max's Grille in Miami and Windows on Urbanna Creek in Urbanna, Va. The guest of honor will be Julia Child.
Patrons and sponsors, categories that require purchases of multiple tickets, will be admitted starting at 4:30 P.M. Holders of general-admission tickets, which are $155 each, will be admitted after 6:15 P.M. The event lasts until 10 P.M. For tickets, call Shannon Phelan at (212) 421-3390. American Express cards are accepted. Tickets will not be sold at the door.
 
Mock Apple Pie Is Back
While the pundits debate the condition of the economy, 1,500 consumers a year have been clamoring for a recipe that is a holdover from the Depression. In response to their requests, the recipe for mock apple pie is back on boxes of Ritz crackers, after a 10-year hiatus.
The pie is made with cracker crumbs, water, sugar, lemon juice, cream of tartar, margarine and cinnamon. It contains no apples, yet it tastes something like apple pie. A spokeswoman for Nabisco Brands said that decades ago, apples were not as readily available out of season and those that were available were expensive, accounting for the popularity of the mock apple pie.
Actually, the recipe is a lot older than Ritz crackers. Pioneer families crossing the Great Plains in the 19th century also made pies like this when they ran out of fresh or dried apples, using apple juice or apple-cider vinegar in place of the lemon juice.
 
Food for the Philharmonic
The New York Philharmonic will hold its annual fund-raising Radiothon over WQXR on March 1-3. In this year's catalogue are dozens of food gifts, as well as dinners contributed by more than 100 restaurants. Food gifts range from a $10 jar of jam from Martha's Vineyard and to a $550 gift certificate at Zabar's. There is also a lime cheesecake made by a member of the orchestra.
The catalogue, from which gifts can be ordered before the Radiothon, is available by calling (212) 721-4900.
 
For Cookbook Collectors
A new spiral-bound book called "Just Cookbooks" by Mary-Margaret Barile (Heritage Publications, 1990) is a directory of source material for cookbook collectors and writers. It lists dealers, publishers, mail-order companies, suppliers of recipe software for computers, newsletters, auction houses, libraries and other resources. It is available for $10.95, including postage, from Heritage Publications, A21 Church Street, Arkville, N.Y. 12406. Telephone: (914) 586-3810.
This publisher also stocks a number of new and used regional cookbooks, and a free list of them is also available.
 
Fit to Eat? Perhaps Not
EIGHTY-FIVE percent of food-borne illnesses could be avoided if people handled food safely after buying it, the Centers for Disease Control say. To help consumers, the United States Department of Agriculture has just published a pamphlet called "A Quick Consumer Guide to Safe Food Handling."
The fold-out pamphlet provides tips on every step, including shopping, storage, preparation, cooking, serving and reheating. A chart shows how long various foods can be stored safely.
The free pamphlet can be obtained by writing to Safe Food, Consumer Information Center, 574-X, Pueblo, Colo. 81009.

HEADLINE: How Fed Chief Got War News

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20

 BODY:
On the night war broke out with Iraq, Jan. 16, most Americans were glued to their televison sets. Not Alan Greenspan. He got his news from his computer terminal. He remembered that night in his testimony today before the Senate Banking Committee.
"I recall vividly sitting by my computer screen on the night of the air attacks on Iraq," he said. "It became fairly clear at that point that the war would not evolve into a pattern which would create a major destruction of oil resources in the Middle East.
"And when that became apparent as the night evolved, you could basically see not only the price of oil coming down very sharply across the world, but you could see the effects minute by minute in the exchange markets, in the interest rate markets, in the gold markets, all arbitraged across and around the world."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends Day Mixed, But Rises Against Mark

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar ended mixed against leading currencies yesterday, but strengthened against the German mark after United States officials expressed concern about any further declines in the American currency.
The dollar finished at 1.4960 marks, up from 1.4935 on Tuesday. The dollar briefly rose above 1.5000 marks, but failed to stay above that level. 
 Dealers said the threat of an imminent ground war in the Persian Gulf helped pare the dollar's advance. Investors fear that a ground offensive may not be brief.
The dollar finished slightly lower against the Japanese yen yesterday, at 131.50 yen, down from 131.58 yen.
The Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, said in Congressional testimony that the dollar's recent weakness was unwelcome. He said a weak dollar could hurt the economy by pushing up long-term interest rates.
In addition, Treasury Under Secretary David C. Mulford said currency rates reflected economic fundamentals better now than in the past, a statement dealers took to mean the White House did not favor a further dollar drop.
"I think the U.S. Administration and the Fed don't want to devalue the dollar at all," said John Lyman of the Bank of Tokyo's office in New York. "We're starting to see a fair amount of verbal support of the dollar."
In morning trading, a rise of four-tenths of a percent in consumer prices last month lifted the dollar amid the belief that the Fed might be more reluctant to push down interest rates out of fear of fueling inflation. Lower rates, while helping to revive the economy, reduce the return on dollar-denominated investments.
The effect of the price data was muted, however, by a 12.8 percent plunge in housing starts in January, a drop that brought starts to their lowest level in nine years.
Meanwhile, traders awaited Iraq's response to a gulf peace plan presented by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union.
In other trading, the British pound closed at $1.9500, down slightly from $1.9505 Tuesday.
Against the Japanese currency, the dollar closed in New York at 131.43 yen, down from 131.58 on Tuesday.
The dollar closed at 1.2790 Swiss francs, up marginally from 1.2780, and at 5.0865 French francs, up from 5.0825 Tuesday.
On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold rose slightly, with bullion for February delivery settling at $364.70 an ounce, up 20 cents.

HEADLINE: Greenspan Sees Risks to Recovery

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, told Congress today that he expected a recovery from the recession to begin "reasonably soon." But he said the war with Iraq and questions about the health of the banking system and the availability of credit gave his forecast "an unusually high degree of uncertainty."
"It would be most unwise to rule out the possibility that the recession may become more serious than already is apparent," said Mr. Greenspan, the Government's most influential economic policy maker and leading forecaster. "Nonetheless," he continued, "the balance of forces does appear to suggest that this downturn could well prove shorter and shallower than most prior post-war recessions." 
 Mr. Greenspan was not asked about and did not comment on the Government's report today that consumer prices rose by four-tenths of a percent last month and by twice as much if energy and food prices were excluded from the calculation. But he said he expected the overall inflation rate this year to be lower than it has been for several years.
 
 Before Senate Panel
 Mr. Greenspan appeared before the Senate Banking Committee, as he is required by law to do twice a year, to discuss monetary policy and the state of the economy.
Sometimes in these appearances, it is possible to decipher the Federal Reserve's intentions about raising or lowering interest rates. But Mr. Greenspan carefully avoided such hints today, implying that he was genuinely unsure which way the economy would turn and thus which way the Fed should step.
"The major mistakes in monetary policy are often made at turning points, and it is very difficult to avoid them," he said at one point. And toward the end of the hearing, he declared: "I have been very purposefully slightly evasive so as not to be able to leave such conclusions one way or another, because I do think it is important that we not be in a position where we cannot be responding to continuous data as it emerges over time."
One interpretation of his remarks is that the Fed plans to stand pat for at least several weeks to give the interest rate reductions of late last year and early this year time to work their way through the economy. Mr. Greenspan did say, however, that the reduced threat of inflation gave the Fed the flexibility to lower rates if that should prove necessary. And he took issue with economists who argue that the Fed's hands were tied by the scarcity of credit and other current economic conditions.
 
Consensus Forecast Issued

Along with his testimony, Mr. Greenspan released the consensus forecast for 1991 by the Federal Reserve Board governors and the presidents of the regional Federal Reserve banks. They expect the gross national product, adjusted for inflation, to rise between three-fourths of a percent and 1.5 percent; inflation, as measured by the Consumer Price Index, to rise between 3.25 percent and 4 percent, and the unemployment rate in the fourth quarter to be 6.5 percent to 7 percent.
Those ranges are similar to the predictions of the Bush Administration, the Congressional Budget Office and many private economists. The Administration, for example, has predicted that the G.N.P. will rise by nine-tenths of a percent, that prices will rise 4.3 percent and that the unemployment rate in the fourth quarter will be 6.6 percent.
Last year, the G.N.P. rose three-tenths of 1 percent, the Consumer Price Index rose 6.1 percent and the unemployment rate in the fourth quarter was 5.9 percent.
Mr. Greenspan said the recent drop in oil prices, the decline in interest rates, the high level of exports and the lean inventories in most businesses enhanced the chances of economic recovery soon. "Indeed," he said, "there is some possibility that once the economy turns around, the expansion could become fairly robust."
On the other hand, he said, "downside risks are obviously there and not difficult to identify."
 
Worry on Credit Crunch

Mr. Greenspan said that "an extended war with Iraq" could undercut public confidence and spending, and he worried aloud about the Fed's inability so far to relieve what he repeatedly called the credit crunch, or the reluctance of banks to lend money even to relatively creditworthy ventures.
"We are looking at the credit crunch as being the most critical thing that confronts monetary policy at this particular stage," he said, and he promised that "we will continue to move against the credit crunch until it gets resolved."
Mr. Greenspan declined to say what those moves would be, although he said one step could come in the next few days when bank supervisors from the Fed and other Government agencies issue new regulatory guidelines that could improve bank profits. One of those regulations, he suggested, would change the way real estate collateral is recorded on banks' books.
The chairman did seem to rule out a further reduction in the percentage of deposits that banks must hold in reserve in cash or interest-free at regional Federal Reserve banks. Recent experience has shown, he said, that banks need reserves at the current level to cover day-to-day transactions. But he advocated, as he has done many times before, a change in the law so that interest could be paid on bank reserves.
 
His Role on Panel

On another matter, Mr. Greenspan seemed to have little inkling of what President Bush meant when he announced in his State of the Union Message last month that Mr. Greenspan, who has long advocated abolition of the capital gains tax, would head a commission to study "technical differences" between the White House and Congress over capital gains.
The announcement was widely seen here as an effort by the President to get the capital gains issue out of the political news this year.
"I'm awaiting the views of the President, the Administration and the bipartisan leadership of the Congress with respect to what type of assignment they would like us to pursue," Mr. Greenspan said.

HEADLINE: Legislator Offers Option on Taxes And School Subsidy in New Jersey

BYLINE: By PETER KERR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Feb. 20

 BODY:
The Speaker of the New Jersey Assembly, Joseph V. Doria Jr., today unveiled a plan to revise Gov. Jim Florio's education and property tax program to shift money from school aid to property tax relief for homeowners.
The plan, which calls for moving $244 million from school aid to tax relief, differs substantially from a proposal put forward last month by the president of the State Senate to shift $395 million into property tax relief from the $1.1 billion in increased school-aid that Mr. Florio pushed through the Legislature last year. 
 The Assembly plan would not offer direct property tax relief to commericial and industrial property taxpayers, as the Senate plan would, and the Assembly plan would lapse after two years, in constrast with the Senate proposal, which would be permanent. Most important, perhaps, it protects most of Mr. Florio's planned aid to poorer school districts.
"Philosophically, this is a very different approach," Mr. Doria said when asked how he differed with his fellow Democrats in the Senate. "The Senate plan is based on the belief that property tax relief is a priority and education is secondary."
 
Seeking Compromise
 The Governor and the leaders of the Assembly and the Senate, who are all Democrats, are now under intense pressure to come up with a compromise program in the next week so that Trenton can tell the state's 587 school districts how much shool aid they will receive and permit them to draft budgets for the 1991-92 school year.
But the Senate president, John A. Lynch, immediately attacked the Assembly plan as not going far enough to ease the plight of homeowners.
Senate Democratic leaders have said privately that they believe Mr. Doria's proposal represents the Governor's position.
At issue is exactly how far the three men will go to revise the Quality Education Act, which was enacted to raise $1.3 billion from income taxes on more affluent New Jerseyans and use it to aid poorer school districts and relieve the rising property taxes of middle-income homeowners.
All three men embraced the Florio package before it was passed last spring, but after the public reacted angrily last fall they agreed that the education act should be revised.
Mr. Lynch has argued, angrily at times, that Democrats should give top priority to relieving the plight of middle-income voters in time for legislative elections next fall. Mr. Doria and Mr. Florio both wish to defend large increases in aid to poorer school districts, which they say have long suffered unfair treatment under the state's tax system.
In a news conference today Mr. Doria, together with the Democratic majority leader of the Assembly, Wayne R. Bryant, described their plan, which includes these points:
*The $244 million in property tax relief would be distributed to residential property owners in the form of a tax credit; all homeowners in a single municipality would receive a credit of the same amount.
*Most of the money for property tax relief would be taken from the transition aid now designated to help affluent districts as they lose state aid in the next five years. Under the Lynch plan, increased property tax relief would come in part from reducing school aid to poorer districts.
*The Doria plan would impose "floating caps" on how much most school districts could increase their budgets, ranging between 7.5 percent and 9.2 percent, except for the 30 poorest districts. The Lynch plan would impose an 8.5 percent cap on increased district spending, except in the poorest districts, where the cap would be 13.5 percent.
The Assembly proposal would also revise the Quality Education Act to continue state support for teachers' pensions for two years. Mr. Florio's plan last year included the shifting of pension costs from the state to school districts, a move that enraged school administrators and the New Jersey Education Association, the state teachers' union, which is a powerful force in Democratic politics.
But the Senate president had little positive to say about the Assembly plan, reflecting, politicians here said, the growing philosophical and political divide between Mr. Lynch and Mr. Doria. "The plan appears to be strongly weighted in favor of the urban centers at the expense of the suburbs," Mr. Lynch said. "I must say the plan leaves me disappointed."
Mr. Lynch said he was particularly disturbed that the Doria plan placed less stringent limits on school district spending than his plan, and that the property-tax relief would be financed for only two years. In addition, Mr. Lynch said that Mr. Doria's decision to provide property-tax relief to homeowners but not businesses might violate the State Constitution.
"It discriminates against large and small business owners who are also fighting to survive during these tough economic times," Mr. Lynch said.
Closed-door meetings are expected between Assembly and Senate leaders through the weekend. Legislators and aides to the Governor say that if an agreement is not reached by the first week of March widespread disarray at the state's school districts, which are waiting to prepare their budgets, would be politically damaging to all Democrats in Trenton.

HEADLINE: Federal Regulators Tell New England Governors of Plans to Help Banks

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NASHUA, N.H., Feb. 20

 BODY:
Federal banking regulators told a meeting of New England governors, bankers and business executives today that new accounting rules to benefit banks would be announced within a week.
L. William Seidman, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, also told those attending the New England Governors Conference here that he was considering helping banks by making direct investments of F.D.I.C. capital. 
 Robert R. Glauber, Under Secretary of the Treasury, said the new accounting proposals would include provisions that place more emphasis in real estate appraisals on the income produced from a property and its long-term prospects rather than the deeply depressed price at which the property could be sold in the current market.
The appraisal issue is important to banks because the value of many of their loans for commercial real estate projects depends on the value of the projects backing those loans.
Banking regulators also proposed to allow banks to "split" bad loans into two parts, if accountants and the Securities and Exchange Commission agree. Part of such loans could be written off as losses, while the remainder, which could pay full interest and be backed by sound collateral, could be included in the banks' financial statements as good loans.
Currently, all of a troubled loan paying partial interest or with collateral worth less than the loan is reported as "nonperforming," meaning that it is delinquent by 90 days or more or so troubled that repayment in full is not expected.
Such changes would be welcome news for political leaders in New England, who have complained that excessively harsh treatment of banks by regulators was pushing the region deeper into recession by causing banks to cut back their lending.
"There is a tremendous amount of fear among bankers about examiners and how loans will be treated," said Robert V. Wilkie, an official at the Sugar River Savings Bank in New Hampshire. "I hope to see some change to standards that are not so harsh."
James B. O'Brien, head of commercial real estate in the Boston office of Coldwell Banker, said, "The accounting changes and changes in appraisal practices will help." He added that "without some changes, the banks in this area would face huge loan write-offs" in coming months.
On the proposal for the F.D.I.C. to make direct investments in banks, Mr. Seidman said that although there was no need for a national program for such investments, there were some cases where they could be less expensive for the deposit insurance fund than closing institutions.
Gov. Judd Gregg of New Hampshire said his state was exploring an idea under which several of its weakest banks would agree to a merger, greatly reducing their costs and possibly increasing their ability to attract private capital to supplement any investment from the F.D.I.C.
Lawrence Connell, chairman of the New Hampshire Savings Bank, an insolvent bank that is also the largest savings institution in the state, said his bank was exploring many ways to raise capital and that merely cutting costs was not enough.
"Bankers in the region are realizing that consolidation is necessary," Mr. Connell said.
Mr. Seidman declined to comment on the idea for New Hampshire banks, but he warned that in general "assistance from the F.D.I.C. is not a way to save the shareholders of those banks." Nor, he added, does the F.D.I.C. see potential investments in banks as a tool for regional economic development.
Mr. Seidman said the F.D.I.C. had enough money for a few investments in banks, but that a recapitalization of the deposit insurance fund would be needed for any broad-based program of such investments.
The F.D.I.C., which has about $8 billion in its bank deposit insuance fund, has been meeting with banking leaders to develop a plan to raise more money for the fund. It does not want to rely on taxpayer funds to pay losses at failed banks.
Ira Stepanian, chairman of the Bank of Boston Corporation, the largest banking company in the region, said capital investments by the Federal Government would probably not be needed if the industry moved ahead with mergers and consolidations, which would reduce costs. With lower costs and more profit, he said, the remaining banks could accumulate and attract the capital needed to be more active lenders.
Mr. Stepanian said regulators should encourage the consolidation of the industry when they select a buyer or buyers for the Bank of New England and its affiliates. Since that bank was seized by the Government in early January, the Bank of Boston has emerged as a bidder in competition with several companies not in the region, like the Banc One Corporation of Columbus, Ohio, and the BankAmerica Corporation of San Francisco.
Selling the Bank of New England to an out-of-region buyer would not necessarily lead to more lending in the local market, Mr. Stepanian said, and would not solve the fundamental problem of too many banks chasing too few customers. A local buyer is better, he said, because it would allow for reduced costs, which would make more money available for lending in the local market.

HEADLINE: Metro Matters;
Better to Call The Melting Pot A Motley Quilt

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
Census figures to be released today are all but certain to confirm an epochal demographic shift: For the first time in nearly four centuries, non-Hispanic whites no longer constitute a majority in New York City.
Visions of Newark or Detroit? Typically, the changing complexion of America's cities has provoked a hue and cry among some indigenous whites when a tipping point pivoted them into a racial minority. Some felt vulnerable and fled -- hastening the quiet evolution that produced the change in the first place. 
 But New York may be less likely to mirror those cities where a single racial or ethnic group emerged as the new majority. In contrast, New York -- despite or perhaps because of its preoccupation with race and ethnicity -- may simply become more cosmopolitan.
"The truth is," says Louis Winnick, an urban analyst, "New York City has become a polity without a clear-cut ethnic majority."
Mayor David N. Dinkins's metaphorical mosaic is no tile of two cities. The minorities that now collectively constitute a majority are striking in their diversity. Because they are not monolithic, they may seem less threatening to whites than they were once perceived to be, when unscrupulous real-estate brokers and others profited from racial conflict (although many whites may still feel more comfortable with Asian immigrants than with American blacks).
"The social distance between Jamaicans and Haitians, and of both from native blacks, is considerable and is comparable to the distance between Soviet Jews in Brighton Beach and Hasidic Jews in Williamsburg," said Mr. Winnick, whose book, "New People in Old Neighborhoods," chronicles another Brooklyn community.
By that definition, all New Yorkers are members of minorities, which is how it has been for hundreds of years. The Dutch replaced the Indians, and then the British predominated until the mid-1800's, followed by Irish, Germans, Jews and Italians, all of whom, though white, were no more homogenous than thesuccession of non-white immigrants. (Imagine how some white Anglo-Saxon Protestants greeted 19th-century census figures that proclaimed the ascension of Catholics and Jews.)
 The 1990 census documents a fundamental shift that began decades ago and that was affected by migration and fertility rates. Together, blacks and growing numbers of Asian and Hispanic New Yorkers probably became a majority in the mid-1980's.
What does this mean? Among many whites, Mr. Winnick said, "there's an unspoken thought that something ominous is happening."
"The fear is that people think New York will become one big Harlem, but it won't," he said."The real worry is not the ratio, but the objective things: education, crime, jobs."
Growing numbers of black and Hispanic New Yorkers have climbed into the middle class, but black and Hispanic unemployment and dependency have been higher than with non-Hispanic whites. Celebrating or tolerating diversity may be difficult when many people are still unable to reconcile differences between blacks and whites, even before Asian and Hispanic New Yorkers complicate the equation.
"A lot of whites are simply not comfortable sending their children to a school where the predominant number of students is not of the same group as they are," said Charles V. Hamilton, a Columbia University professor of government. "That will also be reflected in neighborhoods, because people simply don't feel as comfortable living in communities where they are in the minority." Angelo Falcon, president of the Institute for Puerto Rican Policy, agreed that many white New Yorkers seem to feel "besieged by people of color."
In 1989, Mr. Dinkins was elected the city's first black mayor by a coalition of minorities, organized labor and progressive whites. The political power of black, Hispanic and Asian New Yorkers will be tested again this year in special elections for an expanded City Council. But for the time being, the latest census figures may count for less than meets the eye.
Years ago, Nathan Glazer and Daniel P. Moynihan wrote in "Beyond the Melting Pot" that "the classic heterogeneity of great cities has been limited to the elite part of the population," but "the heterogeneity of New York is of the masses." If that remains largely true, it means that most power is still wielded by whites.
"New York, the most powerful center of communications and finance in the world, will not experience a major social transformation," the sociologist William Julius Wilsonsaid yesterday. "People should not view these changes with alarm."

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Money Funds Mixed, Ending 5-Week Drop

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields of money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were mixed for the week ended yesterday, after five straight weeks in which yields declined.
Money fund yields continued to weaken, reflecting falling rates in the general money market, analysts at Donoghue's said. Over the next month or so, rates on the short end of the market will be influenced by the performance of the economy, they said. 
 Walter S. Frank, Donoghue's chief economist, said the Fed had done all it was going to do for now in pushing down short-term interest rates and would wait for the next round of economic data and the impact of its last credit easing. He said he expected yields to flatten over the next few weeks.
Tax-exempt money funds this week show the average number of days that securities were held in portfolios was unchanged at 49 days. Assets increased $80 million, to $91.3 billion.
The average seven-day compounded yield for the week fell 15 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 4.22 percent, while the 30-day compounded average yield fell 9 basis points, to 4.51 percent.
The taxable equivalent of the current seven-day tax-exempt yield is 5.86 in the 28 percent tax bracket, and 6.29 percent in the 33 percent bracket.
Of the tax-exempt funds with assets of more than $100 million monitored by IBC/Donoghue's, the USAA Tax Exempt Money Market fund produced the best return on investment for the third consecutive week, with a yield of 5.46 percent. The fund is managed by the USAA Investment Management Company of San Antonio.
Assets on taxable funds rose $3.5 billion, up from last week's $2 billion, to a record $451.3 billion. Consumer fund assets received almost the whole inflow of cash, $3 billion, for a total of $340 billion, while institutional fund assets rose $500 million, to a total of $111.3 billion. About $1 billion of the new money went into Government and Government agency securities, with the remaining $2 billion among all the other funds.
The average seven-day compounded taxable yield rose by 11 basis points, to 6.56 percent, while the 30-day fell 11 basis points, to 6.79 percent. A new fund, American Performance Cash Management, paid the best return on investment this week, with a yield of 8.42 percent. The fund is managed by AMR Investment Services of Dallas.
By comparison, Bank money market accounts, which compete with the money funds and are included in The Bank Rate Monitor national index, showed the average rate of return at 5.65 percent, down 4 basis points from last week.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Weather and War Reports Push Oil Up at Least 41 Cents

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Oil futures prices were driven higher on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday by forecasts of colder weather in Europe and reports that American-led forces were poised to begin a ground war to drive Iraqi forces from Kuwait.
Crude oil futures settled 41 cents to 76 cents higher in New York. The contract for delivery in March expired at $20.48 a barrel, 41 cents higher than Tuesday's close, and the April contract, which now moves into the near-term delivery slot, closed at $19.55 a barrel, up 76 cents. 
 Wholesale home heating oil futures finished 0.81 cent to 4.09 cents higher, with March at 64.72 cents a gallon, and unleaded gasoline was 1.3 cents to 2.08 cents higher, with March at 60.72 cents a gallon. But natural gas was unchanged to 2.5 cents lower, with April at $1.355 per 1,000 cubic feet.
The rally was led by heating oil, which rose sharply in line with home heating oil prices in London amid forecasts for a return to unusually cold temperatures in Europe.
Lack of movement on the Soviet Union's plan to resolve the Persian Gulf crisis also supported oil futures when Iraq did not immediately respond to the Soviet proposal.
"A lot of people were thinking there was a strong likelihood we were going to see some sort of peace proposal that was going to be a factor," said Peter Beutel, energy director of the Pegasus Econometric Group in Hoboken, N.J.
On the Chicago Board of Trade, grain and soybean futures prices fell slightly, reflecting increased chances for rain in a leading Brazilian soybean area and disappointment over a lack of grain sales to the Soviet Union.
Wheat futures finished 1 1/2 cents to 2 cents lower, with March at $2.52 1/2 a bushel; corn was 3/4 cent to 1 1/4 cents lower, with March at $2.39 a bushel; oats were unchanged to 1 cent lower, with March at $1.08 1/4 a bushel, and soybeans were 1 1/2 cents to 5 cents lower, with March at $5.73 1/4 a bushel.
On the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, cattle futures rose on reports of cash prices and strong retail beef demand. But pork futures retreated.
Live cattle were 0.05 cent to 0.50 cent higher, with February at 79.62 cents a pound; feeder cattle were 0.15 cent to 0.30 cent higher, with March at 89.02 cents a pound; live cattle were 0.20 cent lower to 0.02 cent higher, with February at 51.85 cents a pound, and frozen pork bellies were 0.03 cent to 0.50 cent lower, with February at 64.25 cents a pound.

HEADLINE: U.S. Says Most of Growth in 80's Was in Major Metropolitan Areas

BYLINE: By EDWARD B. FISKE

 BODY:
The nation's flirtation with a return to rural areas in the 1970's ended abruptly in the 1980's, as 90 percent of the decade's population growth occurred in metropolitan areas of more than one million people, the Census Bureau reported yesterday.
Figures from the 1990 census show that for the first time, a majority of Americans, 50.2 percent, live in these large metropolitan areas, as against 45.9 percent in 1980. 
 "We are a country not only of city dwellers, which we have been, but of large-city dwellers, a country of metropolitan-dwellers," said Richard Forstall, chief of the bureau's population distribution branch.
The New York metropolitan area remained the country's largest, with 18,087,251 people, up 547,719, or 3.1 percent, from 1980. The Los Angeles metropolitan area, with 14,531,529 people, remained second, but narrowed the gap by adding 3,033,980 people, for a gain of 26.4 percent over the decade.
 
Growth in Sun Belt
 Most of the other big gainers were in the Sun Belt. Orlando, Fla., was up by 53.3 percent, Phoenix by 40.6 percent, San Diego by 34.2 percent, Dallas-Fort Worth by 32.6 percent and Atlanta by 32.5 percent.
Across the country the pattern was for metropolitan areas to grow fastest on their fringes, where land was plentiful and housing less expensive. Many central cities stabilized or even grew in population during the decade, but were still smaller parts of their metropolitan areas.
The figures released yesterday were from the Census Bureau's list of 284 metropolitan statistical areas, defined as urban cores of at least 50,000 people and the surrounding communities that are dependent on them economically, socially and culturally.
The New York metropolitan area, for example, consists of not only New York City, Long Island, and the lower Hudson Valley, but also northern New Jersey and Fairfield County, Conn.
 
Half Live in 39 Areas
 The bureau said 77.5 percent of the country's 249,632,692 million people now live in metropolitan areas, up from 76.2 percent in 1980. And nearly 125 million people live in the 39 metropolitan areas with more than one million people.
In the 1980's, metropolitan areas grew by 11.6 percent, while non-metropolitan ones increased by only 3.9 per cent.
This constituted a reversal of the pattern in the 1970's, when non-metropolitan areas grew by 15.1 percent and metropolitan areas by only 10.2 percent.
Margery Turner, a senior research associate at the Urban Institute, a private research organization in Washington, said the popularity of rural areas in the 1970's reflected economic trends, like increased mining and oil drilling in the Southwest. Likewise, the return to urban areas in the 80's is a product of new economic trends.
"The growth of the big metropolitan areas reflects the shift in the economy from manufacturing to service industries, especially those involving communications and information," she said.
 
Some Cities Decline
 Carl Haub, a demographer at the Population Reference Bureau, another Washington research organization, noted that the rapid growth of metropolitan areas was not tantamount to a resurgence of population in core cities. To the contrary, many cities, like De troit, actually lost population during the 1980's.
"What you're seeing is a metropolitanizing phenomenon," he said. "Instead of a single city sitting like a hub with spokes going out in all directions to people who are dependent on it, you're seeing a lot of satellite cities. They are related to the older city, but they are also employment centers in their own right, and they relate to each other as well as to the core city."
Such a pattern is well established in the Northeast, where "satellite" cities like White Plains or Danbury are plentiful around New York.
"It's a newer phenomenon in the Sun Belt," he said. Much of the growth of Phoenix, for example, was the result of ballooning population in adjacent towns like Tempe and Scottsdale.
 
4 More Areas Added
 The Census Bureau redefines its metropolitan statistical areas after each census; the figures for 1980 are for the redefines areas. In 1980 four new areas were added: Charlotte, N.C; Salt Lake City; Orlando, and Rochester. Charlotte achieved metropolitan status then because of annexation of new areas, but the others did so through population growth.
Florida dominated the list of most rapidly growing metropolitan areas during the 1980's. Naples recorded the largest increase: 77 percent. In addition to Orlando, other big gainers included Fort Pierce, up 66 percent; Fort Myers, up 63 percent; Ocala, up 59 percent; and West Palm Beach, up 50 percent.
In many cases immigration was a major factor in the growth of metropolitan areas, though the nature of this immigration differed.
Jeff Passel, a researcher at the Urban Institute, noted that California registered a net increase of 3.2 million newcomers during the decade and that 2.3 million were from other countries. By contrast, 2.3 million of Florida's 2.8 million newcomers came from other states. "Places like Orlando are not a major destination for immigrants," he said.
Five metropolitan areas with more than one million residents lost population during the 1980's. Four were centered upon aging industrial cities, Detroit, Cleveland, Pittsburg and Buffalo, while the fifth, New Orleans, suffered from the economic downturn of the oil industry.

HEADLINE: Cuomo Turning Budget Gap Into Tool to Sell Policy Shifts

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Feb. 20

 BODY:
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, doing his best to squeeze oratorical lemonade from fiscal lemons, has been speaking often these days about the "opportunities" afforded by the state's $6 billion budget gap. The state, he reasons with relish, must "reform, refocus and renew" its policies and priorities.
 Those who endorse Mr. Cuomo's plans to cut costs through initiatives like closing psychiatric hospitals and loosening sentencing laws are applauding the policy shifts. But they are asking a question that is central to Albany politics: what took so long?If carried out in the past, many of Mr. Cuomo's proposals might have softened some of this year's pain, the critics contend. But the bounty of the last half-decade never offered state leaders the political imperative -- some have called it the political cover -- to push for or accept unpopular proposals. 
 Now, in a year when money must be saved in every nook of the state budget, a sensitive change in political direction can be sold more as a cost-cutting device than a shift in policy.
"This fiscal crisis gives the Governor a better chance to fight for these changes because it gives him the ability to ask the ultimate question: 'What is your alternative?' " said Assembly Speaker Mel Miller.
Eve Brooks, the executive director ofStatewide Youth Advocacy, a nonprofit group that lobbies for children's programs, said the state was able to focus in rich budget years on dividing an expanding pie rather than examining the underpinnings of state government.
"Had we done this kind of priority setting two or three years ago, we might not have had such a problem this year," she said.
 
A Case in Point
 Perhaps the best example is the proposal in the Governor's budget for the 1991-92 fiscal year, which starts on April 1, to close Gowanda Psychiatric Center in southwestern New York. Although the number of patients at Gowanda has declined for years, while the cost of operating it continued to grow, the Governor did not consider shutting itsdoors until this year.
The primary reason, said Richard C. Surles, Mr. Cuomo's Mental Health Commissioner, has been the entrenched opposition of the labor unions that represent workers at Gowanda and other psychiatric hospitals being considered for closing.
Last spring, the Public Employees Federation used an aggressive $25,000 advertising campaign to fight off a plan to lay off 262 mental health workers in outpatient clinics. Some of the advertisements attacked Mr. Surles personally, saying that he was "creating thousands of personal tragedies" and that the mental health system under his stewardship was "careening out of control."
The union effectively argued that the cuts would harm patient care and worsen homelessness, and the Legislature restored the jobs. Later in the year, the Public Employees Federation and the Civil Service Employees Association combined to contribute almost $700,000 to legislative campaign committees and candidates. Neither contributed to Mr. Cuomo's campaign.
Only the magnitude of next year's budget shortfall, which represents one-fifth of the size of this year's entire budget, led Mr. Surles and the Governor's Budget Division to conclude that closing hospitals might be politically possible. "My strategy had been, because of what I learned last year, that layoffs were an unrealistic strategy in New York," Mr. Surles said.
 
Praise for Decision
 Evelyn R. Frankford, a mental health analyst for the State Communities Aid Association, commended the decision to close the hospitals but said the state's community-based mental health services had been neglected in the interim.
"The decision to close and consolidate some psychiatric centers has been long in coming, and if made years ago would have produced the community system and the savings that we all want," she said.
Similarly, Mr. Cuomo had been loath in previous years to recommend giving judges more discretion in sentencing nonviolent offenders who commit their second felonies. Existing law requires that second-time felons serve terms in prison.
Mr. Miller, the Assembly Speaker, speculated that Mr. Cuomo has resisted such a change in the past because the Governor has felt the need to "offset" his opposition to the death penalty.
The Governor's new proposal would allow judges to sentence nonviolent second-time offenders to alternative programs. About 5,000 of the state's 55,000 inmates would qualify. By keeping even half of those convicts out of jail, prison space could be created for violent felons without building new prisons.
If he is successful in amending the law on second-felony offenders and in pushing through other changes in the structure of the prison system, Mr. Cuomo plans to cancel construction of five prisons scheduled to be built for $235 million.
Gerald C. Crotty, the Governor's secretary, said the prison system, which has grown by 28,000 beds during Mr. Cuomo's two four-year terms, was only now large enough to allow such "economies of scale."
Robert Gangi, executive director of the Correctional Association of New York, which conducts research on prison issues, commended the Governor for endorsing the changes. But he questioned why it took a fiscal crisis to convince him to do so.
 "As a political leader who generally has high standing, he should have been willing to step forward during the normal course of events because it makes sense from a fiscal stand and because it provides a more efficient and equitable system of justice," he said.
Many of the policy changes hidden within the numbers in Mr. Cuomo's budget have been seen repeatedly in past budgets. As always, the Governor has proposed eliminating state boards and commissions, consolidating some state agencies and restructuring the state's school aid formula to favor the neediest districts.
But a number of other proposals, like laying off 7,200 state workers and reducing the state's Medicaid coverage, mark a stark departure for Mr. Cuomo, and many have brought immediate resistance from some of his loyal constituency groups -- labor, minorities, liberals and the poor.
After laying off a total of 5,464 state workers in his first eight years, he has proposed laying off an additional 7,200 this year. He has also called for cancelling Medicaid reimbursement for services like dentistry, podiatry, audiology and clinical psychology and has proposed that some Medicaid recipients pay a part of the cost of their care.
 "The fiscal situation makes a lot of things easier," said Anne W. Crowley, Mr. Cuomo's press secretary. "It makes things a lot more achievable."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices of Treasury Securities Fall

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Credit market participants sifted through a wealth of new information yesterday and apparently concluded that, on balance, the news was negative, because prices of Treasury securities fell and yields on long-term bonds inched back above 8 percent.
Developments that influenced prices during the session were disturbing new inflation figures, a report that showed the housing industry continues to contract, a wealth of comments from Alan Greenspan, Federal Reserve Board chairman, and an auction of $12 billion worth of new two-year Treasury notes. 
 Market participants drove down prices after the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported that the consumer price index rose four-tenths of a percentage point in January, and double that amount if food and energy prices are excluded.
Analysts said the price increases were at least partly aberrational, and continued to hold to the view that the recession put downward pressure on prices.
Still, the January figures, "were a surprise, no question," said Donald Ratajczak, head of the economic forecasting project at Georgia State University. "But at this point I am not willing to give up the ghost on our forecast."
Mr. Ratajczak is projecting that for the twelve months ending Dec. 31, 1991, the consumer price index will rise at a 2.9 percent rate.
 
 Fed's Inflation Outlook

In testimony before the Senate Banking Committee, Alan Greenspan indicated that the Fed is only slightly less optimistic about the inflation outlook than Mr. Ratajczak.
In presenting the Fed's semi-annual economic forecast, Mr. Greenspan said the central bank expected consumer prices to rise at an annual rate of 3.25 percent to 4 percent this year. In July, the last time the Fed provided Congress with economic projections, the Fed was anticipating prices would rise at an annual rate of 4.5 percent to 5 percent in 1991.
"There is no question that the January consumer price numbers overstate the underlying core rate of inflation," said John R. Williams, a managing director at the Bankers Trust Company.
"Lower inflation will be the hallmark of the next couple of quarters for the fixed-income markets. And if inflation rises at a 4 percent rate or less, that suggests that 7 percent bond yields are not out of the question."
In addition to providing new statistical forecasts on the economy and inflation, Mr. Greenspan, in his comments, led market participants to infer that the Fed may not be finished pushing down short-term interest rates.
Of particular interest to traders were remarks Mr. Greenspan made about the problems facing the nation's banks that have prompted them to pull back on lending, a situation the Fed chairman suggested has not yet been remedied.
"Greenspan's testimony was bullish in the sense that there were some remarks that indicated the credit crunch was his single most important priority," said James R. Capra, a principal at Moore Capital Management, a money management firm.
 
Attempts Offset Credit Crunch

"Attempts to offset the credit crunch really has only one implication," said Ward McCarthy, a managing director at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates, a Princeton, N.J. research and consulting firm. "The Fed will continue to lower rates as long as the economy continues to sag."
A report on housing activity in January reaffirmed economic weakness: housing starts fell more than 12 percent last month, to 850,000 units at an annual rate, the lowest level in nine years.
Prices firmed somewhat during Mr. Greenspan's testimony, but weakened later, after results from the two-year Treasury note auction were announced.
Bids at the auction produced an average yield of 6.87 percent, down from an average 7.09 percent yield at the last two-year note sale on Jan. 23 and the lowest rate on a new two-year Treasury note in nearly four years. The two-year notes sold on March 24, 1987, carried an average yield of 6.43 percent.
Wall Street firms bought the bulk of the $12 billion issue, and prices of most Treasury securities fell a bit further after the results were announced.
Reflecting the selling, the new two-year notes were offered on a when-issued basis late yesterday at a price to yield 6.89 percent.
The Treasury is expected to sell $9 billion worth of new five-year notes today. Those securities were offered on a when-issued basis late yesterday at a price to yield 7.50 percent, compared to 7.45 percent late Tuesday.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 7 7/8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered at a price of 98 7/32 in late trading, down 15/32, to yield 8.03 percent, up from 7.98 percent late Tuesday.
Among note issues, the 7 3/4 percent ten-year notes were offered at 99 9/ 32, down 3/8, to yield 7.85 percent. Traders said an offering of $1.5 billion worth of new World Bank ten-year global bonds probably helped to depress prices of outstanding ten-year Treasury issues.
Shorter-term Treasury maturities did not fare as badly.
By late in the day, the 6 7/8 percent three-year notes were offered at 99 14/32, down 3/32, to yield 7.08 percent.
Short-term Treasury rates were little changed.
Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 5.93 percent late yesterday, down one basis point, or hundredth of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates were unchanged at 5.91 percent.
The World Bank offering highlighted activity in the investment-grade corporate bond market.
The 8 1/8 percent issue, which was offered simultaneously in Europe, Japan and the United States, was priced at $99.178, to yield 8.247 percent, 42 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 7 3/4 percent ten-year notes at the time of pricing.
Merrill Lynch & Co. and J.P. Morgan Securities acted as lead managers for the underwriting. The securities are rated AAA by both Moody's Investors Service and by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
A number of other issuers also priced new debt offerings, including United Technologies, which offered $250 million worth of 30-year debentures through an underwriting group led by Salomon Brothers.
The 8.75 percent securities, which mature March 1, 2021, were priced at $97.52, to yield 8.99 percent, 96 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 7 7/8 percent bonds of 2021 at the time of pricing.
The issue, which is non-callable for life, is rated AA by Moody's and AA-3 by Standard & Poor's.
The decline in Treasury prices and the heavy supply of new issues combined to push down prices in the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds.
Traders said that prices of most issues slipped by 1/4 of a point to 3/8 of a point.
Prices in the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds remained under downward pressure.
Market participants said prices of most widely quoted tax-exempt issues fell by 1/2 of a point to 3/4 of a point.
"We need the Fed to ease or the war to end before this market will do better," one municipal bond trader said.

HEADLINE: WAR IN THE GULF: Soviet Union;
Awaiting Reply From Iraq, Soviets Debate Peace Plan

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Feb. 20

 BODY:
Another day came and went today with no signals from Baghdad on whether it would agree to the Soviet initiative on Kuwait, as the debate in Moscow continued on the merits and motives of the Soviet plan, Iraq's options and Washington's response.
The Kremlin continued to say it expected a quick response from Baghdad on the confidential proposals that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev handed to Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz of Iraq on Monday. 
 "I am sure we will get a response, and we want it as soon as possible," said the Foreign Ministry spokesman, Vitaly Churkin.
 
Iraqi to Return 'Soon'
 The Baghdad radio announced tonight that Mr. Aziz would be sent to Moscow "soon to convey the leadership's response to the Soviet proposal." The broadcast did not give any suggestion of what the response would be.
As suspense over the Soviet plan took center stage in the Persian Gulf crisis, debate swirled over why Mr. Gorbachev had chosen this moment to make his offer and to warn that the West was about to overstep the limits of the United Nations Security Council mandate sanctioning force to oust Iraq from Kuwait.
Western suspicions that Moscow was trying to reclaim a role in the Middle East crossed Soviet suspicions that Washington was trying to obliterate Iraq. But Moscow insisted, evidently to Washington's satisfaction, that the plan adhered fully to the United Nations Security Council resolutions demanding Iraq's unconditional withdrawal from Kuwait.
The details of Mr. Gorbachev's plan continued to be shrouded in secrecy and speculation. It was generally presumed to call for Iraq's unconditional withdrawal from Kuwait, as demanded by the United Nations, coupled with a Soviet-backed package that would look to Iraq's security and steps toward a broad Mideast conference.
 
Not a Rejection, Soviets Say
 President Bush declared that the plan "falls well short of what would be required," but the Soviets insisted this was not a rejection.
The youth daily Komsomolskaya Pravda, citing "well-informed sources close to the Kremlin," said the first point of the plan committed President Saddam Hussein of Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait within a specified time. If the United States-led coalition agreed, a cease-fire would be declared.
Beyond that, the paper speculated that Moscow would propose a Middle East conference, replacement of allied forces by a pan-Arab or United Nations force, and possibly the lifting of economic sanctions against Iraq.
The debate over Iraq reached deep into domestic Soviet politics. For the right wing, the idea that the West was battling a recent Soviet ally with Moscow's blessing seemed another humiliating symbol of Moscow's surrender of its global influence. The notion of NATO forces waging a ground war with the latest in modern weaponry so near the southern Soviet border seemed to cause special alarm among the military.
 
Images of Civilian Victims
 Right-wing legislators in the Supreme Soviet invoked emotional images of civilian victims in Iraq, while moderate speakers, including Foreign Minister Aleksandr A. Bessmertnykh and his predecessor, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, countered that Kuwaiti victims of the Iraqi aggression should not be neglected.
On the international side, the initiative seemed a revival of Moscow's old fear of being locked out of the Middle East. Soviet commentators noted that the move had potential benefits whether the war ended or not.
If it did, Moscow would be credited with avoiding carnage and would emerge as something of a "defense attorney" for Iraq in subsequent forums. If the war continued, Moscow could still benefit in the Arab world for having tried to help.
Yevgeny M. Primakov, the envoy Mr. Gorbachev has dispatched several times to intercede with Mr. Hussein, suggested in an interview on Soviet television on Tuesday that the West had motives that ranged beyond the liberation of Kuwait in pursuing its attack on Iraq. He described demolished bridges and ministries he had seen recently in Baghdad as evidence that the Western bombing went considerably beyond attacks on military targets.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Hussein Sending Response
 BAGHDAD, Iraq, Feb. 20 (AP) -- President Saddam Hussein decided today to send his Foreign Minister back to Moscow to convey Iraq's response to a Soviet offer Moscow hopes will spare the region all-out war, the Baghdad radio reported.
The radio said President Hussein presided at a Revolutionary Command Council meeting that studied the proposals by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union, which Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz brought to Baghdad from Moscow on Monday. The council decided to send Mr. Aziz to Moscow "soon to convey the leadership's response to the Soviet proposal," the radio said.
Also today, Information Minister Latif Jassim ridiculed statements attributed to the commander of the United States forces in the gulf, Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, that the Iraqi military was "on the verge of collapse." Mr. Jassim said, "This is just another fabrication of this damned criminal's rotten mind."

HEADLINE: Mayors Win Concession on U.S. Aid

BYLINE: By WAYNE KING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20

 BODY:
In a move that appeared to further weaken President Bush's proposal to shift $15 billion in Federal assistance from Federal to state control, a spokesman for the nation's governors told the Senate today that the states have no interest in assuming control over community development funds or other programs whose loss would threaten the cities.
The move came at a Senate Budget Committee hearing that also brought angry testimony from two big-city Mayors, David N. Dinkins of New York and Raymond L. Flynn of Boston, and strong hints from Democratic members that the President's proposal would have tough sledding in the Democratic-controlled Congress. 
 Many members of Congress, particularly Democrats, view the proposal as a move to starve the cities and eventually to wean them off much Federal assistance.
Under Mr. Bush's proposal, $15 billion in money now being made available to state and local governments under various specific programs would be turned over exclusively to the states as block grants, to be parceled out as the states deem necessary. The proposal, first mentioned by the President in his State of the Union Message last month, immediately drew criticism from the nation's mayors but won expressions of pleasant expectation from most, though not all, of the governors.
In testimony before the Senate Budget Committee today, Gov. John Ashcroft of Missouri, a Republican who is vice chairman of the National Governors' Association, said the governors supported the block grant concept.
 
Easing the Cities' Fears
 But Governor Ashcroft, who said he spoke for the nation's governors, made a clear attempt to lessen the fears of cities that the President's proposal will cheat them, telling the committee that "the governors are not interested in including grants that are currently targeted to local government."
The Bush Administration did not specify what programs would be shifted to block grants, instead providing a list of programs as examples of what the states might take over.
What particularly outraged the mayors was inclusion on the list of $3.1 billion in Community Development Block Grants for housing, parks, child care and other social services. Urban areas now get two-thirds of that money, and the states get the rest.
Mayor Flynn and Mayor Dinkins, along with Mayor William J. Althaus of York, Pa., also testified later before the House Budget Committee. They said that because most legislatures were dominated by rural and suburban interests, cities could get short shrift if the states took control of money now earmarked for the cities.
But Governor Ashcroft said he and the other governors would specifically exclude the Community Development Block Grant program "and would not threaten resources that are now being made available to the cities."
While the mayors welcomed the concession, Mr. Althaus said a compromise was not acceptable to the cities. "We would insist that this particular proposal be taken off the table," he said. "It is not workable and not in the interest of the people concerned."
Mr. Flynn told the House committee that the proposal was a diversionary tactic intended to get cities and states warring among themselves.
Mr. Dinkins, like the other mayors, aimed most of his fire at the block grant proposal, contending that it amounted to an "abandonment" of the cities.

HEADLINE: Bush Asserts Need for Foreign Oil

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20

 BODY:
Saying he was committed to "the power of the marketplace," President Bush presented an energy policy today that he asserted would save energy, increase domestic production of fuels and improve the environment without new taxes or harsh Government edicts.
Because the policy includes only a very limited effort to improve gasoline mileage -- the factor in the energy balance most experts believe easiest to influence -- Mr. Bush appeared to set the stage today for a major battle with Congress. 
 The plan gives considerable attention to oil. In contrast to the energy policy initiatives undertaken by Presidents Richard Nixon and Jimmy Carter in the oil crises that occured during their terms, the Bush proposal asserts that the United States will have to live with a high level of dependence on foreign oil. The nation should reduce its vulnerability to sudden price increases, the new plan says, through diversifying supply, improving the ability to switch to other fuels and raising efficiency.
The Energy Secretary, James D. Watkins, defended the policy's approach to energy efficiency, saying that its critics "want Government control of how you run your life."
 
 Skepticism on Mileage
 Congressional reaction was especially skeptical on the issue of raising the fuel-economy requirements on automobiles, which swallow 40 percent of the oil used in this country. Representative Philip R. Sharp of Indiana, chairman of the Subcommittee on Energy and Power of the House Energy and Commerce Committee, said it would be "very hard" to raise automobile mileage unless changes were required by the Government.
Currently, auto makers are allowed a small exemption from the fuel-economy standard if they build cars that run on something besides gasoline. The Administration is proposing to do away with limits on the credits auto makers can earn with vehicles using alternative fuels. Critics say this step might create huge numbers of low-mileage vehicles that could run on methanol or some other substitute, but in all likelihood would be run on gasoline.
Mr. Sharp said that this was possible, but he added that no one would market the fuel before vehicles were in place to use it.
Senator Al Gore, Democrat of Tennessee, called the Bush proposal "breathtakingly dumb" and added, "Under this plan our consumption of imported oil will increae dramatically, even as our soldiers are engaged in combat in the Persian Gulf."
Some analysts believe the war has created a political opportunity for new policies. Wilfrid Kohl, the director of the International Energy Program at Johns Hopkins School of Advanced International Studies, said: "Obviously the Administration is not reading anything larger out of this gulf crisis. I think they're terribly mistaken, and I think the Democrats know that."
A centerpiece of the plan, most details of which had become public in the last two weeks, is to allow drilling in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge, an area east of the Prudhoe Bay field in Alaska that is currently protected. That aspect, combined with the absence of new mandates for energy conservation, drew bitter comments from environmental organizations.
"The White House staff equates energy efficiency with sacrifice, and apparently doesn't mind sacrificing the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge," said Daniel A. Lashof, a senior scientist at the Natural Resources Defense Council. But efficiency, he said, was simply performing the same work with less fuel.
 
Industry's Point of View

Reaction from the oil industry, meanwhile, ranged from lukewarm to cold. Charles DiBona, the president of the American Petroleum Institute, the largest trade organization, said the proposal was "a good start in a reasonable direction." But a requirement for alternative fuel for fleet vehicles might save oil at an unjustifiably high cost, he said.
Mr. DiBona said the plan, if enacted, would not halt the decline in American oil production. "We would be doing very, very well to hold production at anything like constant," he said. And while the Bush Administration projected that the plan would hold imports to 40 to 45 percent of demand, Mr. DiBona said it would be difficult to cut the level that now prevails, which he said was about 50 percent.
At the Independent Petroleum Association of America, which represents smaller oil and gas drillers, Denise A. Bode, the president, borrowed a phrase from President Bush's reaction to the Soviet peace plan and said that his energy plan "falls short of the mark." It does not stabilize the price of oil and gas, which is needed for more investment, she said, and it does not eliminate tax inequities.
The industry says it would increase domestic production if it were given subsidies to do so.
 
Disagreeing With the Critics
 Mr. Watkins, in a briefing for reporters at the Energy Department, said that a goal of the policy was "to wean ourselves away from this voracious appetite" for oil. Linda G. Stuntz, a Deputy Under Secretary who supervised the drafting of the policy, said that "tinkering" with cars was "not nearly as good an answer as looking for fundamentally different technology," in this case, alternative fuel.
The Administration also disagrees with its critics over how much difference would result from raising the current standard, 27.5 miles a gallon; the Senate approved a bill last year that would have raised the standard to about 40 miles a gallon, and the sponsor, Senator Richard Bryan of Nevada, said it would save 2.8 million barrels a day by 2005. But Mr. Watkins said yesterday that it would save only 500,000 barrels a day, compared with letting the market take its course, in which case, he said, consumers will choose increasingly efficient cars as the years go by. "It's not as though people are going to sit around at 27.5 miles per gallon," he said.
But proponents of a change point to Government statistics showing that new vehicles sold last year were less efficient than those sold in the previous two years, suggesting that over the 1990's, market-driven improvements will be small, especially if the current low price of gasoline persists. Senator Bryan said yesterday that a bill like his would save almost 10 times as much oil daily as the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge was likely to produce, and added that raising auto efficiency standards was a proven success.
"No one argues that we would be better off today if our automobiles were less efficient," he said.
 
 
AIMS OF THE NEW STRATEGY

 
Projected results of the nearly 100 policy changes proposed by the Bush Administration, based on its computerized model of energy production and consumption patterns. The Administration expects the following results in the year 2010:
 
Increase domestic oil production by 3.8 million barrels a day and reduce demand by 3.4 million barrels a day, from projected levels.
 
Hold oil imports to 40 to 45 percent of demand. The model projected 65 percent reliance on imports if no action is taken.
 
Increase the amount of domestic oil that can be profitably pumped by 20 billion barrels to 75 billion barrels.
 
Increase by 16 percent the production of electricity from renewable sources, like hydro, solar and wind.
 
Reduce total energy consumption by 7.5 quadrillin B.T.U.'s. If no action is taken, the model projects a rise in consumption from 85 quadrillion B.T.U.'s to about 100 quadrillion B.T.U.'s
 
Save consumers $750 billion in gasoline, home heating oil and other liquid fuel bills and $130 billion in electric bills, through increased efficiency.
 
Cut gasoline and home heating oil prices by 10 percent.
