HEADLINE: Dow Tumbles by 33.17 Points, to 2,899.01

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
Stocks tumbled yesterday as investors turned skittish and took profits. The Dow Jones industrial average sank 33.17, or 1.1 percent, to 2,899.01, while the broader Standard & Poor's 500 index fell almost the same, suggesting that the downturn swept broadly across the market.
Averages among the smaller stocks also fell, but to a lesser extent. 
 Losses in the blue chips were widespread, with declines of a point or more for 3M, Procter & Gamble, General Motors, American Express, Boeing, General Electric, I.B.M. and Merck.
Big Board activity, while fairly strong, dropped to 185.7 million shares from 189.9 million the day before. Declines led advances by more than two to one, but while 2 stocks fell to new lows, 73 rose to new highs.
One stock at a new high price was Honeywell, which rose 1 1/8, to 55 5/8, after hitting a new high of 56 1/2. The electronics producer said profits from continuing operations rose in both the fourth quarter and the year, with gains in all business segments.
"Traders I've talked to from the big investment and money management firms seem to think the market's focusing more on economic fundamentals than the war in the Middle East," said Sung Won Sohn, chief economist for the Norwest Corporation in Minneapolis. Still, he said, many analysts look for things to bounce back fairly quickly.
"The main concern in the short run, of course," he said, "is the gulf crisis. But the analysts I talk to are in the bullish camp. They believe that despite the uncertainties in the gulf, the war will be over with a decisive allied victory shortly, that the end of the war will help revive the economy, bring interest rates down and perk up corporate profits."
The big market winner yesterday was Square D, the electrical-equipment producer, whose stock soared $20.25 a share, to $72.25, after climbing to a new high of $75. More than 3.7 million shares changed hands after Groupe Schneider of France proposed on Tuesday to buy the company for $78 a share, or roughly $1.8 billion.
In another big takeover situation, NCR, target of a hostile A.T.&.T. offer of $90 a share, rose 1 1/8, to 91 7/8.
In other movers, Upjohn, the big drug company, climbed 3 1/8, to 44 1/2, in heavy trading after jumping to a new high of 44 3/8. But Lilly, another big drug producer, fell 1 3/4, to 79 1/2, while Pfizer fell 2 1/2, to 101.
The Dow dropped sharply at the start of trading, acting in sympathy with the bond market, which slumped over fears that inflation had picked up again and might prevent the Fed from bringing interest rates down further.
Dr. Sohn, of Norwest, said Congressional testimony yesterday by Alan Greenspan, the Fed's chairman, disappointed traders. "They had anticipated some encouragement for an easing of monetary policy in the near future," he said, "but Greenspan was being deliberately vague, pointing out that the Fed had done enough and wanted to wait and see how economic activity unfolds in the coming weeks and months."
 
STOCKS LOWER IN TOKYO
 TOKYO, Feb. 21 (REUTERS) -- Japanese stock prices were slightly lower at midday today. The Nikkei index of 225 issues was off 6.56 points, or 0.03 percent, to 26,192.23 at the end of the morning trading session. On Wednesday, the Nikkei gained 31.81 points.

HEADLINE: Reforms in Banking Call For a Shrinking U.S. Role

SERIES: Banks Under Stress: Windows on the Future - Last article of a series

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
The proposals for bank reform are piling up -- from the Bush Administration this month, from Congress in several bills, and from bankers, economists and Government regulators in their numerous public statements. They disagree on many points. But a common ground appears to be emerging, and it is this:
The nation's 12,926 commercial banks should move into a second phase of deregulation, one in which the Government's role as a savior of failing banks through deposit insurance would shrink. The proposals, in fact, focus mainly on how to minimize the next banking crisis -- so the Government will not get stuck with another huge bailout bill -- and not so much on how to restore failing banks to good health in the current crisis. 
 Given the growing consensus to move deeper into deregulation, a new banking law, if Congress manages to enact one this year, would probably force banks to acknowledge, much more openly than in the past, that they are operating with a big chunk of uninsured deposits.
Two levels of banking would in effect be created, or two "windows." At one, customers would have their deposits federally insured. At the other, interest rates on deposits would be higher, but the deposits themselves would not be insured. Billions in pension fund savings held in one account, for example, would lose coverage, and some family savings beyond $100,000, deposited in multiple accounts at one bank, would also go uninsured.
"The banks will be happy to open for you an uninsured account, perhaps giving you a red deposit slip rather than the green one that you'll get for the money you put in your insured account," Robert R. Glauber, Under Secretary of the Treasury for Finance and the chief author of the Administration's bank reform proposals, said in an interview. "There will be clear labeling for consumer protection, with the uninsured deposits probably earning higher interest," Mr. Glauber said.
 
Between the Lines
 Nowhere in the bank reform bills is two-level banking spelled out, but politicians and bankers say the concept comes through clearly between the lines of the Administration's proposal and those put forth in Congress. L. William Seidman, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, would like banks to literally operate separate teller windows, one labeled for insured deposits, the other for uninsured. Depositors would have no doubt about which of their funds were protected and which would be subject to greater risk.
A heated debate is developing over the details of this new phase of deregulation -- for example, over which Federal agencies should supervise the banks, how much capital banks should keep on hand to help reimburse depositors in emergencies, whether they should be allowed to sell insurance and who should be allowed to own banks. But virtually every proposal embraces the concept of shrinking Federal deposit insurance, if not all at once, then over a year or two. What opposition there is comes most loudly from small banks, but it appears insufficient to stop the trend.
In recent years, Federal insur- ance has made good on 99 percent of the deposits in banks that failed, the Treasury Department reports. Bank reform, whatever the version, would reduce this to 70 percent or less.
"Most of the people we do business with know that their money is not insured and I don't see the monumental risk in being explicit about this," said Thomas C. Theobald, chairman of the Continental Bank Corporation in Chicago, whose major clients are companies, individuals and even smaller banks that deposit millions, often through the purchase of Continental's certificates of deposit.
 
The 2 Windows
Higher Interest In 'Risk' Sector
 In this proposed new world of explicit banking, money deposited at the "safe" window would be lent to borrowers who do not usually default in hard times. Consumer credit and small-business loans, for example, fall into this safe category. In the unlikely event that these loans were not repaid and the depositors lost their money, the Federal Government would reimburse them, much as it has reimbursed depositors who lost their money at failed savings and loan associations and, increasingly, at commercial banks.
Insurance under the Bush proposal and most of the others would be limited to $100,000 per person per bank, with an extra $100,000 for a retirement account. Family accounts created by opening a joint account in the names of two people who already have individual accounts at the same bank would no longer qualify for insurance. The new laws would also eliminate various procedures under which pension funds and brokers obtained Federal insurance for millions in deposits, usually by breaking them up into $100,000 units. Eventually, individuals would be allowed to insure only $100,000 in savings, no matter how many banks they used, if Mr. Bush can override opposition in Congress to this extra limitation.
Such restrictions would make the "risk" window an increasingly busy place. The risk tellers would also take in deposits and lend them out. But as the quid pro quo for forgoing the protection of Federal insurance, the risk window depositors would earn higher interest rates than their more cautious brethren. And the tellers at this window would deal in the riskier class of lending, such things as loans for office construction and corporate takeovers. Or the deposits might be invested in mutual funds, which the banks would now be allowed to operate.
 
U.S. Supervision Maintained
 The advocates of this system argue that the risk window would not be all that risky. For one thing, Federal regulators would supervise the lending practices. Extra capital would have to be ept on hand so that banks could reimburse depositors out of their own pockets if loans were not repaid.
Potential depositors would stay away from the risk window, presumably, even though the returns would be higher, if they concluded from public disclosure that the tellers were making loans that were too risky.
Along with their red deposit slips, depositors at a risk window might even get a prospectus stating precisely how their funds were invested, and warning of the risks. This would be the same sort of prospectus that goes out today to the millions of Americans who put money, uninsured, into a T. Rowe Price or a Fidelity Group mutual fund.
But the Government would be off the hook if risky lending in, say, the mid-90's produced another wave of loan failures similar to today's experience with real estate lending. "We would get what everyone wants," Mr. Seidman said, "more lending outside the insured banking system and the collapses, if they came, would also be outside the system."
The goal, in effect, is a sufficiently safe system, with less Government insurance as a backup. Or, as Mr. Seidman put it, somewhat doubtfully: "We are attempting to get on a horse and ride off in two directions at once."
 
Branching Out
Adding States And Businesses
 Apart from the creation of new categories of banking, there appears to be agreement among Bush Administration officials and key Congressmen on other measures. The McFadden Act would be repealed so that banks would no longer be prohibited from operating across state lines.
Banks would also be authorized to branch out, for the first time since the 1930's, into various non-bank businesses, among them financing new stock issues and providing other services now usually prohibited under the Glass-Steagall Act.
These new entrepreneurial businesses would operate behind "firewalls" -- in separately incorporated divisions that could not go to the bank operation for help if one of the non-banking ventures failed.
Firewalls may sound sensible in theory, but many experts question whether a banking company's entrepreneurial venture, if it got into trouble, could in fact be prevented from draining capital from the healthy bank operation. "What the marketplace tells us with almost unfailing regularity is that in times of stress, some parts of a financial entity cannot safely be insulated from the problems of affiliated entities," Gerald Corrigan, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, has told the Senate Banking Committee. Others reiterate this criticism.
 
Current Failures
Who Will Pay The Depositors?
 As for dealing with the industry's present troubles, there is no absence of squabbling. As bank failures proliferate today, the main disagreement is over who is to reimburse depositors once the F.D.I.C.'s funds are depleted -- the Government or the banks themselves. The total cost is likely to be $25 billion or more, by most estimates.
If the Government foots the bill, it might do so through a fresh appropriation to the F.D.I.C.'s fund, which is expected to decline to $4 billion this year from $18.3 billion in 1987. If the burden falls to the banks, it might come in the form of higher premiums for Federal insurance. Or the banks might be allowed, for the first time, to sell stock to a commercial corporation.
That sort of cross-fertilization would be unsound, in the view of Mr. Corrigan and others. They believe that banks have a special role in the nation's financial system -- to funnel deposits that must be repaid more or less on demand into longer-term loans for ventures that expand the economy. "I look with concern, if not alarm, at the economic, financial -- and perhaps even social -- implications of Exxon owning Chase Manhattan, Ford owning Citicorp, or RJR Nabisco owning J. P. Morgan," Mr. Corrigan has said. The advocates of corporate ownership counter that the "firewall" and the Federal regulators would prevent a corporation from interfering unduly with its subsidiary bank.
 
Opposition Seems to Dwindle
 But more generally, opposition to the Administration's approach to bank reform appears to be dwindling. The Wall Street investment houses and the insurance industry, once adamantly opposed to letting banks into their fields, became less and less outspoken as banks found ways in the 80's to get into their businesses anyway.
And many bankers endorse the Bush proposals, not only for the obvious reason that the industry's horizons would be allowed to expand, but more important, because the banks themselves must finance the Federal insurance fund administered by the F.D.I.C. The commercial banks now pay 19.5 cents in premiums for every $100 in insured deposits. Shrinking the coverage, as the Administration proposes, would probably keep premiums from rising.
"We applaud the direction and many of the specifics that the Bush Administration has outlined," said Thomas L. Ashley, president of the Association of Bank Holding Companies. "The President is trying to get deposit insurance back in line with market discipline."
 
The Risk Window
What if Deposits Were Not Paid?
 In the new two-window banking system, the risk windows would operate similarly to private financiers -- the General Electric Credit Corporation or the Household Finance Corporation, for example -- which have made huge inroads into bank lending over the last 20 years.
But what if a big private lender fails, or one of the newly created risk operations at a big commercial bank goes under? Although the private lenders have avoided major failures in recent years, cracks are developing in the insurance industry. The Equitable, for example, has lost millions recently because it went heavily into real estate lending, and now many of these loans are in default.
What if a big insurer like Equitable or a money center bank like Chase Manhattan were unable, because of loan losses, to pay back hundreds of millions of dollars in uninsured deposits in teachers' pension savings, for example, which are often "deposited" at higher rates outside the banking system?
Would the Federal Government turn its back?
The answer seems to be no for now.
For the next few years, at least at the biggest banks, when the chips are down, the Government will bail out major lending institutions heading for default, even if the deposits at a bank's risk window are not insured. That is the message in the reform proposals.
Is this not taking the risk out of the risk window? The answer appears to be yes at banks that are so huge that their failure would endanger the nation's financial system. The Bush Administration says it is striving mightily, however, to limit the number of institutions that would qualify for bailouts.
 
Determining U.S. Responsibility
 The policy of saving big banks, called the doctrine of "too big to fail," has been liberally practiced in recent years, starting with the bailout of the Continental Illinois Bank and Trust Company in Chicago in 1984 (predecessor to Mr. Theobald's Continental Corporation) and the recent saving of the Bank of New England. In each case, the Government ignored its own ceiling on Federal deposit insurance and in effect reimbursed all depositors.
The liberal use of the doctrine is over, Mr. Glauber says. "We are significantly changing and limiting too-big-to-fail," he said. "We say the F.D.I.C. is out of the business of paying off uninsured depositors."
But he adds, "We do say that the Federal Reserve can make the decision that an institution is too big to fail." That loophole means that in practice, too big to fail might end up being administered in the 1990's much as it has been over the last seven years.
The Bush proposals would shift responsibility for administering the policy to the Treasury as well as the Federal Reserve, and out of the hands of the F.D.I.C. But Mr. Seidman says the Treasury and the Fed have had a say in all the F.D.I.C.'s bailout decisions to date, and often were more eager than the F.D.I.C. to go through with a bailout.
 
Limitations Doubted
 "I don't see that too-big-to-fail is going to be limited," Mr. Seidman said. "There is nothing in any of the proposals that are restrictive enough to make a lot of difference."
Mr. Seidman cites the Bank of New England as a case in point. Among the various bailouts over the last decade, that bank's failure presented the least risk to the financial system, some critics argue. But Mr. Seidman said, "Treasury declined to veto our decision to bail out the bank, and the Federal Reserve extended the bailout to foreign exchange losses and to other things we had not planned to cover."
The Federal Reserve indeed views the too-big-to-fail doctrine as a necessity. "There has to be enough flexibility to permit an ad hoc approach, if we or some other Federal agency concluded that a bank's failure would hurt the financial system," said John P. LaWare, a Federal Reserve governor.
 
Bankers Offer Another View
 The banking industry has a different viewpoint: If the Fed decides to invoke the policy, then the bailout money should not come from the F.D.I.C.'s insurance fund, financed with premiums paid by the banks. Even Mr. Theobald, whose Continental Bank benefited from a bailout, takes this view: "If the Fed wants to go beyond the $100,000 insurance limit, it should do so with taxpayers' dollars."
Neither the Bush proposal nor those introduced by Representative Henry B. Gonzalez, chairman of the House Banking Committee, and Senator Donald W. Riegle Jr., chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, contain such a provision -- although critics say the Fed would be more reluctant to authorize a bailout if taxpayers had to finance it.
Whoever ends up paying the bill, phasing in the change will take time. "At this stage, it is almost impossible to get out of too-big-to-fail," Mr. Glauber said. "But we might be able to say: 'Time out. New rules will go into effect two years down the road, and when the time comes, we'll play under the new rules that limit deposit insurance.' "
He went on, "What we want to do is set up a system where people no longer anticipate that the Government will step in with a bailout, but at the same time there has to be a provision to let the Government step in."
Mr. Seidman and Robert L. Clarke, Comptroller of the Currency, also express the hope that the doctrine can be phased out gradually. "If you are going to make the policy change from too-big-to-fail, then you want to give sufficient notice," Mr. Clarke said. And Mr. Glauber concluded, "The key is to get the balance right; we now use the doctrine too much."
 
Quicker Shutdowns
Goal Is to Limit Federal Bailouts
 The use of the too-big-to-fail doctrine might be minimized through considerable Federal supervision. Senator Riegle and Representative Gonzalez want regulators to shut an institution as soon as it seems to be getting into trouble -- and not, as in the Bank of New England's case, when loan losses have become so great that the bank no longer has any capital left to reimburse depositors and must call in the F.D.I.C. The Bush Administration agrees.
The goal, in sum, is to fall back as infrequently as possible on a Federal bailout. What's more, the bailouts simply perpetuate what economists describe as overcapacity in banking: too many lenders chasing too few borrowers. "If you frustrate the market's attempts to consolidate banking, you contribute to the pressures that will force other banks to fail," said Martin Mayer, the banking expert and author.
 
Small Banks Are Fearful
 The most vociferous opponents of the too-big-to-fail doctrine are the small banks. For Kenneth Guenther, the executive vice president of the Independent Bankers Association, the plan could bring about the eventual disappearance of the smaller banks -- many of them community operations that lend, say, to the corner grocer. His association represents 6,200 small banks.
"You are setting up a system where the financial giants of the world, whose failure would cause the greatest systemic risk, would have 100 percent coverage, while tens of thousands of community banks would find their insurance capped," he said. "This is a prescription for slowly encouraging the migration of deposits from small banks to the too-big-to-fail institutions."
Viewing the policy as a fait accompli of the Bush Administration, Mr. Guenther argues that at the very least, bank reform should continue the present practice of insuring individuals up to $100,000 for each bank in which they have deposits -- rejecting in effect the Bush plan to eventually limit insurance to $100,000 per person, no matter how many banks are involved.
Mr. Seidman, while favoring the too-big-to-fail doctrine in the short term, expresses a similar concern that banking could become concentrated in the big-city banks, mostly on the East and West Coasts. "Our country has always been populist, if you will," he said. "There has always been a general desire of the debtors to want to beat the creditors. So we have developed a decentralized banking system, without the concentration of power in the big, bad Eastern bankers."
 
Hunting Solutions
Some Suggest Return to the Past
 A few have suggested that one way out of the present situation would be to return to the regulations of the past, when banks put ceilings on the interest rates they paid to depositors and charged higher rates for loans. The spread -- between a 5 percent savings account and an 8 percent auto loan, for example -- guaranteed profits to a bank and made deposit insurance a seldom used safety net.
But as inflation in the 1970's raised interest rates, consumers sought yields higher than those offered by banks, and money market mutual funds were born to help meet this new demand. Finally, in the late 70's and early 80's, the interest rate ceilings on bank deposits were lifted and the banks, no longer sure of a profit, engaged in ever riskier lending to earn enough money to pay higher rates to depositors.
Some call for a partial return, to reduce the likelihood of future bank failures. Lowell Bryan, a bank expert at McKinsey & Company, proposes an adjustable interest-rate ceiling on deposits, tied to Treasury rates. Inflation, he notes, has subsided, reducing the competition among banks, money market funds and private lenders for deposits.
Most experts say the old days cannot be retrieved, if only because new technology and instant communication permit consumers to search the world for the best returns. As Mr. Clarke put it: "The genie is permanently out of the bottle."
 


GRAPHIC: A consensus is emerging that the Government's expensive role in insuring banks should shrink. To accomplish this, two levels of banking would be created.
 
The Safe Window
Chart: Two-Window Banking of Tomorrow
 Here, a customer would deposit money that would be F.D.I.C. - insured for up to $100,000. Loans made from this window would be conservative and unlikely to default. The banks' main responsibility here would be the safety of the deposits.
 
The Risk Window
 Deposits would earn higher interest rates but would not be insured. Loans from this window would be made for riskier ventures, and banks would have to hold more capital in reserve to offset the risks.

HEADLINE: Concerns Raised on Mexican Trade

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20

 BODY:
The United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, today ran into a fusillade of hostile questions at a House Ways and Means Committee hearing on a projected free trade agreement with Mexico, signaling a tough battle ahead in selling a pact to Congress.
The principal concerns were about weaker Mexican environmental rules and lower Mexican wages that under free trade conditions, several lawmakers said, might erode standards in this country. 
 Representative Donald J. Pease, a Democrat representing an industrial area outside of Cleveland, said he feared the agreement would cause factory wages to slide in his district as companies struggled to meet the low-wage Mexican competition.
 
 'Lax Tax Record'
 Representative Frank J. Guarini, Democrat of Jersey City, said that Mexico had a "lax track record" in enforcement of environmental rules and that as a result more American companies might move south of the border to cut costs.
While expressing their concerns, many of the lawmakers still voiced general support for the free trade idea. Sam Gibbons, Democrat of Florida, chairman of the Ways and Means Committee's Trade subcommittee, told Mrs. Hills that despite the antagonistic questioning, "I think you will have successful negotiations."
A number of other concerns, involving items ranging from steel and beer to fruits and vegetables, were highlighted as the committee, which has jurisdiction over trade matters in the House, held its first hearing on President Bush's request for authority to negotiate a trade agreement with Mexico.
 
 North American Trade Zone
 The goal is a comprehensive North American trade agreement linking 360 million people who produce $6 trillion of goods and services a year in what would become the world's largest free trade zone. Canada would participate in the negotiations, which could lead to certain modifications -- what officials are calling "enhancements" -- in its two-year-old free trade pact with the United States.
Provided the Bush Administration gets the authority to negotiate an agreement that would then be submitted to Congress for approval or disapproval without amendments, the United States would start talks with Mexico in June and try to wind them up by the end of the year.
Mrs. Hills, who spent nearly four hours fielding questions at the packed hearing, said those who do not support freer exchanges with Mexico view trade as a "zero sum game" and did not take into account mutually reinforced growth that would make both Mexico and the United States more prosperous.
 
 'Win-Win Situation'

"Reduced barriers will improve the efficiency and productivity of U.S. and Mexican industry and enhance their competitiveness in international markets," she said, calling a free trade pact a "win-win situation."
She strongly disputed assertions that jobs would be lost or that standards would slide in the United States as a result of a trade agreement.
A number of Government studies, including ones published by the Labor Department and the International Trade Commission, have projected overall benefits for the economy.
On the question of environmental standards, she said environmental issues might needlessly complicate an agreement about lowering tariffs and other trade matters, but stressed that the Administration still "wants to insure that Mexico does as much as is humanly possible to protect the environment."

HEADLINE: Consumer Prices Up By 0.4%

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20

 BODY:
The Consumer Price Index climbed four-tenths of 1 percent in January, and twice as much if gyrating food and energy costs were excluded. But economists said inflation at the retail level was not as bad as it seemed.
Separately, new housing activity skidded to its lowest levels since the early 1980's, with builders starting just 850,000 new homes and apartments at an annual rate, 12.8 percent below the depressed December level. Permits for future construction fell 4.7 percent. 
 Taken together, the reports provided a mixed reading of economic performance last month, with the price figures tending to support the notion that downward momentum was being contained and the housing figures reflecting an industry mired in deepening recession.
 
War and the Credit Crunch
 Even housing, however, was said by various specialists to have shown signs of rebound in early February.
"Hopefully, we are near the bottom of this recession," said Mark Tipton, president of the National Association of Home Builders. He attributed the January drop in housing starts to a sharp decline in consumer confidence before the outbreak of war in the Persian Gulf and "a severe credit crunch," or a reluctance of banks to make loans.
Patrick C. Jackman, the Labor Department official who supervises the data-gathering for the price index, said most of the unexpected jolts in today's report could be explained away and that inflation seemed likely to remain in check.
"If I were Mr. Greenspan, I certainly would not change my policy based upon these numbers," Mr. Jackman said, referring to Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve.
 
Greenspan's Forecast
 Indeed, the Fed chief projected at a Congressional hearing today that consumer prices would rise by 3.25 to 4 percent this year, down from 6.1 percent in 1990. The Fed chairman also said that he expected a recovery "reasonably soon," but saw risks to the economy from the war, the health of the banking system and availability of credit. [Page D19.]
The consumer price figures, which were worse than expected, pushed up interest rates in early trading in the credit markets, but upon closer examination traders and investors appeared to have decided that there was little danger of a sustained rise in inflation.
Much of the increase reflected the imposition of luxury and other taxes on Jan. 1 and presumably temporary advances for new cars, resort lodging and fresh fruits and vegetables.
"The rate of inflation is likely to be lower" in coming months, said Richard D. Rippe, chief economist at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. He contended, for example, that a 1.3 percent January jump in the price of new cars, the biggest increase since May 1981, was unlikely to be repeated anytime soon.
 
1991 Models Costlier

The Labor Department said the January rise reflected the continued introduction of higher-priced 1991 models as well an end to rebates on some models. The introduction of new models, starting in the fall, has been slower than usual this year.
The four-tenths of 1 percent rise in the January Consumer Price Index covering all urban consumers followed two months of three-tenths of 1 percent increases. It was marked, among other things, by a 2.4 percent drop in the price of energy, and was partly offset by a nine-tenths of 1 percent jump in the price of food and beverages.
Exceptionally cold weather in late December, especially in California, sent some food prices soaring, with oranges up 37.2 percent and lettuce up 24.5 percent. The price of alcoholic beverages advanced a record 4.9 percent, partly reflecting a Jan. 1 rise in Federal excise taxes but also reflecting industry increases put through at the same time.
Cereal and bakery products jumped 1.3 percent, but dairy products fell for the third straight month and beef, pork and seafood also fell.
 
Housing Component Up
 The housing component also rose much faster than in December, increasing eight-tenths of 1 percent. That was the largest increase since mid-1982. A big factor, however, was a 6.8 percent jump in out-of-town lodging costs, reflecting greater-than-usual increases in vacation areas. Mr. Jackman speculated that advertised hotel and motel discounts applied mostly to weekend and other brief trips and not to longer stays.
But household fuels also rose 1.5 percent as increases for electricity and natural gas -- up 2.8 percent and 1 percent, respectively -- more than offset a 5.6 percent drop for fuel oil. Local phone service rose 4 percent.
The transportation component dropped 1.2 percent as gasoline fell 6.9 percent and used cars, tires and automobile body work also cost less. Besides new cars, the cost of auto financing rose and there was another sharp increase in airline fares that brought the advance to 13.4 percent over the latest five months.
Apparel jumped 1 percent, reflecting smaller-than-usual price reductions for fall and winter clothing, as well as an earlier-than-usual introduction of higher-priced spring and summer clothing, the department said. The subindex for watches and jewelry climbed 4.3 percent, partly reflecting the new Federal luxury tax.
 
Medical Costs Rise

Medical care rose six-tenths of 1 percent last month, somewhat less than the eight-tenths of 1 percent average in the second half of 1990, while the "other" goods and services category rose seven-tenths of 1 percent for the third straight month. The latter category includes tobacco, on which taxes were also raised last month, and school tuitions.
The eight-tenths of 1 percent increase in the so-called core inflation rate that excludes food and energy compared with a four-tenths of 1 percent average monthly rise in 1990.
Before rounding, the consumer price index covering all urban consumers rose 0.4470939, a rate that if maintained and compounded over 12 months would produce annual inflation of 5.5 percent.
Prices in the New York City area rose 1 percent last month, today's report also showed, with one of the main factors being the jump in out-of-town lodging. Mr. Jackman said that if many New Yorkers wintered in, say, Miami the cost of Miami lodging would be incorporated in the New York inflation rate.
The index now stands at 134.6, which means that a basket of goods and services that cost $10 in 1982-1984 now costs $13.46.
The C.P.I.-W covering urban wage earners and clerical workers also advanced four-tenths of 1 percent last month following two months of minimally smaller increases.
Housing Starts
The housing figures, which are compiled by the Commerce Department, showed that starts of new homes ran at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 850,000 last month, down from 975,000 in December and barely half the 1,543,000 started in January 1990, which was exceptionally warm. Last month's was also the lowest since January 1982, which had an annual rate of 843,000 units.
Single-family dwellings accounted for most of the decline, falling 15.6 percent to a rate of 632,000, the lowest since June 1982, when 613,000 houses were started at an annual rate. Buildings with five or more units accounted for 189,000 at an annual rate, with smaller multiple-dwellings accounting for 29,000.
By region, the drop in the Northeast was just under 30 percent, to a rate of 77,000 a year. The Midwest and South had 15 percent declines, to 198,000 and 340,000, respectively, while the West posted a tiny advance to 235,000.
Amid the gloomy figures, however, the home builders' group and other analysts said they see some signs of revival. Mr. Tipton, of the home builders association, said he expected construction to begin rising after another two months or so because of lower interest rates, a restoration of confidence and evidence from a survey in the first half of February showing 42 percent of builders experiencing "high to average" traffic in their subdivisions, up from 24 percent who ranked traffic that high a month earlier.
Mr. Rippe of Dean Witter also found "some positive signs" emerging in housing, including a faster rate of sale of existing homes and increasing affordability of housing over the past six months.
Permits for future construction fell 4.7 percent last month to a rate of 804,000, 5 percent below the revised December rate of 844,000 and far below the 1,739,000 rate of January 1990 when there was a rush to beat new Federal requirements for accessibility by the handicapped to multi-family dwellings.
Permits for single-family units were 6 percent lower, at an annual rate of 606,000, with the rate about unchanged at 99,000 in the Northeast, modestly higher at 187,000 in the Midwest and lower in the South and West with 301,000 and 217,000, respectively.
The Commerce Department's report also showed that shipments of mobile homes for December ran at a rate of 167,000, 8 percent less than in November.

HEADLINE: Washington Talk;
Discreet Maneuvers Over War Issue

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20

 BODY:
Much of American politics has seemed frozen since the war began in the Persian Gulf, and few expect that to change very soon. Even so, beneath the seeming truce on partisan maneuvering, professionals in both parties are engaged in quiet, careful efforts to manage the war issue as they head into the 1992 campaign.
These efforts vary widely. In recent week, newspapers have begun receiving strikingly similar letters to the editor urging support for the troops and denouncing the attention given to war protesters. The campaign, it turned out, was courtesy of the Republican National Committee, which mailed sample letters to 500,000 regular party contributors, suggesting they send the missives to their local newspapers. 
 Campaign committees in both parties are conducting war-related research on Congressional voting records. Republicans are trying to build a case that Democrats opposed not only the resolution authorizing the use of force in the Persian Gulf, but also many of the weapons that have proven so effective there. For its part, the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee sent members home for last week's recess with statistics and "talking points" about the party's "major role in insuring that we purchase the right weapons and weapons that work."
At the level of Presidential politics, the war has chilled any overt maneuvering by Democratic hopefuls; this is not the time to make a case against the Commander in Chief. But perhaps even more significantly, the war has raised anew an issue that has haunted Democratic candidates for at least a decade: national security.
The speeches of Senator Phil Gramm of Texas, chairman of the National Republican Senatorial Committee and an influential party strategist, offer a taste of what could come, if the war goes well: "I think it is important that we remember and that we not let the American people forget that had Jimmy Carter, Walter Mondale and Michael Dukakis been elected President, the Berlin Wall would still be standing and Saddam Hussein would be in Saudi Arabia today."
The Democrats' strategic imperative is getting the political debate back to domestic issues -- notably the economy. "My assumption is this: that the key and most pressing and most salient issues in 1992 are going to be the economy and the domestic agenda," said Ronald H. Brown, the chairman of the Democratic National Committee. "We certainly would hope and trust that by that time, the war will be long over."
Some Democrats are trying to jump-start the domestic debate by casting issues like the pending civil rights bill, which supporters say would reinforce legal protections against job discrimination, in terms of what it would mean for American soldiers in the gulf. In the meantime, Democratic Congressional leaders have carefully closed ranks with the White House and expressed, again and again, support for the troops.
Geoffrey Garin, a Democratic poll taker, said: "I don't think we've had as powerful a symbol in America for a long time as we have in the troops. They are going to be the political icons for the next cycle."
The Republicans face their own obvious risks in the Persian Gulf war, first and foremost the impact of American casualties when and if a ground offensive begins. One prominent consultant said last week that the worst case for his party was a prolonged war and an economy still stalled in recession in 1992. Republicans still remember the slide Mr. Bush took in the public opinion polls during last fall's budget struggle.
All of this strategizing and planning is, to a large extent, muted and subterranean; both parties are keenly aware of how little the public likes the notion of seeking partisan advantage from a war. Perhaps the clearest measure of this came when the White House quickly distanced itself from the remarks of the new Republican chairman, Clayton K. Yeutter, who said that Democrats in the 1992 campaigns would come to regret their votes against the use of force.
A senior Republican said: "It's in the Republicans' best interest for support for the war to stay bipartisan now. That was Yeutter's mistake. At the end of the day, the President will get credit, and at the end of the day, if the war goes well, those who supported it will get credit. But there's plenty of time for that to happen."
Meantime, beneath the surface, both parties are planning for the time when the truce no longer applies.

HEADLINE: Senate Vote Revives Sanctions for a Role In Chemical Arms

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20

 BODY:
The Senate passed legislation tonight requiring the President to impose sanctions on countries and companies developing or using chemical or biological weapons.
President Bush rejected an almost identical measure last year. But Congress had adjourned by the time he announced his decision and there was no chance to try to override a veto. Mr. Bush said then that he could not accept the bill because it did not give him the authority to waive all sanctions if he thought the national interest required him to. 
 But tonight, the White House accepted the bill after Senator Bob Dole, Republican of Kansas, the minority leader, and Senator Jake Garn, Republican of Utah, pressed for acceptance of only modest changes. These amendments would allow Mr. Bush to delay the imposition of sanctions against foreign companies while he sought to get their own governments to punish them. The Dole-Garn amendment did not allow any delays or waivers in sanctions against countries that use poison gas or germ warfare.
The amendment and the bill itself were passed without opposition on roll-call votes. It was clear all along that the bill had enough support to pass, and perhaps to overcome a veto. Last year, the Senate adopted it, 92 to 0.
Among the leading Republicans speaking for mandatory sanctions was Senator Jesse Helms, the conservative North Carolina Repbulican. He insisted that failure to impose sanctions against Iraq for using poison gas, and against German companies that had aided Baghdad, had encouraged those companies to help Libya, too.
The bill, the Omnibus Export Amendments Act, also included provisions that would ease controls on exports of high technology to East European countries if they agreed to protect that technology; establish procedures for updating lists of prohibited exports; reauthorize and expand export-promotion activities of the Commerce Department, and extend the Export-Import Bank subsidy program to help support American exports.

HEADLINE: Bank of America Cuts Prime Rate to 8 3/4%

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH

 BODY:
The Bank of America, the nation's second-largest bank after Citibank, said yesterday that it was cutting its prime lending rate to 8 3/4 percent from 9 percent.
The cut by the huge San Francisco-based bank, which takes effect today, comes less than three weeks after many banks lowered their rates from 9 1/2 percent, and less than two months after all of the nation's largest banks, almost in unison, cut their prime rates to 9 1/2 percent from 10 percent. 
 The prime rate, which once applied only to business loans, now has a wider impact. Home equity lines of credit, credit-card interest rates, mortgage rates and even some traditional installment loans like auto loans have increasingly been tied to the prime. A reduction therefore could be felt by a broad spectrum of borrowers.
Frank McCormick, senior economist at the Bank of America, said the bank's rate decision was in large part a reaction to a general decline recently in the bank's cost of funds -- money it borrows and re-lends to customers at higher interest rates.
But the timing, Mr. McCormick said, was dictated by comments made yesterday by the Federal Reserve Board chairman, Alan Greenspan, in testimony to Congress.
"Chairman Greenspan left the door open to a further decline in short-term interest rates," he said. In fact, Mr. Greenspan told the Senate Banking Committee that "the Federal Reserve will need to remain alert to possible contingencies and will have to continue to respond flexibly to information about evolving trends."
Many market analysts interpreted those words to mean that the Fed would like to see lower interest rates, which might push the rates for Treasury bills and certificates of deposit down further.
Still, those factors would affect all banks, and as of close of business yesterday, none of the other large banks had taken a similar step. Bank of America announced its cut after the banks on the East Coast had closed.
P. Kenneth Ackbarali, the senior economist for First Interstate Bancorp in Los Angeles, expects, however, that by early next week most major banks, including his own, will have followed suit. He noted that certificates of deposit, a good indicator of the cost of money to banks, have been trading at around 6.55 percent, and that the Federal funds rate, which banks charge each other on overnight loans, has been dropping.
"We're surprised at the timing of Bank of America's move, but there is definitely overwhelming pressure on the banks to lower the rate," Mr. Ackbarali said. "And if we all do -- and if consumers think the gulf war will be short, as they seem to lately -- then it will have a stimulating impact on the economy."
 
 Other Views

But Robert Giordano, the director of economic research at Goldman, Sachs & Company in New York, thinks the opposite.
"What Bank of America is doing is aggressively going after other banks' market share, because most of the other major banks are under too much earnings pressure and too many capital constraints to follow suit," he said.
Robert Brusca, chief economist at Nikkko Securities International Inc. in New York, told The Associated Press that he expected banks would be slow to follow suit. "In fact," he said, "this time I would expect that until the Fed really signals another move, we could have a split prime rate."

HEADLINE: Transit Deficit Has Tripled in 7 Weeks

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

 BODY:
New York City transit officials said yesterday that the Transit Authority's budget deficit had tripled since the beginning of the year to an estimated $215 million.
The shortfall is likely to force officials not only to raise bus and subway fares but also to cut services. It has been caused by a combination of proposed cuts in state aid, a drop in ridership and declining revenues from the city's real-estate taxes, the officials said. 
 The Transit Authority's executive director said he was certain that fares would need to rise to more than $1.25 from the current $1.15 and that the authority would seek an increase of more than 10 cents from the Metropolitan Transportation Authority board.
 
'A Graver Situation'
 Last Friday, officials estimated that the budget gap would be $130 million to $140 million.
But new information indicates that revenues will be lower, said Mortimer L. Downey, executive director of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which oversees the Transit Authority. In addition, last year's deficit of up to $15 million must be made up, he said.
"We are faced with a graver situation than we thought, and we have to move much quicker," said David A. Winfield, the Transit Authority's executive director.
Mr. Winfield said a number of factors have increased the projected budget gap to $215 million from the $70 million estimated in January. Among them are these:
*A decrease in ridership in January. Far fewer people rode the system than expected, meaning fare receipts for the year could be $38 million less than anticipated.
*A possibility of decreased revenues from taxes on real-estate transactions. Based on January receipts, these revenues may be $37 million less than expected. Transit officials also said they expected a shortfall in revenue from the mortgage recording tax of $40 million to $45 million.
*Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's budget proposal to cut $12 million from state subsidies. The State Legislature will be debating that budget soon, and the M.T.A. is expected to lobby hard for more money.
*A decrease in municipal subsidies based on real-estate taxes. Officials said the subsidies were $10 million below expectations for November and December.
 
Possible Funds Shift
 Given the swelling deficits, Mr. Winfield said, a fare increase of more than 10 cents is certain. "This is coming faster and harder than we can deal with it, and we thought a 10-cent adjustment could handle it," he said.
Transit officials hope a fare increase could go into effect in the next few months.
Mr. Winfield said it could be necessary to shift money planned for improving the subway and bus systems to subsidize operating costs.
The projections were announced at a meeting of the M.T.A. finance committee. Speaking to committee members, Mr. Downey said an increase of more than a dime would be difficult, logistically as well as politically.
Recalling the lines of riders that were created when token clerks, used to selling $1 tokens, had to make change for $1.15 tokens, he said: "Remember that the amounts you come up with for the T.A. can be awkward -- $1.29? If they can do it for stamps. . . ."
The acting M.T.A. chairman, Daniel J. Scannell, broke in, saying, "And you've seen the lines at the post office."
State legislators who represent the metropolitan region said they would fight efforts to raise the fare or cut services.
 
Role of Legislators
 "At this point, further service cutbacks and a fare hike are just going to create a spiral of decline which can destroy the whole system," said Jerrold Nadler, chairman of the Assembly Corporations, Authorities and Commissions Committee.
But legislators also said they would oppose Mr. Cuomo's proposal to cut $12 million in combined state and city aid to the mass-transit system. "The best investment the State of New York could make in economic development is to shore up the transit system of the City of New York," said State Senator Franz S. Leichter, Democrat of Manhattan.
Mr. Nadler, also a Manhattan Democrat, said he, too, would work to dedicate to mass transit a portion of the 10-cent increase in the gasoline tax that the Governor has proposed. Both Mr. Nadler and Mr. Leichter said trimming the Transit Authority headquarters staff could help narrow the budget gap.
Mr. Downey said the agency had already cut about 250 management positions and had frozen salaries, and he said staff reductions alone would not repair the budget. "The T.A. went through a pretty painful process of eliminating the fat already, and I think all the significant savings have already been realized from that process," he said.
 
'Not Crying Wolf'

Gene Russianoff, a staff lawyer for the Straphangers Campaign, a transit users group, said legislators would have to choose between raising more tax revenue for mass transit or listening to their constituents complain about increased fares and decreased service.
The M.T.A. is "not crying wolf on this deficit," he said. "They're crying reality. Legislators will have to decide what's more politically painful: enacting new transit taxes or letting the fare go up to as much as $1.40 in April or May, and I don't think there's any avoiding that dilemma."
Stephen B. Dobrow, director of the Committee for Better Transit, another consumer group, said that unlike in the mid-1970's, when the state bailed the city and its transit system out of bankruptcy, the state now has its own financial crises.
"If it was only the transit mess, it wouldn't be so bad, but it's an everything mess," he said. "Everything is more difficult because there are so many problems at the same time."
 
Labor Talks
 Mr. Downey also said the Transit Authority's problems could worsen. In estimating a $215 million gap, he said: "We've taken a mid-range on the ridership loss and a mid-range on the taxes. If everything went to the downside, it would be a larger number."
He said the biggest variable in the deficit calculations was the labor negotiations that are planned.
Mr. Downey said the Transit Authority expected to realize as much as $45 million in savings through greater investment earnings from its pension fund, which is managed by the city.
But he warned that labor negotiations, which will begin this spring, might consume those savings. The Transit Authority budget provided for a 1.5 percent wage increase, but the city recently negotiated increases of more than twice that for teachers and other employees.

HEADLINE: For Record Companies, A Battle of the Parties

BYLINE: By STEPHEN HOLDEN

 BODY:
In the past two days, gripped by Grammy fever, the major record companies have been fighting what one press agent called "the battle of the bashes," trying to outdo each other in lavish, imaginative party-giving.
It all began on Tuesday night at the Plaza Hotel, where Clive Davis, the president of Arista Records, gave a cocktail party and sitdown dinner for 500 guests. The gala exemplified the giddy mixture of civic and corporate pride surrounding the Grammys, which this week brought an estimated 6,000 people to New York and made the city feel like Hollywood East. 
 Mr. Davis's party was attended by most of the major record company presidents, and by such celebrities as Brooke Shields, Mort Zuckerman and M.C. Hammer. The evening featured entertainment by Arista artists, including Nick Ashford and Valerie Simpson, Kenny G and Jeffrey Osborne, and culminated in an all-star finale of "Reach Out and Touch Somebody's Hand."
The Arista party overlapped with two official functions involving the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences. A thousand people, including Mayor David N. Dinkins, attended an early-evening party at the Rainbow Room welcoming past and present Grammy nominees. In his speech, the Mayor urged those present to use their positions as artists to speak out against racism and to address social issues. The chairman of Warner Communications, Steve Ross, was the host of a party at Gracie Mansion attended by Quincy Jones and Phil Collins, among others.
 
New York in Miniature
 At a cost of $250,000 last night, the Time-Warner labels (Warner Brothers, Elektra and Atlantic) turned Roseland into a replica of New York City, complete with a graffiti-embellished subway station, a miniature Central Park, assorted ethnic eating places and a Donald Trump look-alike selling hot dogs.
The Polygram labels spent almost as much to transform the Ritz, on West 54th Street, into a New Orleans Mardi Gras environment, while the Sony labels took over the entire Rainbow complex on the 65th floor of the General Electric Building. Capitol-EMI and its associated record companies occupied 21. MCA Records celebrated at the Four Seasons and RCA at Tatou, on East 50th Street.
The hoopla was an indication of just how confident the nearly $7 billion record business continues to be in the face of the recession and the Persian Gulf war. While there have been ominous predictions of a downturn in the concert business, record sales have remained stable. The parties also demonstrated just how important the Grammys have become to the industry, both in prestige and in economic impact.
"The public has come to look to the Grammys as a signal that a star has really arrived, and the impact can be enormous," the president of Sony Records, Tommy Mottola, said yesterday. "Depending on the timing, a Grammy win can increase the sales of an album by anywhere from half a million to two million albums."
 
Rap Is Bumped
 A major-category nomination alone can have a significant impact. "Mariah Carey," the debut album of a Mottola protegee, received five nominations. In next week's Billboard, the three-million selling album reaches No. 1 on the pop album chart for the first time. It is the first non-rap album to top the chart in well over six months. The impact of several nominations has also strongly affected the sales of the debut on SBK Records of the South California trio Wilson Phillips.
Charles Koppelman, the head of SBK Records, credited the MTV cable channels with helping to make the difference. "MTV and VH1 have been a major contributor to the Grammys by expanding the audience tremendously," Mr. Koppelman said. "Because it's a visual medium you have much greater identification with the artists. That visual identification gives the Grammy telecast a greater impact."
Beyond its impact on specific records, the Grammy festivities show just how much record companies value their images as imaginative, free-spending enterprises. Record companies live or die on the quality of the talent they attract. Given the steadily rising costs of producing records and music videos, the signing of a new pop act represents a minimum investment of $500,000.
As one weary press agent explained: "For every record company, this is a time when you show off your stars. In this business, success is so much a matter of perception. If people perceive you as being successful, they'll give you other good artists, because success breeds success."

HEADLINE: Decorating Simply Without Sacrificing Standards

BYLINE: By SUZANNE SLESIN

 BODY:
THESE are the times that try New Yorkers' stressed-out souls.
Tassels and brocade and Biedermeier period rooms and "Bonfire of the Vanities" details do not seem to fit the spirit of this interior decorating moment. Yet decorating goes on: these days New Yorkers seem to be having fun and trying not to spend too much on stylish, livable rooms. Call it the sophisticated new homeyness. 
 "Welcome to the chateau," is the usual wry greeting that Marc Manigault, a stylist, gives visitors to his West Side apartment. "I tried to keep it cozy and simple so people can just relax here, without running out somewhere."
Howard and Mindy Partman, who are fashion retailers, see it this way: "Creativity and color are what keep us going and make us feel good."
And as Barbara Toll, the owner of an art gallery in SoHo, said, "I was not interested in coming home and lying in bed and looking at more art."
A stylist who specializes in boutique windows, a couple who design and sell trendy clothes and a dealer in contemporary art: these are people who earn their livelihoods by being attuned to the moment. And this, they feel, given the economy and a war, might not be the most appropriate moment to get carried away about decorating. They might be earnest about their design standards, but right now they are sure enough of their taste to keep things simple.
"Wood floors and basic beige walls -- that was it," said Mr. Partman, who moved into his 1930's apartment building just before his wedding a year ago. It is within walking distance of San Francisco, the couple's clothing store on Lexington Avenue between 70th and 71st Street.
They asked Ivan Dolin, a friend and interior decorator, for help, and he told them " 'Don't get too involved; after all, it's a rental,' " Mrs. Partman said. "We were tired of everything that was overdone."
The Partmans brought their individual collections to their new shared home. He likes furniture -- a chair by Ettore Sottsass, modern lamps, a 60's portable bar -- preferably with a strange twist. She collects eyeglasses ("dozens and dozens") and handbags ("they have to be hangable") and flea-market finds.
Among them are the medieval-style painted wood heads above the fireplace. The fireplace wall was given Mr. Dolin's ripped-wallpaper treatment.
"I wanted an alternative to an expensive mantel," Mrs. Partman said.
Mr. Dolin added: "It was very expensive and came from England, but we didn't need that much. The magenta color clashed with everything we had already. That was perfect."
He emphasized the Partmans' brightly hued minimalist look with bold black and white tiles for the kitchen floor, large rugs made out of vintage carpet runners and a sweeping 50's turquoise sofa with triangular yellow pillows. Mr. Dolin painted a frame around the window so the couple could forgo fancy window treatments.
"We were willing to spend some money," Mr. Partman said, "but it became more challenging to find ways of not having to."
"Freebies" was the way Mrs. Partman described the green vinyl chairs at their kitchen table. "They came from a restaurant my father had years ago, and we found lots of them in my mother's basement."
One of the couple's first tiffs revolved around a 1920's children's piano, which Mrs. Partman brought home from a flea market.
" 'Where will you put it?' " she remembered his asking. "I said I didn't know."
The piano is now a night table.
Ms. Toll's decor is "nonaggressive, noncompetitive and nonarbitrary," according to Michael Formica, a Manhattan interior designer who helped her with her SoHo loft.
His first impression of the art dealer's dark loft was "all-brown, even though there was nothing brown in it." He suggested Ms. Toll paint the quarry tile floor white.
"I suddenly felt optimistic," his client recalled.
Mr. Formica also suggested that the space could be "pretty." That clinched the job.
Though Ms. Toll wanted a large painting to be the focus in the living and dining rooms, she did not want art to dominate the bedroom and sitting room that are now her private oases on the island of Manhattan.
In the living room area, balloon shades made out of muslin filter the light and provide privacy from the street. But because there was hardly any natural light in the bedroom, the 12-foot high wall behind the bed was a good place to display Ms. Toll's always-evolving collection of drawings.
"It works," she said, "because if I sit in the sitting room part of the bedroom I can look at the drawings, but I don't have to if I'm in bed."
Apart from the mismatched French Art Deco night tables, the most striking element in the bedroom is the curved upholstered headboard and its matching striped pillows.
"I saw it as a funny play on the teen-age room of the 60's," Ms. Toll said. They made it "in a severe material to make it look less frilly."
The synthesis of art and decor reaches its subtle peak in the dining room, where it's hard to tell art from furniture.
On one wall, a dark red vinyl-covered chair is poised next to a painting of pastel stripes. "It's by John Armleder and one piece of art," she said. "The chair was found on the street, and its tufted buttons provide the circular counterpoint to the painting."
On the adjacent wall, eight Italian leather-backed chairs are lined up like a small regiment under a painting by Louise Fishman, "as if they were waiting in a ballroom for an event," Ms. Toll said.
Mr. Manigault, who shares a two-bedroom co-op apartment with Masazumi Chaya, the ballet director of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, furnished the high-ceilinged rooms with overscale seating and accessories to avoid clutter and emphasize dramatic effects.
Huge black pots sit atop tall columns and frame the dining room table. In a corner, an impressive forest of bamboo reaches to the ceiling.
"We have light, but no direct sunlight," Mr. Manigault said. "The banana and fishtail trees and even the palms all died."
Mr. Chaya came up with the solution: crisscrossed thick bamboo poles that go from pebbled planter to the 12-foot ceiling. They require no maintenance -- and they cannot be ignored.
Mr. Manigault approached the den with the same bold strokes. He installed a wall of shelving for his records, compact disks and videotapes, a mountain of stereo equipment and three large television sets.
"I love TV," he said. "And I have to be able to tape 'Knots Landing' when I'm watching 'L.A. Law.' "
A few months ago, when Mr. Manigault's mother came to visit, she wanted to watch her favorite soap opera. "There were 12 remote controls," he said, "and she turned everything on except the TV."
He added, "The next day she decided to go to stay at my sister's, where things are simpler and where, she said, you don't need a college education to work the TV."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Mets' New Offer Doesn't Overwhelm Gooden

BYLINE: By JOE SEXTON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., Feb. 20

 BODY:
With Dwight Gooden's deadline for a contract extension 48 hours away, the Mets said today that they had mailed a revised offer to the right-hander that would make him the third-highest-paid player in baseball.
Frank Cashen, the team's general manager, said at a news conference in his office here that the proposal was for three years and that its annual value fell between the $4.05-million-a-year deal the Dodgers awarded Darryl Strawberry and the $4.7 million Jose Canseco is collecting from the Oakland Athletics. Roger Clemens, whose new deal is worth more than $5 million a year, is the highest-paid player. 
 "It's a new and improved offer," said Cashen. "And I make no apologies for it."
 
Agent Seems Flexible

 It stands, though, to make only modest headway in the negotiations with Gooden. The 26-year-old ace of the staff, who with a career record of 119-46 has the highest winning percentage of any pitcher in history with 100 or more triumphs (.721), has insisted for weeks that he wants an extension for four years at a yearly rate that compares with the four-year, $21.5 million deal the Red Sox signed with Clemens.
 Gooden has maintained that if an extension is not signed by Friday he will end negotiations with the Mets and declare for free agency at the end of the season.
"Of course, that won't get it done," James Neader, Gooden's agent said of the deal as described by Cashen. "But it at least will initiate talk. It gives us the chance to get it done."
Neither Neader nor Gooden, however, was prepared to say that the offer represented enough encouraging movement for the Feb. 22 deadline to be removed. Both, though, expressed mystification at why the Mets had waited so long to begin negotiations in earnest and then chosen to complicate them further by mailing their offer instead of delivering it more directly.
"It's their choice, their doing," said Gooden, who sounded distinctly unimpressed by the offer. "We'll find out if they are right or wrong."
 
Due to Report Today
 Gooden, who is in the final year of a contract that will pay him $2.25 million this season, is scheduled to report here Thursday for the opening of spring training. Neader said that there was no chance Gooden would not report, but indicated that Gooden was entirely prepared to finish out the contract with the Mets and that he remained fully confident he could attract a contract comparable to Clemens's in the free-agent market next fall.
"Dwight Gooden can command those dollars whether it's now or later," Neader said. The agent added that plans were in place for Gooden to take out a multimillion-dollar insurance policy to safeguard himself against injury if he decided to end negotiations with the Mets.
Obviously irritated by what he termed the "artificial end date" publicly imposed by Gooden, Cashen took pains to say he considered the former Cy Young Award winner a "special" individual and one the Mets were eager to sign.
 
Holding Firm
 "Dwight Gooden is a valid and vivid part of this organization," said Cashen, who only last November endured an avalanche of criticism after Darryl Strawberry's departure to Los Angeles. "I have not laid down any arbitrary barriers. The negotiating door is always open to him: today, tomorrow, before the start of the season, during the season."
The Mets, it would appear through their repeated references to Clemens's contract as an "aberration," have only opened that door a crack at the moment, and they acknowledged that it could slam shut altogether if Gooden refused to move off the issue of the length of the extension.
"Four years, for me, would be a deal-buster," Cashen said. The general manager said "prudence and logic" as well as a look at the history of long-term contracts for pitchers convinced him that an extension to Gooden of four years would not be in the best interests of the organization.
 
Cashen's Reasoning
 As well, he added that the uncertain financial future of the sport in light of the country's economic recession and the team's steeply escalating payroll -- the Mets, whose payroll of slightly more than $20 million last year was the highest in the National League, expect it to top $30 million in 1992 -- had reinforced his resolve to be cautious in contract negotiations.
"I'm not here to plead poverty on behalf of the Mets," Cashen said. "And however inappropriate I might consider the decision of the Red Sox, we recognize Boston's need and right to do what's right for their organization. But we would defend with equal vigor our right to do what's right for our organization."
Of negotiations with Frank Viola, Cashen said the star left-hander and his agent had taken the "more commendable" route of not installing any deadline and that discussions were expected to continue. Viola's response to the club's preliminary offers has been unenthusiastic.

HEADLINE: Puerto Rico Will Choose, Despite White House;
Civil Rights Issue

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Tom Wicker expresses puzzlement about President Bush's preference for statehood for Puerto Rico in "The 51st State?" (column, Feb. 9). He portrays the President as politically naive. Puerto Ricans are Democrats he suggests; and insinuates that the President, a Republican, is ill advised in wanting Puerto Ricans to have the right to vote in Federal elections.
Mr. Wicker seems to underestimate the value the President places on fairness. I doubt that Mr. Bush is unaware of the possibility that Puerto Ricans would not rally behind the Republican Party under statehood. His endorsement of statehood responds to his knowledge that Puerto Ricans do not enjoy equal treatment as United States citizens. Yet we fight and die for this country side by side with everybody else.
There are more men and women from Puerto Rico in the Persian Gulf today, proportionately, than there are from each of the 50 states. Yet Puerto Ricans did not elect the President that sent them there.
The issue of statehood for Puerto Rico is one of civil rights.
Mr. Wicker portrays Puerto Ricans as opportunists. He argues that statehood would be devastating for Puerto Rico, resulting in the loss of what, to him, are indispensable tax exemptions and in significant unemployment. He suggests that Puerto Ricans prefer statehood anyway because of a welfare mentality: "One reason" -- for the preference -- "is that many islanders are too poor to pay income tax, and statehood would make many eligible for nearly double welfare benefits -- causing an estimated $17 billion rise in Federal outlays for Puerto Rico, a short-term bonanza."
In a poll conducted in Puerto Rico last summer by the newspaper El Mundo and Channel 40 of Puerto Rico, and reported in the national press, those polled ranked considerations about which status would bring more assistance from the Federal Government as last in importance of seven choices they were given. The prospect of more employment opportunities and the right to vote for the President and Congress were clearly the most important issues for Puerto Ricans.
 
GILBERTO PAGAN JR.
President, New Jersey Chapter
National Committee for Puerto Rican Statehood
Colonia, N.J., Feb. 13, 1991

HEADLINE: Louis O. Kelso, Who Advocated Worker-Capitalism, Is Dead at 77

BYLINE: By ALFONSO A. NARVAEZ

 BODY:
Louis Orth Kelso, a lawyer and economist who sought to revolutionize capitalism through employee stock ownership plans, which he invented, died on Sunday at the Pacific Medical Center in San Francisco. He was 77 years old and lived in San Francisco.
He died of a heart ailment, said a spokesman for Kelso & Company, where Mr. Kelso was chairman. 
 For nearly 50 years Mr. Kelso propounded his theory of worker-capitalists, in which workers would borrow money to buy capital assets, including exisiting companies that are automating and eliminating jobs.
 
A Reward for Company
 "The employee stock ownership plan, known as ESOP, was invented to democratize access to capital credit," Mr. Kelso and his wife, Patricia Hetter Kelso, wrote in 1989 in The New York Times.
"In human terms, it is a financing device that gradually transforms labor workers into capital workers. It does this by making a corporation's credit available to the employees, who then use it to buy stock in the company. The earnings of the company itself are used to pay for the stock. The company's reward from an ESOP -- in addition to a motivated work force of worker/owners -- is the low-cost financing of its own capital needs."
The first employee stock ownership plan was put into effect by Mr. Kelso in 1956 to enable the employees of Peninsula Newspapers Inc. in Palo Alto, Calif., to buy the newspaper chain. It has since been used by hundreds of companies, including Avis, Exxon, Standard Oil of California and Atlantic Richfield.
Born in Denver on Dec. 4, 1913, Mr. Kelso received degrees in finance and law from the University of Colorado. He practiced law in Denver with Pershing, Bosworth, Dick & Dawson from 1938 to 1942 and after serving in the Navy in World War II, briefly taught constitutional law and municipal finance at the University of Colorado.
He then moved to San Francisco and became a partner with the law firm of Kelso, Cotton, Seligman & Ray. In 1970, after he failed to persuade conventional banking investors to adopt ownership-broadening financing techniques, he founded Louis O. Kelso Inc. to promote employee stock ownership plans and also founded Kelso Bangert & Company, investment bankers.
 
Presidency of Institute
 Kelso Bangert & Company eventually became Kelso & Company, and Mr. Kelso served as managing director and chief executive. He was also president of the Kelso Institute for Economic Research and was a board member of the Institute for Philosophical Research in Chicago.
It was during his years in the Navy, as an intelligence officer in Panama, that Mr. Kelso first formulated his concept of employee ownership. The idea remained relatively dormant until the mid-1950's, when he met the philosopher Mortimer J. Adler. Together they wrote "The Capitalist Manifesto," published by Random House in 1958. They wrote a second book, "The New Capitalists: A Proposal to Free Economic Growth from the Slavery of Savings," published in 1961 by Random House.
Mr. Kelso refined and expanded on his idea in a third book, "The Two-Factor Theory: The Economics of Reality," published by Random House in 1968. This book, also titled "How to Turn Eighty Million Workers into Capitalists on Borrowed Money," was written with Patricia Hetter, whom he later married.
 
Push for New Laws
 They also collaborated on "Democracy and Economic Power: Extending the ESOP Revolution Through Binary Economics," published by Ballinger Press in 1986 and reissued in January by University Press of America.
Mr. Kelso was instrumental in having Federal and state laws passed to encourage expanded employee stock ownership. He also helped push for changes in the tax laws that were beneficial to employee stock ownership plans.
In addition to his wife, Patricia, he leaves two daughters from a previous marriage, Martha Brookman of Woodside, Calif., and Katie Balestreri of San Francisco, and three grandchildren.
