HEADLINE: In Dinkins Inner Circle, Persistent Disarray

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
More than a year after he took office, Mayor David N. Dinkins's City Hall staff is plagued by internal disarray so persistent and open that other government officials, community groups and even some mayoral aides complain that important policy goals have suffered.
Mr. Dinkins has acknowledged that his administration has problems, saying that the biggest is a general failure to communicate effectively with New Yorkers. But some of his own aides and outside critics say the troubles have deeper dimensions. 
 Mr. Dinkins has long favored a chain of command that delegates much responsibility to his staff. He rides his aides hard butdoes not always make sure that they pull in the same direction, they say. As a result, some of his senior advisers say squabbles among his top aides aggravate what they cite as the Mayor's own weaknesses -- a ponderous style, stubbornness and a schedule so overcrowded that he often rushes from subject to subject.
 
Difficult Interplay
 Commissioners complain that they cannot get to see the Mayor enough, and jockeying is so pronounced among the five Deputy Mayors that in recent interviews some of them harshly criticized each other on the condition that their names not be attached to their remarks.
At the center of the squabbles is thestrange and difficult interplay among the Deputy Mayors. There is Mr. Dinkins's nominal right-hand man, Norman Steisel, who carries the title of First Deputy Mayor but worries, colleagues say, that he lacks the Mayor's unstinting confidence and is thus not always forceful enough with others in the Mayor's inner circle.
For example, Mr. Steisel's staff drafted a plan to combine or eliminate several city agencies as an efficiency move, but then he abandoned the plans when other senior Dinkins aides, with longer personal ties to the Mayor, complained to Mr. Dinkins.
Then there is Bill Lynch, the Deputy Mayor for Intergovernmental Affairs, who is subordinate to Mr. Steisel by title but closer to the Mayor by dint of long service as campaign manager and chief of staff when Mr. Dinkins was the Manhattan Borough President.
Mr. Lynch, a former community organizer as subtle as Mr. Steisel is blunt, has recently mused in an unusually public way about his self-perceived failings in a government role that he is not sure he likes. "He feels he's part of a process that is not serving the Mayor well," one Deputy Mayor sympathetic to him said.
 
Internal Stress
 Aides to both Mr. Lynch and Mr. Steisel say the two deputies like and respect each other but do not always understand each other. In a recent meeting of Deputy Mayors, Mr. Lynch implored Mr. Steisel to "lead us," one senior aide said, and Mr. Steisel's reaction was to ask another aide why Mr. Lynch was playing mind games with him.
This internal stress is becoming more than just a matter for City Hall gossip. Members of the City Council, the State Legislature, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and others have all made unusually pointed criticisms of City Hall's management in recent weeks. Last week, the State Comptroller, Edward V. Regan, warned that mixed messages from the Dinkins administration -- one external sign of the internal confusion -- had endangered the city's credibility in the financial world.
"The management problems are perhaps matters of perception," Mr. Regan said in a speech to the Citizens Budget Commission, an independent watchdog group, "but are illustrated by the often-reported switches in fiscal signals coming from City Hall -- for example, pay raises coupled with layoff announcements."
People who must deal regularly with City Hall -- from politicians and lobbyists to interest groups and reporters -- say they are often unsure who can answer questions definitively, let alone whom to go to for decisions and action.
Mr. Dinkins himself, when asked who could speak authoritatively for the administration, said in a recent interview, "Depends on what it is." He added that he relied on each of his five deputies, or combinations of them, to handle particular areas, and then to make the final decisions with him.
Mr. Dinkins's first year has been unusually difficult, dominated by steadily deepening fiscal problems. He also had to confront both high expectations and deep skepticism as the city's first black mayor, as have other black politicians around the country. But his own aides concede that stresses within the staff have made it harder to cope with such headaches.
Outsiders say the internal problems have slowed adoption of policies and programs on issues from the homeless to labor negotiations to maintaining strong ties to Mr. Dinkins's core electoral coalition of black and Hispanic voters.
 
An Albany Victory
 Ten days ago, Mr. Dinkins won the biggest victory of his administration, securing an agreement with the Legislature on a plan to hire thousands of police officers and expand the justice system, a program the Mayor called "motherhood and apple pie." But politicians in Albany and on the City Council were soured enough by the fight to charge that the victory came despite City Hall's efforts as much as because of them.
Last year, Mr. Dinkins took particular pains to say he would form an administration reflecting the city's diversity. That has thrown a mix of former community advocates together with longtime city officials who have served in a number of administrations but did not know Mr. Dinkins well, like Mr. Steisel.
"The mix between outsiders and insiders produces clashes," said one senior aide who has worked for several mayors. "That's a constant frustration and also a challenge for all of us to recognize and pull together.
"The Mayor compartmentalizes people. To the extent he does that and gives off that impression, it makes it harder to weld a team together."
 
Control Over Schedule
 Mr. Dinkins said he was seeking to assert greater control over his schedule and wanted to meet more often with his commissioners. But he also expressed some annoyance at any suggestion that he is too isolated from the people running his government.
If anyone needs to speak with him, he said, "it's very simple: all you do is call me up and leave a number."
"Whatever complaints they've got," he said, "they cannot say I don't return phone calls."
Other administrations have had troubled first years. Former Mayor Edward I. Koch had well-chronicled staff problems, which led him after 19 months to shrink his staff from seven deputy mayors to three overnight. Another Mayor, John V. Lindsay, lost his press secretary and his chief deputy within his first year in office.
"It's come to be a historical imperative that sometime around the first year there are fireworks at City Hall," said Gordon J. Davis, a former Parks Commissioner who served on Mr. Dinkins's transition team. "I'm surprised there haven't been. I think it's a necessity, but it hasn't happened and I'm not close enough to it to say why."
Mr. Dinkins has given no hints that he plans big changes. So far, the only senior official to resign is the press secretary, Albert Scardino.
Every mayor creates his own structure at City Hall and Mr. Dinkins's is led by Mr. Steisel, a former Sanitation Commissioner as burly as the garbage collectors he once bossed.
But both supporters and critics of Mr. Steisel say his gruffness masks an insecurity with his standing, which leads him at times to be too deferential to his colleagues, hesitating to lead the administration's charges, especially in building political support -- a criticism Mr. Steisel called "ridiculous."
At the same time, these aides say, Mr. Dinkins takes the "first" in Mr. Steisel's title seriously, often making other deputies reluctant or unable to step in.
At Mr. Dinkins's other hand is his chief political aide, Mr. Lynch, who in recent conversations has talked openly about the disappointment of many of the Mayor's grass-roots supporters over the administration's inability to mount new programs.
The old campaigner, Mr. Lynch's friends say, is deeply distressed in a government role he is not sure he likes, but feels powerless to change, and has considered leaving.
Mr. Lynch says he is staying and he rejects suggestions that he is not good at government. "There are some frustrations, sure," he said.
 
Full Confidence
 Mr. Dinkins said that he has full confidence in all his deputies and that they need not always agree. "The awareness that there's more than one perspective, if you will, that's damn healthy and desirable," he said.
But his aides say the differing perspectives do not always get blended.
When two other longtime Dinkins aides, Deputy Mayor Barbara J. Fife, who is in charge of planning, and Deputy Mayor Sally B. Hernandez-Pinero, who is responsible for finance and economic development, complained to the Mayor about proposals to combine or eliminate city agencies under their purview, Mr. Steisel abandoned the plans, which had been drafted at his direction, aides said.
"They know how to play him," one senior aide sympathetic to Mr. Steisel said of the relationships of Mr. Lynch, Mrs. Fife and Ms. Hernandez-Pinero with the Mayor.
The fifth Deputy Mayor, Milton Mollen, a former appellate judge who now oversees public safety, has been most visible as the chief lobbyist for Mr. Dinkins's plan to hire thousands of police officers and expand the justice system.
Mr. Mollen said he viewed passage of the plan as a "victory for determination, and flexibility in dealing with the concerns of the Legislature, even when some of the things were not truly relevant but nevertheless things we had to deal with."
 
'Reeked With Merit'
 But he also said the plan had passed because it "reeked with merit" and conceded that in pressing for it, the administration made some missteps that left it politically vulnerable. When the Council proposed that the five borough presidents have no say in how the money for the crime plan would be spent, the administration intially acquiesced, even though the City Charter specifies that the borough presidents together have the right to jointly propose 5 percent of discretionary mayoral spending.
Only when the borough presidents complained loudly to the Mayor and threatened to sue did the administration agree to include them.
The Mayor and his staff often fail to follow through on the most elemental details of planning. On Feb. 10, Mr. Dinkins appeared at a church fund-raiser for Representative Floyd H. Flake, the Queens minister who has been indicted on charges of diverting church funds to his own use. The stop never appeared on the Mayor's schedule -- an inadvertent lapse, he said. When reporters asked about it, he lectured them on what they had missed.
"I got a very wonderful reception from an audience that was 99.9 percent African-American, at a time when some were suggesting the African-American community was displeased with my trip to Israel, for whatever that's worth," he said.
The Mayor said of his overall efforts: "We're getting some things accomplished that people said we could not get accomplished, and I'm satisfied that it's going to get better because we are smarter every minute. We're learning more and more every day, and I think people to some degree are coming to accept me for who I am and what I am."

HEADLINE: Labor Secretary Makes Careful Overture

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 20

 BODY:
In her first public appearance with the leaders of organized labor, the new Labor Secretary, Lynn Martin, made it clear today that she was unlikely to kick up dust any time soon.
Mrs. Martin showed support for some goals of labor that the Administration has previously endorsed, like removing the "glass ceiling" that often blocks the promotion of women and members of minorities into top management. 
 But she also seemed unlikely to break with President Bush on initiatives he has opposed, like requiring employers to grant leaves to new parents, or civil rights legislation that incorporates what the Administration considers hiring quotas for women and minority workers.
Mrs. Martin, who has been confirmed by the Senate and is to be sworn in Friday, said, "I am a Republican and I work for the President," according to several union presidents who attended her closed-door appearance before the 35-member executive council of the A.F.L.-C.I.O.
 
Briefing by Kirkland
 "She said she was against quotas for civil rights," Lane Kirkland, president of the federation, said at a briefing for reporters. Unions and Democratic leaders in Congress seek legislation allowing workers to use company personnel statistics to support complaints of discrimination against women and minorities. The President vetoed such legislation last year, arguing that it would lead to hiring quotas, an assertion proponents of the bill deny.
As a Republican Congresswoman from Illinois, Mrs. Martin did break with the White House last year. She supported a bill, later vetoed by President Bush, to require employers to allow family leaves after the birth and adoption of children or to attend to seriously ill family members.
Her stance on the bill and on a few other issues, despite an overall voting record that unions judged strongly anti-labor, has raised hopes here that Mrs. Martin might prove the Trojan horse in the White House.
Mrs. Martin gave up her seat in Congress to run against Senator Paul Simon, a Democrat who defeated her in November. Speaking to reporters about her conversations with Mr. Bush about her appointment, she said, "At no time did he suggest that I change."
 
Issue of Replacements
 The family-leave legislation being reintroduced this year is still "a case of mandated benefits, and that's where there's a problem," she said. But she did not indicate whether she, as well as the President, perceived the legislation as a problem.
The issue that most angers unions is the hiring of "permanent replacements" by companies when workers go on strike, and Mrs. Martin revealed little of her own views on the matter. Labor sees the widening use of permanent replacements by strikebound employers like The Daily News in New York, Greyhound and Eastern Airlines as undermining its already greatly diminished place in the economy.
 
Issue of Replacements
 Unions complain that, when employers hire replacements and keep them after a strike, strikers lose their jobs and unions lose their most effective weapon, the strike, in seeking better pay and working conditions. "She hasn't made up her mind" on the issue, Mr. Kirkland said. "That's what she told us."
The Administration has yet to state a position on permanent replacements, but one senior official, who commented only on the condition of not being identified, said he and some colleagues felt that banning the practice, which the law has permitted for more than 50 years but which was rarely used until the 1980's, could lead to waves of strikes and disruption of the economy.
Mrs. Martin and the Administration may have to take a position soon because of widespread expectations that the House of Representatives is close to approving a bill to end the use of permanent replacements. During a visit here Tuesday, the new chairman of the House Education and Labor Commitee, Representative William D. Ford of Michigan, said the bill already has 193 co-sponsors in the House.
Mrs. Martin was quiet on the issue of a resolution supporting a national health care program that the executive council, after hard debate, adopted here. The council voted in favor of having the Government require all employers either to provide health insurance or pay a tax for Government-provided health insurance.
Congressional leaders who visited the labor meeting cautioned unions not to expect quick action on the issue, given the certain opposition of thousands of employers, many of them small, who do not provide insurance.
"I don't think we will do national health insurance in this session," Speaker Thomas S. Foley of Washington told reporters after meeting with the council. "But we'll begin the national debate."
Despite the chilly reception Mr. Kirkland gave the President's announcement of Mrs. Martin's appointment, he and the union presidents received her warmly here, much as they used to receive her predecessor, Elizabeth Dole.
Mrs. Martin adopted much the same conciliatory approach as Mrs. Dole, promising to keep her door open to unions, to funnel their views to the White House and to dwell more on issues on which labor and the White House agree rather than on those they dispute. Unlike any Republican predecessor the union leaders here could recall, she spent three days here, dining and meeting with them and sounding them out -- but without making major commitments on issues.
"We have high hopes, but we're realists," said Morton Bahr, president of the Communications Workers of America. He said he was encouraged by the interest she showed in worker safety and programs to retrain workers who lose jobs in old industries. "But on parental leave, striker replacement, health-care reform, she's going to be on board with whatever the Administration is."

HEADLINE: PRO FOOTBALL;
Robert Tisch Agrees to Buy 50% of the Champion Giants

BYLINE: By GERALD ESKENAZI

 BODY:
Preston Robert Tisch, the billionaire president of Loews Corporation, agreed yesterday to purchase 50 percent of the Super Bowl champion New York Giants for a price believed to be at least $60 million.
"I think it's one of the great franchises in the sports world," Mr. Tisch said. "I grew up as a New Yorker and in Brooklyn." 
 Mr. Tisch, whose brother, Laurence, is chairman of CBS, said he would leave the football operations in the hands of Wellington Mara, who will continue to own the other 50 percent of the club.
 
Concern Over CBS Link
 Paul Tagliabue, the National Football League commissioner, said in a statement yesterday that the agreement to buy the team included a guarantee that there would be "total separation" between the league and CBS, which is one of the five networks that televise N.F.L. games. Loews Corporation owns 22.9 percent of CBS.
"I've never been involved with CBS," Mr. Tisch, who is known as Bob, said when asked if there was a possible conflict of interest. "I'm an outside director of CBS." He said that he was the sole buyer in the deal and that it was being done personally, not corporately. For the deal to go through, it must be approved by 21 of the 28 N.F.L. owners, whose next scheduled meeting is in March.
Mr. Tisch is buying the half of the team owned by Tim Mara -- Wellington Mara's nephew -- and his mother, Helen Mara Nugent, and sister, Maura Concannon. Wellington and Tim Mara have been at odds for years, and even the success of recent seasons, including Super Bowl victories in 1987 and last month, did not end their dispute.
 
'The Time Was Right'
 "We considered selling the team twice before, in 1984 and 1986," Tim Mara, who is 53 years old, said yesterday. "But this is the first one we seriously considered. I just felt that at this point in my life the time was right."
In 1925, the year before Mr. Tisch was born, Timothy Mara, who was Wellington's father and Tim's grandfather, purchased the National Football League franchise for New York for $500 from his earnings as a legal bookmaker. He put it into the Polo Grounds and named it the Giants after the baseball team that played there. Five years later, ownership passed to his young sons, Jack and Wellington, although he retained control.
When Jack Mara died in 1965, his half of the franchise went to his widow, Helen, and his two children, Tim and Maura. The 64-year-old Mr. Tisch, who served as Postmaster General in the Reagan Administration from August 1986 to March 1988, said he would not be involved in football decisions.
"Wellington will continue to be responsible for the day-to-day football operations, and I'll handle the financial aspects," Mr. Tisch said. "I will take an active part in that part of the operation."
 
Young's Role
 He said George Young, the general manager, would continue to have the final say on player contracts.
Mr. Tisch would not put a dollar figure on the transaction. When asked about the purchase price, Tim Mara said $60 million "is low."
More than $60 million would be in line with the estimated value of one of the league's premier franchises. The Giants' ticket revenues exceed $15 million a year. Like all other N.F.L. teams, they will earn $28 million from television this year.
A high-ranking official of another franchise, who insisted on anonymity, said the Giants were worth between $120 million to $130 million. A club owner who spoke on condition of anonymity suggested those figures could be on the low side.
 
Value Hard to Assess
 The value of sports franchises, most of which are privately held, is difficult to estimate because of fluctuations in the market based not only on general economic conditions, but also on the success or failure of the team.
Based on a 20 percent sale, the Chicago Bears, one of the most successful pro football franchises, were valued at $120 million in 1990. In the case of the Giants, total ownership of the team, fresh from a Super Bowl triumph, may be worth even more than twice the value of the half-interest Mr. Tisch is buying.
Financial success, though, could not overcome the animosity between the Maras as the Giants suffered through 15 years of mostly losing football after the glory years of the early 1960's. In 1978 the pair brought their feud into the open over Wellington's desire to bring in a general manager that Tim did not approve of. Finally, in 1979, Pete Rozelle, then the commissioner, stepped in.
 
Team Has Prospered
 On Valentine's Day, Mr. Young was installed as the club's general manager, and, often acting as a buffer between the uncle and nephew, has seen it prosper. There have been two Super Bowl championships, achieved under Coach Bill Parcells, and an unending string of season-ticket sales of all 76,000 seats in Giants Stadium.
Mr. Tisch, of course, is no stranger to prosperity. He and Laurence were estimated by Forbes magazine to be worth $3.1 billion. Between them, their 27.3 percent of Loews is worth almost $2 billion.
The roots of the family fortune trace to 1946 when Laurence, studying law at Harvard, persuaded his parents to sell two summer camps and use the proceeds to buy a hotel in Lakewood, N.J. Robert graduated from the University of Michigan in 1948 with a B.A. in economics, and the brothers invested the hotel's profits and before long had one of the fastest-growing corporations in the country.
Mr. Tisch, who has had a longstanding interest in owning a football team said: "The Giants came into my life last November. Wellington and I had lunch and I heard there was a possibility Helen was selling."

HEADLINE: Doing Business Screen to Screen

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES

 BODY:
By most measures, the business of holding video conferences was a boom waiting to happen. Thanks to an unpredictable confluence of events, ranging from the Persian Gulf crisis, to corporate curtailment of foreign and domestic travel, to a sizable drop in the cost of meeting screen-to-screen, video conference rooms are filling up.
 "It's incredible," says Holly Owens, director of the Sprint Meeting Channel, a unit of U S Sprint based in Atlanta. One big company, she said, has reserved meeting times in 900 video conference rooms on the Sprint network between now and July. The company expects to hold 140 meetings between managers in the United States and foreign cities. "We've never seen anything like that before," Ms. Owens said. "Video conferencing was popular before, but nothing like it has been since January 15," shortly before war erupted in the Persian Gulf. 
This blooming of the video conference comes after important advances in computer chips that helped manufacturers correct balky, slow-motion, screen images and other technical bugs, as well as slash prices. The fully equipped conference room can be outfitted for less than $50,000, down from $90,000 just four years ago. And like just about everything in electronic wizardry, many analysts predict that prices will continue to fall. In fact, the PictureTel Corporation, one of three makers of video conference equipment, recently displayed a complete system priced at $39,700.
 Managers at Air Products and Chemicals Inc. plan to hold 60 hours of video conference meetings between the company's headquarters in Allentown, Pa., and its office outside London this month because of worries about terrorism and travel budget cuts. That is up from 20 hours in January.
 Prior to the war, the company figured that video conferences between Allentown and Houston, where it was working with the Bechtel Corporation to design and build a new polyvinyl plant, had reduced travel expenses by more than $100,000 in the last two years.
 "In some cases, we've cut weeks out of the whole construction process" said Virgil W. Palmer, Air Products' head of telecommunications planning. "We can get key people in two locations to sit down together, work through their problems and issues and then go off and implement the changes without ever having been in the same room."
 
80% Occupancy
 At Brown & Root Inc., an engineering and construction unit of the Halliburton Company, the video meeting room at its Houston headquarters is occupied 80 percent of the time, up from a prewar reservation rate of about 50 percent.
 A group of five research engineers at the Hewlett-Packard Company, in Palo Alto, Calif., canceled a trip to Waldbronn, Germany, a week after the war broke out, but still conducted the meeting as scheduled by using one of the company's 29 video meeting rooms. Reservations at the Hewlett-Packard rooms in Europe have risen nearly threefold this month, said Brad Whitworth, a spokesman.
 Companies that do not have video meeting systems of their own have besieged "public" rooms, like those connected by Sprint, often to tie down reservations for the same times that they had been scheduled to be shaking hands or sipping tea out of town.
 After the war started, a team at J.C. Penney Company postponed a meeting in Japan with a potentially important business contact. But Penney managers recovered by booking a room in Dallas and the session went on virtually as planned Tuesday night.
 "They couldn't travel and we couldn't travel, but this was a way to continue our discussions," said Al Lynch, director of a new division of international development at Penney. "The consensus on both sides was that it was a very successful meeting. The transmission from Japan was very clear.
 " If I were to have my preference, I would have had this as the second meeting, rather than our first. But this was a very meaningful supplement. You do get some rapport, but it's not the same thing." Stunted Growth
 The growth in video conferencing, as dramatic as it has been recently, has also been stunted because most meetings must use coding equipment made by the same producer and must be confined to two rooms. But later this year, when makers of coding devices adopt the same standard for transmitting video images, the possibilities for video conferences will rise. And, within another two years, equipment will be available for groups meeting in several locations simultaneously.
 Video conferencing equipment has been available since the late 1970's, when Compression Labs Inc. of San Jose was founded, but until recently it was scorned as too costly and unworkable. In the early 1980's, users paid $1 million to dress up conference rooms, and then $1,200 for each one-hour, coast-to-coast telephone call to link the rooms. Few companies considered a video conference worth the expense.
 But in the last two years, the prices have fallen so much that many managers eager for alternatives to travel said that the new equipment caused them to take a closer look. Prices for equipment now average about $50,000 a room. Rates for video conference calls over digital networks coast-to-coast are as low as $30 an hour at the slowest transmission speed, down from $96 an hour as recently as 1985.
 
2,500 Video Conference Rooms
 Sales of the boxy computers that compress and reassemble video images, and can transmit them great distances over telephone lines, are rising. The number of meeting rooms equipped for video teleconferences in the United States rose to 2,500 last year, from 700 in 1988, according to American Telephone and Telegraph.
 "The technology and the economic justification for video teleconferencing were catching on very rapidly prior to the war," said Herbert R. Maher, a telecommunications analyst at Tucker, Anthony Inc., in Boston. "But the publicity that it's gotten as a result of the war has caused a lot of people to try it."
 Mr. Maher said revenues for makers of video conferencing equipment increased by 90 percent a year in the last two years, to $110 million in 1990, and will exceed $500 million in 1994. Most equipment sold in the United States is made by three manufacturers: Compression Labs, PictureTel of Peabody, Mass., and VideoTelecom Corporation, of Austin, Tex. Analysts said large Japanese electronics makers, including Sony and Matsushita, will enter the fray soon. The order backlog at Compression Labs, the largest manufacturer with $51.8 million in 1990 sales, has risen to $26 million. "We've got our hands full," said David Belove, a spokesman.
 
Cost Is Falling
 Managers at the Syntex Corporation, which plans to install its first four video conferencing systems in the next year, figured that the average cost of aone-hour video meeting between its headquarters in Palo Alto, Calif., and New York City has dropped to $250, from $750 a year ago.
 The pharmaceutical company, concluded after a four-month study last year that it saved $1,700 in travel expenses each time a video meeting was used in place of a trip. Most people said the video meetings were as useful as face to face meetings.
 Syntex senior executives are counting on video meetings to improve productivity more than anything else, said Hans Wolf, vice chairman and chief administrative officer. Fewer than 4,000 of Syntex's 10,000 employees live and work in the San Francisco Bay area, so many of its scientists and managers travel frequently.
 "We are a research-oriented company operating in every continent except Africa with a very high percentage of professionals, many trained as scientists," he said. "The time of our people is worth a lot more than saving $1,700 a day in travel costs. Our primary goal is to avoid travel."
 For that reason, Syntex is buying equipment for a new site that will open next year 40 miles from its Palo Alto home office in San Jose, as well as for a research unit in Boulder, Colo., and a manufacturing plant in Puerto Rico.
 
Less Travel
 "There won't have to be as much travel between Palo Alto and San Jose," Mr. Wolf said. "It doesn't sound very far, but just the driving can take a couple hours out of your day."
 Video conferences are possible in most major metropolitan areas, where long-distance telephone companies like A.T.&T., Sprint and MCI, which are battling for bigger shares of the growing business, have completed fiber-optic networks required to transmit the digital signals.
 Ellen Curtis, senior product manager at Syntex, said there were limitations to video conferece calls, but overall she is pleased with the technology.
 "Depending on what the purpose of the meeting is, a video conference can be 90 percent as effective as being there in person." she said. "Maybe 100 percent, if your purpose is communicating information. It's a little tougher when you're there for a brainstorming, creative purpose, especially knowing that the dollars are ticking away. That may not be the best utility for it."

CORRECTION-DATE: February 22, 1991, Friday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about video conferences misstated the number of rooms on the Sprint Meeting Channel reserved by one big company after the start of the Persian Gulf war. It was some, not all, of Sprint's 900 rooms.

HEADLINE: WAR IN THE GULF: Iraqi Leader;
Text of Hussein's Radio Speech Dealing With War and Peace

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21

 BODY:
Following is the text of a speech by President Saddam Hussein of Iraq broadcast today on Baghdad Radio, as translated by the Foreign Broadcast Information Service, an agency of the United States Government:
O great people; O stalwart men in our valiant armed forces; O faithful, honest Muslims, wherever you may be; O people wherever faith in God has found its way to your hearts, and wherever it found what embodies it in the sincerity of your intentions and deeds; O lovers of humanity, virtue, and fairness, who reject aggressiveness, injustice, and unfairness. In difficult circumstances and their events, some people -- more often than not -- lose the connection with the beginning and preoccupy themselves with the results -- or forget, when there are resemblances -- the connection between any result and the reasons that gave rise to those events, and on whose basis those results were based. 
 Furthermore, in difficult circumstances, which difficulty is hard to describe, the mind and consciousness are generally preoccupied with what influences the life of the individual concerned with that circumstance. Thus, he bases his opinion and position on it without connecting every individual case with what is collective. The future is even absent at times, or not given very great importance as a indispensable weight for assessing the [inaudible] of each case, regardless of whether that case, or individual item that is being assessed, is connected to the past and present or to the reasons and beginnings, or whether it is part of the results; and regardless of whether it was part of the simple results and individual items, with limited effect, or of the major results that have a comprehensive effect that go beyond the individual, a number of individuals, or only a specific sector in the society, to the society as a whole and where it goes beyond the transient and quick moving present to the future as a whole.
 
The Boycott of Iraq
Some have either completely forgotten these influential facts in the life of man, whether in this or that direction, or the presence of these facts in their minds has become weak. Many facts between causes and effects, or between the prelude to and the results of the circumstances and events that preceded 2 August and what took place on 2 August and afterward, have been missed.

We know that recalling the preludes and causes leading up to the results, and recalling the grounds for an event or events in a permanent manner and in all [inaudible] is not an easy undertaking. HEADLINE: Israel Asserts New U.S. Aid For Housing Is Insufficient

BYLINE: By JOEL BRINKLEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Feb. 21

 BODY:
Only hours after the United States finally approved a long-disputed $400 million in loan guarantees for housing Soviet immigrants, Israeli officials warned today that the sum was grossly insufficient.
"In fact, it's a very small sum that only accounts for 3 or 4 percent of the overall figure," the Immigrant Absorption Minister, Yitzhak Peretz, said today. 
 As he spoke, leaders of the Jewish Agency, the semi-public office with the largest role in immigration matters, were meeting here, working out agreement on the private fund-raising goal for the coming year.
After several days of debate, the agency's leaders said they had decided to seek $1 billion in donations from the world's Jews -- 60 percent more than was raised in the current year's fund-raising drive, already a record.
The new figure would have to be approved by fund-raisers in the United States and Europe. If past practice holds true, American Jews would be asked to contribute about 70 percent of the $1 billion.
 
$10 Billion Need Seen
 Last month, Israel's Finance Minister told a visiting American official that Israel would also need another $10 billion in grants and loans from the United States Government over the next few years. Washington's reception to that request was cool.
The Administration approved the $400 million in housing loan guarantees Wednesday after it had held up the package for a year while negotiating with Israel over assurances that the money would not be used to build housing in the occupied West Bank or Gaza Strip or in neighborhoods of East Jerusalem. The guarantees will enable Israel to get commercial loans at lower rates.
The action came as Israeli officials are lowering their estimate of the numbers of immigrants expected this year because of the Persian Gulf war.
Before the war began, Israeli officials repeatedly said they expected a million Soviet immigrants within two or three years. About 185,000 arrived last year.
But earlier this week, Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir said the gulf war and the Iraqi missile attacks on Israel had forced Israeli officials to revise the estimates.
"Before the war, it looked like this number would arrive within three or four years," he said, including 1990 as one of those years. "Perhaps now it will take another year or two."
 
300,000 Expected This Year
 In the short term, officials say immigration this year is likely to be 25 percent lower than expected -- 300,000 people instead of the 400,000 projected earlier.
About 10,000 Soviet Jews have arrived here in the five weeks since the war began, compared with about 35,000 in December. While fear of attack is an important reason Soviet immigration has dropped, there are others as well.
For one thing, on Jan. 1 Israel seriously reduced the financial benefits given to all new immigrants because the state could no longer afford what it had been offering.
Word of that circulated among Jews in the Soviet Union, and many people who arrived in December said they rushed to get here before Jan. 1.
In one sense, the decline is good for Israel, since the Government is more than a year behind in building housing for the newcomers. The gulf war, with its missile attacks on Israel and attendant problems, has seriously worsened the economic problems already affecting the nation, hindering Israel's ability to absorb the immigrants.
 
Appeal by Shamir
 Those are among the reasons that Mr. Shamir, Mr. Dinitz and others called on the world's Jews to give even more money than the unparalleled donations already given.
"I cannot deal in specific numbers," Mr. Shamir told the group of visiting Jewish leaders, but he then urged his audience to "double and treble your efforts -- and even more."
Even with the increased fund-raising and reduced immigration, the Jewish Agency has still been forced to propose reducing immigrant benefits even more -- changing some gifts to long-term, low-interest loans, for instance.
Mr. Peretz, who competes with Mr. Dinitz for influence in the immigration field, said he thought that would be a mistake.
 
Some Blame Foreign Jews
 "We're expecting that when the crisis ends that we'll return to same numbers as we had in December," he said of the immigrants, "on the condition that the Israeli Government and the Jewish Agency don't cut the aid to immigrants but strengthen it."
Behind all this, some in Israel are blaming foreign Jews for the shortfall in cash, despite the record donations last year.
As an example, an editorial in the daily newspaper Yediot Aharonot on Tuesday complained that Jews who live in other countries "are clenching their fists."
"Russian Jews are their brothers as much as they are our brothers, perhaps even more," the editorial said. "But when it comes to responsibility and sharing it, they, our brothers abroad, disappear. And the gentlemen in the Jewish Agency are left to absorb the complaints and the scorn."

HEADLINE: Market Place;
The Stock Surge At Fannie Mae

BYLINE: By Edmund L. Andrews

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
DESPITE the relentless grim news from banks and savings institutions, the stock of the Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, has been performing well lately.
As a for-profit corporation created by Congress, Fannie Mae buys residential mortgages from banks and savings institutions; it then holds them for its own investment portfolio or packages them into securities for sale to institutional investors. 
 Despite gloom in the real estate market and yawning volumes of problem loans at many banks, Fannie Mae's stock has surged 35 percent since Jan. 1. Shares reached a record high of $47.25 last week and have since eased a bit, closing yesterday at $43.875, unchanged, on the New York Stock Exchange. The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, or Freddie Mac, which performs a similar function, is also seeing its stock move higher.
To be sure, the current market rally has lifted most stocks, but not as much as Fannie Mae's. The Dow Jones industrial average is up about 11.3 percent this year, while the Standard & Poor's index of financial stocks has climbed about 22 percent.
So why the outstanding performance of Fannie Mae? For one thing, the popularity of the stock stems partly from the troubles of lenders elsewhere. Banks and savings institutions have been forced to take huge write-offs for problem loans on office buildings, shopping centers and other failed commercial projects, while Fannie Mae sticks to residential lending. The failed commercial loans have reduced the capital of banks and savings institutions, forcing them to sell more of their residential mortgages to raise cash. The result is a big realignment in the financial services industry, as banks and savings institutions serve more as agents or brokers than as lenders.
According to David S. Hochstim, an analyst with Bear, Stearns & Company, 65 percent of all new mortgages in 1990 were resold to investors in the secondary markets -- up from about 45 percent in 1988 and 1989.
Falling interest rates may give Fannie Mae an additional lift this year. It buys only fixed-rate mortgages, because adjustable-rate loans are impossible to package for investors. Demand for fixed-rate loans tends to increase during periods of low interest rates, as home buyers seek to lock in lower payments.
Yet Fannie Mae's flirtation with new stock highs presents particularly interesting questions for investors. On one hand, earnings have soared tenfold since 1986 -- from $105 million, to $1.1 billion in 1990. Fannie Mae has also had 11 straight quarters of higher profits.
On the other hand, two-thirds of the profits of Fannie Mae come from its own portfolio of mortgages -- loans the company did not repackage as securities but kept for itself. If home prices plummet, as they did in Houston during the mid-1980's and as they are now doing in some parts of the Northeast, Fannie Mae could find its assets far less valuable.
The other risk Fannie Mae faces is exposure tointerest rate changes. If the interest generated from its mortgages fails to keep up with its cost of borrowing, earnings could plunge.
Fannie Mae has tried to insulate itself from that risk, however. Unlike banks or savings institutions, which rely on deposits for funds to lend, Fannie Mae raises money by selling debt securities to institutional investors at rates just above Treasury security rates. That has made it easier to match up income it receives from interest on new mortgages with rates it must pay for funds to buy the mortgages. But investors are still unsure.
Even at its current levels, Fannie Mae's stock still trades at only about 10 times its 1990 earnings. That is on a par with or below the stocks of other lending institutions.
But Bruce Harting, an analyst with Salomon Brothers, argues that Wall Street's judgment has been clouded by the recent disasters in commercial real estate lending, which is not part of Fannie Mae's business. Salomon Brothers estimates that the nation has an oversupply of office buildings that will take eight to ten years to work down. By contrast, Mr. Harting said, housing starts have followed the growth in new households fairly closely.
By law, moreover, Fannie Mae is barred from buying mortgages greater than $191,250. Thus, it steered clear of the most overpriced areas that are now most vulnerable to deflation in housing prices.
In addition, Fannie Mae tightened its underwriting requirements in 1986 and has reduced the foreclosed properties in its inventory from about 10,000 in 1987 to 3,585 in 1990. Loan write-offs last year totaled $233.5 million, about one-tenth of 1 percent of its portfolio and its mortgage-backed securities.
These measures have made Fannie Mae officials confident about the future. "Even at a time when the banks are having extreme difficulty, we're still there," said Timothy Howard, the company's chief financial officer. "There is no credit crunch in housing."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Armco to Lay Off 500 Plant Workers

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: ASHLAND, Ky., Feb. 21

 BODY:
The Armco Steel Company said it would lay off 500 employees at its Ashland plant for 8 to 12 weeks. The company said the layoffs, to begin next month, would be made as it idled some operating units. Company officials blamed the recession and depressed demand for Armco's products for the move. Company officials said about 2,700 employees would remain on the job.
The laid-off workers will collect about 65 percent of their take-home pay through state and company unemployment benefits, an Armco official said. Armco, based in Parsippany, N.J., produces carbon flat-rolled steel for the automotive, appliance, construction and manufacturing markets.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Made in the U.S.A., but by Sharp

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Feb. 21

 BODY:
Japan's largest maker of flat-panel display screens, the Sharp Corporation, said today that it would begin producing some of them in the United States. The announcement appears to be a largely political gesture intended to defuse a new and increasingly contentious high-technology trade dispute.
Sharp is the leading producer of the ultra-thin video screens, which are used in laptop and notebook computers. Its decision -- which is likely to be followed by other Japanese screen manufacturers -- comes less than a week after the Commerce Department accused those manufacturers of selling their products below fair market value.
 
 Following Car Makers' Lead
 
 With its decision, Sharp appears to be following a strategy that has worked brilliantly for Japan's auto makers: to produce a good portion of their product in the United States, with American workers, making it far more difficult for Congress to take punitive or protective measures. Sharp said that in 1993 it plans to produce a half-million screens a year at the United States plant, or roughly a third of its projected market for this country.
The announcement marks the first time that any Japanese maker has moved production of the screens to the United States. There is a smattering of American flat-panel producers, but they are widely considered to be well behind their Japanese competitors and far too small to make the kind of investments needed to produce the screens in volume.
In the coming decade, virtually all computers -- and many types of television sets as well -- are expected to display their information on the sleek, thin panels, experts say, making it increasingly important for the United States that some production technology reside there.
At a news conference here today, Sharp officials said that at least for the first few years, the $30 million, 250-employee plant they are building in Camas, Wash., near Portland, Ore., would perform "final assembly" operations. That means that the most difficult technology involved in manufacturing flat-panel displays -- producing the 10-inch computer screens from silicon, without a single flaw -- would remain in Japan. In the United States, the company will add peripheral electronics and the frame used to mount the screens in various types of computers.
Sharp will produce only its simplest screens in the United States. The most expensive, sophisticated screens, involving color displays that use a new technology called "active matrix," will remain in Japan.
Sharp officials denied that they were moving only a minimum amount of production and technology to the United States in hopes of preventing Congressional action against the Japanese producers.
 
No Economic Reason Seen
 "If you include U.S.-made parts, half the value added of these screens will be in the United States," said Toshio Toda, the deputy general manager of Sharp's liquid crystal display group.
But industry officials said there was no economic advantage for Sharp in producing the screens outside Japan. Because the screens are small and light, and require little direct labor, shipping them around the globe is relatively easy.
"It is a familiar pattern," said John Stern, who heads a trade group office for American electronics makers in Tokyo. "After there are allegations of dumping, production begins to move to America." The term "dumping" refers to the practice of selling screens below the cost of producing and marketing them.
Whether the Japanese are dumping has turned into a divisive issue for American industry. The small American companies working on flat-panel technology, which filed the initial complaints in Washington against Japanese competitors, said that unless the United States took action the domestic industry would slowly die.
But the biggest computer makers in the United States, including the International Business Machines Corporation and Apple Computer Inc., pointed out that domestic screen makers do not make the kinds of screens needed for the next generation of portable computers. It would be ridiculous, they said, to force the Japanese to raise prices, and thus increase costs to American computer makers.
 
The Japanese 'Are Ahead'
 "The Japanese are clearly ahead in flat-panel displays," John Sculley, the chief executive of Apple, said here last week. "What is happening in America is really small-scale stuff compared to what is happening in Japan, and I don't see that changing anytime soon."
Mr. Sculley and his fellow producers seemed to score a modest victory when the Commerce Department issued its preliminary ruling last week. The department concluded that the price differences, or "dumping margins," on which any import tariffs are calculated were relatively small.
Nonetheless, the ruling seemed to galvanize the Japanese makers. Toshiba, Hitachi, Fujitsu, Sony and others are all investing heavily in flat-panel technology, concluding that it is a critical link in the food chain of high-technology parts that are common to a huge range of electronic goods. But tariffs and a growing American unease that the technology, which originated in the United States, was being hoarded in Japan could create a morass of political problems.
Last year a Sharp executive said that his company would move production to the United States "when it becomes a necessity politically." But that moment has apparently not arrived for other companies. The Toshiba Corporation, which has a joint venture in the technology with I.B.M., is building new operations in Japan. I.B.M. has announced no plans to fabricate the screen in the United States, though it is widely assumed that eventually it will also move some production there.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Honda to Lift Civic's Mileage

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Feb 21

 BODY:
The Honda Motor Company said today that it would replace its Civic CRX HF subcompact model this fall with a version that would achieve 65 miles a gallon in highway driving and 50 miles a gallon in the city.
The mileage ratings, if achieved, would represent a sizable increase in the fuel efficiency of the Civic CRX HF, which now travels 52 miles on a gallon in highway driving and 49 miles on a gallon in the city, the highest figures of any vehicle with a four-cylinder engine. 
 The mileage targets for the new Civic Hatchback VX were made in remarks today by Thomas Elliott, executive vice president of Honda's American operation. Mr. Elliott was one of several automobile company executives who testified before a United States Senate subcommittee that is considering a proposal to increase fuel economy standards.
A Honda spokesman would not elaborate on how the company was able to achieve its mileage targets in preliminary testing, except to say it was not a result of any breakthrough technology.
The Geo Metro subcompact, made by Suzuki for General Motors, is the current mileage leader, with 58 miles a gallon in highway driving and 53 in the city. The Geo Metro is powered by a three-cylinder engine.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Continental's La Guardia Service Rises

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS

 BODY:
Continental Airlines said yesterday that it would add 32 flights to nine cities from La Guardia Airport, largely filling the vacuum left by the collapse of Eastern Airlines.
The airline said it would begin new flights to Florida on March 21, and to cities in the South and Midwest on April 8. Some of the routes were already being served by Continental and some will be new ones for the airline. The added service will make Continental the second-largest carrier at La Guardia behind USAir. 
 Continential will use 64 landing and takeoff slots and 6 gates at La Guardia that it bought at an auction of Eastern assets held earlier this month. Continental paid for the assets by assuming about $54 million in lease obligations held by Eastern, which is being liquidated under the supervision of the bankruptcy court.
 
'La Guardia Is a Gold Mine'
 "La Guardia is a gold mine," John Nelson, Continental's executive vice president, said in explaining why the airline was expanding during a recession and while it is seeking to reorganize under the protection of Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Code.
Continental was forced to enter bankruptcy by the huge costs of its debt, a legacy of when it was one of the rapidly expanding companies of Frank Lorenzo, who also owned Eastern. Mr. Nelson said Continental had obtained permission from its creditors to undertake the La Guardia expansion.
He said that the airport was the preferred departure point for business travelers from Manhattan, which has the world's largest concentration of such travelers.
"The flying that we do out of La Guardia is immensely profitable," he added. He predicted that the new flights would soon be profitable, because many are on routes used by business travelers, who tend to pay full fares rather than discount fares. He added that there would be no special promotional fares to inaugurate the new routes.
Edward Starkman, an airline analyst with Paine Webber Inc., said that the expansion at La Guardia would allow Continental to feed more traffic to its major hubs, like Houston and Denver. He also said the new gates would allow Continental to use more wide-bodied airplanes, like the Airbus A300, providing more capacity.
"It's going to mean a lot," he said, adding that before the expansion, Continental was often unable to meet the demand for seats on flights out of La Guardia.
Continental, which is the largest carrier at Newark International Airport and the largest carrier in the New York metropolitan area, now serves much of the eastern half of the country and Texas from La Guardia.
Continental will have to add some employees for the expansion, Mr. Nelson said. The number of new jobs, however, is not expected to reach the 1,350 vacancies created with the demise of Eastern's La Guardia operations.
The service to Florida will be made up of four daily flights to Fort Lauderdale and Miami, three daily flights to Orlando and West Palm Beach, and two daily departures to Tampa. The other new flights will be five daily to Atlanta; four to Buffalo; three to Columbus, Ohio, and four to Detroit.
The expansion comes at a time when most airlines are cutting back on flights and resorting to layoffs as air travel has shrunk since the Persian Gulf war began on Jan. 16.
 
Gulf War's Effect on Traffic
 Mr. Nelson said that Continental's traffic was not as severely affected as other airlines', however, since the carrier picked up some of Eastern's traffic after it shut down on Jan. 18 because many Continental routes overlapped those of Eastern.
He said that while traffic had declined by about 30 percent for the industry since the war began, Continental's decline was only about 10 percent.
Mr. Nelson also said that Continental had taken a step to widen its reservation system and is expected to reach an agreement to have its System 1 computer-reservation system incorporated into the Worldspan system owned by several other airlines.

HEADLINE: Waking From a Dream: New York City Lays Off 400

BYLINE: By FELICIA R. LEE

 BODY:
Linda Moses was sick and tired of being sick and tired, so the single mother dangling on welfare decided to get some schooling and some job training. In November of 1987 she realized her modest dream of independence through a job as an office aide for New York City. That dream is now ending with a pink slip.
Today or Saturday will be the last day of work for more than 400 people who are part of the first wave of municipal employees laid off as grim testament to the city's budget woes. Between March 1 and March 8 at least 200 more -- including Ms. Moses -- are to lose their jobs, and about 400 more will be out of work by June 30, when the city's fiscal year ends. 
Those layoffs are a handful compared with the 16,000 called for on Jan. 16, when Mayor David N. Dinkins released his preliminary plan for closing a budget gap of $3 billion in this and the next fiscal year. Just how many jobs will be lost -- and whose -- is still being fought out.
 
Accusing, Shifting and Lobbying
 Mr. Dinkins is now talking about many thousands fewer. The city workers' unions are continuing to lobby to hold on to jobs, while the State Comptroller, Edward V. Regan, said yesterday that the Mayor's plan was "not credible" and that city government was growing instead of shrinking. And workers with seniority are being transferred in large numbers to other departments.
Still, as city employees scramble for new jobs, apply for welfare and take out loans, the budget gaps and red ink that were once government abstractions have become real.
Most of the layoffs this weekend involve workers known as provisionals -- employees who were not hired through competitive Civil Service procedures and who do not have Civil Service protections. The layoffs will be falling disproportionately hard on women and minority-groupmembers, who in general have less seniority and hold lower-level jobs. Many, like Ms. Moses, are single mothers who in the past relied on public assistance.
"I don't want to go back on welfare; it's degrading," said Ms. Moses, a Department of Housing Preservation and Development office aide with two children, mounting bills and no idea what she will do next.
"I felt real bad. Why did they have to pick me?" she asked yesterday, her voice shaking." I'm scared, I'm mad and frustrated and all of that."
Ms. Moses relied on welfare for five years. She received her general equivalency diploma in 1986 and got her current job in November 1987.
On Feb. 13, when her boss talked about the grim state of the city's economy, she knew it was all over -- the $380 and change she took home every two weeks, after taxes and a loan deduction, to take care of her two children, ages 9 and 4.
"What's going to happen to me and my kids?" she asked aloud. "I want to go back to school, maybe a two-year school. Get another job. Something real important, where they won't lay me off."
The layoffs this weekend are sprinkled throughout city agencies. A Personnel Department spokeswoman, Denise Collins, said yesterday that 159 or 160 sanitation workers had received pink slips, as had 105 in the Finance Department, 45 in the Department for the Aging, 31 in the Department of Youth Services, 15 in the Taxi and Limousine Commission, 22 in the Department of City Planning, 26 in the Department of Parks and Recreation and a total of 5 between the Department of Economic Development and the Department of Ports and Trade.
 
Numbers Are in Flux
 Since Dec. 31, 146 employees have been laid off, not including about 250 hospital and library workers not officially on the city payroll.
"The numbers constantly are in flux," Ms. Collins said. "People have rights, and it changes the numbers you've just done. With the civil servants the idea is to not have them on the streets. They are laid off in inverse order of seniority.
"For the provisionals, they're given booklets about job counseling, possible re-training and openings further down the road," she said.
That kind of help will be of little comfort to Deborah Richardson when she walks into her office in the Department of General Services on March 8 for her last day of work. She is a provisional employee who works as an office aide. March 12 would have been the second anniversary at her job for the single mother of three children, ages 10, 6 and 11 months.
 
Sense of Pride
 Ms. Richardson, who is 36 years old and spent "seven or eight" years on welfare, said she had obtained her job through a program for welfare recepients. She said she was proud to take home $573 every other Friday not because it ever went very far but because it was money she earned.
"I either have to go back on welfare or get some help," she said. "I was very delighted with the job; being at home a long time you have no choices. For the first time I had some money for little things: shoes, balloons for the kids. I haven't slept too well."
"I told the kids what happened," Ms. Richardson said. "I said, 'As of next week your mom's not going to work.' They were sad. They don't really understand."
An office associate in the Department of Housing Preservation and Development, Adrian Manigault, said yesterday that she was more angry than sad that she will be unemployed after March 1.
"We're laid off, and all these people with big money are still there," she said. "A lot of people are angry. The majority laid off are women with children, and they're black and Hispanic."
Ms. Manigault is 40 years old and was on public assistance for more than one-fourth of her life. She said she has a fantasy of sending her 16-year-old son to college to escape her fate of dreams deferred, but she is not sure how to do it now. "I'm mad at the system," she said. "I got back on my feet, I raised my kids, I thought it was going to be smooth going. Then they pull the rug from under your feet."

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
The Impact Of the Gulf War

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
HISTORICALLY, wars have given a powerful thrust to the economy by increasing spending on arms and manpower, reducing unemployment, raising consumers' incomes and putting pressure on industrial capacity. World War II wiped out what remained of the Depression; the Korean War ended the 1949 recession, and Vietnam kept the longest expansion on record rolling.
Is the war in the Persian Gulf different from these in its economic effects? 
 The economic section of President Bush's budget message for the fiscal year 1992, which was developed jointly by the Council of Economic Advisers, the Treasury and the Office of Management and Budget, states: "The precipitous loss of consumer confidence since July was due to an external development, the Persian Gulf crisis, rather than internal weakness. Confidence can be restored quickly if it becomes evident that there will not be a replay of the previous oil shocks."
And, in his Congressional testimony this week, Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, repeated his view that "an extended war with Iraq" could damage public confidence and spending, but that with an early end to the war "this downturn could well prove shorter and shallower than most postwar recessions."
The two main surveys of consumer confidence lend support to the Administration's contention that the crisis in the gulf kicked off the recession and that an early end to the war would end it. The University of Michigan's Index of Consumer Sentiment stood at 88.2 last July; in August it plunged to 76.4 and kept falling until it hit 63.9 in October. Then it began to edge up, reaching 66.8 in January. The February data are not in yet.
The Conference Board's Index of Consumer Confidence fell even more steeply; it dropped from 101.7 last July to 84.7 in August, and slid to 54 inJanuary, the lowest level in 10 years. But, after Jan. 17, when the United States and coalition forces began their attack on Iraq, the Conference Board index apparently began to firm up.
"Survey results recorded in the first half of January were down sharply as last-minute peace negotiations failed," said Fabien Linden, executive director of the Conference Board's consumer research center. "But after military action began, consumer confidence picked up slightly, presumably because early indications suggested a short war. A reasonably quick victory might well provide the psychological thrust to invigorate the economy."
Are these measured changes in consumer confidence useful forecasters of the business cycle, or do they simply reflect real economic factors, as consumers currently assess them? They certainly wiggle about in reaction to breaking business, political or military news. A sudden event -- a President's heart attack, like Eisenhower's, or assassination, like Kennedy's, can give consumer confidence and the stock market a jolt, but with little lasting effect on the economy. That was even true of the stock market crash of October 1987.
Indeed, many economists believe that the true causal sequence between consumer attitudes andobjective economic conditions is the reverse of what the psychological approach assumes. When layoffs are rising, consumer confidence sinks. As the job picture starts to improve (just after consumer confidence touches bottom), consumers' spirits rise -- and they spend more.
George L. Perry, the Brookings Institution's chief forecaster, finds that surveys of consumer attitudes have little or no predictive value, say, six months into the future. But he thinks the surveys provide useful clues to the consumer's very short-term behavior. Thus, if the effects of a war, or the end of a war, on consumer attitudes is prompt and sharp, a quick and successful end to the war may provide enough lift to consumer spending to end the recession.
Consumer spending constitutes two-thirds of the gross national product. A surge of spending could lift the G.N.P. into positive numbers by the third quarter of this year, or possibly even before the second quarter is over.
Even in the longer run, psychological factors might act as a vital link between real incomes, consumer spending and economic growth: An optimistic public would convert income into expenditures at a higher rate than a pessimistic public, and thereby lead to more rapid growth, until the economy reaches its full-employment and capacity limits, and inflationary pressures intensify.
This view may be regarded as a translation into macroeconomics of the personal-psychological thesis of Dr. Martin E. P. Seligman's new book, "Learned Optimism": that an optimistic attitude may cure psychological depression by overcoming the resigned and helpless attitudes of individuals who habitually react to adversity pessimistically.
But "positive thinking," of itself, is no automatic cure for the ills of depression, psychological or economic. Ill-founded optimism can be a pipe dream that helps cause crashes or breeds crunches. The great virtue of pessimism is that it looks at reality and forces individuals, or a nation, to recognize their serious problems. A sound balance between optimism and pessimism can lead to both realism and constructive action, rather than an evasion of problems by happy-talk and wish-think.

HEADLINE: For Greenspan, Problems Not Confronted Before

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21

 BODY:
Like judges, economic policy makers rely on precedents. If the economy performed a certain way in a particular set of circumstances, then, the policy makers assume, it will perform a similar way when those circumstances recur.
 Alan Greenspan, who is not only the Government's foremost economic policy maker nowadays but practically its only one, has always depended on the lessons of the past. The problem for Mr. Greenspan now is that the economy faces conditions that he and other economists have never seen before. 
 Probably no other chairman of the Federal Reserve has had a firmer grasp of economic history, has logged more hours in front of the computer screen working with historical models or has more faith in the view that a master tailor could turn the economy into a seamless fabric with careful nips and tucks. He once told a visitor that at any one time there is one perfect interest rate and that his job description was to find that rate.
But in two days of Congressional testimony this week, the semiannual testimony he is required by law to give on monetary policy and the state of the economy, Mr. Greenspan seemed to be in a quandary about whether to lower interest rates further to counter the recession or stand pat and let the rate cuts of late last year and early this year work their way through the economy.
 
Outlook 'Unusually Clouded'
 The times warrant extreme caution, he told the Senate Banking Committee on Wednesday, because "the major mistakes in monetary policy are often made at turning points, and it is very difficult to avoid them." He made a similar statement today to the House Banking Committee's Subcommittee on Domestic Monetary Policy.
"The current outlook is unusually clouded," Mr. Greenspan said, "by uncertainties about the war and its effects." Not only does no one know how long the war will last, but economists have no experience with a war fought in large part with military stocks that may not have to be replaced.
Other circumstances are equally unfamiliar to the Federal Reserve and other economists, including these:
*The current recession is the first since at least World War II that began when interest rates were already falling.
*Despite one move after another, the Fed has been unable so far to counteract the persistent scarcity of credit.
*The financial system is extremely weak, and some economists believe a few bank failures could have devastating economic consequences.
*For the first time in memory, the Government has no fiscal policy to deal with economic hard times.
Mr. Greenspan said the "central tendency" of Federal Reserve Board governors and regional bank presidents was to believe that the economy would grow between three-fourths of a percent and 1.5 percent this year, a forecast in line with the ones made by the Bush Administration and many private economists. But Mr. Greenspan said the range of views among the 6 governors and 12 bank presidents was much wider, with one and perhaps more predicting the economy would shrink by as much as half of 1 percent this year.
"This divergence of opinion has its roots in the major uncertainties facing all forecasters today," the chairman said. He said he could not rule out the possibility of a long and deep recession.
 
Lending Curtailed
 Of all these uncertainties, the most serious and the hardest to fathom, in Mr. Greenspan's view, is the continued failure of banks to make loans to creditworthy customers. As long as banks are not lending, businesses will not invest, consumers will not spend and the country cannot pull out of the recession.
Mr. Greenspan says he knows what caused the problem: Reckless lending practices in the 1980's, much of it resulting from the favorable tax treatment of real estate projects, left banks with many bad loans. When the bubble burst, bankers became "very chary about extending credit, which would undercut their capital positions" and perhaps lead investors to feel the banks were undercapitalized. And "superimposed on top of that," Mr. Greenspan said in his testimony, some bank examiners, blamed for not having been tough enough in the past, became unreasonably tight in their supervision.
But the cure has proved elusive. Since fall, the Federal Reserve has taken a series of forceful steps, lowering interest rates and cutting the amount of reserves banks are required to hold, to improve bank profits and thus make renewed lending more attractive. But so far they have not worked.
In his testimony this week, Mr. Greenspan promised new steps. He said new regulations to be announced soon would change the way real estate collateral is recorded on banks' books. And for the first time, he encouraged banks to begin borrowing directly from the Federal Reserve at a rate lower than commercial rates. But he conceded that he saw no clear evidence that the credit situation had begun to ease.
 
'The Most Critical Thing'
 "We are looking at the credit crunch as being the most critical thing that confronts monetary policy at this particular stage," Mr. Greenspan told the Senate committee.
For the first time since he became chairman three and a half years ago, Mr. Greenspan was forced not only to explain the Fed's policies but also to defend them against repeated assaults.
Even in hindsight, he insisted repeatedly, the central bank was right not to lower interest rates in the first half of last year. He maintained that had it not been for Iraq's invasion of Kuwait in August, which he could not possibly have predicted, the odds were much better than even that a recession would have been averted.
And pressed on why he had taken so long to recognize the credit squeeze, Mr. Greenspan said that the tighter lending practices early last year were healthy for the economy because they meant that banks were overhauling their lax practices of the 80's.
The Bush Administration has leveled similar criticism at Mr. Greenspan. But unless an economic catastrophe develops in the next six months for which the Bush Administration decides to make him a scapegoat, Mr. Greenspan's reappointment when his four-year term expires in August seems almost certain.
That is true as much because of his personality as his ability. Even those in the Bush Administration and Congress who disagree with him like him and trust him. Administration officials blame him for the recession but see him as a loyalist. Lawmakers see him as an honest broker. He never loses his temper in the face of criticism and never talks down to even the most mindless questioner.
Late in today's subcommittee hearing, Representative Joseph P. Kennedy 2d, a Massachusetts Democrat, strode into the room and asked a series of hostile and sometimes misinformed questions. Mr. Greenspan looked Mr. Kennedy in the eye and responded to the questions calmly and without condescension.
When Mr. Kennedy's questioning time was up, Mr. Greenspan suggested he drop by the Fed so they could continue their discussion. Mr. Kennedy smiled for the first time, said he would make an appointment this afternoon and left happy.
