HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Saatchi Trims Debt Burden With Revised Capital Plan

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Feb. 21

 BODY:
Bowing to pressure from its preferred shareholders, the Saatchi & Saatchi Company, the world's second-largest advertising concern, introduced a revised recapitalization plan today that would give such shareholders a much larger ownership stake but would significantly ease its debt problems.
The plan would give 75 percent to 80 percent of Saatchi to preferred shareholders and would leave common shareholders with about 15 percent to 20 percent. Under the original plan proposed on Jan. 10, preferred shareholders would have owned 60 percent to 65 percent of Saatchi, with the common holders owning 30 percent to 35 percent. 
 In response to the latest proposal, the price of Saatchi's common shares plunged 38 percent on the London International Stock Exchange today, closing at 16.75 pence, or 32.8 cents. The stock fell 10.25 pence, or 20.1 cents.
Analysts predicted that preferred and common holders would approve the plan, noting that preferred shareholders were in a strong bargaining position. They also pointed out that with Saatchi struggling in a tough business climate, the plan would save the company from possible financial collapse.
"You're not dealing with a situation where people have a lot of choice," said James D. Dougherty, an analyst at County Natwest Securities U.S.A. in New York. "The place is going bankrupt if they don't do something like this."
 
Unit Pledges Support
 Saatchi said it had been promised the support of the senior managers of KMP Humphreys Bull & Barker Ltd., a British advertising agency that Saatchi bought in 1985. Under the deal, the managers will be paid about 48 million common shares next month at the current market price, which means they will own about 23 percent of the common shares when the revised plan is voted on next month.
A spokeswoman for Southeast Asset Management, a Memphis investment firm that owns about 14 percent of Saatchi's common shares, declined to comment on the plan.
Under the revised Saatchi plan, 311 pounds, or about $608.9 million, in preference shares would be converted into equity. It also includes investor commitments that will enable Saatchi to raise about $117.5 million by selling new common shares.
Under the previous plan, Saatchi would have been certain to raise at least $49 million in new funds. But $39.2 million of it would have been an expensive loan from a limited partnership affiliated with the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation in New York, which Saatchi would not have to take under the revised plan.
 
Other Endorsements
 If the owners of Saatchi's common, Europreference and British preferred shares approve the plan, St. James's Place Capital P.L.C., a London investment firm controlled by the financier Jacob Rothschild, would become Saatchi's largest shareholder, with a stake of at least 12.5 percent. St. James's Place owns 20 percent of the Europreference shares.
"St. James's has given its full support to the new proposals and is delighted that it will be a significant shareholder," Clive Gibson, a director of the firm, said.
An investor group headed by ESL Partners II L.P., a Dallas investment firm that owns 17 percent of the Europreference shares, would own more than 10 percent of Saatchi if the revised plan is approved. In Dallas, Edward S. Lampert, ESL's general partner, pledged to support the plan.
A person representing investors with about 15 percent of the Europreference shares predicted today they would also vote for the plan, thus giving the revised proposal the backing of investors owning at least 52 percent of the Europreference shares. The person insisted on anonymity.
Altogether, Europreference shareholders would end up with about 65 percent of the common shares under the plan. British preferred shareholders would have about 15 percent.
 
Strong Position
 Saatchi's Europreference shareholders had a strong bargaining position because the advertising company faced the prospect of having to pay $413.1 million to redeem them in July 1993. The analysts said the financially weak Saatchi would have difficulty coming up with the money. The British preferred shares are redeemable in 2015.
The revised plan calls for exchanging each Europreference and British preferred share for 3.5 and 1.3 new common shares, respectively.
Saatchi is also optimistic that its 19 bank will agree to increase its credit by $58.7 million and will extend the life of the lines, which now total about $510 million, to January 1996 from January 1993, Simon Mellor, a Saatchi director, said.
In opposing the first plan, the preferred shareholders contended that because the new preferred shares would have no dividend for three years and because of Saatchi's shaky financial condition, the securities would not have had much value and would have been difficult to sell. They also said the plan would have left Saatchi with too much debt.
They also objected to the expensive Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette loan.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices of Treasury Securities Ease

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities dipped slightly yesterday, as dealers adjusted positions in order to place bids at the auction of $9 billion worth of new five-year Treasury notes.
The new notes were sold at an average yield of 7.51 percent, down from an average rate of 7.62 percent at the last five-year note sale on Jan. 24. It is the lowest rate on a new five-year Treasury security since the auction of Feb. 25, 1987. 
 Despite the low yield, traders said the level was very attractive, given the economy's weak condition and the prospects that interest rates will probably move lower.
"I think these fives will ultimately be a good issue, once they get distributed," one government bond trader said.
Dealers apparently did not think so much of the issue in the trading period following the announcement of the auction results, however. By late yesterday, the new notes were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 7.54 percent.
 
Improvement in Prices Seen
 Since Wall Street bought most of the issue, the distribution process may take a little time. But with no additional new supply of securities scheduled to be sold for some weeks, market participants said they anticipate a further improvement in prices.
"We don't have any supply for a while, and I think that puts the bulls in the driver's seat," the trader said. "As the distribution process unfolds, the market will get better."
Over the course of the last three weeks, dealers have had to absorb some $55 billion worth of new Treasury notes and bonds.
No new bonds will be sold until May, at the next quarterly refunding auctions. Note sales next month will be limited to another round of two-year and five-year issues.
Joseph Liro, a senior vice president and money market economist at S.G. Warburg & Company, said that at the moment, price movement "is toward the downside, due to the weight of all the securities, as well as the Fed's wait-and-hold strategy."
"Right now, we are in the midst of a fairly orderly consolidation phase, but on the next strong blast of weak economic news the rally will recommence," he added.
 
Testimony by Greenspan
 Traders said that testimony in front of the House Banking Committee by Alan Greenspan, Federal Reserve Board chairman, had no impact in the credit markets. And the speech by President Saddam Hussein of Iraq, which some had hoped would mark an end to the Persian Gulf war, proved a disappointment.
"There had been some hope that Hussein would say something conciliatory, but that didn't happen," the bond trader said. "His speech didn't move the market much, but he was not a positive influence."
Word of Iraq's acceptance of a peace proposal offered by the Soviet Union came well after trading activity had ceased in the United States.
Also overlooked was another big drop in the Commodity Research Bureau's index of 21 spot commodity prices. The index fell by 1.87, to 211.20.
"The CRB index is telling us exactly the opposite of what the producer price and consumer price data told us earlier," Mr. Liro said. "I don't know if anybody was trading off the CRB, but a lot of people were talking about it."
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 7 7/8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered at a price of 97 29/32 late yesterday, down 10/ 32, to yield 8.06 percent, up from 8.03 percent late Wednesday.
Among note issues, the 7 3/4 percent 10-year notes were offered at 99 1/ 32, down 1/4 point, to yield 7.89 percent. And the new 6 3/4 percent two-year notes auctioned on Wednesday were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 6.93 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates were narrowly mixed.
Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 5.91 percent, down two basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates fell by one basis point, to a late-offered rate of 5.90 percent. But one-year bill rates rose by two basis points, to a late offered rate of 5.94 percent.
In other developments, the Federal Reserve Board reported yesterday that all three measures of the nation's money supply rose sharply during the week ended Feb. 11.
The Fed has expressed concern about sluggish growth in the monetary aggregates, but the gains since the first of the year should allay some of their worries.
Including the most recent gains, M-2, the monetary measure most closely monitored by the Fed, has grown at a 3.3 percent annual rate since the end of the fourth quarter, well within the Fed's target range of 2.5 percent to 6.5 percent, said Wayne Smith, an economist at Ried Thunberg & Company, an investment advisory firm in Westport, Conn.
"With M-2 comfortably in its target range, it probably won't be as much of a concern to the Fed" as before, Mr. Smith said. "But concern about M-2 was only a veil for worries about sluggish credit growth. If that doesn't pick up, the Fed will probably be moved to ease monetary policy again."
Release of the money numbers had little impact on prices in the credit markets.
Elsewhere, participants in the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds said that prices of most issues fell by about 3/8 point in fairly quiet trading.
In the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds, prices continued to slide, as dealers groped to rid themselves of a slew of new issues.
"The Street has lost lots of money this week," one municipal bond trader said. "Bonds are disappearing, but at lower prices. It has been bloody."
Traders said that prices of most widely quoted municipal bonds fell by about 1/4 point.

HEADLINE: Prove You Need Fare Rise, Cuomo Demands of M.T.A.

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS

 BODY:
The fight over potential fare increases on New York City's subways, buses and commuter railroads got into full swing yesterday when the Governor and ranking state legislators told the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to prove that higher fares were critical to offset rising budget deficits.
Discussing the issue at a family health center in Brooklyn, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo said: 'It's not unusual for people like the M.T.A. or local governments or anybody else to put the pressure on you by saying, 'Unless you give more money, we're gong to raise the local taxes, we're going to raise the fares." 
 The Governor's comments were the latest salvo in what promises to be a continuing political and financial battle over increasing transit and railroad fares.
Senator Norman Levy, chairman of the Senate Transportation Committee, accused the M.T.A. yesterday of using the specter of a fare increase to try to force the State Legislature to increase subsidies for mass transit, possibly through a proposed rise in the gasoline tax.
 
$1.40 Fare Possible
 "I am concerned about the validity of the estimates that are coming from the authority and whether these deficits are just sword-rattling to try to generate additional revenues," Mr. Levy said.
But M.T.A. officials said they were prepared to make their case, warning that ballooning deficits could mean subway and bus fares might rise as high as $1.40 this summer, accompanied by proportionate increases on the Long Island Rail Road and Metro-North Commuter Railroad.
The revenue shortfall is a result of declining ridership, proposed lower state subsidies and a drop in revenues from city real-estate taxes, the M.T.A. officials said. They said they would meet with state legislators in Albany next week to argue for a fare rise.
"We are in such bad shape that it's inconceivable that we can put off a fare increase this year," said Mortimer L. Downey, the M.T.A.'s executive director and chief financial officer.
The M.T.A. estimates that the Transit Authority, which operates the city's subways and buses, will have a $215 million deficit for 1991 and that the Long Island Rail Road and Metro-North will have shortfalls of $22 million and $17 million, respectively.
 
Further Losses Feared
 State and local officials and mass-transit consumer advocates have warned that higher fares would mean serious further loss of passengers at a time when subway and bus ridership have reached new lows. Recently proposed massive service cuts -- on top of substantial cuts made in the past year -- could have similar negative effects, the officials and advocates said.
Technically the 17 members of the M.T.A. board can approve fare increases without the agreement of lawmakers. But the State Legislature, particularly the Senate Transportation Committee, controls the authority's huge capital plans, giving it some influence over the fare increase.
At the same time the Governor appoints six of the board members and Mayor David N. Dinkins four members, and both exert considerable influence over their appointees. The remaining M.T.A. board members are appointed by the Executives of Nassau, Westchester, Putnam, Orange, Rockland, and Dutchess Counties.
 
Alternatives Sought
 Terry Lynam, a spokesman for Mr. Cuomo, said in a telephone interview from Albany yesterday that the Governor felt that a fare increase should be a last resort, but that the ultimate decision rested with the M.T.A. board.
Sharon Landers, director of the Mayor's Office of Transportation, said Mr. Dinkins was deeply concerned about a fare increase, particularly a big one that some riders might not be able to afford. She said that the Transit Authority should make every effort to cut administrative costs before raising the fare and that the Mayor's recent appointments to the M.T.A. board would vote in accordance with the city's position.
The process for raising fares, which requires public hearings, usually makes it impossible for an increase to go into effect before 60 days. But the M.T.A. can declare a financial emergency and raise the fare with only 30 days' notice.
 
Consumer Group Objects
 Gene Russianoff, a spokesman for the Straphangers Campaign, a consumer advocacy group for New York subway riders, said that while he acknowledged the M.T.A.'s poor financial condition, increasing the subway and bus fare to $1.40 was totally unjustified. It would, he said, break a promise made by the Governor's Council on Fiscal and Economic Priorities five years ago to keep the fare at its current $1.15 until 1992.
"The Transit Authority is right to alert the public and Legislature that things are tough," Mr. Russianoff said, "but raising fares is not the solution. We need more subsidies for mass transit that are not so heavily tied to the regional economy."

HEADLINE: A Disappointing Deal for Browning

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER

 BODY:
Browning-Ferris Industries had little to celebrate as it quietly reached a preliminary agreement last week to sell its state-of-the-art hazardous waste disposal site 70 miles east of Denver to the Concord Resources Group, a recently formed joint venture of the Consolidated Rail Corporation and the OHM Corporation.
Although the price was not disclosed, interviews with company executives and bankers suggest that it was 20 percent less than had been hoped for when the site was put up for sale last summer. The price was even slightly under an internal valuation by Houston-based Browning-Ferris, which has a reputation for conservative accounting. 
 The gap between Browning-Ferris's dream deal and the one it finally struck reflected in part the weak market for most types of corporate assets in this recession. But it also highlighted uncertainties peculiar to environmental businesses, especially those in fields like hazardous waste where the investment demands -- as well as the regulatory and technology risks -- are substantial.
Browning-Ferris had reason to believe that it was in an enviable bargaining position when it began the process of selling its Last Chance site, which takes its nickname from a nearby hamlet. The Environmental Protection Agency has called Last Chance "the best designed land disposal site in the nation."
Moreover, analysts who follow environmental companies say that hazardous waste disposal, currently a $3 billion to $4 billion business, may be the most lucrative segment of the waste management industry over the next 20 years. The basic reason: As new regulations continue to expand the range of materials classified as hazardous waste, the number of legal disposal sites is declining.
Despite such prospects, Browning-Ferris decided last April to bail out of the hazardous waste business and concentrate on solid waste disposal and recycling. Browning-Ferris is the second-largest solid-waste disposal company in the nation after Waste Management Inc.
Browning-Ferris had tripped from one financial setback to another in hazardous waste, damaging its reputation with regulators and environmental groups. It was never able overcome a history of shoddy operations at landfills it acquired in New York, Ohio and Louisiana. When William D. Ruckleshaus, the company's chief executive, decided to retreat last spring, the company set aside $295 million after taxes to cover the costs of discontinuing the business.
In Last Chance, buyers were being offered the company's one hazardous waste jewel. "I think they basically put it together as well as humanly possible," said Tanelle Roberts, the engineer overseeing the permit process for the Colorado Health Department.
Moreover, the new owner would be taking over at an ideal time, just as the last regulatory reviews were completed, wiping away any fear that previous operations had created unknown perils that could lead to fines, remediation expenses or closures.
Browning-Ferris's expectations were also colored by its pride in Last Chance, formally known as the Highway 36 Treatment Storage and Disposal Facility. It is the first -- and so far only -- new hazardous waste site to receive state and Federal operating permits under new regulations established by the E.P.A. in 1984. More than $50 million had been sunk into the site since acquisition of its 5,700 acres began in 1980.
Last Chance is intended to handle a variety of liquid and solid wastes, including incinerator ash, sludges from other waste treatment operations, toxic metal plating sludge, contaminated soil and asbestos.
Materials to be sent to the site must be pre-tested at a laboratory in Denver and can only be accepted if they come in a scheduled delivery. They also will be retested at the site. All wastes to be buried will be solidified. The permit calls for disposal in four-acre cells that are 40 feet deep, lined with alternating layers of plastic and compacted clay and ringed with leak detectors.
 
Concord's Second Acquisition
 The Last Chance deal came within days after Concord Resources, based in Pittsburgh, had announced its first acquisition, the purchase of Stablex, a Montreal hazardous waste firm.
"This is a great time to be buying hazardous waste assets," said Swep T. Davis, Concord's chief executive, reflecting on the leverage willing buyers have in a slow market.
"From 1984 to 1988, sellers could be very rigid on bidding specifications, which sometimes read like ultimatums," acknowledged Clay Lifflander, the Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company banker who led the sales effort. "People don't like to feel like they are in an auction today. It's more like a negotiation."
The sales process began last June, when thick booklets describing the site were sent to those who had expressed an interest, along with a letter hinting that Browning-Ferris would welcome a pre-emptive bid. None came. Smith Barney executives began to realize that while the site clearly did not have any skeletons in its closet, it also had no record by which to judge Browning-Ferris's income projections.
Only potential bidders were allowed to see the projections, but there are some hints about the potential profits. At $200 a square yard, a rough industry average price last year, the site has already been permitted to receive 2.5 million cubic yards of material, or $500 million worth. And it has the capacity to receive 7.6 million more without violating any of its basic operating conditions.
Although it is the only permitted site in Colorado under the new regulations and is hundreds of miles from its nearest competitor, the problem for potential purchasers is calculating how much of Last Chance's income can be generated locally where its competitive advantage is strongest and how rapidly that demand might build.
Industry experts said Last Chance has several potential shortcomings. It is a long way from the nearest rail line, meaning that its waste will come from relatively long-distance truck runs. Moreover, several of the largest sources of hazardous waste in Colorado, like the Rocky Mountain Arsenal and the Rocky Flats military base, are so heavily contaminated that onsite disposal plans may be more economical than shipping wastes to another site, Mr. Davis said.
Browning-Ferris's marketing projections were repeatedly questioned as the number of interested parties fell to five and then to two, including Concord. Smith Barney declined to name the other finalist.
The finalists made several visits to the site, which is in an area so remote that there are only 250 residents in a 10-mile radius. They examined legal documents, met with regulators and pored over the multi-volume operating permit, which specified not only the equipment and operations needed, but also the types of employees the site must have, their level of training and operating details.
"The new owners won't make changes very easily," Augustus Cummings, the site manager, told a visitor last summer. "Everything is in the permit."
The process of preparing for a bid dragged into the fall, several months longer than Smith Barney had hoped.
 
Guarantee on Capacity
 One sticking point was whether Browning-Ferris would offer guarantees on how much waste the site could take. Browning-Ferris resisted that because it intended to close the books on its hazardous waste business. Ultimately, the company agreed to an "earnout" provision that tied its total compensation to the site's performance.
Completing the deal and clearing up minor permit modifications is expected to take three or four months, Mr. Davis said. Both sides are looking forward to testing Browning-Ferris's market projections.
"Browning-Ferris started the facility assuming that these sites are going to be rare and that has held up," Mr. Davis said. "There are about dozen new projects for all types of hazardous waste disposal under way around the U.S., but I don't expect more than three or four to get built and opened like this one."

LENGTH: 1219 words

HEADLINE: WAR IN THE GULF: Analysis;
U.S. Keeps Options Open

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21

 BODY:
In its response this evening to the latest Soviet plan for an Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait, the White House took a tentative step toward becoming engaged in negotiations to end the war.
 Although the White House later rejected the proposal as approving only a partial Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait, the careful phrasing of the responses left open the possibility of Washington's entering at least an initial dialogue with Moscow, and indirectly Baghdad, about the terms for ending the war. 
 The Soviet proposal, according to Administration officials, leaves President Bush with a number of decisions. One is whether to encourage a negotiating process that might deprive the United States-led coalition, including its Arab allies, of a chance to decisively defeat President Saddam Hussein and the Iraqi military -- something many of them have long sought.
Another is whether the cost of rejecting the Soviet proposal is worth a breach in Soviet-American relations and a potential domestic political backlash for taking the nation into a ground war that might have been avoided.
If the Bush Administration is annoyed with the Soviets for interposing themselves on the eve of an anticipated major ground war and preventing a clear-cut military conclusion -- and some officials no doubt are -- the White House kept it well hidden this evening, treating the initiative by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev publicly with great respect.
 
Iraq Scales Back Demands
 Since last Friday when Iraq first said it was prepared to consider a withdrawal from Kuwait -- in return for a lengthy list of political, economic and military concessions -- President Hussein has clearly scaled back his demands.
Unlike the earlier withdrawal plans presented by Iraq and the Soviet Union in the last week, the latest proposal appears to offer no political reward to President Hussein for pulling out of Kuwait. Apparently gone are Iraqi demands that a withdrawal from Kuwait be linked with an Israeli pullout from the West Bank or the convening of an overall Middle East peace conference. Also absent is the demand that Iraq be paid reparations for war damage inflicted by the allies, and the demand that the United States and other countries withdraw their military forces from the region.
Instead, the latest Soviet-Iraqi proposal begins with the principle of a complete and unconditional Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait and then goes on to lay down conditions under which that withdrawal should take place. They do not offer Mr. Hussein a clear reward, or compensation, he can cite for the tremendous losses the Iraqi people and economy have suffered as a result of his Kuwait adventure.
That is critical for the Administration, because it has been arguing for weeks that if it cannot destroy the Iraqi army in a ground war, it wants to make certain that President Hussein is dealt such a humiliating political defeat that his chances of surviving for long as the leader of Iraq after this war will be greatly diminished.
 
Some Points Acceptable
 Washington has no problem with the first of the Soviet plan's seven points, which calls for a complete, unconditional Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait. The Administration has not only demanded that there should be such a withdrawal, but also that it be in accordance with all 12 United Nations resolutions.
That is important because the 12 United Nations resolutions deal with more than an Iraqi withdrawal. For instance, resolution 660 "Demands that Iraq withdraw immediately and unconditionally all its forces to the positions in which they were located on August 1, 1990." That would seem to mean that Iraqi units in Kuwait cannot just be driven over the border to Iraq but have to be dispersed around Iraq to their original bases. Resolution 662 demands that "Iraq rescind its actions purporting to annex Kuwait." In other words, the Iraqi Parliament must annul its annexation of Kuwait as its 19th province.
In addition, there is no mention in the Soviet plan of the restoration of the legitimate government of Kuwait or payment of reparations to Kuwait for the damage wrought by the Iraqis on that country, or negotiations between Iraq and Kuwait to settle their differences, all of which are contained in the United Nations resolutions.
 
Linkage Idea Abandoned
 But assurances on Kuwait came from Sergei Grigoriev, a Soviet spokesman who translated Mr. Bush's words for Mr. Gorbachev in their telephone conversation tonight about the peace proposal. Mr. Grigoriev, interviewed on the ABC News program, "Nightline," said, "It is the unconditional withdrawal of all Iraqi troops from Kuwait; it is the restoration of Kuwait's independence and sovereignty, and it is the recognition of the fact that only the legitimate rulers of Kuwait can come back and be the rulers in their own country."
Mr. Grigoriev also made it clear that Mr. Hussein's previous demand that the withdrawal of his troops be linked to an Arab-Israeli peace conference has been abandoned in the current proposal.
"I can understand that this was dropped out completely, as the Iraqis are no longer raising this question," he said. "It was made very clear to Mr. Aziz that we are not raising this question, and no one is raising this question in connection with other issues."
The second of the Soviet plan's points -- that the Iraqi withdrawal would not begin until two days after the start of the ceasefire -- would be unacceptable to the United States, since Washington does not want to give the Iraqi forces any pause in the war until they start pulling out. The third point stipulates that the Iraqi withdrawal take place in a fixed, but as yet publicly unspecified time frame. The United States had wanted the limit to be four days so that the Iraqis would be forced to leave behind some of their heavy weapons.
 
U.S. Wants Arms Embargo Continued
 The fourth point states that after the withdrawal of two-thirds of the Iraqi forces, the United Nations economic sanctions against Iraq should cease to apply. Administration officials say this is unacceptable to Washington, which would only consider passing a new Security Council resolution lifting such sanctions after Iraq has completely withdrawn and lived up to the provisions of all other relevant resolutions on Kuwait. The United States could veto a Soviet effort to end the sanctions after only a partial withdrawal.
The United States and some of its allies have declared their intention of imposing at least a limited arms embargo on Iraq after it withdraws to insure that Baghdad cannot rebuild its chemical, biological and nuclear facilities or rearm in a way that could threaten its neighbors.
The fifth point -- that after the full Iraqi withdrawal, the causes for the remaining United Nations resolutions against Iraq cease to exist -- would also not be acceptable to Washington, since the United States sees an Iraqi withdrawal as only one element of fulfilling the United Nations resolutions.
The United States probably would not have any problem with the sixth point, which stipulates that after the cease-fire, all prisoners of war would be immediately released, but it might have a problem with the seventh -- that the withdrawal will be monitored by countries not directly involved in hostilities.

LENGTH: 1203 words

HEADLINE: WAR IN THE GULF: Diplomacy;
SOVIETS SAY IRAQ ACCEPTS KUWAIT PULLOUT LINKED TO TRUCE AND AN END TO SANCTIONS; BUSH REJECTS CONDITIONS: WAR IS TO GO ON

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Friday, Feb. 22

 BODY:
Moscow announced early today after talks with Iraq's Foreign Minister that President Saddam Hussein had given a "positive" response to a new Soviet peace proposal and had agreed to withdraw from Kuwait.
A breathless spokesman for President Mikhail S. Gorbachev rushed into a press briefing at 2:40 A.M. Moscow time after the meeting with the Foreign Minister, Tariq Aziz, and declared, "The response is positive." 
 "The two parties," he said, "came to the conclusion that it is possible to find a way out of the military conflict in the gulf, along the following lines." [Transcript of Soviet statement, page A6.]
 
U.S. Rejects Proposal
 In Washington, Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, initially described the Soviet effort as "useful," although he said that President Bush had "serious concerns" about it.
But President Bush decided after a meeting with his national security advisers that the Soviet plan had to be rejected because it set conditions for an Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait, his spokesman said.
Mr. Fitzwater had said earlier that the allied forces would in any case "continue to prosecute the war" while diplomacy continued.
 
Economic Sanctions Would End
 The seven-point Soviet plan outlined for the first time by the spokesman, Vitaly N. Ignatenko, called for the Iraqi withdrawal to begin after the end of hostilities and to be concluded within an unspecified time.
It also called for the removal of economic sanctions against Iraq once two-thirds of its forces were out of Kuwait and for all other United Nations resolutions to be lifted once all the troops were gone. That provision would appear to excuse Iraq from paying compensation to Kuwait. There was also no specific mention made of restoring Kuwait's rulers to power as called for by the United Nations.
Also conspicuously absent from the plan was any mention of a peace conference or a broader Middle East settlement that would include the Arab-Israeli conflict. Such a demand, which had been introduced as a condition in earlier Iraqi feelers, would probably have been strongly opposed at least by the United States and Israel.
 
Work Said to Continue
 Mr. Ignatenko said that the first point of the plan was a declaration by Iraq of a "full and unconditional withdrawal from Kuwait." But in the preliminary version he outlined, the envisioned retreat was linked to a number of steps and qualifications. He said that work on concrete details of the plan was continuing and that the conclusions would be announced today to members of the United Nations Security Council and the United Nations Secretary General, Javier Perez de Cuellar.
Though the proposals and their reported acceptance by Iraq were enthusiastically detailed at the Foreign Ministry, no commentary was offered by Mr. Aziz, and President Hussein had not spelled out any of its provisions in a speech on Radio Baghdad on Thursday.
The announcement in Moscow shifted the spotlight back to Washington, where President Bush had to decide whether the proposals were sufficient to call off the widely anticipated ground war and declare a cease-fire. He finally concluded that the offer did not provide for an unconditional Iraqi withdrawal, among other United Nations demands, and that it therefore had to be rejected.
Moscow's announcement culminated a tense seesaw between war and peace as President Gorbachev pursued its 11th-hour mediating effort, Washington prepared a vast ground campaign, and President Hussein issued conflicting signals from his smoldering capital.
 
An Address by Hussein
 Mr. Aziz's arrival in Moscow came scant hours after Mr. Hussein had delivered a 40-minute address that seemed to close the door to any peaceful solution. In his speech, Mr. Hussein declared that Iraq was ready for "the mother of all battles." But he also said that his Foreign Minister was carrying a plan to Moscow whose rejection would expose "the premeditated intentions of the aggression against us."
Mr. Aziz's rush to Moscow capped a bold and unexpected Soviet mediating effort that began Feb. 9 with an announcement by Mr. Gorbachev that the Persian Gulf war threatened to exceed the mandate of the United Nations and that he was sending a personal envoy, Yevgeny M. Primakov, to Baghdad with a personal appeal to President Hussein.
The following days became a race between the beginning of a ground attack by the United States-led alliance and the Soviet diplomacy. Iraq raised hopes when it announced that it was prepared to withdraw from Kuwait and dashed them by saddling the offer with a host of conditions.
Then Mr. Aziz traveled to Moscow to receive a confidential peace plan from Mr. Gorbachev, while the Soviets held a flurry of private contacts with Washington and its allies.
Returning with Mr. Hussein's response shortly before midnight, Mr. Aziz was rushed straight to a meeting with Mr. Gorbachev, which lasted two hours and two minutes. Foreign correspondents were summoned to the Foreign Ministry press center at midnight.
 
'The Effort Was Worthwhile'
 Mr. Ignatenko rushed into the press center breathless and excited 10 minutes after the meeting ended in the Kremlin. "Please excuse me for having kept you for so long, but I think the effort was worthwhile," he declared.
At the end, several Soviet and Arab reporters broke into applause, and Mr. Ignatenko happily joined them. The jubilant mood indicated that the Kremlin believed it had succeeded, even if Washington had yet to respond and there were still details to work out.
Mr. Ignatenko said that Mr. Gorbachev had telephoned President Bush to report on the talks with Mr. Aziz.
While the package presented today compelled Mr. Hussein to abandon Kuwait, it also freed him of paying compensation and left him in office.
The brief outline offered by Mr. Ignatenko left questions unanswered. The description of the plan as a list of "approaches" and "positions" suggested that it remained open to change and negotiation, and it was not clear at what stage Iraq was to declare its unconditional withdrawal from Kuwait and when the allies were to call a cease-fire.
The preliminary package seemed to have both pros and cons from the allied perspective. Washington had declared, for example, that it will not call a halt to the bombing of Iraq until the Iraqis begin to withdraw from Kuwait. The allies have also been reluctant to lift sanctions before all forces are withdrawn, or to forgive Iraq the payment of any compensation for the millions stolen and destroyed in Kuwait by the occupying troops.
 
Other Elements Not Included
 On the other side, the proposals did not include several elements that had been mentioned before by Iraq and Moscow and that would have been difficult for Washington to accept. Foremost among these was the absence of any mention of a Middle East peace conference or of the Arab-Israeli conflict.
Mr. Hussein had often before tried to depict his struggle as one that encompassed the greater battle to end Israeli occupation of Arab lands, and Mr. Gorbachev's initial declaration on the gulf war also mentioned the need to convene a peace conference with Iraq as a participant.

LENGTH: 1546 words

HEADLINE: Women's Milestone: Majority on Minnesota Court

BYLINE: By DAVID MARGOLICK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MINNEAPOLIS

 BODY:
Everyone knows that women are entering the legal profession in record numbers. But no powerful legal institution -- no law school faculty, no large corporate law firm, no appellate court -- has ever been dominated by women. Until now.
Last month, in the waning moments of his tenure, Gov. Rudy Perpich of Minnesota named a fourth woman, Sandra Gardebring, to that state's Supreme Court. When she was sworn in on Jan. 4, it marked the first time that women had achieved the most critical of critical masses on a court of last resort: a majority. 
 It is no longer news when a woman is named to a state supreme court. Currently, at least one sits on 27 of them. But for the most part, one is where the count has remained, just as it has on the United States Supreme Court. Only one state, Oklahoma, has two women on its highest court, and none have three.
But the first woman named the Minnesota Court, Rosalie E. Wahl, named by Governor Perpich in 1977, turned out to be more prelude than token. A second woman, M. Jeanne Coyne, was appointed by Gov. Albert Quie in 1982. Governor Perpich named the third, Esther M. Tomljanovich, in August 1990 and Judge Gardebring on his last work day in office.
No one is predicting that the new female majority on the seven-member Minnesota court will instantly produce changes in its jurisprudence, though some lawyers anticipate heightened sensitivity to cases involving domestic abuse, child custody, spousal support, sexual harassment, employment discrimination and other issues of traditional concern to women.
 
Trend in Cases Is Predicted
 Edward L. Winer, a Minneapolis divorce lawyer, said he expected the State Supreme Court to accept more family law cases and to "be more sensitive to traditional homemakers' being forced to return to the job market." In at least three instances in the past several years, the court's women have dissented from rulings in which the male majority reduced support payments for older women who had spent their prime years rearing children.
"It's not a question of liberal or conservative but of a different set of experiences," said Aviva Breen, director of the State Legislature's commission on the economic status of women.
At the same time, no one is minimizing the symbolic significance of the event, both on and off the court. To boys and girls now growing up in Minnesota, Ms. Breen said, an important institution with a majority of women on it will never be such an oddity. Moreover, the women on the court say the new numbers afford them a peculiar kind of freedom: to be themselves, rather than to be perceived as standard bearers for their sex.
Now, they say, they can be liberals or conservatives, activists or strict constructionists, heavyweights or hacks -- all the things male judges have always been free to be, including very different from one another. "I wouldn't expect the women to vote as a bloc any more often then the men," Justice Gardebring said.
The four women come from widely varying legal backgrounds. Justice Wahl was a public defender and law professor before her appointment, while Justice Coyne was a partner in a large Minneapolis law firm. Justice Tomljanovich was a trial judge and Justice Gardebring a state administrator before being named to the state appellate court in 1989.
Their marital backgrounds, too, are varied. Justice Wahl, 66 years old, is the divorced mother of five; Justice Coyne, 64, never married; Justice Tomljanovich, 59, has been married for many years and Justice Gardebring, at 43 the court's youngest member, married only recently.
Public reaction to the historic change has been muted. Still, it appears to have occasioned a quiet pride in the state's political tradition. "To the extent that we elected Rudy Perpich Governor, it reflects a part of us: the part that feels liberal, likes the unconventional, likes to think of ourselves as socially advanced," said Eric J. Magnuson, a Minneapolis lawyer who often argues before the Supreme Court.
Privately, several male lawyers pleaded with Governor Perpich not to appoint another woman. "With the white male establishment, one woman was O.K. and two women were not bad, but when it came to a majority, they were dead set against it," recalled Mr. Perpich's son, also named Rudy, who is a lawyer and an adviser to his father. "Over and over, I heard, 'But Governor, only 15 percent of the lawyers in the state are women.' "
But no one has expressed such sentiments publicly. "To hear those comments, you'd have to go to the men's locker room at the athletic club," said Justice Wahl.
D. Gerald Wilhelm, the county prosecutor in Fairmont, Minn., doubted that critics could be found even in there. "I cannot recall a rational person being terribly upset over this," he said. "There are always some people who are going to gripe, but that's antediluvian thinking."
The men on the court seem unperturbed by the change. "It just all of a sudden happened, and I don't think anyone has thought of it yet," said Chief Justice A. M. (Sandy) Keith, 62. Justice Lawrence R. Yetka, 66, the Court's senior member, appeared equally nonchalant. "I don't feel picked upon -- yet, at least," he said. The seventh justice is John E. Simonett.
Mr. Perpich appointed Justice Wahl to what was then a nine-member court in 1977, at a time when only four other states had women justices. When she joined the court, its quarters at the time, in the east wing of the state capitol did not have a women's restroom. "They hadn't thought of it," she recalled. She used the public restroom in the corridor.
 
A Liberal Tradition
 Some say Minnesota's first reflects a continuing legacy of Hubert H. Humphrey and the liberal Democrat-Farmer-Labor coalition he helped build. Still, until recently the state courts here were white male bastions; with names like Knutson, Christianson, and Nelson, the roster of Justices read like the telephone directory of the fictional Lake Wobegon.
More attribute the development to Mr. Perpich. In Minnesota, one phrase usually suffices to explain the former Governor's politics: "He's an Iron Ranger." Technically, that means he comes from the northeastern part of the state, the area including Hibbing, Chisholm, and Ely, where Eastern European miners arrived in the early years of the century. In addition to iron ore and taconite, the area produced a tradition of liberal politics, unionism and intense identification with underdogs.
Though Minnesota's population of minority citizens is small, Mr. Perpich stocked the lower levels of the state courts with them. And of his four Supreme Court appointments, three went to women. "I wasn't consciously trying to create a majority," Mr. Perpich recalled in an interview. "As Governor, I decided that bench should be more reflective of society, and more than half of society are women."
Oddly enough, Mr. Perpich, who named many women to other top positions in his administration and championed women's rights, lost his re-election bid largely due to the votes of women offended by his anti-abortion stand. Undeterred, he named Ms. Gardebring, who favors a woman's right to choose abortion. She, like Justice Tomljanovich, was a longtime protegee of the Governor's, proving that new-fangled sexual politics can combine with old-fangled politics of loyalty from the Iron Range.
Whether women behave differently from men on the bench is unclear. Based on her analysis of the opinions of Justices William H. Rehnquist and Sandra Day O'Connor, Suzanna Sherry of the University of Minnesota Law School suggested that rather than devise abstract rules, women jurists are more likely to scrutinize the facts in particular cases, and might place a higher premium on what she called "fostering community" -- that is, they try to decide cases in ways that leave losing parties feeling less alienated or disenfranchised.
 
Demonstration of Differences
 The divergent personal styles and philosophies of the four women, as well as the changing complexion of the legal profession, were apparent during oral arguments the court held here in a special appearance earlier this month at William Mitchell Law School, the alma mater of the former Chief Justice Warren E. Burger here.
Half of the students in the audience were women. So, too, were three of the four lawyers sitting at the counsel's table. The women on the improvised bench questioned the lawyers, particularly the woman advocate, far more aggressively than did their male counterparts. The most barbed questions came from Justice Coyne, who proved that in an increasingly egalitarian age, women judges, too, can be called "crusty."
Later, a student asked the justices to assess the significance of the new balance on the court. The women justices disagreed even on that. "I don't thing men are going to have to run for the hills, but there is definitely a woman's perspective," said Justice Tomljanovich, recalling past humiliations she had experienced as a woman in her personal life.
Justice Coyne dissented, saying she was "not going to get very excited" over the change. "A wise old man and a wise old woman reach the same conclusion," she said. "In the vast majority of cases, it will have no impact whatever."

HEADLINE: WAR IN THE GULF: White House;
PRESSING DEMANDS

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Friday, Feb. 22

 BODY:
After meeting with his advisers until midnight, President Bush decided today that the United States could not accept the latest Soviet proposal for an Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait, his spokesman said.
The spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said the State Department sent messages to military allies informing them that Mr. Bush had come to the conclusion that the Soviet plan would represent a "conditional withdrawal." The Soviet Government will be informed of the decision later today, he added. 
 Administration officials said that Mr. Bush was prepared to go ahead with the ground war unless President Saddam Hussein of Iraq agreed to an immediate and unconditional withdrawal. "We're going to hold him to the line," a senior aide to Mr. Bush said.
 
2 Main Objections
 Mr. Fitzwater said the Administration's two main objections to the Soviet proposal were a provision that would begin lifting the United Nations sanctions against Iraq when a troop withdrawal was only two-thirds complete, and another that would nullify all of the United Nations resolutions after the withdrawal ended.
The Administration wants to keep some sanctions in effect, notably an embargo on arms trade with Iraq, and it particularly wants to enforce a resolution that would require Iraq to pay reparations to Kuwait, the White House spokesman said.
It was unclear whether Bush Administration officials were hoping that the Soviets and Iraqis would recast the peace proposal, or whether they would prefer a decisive military victory that would rob Mr. Hussein of his political and military strengths. The Administration still sees the Iraqi leader on the ropes, militarily speaking, and a decisive allied victory within reach.
Administration officials have said it would be difficult to reject a peace proposal that would prevent a costly ground war. But as one senior Administration official put it, the United States wants to avoid a situation in which President Hussein escapes "without paying any real price for having invaded Kuwait."
The idea is to leave Mr. Hussein with as little of his vast military arsenal as possible after the war ends. For the same reason, the United States can be expected to continue its bombing while any remaining diplomacy takes it course.
But the tone of the White House response to the latest Soviet proposal was initially more positive than its reaction to two earlier peace initiatives.
Mr. Fitzwater said that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev telephoned President Bush on Thursday after meeting with the Iraqi Foreign Minister, Tariq Aziz, at 6:47 P.M Washington time, and that the two leaders spoke for 33 minutes.
Mr. Bush told Mr. Gorbachev that his quest for peace was "useful," although he said he had "serious concerns" about the specifics of the proposal. Mr. Fitzwater, choosing his words carefully, said then that the United States would study the plan, consult with its allies and shape a response. But he said that the military coalition would continue "to prosecute the war."
Sending out his first feeler last Friday, Mr. Hussein said he was prepared to "deal with" the first United Nations resolution demanding his withdrawal from Kuwait, but only under a series of conditions that included a conference on the Palestinian issue, an Israeli withdrawal from the West Bank and payments by the allied forces to rebuild Iraq.
Mr. Bush denounced that offer as "a cruel hoax" and "dead on arrival."
On Monday, Mr. Bush received the first Soviet proposal for an end to the gulf war. He said it fell "well short of what would be required" because it contained references to a conference on the Palestinians and guarantees of Iraq's territorial integrity. It also did not offer a specific timetable for withdrawal.
The proposal unveiled by the Soviets on Thursday did not mention a conference on the Palestinian issue, which was a major element of the initial Soviet proposal that Mr. Bush rejected so forcefully on Monday.
 
Bush Attends Play
 On Thursday evening, President Bush went to Ford's Theater to see "Black Eagles," a play about black pilots during World War II, while his advisers conferred on the offer.
After returning from the play, he met with his national security advisers for an hour and 40 minutes to discuss the latest Soviet proposal, Mr. Fitzwater said. Members of the military alliance aagainst Iraq were also consulted before the President decided to reject the initiative, the spokesman said.
Mr. Fitzwater said that the United States was still insisting on full compliance with all 12 United Nations resolutions on Kuwait. Some of the demands set by the United Nations were not mentioned in the Soviet proposal, including the stipulation that Iraq annul its annexation of Kuwait and restore the deposed Kuwaiti Emir.
The Pentagon said after the proposal was announced on Thursday that American forces would continue to fight until they received orders for a cease-fire from the White House. Pentagon officials said privately that they were opposed to any cease-fire before a complete Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait because it could be dangerous for allied forces.
"The military operation will continue," a Pentagon official said. "We've had no order to do otherwise."
 
On Verge of Ground War
 That left the military poised on the verge of a ground war which, according to Administration officials and diplomats, would begin with an assault on Iraq's defensive lines in southern Kuwait by United States Marines and Arab forces, along with a flanking attack by the United States Army directly toward the Republican Guards dug in on the north side of Kuwait.
The apparent success of the Soviet mediation effort had created a potential dilemma for President Bush. Congressional leaders had observed that if Mr. Hussein agreed to withdraw from Kuwait without getting any major concessions, it would put Mr. Bush in a painful box: He might have to go along or risk being seen as unreasonably extending the war.
But Administration officials said the danger was that such a resolution could allow Mr. Hussein to continue with enough political and military strength intact that he would remain in power with plenty of oil money to rebuild his air force and army.
 
Hopeful to Skeptical Reaction
 The reaction in Washington, at the United Nations and around the world had initially ranged from hopeful to skeptical, as officials tried to learn the details of the peace plan.
"Let's be very certain we've examined it carefully," said Bob Dole, the leader of the Senate's Republican minority, on the floor Thursday night. "Let's remember that the Soviet Union has only been an observer in this process. They haven't contributed any materiel or any young men or young women to the gulf coalition forces. And let's remember that Saddam Hussein may be playing a stalling game."
Senator Trent Lott, Republican of Mississippi, was more optimistic. "It sounds like this may be what we're looking for, Saddam getting out without condition," he said.
 
A Pessimistic Mood
 The turn of events in Moscow followed a day in which Washington had been consumed by a growing sense that the Soviet mediation would fall through and that a ground war was, as one senior Arab diplomat put it this afternoon, "damn close."
The pessimistic mood had been reinforced by the Bush Administration's response to a radio address in which Mr. Hussein said that his army of occupation was prepared for a land war if President Bush continued to reject Iraq's conditions for peace.
The Bush Administration reacted by warning that it was moving ahead with plans for one of the largest ground attacks in modern history. The President took Mr. Hussein's speech as a signal that "he intends to continue the war," Mr. Fitzwater said then.
But the address on Baghdad Radio, couched in heroic and vague language and laced with quotations from the Koran, seemed more indirect and less categorical than the Administration's reading of it. It appeared to be directed primarily trying to push the Administration into a negotiated settlement. In retrospect, it seemed to be Mr. Hussein's attempt to lay the groundwork for a claim that he had defied the enormous military arsenal assembled against him.
 
'The Same Invective'
 "O, brothers, O people, note how those who feared a ground battle have now avoided the showdown for over a month," Mr. Hussein said. He accused the allies of "killing civilians and destroying property with their long-range aircraft and missiles" and added, "They are doing this to cover up their inability to confront our land forces in southern Iraq."
The speech described the war as a "conflict between Iraq -- as a bastion of faith and honorable aspiration and Zionism and U.S. imperialism." It included a litany of complaints about "what Zionism and U.S. imperialism have done against Iraq, beginning with the Irangate plot or the Iran-contra scandal in 1986." It also attacked other Arab leaders, including King Fahd of Saudi Arabia, who Mr. Hussein said "chews his words like a camel chews the grasses."
After listening to Mr. Hussein's speech on Thursday morning, the White House dismissed it as "the same invective and disregard for the United Nations mandate that we have heard so often since Aug. 2."
 
Bush Listens in Study
 The President listened to the speech in his study off the Oval Office, then studied a translation of it with his national security advisers.
"We read the words very carefully," Mr. Fitzwater said, adding that the Administration's initial impression was that Mr. Hussein "intends to continue the war."
Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, testifying before the Senate Armed Services Committee, said that the United States was on course for "one of the largest land assaults of modern times."
Reflecing the mood in the capital, a senior Arab diplomat said at midafternoon on Thursday that Mr. Hussein's speech was self-destructive and certain to set off a ground war.
The diplomat called the speech "music to my ears" because he thought it was the death knell for hopes of peace before a ground war. He said he had been concerned that the coalition would accept a settlement between the Soviets and Iraqis that left too much of Mr. Hussein's power intact.
The debate over the terms for a withdrawal centers on what kind of military Iraq should have after the Persian Gulf crisis, one strong enough that might allow Mr. Hussein to exert his power regionally in the future, or one so weakened and humiliated that its leadership, perhaps allied with opposition forces, would be tempted to overthrow Mr. Hussein.
United States military officials said it could take weeks for Iraq to withdraw the hundreds of thousands of troops occupying Kuwait as part of an overall 540,000-member army that extends into southern Iraq. An Army tank expert expressed doubt whether Iraqi forces could start the engines and start moving many of its top-of-the-line Soviet tanks, that have spent months buried deeply in sand berms with little or no preventative maintenance.
An allied demand for Iraqi troops to leave Kuwait in a matter of a few days -- the Soviet plan unveiled on Thursday included an unspecified time limit -- would force them to abandon thousands of pieces of heavy armored equipment that would cost billions of dollars to replace, military officials said.
"If he has to leave fast, he can't take all that with him," one White House official said. Asked how could such a large army could leave Kuwait on such a rapid schedule, given the devastation to roads, bridges and basic supplies like food, the official replied, "With their shoes on."
An Administration official, acknowledging that the United Nations mandate did not provide for stripping Iraq of its military equipment, said, "If he keeps that equipment, it could affect our ability to rebuild the peace and stability in the gulf, which is one of the objectives of the U.N. resolutions."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Iraqi prisoners waiting to be processed early yesterday by the 101st Airborne Division. They were among more than 400 captured on Wednesday when American helicopters attacked an Iraqi bunker complex. (Reuters) (pg. A1); Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, left, and Gen. Colin L. Powell, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, at Senate hearing yesterday before announcement of Soviet-Iraqi plan. Mr. Cheney told of the prospect of what he said would be "one of the largest land assaults of modern times." (Andrea Mohin for The New York Times) (pg. A6)

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Off in World Trading, And Gold Prices Also Drop

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar declined on world currency markets yesterday as traders believed a ground offensive against Iraq appeared to be near. Long after the market closed, however, the Soviet Union announced that Iraq had agreed on steps that could lead to an Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait and an end to the Persian Gulf War.
The White House said the United States would study the proposal and shape a response after consulting its allies. 
 The dollar tumbled in European trading after a speech by President Saddam Hussein of Iraq in which he held his ground against withdrawal from Kuwait.
"Before he spoke there was anticipation of a pullout," said Andrew Busch, a trader with the Harris Trust and Savings Bank in Chicago. But as soon as President Hussein said his position was unchanged, Mr. Busch added, traders began to sell the dollar and it hit the lows of the day.
Most traders said that they expected an allied-led ground battle to erupt and that investors were moving to the sidelines to await further war developments.
When dealing shifted to domestic markets, the dollar seesawed on comments from Alan Greenspan, Federal Reserve chairman. His characterization of the dollar's recent slide as unwelcome was initially bullish for the currency, and it moved higher.
But in further testimony before Congress, he indicated that banks remained reluctant to lend. And that, said Marc Chandler, an analyst with the firm IDEA, was interpreted by the market as a sign that "more Fed easing is likely."
A move by the Fed to ease credit by lowering interest rates generally hurts the dollar because it makes dollar-denominated securities less valuable for investors.
Traders said his comments made for choppy dealing, and the dollar was unable to recover.
In New York the dollar settled at 131.27 yen, down from 131.50 yen on Wednesday.
It cost $1.9568, meanwhile, to buy one British pound in New York, more expensive than Wednesday's $1.9500.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Wednesday's rates, included: 1.4925 German marks, down from 1.4955; 1.2745 Swiss francs, down from 1.2785; 5.0755 French francs, down from 5.0865; 1,117.25 Italian lire, down from 1,121.00, and 1.1495 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1527.
Gold prices also lost ground yesterday. On New York's Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery fell $2 an ounce to settle at $362.70. The Republic National Bank quoted a late bid for gold of $361.25, down $2.45 an ounce.

LENGTH: 1084 words

HEADLINE: Oregon Shakes Up Pioneering Health Plan for the Poor

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORTLAND, Ore., Feb. 21

 BODY:
After coming under intense criticism for a list of medical priorities that placed headaches and thumb-sucking ahead of diseases like cystic fibrosis and viral pneumonia, Oregon health officials have overhauled the rankings and produced a list that is far more reflective of popular sentiment -- a kind of health care by democracy.
If the Federal Government approves, Oregon will use the list to expand public health care to thousands of people as part of its effort to become the first state to guarantee basic health care to all its citizens. 
 Medicaid, the Federal-state health care program for the poor, will finance treatment only for those procedures in the upper part of the list; the money saved by eliminating costly procedures at the bottom will be used to provide treatment for many more people. To spread the money around to every Oregonian who is without health insurance, fewer options for treatment would be available to the 190,000 who are receiving Medicaid now.
The final plan was adopted Wednesday by the Oregon Health Services Commission. As with the earlier draft list, issued in May, its emphasis is on preventive care and treatable life-threatening diseases that affect many people, rather than on conditions that are minor or, by contrast, fatal and incurable.
 
A Line-by-Line Vote on Illnesses
 But the earlier version was generated by computer, based on a formula that took into account the costs of treating 1,600 diseases and the benefits of such treatment -- a blend of objective and subjective considerations that included the average period of survival and the "quality of well-being" after treatment.
The new list uses the same formula as a base, but it reflects extensive polls and interviews with ordinary Oregonians, followed by a line-by-line vote by the 11 members of the health commission to move illnesses up or down the list. In the process, the list was boiled down to 800 by combining groups of related diseases -- several kinds of pneumonia, for example.
The commissioners, who approved the plan unanimously, said they used common-sense human judgments. "We realized that the initial formula did not take into account a lot of what people were telling us in public hearings and polls," said one member, Dr. Rick Wopat. He is one of five physicians on the commission, whose members are appointed by the Governor; the others are a social worker, a nurse and four representatives of patients' advocacy groups.
The new rankings move organ transplants from near the bottom to near the middle. Familiar ailments like pneumonia and tuberculosis move to the top of the list, replacing less well-known ones, like candidiasis, a fungal infection, and Wilms tumor, a type of cancer. Terminal AIDS, with less than 10 percent chance of survival, and several untreatable ailments are ranked in the bottom 10. AIDS detected in the early phases, for which some treatment is available, is ranked in the upper 25 percent of the list.
The cutoff -- the line below which no public financing would be provided -- is to be drawn later this year, after actuaries determine the full cost of the operations and the budget. Oregon now spends $700 million on public health care every two years; it gets 63 percent of that from the Federal Government. The new program is expected to increase health care expenditures by at least 10 percent.
 
Congressional Skepticism
 The plan requires a waiver of Medicaid rules from Dr. Louis Sullivan, the Secretary of Health and Human Services. He has not indicated whether he will support the experiment, saying he is waiting to see how much it will cost. Proponents are also asking Congress to change the Federal law that governs allocation of Medicaid benefits.
The plan has been widely praised in Oregon, with proponents, including Gov. Barbara Roberts, calling it the first comprehensive attempt by any state to provide health care to all its citizens. John Kitzhaber, a physician who is the State Senate President and who proposed the plan, said: "No one else in this country has been willing to confront the inequities in our current system. It's the non-policy on the Potomac that has driven us to the situation we have now, where 37 million Americans are without medical insurance."
Critics, both here and in Congress, say the plan amounts to rationing of government health money. Representative Henry Waxman, the California Democrat who is chairman of the House Health and Environment Committee, said the plan set up a two-tier medical system: one for those with access to the costly miracles of modern medicine, one for those without.
That criticism was echoed today by Sandy Willow of the Northwest Seasonal Workers Association, an advocacy group for the poor. "At a time when so many people can indulge themselves by buying face lifts and tummy tucks," she said, "this state is saying they have no options but to determine which among the poor will be left to die or suffer for want of money."
Lynn M. Etheredge, a health economist who worked at the Federal Office of Management and Budget from 1969 to 1982, said Oregon's proposal was an example of the lengths to which states were going to deal with the rapidly rising costs of Medicaid. "In my view," he said, "we ought to avoid doing this until we have exhausted all other means of trying to control health care costs."
But in Oregon, the medical establishment, consumer groups and advocates for the poor are applauding the plan for its pioneering attempt to compile a comprehensive ranking of medical procedures. "Even if this list is ultimately not used, it's a very useful tool for everybody concerned about health care," said Wendy Van Elverdinghe, of Oregon Health Action Committee, a consumer group.
Dr. Kitzhaber, whose supporters in Congress see the Oregon plan as a potential model for a national health care system, said the existing system already amounted to health care rationing by default because it deprived so many people of any health insurance. In Oregon, for example, a family of four cannot qualify for Medicaid if its income is more than $6,493 a year.
Dr. Michael Garland, a medical ethicist at Oregon Health Sciences University, said, "Explicit choice is better than hidden rationing."
Dr. Tina Castanares, a member of the health services commission whose medical practice treats primarily low-income patients, said the plan would make care available to people who are seldom seen except in costly emergencies.

HEADLINE: New York City's Finances Worsening, Regan Says

BYLINE: By JOSH BARBANEL

 BODY:
State Comptroller Edward V. Regan said yesterday that New York City's fiscal situation had sharply worsened, even in the last month or so, and that the Dinkins administration had not presented a "credible plan" to deal with it.
"It is a failure of leadership," he said. But he tempered his comments by noting that the administration faced a huge problem and was operating under especially strict reporting and accounting standards, required after the city's brush with bankruptcy in the 1970's. 
 Mr. Regan made his remarks at his Manhattan office, where he released a commentary on a preliminary budget issued by Mr. Dinkins last month. While Mr. Dinkins called for a shrinking of city government, the report said the Mayor's budget would continue to grow faster than the inflation rate.
The report is one of a series of critical reports due to be released in the next week or so that fiscal analysts say will likely paint gloomy portraits of a city teetering toward what could be a fiscal crisis, requiring deep service cuts and tax increases.
Mr. Regan's report said the $2 billion gap between revenues and expenses documented by Mr. Dinkins last month had grown to $3 billion, partly because of state budget cuts and a worsening local economy, and that many of the measures proposed to close the gap were uncertain at best. Mr. Regan is a member of the state's Financial Control Board, which oversees the city's finances, and is required by law to report on the city's fiscal plans.
"We have very difficult fiscal problems," said Philip R. Michael, the city's Budget Director. "But we have them well under control with plenty of time to deal with them." He said the city was doing far better than the state, which faces a $6 billion deficit. "I forget," Mr. Michael asked dryly, "who is the State Comptroller." 
Mr. Regan's analysis shows that despite a local recession, spending, supported by city taxes, is scheduled to rise 7.1 percent in the fiscal year ending June 30 and 5.9 percent in the next year, higher than the local inflation rate. Tax increases will pay for most of the rise in spending, his report said.
He called on Mr. Dinkins to make deep permanent changes in how the city operates, demanding productivity increases and work-rule changes from city workers, changing Civil Service laws that "entrench low-priority functions and employees," supporting cuts in Medicaid benefits and reducing services in city hospitals.
Mr. Regan's report is based on assumptions that a recession in the local economy will be somewhat longer and slightly worse than the Dinkins administration expects. It predicts that the city will be unable to win approval for some of the taxing authority it is seeking and that it will have difficulty carrying out $400 million in budget cuts at the Board of Education for next year.
The report estimates that there is a $277 million gap in this fiscal year's budget and puts the city's gap next year at nearly $1 billion above the gap expected by the administration. Of this, $500 million comes from reductions in state aid and $174 million in lower tax revenue, with the balance from higher spending on city programs.
Mr. Dinkins presented a plan to close a $2 billion gap. But Mr. Regan said about half of this plan was uncertain, including some of the $580 million in tax increases proposed by the administration and cuts in education aid.

HEADLINE: New Orleans Journal;
In One City, 2 Campuses Worlds Apart on War

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 16

 BODY:
Two black Avia hightop sneakers rest at the bottom of an abandoned locker in the Xavier University gym, and the size 15 feet that used to fill them are now swathed in military leather. Chris Harvey, a 6-foot 7-inch junior, had just become the basketball team's starting center last November when the mobilization put his athletic career on hold. Like many black students, this former reservist is in the Army now.
Similar stories of interrupted lives are being told across this modest campus, home to one of the nation's 41 historically black colleges. Many students here have left to fulfill military obligations, often incurred to help pay for college, and virtually everyone has friends or family in the Persian Gulf. 
 That personal contact is bringing bitterness; almost unanimously, Xavier students speak angrily about the war. They argue that the United States is being hypocritical by seeking to fight problems overseas while ignoring those at home, and that the nation is asking blacks to bear a disproportionate burden on both fronts.
Dr. Norman C. Francis, Xavier's president since 1968, used the word "pall" to describe the campus mood and said today's students felt more threatened by this war than the previous generation did by the one in Vietnam. The difference, he said, is that today's fighting comes as students are already fearful of what they see as their own waning economic prospects and an assault on civil rights.
The attitudes at Xavier are strikingly different from those at Tulane, a predominantly white university about mile away but a world apart in the backgrounds of its students. The proportion of Xavier students who have been forced from school because of military obligations is many times greater than that at Tulane. Perhaps as a result, it is almost as hard to find an Xavier student willing to defend the war as it is to find one at Tulane willing to criticize it.
The contrast suggests that in the absence of a draft, which helped form a generational division on the war in Vietnam, student views on this war are sculptered less by age than by forces like race and class.
"War Disrupts Campus," proclaimed the Xavier Herald, where one editor of the student newspaper wrote of "50,000 body bags per month" coming home and another described her husband's call to active duty as a form of slavery.
In a locker room discussion after basketball practice this week, Mr. Harvey's former teammates voiced similar disenchantment.
"I'd rather go to Canada," said Raymond Brothers, a 21-year-old senior guard from Lafayette, La. "The U.S. steps in in Iraq, but they've got apartheid in South Africa -- why doesn't the U.S. step in there?"
Merlin Peters, the team's co-captain, served four years as a marine before being spotted in a pickup game and offered a basketball scholarship to Xavier. He said his mother pressured him to join the service to get him away from the street corners of a New Orleans housing project.
"They're not over there by choice, by no stretch of the imagination," said Mr. Peters, whose brother is a marine in the gulf. "Blacks mainly join for economic reasons."
The registrar's office said about 33 of Xavier's 2,900 students have withdrawn to fulfill military obligations.
That rate is about 10 times as high as at Tulane, where about a dozen of 11,000 students have left for military reasons. There, the war brought few protesters and no student editorials.
On a campus where nearly a third of the students are Jewish, some support for the war is concentrated in organizations like Hillel, which has sponsored several demonstrations in favor of United States policy. "Any time there's a threat to Israel we see it as a threat to ourselves as well," said David Fox, the 19-year-old sophomore who is president the group.
Most fraternity members support the war as well. The Sigma Alpha Epsilon fraternity house appeared a hotbed of social rest on the day after Mardi Gras, with the smell of stale beer wafting upstairs to the room where Spencer Ott sat watching a videotape movie. Mr. Ott won the agreement of his fraternity brothers when he said the United States was the only country capable of stopping President Saddam Hussein of Iraq. "It's our duty to the world," he said.
Mr. Ott, whose father is a Naples, Fla., investor, said he could already see domestic gains from the war, in a rising stock market and falling oil prices, and he was unpersuaded that it reflected social inequities.
"You could argue that there are more black people fighting because there are more black people who are poor," he said. "But it's better that they're doing something with their lives, not turning to crime and drugs like you see on T.V."
Like Mr. Ott, Mr. Harvey, the former Xavier center, did not envision himself being involved in a war. Though Xavier provided him with a full scholarship, friends said he joined the Army Reserves last spring
to earn some extra spending money: $112.48 a month for one weekend's duty as an administrative clerk.
The walls of his mother's home in the St. Thomas housing project here are papered with similar emblems of his strivings: commendations for his work in school, on the court and in summer jobs at the sheriff's office.
No one recalls hearing him complain when he learned he was being called up. He is now at Fort Polk, La., awaiting further orders.
