HEADLINE: Dow Slips 7.18 for Third Consecutive Loss

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
Stock prices turned mixed yesterday, with Soviet-Iraqi negotiations on all-out war or peace in the Middle East too close to call by the market's closing hour.
Suggesting that investors were not buying or selling much of anything to any great extent, the Dow Jones industrial average of 30 blue chips fell 7.18, to 2,891.83, for the third loss in as many days. 
Well after the market had closed, the Soviet Union announced that Iraq had accepted a peace proposal, but the White House responded cautiously, saying it would study the proposal and prepare a response after discussions with its allies.
At Instinet, the after-hours trading service, Richard Schenkman, vice president, said last night after the announcement, "We're open for business, but haven't seen a whole lot of interest in response to what's going on."
 
Drop in Volume
 On the Big Board yesterday, trading, which has been steadily dropping, fell to 180.8 million shares from 185.7 million the day before. Birinyi Associates said program buying lifted the Dow only 2.5 points throughout the day.
Even so, 834 Big Board stocks advanced while 715 fell. Only 4 hit new lows, while 74 rose to new highs. One of the new highs was A. G. Edwards, the brokerage firm, which fell 3/8, to 28 1/4, after a reaching a new high of 29 1/8.
"We're in a holding pattern," Jack Solomon, market technician for Bear, Stearns & Company, said of the day's action.
"We're waiting to see what the messengers and minions have to say between Baghdad and Moscow and, ultimately, for Washington's response."
In a cautious upside forecast, he argued that "if we win the war and lose the peace, the market would go down in frustration." But, he added, "if we go into a land war and succeed -- and are not too bloodied in the process -- this market will crash through the 3,000 barrier in no time flat."
The Dow soared last July to a record 2,999.75, sank to a low of 2,365.10 in October and has been building almost steadily since then. As of yesterday, the Dow was only a little more than 100 points below the record.
 
Deeper Recession Forecast
 While the most recent Government figures tend to suggest that inflation could still be a problem, and, therefore, make it difficult for the Federal Reserve to bring down interest rates to stimulate business, the Commodity Research Bureau index sank yesterday to 211.21, a new low for the year.
Asked about the number, Stuart Shinbein, senior technical editor for the index, said, "It means we're still on course for a deeper recession, and we're not coming out quick."
"If we were to come out of recession by the next quarter, as so many now assume," he said, "we would have seen a reversal in the bear trend in commodity prices that began with the 1988 peak in grain prices."
The decline, he said, is "across the board," except for cattle and cotton.
With the Dow blue chips down, only moderately, changes among the 30 industrials were small. But I.B.M., which dozens of traders check even before checking the Dow to see where the market is going, dropped 2 3/8, to 135 1/2, with 1.6 million shares changing hands.
Digital Equipment also fell, by 1 1/8, to 76 1/2; Apple Computer was down 2, to 59; Microsoft 2 3/4, to 100; System Software dropped 2 3/4, to 19 1/4, and General Motors E was off 1 3/8, to 41 1/4.
Among advancing issues, Conner Peripherals rose 1 3/8, to 26 1/8; Gerber Scientific 1 1/8, to 11, and Adobe Systems 2 1/4, to 45 1/2. Bruce Lupatkin of Hambrecht & Quist recommended Adobe because of several new products to be introduced in March.

 TOKYO, Friday, Feb. 22 (Reuters) -- Stocks were down at midday today in Tokyo on news of the guarded reaction from Washington to the Soviet-Iraqi peace plan. At the end of the morning session, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was off 32.20 points, to 25,992.17.

HEADLINE: U.S. Rules Would Force Businesses To Make Alterations for the Disabled

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21

 BODY:
The Bush Administration today proposed rules that would require businesses to make structural alterations to offices and stores to accommodate the disabled unless they can show that the expense would be too great or if they furnish an alternative way of providing service.
The regulations, spelling out how last year's Americans with Disablities Act will be enforced, would also require that businesses, including professional practitioners, insure that disabled consumers receive the same level of services as other customers as much as possible, even if that means altering the way business is conducted. 
 The rules, to be published Friday in the Federal Register, follow the publication of guidelines last month for enforcing the new law, which prohibits discrimination against people with physical and mental impairments in employment, transportation, telecommunications services and public accommodations.
The guidelines were written by a Federal advisory agency, the Architectural and Transportation Compliance Board, to help the Department of Justice set "accessibility standards" for commercial establishments being built or renovated.
 
Rules for Existing Businesses
 The Justice Department rules proposed today incorporate those guidelines and go further by covering what existing businesses must do. Last month's rules simply specified the structural provisions that must be made to accommodate the handicapped when a building is built or renovated.
The rules, which are subject to revision after a 60-day period of public comment, are to go into effect Jan. 26, 1992. Businesses with 25 or fewer employees will have an additional six months to comply, and businesses with 10 or fewer workers will not be covered until Jan. 26, 1993.
In addition to specifying the structural changes required by the disabilities act, the draft rules issued today address changes in services.
For example, restaurants would have to make sure that blind customers are aware of what dishes are available, either by providing menus in Braille or having a waiter read the selections. Banks would have to make automatic teller machines accessible to disabled individuals, largely by building or moving the machines low enough to be reached by people in wheelchairs.
 
Millions of Businesses
 "These regulations represent a fair and balanced enforcement tool for the Americans with Disabilities Act," Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said in a statement that accompanied the release of the draft rules. "The Department of Justice has sought to strike a balance between the right of persons with disabilities to enter the mainstream of society and the workplace, and the financial and physical limits of the business community."
According to the Census Bureau, 1.7 million Americans are deaf in both ears, 7.7 million Americans have trouble hearing what is said in normal conversations and more than 13 million have impaired vision. At least 1.3 million people use wheelchairs or walkers, and 8 million have severe difficulty walking.
The regulations proposed today deal exclusively with the public accommodation provisions of the law. They will affect more than 3.8 million companies that operate an estimated five million commercial establishments, including hotels, motels, theaters, concert halls, restaurants, banks, retail outlets, museums, doctors and lawyers offices, gyms, day care centers, parks and rental car companies. Private clubs, churches and establishments run by religious organizations are exempt from the regulations.
Violators are subject to a fine of up to $50,000 for the first offense and up to $100,000 for subsequent offenses. Disabled people or the Justice Department may seek a court order to enforce the law, and the Justice Department may also seek civil damages on behalf of disabled people who complain of biased treatment.
Pat Wright, director of government affairs for the Disability Rights Education and Defense Fund, a advocacy group based in Berkeley, Calif., said that she was generally pleased with the draft regulations but that lobbyists for disabled groups would seek to toughen some of the proposals to allow more access for the disabled to various businesses and services.
 
'Fine Tuning' Sought
 "I think they reflect the spirit of the law," she said. "But I think they need some fine tuning." Ms. Wright added that about 70 disabled groups would be meeting here next week to analyze the regulations line by line.
Officials from the United States Chamber of Commerce, which has raised concerns about the potential cost to business, said they had not yet analyzed the regulations and therefore would not comment on them.
Under the disabilities law, enacted in July, all new commercial establishments must be accessible to people with physical disabilities, including those in wheelchairs. Existing businesses must alter their premises so disabled individuals can enter and easily conduct their business. Such alterations, the regulations say, might include placing ramps over stairways, widening aisles and lowering shelves.
Alterations do not need to be made if the company demonstrates that they would be too difficult or too xpensive to undertake. Companies can also opt not to renovate if they devise an alternative method of serving disabled customers, like curbside service or home delivery.
 
Changing Habits, Not Just Offices
 But beyond the issue of accessiblity, commercial outlets will have to modify some of their practices to accommodate individuals with physical or mental impairments.
Some of the modifications are relatively minor. Retail outlets could satisfy the needs of deaf or speech-impaired clients by providing pencils and pads. On the other hand, doctors discussing medical problems with a deaf patient could be required to hire a sign-language interpreter. Hotels and motels that have five or more rooms must be able to provide special telephones in the rooms upon request so that deaf and speech-impaired guests can make outside calls or contact the front desk or room service.
Businesses must also jettison policies that tend to exclude disabled individuals.
For example, businesses would no longer be able to use a drivers license as the only means of identification when cashing a check because such a policy excludes blind people. Companies would, however, be able to maintain policies that are necessary for the safe and effecient operation of the business. Thus, an amusement park operator could keep a height requirement for a ride if that criterion is considered a safety measure.
 
Integrating the Disabled
 The regulations call for integrating the disabled as much as possible. For example, unless it is prohibitively expensive, movie houses, theaters, concert halls, sports arenas and auditoriums must maintain seating arrangements that allow disabled and able-bodied individuals to sit together.
The regulations specify that if a company declares that altering its facility or practices creates an undue financial hardship, a Federal court would be allowed to look at the finances of both the business and its parent company in assessing that claim.
Wendy Lechner, manager of research and policy development for the National Federation of Independent Business, a lobbying group for small businesses that has opposed certain provisions of the law, said that the regulations could force some companies to abandon operations in less economically viable locations.
"It will make business owners think twice about where they will locate a facility," Ms. Lechner said. "It may hurt business in inner city or rural areas."

HEADLINE: WAR IN THE GULF: Washington;
New Bill Mandates Sanctions On Makers of Chemical Arms

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21

 BODY:
The Senate passed legislation on Wednesday night that requires the President to impose sanctions on countries and companies developing or using chemical or biological weapons.
President Bush rejected an almost identical measure last year. But Congress had adjourned by the time he announced his decision and there was no chance to try to override a veto. Mr. Bush said then that he could not accept the bill because it did not give him the authority to waive all sanctions if he thought the national interest required him to. 
 But on Wednesday night, the White House accepted the bill after Senator Bob Dole, Republican of Kansas, the minority leader, and Senator Jake Garn, Republican of Utah, pressed for only modest changes. The revisions would allow Mr. Bush to delay the imposition of sanctions against foreign companies while he sought to get their own governments to punish them. The Dole-Garn amendment did not allow any delays or waivers in sanctions against countries that use poison gas or germ warfare.
The amendment and the bill itself were passed without opposition on roll-call votes. It was clear all along that the bill had enough support to pass, and perhaps to overcome a veto. Last year the Senate voted 92 to 0 to adopt it.
Among the leading Republicans speaking for mandatory sanctions was Senator Jesse Helms, the conservative North Carolina Republican. He insisted that failure to impose sanctions against Iraq for using poison gas, and against German companies that had aided Baghdad, had encouraged those companies to help Libya, too.
The bill, the Omnibus Export Amendments Act, also included provisions that would ease controls on exports of high technology to Eastern European countries if they agreed to protect that technology; establish procedures for updating lists of prohibited exports; reauthorize and expand export-promotion activities of the Commerce Department, and extend the Export-Import Bank subsidy program to help support American exports.

HEADLINE: ABROAD AT HOME;
It Is a Victory

BYLINE: By Anthony Lewis

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
The late-night agreement between Moscow and Baghdad poses hard questions for President Bush. But it entitles him to claim a great victory of principle. And that is the way he should frame his reply: as a statement of victory.
Saddam Hussein is ready to withdraw from Kuwait. That is the bottom line. 
 Moreover, he -- and President Gorbachev -- gave up any linkage to the Palestinian or other Middle East issues. He agreed to the immediate release of war prisoners, a point demanded by Mr. Bush. And he abandoned his insistence that American and other foreign forces withdraw from the gulf as his leave Kuwait.
Some of the terms will be hard to swallow for President Bush and even some Americans who have disagreed with him about the war.
One is the provision that all United Nations resolutions about the gulf crisis be canceled, apparently including the call for payment of reparations by Iraq. Why shouldn't Iraq pay for the horrors it has inflicted on Kuwait? On the other hand, is there any realistic expectation of payment in Iraq's stricken state? But the provision does grate.
Another difficult provision calls for the lifting of economic sanctions on Iraq when its withdrawal from Kuwait is two-thirds complete. Sanctions could be a useful tool to keep degrees of international control on what Saddam Hussein may do in the future.
But against the doubts over those clauses there is the overwhelming human fact of the peace agreement: It would spare the United States and its allies a ground war. That President Bush could insist on a massive ground attack in this circumstance seems politically impossible.
A ground war must be off at least until the new situation is clarified. But President Bush can keep the air attacks going on Iraqi forces in the Kuwait area while he goes into what amounts to an unacknowledged negotiating phase.
Mr. Bush can answer the proposal with modifications of his own. But the thought here is that he should frame his answer in affirmative terms, treating this as a victory on the fundamental question of Iraq's aggression in Kuwait.
There will be voices on the American Right urging Mr. Bush to say a flat no. Those conservative voices want the United States to expand the aims of the war from freeing Kuwait to removing Saddam Hussein.
A recent editorial in The Wall Street Journal was an example of such thinking. Saddam Hussein, it said, must be removed "by death, flight or, preferably, capture." The editorial did not shy from urging that American forces battle on as far as necessary to capture him.
It indeed would be a blessing to have a different president of Iraq at the end of this affair. Saddam Hussein is a vicious tyrant who would make as much trouble as he could if in office, even with his military power largely destroyed.
But to have American armies pursue him across Iraq and capture him would be the surest way to make him a martyr. All his propaganda about the imperialist conspiracy would be borne out in the minds of many Arabs and other third world peoples.
And if American forces fought their way to Baghdad, what would they do then? Install a U.S. proconsul to govern Iraq? Choose a new president? Either of those courses would arouse profound hostility among Arabs, who have long since made clear their feelings about the way Britain and France installed rulers over them after World War I.
The coalition wisely formed by President Bush to undo the Iraqi occupation of Kuwait would split over such an expansion of war aims at the very moment peace is a possibility. The United Nations Security Council would not authorize it. The international consensus that gave the allied cause legitimacy would be gone, and with it what hope remained of Mr. Bush's "new world order."
The idea of carrying this war on to Baghdad to capture Saddam Hussein rests, in the end, on a fundamental illusion. That is the belief that complicated political problems can be solved by military action -- unilateral American military action.
The Middle East is a stew-pot of conflicting religions, races, dreams. Secretary of State Baker was surely right when he said the United States must address the region's problems "with a due sense of modesty."
The one great recent success in easing Middle East conflicts was a substitution of politics for force. Anwar Sadat and Menachem Begin made peace, and their work endures amid so much instability and fear.

HEADLINE: Latins Admire the Stability of the Dollar

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Dependence and Sovereignty Pull at Panama's Equilibrium" (front page, Feb. 11) mentions, somewhat disdainfully, that Panama's currency remains the United States dollar. It is true that one balboa has always been worth exactly $1. But in a hemisphere where central banks usually become the Treasury's printing office, what a blessing it has been for Panamanians not to have a separate currency and a central bank easily manipulated by corrupt governments. Panama remains Latin America's only country without a history of appalling inflation; Latin governments often rob their citizens without raising taxes, just by printing money.
Shoeshine boys in Rio ask to be paid in greenbacks, and real estate is often advertised south of the border in United States dollars; or by the time the transaction is closed the house may be worth a tenth of the asking price. People also save in dollars because "democratic" governments have frozen their savings.
Democracy does not mean very much if not linked to property rights. It is beautiful to vote every four or five years for the politicians of our choice, but it is far more important to have the freedom to vote every day with our money in the marketplace. Brazilian shoeshine boys know that; American intellectuals tend to forget it. That's a luxury we Latins can't afford.
 
CARLOS BALL
Boca Raton, Fla., Feb. 11, 1991
 
The writer is a Venezuelan journalist.

HEADLINE: Cuts to Health Centers Are Ill Conceived

 BODY:
To the Editor:
President Bush's proposal to combat infant mortality in 10 cities by taking money from the community health center program and the block grant for maternal and child health is an ill-conceived plan with potentially disastrous consequences (front page, Feb. 7). Community health centers, in existence in the United States since the beginning of this century, have had a long and successful history, serving urban and rural areas.
In 1907, Wilbur Phillips, secretary of the New York City Milk Committee, established the "milk depot," a maternal and child health center to reduce high infant mortality rates in the city. Over the years, community health centers provided medical and social services in neighborhoods with concentrations of poor immigrants.
During the 1960's war on poverty, community health centers played a major role in reducing infant mortality rates, low birthweight, and infectious and communicable diseases. Recently, community health centers have provided vital services for prevention, education and treatment of acquired immune deficiency syndrome. Today community health centers, despite strong evidence of their effectiveness, struggle for existence, surviving on minimal state, Federal and private grants.
The maternal and child health block grant, initiated in 1982 by the Reagan Administration, has channeled Federal dollars to local community agencies for maternal, infant, child and adolescent services. Most states have plans for maternal and child health block grants that give priority to lowering infant mortality rates and closing the gap between white and nonwhite infant mortality rates and low birthweight.
To achieve a quick fix solution to the high infant mortality, the Bush Administration is ignoring the record of well-organized comprehensive programs. The long-term consequences may be increased costs to society, as community health centers and other local programs lose economic support and close their doors to the communities they are dedicated to serving.
 
ANNE DIEVLER
Baltimore, Feb. 11, 1991
 
The writer is a doctoral candidate at the Johns Hopkins School of Hygiene and Public Health.

HEADLINE: The Prince a Corporate Raider? No, Just Joking

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR

 BODY:
Prince al-Waleed bin Talal, the 35-year-old Saudi who is investing $590 million in Citicorp, once declared in an effusive moment that he would "love to be a corporate raider."
Prince Waleed was said to be unavailable in Saudi Arabia yesterday, but his advisers were assuring Citicorp that the remark in 1988 to a reporter for Forbes magazine was made in jest. 
 The source of his money for the Citicorp move is not completely clear. Most of what is known about the Prince comes from his advisers and his own account, rendered during the few times he has spoken with the press.
 
Started With a $15,000 Loan
 By their version, he started in business in Riyadh in 1979 after receiving a degree in business administration from Menlo College in Atherton, Calif. His start-up capital was $15,000 he borrowed from his father, Prince Talal bin Abdul Aziz. He quickly exhausted that money and, when his father refused to bankroll him further, went to the local branch of Citibank.
At first, Citibank was also reluctant, but agreed to a loan when the young Prince put up his home as collateral. His fledgling enterprise, Kingdom Establishment for Trading and Contracting, grew and expanded remarkably in a variety of fields including real estate, construction, travel and finance. In 1988, Forbes magazine estimated that Prince Waleed, at 33, had a net worth of "at least $1 billion," making him perhaps one of the dozen richest members of the royal family. Yet in its 1990 tabulation of the world's billionaires, Forbes did not mention Prince Waleed.
But some Saudi experts expressed doubts yesterday about the notion that Prince Waleed was a self-made billionaire whose money for the Citicorp move came entirely from his own coffers. One adviser to the Saudi royal family -- an extended tribe with roughly 20,000 members and 4,000 princes and princesses -- said it seemed unlikely Prince Waleed could have made so much money during the 1980's, when oil prices were depressed for several years, which slowed the Saudi economy.
Instead, the adviser and an Arab banker, both of whom asked not to be identified, said the American-educated Prince probably had some help from his father, Prince Talal, a Saudi businessman of established wealth.
Prince Talal was a Saudi Government official who, like some of his countrymen, became enamored of the Egyptian leader Gamal Abdel Nasser's message of pan-Arab nationalism in the late 1950's -- an ideology opposed by the monarchy of Saudi Arabia. Prince Talal moved to Egypt in the early 1960's but later became disenchanted with Mr. Nasser. By the late 1960's, he had moved back to his homeland, but the Saudi rulers would not allow him to rejoin the Government. So he went into business.
 
Favorable Terms for the Saudis
 Middle Eastern finance experts said the big Saudi investment in Citicorp was probably not directly related to the gulf war or championed by the Riyadh Government. The fall in the price of the shares of big American banks since the war and the recession began, however, made it possible for the Saudis to make a large investment on more favorable terms.
Prince Waleed's investment, they said, mirrored the optimism of most Middle East investors about the long-range prospects for the United States economy. "He undoubtedly views this an an investment in a premier bank in a country that still has tremendous potential -- that's got to be the principal motivation," said Sharif Ghalib, a Middle East expert at the Institute of International Finance in Washington. "And there's no question that that is how gulf investors view the United States."

HEADLINE: New York Growth is Linked to Immigration

BYLINE: By EDWARD B. FISKE

 BODY:
New York City took in 854,000 immigrants between 1980 and 1989, who fanned out into all five boroughs to feed great changes in racial and ethnic concentrations, according to data released yesterday by Federal immigration officials and the Census Bureau.
 The figures show that the city's rebound in population in the 1980's rode upon waves of immigrants from Asia, the Caribbean and Latin America, who more than made up for a continuing loss of whites. 
All this created a much different city, where one out of nine New Yorkers came from another country in the last decade and where whites of European ancestry now account for less than half of the city's population.
 Residents identifying themselves as Hispanic grew by 281,797 -- to 1,783,511. Asians more than doubled in number, growing by 281,218 -- to 512,719.
 
Decline in White Population
 Asians grew sharply across the country, according to the census, and that pattern held across New York State, where they grew to 693,760 residents from 310,526 in 1980. More than half live in Brooklyn and Queens, whose Asian populations now both outnumber Manhattan's Asian population.
 The city's overall population increased by 3.5 percent, to 7,322,564, despite a 10.9 percent decline in whites. The number of whites, which in the data released yesterday includes several hundred thousand Hispanic residents who identify themselves as white, fell to 3,827,088, from 4,294,075 in 1980.
 Similar patterns were seen in New York State, where the overall population increased by 2.5 percent, to 17,990,455, even though the white population fell by 4.1 percent. There were 13,385,255 whites in the state in 1990, down from 13,960,868 a decade earlier.
 In contrast with the growth in New York City, though, immigration in New York's next largest cities -- Buffalo, Rochester, Yonkers and Syracuse -- was not enough to prevent overall population declines because of the loss of whites.
 The new census data confirm trends that have long been noted by demographers and others. "We've gotten used to the fact that New York City is a place where the whiteEuropean population is now less than 50 percent and falling," said Rosemary Scanlon, chief economist of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.
 The data released yesterday elaborated on overall population figures released last month. New York and other cities have challenged the data in a lawsuit, on the ground that the Census Bureau failed to count thousands of residents, many of them minorities.
 The figures, according to New York officials, are likely to understate the actual minority population. Figures from the Immigration and Naturalization Service show that between 1980 and 1989 New York City took in 854,000 immigrants. This is seen as the principal reason why the city's population grew both in absolute numbers and diversity in the last decade.
 Among the various racial and ethnic groups, blacks showed the largest increase: 318,175. The census put the number of blacks at 2,102,512, up 17.8 percent over the 1,784,337 reported in 1980. Nearly half of the increase -- 149,493 -- was registered in Brooklyn, which has seen a large influx from the Caribbean.
 The most dramatic increases were registered by Asians, whose population was put at 512,719, more than double the 1980 total of 231,501. The largest influx was in Queens, which has become a favorite destination of Chinese immigrants. There were 238,336 Asians in that borough, or 154 percent morethan the 93,780 counted in 1980. The Asian population also grew by 159 percent in Brooklyn, 135 percent in the Bronx, 153 percent on Staten Island and 52 percent in Manhattan.
 The data released yesterday showed that whites still constitute 52 percent of New York City's population. But the figure of 3,827,088 whites includes a high percentage of the city's 1,783,511 Hispanic residents.
 Demographers thus agree that sometime during the mid-1980's non-Hispanic whites ceased to be a majority of the city's population. Confirmation of this must await the release of further data from the Census Bureau, possibly next week.
 
Many Whites Leave City
 The proportion of non-Hispanic whites in the city has been declining for several decades, and analysts generally agree that the net loss of 466,987 whites over the decade was caused almost entirely by continued migration of this group.
 Manhattan and Staten Island could be exceptions to this trend. The white population of Manhattan, including some Hispanic residents, grew by 26,023 during the decade, to 867,227, a gain of 3.1 percent. Staten Island added 8,509 whites for a total of 322,043, a gain of 2.7 percent.
 The number of Hispanic people in the city increased by 281,797, a gain of 18.8 percent. The largest gain, 126,758, was in the Bronx, which became the only borough in which Hispanic residents now outnumber whites. In 1980 there were 554,046 whites and 396,353 Hispanics in the Bronx. In 1990, the bureau reported, there were 430,077 whites and 523,111 Hispanics.
 Data for New York State showed that, among the various racial and ethnic groups, Hispanic people accounted for the biggest gains. There were 1,659,300 Hispanic residents in 1980, or 9.5 percent of the overall popultion. By last year this figure had increased by 554,726 to 2,214,026, or 12.3 percent of the total.
 
Strong Black Growth
 Blacks also showed strong growth in the state, increasing by 457,049. The black population went from 2,402,006, or 13.7 percent of the population, in 1980 to 2,859,055, or 15.9 percent of the total, in 1990.
 Asians showed the strongest percentage growth, registering an increase of 123.4 percent. The statewide Asian population grew from 310,526, or 1.8 percent of the total, in 1980 to 693,760, or 3.9 percent, in 1990.
 Suburban counties showed what is also becoming a pattern throughout the metropolitan area: stagnation of the white population and an increase in the number of residents from racial and ethnic minorities.
 Nassau and Westchester Counties, for example, both registered overall declines in population because of loss of whites. In Nassau the white population dropped by 7.4 percent, to 1,115,119, while in Westchester the number of whites declined by 4.9 percent, to 694,308.
 Ms. Scanlon of the Port Authority said that the decline in white population in such suburbs was largely a result of declining family size. "There's a lot of empty nesting in those areas," she said.
 Suffolk County, which has a somewhat younger overall population, was something of an exception to this trend.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 15; Column 1; Cultural Desk

LENGTH: 934 words

HEADLINE: Critic's Notebook;
An Excess of Excess, But What A Party

BYLINE: By JOHN ROCKWELL

 BODY:
Let's see: a Playskool Tiny Tim, three pens, four buttons, "The Big Apple Guide," one can of caffeine-free Diet Pepsi, a bottle of lemon-flavored Perrier, a small bottle of Glenfiddich Scotch whisky, a cassette sampler, a New York restaurant guide, not one but two copies of Entertainment Weekly magazine, a sample of Elizabeth Taylor's Passion for Men cologne, a Warner Brothers cap, a Life magazine 1991 calendar, a Trump Plaza key chain, a C.D./book package of "The Lives of Quincy Jones." Anything else? Oh, yes, the most important: earplugs.
 Those were the contents of a shopping bag full of plunder handed out to anyone who asked for one at the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences post-Grammy party at the Hilton Hotel. Of course, those famous people who were there were probably too cool to accept such trivia. And most of the really famous folk were at one of the record-company parties in other hotels, clubs and restaurants around town. But the Hilton bag still served as some sort of symbol of Grammy acquisitiveness. 
 This year, I found myself clutching an actual Grammy ticket, which cost $200, and thus was privileged to move among the actual demigods who make up today's record business. The experience was intermittently amusing, instructive, appalling, exciting and pulverizingly dull.
<> <>
 The Grammys on Wednesday, held in New York for the first time since 1988, make an easy target for the varied constituency that laments the commercialization of music, from Frankfurt School Marxists to neo-conservatives to rock critics to Sinead O'Connor to religious moralists who puritanically oppose all manifestations of Mammon.
 Mammonophobes would have had a field day on Wednesday evening. Wretched excess was everywhere; if we live in a recession or if pop music is under siege from tape pirates or if we are tastefully espousing austerity in wartime, the record business hasn't heard the news. From the lavish ice sculptures at the Hilton to Warner Brothers' recreation of tout New York at Roseland, the record companies flaunted everything they could flaunt.
 Which included female bodies: decolletage is definitely in, or out, as the case may be, although my companion noted somewhat acerbicly that such exposure has never gone out of showbiz style. The snazzy clothes were mostly on the stars of both sexes and the male executives' trophy wives and girlfriends. But since the record business caters to youth and young bodies are usually cuter and sexier than older ones, the cutest clothes were on the small army of young women in bouncy miniskirts and young men in neat little pony tails and earrings who were directed by field generals with walkie-talkies to fill up even momentarily empty seats in the first 20 rows at Radio City Music Hall.
 If you have any sort of taste for mainstream pop music, the production numbers were mostly pretty sophisticated, at least compared with Hollywood glitz of the past, with M.C. Hammer's flashy energy-burst an early highlight. Along with a touching John Lennon montage and Kitty Wells's achievement award, the oldsters' high point was Bob Dylan's craftily mumbled, slyly enigmatic acceptance speech. It was only later that most people (myself included) realized that his nearly unrecognizable song was one of his most trenchant pacifist denunciations, "Masters of War."
 There are seemingly hundreds of Grammys, far too many to make a meaningful viewing experience. While one can understand the two-tiered class system that banishes many awards to before the telecast, the treatment of some of the pre-telecast artists is pretty shabby. Too bad television viewers missed Alannah Myles's leather-and-tights outfit in her victory as best female rock singer, while Eric Clapton's award as best male rock singer was beamed out to a waiting world. And by the time the pre-telecast awards got around to classical music, all mention of the nominees had been dropped and winners were hustled on and off the stage like cattle, without time for acceptance speeches. All to make more time for Gary Shandling's jokes.
<> <> In the end, however, I found myself feeling less censorious about the whole brouhaha than I had thought I might. Of course it's excessive, with a cast of characters straight out of a Weimar Berlin gallery of capitalist sharks. But it's also an all-American party. Of course pop music is commercial. But while the nominations celebrate commercial success even more than the Oscars, the voting seems as often to reflect clubby feelings for paying your dues as sheer numbers of records sold. Thus the awards to veterans like Bonnie Raitt last year and the slighting this year of such hot-selling parvenus as Wilson Phillips and Vanilla Ice.
 Still, most aspiring popsters, even the critically respected ones, want to "make it," by which they most often mean not winning a critics' poll but selling records by the truckload. Unlike other art forms, music has been bifurcated into noncommerical art and commercial, youth-oriented entertainment. If you want art, you can get it at Carnegie Hall or the Knitting Factory. If you want flash and sexy style and exultation in success and, sometimes, pretty vibrant music, you got it at the Grammys.
 Vernon Reid, the guitarist of the critically beloved band Living Colour, dedicated the award for best hard rock performance to "all the bar bands, all the acts who are struggling to make it." He was wearing a Sinead O'Connor T-shirt, but his words suggested a willingness to participate in just the commercial process Ms. O'Connor professes to abhor.

HEADLINE: If a Shop Closes With Your Item Inside

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE

 BODY:
When Hank Hachmann left a computer printer at a store to be repaired late last year, he thought he would have it back in a couple of weeks. But the store, Wolff Office Equipment at 23 West 18th Street in Manhattan, filed for bankruptcy under Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Code on Dec. 28 and closed its doors.
"I tried to call the business number and the service number every couple of days but nobody answered," Mr. Hachmann said. "I was frustrated because I thought the printer was gone and it was a very big inconvenience." 
 Still, Mr. Hachmann considers himself lucky. Last month Wolff reopened in the same location to liquidate its inventory. And Mr. Hachman got a call to come retrieve his goods.
Robert Wolff, president of the concern, said: "We called or wrote every person who had machines in the shop and they got them back." An offer to buy the business is now under consideration by the creditors and the United States Bankruptcy Court.
 
An Increase in Closings
 Mr. Hachmann was indeed lucky. In other circumstances, when a company goes bankrupt, is seized by the Internal Revenue Service or goes out of business suddenly for whatever reason, customers who leave clothes to be cleaned or appliances to be repaired never get their merchandise back. And such store closings have become frequent during the recession.
"I've seen a significant increase in these closings in recent weeks," said Barbara Berger Opotowsky, president of the Better Business Bureau of Metropolitan New York. "If someone who has goods in a store sees the doors closed, it's a hysterical feeling."
"It's a painful fact of life that when businesses go out, in many instances consumers lose," said Richard M. Kessel, executive director of the New York State Consumer Protection Board, "but that doesn't mean that consumers shouldn't try to get their things back."
 
Who's in Charge Here? (Where?)
 The first thing to do, experts say, is to try to find out who is responsible for the business: an individual, a corporation or partners. See if there is a sign on the door with the address of a new location or a phone number. Failing that, send a registered letter to the company at the address where the merchandise was left, requesting a return receipt showing to whom the letter was delivered, and at what address. In addition, ask in other stores in the neighborhood if anybody knows where those who ran the business have gone.
"Contact the landlord," said Barbara Gregg, director of the Office of Consumer Affairs of Montgomery County, Md. "The landlord doesn't have a lien on the goods and you may be able to get your stuff."
"If it's a franchise, go to the franchiser," said John A. Goodman, president of Technical Assistance Research Programs, a nonprofit consulting organization in Washington. "The franchiser has a very significant stake in his reputation and, in many cases, he can make you whole."
Also, check with the nearest post office for a forwarding address. And, of course, a call or letter to the city or county consumer affairs agency, your state Attorney General's office or local Better Business Bureau might prove fruitful.
If a business like a dry cleaner or a repair shop does not pay its taxes, it can be seized by the I.R.S. and closed. Even so, said Wilson Fadely, a spokesman for the service, "We bend over backwards to see that consumers get their property."
The service, Mr. Fadely said, will post a notice on the store's front door telling of "A Seizure of Real Property" and giving the name and phone number of the revenue officer handling that seizure. The I.R.S. will often open the store for a while and notify those with repair tickets or identification so they can claim their property.
An I.R.S. manual states: "If the taxpayer's business hours extended beyond normal I.R.S. work hours, the establishment should be opened during some portions of the non-I.R.S. work hours. For example, if Saturday operation was customary, consideration should be given to providing at least some Saturday hours."
The situation is somewhat different when you pay all or part of the cost of new merchandise that is still in a closed store. Many consumers have learned that the chances of retrieving any money or the item are small.
"The best thing to do," said Mr. Goodman of Technical Research Assistance Programs, "is to put down a minimum deposit and pay on a credit card, rather than cash."

 
 
ACTIONS TO TAKE IN A BANKRUPTCY
 If you take merchandise to a store and leave it there -- for repairing, cleaning or any other reason -- what do you do if the business suddenly closes its doors? There are steps you can take to get your goods back and possibly some money, too.
To find out if the business has filed for bankruptcy, first make inquiries at the Federal bankruptcy court in the district where the business was located. You will need to provide the last known name and address of the business, and your own name, address and telephone number.
If a bankruptcy filing is found, the court clerk will give you the docket number and the name of the judge hearing the case.
You then have about six months from the date of filing to submit a written claim for merchandise left in the store. You use a legal form called Proof of Claim.
Attach to that form any proof of payment, receipt for deposit or other written evidence substantiating your claim and be prepared to wait for the merchandise.
You may also have some dollar claims against the business if, for example, the item is broken or ruined.
"There are special protections in the Bankruptcy Code for consumers with claims up to $900," said Robert Sable, a staff attorney at the National Consumer Law Center in Boston, a national support center for Legal Services offices. "The problem is that by the time most businesses that go into bankruptcy have paid off their creditors, the $900 protection is more theoretical than real."

(Neal Boenzi/The New York Times); Richard M. (Vic DeLucia/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Health System In New York Faces Big Cuts

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN

 BODY:
Hospitals and nursing homes in New York State face the loss of $1.15 billion in Medicaid and Medicare funds -- 5.5 percent of their total revenues -- under state and Federal budget cuts planned for the coming year, health-care experts said yesterday.
To officials responsible for a system already weakened by recession, soaring costs and chronic deficits, it was a grim prognosis: like telling a group of seriously ill patients that the flu season was on the way and that, unless strong medicine could be found, some were not going to survive. 
 "We will try to stave off the death blows," Kenneth E. Raske, president of the Greater New York Hospital Association, said before meeting 300 hospital and nursing home executives at a conference at the Sheraton Centre in Manhattan. "But if we don't succeed, we are going to see a vast destruction of the health-care system in New York."
 
Warnings of Disaster
 Coming atop three years of operating deficits, the cuts could force the 250 hospitals and 625 nursing homes across the state to lay off thousands of workers and cut patient services at a time when an AIDS epidemic, drug abuse and violent crime have created record demands for medical care, Mr. Raske told the gathering.
Some clinics and pharmacies would be closed, delays for treatment in emergency rooms and for admission to hospitals would lengthen, patients would be urged to leave recovery beds earlier, plans for new equipment and expansion would have to be scaled back or abandoned, some hospitals might default on bonds and a few might go bankrupt, Mr. Raske warned.
In New York State, the cuts would affect 220 voluntary hospitals, which are private, nonprofit institutions, about 20 municipal hospitals and 10 private hospitals, as well as 625 nursing homes, about half of which are nonprofit. The hospitals get two-thirds of their $17 billion annual income from Medicaid and Medicare, while 80 to 90 percent of the nursing homes' revenues of $3.75 billion is from Medicaid.
The conference, sponsored by the association, which represents 71 voluntary hospitals and 55 nursing homes in the metropolitan area, and the United Hospital Fund, a nonprofit research and philanthropic group that analyzes hospital problems, was largely informational, outlining the size and probable impact of planned Medicaid and Medicare cuts.
While no plan for combating the cuts was formulated, many hospital and nursing home administrators, fiscal officers and trustees, and several political leaders who attended the conference, called the projections a call to arms for an endangered health-care system.
"This will damage the lives of tens of thousands of children," said Assemblyman Richard N. Gottfried, a Manhattan Democrat who is chairman of the Assembly's health committee. He urged the gathering: "Do not mourn -- organize!"
 
'Chaplains Have Even Been Fired'
 Representative Charles B. Rangel, a Manhattan Democrat, denounced the proposed cuts. "People are getting sick because they don't have doctors to care for them," he said. "People don't go to doctors because they don't have the finances. It's getting so bad that the chaplains have even been fired."
Asked about the assertions of the health-care officials, Tom Conroy, a spokesman for Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, acknowledged that hospitals and nursing homes faced large cuts, but said they were necessary and not disproportionate.
"Because support for health care is such a large part of the budget, there's no way the state could exempt that area from cuts in trying to close a potential $6 billion deficit," he said. Mr. Conroy said that Medicaid eligibility standards had not been narrowed and that the state's share of Medicaid spending next year would be $3.7 billion, or $236 million less than this year.
Bruce C. Vladeck, president of the United Hospital Fund, said an analysis showed that hospitals in the New York region -- two-thirds of their income from Medicaid and Medicare -- were increasingly vulnerable to government budget cuts because an increasing proportion of their revenues were coming from Medicaid, the state-run program of health care for the poor, which is 50 percent federally financed, with state and local governments paying the rest.
 
Cost of $393 Million
 Moreover, Mr. Vladeck noted, Medicaid reimbursement rates are used to determine what private health insurers pay for hospital services. Thus, he said, cuts in Medicaid reimbursements would be compounded by a loss of revenue from private insurers as well.
Citing figures provided by the New York State Hospital Association, Mr. Raske said that proposed cuts in Medicaid would generate a combined revenue loss of $597.5 million for all hospitals in the state in the 1992 fiscal year.
At the same time, he said, proposed changes in Medicare, the Federal health-insurance program for the elderly, including cuts in payments to teaching hospitals mostly concentrated in New York City, would cost hospitals in the state $393 million, of which $279.1 million would be borne by hospitals in the New York metropolitan area.
The combined estimated loss of $990.5 million in reimbursements as a result of the state and Federal cutbacks would deprive the state's 250 hospitals of more than 5.8 percent of their $17 billion in aggregate revenues, Mr. Raske said. About 70 percent of those losses, he said, would hit hospitals in the metropolitan area because they have a larger share of patients and those patients eligible for Medicaid.
For the state's 625 nursing homes, cutbacks in Medicaid, which provides 80 percent of their income statewide and 90 percent in New York City, would cost an estimated $159.6 million, or 4.3 percent of the nursing homes' $3.75 billion annual revenues, Mr. Raske said, quoting state hospital association figures.
Some of the revenue losses would come from cuts in the annual rate adjustments the Federal and state programs make for inflation; others would be actual cuts in reimbursement rates; still others would arise from mandated delays in payments, cuts in care deemed less essential and cuts in education reimbursements to teaching hospitals.
"These are the worst combined cutbacks we've ever seen," Mr. Raske said in an interview. "The impact is staggering. In a recession, you normally find demand declining. But in health care, it often increases. We now have epidemics of AIDS and drugs. The needs of the elderly are growing.
Hospitals in the metropolitan area, which employ 153,000 people, might have to lay off more than 5,000 workers in the next fiscal year, Mr. Raske warned. He said layoffs in recent years had already cut hospital staffs to the bone.
Clinics, pharmacies and other hospital services that are regarded as uneconomical but socially and medically desirable also might have to be closed, and equipment modernization plans delayed or abandoned, he said.

Raske, left, president of the GreaterNew York Hospital Association. He spoke with Representative Charles B. Rangel at conference of hospital and nursing home executives. (Jim Estrin for The New York Times) (pg. 28)

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Grumman Warns Of 4,100 Layoffs

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The Grumman Corporation warned that it might be forced to lay off 4,100 workers if the Government does not soon release nearly $1 billion appropriated for upgrading F-14 fighter planes. Grumman's chief executive, Renso L. Caporali, in a letter to the company's 26,100 employees, said the layoffs could begin shortly after March 1.
"Money authorized and appropriated for remanufactured F-14's last year has not yet been released, for reasons that have not yet been made clear to us," he said in the letter. The Secretary of Defense, Dick Cheney, is said to be considering rescinding the expenditure of 1991 funds for upgrading the F-14's in light of budget constraints. Grumman said advance Government funds would run out next Friday, making it impossible for Grumman to pay suppliers, purchase materials and keep in-house operations going.

HEADLINE: F.A.A. Sees Quick Recovery for Airlines

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22

 BODY:
The Federal Aviation Administration predicted today that the airline industry would quickly recover from its costly recession as fuel prices stabilize once the war ends in the Middle East.
But James B. Busey, the agency's head, said the weakest airlines might face lingering difficulties. 
 "Until we are totally out of the woods -- until the recession is over, until the price and availability of oil clearly stabilize, and until airlines bring under control their debt and high labor costs -- tough times may continue for portions of our industry," he said in a speech to a conference where the agency's long-term aviation forecast was presented.
Mr. Busey said, however, that the Government would not agree to recent requests by some industry officials for Government financial assistance. The only steps the agency would take, he said, would be to seek cost savings through more efficient air traffic control, which can cut fuel consumption.
The leading domestic airlines lost some $2 billion last year. Three of them are in bankruptcy.
In general, the agency's detailed forecasts for the industry were optimistic.
"It is very difficult to predict future air traffic with all the uncertainties about the national economy and world events," said William E. Jackman, a spokesman for the Air Transport Association, which represents the major domestic airlines. "But we sure hope they are right," he said when asked to comment on the F.A.A. forecast.
In a separate forecast that is scheduled to be issued on Monday, the Boeing Corporation, the world's biggest producer of passenger jets, reached much the same conclusion: Fuel prices will decline and then stabilize, the economy will recover and air travel will rebound quickly after the end of the war.
Over the next 15 years, Boeing projected a 5.2 percent annual rate of growth in air travel worldwide -- enough to double the total passenger-miles, which would reach 89 billion by 2005.
Boeing said the world demand for new jets would be nearly 9,000 planes over 15 years, worth $617 billion in 1991 dollars.
The F.A.A. forecast, which assumes that the overall recession will last only six months and might well have already ended, did not include projections of industry profitability. It predicts only the growth in passenger traffic.
 
Worst Seen as Over

"In summary, we think the worst is probably over, even as I speak," said John M. Rodgers, director of the agency's office of policy and plans, who presented the annual forecast.
The forecast called for a decline in passenger flying miles of 1 percent this year because of the lingering recession, higher ticket prices and fears of terrorism. Next year, however, traffic is expected to rise 4 percent, and the increase is expected to average 5 percent a year for the next 10 years. (For the last 12 years traffic went up 8 percent annually.)
The key factor in the forecast is jet fuel prices, one of the biggest costs paid by airlines. Jet fuel has dropped from a November peak of $1.40 a gallon to 70 cents. In July, before the invasion of Kuwait, it was about 55 cents.
Fuel prices "should moderate even more in the second half of 1991 and decline further in 1992," Mr. Rodgers said. "For the balance of the forecast period, we expect plentiful and affordable fuel."
 
Long-Term Fuel Price

The forecast predicted that the average price of fuel from 1989 to 1995 would go up at an annual rate of 3.7 percent, slightly less than the anticipated rate of inflation throughout the economy.
But the long-term forecast was based on the assumption that the war would end "without any significant destruction of oilfields, refineries, and transportation facilities," the forecast said.
Today, the Pentagon said that about 15 percent of the oil wells in Kuwait had been set afire by the Iraqi Army, and President Bush said that other oil installations in occupied Kuwait were also being destroyed in what he termed a "scorched earth" policy.
As it has in recent years, the aviation agency predicted that international air traffic would grow faster than domestic traffic, and it identified as a primary trend in the industry the movement of large, strong carriers to expand internationally. International air traffic, measured in passenger-miles flown, would increase 6.4 percent annually between now and 1992.
Some airlines, seeking to solve their immediate financial problems, have publicly floated the idea of borrowing the 10 percent ticket tax imposed by the Government on all airline travelers, which would provide an infusion of billions of dollars this year. The tax is now used to pay most of the F.A.A.'s expenses.
"I don't think that's a starter," Mr. Busey said in a brief interview. "It equates to a Government bailout."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Komatsu Dresser To Cut 200 Jobs

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: GALION, Ohio, Feb. 22

 BODY:
The Komatsu Dresser Company said it would lay off half of its work force by the end of the year because of a slowdown in the construction and heavy equipment industries. The layoffs will furlough about 200 salaried and hourly workers, Michael Guilfoy, company human resources manager, said. One of two plants Komatsu Dresser operates here also will be closed, he said. The company manufactures heavy equipment for the road construction industry, including graders and cranes. It is a joint venture between Komatsu Ltd. of Japan and Dallas-based Dresser Industries.

HEADLINE: Role of Taxes Debated in Adding to Income Gap

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHABECOFF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22

 BODY:
Federal tax policy contributed to the widening gap between the wealth of rich and poor Americans in the 1980's, a group of experts told the Senate Budget Committee today, but they disagreed on how great a role other economic factors played in the inequity.
There was near unanimity that, as the committee chairman, Jim Sasser of Tennessee, put it, the 80's were "the decade when the rich got richer and the poor got poorer." 
 Robert McIntyre, director of Citizens for Tax Justice, a coalition of labor, public interest and community groups, said "huge tax breaks" for wealthy Americans had stimulated "gross overconsumption" by that sector of society. At the same time, he said, lower-income families were facing increased tax burdens because Social Security taxes were raised and because states had to raise sales taxes and other taxes to make up for reduced Federal aid.
 
 A Conservative Viewpoint
 A contrary view was expressed by Marvin H. Kosters, an economist with the American Enterprise Institute, a conservative research and policy group here. Mr. Kosters said tax policy might have had some effect on the distribution of income, but it was a relatively minor element. The chief factor for the change, he said, was the widening gap between the wages paid to skilled, educated workers and their unskilled, uneducated counterparts.
An important way to close the gap, he said, would be to improve the education and training of unskilled workers. Tax policies that aim at redistributing income, he said, "are more likely to impair human-capital investment and income growth."
Gary Burtless, a senior fellow of the Brookings Institution, said economic and demographic developments, including the declining demand for unskilled labor and the growing number of single-parent families, "were far more important than direct Government policy in explaining the swelling incomes of the affluent and the shrinking wages of the less skilled."
 
 The Role of Government

But he added, "Even if the role of Government was smaller than sometimes suggested in the press or Congress, I regard it as scandalous that Government policy should have played any role at all in making the matter worse."
Mr. Burtless, too, urged that unskilled workers get more and better training and that schools provide more help to students who are not bound for college.
He also said he thought the issue of income distribution should be directly addressed by reducing Government transfers of income to the wealthy, like Social Security and Medicare payments. He proposed taxing such benefits once they exceeded the payroll contributions made by the recipient.
 
 Data on Average Family
 Senator Sasser said the net worth of the average American family, adjusted for inflation, declined by 3.4 percent between 1984 and 1988, while the richest 20 percent of households saw a 14 percent increase in wealth during the period.
He also cited data showing that the real hourly earnings of the average worker had declined 4 percent since 1982. He added, "That's 4 percent below the low point of the 1982 recession -- the deepest postwar recession we've seen."
Mr. Sasser said the income disparity was reflected in tax trends during the decade. The wealthiest 1 percent of Americans, he said, pay a tax rate that is 9 percent below the rate paid 10 years ago because of "the supply-side tax cuts of the 1980's."
"By contrast," he said, "tax rates for 60 percent of Americans have increased."
Senator Pete V. Domenici, Republican of New Mexico, expressed skepticism about the disparity of wealth in the United States, saying that the 1980's had been a time of general prosperity for the nation.
"If you torture numbers long enough they will tell you anything," he said, challenging the statistics.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Firmer Worldwide As Bush Gives Ultimatum

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar strengthened on world currency markets yesterday after President Bush gave President Saddam Hussein of Iraq an ultimatum to begin withdrawing his forces from Kuwait by noon today.
Gold was moderately lower, because of technical factors and the dimming of its safe-harbor appeal amid peace prospects. On New York's Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery fell $5.70 a troy ounce to settle at $357.00, the lowest spot gold price since early July. The Republic National Bank quoted a late bid for gold of $356.75, down $4.50 a troy ounce. 
Silver also declined, dropping in New York to a 17-year low. On the Comex, silver for February delivery fell 12.9 cents a troy ounce, to $3.508.
The dollar rose quickly in European and United States trading after President Bush told Mr. Hussein in a speech to "begin his immediate and unconditional withdrawal from Kuwait" or face a decisive ground assault.
The terms released by the White House were that Iraq's half-million troops must complete their withdrawal within one week, Baghdad must free all prisoners of war in the first 48 hours, and coalition forces will not attack withdrawing troops.
"The prospects for a long, drawn-out war and the negative impact it would have on the U.S. economy is diminished," said Tom Benfer, senior market representative in foreign exchange at the Bank of Montreal in New York.
Technical factors also lifted the dollar yesterday. President Bush's comments helped push the dollar to 1.5000 German marks inUnited States dealings around midday, a barrier it had struggled to surpass for the last month.
"Once we broke through, it moved up quite quickly," Mr. Benfer said.
The dollar settled in New York at 1.5055 German marks late yesterday, up from late Thursday's 1.4925 marks. In European dealings, the dollar bought 1.5045 marks, up from 1.4905.
In London, the British pound fell to $1.9440, from $1.9580 late Thursday, while in New York it fetched $1.9445, less expensive than late Thursday's $1.9568.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 130.85 yen, down 0.58 yen from Thursday's close. Later, in London, it rose to 132.20 yen, and in New York, the dollar settled at 132.15 yen, up from late Thursday's 131.27.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Thursday's rates, included: 1.2925 Swiss francs, up from 1.2745; 5.1225 French francs, up from 5.0755; 1,127.50 Italian lire, up from 1,117.25, and 1.1524 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1495.
Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Thursday, included: 1.2900 Swiss francs, up from 1.2735; 5.1155 French francs, up from 5.0710; 1.6960 Dutch guilders, up from 1.6798; 1,126.00 Italian lire, up from 1,116.75, and 1.1520 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1513.
Gold fell in London to a late bid price of $359.00 a troy ounce, down from $363.50 bid late Thursday. In Zurich, it fell to a closing bid of $358.80.

HEADLINE: Treasury Securities Hold Steady

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
The Treasury securities market meandered in a narrow price range yesterday after a brief upward movement early in the session. Dealers said bond prices rose about a quarter-point after the opening on hopes of an end to the Persian Gulf war. But there was no follow-through buying and prices retreated to opening levels.
Late in the session, the Treasury's benchmark long bonds, the 7 7/8 percent issue maturing in February 2021, were unchanged at 97 30/32, as was the yield of 8.06 percent, a bit below its three-week high of 8.07 percent. A week ago the long bond's yield was 7.97 percent. The long notes, the 7.75 percent issue due February 2001, were unchanged at 99, as was the yield of 7.89 percent.
 
 "The Street simply does not know what the consequences of peace or war will be," said William V. Sullivan Jr., senior vice president at Dean Witter Reynolds. "In the past few weeks, the Street seemed to favor bonds. Now no one knows."
 
 Inventories Reduced
 Given the market's lack of direction, Mr. Sullivan continued, the day's activity was confined largely to professional traders, like dealers and speculators, with both groups trying to reduce holdings. There was little retail investor interest in the bond market, he said.
Although dealer carrying, or financing, costs remained comfortable, the uncertainty overhanging the market encouraged dealers to reduce inventories of Treasury securities.
"Despite the easy carrying costs, dealers do have a heavy supply of Treasury paper on their hands," Mr. Sullivan said. "After all, they did absorb $55 billion of Treasury coupon issues, including the $34 billion of refunding issues, in just the past 10 days."
The easier dealer financing costs reflect the fact that the Federal funds rate has been less than the yields the dealers are getting on the Treasury issues on their shelves. Dealers usually finance their inventory at roughly the funds rate, which is also what banks charge each other for temporary loans.
 
Move on Funds Rate
 The Federal Reserve moved to reduce the funds rate yesterday by a systemwide infusion of reserves into the banking system. The funds were trading at 6 3/8 percent on an annual basis at the time, slightly above what is perceived to the the Fed's target of 6.25 percent. As is often the case on Friday, the lack of interest in borrowing Federal funds reduced the rate even below the target level and the rate eventuallly closed at 5 percent.
But the discount rates on Treasury bills, which are most sensitive to the funds rate, were narrowly mixed. The 90-day bills rose a basis point, or one-hundredth of a percentage point, to 5.96 percent; the six-month bills were unchanged at 5.95 percent, and the one-year bills also gained a basis point, at 5.97 percent.
Among some other representative Treasury issues traded in the secondary market, the new 6.75 percent notes of 1993 lost 3/32, at 99 19/32, and now yield 6.97 percent; the new 7.5 percent notes of 1998, which were also auctioned this week, slipped 1/32, to 99 24/32, and now have a yield of 7.56 percent.

HEADLINE: Hudson County a Harbinger of a New Hispanic Influence

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNION CITY, N.J., Feb. 21

 BODY:
"In the beginning, it used to be signs saying, 'We speak Spanish,' " Jose Michel Lopez said as he strolled down a stretch of Bergenline Avenue, looking at row after row of windows of Hispanic-owned shops.
"Now the signs say, 'We speak English,' " Mr. Lopez said. 
 For years the signs, sounds and smells of food along Bergenline Avenue have pointed to a trend that the 1990 census is now confirming: New Jersey's Hispanic population is increasing at a pace that outstrips every other major ethnic group.
What began in Union City as an enclave of Cubans who fled Fidel Castro's revolution three decades ago has matured into a community of Chileans, Colombians, Ecuadoreans, Guatemalans and other groups of Hispanic origin who have reshaped the culture of the area, taken control of much of its economy and begun consolidating political power.
In Union City, West New York, Passaic and Paterson, the Hispanic population has not only surpassed the black population, butnow outnumbers non-Hispanic whites.
Overall, 9.6 percent of New Jersey's population is now Hispanic, compared with 6.7 percent a decade ago. The trend also applies in Connecticut and New York, demographers say, adding that as whites and middle-class blacks leave the big cities for towns and suburbia, it will only accelerate.
 
Heart of the Community
 "Much of this started with the change in the immigration laws in 1964, which shifted the quota from northern European countries to the rest of the world," said James Hughes, a professor of urban planning at Rutgers University.
The heart of New Jersey's Hispanic population lies here in Union City and its neighbors, a cluster of Hudson County communities in the shadow of the Manhattan skyline that are home to 183,465 Hispanic people, according to the census. Bergenline Avenue is the main artery, a bustling, mostly commercial strip that begins in Union City and runs north for 90 blocks roughly parallel to the Hudson River.
Hispanic-owned businesses -- from small fruit stands and coffee shops to nightclubs and upscale clothing stores -- have multiplied and thrived along the avenue.
"When we came to this city it was like a ghost town," said Mr. Lopez, a truck driver who settled in Union City 32 years ago after leaving his native Cuba. "Now it's like a cosmopolitan small city.
"This is like being in Havana in the afternoon," said Mr. Lopez, who is a only a short walk away from the food, entertainment and culture he knew in Cuba. Just off the avenue, he can even get hand-rolled cigars "made by Cubans" in La Isla, a storefront factory run by Elsie Gonzalez and her husband Berto Ale.
Hispanic-owned businesses have squeezed out virtually all competition along Bergenline Avenue. One of the few vacant buildings used to house Fung Wong Kitchen, a Chinese restaurant.
McDonald's and Roy Rogers fast food restaurants appear to be holding their own, as does Marzigliano Live Poultry Market in West New York, which offers just about any kind of fowl that is domesticated, and rabbits too -- live.
 
Series of Changes
 "We're the oldest business on Bergenline Avenue," said Anthony Marzigliano, whose grandfather, an Italian immigrant, started the business 75 years ago.
Mr. Marzigliano has seen the neighborhood change from Italian, to Irish, to Cuban and now to mixed Hispanic influence. Business has never been better, he said, as he snatched a plump chicken from one of the dozens of cages stacked six high.
While Mr. Lopez can point to the businesses as a show of Hispanic economic power, he also can point to City Hall as an example of political prowess.
Five years ago, Robert Menendez, a lawyer and Democrat, beat the slate of candidates backed by the local Democratic Party organization to take control of the Board of Commissioners and become Mayor of Union City.
Mr. Menendez, the 37-year-old son of Cuban immigrants, became a member of the New Jersey Assembly in 1987, serving as Democratic majority whip, vice chairman of the Appropriations Committee and chairman of the subcommittee on taxation and state aid. This week, the state Democratic Party selected him to fill the unexpired state Senate term of the late Christopher J. Jackman.
 
A Hispanic Edge
 Mr. Menendez is New Jersey's highest-ranking Hispanic elected official and the only one ever to serve in the Legislature.
"What we're seeing now is the culmination of something that took a quarter of a century to build," said Professor Hughes.
He believes that culturally, Hispanic citizens may have a natural advantage in politics because of their strong tradition of extended families. That social bond could easily be transferred to a political union, he said.
Mr. Hughes identified New Jersey, New York and Connecticut as "population laggards," each of them showing overall growth well below the 10 percent to 11 percent national average during the last decade. The region's Hispanic population growth rate mirrored the national average, but was accentuated by the lower overall increase, he said.
Of New Jersey's 7,730,188 million people, according to the 1990 census, 739,861 are of Hispanic origin. The 5,718,966 non-Hispanic whites make up 74 percent of the population, and non-Hispanic blacks number 984,845, or 12.7 percent of the total.
 
Increase in Every County
 While New Jersey's non-Hispanic white population fell 1.8 percent from 1980 to 1990 and and the number of blacks increased 8.5 percent, the Hispanic population increased by 50.4 percent, and was the only group to show increases in each of New Jersey's 21 counties.
These numbers may actually understate the minority population. Many New Jersey cities have challenged the census count, saying it missed thousands of city residents, many of whom are black or Hispanic.
In Connecticut, the Hispanic population grew by nearly 89,000, or 71.2 percent, to 213,116. That represents 6.5 percent of the state's 3,287,116 residents.
In New York, the number of people identifying themselves as Hispanic grew 33.4 percent, to 2,214,026 of the state's 17,990,455 residents, or 12.3 percent of the total.
In New Jersey, the census also shows -- and Chilean nightclubs and Colombian fast-food diners along Bergenline Avenue back up the numbers -- that the solid block of Cuban control has started to crack under the weight of waves of new, non-Cuban Hispanic immigrants.
"What has happened is that you had a rise to the middle class to a large degree of the early migrants and you've had a continuous replenishment of the Spanish," Mr. Hughes said.
He said the new Hispanic residents "will fit the Democratic Party mold" but will not necessarily be allied with the old powerbrokers.
Mr. Menendez bears out that theory.
Beginning in 1981, he tried and failed several times to defeat a Democratic Party political organization that held sway over Union City for 20 years. On the eve of the 1982 election, Mayor William Musto was convicted in Federal court of stealing funds from the Union City Board of Education, but he and his entire team still swept the elections the next day. Mr. Musto was sent to jail, but still ran the city until Mr. Menendez's victory in 1986.
Besides Mr. Menendez, there is one other Hispanic member on Union City's five-member Board of Commissioners. The board is elected directly by the voters, and then choses one of its members as mayor.
But Mr. Hughes believes that Hispanic political clout does not stop at clubbing the traditional white powerbrokers. "It certainly would put a black, English-speaking candidate at some disadvantage," he said.
If Hudson County is viewed as a whole, Mr. Hughes said, he sees Miami as a model for the area's future. Miami's large Hispanic population elected a Hispanic mayor several years ago and then helped to elect the country's first Hispanic governor.
What happens in Hudson County may then be repeated in other areas of New Jersey and in New York and Connecticut, he said. "If people have the political clout now, they certainly should be apprehensive, if the democracy keeps evolving," he said.
