HEADLINE: When Somewhere to Live Isn't Enough

BYLINE: By THOMAS MORGAN

 BODY:
A decade ago, when advocates for the homeless first began to press their demands on New York City, they portrayed their constituents as ordinary people who, down on their luck in the nation's tightest housing market, just needed a place to stay.
Today, advocates acknowledge that this initial portrayal was, at best, incomplete. Many of the homeless are not just people without homes, but people suffering from drug addiction, AIDS and mental illness. Growing numbers of the homeless need psychological counseling and drug and alchohol treatment. Others, particularly the rising number of young,poorly educated women with children, need job training and day care. 
 And as a financially strapped city struggles just to provide shelter, it finds itself with a doubly difficult challenge: assessing the needs of the homeless and finding ways to pay for the expensive social services.
 
Hand in Hand With Services
 While private groups have developed model housing with special services, it is still a matter of debate which models work best and which can be replicated economically on a large scale.
Dr. Kim Hopper, a research scientist at the Nathan Kline Institute for Psychiatric Research who has studied the homeless, said housing must go hand in hand with social services.
"Advocates 10 years ago minimized what all of us recognized were basic service needs of the homeless adults and threw our weight behind the housing side of the argument," he said. "Before, homelessness had been thought of as an unemployment problem or one of personal disability."
The few studies that exist show that between a quarter and a half of all single homeless adults use illicit drugs, he said.
About a third exhibit signs of mental illness, and there is a signficant overlap between the two groups. "It's not clear that the diagnostic tags are reliable indicators of the housing that homeless people need," Dr. Hopper said. "Nor does it tell you how intense, prolonged or complicated that service package needs to be."
Not all homeless people who move from temporary housing into permanent apartments make the transition successfully. No one seems to know how many end up back in shelters.
One indication, however, comes from the experience of a nonprofit housing program called Housing Enterprise for the Less Privileged, or HELP, run by Andrew Cuomo. Mr. Cuomo said that about 10 percent of the families who stay in contact with his agency after moving to permanent apartments have difficulty maintaining them.
 
$1.2 Billion for Services
 "We should become disabused of the notion that therapeutic and survival needs are two separate domains," Dr. Hopper said. "Service people argue that unless someone can be stabilized they won't be able to take advantage of housing opportunities that you make. But the converse is also valid. Unless someone has a stable housing situation, their abilities to take advantage of the social services are compromised."
Since late 1985, New York City has spent more than $1.2 billion to give homeless families temporary quarters and social services in shelters, hotels and temporary apartments, according to the Mayor's Office on Homelessness and SRO Housing. By June, the Koch and Dinkins administrations will have created 26,806 permanent apartments. Just the construction costs of those apartments is more than $600 million.
None of this spending, nor the millions spent by nonprofit organizations, has come close to solving the problem. Advocates and city officials say that at least 100,000 apartments are needed to address homelessness and severe overcrowding. At $70,000 per apartment -- a low estimate of the cost of renovation or new construction -- it would cost a minimum of $7 billion for 100,000 homes. No one has an estimate of how much more the social services would cost.
 
Successful Models
 There are successful models of housing with social services, but expanding them to help everyone who needs them would be prohibitively expensive, city officials said.
Among the more promising models are two run by nonprofit organizations, the Settlement Housing Fund and Mr. Cuomo's HELP. Both mix homeless families into apartment buildings with low- to moderate-income families so that the formerly homeless are 30 to 50 percent of the buildings. The idea is to give the families stable environments with successful role models. The housing usually has some social services, either on-site or through referrals to agencies.
At one of the Settlement Housing Fund's projects in the Bronx, a staff of seven that includes caseworkers, community aides and youth workers help about 300 homeless families get job training, alcohol and drug abuse treatment, day care and homemaking or parenting classes. Carol Lamberg, of the Settlement Fund, said it costs about $350,000 a year just for the staff.
 
Families to Help Manage
 At HELP Homes, the 150 apartment project in Brooklyn, a staff of about 35 will give services to the 75 homeless families in the apartment complex at a cost of about $700,000 a year, Mr. Cuomo said. Services will include day care, job training, and counseling.
In addition, he said, the families will be required to help manage the complex, join tenant councils and develop leadership skills.
"The days of thinking that there is one solution to homelessness -- just providing housing -- are gone," Mr. Cuomo said.
Nancy Wackstein, director of the Mayor's Office on Homelessness and SRO Housing, said HELP is able to offer many services because Mr. Cuomo has received both Federal housing vouchers and state tax credits.
"Most of our projects either have one or the other," she said. "There is a limited pool of both."
Ms. Wackstein said that the city government has also integrated homeless people into apartment buildings with stable low-income families and that services are offered in some projects. But she said the city cannot afford to spend the amount of money that HELP does.
Barbara J. Sabol, the New York City Human Resources Administrator, said recently that the city plans to offer social services in schools, day care and Head Start centers and public health centers. If that works, there may be no need for on-site services in apartment buildings, city officials said.
Advocates for the homeless are skeptical. They say the city is housing too many homeless in isolated and devastated Bronx and Brooklyn neighborhoods that already lack adequate transportation and shopping, much less social services.
City officials answer that community groups fight them when they try to house the homeless in more established communities.
Of the estimated 100,000 homeless in the city, almost 4,000 families live in temporary housing, with about 600 of those in welfare hotels. In the winter, the city puts up about 10,000 single adults in overnight beds in armories, recreation centers and churches, and it assumes that there are thousands more who will sleep on the street rather than go to shelters.
"There is no longer a Federal role in housing, and the city is only able to provide for the most needy, which has been defined as people in the shelter system," Ms. Wackstein said. "I don't disagree with advocates who say we need 100,000 new apartments. That would enable us to begin addressing some of the overcrowding and people living in substandard apartments."
But advocates for the homeless say putting the homeless in hotels or shelters until apartments become available is misdirected.
 "The flaw in the city's approach has been to target the number of permanent housing units to the numbers of families in the shelter system, rather than developing a comprehensive plan to address the overall need," said Steve Banks, a supervising attorney with the Legal Aid Society's Homeless Family Rights Project. "To some extent the Federal and state governments are not innocent parties either. The result is going to be greater long-term costs for all three levels of government."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Carol Lamberg, left, with children at a Settlement Housing Fund project in the Bronx, where a staff of seven helps about 300 homeless families get day care and spots in job training programs and alcohol and drug abuse treatment. (Angel Franco/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: U.S. Surplus In January

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22

 BODY:
The Federal Government recorded a small budget surplus of $1.76 billion in January, despite sharply lower tax receipts from corporations, the Treasury Department said today.
The surplus in January, the fourth month of the 1991 fiscal year, compared with a deficit of $7.3 billion in December. In January a year ago, there was a surplus of $8.28 billion. 
 With the country in recession, money from corporate income taxes fell to $3.83 billion last month from $22.52 billion in December. Most corporations make payments once a quarter based on their estimated earnings for the period.
Tax payments by individuals increased to $50.88 billion, from $46.47 billion in December.
Military spending on fell last month to $20.87 billion from$25.17 billion in December despite the beginning of the Persian Gulf war in mid-January.
Total Government income in January was $101.80 billion, down from $102.27 billion in December. Spending fell last month to $100.04 billion from $109.58 billion in December.

Markets
Stock prices slid as cautious investors pulled back in heavy trading on the eve of a crucial weekend in the war. In a steep one-hour selling wave, the Dow plunged nearly 60 points from its high for the day. After being ahead 44, it ended up losing 2.47, at 2,889.36, putting the loss for the week at 45.29, or 1.5 percent. [31.]
Oil prices fell below $18, their lowest level since well before the gulf crisis began, amid speculation that the fighting was close to an end. Crude fell 59 cents, to $17.91. [31.]
The Treasury securities market meandered in a narrow price range after a brief upward movement early in the session. Dealers said bond prices rose about a quarter-point after the opening on hopes of an end to the war. [34.]
The dollar strengthened after Bush's ultimatum to Saddam Hussein to begin withdrawing his forces from Kuwait by noon today. Gold was moderately lower. [39.]
 
The Economy
The F.A.A. said the airline industry would recover quickly from its costly recession as fuel prices stabilize once the war ends. But the agency's head said the weakest airlines might face lingering difficulties. [31.]
Retailers who cater to the wealthy and the merely affluent are finding out that things are bad all over. Stores freshly stocked with $1,200 spring suits and $2,000 dresses, in settings of rich mahogany paneling and artful decor, have only a trickle of customers. [31.]
Federal tax policy contributed to the widening gap between the wealth of rich and poor Americans in the 1980's, a group of experts told the Senate Budget Committee, but they disagreed about how great a role other economic factors played in the inequity. [35.]
Proposed rules on the treatment that disabled customers must receive at commercial establishments are so vague that the courts will end up setting the standards, business groups complained. [11.]

HEADLINE: Georgetown Journal;
An Island of Prosperity Since Toyota Moved In

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GEORGETOWN, Ky.

 BODY:
Over a decade ago, pigeons and starlings were making a mess of the little downtown here. "So we had a pigeon shoot," said William N. Offutt 4th, an eye doctor and tobacco farmer.
With official sanction, 30 to 40 men leveled shotguns on the Main Street rooftops one Saturday. "Pigeons were falling on the windshields," said Dr. Offutt, a member of the posse. 
 Then the well-mannered men from Toyota came to town, built an enormous factory and generally sanded the rough edges off this town, about 20 minutes north of Lexington. These days, rooftop spikes keep the pigeons out, Mayor Tom Prather said, and the city dispatches the starlings more peaceably, by broadcasting recordings of starling distress cries to scare them off.
Thanks to Toyota, this town of 12,900 people -- about 3,000 more than a decade ago -- has become an island of prosperity two hours by car northwest of the depression in Appalachia and two hours south of some of the Midwest's industrial graveyards, among them American automobile factories.
The unemployment rate here is less than 4 percent. Toyota employs 68 Japanese and 3,500 Americans at a $1.3 billion factory, where it started making Camrys almost three years ago. Last year it turned out 218,500 of them.
As with most cars, sales of the Camry have been sliding in the recession, said Jim Wiseman, the plant's head of public affairs, noting that they had fallen by about 16 percent since January.
But unlike most American auto makers, Toyota has not laid off anyone and has said it has no plans to do so. Indeed, the company said in November that it would spend $800 million to double Camry production and would add 1,500 workers by 1993.
Not everyone has been enthusiastic about all this activity. The citizen who raised the biggest ruckus is Dr. Offutt, whose forebears were early settlers of the area and who owns a 475-acre tobacco farm downstream from the plant. A little creek, Lane's Run, cuts through the farm and carries storm runoff from the factory.
Toyota has built a $16 million plant to treat effluent from the plant and retention ponds to capture the rainwater from the factory. But Dr. Offutt fears that impurities still get into the runoff and wants the water sent elsewhere. Still, after going to some legal expense, he has given up the struggle, and Toyota and Mayor Prather consider the case closed.
To lure Toyota to Kentucky, the state provided $250 million to $400 million in tax breaks and other incentives, and this stirred some dust, too. To allay ruffled feelings about such a giveaway, Toyota has been paying a little of the money back.
It gave the community 10 Camrys. Mayor Prather and the top county official, Judge Executive George Lusby, each have one. Others have been distributed to nonprofit groups in town. These gifts proved a good investment for Toyota. Officer D. Reed Wilbers of the Georgetown Police Department said the Mayor was impressed enough with his car to invite the police chief to try it, and last year, the department bought nine.
Upon coming to Georgetown, Toyota also gave the city and county a total of $1 million, which they used to buy a failing convent and convert it for use as a senior citizens' center and other community purposes.
Toyota does not pay property taxes as such because the property for the plant was bought through a bond issue. Instead, it paid $900,000 for support of the school system last year, and Mr. Wiseman said that over 20 years the company expected to pay a total of $17 million to the schools.
The president of the plant, Fujio Cho, seems to be cutting an agreeable figure in town.
Unlike many of his executives, who have settled in the more cosmopolitan community of Lexington, Mr. Cho has bought a large brick house in the finest development in Georgetown. Each week he attends the Rotary Club meeting. He is often seen at work wearing the uniform of khaki trousers and a navy blue shirt.
Mayor Prather, an unabashed booster of Toyota, recalled that in 1985 great apprehension greeted the announcement that Toyota would settle here. "There would be 700 people at zoning meetings," he said.
This contrasted with the zoning meeting after the announcement of the plant's expansion. Just one person showed up, the Mayor said, "and he was just a curious neighbor."

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1812 words

HEADLINE: Where America Is Growing: The Suburban Cities

BYLINE: By ROBERTO SURO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PLANO, Tex.

 BODY:
A decade ago this suburb on the outskirts of Dallas was like other bedroom communities that sent their commuters down the freeways every morning. But in the 1980's Plano grew big and rich through a new form of urban development that is transforming the nation's economic geography.
Now, at every rush hour there is traffic in both directions as commuters drive to and from Plano for jobs in office buildings, factories and warehouses that sprang up in the 1980's alongside the housing subdivisions and shopping malls. 
 The 1990 census found that 29 communities had surpassed a population of 100,000, an unofficial but convenient threshold used by statisticians to mark when a town becomes a city. Twenty-two of them, Plano included, are situated in major metropolitan areas and are thus not free-standing cities in the classic sense because they still depend on and exist in the shadow of a metropolis. Yet these cities are no longer mere suburbs either, having become powerful economic centers themselves.
 
A New Type of Urbanization
 "We are in the midst of a new urbanization process that is very different from anything that we have known in post-war period." said Edward Soja, a professor of urban planning at the University of California at Los Angeles. "It is hard even to use the old terms like cities and suburbs, center and periphery, and we haven't created a new vocabulary yet."
Plano may be what the future of urban America looks like. It and the suburban cities like it have succeeded so well as locales for economic growth that they have redefined the idea of a metropolitan area. Workplaces of all sorts, but especially the newest and most profitable, are now as likely to be found on the edges of a metropolis as in the old core cities.
People commute to Plano to work in a complex of telecommunications manufacturing plants that began in another suburb, Richardson, and pushed its way into the south side of Plano.
 
A Corporate 'Campus'
 Others drive to "Legacy Park," a huge office development that houses one of the world's largest data processing centers and the national headquarters of four major corporations, Frito-Lay Inc., Southland Life Insurance, the Electronic Data Systems Corporation and Murata Business Systems. A fifth, the J. C. Penney Company Inc., formerly of New York City, is building its new headquarters "campus" in Legacy Park.
Two big fiber optic communications stations insure that the Legacy complex is firmly plugged into the global economy even as executives take lunch-hour jogs around woods, ponds and hillocks.
Outside the economic sphere, suburban cities like Plano have begun showing many attributes of big urban centers. This city, for instance, has its own small chamber music ensemble. It has Thai, Hunan Chinese and other ethnic restaurants, and even a quaint downtown. Antique and crafts shops now occupy storefronts where cotton farmers used to buy their supplies.
What is most obviously missing is the immigrant and minority population that provide the low-wage work force in most urban areas. More than 87 percent of the students in Plano's public schools are white. In Dallas, on the other hand, the 1990 census showed that for the first time a majority of the city's population was black or Hispanic.
Despite the economic success of the suburban cities, they have aggravated some longstanding social problems. Since the 1950's the movement of the middle class to the suburbs has helped generate economic and educational inequities and racial polarization. These divisions deepened in the 1980's as jobs left the core cities and emerged in the suburbs.
Many of the new suburban cities served as incubators for new enterprises in computing and telecommunications in the 1980's. The growth of cities like Lowell, Mass.; Irvine, Hayward and Oceanside, Calif.; Scottsdale, Ariz., and Irving, Tex., reflects the way the technology industry has sought fresh real estate away from traditional manufacturing areas, but then has created its own corridors of congestion.
 
Tightly Integrated Centers
 "This is no longer sprawl," said Donald A. Hicks, professor of political economy at the University of Texas at Dallas. "These suburban clusters are even more tightly integrated and specialized economically than the core cities used to be, and in the 1980's they became the new salt licks for population growth."
It is not only new Sun Belt cities that have emerged as suburban economic centers. A few older Eastern cities, like Lowell, outside Boston, or Stamford, Conn., outside New York, which were vigorous industrial centers in the 19th century then went into decline, have found new, thriving suburban identities. Indeed, Stamford was in many ways a forerunner of the suburban development in the South and West.
The 1990 census showed that for the first time most Americans live in metropolitan areas of a million residents or more. Nearly 125 million people, a little more than half the total of 249.6 million, now live in 39 areas of a million-plus people.
There are only eight cities with a million or more residents; the rest of the 39 areas include both the cities and their suburbs.
The growth has taken place in the areas beyond the core cities, and the Dallas-Fort Worth area, which includes Plano, is something of a model of this trend. The "Metroplex," as the area is known to its boosters, was among the fastest growing of the nation's big metropolitan areas, the census found. Its population increased 32.6 percent to more than 3.8 million.
In the 1980's the region became a constellation comprising the two core namesake cities and five suburban cities with populations of more than 100,000: Arlington, Garland, Irving, Mesquite and Plano. Altogether the suburban cities grew almost twice as much as did Dallas and Fort Worth.
 
Suburbs of Suburbs
 The suburban cities even began spawning their own small suburbs, classic bedroom communities like "the Colony," a large development on the northern fringe of the Dallas-Fort Worth metropolitan area that is known for a high population of "pink collar" clerical workers.
The change in the urban landscape is evident to anyone who flies over a metropolitan area today, especially one in the Sunbelt. A decade or two ago these areas appeared as a clump of downtown buildings surrounded by a carpet of housing sprawling in every direction.
Now, the core dontown is no longer alone. Smaller clusters of office buildings and factories are scattered around at highway interchanges far out into the countryside.
These centers of economic activity generate other development around them. To local residents, each cluster has a name and a specialized identity. While the traditional American city was built around its central business district, the new cities are focused on a principal business or activity: a collection of computer companies, perhaps, or a large regional medical center, or a sports or recreation complex.
A similar specialization has even reshaped the downtowns of central cities. Professor Soja of the University of California said downtowns have become concentrations of two activities: government and banking, as well as the associated professions of the law and investment.
"There is a structural change which seems to be taking us towards something like city-states," said John V. Roach, chairman and chief executive officer of the Tandy Corporation, which has its headquarters in Fort Worth. "This metro area is already much more than what we are used to thinking of as a city. It is bigger, richer, more complex, more diverse."
 
A More Pessimistic View
 Not all views of new metropolitan development is so sanguine, however, especially in places like the City Hall of an old urban center.
"We've all worked together to promote economic development in the Metroplex because we all benefited," said Mayor Bob Bolen of Fort Worth. "But now these big suburban commercial and industrial projects are putting all the tax-base growth in places that don't share the central city's costs in terms of maintaining an older infrastructure or caring for the elderly, the poor and the sick."
In response, Fort Worth has conducted an aggressive campaign of annexation. "If you can't make the neighboring cities help pay your costs," Mr. Bolen said, "then you have to expand your boundaries to the point that you take in the growth areas."
This option is not available to Dallas, which is surrounded by suburban cities already powerful enough to resist annexation, and the success of the suburbs has become an issue in the Dallas mayoral campaign. The platform of one candidate, Forrest Smith, consists almost entirely of demands that the city defend itself against suburban economic encroachment.
 
In City's Center: Resentment
 The view is even darker from the perspective of minority citizens in one of the core cities. State Senator Eddie Bernice Johnson, a Democrat, represents a constituency on the south side of Dallas that is predominantly black but cuts across economic strata from the poor to affluent professionals.
"No one seems to care that the jobs keep moving farther and farther away from the people that need them the most," she said. "We have plenty of cheap, unused property around here, and when people see everything going way out of town, they get angry and they start talking about racism, and you can't blame them."
 But the core cities were not alone in feeling hardship from the separation of job growth from the largest pool of workers.
 "It is the irony and the tragedy of urban growth in the 1980's that there were simultaneously labor shortages in the suburbs and unemployment in the cities," said John D. Kasarda, director of the Center for Competitiveness and Employment Growth at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill.
 Professor Kasarda sees a breakdown not just in the labor market but also in a fundamental social dynamic. For the first time in history, he said, "we have an underclass that is physically immobilized by the lack of either low cost housing in the areas that where jobs are available or the transportation to get there."
 He advocates programs that increase mobility, like van pool arrangements with suburban employers, job opportunity networks to bring news of suburban jobs to city dwellers and relocation assistance for the needy who find jobs and must move.
 Larry Fonts, president of the Central Dallas Association, a business executives' group, said: "Our government policies are just starting to adapt to our patterns of growth. In this area it's beginning with a regional public transportation system, and there is clear potential for regional approaches to issues like water, parks and waste disposal. Seeing how much further we want to go will be the challenge of the next decade."

HEADLINE: WAR IN THE GULF: The Overview
BUSH DEMANDS IRAQ START PULLOUT TODAY DESPITE ITS ASSENT TO 3-WEEK SOVIET PLAN;
OILFIELDS AND TRENCHES AFLAME IN KUWAIT
GROUND WAR VOWED

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22

 BODY:
As the Soviet Union pressed ahead with its attempt to broker peace in the Persian Gulf, President Bush today gave President Saddam Hussein of Iraq what he said was the alliance's final demand: Start withdrawing from Kuwait by noon on Saturday or face a huge ground attack.
Administration officials said the ultimatum was based on an assessment that Mr. Bush should move swiftly to dictate terms of a withdrawal to Iraq now that five weeks of bombing have brought Baghdad to the point where it has agreed to a Soviet proposal for a pullout and is trying to negotiate the terms. 
 "The coalition will give Saddam Hussein until noon Saturday to do what he must do: begin his immediate and unconditional withdrawal from Kuwait," Mr. Bush said in a statement from the White House Rose Garden. He bolstered his message by accusing Iraq of conducting a "scorched earth" policy to destroy Kuwait's oilfields.
 
Ultimatum Called Shameful
 The White House said Iraq's response should be communicated to the United Nations before the deadline at noon Eastern time. By then, it will be night in Iraq, which would be the right time for an immediate attack should Mr. Bush decide to order one.
Speaking defiantly but showing signs of wavering, Iraq called Mr. Bush's ultimatum shameful and indicated that it was pinning its hopes on the continuing mediation attempt by the Soviet Union, which offered a modified peace proposal today but hinged its suggestions on conditions that were more favorable to Iraq than those demanded by the military alliance. [Transcripts of the American, Soviet and Iraqi statements are on pages 4 to 6.]
 
A Nudge for Gorbachev
 While Mr. Bush thanked President Mikhail S. Gorbachev in public for his efforts, behind the scenes the Administration sought to convey the impression that Mr. Bush was gently moving Mr. Gorbachev aside to prevent Moscow and Baghdad from reaching an agreement that fell short the unconditional victory sought by Washington.
In an indication that Iraq recognizes that time was running short and that it wants to forestall a ground war, the Iraqi statement spelled out clearly that Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz had the authority to make whatever concessions were necessary for the Soviet effort to succeed. That was an extraordinary break with custom for Mr. Hussein, who usually reserves important strategic decisions for himself.
 Iraq's response, read in English by an unidentified Iraqi official to reporters in Al Rashid Hotel in Baghdad, did not directly address Mr. Bush's demand that Iraq pull out of Kuwait City within 48 hours of the deadline and then pull back entirely into Iraq within a week.
 In a sense, the ultimatum delivered today was similar to the one presented in January, when Mr. Bush told Iraq it had until midnight on Jan. 15 to get out Kuwait or face war.
 But Mr. Bush's blunt new threat came in the context of the suspense over when the ground war might begin and also seemed to cut across the diplomatic efforts by Moscow.
 
Talks With Mitterrand
 In a day of satellite-speed diplomacy and public oratory that was played out on television broadcasts from three capitals and included an extraordinarily long conversation between Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev, it was impossible to know for certain how much the President has been coordinating his actions with the Soviet leader.
 But it was revealing that the President did not speak to Mr. Gorbachev today until after he had made public the coalition's position from the White House Rose Garden. The United States said the conversation lasted 72 minutes, longer than any other phone call of its kind. The Soviet Union said it lasted 90 minutes.
 Appearing outside the Oval Office, where his top aides had just been in urgent consultation, tearing up drafts of his statement and rewriting them as the President spoke by telephone with President Francois Mitterrand of France, Mr. Bush said,: "I have decided that the time has come to make public with specificity just exactly what is required of Iraq if a ground war is to be avoided."
 Mr. Bush told Mr. Hussein that by noon on Saturday, Washington time, he must "publicly and authoritatively" convey his acceptance of the coalition's demands and then begin a "large scale" withdrawal from Kuwait.
 
'Instant and Sharp Response'
 Mr. Bush said he would refrain from moving the war into its long-anticipated ground phase until the noon deadline, but he and other officials refused to say how long beyond that they would wait.
 In return for Iraq's withdrawal, Mr. Bush promised only that the allied force would not attack retreating Iraqi soldiers. But he warned that any breach of the withdrawal, or an attack on another country like Israel, would bring "an instant and sharp response."
 In London, Prime Minister John Major said the allies' statement was "perfectly clear and it is not negotiable." He continued: "So Iraq now knows precisely what they have to do. I hope that they recognize that we are not prepared to bargain with them and we are certainly not prepared to be strung along by them."
 Other leading countries in the coalition swiftly backed Mr. Bush's hard line, and then Moscow announced a new peace plan that took a significant step toward the allied position but still contained major differences with the coalition demands.
 
Cushioning an Iraqi Defeat
 While Mr. Bush gave Iraq 48 hours to get out of Kuwait City, return the deposed Emir to power and free all its prisoners of war, Moscow proposed four days to leave Kuwait and three days to free the prisoners. There was no mention in Moscow's plan of the deposed Kuwaiti Government, and Mr. Gorbachev said Iraq should have 21 days, not one week, to withdraw entirely from Kuwait.
 The Soviet proposal also envisions a one-day cease-fire before Iraq would begin its withdrawal, while the allies insist on an immediate withdrawal and promise to stop attacking retreating Iraqi forces only after the pullout begins.
 In another vital difference, the Soviet plan provides for lifting all the United Nations resolutions, including trade sanctions and demands for reparations to Kuwait, as soon as the withdrawal ends. Mr. Bush's list of conditions not only offers no automatic lifting of the sanctions, but envisions that some of them, including a ban on arms trade with Baghdad, would remain in place after a withdrawal to prevent Iraq from rearming. A new vote by the Security Council would be needed to lift the sanctions.
 American officials said they believed that Moscow was trying to cushion defeat for Iraq, in part to find a solution that Baghdad will accept and in part to enhance Soviet status in the Arab world after the war ends.
 In contrast, the White House's list of "nonnegotiable conditions" seemed intended to give Mr. Bush the decisive victory he is seeking, even if Mr. Hussein decides to try to salvage as much of his military power as he can by pulling out.
 
Pressure for Military Victory
 With Mr. Bush under pressure from some advisers and allies to press ahead to an overwhelming military victory that would destroy the Iraqi war machine and perhaps Mr. Hussein, the demands seemed intended to force so swift a withdrawal that Iraq would have to leave behind much of its tanks and artillery.
 But the Pentagon acknowledged today that the Republican Guard, which includes Mr. Hussein's toughest troops and best tanks, would be largely unaffected because it is deployed along the Iraqi border and could be withdrawn quickly.
 A senior Administration official said the White House had also "taken into consideration" the possibility that the demands imposed by the coalition were so stringent that Mr. Hussein would defy them and keep fighting, permitting the alliance to strike for the military victory that it believes is within its grasp.
 It was a day of diplomacy reminiscent in some ways of earlier moments, like the Cuban missile crisis, but this one was played out live on television.
 The electric atmosphere drew an unusually large crowd to the White House gates, where lunch-time onlookers stood two and three deep, peering through the iron bars and hoping for a glimpse of the President and his advisers.
 
Coalition Negotiations
 Washington was a contrast to Moscow, where the attention of much of the public, including protesters in the streets today, was riveted on domestic problems like economic hardship and the Kremlin's battle with its secession-minded republics, and not on the war in the Middle East.
 Mr. Bush appeared in the Rose Garden after a night of intensive consultations with his war council, which concluded about midnight that it would reject the Soviet demands and set forth the allies' conditions for stopping the war.
 During the night, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and Brent Scowcroft, the President's national security adviser, conferred with other members of the coalition to prepare the statement that the White House issued today.
 Mr. Bush's team worked until the last minute before he stepped out of the Oval Office into the Rose Garden. Through the office's windows, Mr. Bush could be seen behind his desk, a phone to his ear. Mr. Scowcroft and Robert M. Gates, his deputy, hurried in and out of the room, clutching papers under their arms, while Mr. Baker stood by the sofa on another phone.

 
Burning of Oil Fields
 Stepping up to a bank of microphones, Mr. Bush accused Iraq of duplicity in its dealings with Moscow and asserted that Baghdad was systematically destroying Kuwait's oil-production installations, the kind of action that Mr. Bush has warned would draw "the strongest possible response."
 "We learned this morning that Saddam has now launched a scorched-earth policy against Kuwait, anticipating perhaps that he will now be forced to leave," Mr. Bush said. "He is wantonly setting fires to and destroying the oil wells, the oil tanks, the export terminals and other installations of that small country.
 Indeed, they are destroying the entire oil production system of Kuwait. And at the same time that that Moscow press conference was going on and Iraq's Foreign Minister was talking peace, Saddam Hussein was launching Scud missiles."
 But at the Pentagon, officials said today that the burning of Kuwait's oil fields might have been a defensive action by Iraq, which appeared to be anticipating imminent attack by allied ground forces.
 A few hours later, Vitaly N. Ignatenko, Mr. Gorbachev's spokesman, announced that the Soviet Union had given Iraq a revised peace proposal that modified the one presented on Thursday so that it "seriously adjusted" what was required from Baghdad.
 "I would like to stress once again," he said, "that the language is being made more watertight."

HEADLINE: WAR IN THE GULF: Soviet Union;
Moscow Sends Revised Plan to Baghdad

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Feb. 22

 BODY:
The Soviet Union and Iraq's Foreign Minister sent proposals for several new Iraqi concessions by radio to President Saddam Hussein of Iraq today in a race against the deadline declared by President Bush.
The new proposals were still short of conditions set by Mr. Bush when he demanded that Iraq begin pulling its troops out of Kuwait by Saturday noon, Eastern time. 
 The Kremlin spokesman, Vitaly N. Ignatenko, said that although Mr. Bush's position was tougher than Moscow's, the latest proposal was the "maximum" Moscow could extract from the Iraqis. Mr. Ignatenko said he expected a reply "today or tomorrow" from Baghdad.
 
Long Telephone Conversation
 Mr. Ignatenko said President Mikhail S. Gorbachev talked by telephone to Mr. Bush for 90 minutes after the Soviet leader had met with the Iraqi Foreign Minister, Tariq Aziz, but before Mr. Bush set his deadline.
Evidently to counter any impression that Mr. Gorbachev and Mr. Bush were working at cross purposes, Mr. Ignatenko seemed to take pains to stress that Moscow remained committed to its policy of building a "real partnership" with the United States.
"Washington understands this, and we have been witness to the fact that since the beginning of the crisis in the Persian Gulf -- and this is important to stress -- the Soviet Union and the United States have always acted in harmony and with regard to each others' interests," he said.
Moscow's latest proposals were hammered out in negotiations this morning among Mr. Aziz, the Soviet Foreign Minister, Aleksandr A. Bessmertnykh, and Yevgeny M. Primakov, a foreign-policy adviser to Mr. Gorbachev who had initiated the latest Soviet negotiating effort with a trip to Baghdad earlier this month.
The new package was essentially a version of the Soviet plan to which Mr. Aziz announced Iraq's agreement when he arrived in Moscow early today, but with modifications apparently made to make the plan closer to what the United States had sought.
 
Central Point Remains
 The central point of the proposal remained an agreement by Iraq to withdraw unconditionally from Kuwait, as required by United Nations Security Council Resolution 660. The new version also reiterated that the pullout would begin 24 hours after a cease-fire, but it set specific limits for its completion -- Iraqi troops would be out of Kuwait City within four days and out of the country within 21 days.
The American ultimatum demanded that Iraq start the pullout by noon on Saturday and that all troops leave Kuwait City within two days and the country within a week.
The Moscow package further called on Iraq to comply with only one United Nations Security Council resolution, the one demanding a full and immediate withdrawal of Iraqi troops. The United States has insisted that all United Nations measures be accepted.
The plan said all prisoners of war would be released within three days of a cease-fire, and the withdrawal would be monitored by observers or peace-keeping forces named by the Security Council. The new wording left open the possibility that these would be the United States-led allied force.
The sole demand dropped by Iraq was that economic sanctions be lifted once two-thirds of its forces were out.
Mr. Ignatenko said the new package was sent by radio to Baghdad over Soviet diplomatic channels about 6 P.M., Moscow time, or 10 A.M., Eastern time. Mr. Aziz remained in Moscow.
The proposals followed what another Soviet spokesman, Vitaly Churkin of the Foreign Ministry, called 24 hours of "unprecedented diplomatic activity."
 
 Aziz's Return to Moscow
 Mr. Aziz, who had taken the original Soviet proposals to Baghdad at the start of the week, returned to Moscow shortly after midnight on Thursday and went directly into two and a half hours of talks with Mr. Gorbachev. Mr. Ignatenko then said at a news briefing that Iraq had agreed to an "unconditional" withdrawal, with terms that Washington later said were conditions.
That night, Mr. Gorbachev called Mr. Bush, and in the morning he continued with calls to other members of the United Nations Security Council. Mr. Bessmertnykh, who had gone on a brief visit to Spain, flew home at 5:30 A.M. to pick up the talks with Mr. Aziz.
Just as the talks concluded and the message was being wired to Mr. Hussein, Mr. Bush issued his ultimatum. His deadline, noon in New York, is 8 P.M. in Moscow.

HEADLINE: WAR IN THE GULF;
Statement by Iraqi Revolutionary Council

 BODY:
Following is a transcript of a statement made in Baghdad yesterday by a spokesman for the ruling Revolutionary Command Council, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of CNN:
 In the name of God, Bush tried in his statement today, in a way expressing his moral deterioration, to portray or hint that what the Foreign Minister, Tariq Aziz, agreed upon in Moscow is one thing and what President Saddam Hussein said in his speech yesterday is another. In his statement, Bush wanted to deceive nobody but himself, because Mr. Tariq Aziz, as authorized by President Saddam Hussein, to be committed to whatever is agreed upon with the Soviets with regard to their peace initiative. 
 Bush tried to issue Don Quixotic ultimatums for Iraq to withdraw until midday tomorrow, as he put it. We don't know whether Bush and his shameful ultimatum have sought to hint that the peace initiative is a result of his ultimatums, or that he wanted to imply to the world that he, together with his frustrated allies, have the allied victory over Iraq as if he imagines that the world is unaware of the fact that all that Bush and his allies have achieved since the 17th of January up to now is not more than sending his crows to implement a cowardly plan of destruction against the civilian property of the Iraqis, as well as against houses of worship, innocent civilians, as was the case in the attacks on Amariya shelter, Falluja, Mosul, Nasiriya, Basra, Karbala and all towns and villages, and even desert shepherds and Bedouins.
Bush and the allies who cooperated with him to commit that crime have sought to make the beginning of the battle not with our courageous ground forces, because they know very well that they lack the legitimacy that may enable them to face the army of jihad and faith. Bush might have been hasty to adopt a stance so that he may enjoy his weekend holiday, hence making hasty statements to bring closer the decision which is close to his evil intentions, namely the continuation of the aggression.
 
Soviet Initiative Backed
 We would like to affirm that Iraq is for peace and has been working seriously to support the Soviet initiative, and to facilitate its success. This is not out of fear of Bush's threats or a sign of respect for him, because we neither respect him nor are we afraid of his aggressive force. He has tried his bad luck all throughout the past time using whatever his bloodstained hands could catch up, criminal means and weapons.
By such a stance we express respect for what we believe in and for what we believe to be necessary for our people and humanity. We adopt such a position as an expression of respect for those whom we respect. And God's enemy and Devil's friend Bush is not among them.
As for Bush's job on destroying properties in Kuwait, such a job is [inaudible] an unfortuate one. Bush appears unaware of what has been destroyed in Kuwait, or in other fields in Iraq, be they petroleum installations or other properties. Bush even did not skip destroying what the most savage saboteurs and invaders avoided to destroy. Hence, Bush is not the right man to evaluate any aptitude or to make charges against others.
If Bush denies this as well as his destructive action to other oil and economic facilities, whether those are related to oil transport or production and extraction, in Kuwait or in Iraq as a whole, we call upon the Security Council to form a neutral committee, to the membership of which we propose China and the U.S.S.R., as well as any other members decided by the Council which are not parties to the fighting or have supported the warring parties. This committee is to get acquainted with the degree of civilian and economic destruction, whether in Kuwait or in Iraq at large.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 24; Column 4; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 548 words

HEADLINE: Recycling Doesn't Come Without Its Costs

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "As Recycling Becomes a Growth Industry, Its Paradoxes Also Multiply" (The Week in Review, Jan. 20): Recycling has paradoxes because many assumptions underlying policies and legislation are not fully defined or scientifically examined. 
 Recycling has become a numbers game. Federal legislation proposed a 25 percent recycling level before one could incinerate municipal solid waste. The provision was deleted from the Clean Air Act Amendments of 1990 at the last minute. The New York State solid-waste management plan requires communities to plan for 40 percent recycling by 1997; 50 percent if you include waste reduction, over which local communities have little control. New Jersey's Gov. Jim Florio has set a goal of 60 percent.
Nobody seems sure what counts toward achieving these goals or what constitutes the 100 percent base. How about communities that have established recycling programs or have operating waste-to-energy plants? Do they have to reduce their wastes as much as communities that start from scratch? How about yard waste, including leaves and grass clippings, that were never part of the waste stream? How about construction and demolition debris, also never part of the municipal waste stream. If these are now recycled, do they count toward mandated goals? How about the scrap-metal industry, particularly scrap automobiles? How about metals recovered from incinerator ash or incinerator ash put to other constructive uses?
These are complicated issues, and it does not help to have rigid, mandated percentages when nobody knows what counts and what does not.
Furthermore, not all forms of recycling are equally feasible, technically, environmentally or economically. Composting, which is being pushed by environmentalists, is fine for yard wastes but questionable for sewage sludge (because of metal contamination) or for mixed municipal solid waste (because of high ratios of noncompostable constituents). Markets for compost are a major issue.
The case for recycling is a mixed bag because of adverse economics. When is the community better off burning paper than recycling? Glass and plastics recycling are economically marginal, because of the high costs of separation and transportation. If recovered materials cost more, chances are it requires more energy to produce them.
If the environmental crisis is a part of the energy crisis, we must be very careful to include all energy costs in the costs of recycling. Plastics recycling also suffers because of the difficulty in producing recovered materials meeting certain specifications. We are attempting to label plastics to allow separation, mostly by manual means, into seven types. Only two of these types have reasonably wellestablished markets.
The most fundamental theoretical flaw of recycling is that it attempts to overcome the second law of thermodynamics, that is, to restore order from randomness. The second law tells us that it always requires energy to do this and that there must always be some waste that cannot be used. Otherwise, we would have alchemy and perpetual-motion machines. The more we try to close the cycle, the more energy it requires and the more energy is lost.
 
JOHN L. ROSE
White Plains, Feb. 3, 1991
 
The writer is an engineer.

HEADLINE: Recycling Doesn't Come Without Its Costs;
Buyback Center

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"New York City Shouldn't Set Up a Center to Buy Recyclables" (letter, Jan. 22) by Harvey Jakob, president of the New York City chapter of the Institute of Scrap Recycling Industries, criticizes a contract between the Department of Sanitation and my organization, the Manhattan Bowery Corporation, to operate a recycling-buyback center. 
 His attacks on the wisdom of the city's recycling effort, the impact of the contract on private dealers and Manhattan Bowery's capacity to perform are misplaced.
A buyback center would purchase recyclables at a posted price and bale or otherwise process these to sell to brokers or end users, some of them members of Mr. Jakob's industry. The center will employ about 25 unemployed homeless people, who will be trained and employed in the facility as it expands or be placed in private sector jobs.
The center will educate the public and encourage recycling; assist residents of lower-income communities by paying cash for recyclable materials; help extend the life of the city's landfills, and help open new markets for hard-to-recycle materials.
Mr. Jakob seems to object to the facility principally because it involves a city subsidy to a not-for-profit operator. The contract was awarded to us after a request for proposals open to all qualified bidders. The private operators Mr. Jakob represents declined to bid for the contract (and the subsidy).
They failed to bid because the contract requires the performance of functions that are not likely to be profitable. For example, it requires handling unprofitable recyclable materials such as newspapers: the market for recycled newsprint is limited, the supply overwhelming. The contract also mandates extensive community education and outreach.
The Department of Sanitation has wisely decided that it is more efficient to pay $92 a ton to dispose of waste materials by recycling than $150 to $400 a ton to collect and deposit waste in landfills.
The Manhattan Bowery Corporation will collect primarily from individuals and not-for-profit institutions that are not sources of material for the private sector, and not from commercial or industrial concerns, since costs associated with handling commercial waste are not eligible for a direct subsidy.
New laws governing recycling will mean a substantial quantity of material from other not-for-profits, particularly large institutions such as hospitals and universities. We can respond to this opportunity as well as serve the walk-in public, while preserving the job and business potential of recycling this material for New York City.
 
EDWARD I. GEFFNER
Executive Director, Manhattan Bowery Corporation
New York, Feb. 11, 1991

HEADLINE: A Likely Winner in Air Dispute

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Feb. 22

 BODY:
It is too early to predict the outcome of the fight between the United States and Britain over landing rights at Heathrow Airport near London. But at least one airline seems likely to emerge a winner: Virgin Atlantic Airways Ltd.
From the looks of it, Virgin, an upstart six-year-old carrier now confined in London to Gatwick Airport, would not only get to fly from Heathrow, a more popular airport, but would also be able to expand significantly the number of American cities where it could offer scheduled flights. Virgin now offers service to five United States destinations, including Newark and Kennedy International Airport in New York. 
 The opportunity for Virgin to offer scheduled flights to more American cities is a result of a sweetener the United States is offering Britain, in an attempt to win approval for American Airlines and United Airlines to buy Heathrow routes from Pan American World Airways and Trans World Airlines. Virgin's chance to offer Heathrow service would come about if Britain scraps a law barring additional carriers from the congested airport. Even before the dispute with the United States, the British Government was considering such a move to foster competition.
 On top of that, there is the prospect that Virgin, which has 8 percent of the Britain-United States market, could pick up two more daily round-trip flights between London and Tokyo; those rights now belong to British Airways P.L.C., the market leader.
All of this was helping Richard Branson, the airline's chairman and majority owner, to forget the pain from a neck injury the other day.
Did the 40-year-old entrepreneur, whose $2.4 billion entertainment and travel empire makes him one of Britain's biggest success stories, sustain the injury when he landed last month in Canada after a record-setting hot-air balloon trip across the Pacific? (He made the 6,761-mile crossing in 46 hours and 6 minutes from Miyakonojo, Japan, to Yellowknife in the Northwest Territories of Canada.)
No, it came from a tennis match, when his partner hit him with a shot, Mr. Branson said, flashing one of his well-known toothy grins.
Mr. Branson is doing his best to be a pain in the neck of his archrival, British Airways, which has 40 percent of the United States-Britain market.
He has persuaded the British Civil Aviation Authority to recommend that the Government take away two valuable round-trip London-Tokyo routes from British Airways and give them to Virgin, so the airline can increase its round-trip flights to Tokyo to six a week. A Government decision is expected soon.
Mr. Branson is also hoping to hear any day whether he is going to win the biggest prize: the right to fly from Heathrow, the home base of British Airways.
Worried about congestion at Heathrow and eager to promote use of Gatwick, Britain has not allowed international airlines without a previous presence at Heathrow to use the airport since 1977. That means that Virgin, which began operations in 1984, has had to fly from Gatwick. But the Conservative Government is widely expected to lift those restrictions.
 
A Wish List of Cities

One inducement that the United States is dangling in front of Britain is something Mr. Branson would also love to have: permission for a second British carrier to fly to many American cities.
Virgin wants to offer scheduled service to and from Washington, San Francisco, Chicago and Orlando, Fla. Besides Virgin's scheduled flights to and from Newark and Kennedy, it flies to Miami and Los Angeles and has permission to begin service at Boston in May. It also offers chartered flights to Orlando.
To be sure, tiny Virgin, with its eight Boeing 747 jumbo jets, does not pose nearly so big a threat to British Airways in the North Atlantic market as mighty American and United.
But with those American carriers likely to be much stronger competitors than the struggling Pan Am and T.W.A., which have 15 percent and 14 percent, respectively, of the British-American market, British Airways can hardly be thrilled at the prospect of having to contend with a stronger Virgin as well.
"Although they're small, they've got to be regarded as serious competition," said Andrew Chambers, an analyst at Nomura Research Institute Europe Ltd. "People think quite highly of their service."<>
Virgin has built customer loyalty by offering a combination of highly praised Upper Class service to business travelers and bargain fares for economy passengers. Upper Class amenities include limousine service to and from airports, roomier seats than most competitors, a Sony Video Walkman for every passenger with a choice of about 35 films on tape, and a free economy ticket. Some flights also offer a masseuse or live entertainment like fashion shows, musicians and magicians.
"I would fly Virgin anytime over British Airways and the American carriers," said James McBurney, a London-based investment banker at Goldman Sachs International Ltd. "If you want to work, you've got more room to work. If you want to be entertained, there's more entertainment."
Plenty of travelers agree, explaining why Virgin has regularly filled 75 to 85 percent of its seats.
Since the Persian Gulf war broke out, its planes have been 71 percent full. While that is down from 74 percent a year ago, it is much higher than the rates for the big carriers, which unlike Virgin are now operating at a loss. Virgin executives say people worried about possible terrorist attacks against the big American and British airlines may be flying Virgin instead.
 
Learning From Failures

Mr. Branson said he had tried to learn from the failures of Laker Airways in Britain and People Express in the United States. Virgin executives include alumni of Laker and of some small British carriers as well as people with no previous airline experience.
Laker and People Express both offered no-frills service and competed on price alone, leaving them vulnerable to price cutting by bigger rivals. But the fat profits Virgin earns from its Upper Class -- the source of about two-thirds of its profits -- make it much less vulnerable to economy-class fare wars.
Virgin now charges $1,946 for a one-way Upper Class ticket from Newark or Kennedy to Gatwick. That is exactly what British Airways, T.W.A. and Continental Airlines charge for business class, but $1,259 less than their first-class fares.
Pan Am, which is in bankruptcy proceedings, has slashed fares in an attempt to raise cash. It is offering a round-trip business-class ticket between New York and London for $1,956, providing it is bought before March 15 and travel starts by May 31. A round-trip first-class ticket with the same restrictions costs $2,564.
 
Higher Profits Predicted
 Even though these are the toughest times the airline industry has faced in decades, "we're actually going to make more money this fiscal year than we made last year," Mr. Branson said. He predicted that pretax earnings would rise to $25 million on revenues of about $600 million in the year that ends on July 31. It earned $13.7 million on revenues of $336.6 million in the last fiscal year.
Mr. Branson said he had been careful not to expand too quickly and was avoiding the cutthroat short-haul business; routes to Ireland and the Netherlands were sold in 1989. Besides flying to the United States and Tokyo, Virgin also serves Moscow.
Virgin would eventually like to add service to Johannesburg, Singapore, Australia and maybe Mexico City. "But the rationale of the airline is not to be the biggest, it's to be the best," said Christopher Moss, Virgin's marketing director.
Mr. Branson, who dropped out of school at 17 to start a magazine for young people and went on to make a fortune in records, now owns or controls some 180 companies. Besides airlines and music recording, publishing and retailing, they include video and film distribution; hotels and real estate; electronic games, and a modeling agency.<>
He said he had been careful not to take on too much debt. He took his non-airline businesses public in 1986 but bought back the shares two years later when he became disillusioned with investors' short-term focus. To finance growth, he has sold minority stakes in some companies to the Japanese, whom he admires for their long-term outlook.<<<<
If Virgin lands at Heathrow, Mr. Branson is assuming that American and United will be there, too, but says he is unafraid. "They are better airlines than Pan Am and T.W.A., but there's nothing outstanding about them," he said.
Virgin executives say the tougher competition will merely goad them on in their quest to give customers more value for their money. As a small company in a land of giants, Mr. Branson said, "we've got to keep on being ahead of the game."

HEADLINE: John Sherman Cooper Dies at 89; Longtime Senator From Kentucky

BYLINE: By ALBIN KREBS

 BODY:
John Sherman Cooper, a liberal Republican from Kentucky who represented his state in the Senate for more than two decades, died in a Washington retirement home on Thursday. He was 89 years old.
His brother, Richard, said Mr. Cooper died of heart failure. 
 Throughout his long career in the Senate, Mr. Cooper, a patrician Kentuckian who served his country in diplomatic posts as well as in Congress, maintained a reputation for absolute independence.
His first roll-call vote, transferring investigatory powers to a special War Investigation Committee soon after World War II, went against the wishes of his party's leaders. So did his second vote, which prompted Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio, to storm up the aisle and demand: "Are you a Republican or a Democrat? When are you going to start voting with us?"
"If you'll pardon me," Senator Cooper replied, "I was sent here to represent my constituents, and I intend to vote as I think best."
 
Led Opposition to McCarthy
 In the years that followed, Senator Cooper proved that he meant what he said. He was one of the first Republicans in the Senate to denounce Senator Joseph R. McCarthy of Wisconsin for the tactics of Mr. McCarthy's anti-Communist campaign. When it was unpopular to do so, Mr. Cooper also opposed legislation to remove from reluctant witnesses the Fifth Amendment's protection against compelled self-incrimination.
In the Vietnam War, Mr. Cooper joined with a Democratic, Senator, Frank Church of Idaho, in drafting the Cooper-Church amendment, which was aimed at barring further United States military action in Cambodia.
Mr. Cooper worked quietly, avoiding histrionics. He left behind no ringing calls to action, perhaps because he was, by his own admission, "a truly terrible public speaker." On the rare occasions when he did take the Senate floor, he was often inaudible. He mumbled and swallowed his words, and apparently made no effort to avoid use of Kentucky dialect in which "great" sounded like "grett," "government" became "guv-ment," and "revenue" was pronounced "rev-noo."
Mr. Cooper was born on Aug. 11, 1901, in Somerset, the seat of Pulaski County in Kentucky. He was named for his father, the wealthiest man in town. The elder Mr. Cooper, like his own father and grandfather before him, was a county judge and a circuit judge, and it was always assumed that the next generation of Coopers would provide the county its leaders.
After a year at Centre College in Danville, Ky., Mr. Cooper went to Yale, where he was captain of the basketball team, and in 1923 was voted most likely to succeed.
 
Forced to Leave Harvard
 He went on to Harvard Law School but had to withdraw in 1925 after learning from his dying father that the recession of 1920 had virtually wiped out the family's resources.
Assuming his father's debts, Mr. Cooper sold the family mansion. Over the next 25 years he paid off the debts and sent six brothers and sisters to college. He passed the state bar examination and was admitted to law practice in 1928.
Mr. Cooper won his first elective office in 1927, a two-year term in the Kentucky Legislature. From 1930 to 1938 he served as county judge, a powerful local administrative post that controlled county patronage.
Mr. Cooper was elected three times to fill unexpired terms in the United States Senate. The first was in 1946, after A. B. (Happy) Chandler resigned to become commissioner of baseball. Mr. Cooper failed to win in the 1948 general election, but in 1952 he was elected to fill the unexpired term of Virgil Chapman.
In the next general election he was defeated by Alben W. Barkley, a Democrat who was Vice President under Harry S. Truman, but Mr. Barkley subsequently died and Mr. Cooper was elected to fill his unexpired term in 1956. Mr. Cooper's Senate service continued until his retirement in 1973.
 
Service in Military Government
 In 1942, after he had campaigned unsuccessfully for the Republican nomination for governor, Mr. Cooper enlisted in the Army as a private. Earning a commission in Officer Candidate School, he was assigned to a military government unit. After Germany surrendered, he was put in charge of reorganizing the court system of Bavaria. While in the Army he married a registered nurse, Evelyn Pfaff. They were divorced in 1949.
Mr. Cooper's brief first stint in the Senate won him friends, among them Arthur Vandenberg, a Republican maverick, and President Truman. In 1949 Mr. Truman made Mr. Cooper a delegate to the United Nations; in subsequent years Mr. Cooper served in other missions to the United Nations and as a special assistant to Secretary of State Dean Acheson.
In 1955, shortly before he had become Ambassador to India and Nepal, Mr. Cooper married the former Lorraine Rowan Shevlin, a Washington social figure. But their stay in Asia lasted only a year because, after the death of Mr. Barkley, President Dwight D. Eisenhower summoned Mr. Cooper back to Kentucky to run for Mr. Barkley's unexpired term.
In the 17 years of Senate service that followed, Mr. Cooper, a member of the Foreign Relations Committee, generally followed the liberal internationalist line on foreign policy. In so doing, he was often in conflict with Old Guard Republicans, notably Senator Everett McKinley Dirksen of Illinois. In 1959 Mr. Cooper sought to become Republican leader of the Senate, but Mr. Dirksen defeated him by four votes.
 
Limits on Combat Troops
 Perhaps Mr. Cooper's greatest Senate victory was his move in 1969 to bar the use of United States combat troops from the fighting in Laos and Thailand.
At first it appeared that the Cooper drive had little chance of success, but after Mr. Cooper had enlisted the aid of Senator Mike Mansfield of Montana, the leader of the Democratic majority, the measure was passed by the Senate and then the House, and President Richard M. Nixon signed it into law.
After leaving office early in 1973, Mr. Cooper joined the Washington law firm of Covington & Burling. Mr. Nixon chose him to be the first United States Ambassador to East Germany shortly after Washington formally recognized that Government. But Mr. Nixon was forced from office in 1974 before he could make the actual appointment, and it was his successor, President Gerald R. Ford, who did so. Mr. Cooper remained in the East German post for two years.
He is survived by his brother, who still lives in Somerset, and a niece, Rebecca Spencer, of Lexington, Ky.

HEADLINE: An Elegist's New England, a Buddhist's Dante

BYLINE: By Richard Tillinghast; Richard Tillinghast's most recent volume of poetry is "Our Flag Was Still There."

 BODY:

OLD AND NEW POEMS
By Donald Hall.
244 pp. New York:
Ticknor & Fields.
Cloth, $24.95.
Paper, $12.95.
 
THE WORLD OF THE TEN THOUSAND THINGS
Poems 1980-1990.
By Charles Wright.
232 pp. New York:
Farrar, Straus & Giroux.
$25. 
 If any living American writer deserves the description "man of letters," it is Donald Hall. "Old and New Poems" is his 10th collection of verse. His contributions to literary criticism have been perennial and salutary. He has written biography, short fiction and children's books. His "String Too Short to Be Saved" contains the best essays, for my money, to have been written on New England. His "Fathers Playing Catch With Sons" is a baseball classic. As a personalized introduction to the leading figures of literary modernism, no better book exists than his "Remembering Poets." Yet his poems are the center of his work. "Old and New Poems" -- a book enriched by the incomparable design given it by Anne Chalmers and Sara Eisenman -- gathers a generous selection of the work from 1947 to the present.
Mr. Hall, as this collection makes clear, has improved with the years. My copy falls open at page 125, where poems written from 1975 to the present begin. Before that time he wrote well, and there is much to admire. The chiseled lines of "My Son My Executioner," found in many anthologies, glisten here. "Christmas Eve in Whitneyville" holds emotion severely in check and is as much social satire as it is elegy:
 
They will not have unpleasant thoughts tonight.
They make their houses jails, and they will take
No risk of freedom for the appetite.
 
The early Donald Hall was a ready assimilator; the young poet who wrote these lines knew his Auden.
When in the 1960's, under the influence of Mr. Hall's friends Robert Bly, Galway Kinnell and James Wright, poetry (like everything else) loosened up, Mr. Hall's poetry eagerly embraced open form. In "Self-Portrait as a Bear" and in these lines from "The Alligator Bride" one hears the zany strains of American surrealism, which gives some of these poems a period tone:
 
The sky is a gun aimed at me.
I pull the trigger.
The skull of my promises
leans in a black closet, gapes
with its good mouth
for a teat to suck.
 
Here too is Mr. Hall's wonderfully hyperbolic humor, as in that poem about poetry readings, "To a Waterfowl" (the title alludes incongruously to William Cullen Bryant), which begins: "Women with hats like the rear ends of pink ducks / applauded you, my poems."
About 15 years ago Mr. Hall found his true place and his true subject. Readers of American poetry have reason to be grateful. Having inherited his grandparents' farm, he settled down in New Hampshire, determined to earn his living as a writer. To write of New England was to write New England's elegy, and Mr. Hall has become our great elegist. This is first made clear in "Kicking the Leaves" (1978), which, though set in Ann Arbor, Mich., already locates the poet spiritually in New England, discovering "the pleasure, the only long pleasure, of taking a place / in the story of leaves."
"Praise for Death," the long poem that closes this magnificent collection, is perhaps the finest sustained evocation of death in American poetry. In it Mr. Hall makes perfectly explicit the direction in which his poetry has tended for at least 40 years:
 
Let us praise death that raises itself to such power
that nothing but death exists: not breakfast nor the Long
Island Expressway, not cigarettes nor beaches at Maui,
not the Tigers nor sunrise except under the aspect of death.
 
This poem's precursors are old chestnuts like Bryant's "Thanatopsis," as well as the cloistered epiphanies of Emily Dickinson. But to find equals for the earthiness and relish of such poems as "Twelve Seasons," "Names of Horses" and "Granite and Grass," one must look to Walt Whitman. In the triumphant work of his maturity, in a burly line not strictly metrical but full-blown in its sonority, Mr. Hall celebrates with grieving joy the transmutation of matter into energy and the consumption of life by death, death seen as the unrefusable essence of life itself. Here is the closing section of "Granite and Grass":
 
Ragged Mountain was granite before Adam divided.
Grass lives because it dies. If weary of discord
we gaze heavenward through the same eye that looks at us,
vision makes light of contradiction:
Granite is grass in the holy meadow of the soul's repose.
 
This is poetry that marches in a stately order; classical in its dignity and perfectly readable, it argues the mystical union of dark and light, death and life.
 The subtle cadences of his verse, his famously "good ear," have won Charles Wright a select place among contemporary poets. "The World of the Ten Thousand Things" gathers his work from "The Southern Cross" (1981) to "Xionia" (last year). Since the early 80's, Mr. Wright has increasingly abandoned short lyrics for journal poems that weave diverse thematic threads into a single autobiographical fabric -- more than 200 pages, written over a 10-year period, that can be read as a single poetic sequence worthy of comparison with such extended works as "The Bridge" by Hart Crane, "The Far Field" by Theodore Roethke and "Dream Songs" by John Berryman. Freed from the stringencies of unity and closure demanded by the sort of poem most readers are used to, Mr. Wright is at liberty to spin out extended meditations that pick up, work with, lay aside and return again to landscapes, historical events and ideas.
The culture of Italy, where Mr. Wright was stationed in the Army and where he has returned over the years, runs like a bright thread through his meditations. Like Ezra Pound, he aspires toward Dante as a poetic master. The spirit of the Tuscan poet, in a form reminiscent of Giotto's painting of him -- "Laurel corona encircling his red transparent headcap," his "voice like a slow rip through silk cloth / In disapproval" -- makes an appearance in "A Journal of the Year of the Ox," the 40-page centerpiece of "Zone Journals" (1988).
One is occasionally reminded of Pound's "Cantos" in these pages. Mr. Wright meanders through cultures -- Chinese (as the book's title suggests), Italian, American (the poet explores his Virginia roots and describes the betrayal and destruction of the Cherokee nation in east Tennessee, his native state). But Mr. Wright's intelligence is supple, humane and inclusive; not for him Pound's crackpot economic and racial theories, his narrowness and crankiness.
"The World of the Ten Thousand Things" records with journal-like intimacy a spiritual quest -- an investigation of the relation between the visible and the invisible worlds. Viewing
 
the fire-knots of late roses
Still pumping their petals of flame
 up from the English loam
 
Mr. Wright exclaims:
 
And I suddenly recognize
The difference between the spirit and flesh
 is finite, and slowly transgressable.
 
These meditations often cross the border separating the living from the dead (family members as well as poetic precursors, including Poe and Petrarch in addition to Dante and Pound). The dead appear with great immediacy. Perhaps paradoxically, however, Mr. Wright takes a philosophical position closely akin to Buddhism -- ontological emptiness is the dimension in which all else is grounded: "this is the dirt their lives were made of, the dirt the world is, / Immeasurable emptiness of all things."
But this is, as it were, a positive emptiness, not an excuse for despair or a refusal to engage the world. The poetry grounds itself firmly in actuality, the "ten thousand things" that constitute the world in its totality -- what we cannot see in addition to what we can see:
 
I stand on the porch of Wickliffe Church,
My kinfolk out back in the bee-stitched vines and weeds,
The night coming on, my flat shirt drawing the light in,
Bright bud on the branch of nothing's tree.
The dialectic between a philosophy that negates phenomena and a sensory keenness for what Richard Wilbur has called "the world's hunks and colors" energizes Charles Wright's poetry, which is often presented as a dialogue between the poet and ideas taken from his reading: "Objects do not exist, / by convention sweet, by convention bitter. / Still, you could have fooled me." This down-to-earth voice makes itself heard from time to time in these meditations, and that's a good thing, because Mr. Wright's bad angel tempts him at times toward abstraction -- "Form tends toward its own dissolution" -- and sometimes toward a level of rhetoric that does not convince: "Inside the self is another self like a black hole / Constantly dying."
Yet Mr. Wright's gift for verbal music, his ability to evoke sensory experience and a boldness of metaphorical reference get the juices flowing whenever the language starts to seem a bit desiccated:
 
 salmon-smoke in the west
Back-vaulting the bats
 who plunged and swooped like wrong
 angels
Hooking their slipped souls in the twilight.
 
This poet is able to soar with Dante:
 
-- A bumblebee the size of my thumb
 rises like Geryon
From the hard Dantescan gloom . . .
Shoulders I've wanted to sit on, a ride I've wanted to take.
 
And he can still remain down-home enough to greet the denizens of the Inferno in high-five American style -- "Bico, my man, are you here?" He continues to reveal himself as a poet of great purity and originality.
