HEADLINE: Splendid Little War

BYLINE: By David Murray; David Murray is a former Chicago Sun-Times reporter who writes frequently on military affairs.

 BODY:

SOMETHING TO DIE FOR
By James Webb.
333 pp. New York:
William Morrow & Company.
$19.95. 
As a Marine officer in the Vietnam War, James Webb won some of this country's most prestigious decorations -- including the Navy Cross, the Silver Star, two Bronze Stars and two Purple Hearts. Later, he served in the Department of Defense and rose to become Secretary of the Navy during the Reagan Adminis tration.
His first novel, "Fields of Fire" (1978), was based on his combat experiences; it is part of the Marine Corps's official reading list for noncommissioned and commissioned officers. Mr. Webb's new novel is grounded in high-level Washington political scheming and combat in the Middle East and the Horn of Africa. As topical as today's news, "Something to Die For" should push Mr. Webb onto anyone's list of first-class military-political writers.
In the novel, Ronald Holcomb, an ambitious and ruthless Secretary of Defense, teams with Adm. Mad Dog Mulcahy, a throwback who misses "all the rock and sock of sailing into harm's way" and who desperately wants a war so that he can cap his career. Holcomb and Mulcahy plot to maneuver feckless President Everett Lodge and the Congressional leadership into taking advantage of civil strife in the Soviet Union and expanding a fabricated international incident in the Red Sea to create what they hope will be a limited war.
Such a small war, in Holcomb's scheme, would accomplish two goals: it would deflect attention from a potentially embarrassing conflict with Japan over the transmittal by a Japanese conglomerate of United States military secrets to the Soviet Union, and it would justify an inflated defense budget that has been stalled in Congress. He envisages a military crisis that would win the backing of the American people, "unite their anger and get their blood going, without causing them any economic or personal discomfort." He wants to provide Americans with "a conflict they could follow as if it were a football game." The plan will carry the code name "Operation Justifiable Anger."
The troops who go on to fight this war are epitomized by Col. Bill Fogarty, a battle-hardened, muddy-boots Marine officer. The dedicated Fogarty believes in Napoleon's tenet that "there are no bad regiments, only bad colonels." He also views the war-loving Mad Dog Mulcahy as "a man of brilliance, whose career had come down to idiocy." There are well-drawn allies and adversaries, including French Foreign Legionnaires and a Cuban colonel who will command the enemy ground troops in the splendid little war.
In Washington, the players include a Senate Majority Leader and a veteran House committee chairman who, eager to manipulate others, find themselves manipulated by Holcomb and Mulcahy. As for Holcomb, when his plans threaten to go completely awry, he is ready for a classic Washington attempt at spin control: "He wouldn't lie. He almost never lied. He would merely package the facts, box them up and wrap them with a bright, optimistic ribbon. And anyway, his version could never be challenged."
Many topical political novels fail because they mirror outlandish events so accurately that they appear to be burlesques, which is probably why there have been few successful novels based on Watergate. When politics is combined with military affairs, particularly in the post-Vietnam era, the author must make comprehensible the modern military's array of Nintendo-game weaponry and at the same time provide a political framework that is credible. David Poyer's novel "The Gulf" succeeded in doing that last year.
But Mr. Webb is even more ambitious in attempting to combine war and politics, since his is a global theme. In this he succeeds masterfully. He understands and describes well the high-tech quality of modern war as well as the blood, sweat and fears of its soldiers. He is also skillful and credible in depicting the world of Washington, and his characters are both universal and believable. "Something to Die For" is a remarkable and angry counterpoint to the dispatches from the Persian Gulf, which, by contrast, often seem pastel versions of Mr. Webb's fictional account.

HEADLINE: Bees With Wheels

BYLINE: By Jonathan Penner; Jonathan Penner's new book is "Natural Order," a novel. He teaches fiction writing at the University of Arizona.

 BODY:

FOLLOWING THE BLOOM
Across America With the Migratory Beekeepers.
By Douglas Whynott.
214 pp. Harrisburg, Pa.: Stackpole Books. $19.95. 
 In 1985, Douglas Whynott traveled and lived with migratory beekeepers, men and women who truck thousands of hives thousands of miles each year in search of nectar and pollen. Because something is always in bloom somewhere -- mallaluca in Florida, blueberry in Maine -- bees on wheels can make honey, and their keepers money, all year. Besides selling honey, these beekeepers also sell sex, receiving payments from the farmers whose crops the bees pollinate. It is exhausting work, an economic gamble and a true romance.
The author, a beekeeper who teaches writing and English at Mount Holyoke College and the University of Massachusetts, chose an ill-starred year to follow the bloom. A dread parasite, the honeybee tracheal mite, reared its microscopic head, causing some states to quarantine beekeepers. In the same year, Africanized "killer" bees first appeared in the United States. This sub-Saharan strain began its march through the Americas in 1957, when a few queens were accidentally released in Brazil. Outbreeding and displacing more profitable varieties, Africanized bees may shrink our honey industry dramatically.
This book offers quick licks -- 44 chapters in just over 200 pages -- of biography and autobiography, popular science and travel writing, the history of beekeeping and the natural history of bees. Though its stated purpose is to profile the beekeepers, Homo sapiens is less interesting here than Apis mellifera.
Mr. Whynott introduces people through their resumes -- the jobs they've worked, the places they've lived -- a method more systematic than lively. Next, he tells us the stories the beekeepers told him. His ear for speech is sharp, but he repeats anecdotes with small regard to their intrinsic interest. Most beekeepers recite the rigors of beekeeping, especially bee transportation: we learn everything that can possibly happen to an old truck and a shifting load. Though harrowing at first, these stories soon become repetitious: to learn that mechanics won't repair a truck laden with bees is interesting, but only once.
When Mr. Whynott offers his own perceptions instead of retailing other people's stories, the images are fresher. Because his mind is more interesting than his subjects', so is his experience. He sees a forklift operator "raise a pallet [of beehives] on the run, like a shortstop scooping a grounder." He watches another man grab a bee, strip the pollen from its legs, pop the pollen into his mouth and pronounce the pollen to be pine. The hum of an apiary is like that of a highway, "a light and generalized overtone mingled with close fast-driver sounds. One bee caught in my hair, zizzed like a car slipped out of gear, got free, and flew on." Here is all the vividness that the hearsay stories lack.
Though bees have been the best publicized of insects, their intricate careers still astonish us. Mr. Whynott writes finely, often lyrically, of the mating flight, the winter cluster, the swarm. He excites our wonder for the dance with which scout bees report the location of a flower -- orienting their signals to the sun even in the darkness of the hive and even, somehow, after the sun has set.
Mr. Whynott warns that harder times are coming to bees and their masters, to farmers and consumers, as the Africanized strain of bees streams north. Professional beekeepers, though, are mounting a stubborn defense, fighting the Africanization of their colonies through careful breeding. By the end of his book, Mr. Whynott finds in their romance a potential for heroism.

GRAPHIC: Photo: A beekeeper, wearing protective clothing, calms honeybees with smoke. (F. Carter Smith of The New York Times)

SECTION: Section 7; Page 7; Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1461 words

HEADLINE: Way Back Yonder in the 1980's

BYLINE: By Michael Janeway; Michael Janeway is dean of the Medill School of Journalism at Northwestern University.

 BODY:

SLEEPWALKING THROUGH HISTORY
America in the Reagan Years.
By Haynes Johnson.
Illustrated. 524 pp. New York:
W. W. Norton & Company.
$24.95. 
 This feisty chronicle of the 1980's pays tribute up front to journalists and historians who have put their stamp on other decades -- for example, Frederick Lewis Allen, whose "Only Yesterday" is a classic account of the Roaring Twenties, and Theodore H. White, whose "Making of the President" series took stock of the nation as well as its leaders in the 1960's. In Allen in particular Haynes Johnson has picked a sound model, for comparisons between the Harding-Coolidge years and the Reagan era have become too pointed to ignore.
"Now you hear a lot of jokes about Silent Cal Coolidge," President Ronald Reagan remarked in 1981, "but I think that the joke is on the people that make jokes because if you look at his record, he cut the taxes four times. We had probably the greatest growth and prosperity that we've ever known. And I have taken heed of that because if he did nothing, maybe that's the answer [for] the Federal Government."
No guile there; rather, an invitation to take the man at his word. It is the considerable virtue of "Sleepwalking Through History: America in the Reagan Years" to step back from the 1980's and frame them, if not with a formal theoretical perspective, then with comprehensiveness, bite and skill. Mr. Johnson takes Mr. Reagan and other key dramatis personae of the 80's at their words and deeds. The result is a mosaic of wretched excess, puerile fantasy, mass inattention and bills outstanding.
A respected columnist for The Washington Post, Mr. Johnson years ago developed a gift for getting outside the Beltway. His specialty has been the trend piece from around the country (he also won a Pulitzer Prize for his reporting on the civil rights confrontation in Selma, Ala., in 1965). That strength serves him well here, for "Sleepwalking Through History" includes stark sketches of the Sun Belt and Rust Belt, of Wall Street and farm country, at the start and close of the decade.
In the Rust Belt, Mr. Johnson found job applicants with college and postgraduate degrees "who falsified their academic credentials -- downward. . . . They did not want to be considered overqualified for scarce factory work." For counterpoint, the Sun Belt: "In Midland, Texas, entrepreneurs in the nation's oil production capital gathered at the Holiday Inn to celebrate Reagan's inaugural. On a buffet table, surrounded by nachos and barbecued smoky links, they placed a cutout of the Capitol dome in Washington. On it was one word: 'Ours.' "
In documentary fashion, Mr. Johnson reviews the decade's parade of folly and waste: the rise and self-immolation of the Moral Majority, the Reagan Administration's environmental delinquency and the sleaze factor, board games called Trump and Greed, savings and loan recklessness and Star Wars sci-fi, the mega-deficits and the 1987 stock market crash, the conspicuous consumption of the yuppies and the invisibility of the ghetto.
The author is frank in citing his reliance on such sources as the University of California's oral history project for insights into Mr. Reagan by his "kitchen cabinet"; on the journalists William Greider and John Brooks, among others, for their versions of the supply-side economics saga. To the efficient marshaling of such evidence and accounts Mr. Johnson adds his own telling reportage. The centerpiece of his book is his recounting of the Iran-contra scheme. He presents it as the Reagan crew's decision to "privatize their intelligence operations," which he characterizes as "a method singularly in keeping with the spirit of the eighties."
The members and staff of the joint Congressional committee that investigated the mess reveal here how deftly the perpetrators turned the day of reckoning into an anticlimax. Thus, the committee's counsel, Arthur Liman, persuaded the committee chairman, Senator Daniel Inouye, Democrat of Hawaii, that Adm. John Poindexter of the National Security Council was a by-the-numbers staff officer who "would not make a decision without telling the president," and they sought to induce truthful testimony from him by moral suasion. Summoning Admiral Poindexter to his office, Senator Inouye commenced an oration about duty, saying "it hurt him . . . to see a man in uniform taking the Fifth Amendment."
"Poindexter's face was hard to read," Mr. Johnson writes. "When it was his turn to speak, he simply said, 'I'm not going to wear my uniform.' He had been looking steadily at Inouye the entire time."
Mr. Liman's moment of truth came during a break in his questioning of Lieut. Col. Oliver North. Returning to the locked Senate Caucus Room, Mr. Liman found Colonel North "posing like a president" while committee functionaries and members of the Senate police force stood in line to have the Senate photographer take their pictures with the winsome colonel.
Mr. Johnson's sketch of the Commander in Chief is devastating, but not without measure. He cites Mr. Reagan's "genuine courage and humor" and "grace" at the time of his near assassination and the overall strength of his Presidency, "especially notable among young Americans, who saw in him their only successful presidential model and the one who repeatedly prevailed over his critics." But here too is Clark Clifford's unforgettable characterization of him as an "amiable dunce," and Representative Lee Hamilton, Democrat of Indiana, recalls a top-level White House briefing on MX missiles that the President interrupted at one point to recount "the plot from 'WarGames,' the movie. That was his only contribution."
Two quibbles: the author's reportorial travels are notable for their omission of inner cities; and one wishes so distinguished a journalist had rid himself of overuse of the passive voice.
Of Mr. Johnson's peers at work today, Garry Wills and Sidney Blumenthal have both written more probingly and thoughtfully about Mr. Reagan and the 1980's, but what makes their work so valuable is the distinctive critical apparatus with which each of them works. Haynes Johnson is more modest in his aspirations. He is a reporter and a chronicler (if an angry one), intent on getting it all down for the record. Those prudent enough to wish, after Santayana, to remember the past are in his debt for doing that so determinedly and readably.
 
CASHING IN ON PUBLIC SERVICE
 Reagan was leaving politics the way he entered it. The same wealthy Californians (among them Holmes Tuttle and Earle Jorgensen) who had purchased a private home for him to use as California's governor, later sold for a profit, had again pooled their money to purchase the Bel Air mansion and leased it to the Reagans. . . . Eighteen of these Californians contributed a reported $156,000 apiece to buy the seventy-two-hundred-square-foot property, set on one and a quarter acres and overlooking Beverly Hills and all of the Los Angeles Basin. The price was $2.5 million. By inaugural day the land value alone had appreciated to more than $3 million, and the property itself was estimated to be worth more than $5 million. Reagan had also recently completed a multimillion-dollar book deal to write his memoirs and publish a collection of his speeches and was preparing to sign an exclusive agreement with a Washington lecture bureau. (At the same time Nancy Reagan signed a $2 million book contract and was retained by the same lecture bureau.) Reagan was to be paid an estimated $50,000 for each speech inside the United States (and double that overseas), making him the highest-paid speaker in the country. For only two speeches a month he could make more than $1 million a year. This, of course, was in addition to his presidential pension of $99,500 a year for life and his annual pension as a former governor of California of $30,800. In addition, he received Secret Service protection from forty full-time agents and other security at a cost to the government estimated at $10 million annually, more than double that of other living presidents. A suite of offices atop a new thirty-four-story office building twenty minutes from his home . . . cost the government $173,000 a year to lease. From the government he also got use of a $1.25 million presidential transition fund for six months and $150,000 a year to pay staff.
All this provided more grist for his critics, who pointed out, not inaccurately, that when it came to cashing in on public service, Reagan, who more than any president in history railed against government benefits and spending, set the standard for all members of his administration. From Reaganomics to Reagabucks, one writer noted wryly. -- From "Sleepwalking Through History."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Lieut. Col. Oliver North in Washington, 1987. (Reuters)

PUB-DATE: February 24, 1991

SECTION: Section 5; Page 3; Column 1; Travel Desk

LENGTH: 1445 words

HEADLINE: PRACTICAL TRAVELER;
When an Airline Takes Flight, What Then?

BYLINE: By ERIC WEINER

 BODY:
ELISE GROSSMAN, a New York student, remembers all too well the inglorious demise of Eastern Airlines last month. She found herself stranded in West Palm Beach, Fla., her Eastern ticket worthless. "I ended up spending an extra $350 to get home," she said. "I was furious."
In the not-too-distant past, passengers chose an airline based on its schedule or its service. Today, an airline's balance sheet factors into the reservation equation. "You have to take into consideration not only flight schedules and amenities but whether the airline will be around three months from now," said David Perelman, president of D.M.S. Travel Group in New York. 
 A combination of higher fuel costs, the recession and wartime jitters means empty seats and record losses for the industry. Two airlines, Pan Am and Continental, recently filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. One other, Trans World Airlines, has failed to make a timely payment to their creditors. And, of course, Eastern Airlines stopped flying altogether last month after 63 years in business, the last two spent under the cloud of a crippling strike.
Once an airline files for Chapter 11 protection, ticket holders become creditors, along with fuel suppliers and aircraft leasing companies. Should the airline cancel all flights, your refund depends on how you paid for the ticket, what safeguards have been arranged by the bankruptcy court and what's left of the airline.
Granted, just because an airline files for bankruptcy protection doesn't necessarily mean it's about to stop flying. Continental, for one, has actually added flights since it filed. But a wise traveler will take precautions before making a reservation on a financially precarious airline.
The surest way to protect yourself is to pay for a ticket with a credit card or charge card. Although a refund is not guaranteed, most card companies will suspend the charges on your card while they go after the bankrupt airline themselves. At the very least, using a credit card buys you some time, since credit companies are legally required to suspend a questionable charge while they investigate it. Credit cards, like Visa and MasterCard, have policies similar to charge cards like American Express, but the precise rules may vary with the bank that issued the card. And while American Express will suspend a charge with only a phone call, many bank cards require written notification.
If you do pay cash for a ticket, you have to file for a refund with the bankruptcy court: a potentially time-consuming task.
Another form of protection is trip-cancellation insurance. Such policies, available from a number of insurance companies, cover all kinds of reasons for a canceled trip, such as sudden illness. If an airline or charter company should go out of business after you've purchased a ticket, the policies will make up the difference between the amount of your original ticket and a more expensive substitute one. A typical policy costs $5.50 for each $100 of coverage.
But travel insurance has some major drawbacks. Some policies must be purchased several weeks before the departure date and, of course, they won't compensate for the inconvenience of being stranded in Jakarta while you frantically search for another flight home. And just as medical insurance rarely covers a "pre-existing condition" most travel policies aren't valid if an airline had already filed for bankruptcy protection when you bought the ticket.
In hopes of winning a loyal customer, other carriers may honor tickets of a recently defunct competitor. After Eastern shut down last month, confusion was the rule at many airports. Some passengers simply handed their Eastern tickets to another airline's gate agent and boarded the plane, while others had to buy a higher priced ticket and then file for a refund from Eastern. "It was pot luck," said Nathan Devore, vice president of Rich Worldwide Travel in New York. "It depended on the ticket agents' mood, their attitude, their knowledge of the situation."
Still, most Eastern passengers were simply inconvenienced. Hoping to reassure travel agents and consumers, Eastern had set up a $50 million escrow account that guaranteed tickets. "The net result is that very few people lost money with Eastern," said Ed Perkins, editor of Consumer Reports Travel Letter.
While a traveler's money may be protected, his frequent-flier miles probably aren't. The airlines have gone to great lengths to insure that the miles are viewed in court as their property, not the passenger's. "The miles go down with the airline," said Jeff Miller, a travel lawyer. He recommends people with bonus miles on a shaky airline either use them or, if possible, transfer them to a participating foreign airline.
Shaky Bookings
Some industry experts recommend that passengers avoid booking far in advance on financially shaky airlines. For instance, America West, a struggling midsize carrier, recently announced a two-for-one special for travel as far in advance as next year. But other, stronger airlines have already matched America West's offer with similar promotions. (Of course, such a strategy may ultimately prove counterproductive, since shunning a weak airline may help lead to its demise, leaving the bigger carriers even more freedom to charge whatever fare they like.)
In today's imploding airline business, the stronger carriers sometimes have a vested interest in prolonging the lives of their weaker competitors. Sometimes, the consumer can benefit. For instance, when United Airlines bought Pan Am's routes to Heathrow Airport in London it agreed to guarantee up to $100 million worth of Pan Am's tickets should the airline stop flying. In addition, Pan Am frequent-flier miles could be redeemed on United. But the entire deal hinges on British Government approval, and negotiations between the two countries hit a snag that had not been resolved at press time.
Seeking the counsel of a reliable travel agent is always a good idea. But agents are caught in a bind between their desire to support a troubled airline -- and thus promote healthy competition -- and their obligation to steer consumers away from an airline that may evaporate at any moment. Some agents were still recommending that consumers fly Eastern right up to the day it shut down.
The American Society of Travel Agents, which represents about half the nation's agents, doesn't discourage its members from booking passengers on troubled airlines because doing so "would become a self-fulfilling prophecy," said Phil Davidoff, president of the group. "We're strong believers in the importance of competition."
Still, many travel agents are now advising passengers if an airline is flying under bankruptcy protection, and some are even requiring clients to sign a waiver, absolving the agent of any financial responsibility should the airline stop flying. At the same time, other agencies, including American Express, the nation's largest, offer no such warnings. (The company will provide information about a carrier's financial status if a client asks.) "We're seeing that consumers are more Chapter-11 indifferent" these days, said Norma Arnold, senior vice president of establishment services marketing at American Express.
It Ain't Necessarily So
Indeed, with airline bankruptcies becoming as common as delayed flights and lost bags, the words "Chapter 11" don't have the stigma they once did. Since Continental Airlines filed for bankruptcy protection (the second time in eight years), it has added three dozen flights from Newark International Airport, and the carrier recently revamped its service. "It's business as usual," said Ned Walker, a Continental spokesman, adding that the airline has not seen a drop in passengers due to its bankruptcy filing.
Still, some on Capitol Hill aren't convinced that consumers are adequately protected. Bills by Representative Sherwood L. Boehlert, Republican of New York, and Senator Nancy Landon Kassebaum, Republican of Kansas, would force the airlines to devise a plan to protect the traveling public's money. Details have yet to be worked out, but one proposal is that a surcharge of a few cents be added to each ticket, establishing a pool of money to be dispensed to passengers stranded by a bankrupt airline. "It's good for business," said Hank Price, a spokesman for Representative Boehlert. "It strengthens the whole industry."
While the bills are supported by travel agents, they are strongly opposed by the leading airlines, who feel that such legislation is, in effect, asking them to subsidize their weaker competitors. So far, the bills have made little progress.

SECTION: Section 5; Page 14; Column 1; Travel Desk

HEADLINE: Sun Valley, an American Original

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN; TIMOTHY EGAN is chief of the Seattle bureau of The New York Times.

 BODY:
CERTAINLY, there are places in the Northern Hemisphere with more flash, better snow, easier access and steeper slopes than Sun Valley, Idaho -- the granddaddy of American winter resorts. But where else can a skier find a blend of big bowls and scrubbed sky by day, and at night curl up in front of a marble fireplace a few feet away from a frame of Ernest Hemingway's last letter and a picture of Judy Garland catching a 16-inch trout? Not Colorado's Aspen or Vail. Not Park City, Utah, or Stowe, Vt. The nation's leading snow playgrounds all have their respective virtues. Most of what Sun Valley has came from nature, the rest came from Hollywood. Together, they make for an American original.
There are skiers in chartreuse outfits who think Hemingway is some sort of cologne, or an intermediate run off the No. 1 chair -- which it is. But it is those who understand what the novelist was looking for when he came to southern Idaho -- the isolation, the way the light pivots at dusk, the cottonwoods along the Big Wood River -- who return to Sun Valley no matter where the new magnets of winter may be. 
 The blessings of Sun Valley -- long, cloudless days amid the sharp walls of the Sawtooth Mountains -- can also be its curse. The area sits in the middle of a sort of weather doughnut: storms dump heavy snow on all the surrounding peaks, but tend to pass over Sun Valley. As a result, the area suffers from frequent droughts, and the last two years have been among the worst. During a visit in early February, barely more than a foot of snow covered the slopes. Typically, a good bit of snow will arrive in early December, followed by a dry spell, and then another load late in February. In between natural snowfalls, the resort relies heavily on manmade snow. But the snowmaking equipment can only cover so much terrain, so that in dry years, much of the big, south-facing bowls are unskiable.
To get around the temperamental fits of nature, Sun Valley has become, with considerable success, a four-season resort. Last summer the area seemed more crowded -- with golfers, bikers, fly-fishermen and hikers -- than it did during a visit this winter.
Created in a great burst of construction and imagination in 1936, the resort is not very old by European standards. But it has been around more than half as long as Idaho has been a state. The Shoshone and Bannock Indians wintered in the valley, which, despite its altitude of nearly 6,000 feet above sea level, boasts a mild climate, with hot springs bubbling up around the breach cut by the Big Wood River. Miners chased the Indians off their land, scrounged silver and galena ore from the mountains, and then left when the strikes went dry and the economy went bust. They were followed by sheepherders, many of them from the Basque provinces of Spain, who grazed their herds in the high meadows of the Sawtooths, then shipped them by rail.
Without the railroad, there would have been no resort. W. Averell Harriman, the diplomat, former New York governor and an American aristocrat if ever there was one, was born in 1891 into a Union Pacific Railroad fortune. By age 18, he was on the railroad's board of directors, and looking around for something more to do with the company's tracks into the West. Harriman was greatly influenced by the Swiss resorts at St. Moritz, site of the 1928 Olympics, and at Gstaad. His idea was to build something of similiar grandeur in America. In 1932, he hired Felix Schaffgotsch, an Austrian count, and sent him off on a journey to find a place for the perfect American ski resort. The setting had to be pristine, with high mountains, ample snow and good weather. And, of course, it had to be close to a Union Pacific rail line.
The count visited Mount Rainier near Seattle and Mount Hood near Portland, Ore. -- dismissing them both for their excessive snow and glaciation, and proximity to big population centers. Then he trudged through Utah, Colorado and Wyoming. Aspen he liked, but he thought its base altitude of more than 8,000 feet would be too hard on the sea-level-dwelling Easterners who would be the resort's primary customers. At last, an Idaho highway employee lured him into Ketchum, the old mining town and sheep center in Sun Valley. During the count's visit, it snowed heavily at night, and was bright and blue by day. The slopes were steep and open.
After three days, the count wired Harriman from Sun Valley: "This combines more delightful features than any place I have seen in the United States, Switzerland or Austria for a winter resort." Harriman, after a visit, shared the count's enthusiasm. He purchased a large section of the valley for $10 an acre. In the field rose a $1.5 million lodge; it looks like wood, but it was cast in concrete, from cedar beams that left a grain imprint, then painted dark brown. On nearby Dollar Mountain, the smaller of two skiable areas in Sun Valley, Harriman built the world's first chairlift, a single-seat lift patterned after a hoist used to haul bananas into ships' holds.
He had his resort, at the end of a Union Pacific Rail line, but he needed people. Idaho is among the least populous states. Hollywood was the key. In 1936, Sun Valley's first year in operation, pictures of Errol Flynn, Clark Cable, Claudette Colbert and others frolicking at the new resort flooded newspapers -- a campaign created by Steve Hannagan, a public relations whiz who launched Miami Beach. Sun Valley was an instant success and was kept that way by movies like "Sun Valley Serenade" with Sonja Henie in 1941.
Harriman died in 1986, at the age of 95. The family sold the resort in 1964, yet they continued to visit, staying in their cottages next to the Lodge. Harriman spent part of his last winter in the valley. Pictures of him, a tall and attractive man, are everywhere, posing with glamorous women or looking over the edge of his skis from a cliff.
Although the valley has changed dramatically over the years, with excessive condominium development and sprawling housing tracts, the resort exudes a timeless quality. Harriman's original hotel, the Sun Valley Lodge, has more than 500 rooms, a large, outdoor pool, and lobby space rich with antiques and windows overlooking the outdoor skating rink. One organization, the Sun Valley Company, runs the Lodge, a smaller hotel called the Sun Valley Inn, condominiums, a retail mall, and operates the lift concession on Bald Mountain.

WITH the exception of small, beginner runs on Dollar Mountain, all of the skiing is done on Baldy, as it's known, a 9,150-foot mountain with more than 1,300 acres of groomed runs and trails. The skiing area is about a mile from the resort village, reachable by a free shuttle bus that operates during daylight hours. There is no night skiing on Baldy. With 13 chairlifts, including 3 high-speed quad lifts, long lines are a rarity. One chair, the Challenger lift, has a vertical rise of 3,144 feet.
When the mountain has ample snow, it seems to live up to the early booster slogan: "God's own choice for a ski resort." The view from the top, at the endless fangs of the Sawtooth Range, is wonderful, free of the urban smog that sometimes creeps up to the skies of such places as Snowbird, Utah, and Mammoth Mountain, California. There are no great cliffs, or sudden drops, no long flat stretches. Instead, runs spill off in gradual descents, the south-facing ones more open and challenging, the other sides evenly groomed and with swaths cut through the trees. Most are intermediate.
Without adequate snow cover, the bowls are closed and skiers are restricted to the runs facing north and east. When the snow-making machines are running, they are noisy, breaking the still of an otherwise fine winter day. Four restaurants are open on the mountain. The coziest, with a huge stone fireplace, ancient wood skis crossed above the mantle, and good hot chili, is the Roundhouse, at the base of the Christmas Chairlift. Dining tables on an outdoor deck look down at the valley, nearly 2,000 feet below.
Twenty-five miles of cross-country ski trails, manicured and marked by degree of difficulty, begin just a few steps from the Sun Valley Lodge. Some of the trails are tame and predictable; others lead into the woods, offering a sense of adventure and isolation. For more open skiing, the Sawtooth National Recreation Area, north of Ketchum, is full of trails and meadows.
Apres-ski, even in early afternoon, the choices are considerable. Horse-pulled sleigh rides glide over the snow-topped golf course or through hayfields. The ice-skating rink behind the Lodge is large and fast. The big circular pool next to the building, heated to 105 degrees, is a cocktail-hour favorite.
The Lodge Dining Room, designed more than 50 years ago as the elegant centerpiece of the resort, is of the Big Night Out dining school: low lights, chandeliers, crisp and bow-tied waiters, music for dancing between courses or cocktails. Idaho wildlife -- venison in wine sauce, broiled duck, stuffed quail -- are favorites.
Depending on the visitor's view of hunting, the numerous pictures of Gary Cooper and Hemingway bagging game either enhance or deter appetite. (A simple memorial to Hemingway is next to Trail Creek not far from the golf course. He is buried next to his wife, Mary, in Ketchum's only cemetery.)
Where once this resort would have been considered a singles playground, pioneered by Harriman himself, who married three times, it has followed the demographic trends in recent years and is now trying to attract families. At most of the hotels and condominiums in the valley, up to two children, no older than 17, stay free and get free lift tickets if registered with their parents. The offer is not good for peak periods, such as Christmas and spring break.
Ketchum, the town that preceded Sun Valley, at the base of Bald Mountain, has undergone considerable growing pains in the last 10 years. Such places as the Casino Club, a bar where local people used to play poker and drink whisky from shot glasses, are surrounded by more than a dozen art galleries and boutiques. Still, unlike Aspen, where fur coats are ubiquitous and hamburgers can cost $10 or more, Ketchum is not pretentious.
Celebrities still abound. Clint Eastwood has a house in the valley, and Bruce Willis is completing his home, south of Ketchum near Hailey. Nobody seems to make much of a fuss over them, with an occasional exception. Residents are still abuzz over a recent appearance in a local bar by three of the movie world's biggest musclemen -- Eastwood, Charles Bronson and Arnold Schwartzenegger -- who walked in together, cutting a swath through the crowded lounge. If Harriman were still alive, he might have been accused of staging the event himself.
 
STOPS ON A VISIT TO THE VALLEY
 
Getting There
Train service to Ketchum has long since ended. Two airlines, Horizon Air and SkyWest, a commuter carrier of Delta, fly directly to Hailey, 11 miles south of Sun Valley, from Salt Lake City, Boise, Idaho, or Seattle. Driving from Boise to Ketchum, on good roads, takes about two and a half hours. There is free bus service throughout the Sun Valley area, from 7:30 A.M. to 11:30 P.M.
 
Hotels
Standard rooms at the Sun Valley Lodge begin at $125 a night and go up to $275 for parlor suites. Children stay free during selected parts of the year. Rooms at the nearby Sun Valley Inn begin at $100, rising to $190 for a family suite. Condominiums are from $115 a night for a studio to $390 for four bedrooms. Reservations and information: 800-786-8259.
The other big resort in the valley is Elkhorn, (800) 635-9356, near the base of Dollar Mountain. Open the year round, Elkhorn is built around a golf course and tennis courts spread over 3,000 acres. Standard room rates begin at $78, a deluxe goes for $138. Condominiums begin at $118 and go up to $258 for four bedrooms.
The Tyrolean Lodge, (800) 333-7912, run by the Best Western Company, is close to the ski runs, at the outskirts of Ketchum. Rooms with a view of Bald Mountain cost around $70.
 
Dining
The Lodge Dining Room, (208) 622-2150, overlooking the outdoor skating rink from the second floor of the Sun Valley Lodge, has not tinkered with its half-century-old formula much. Fish and game, heavy on French sauces, are the menu highlights, with a good wine list. Dinner is $80 to $100 for two, with wine. There's music for dancing.
The Sawtooth Mountains are the last place one would expect to find fresh seafood, but the Saltwater Grill, in Ketchum, (208) 726-5083, has defied logistics and presents a wide-ranging fresh list every night, weather permitting. Oysters, clams and mussels are available. Dinners of salmon, scallops, yellow fin tuna or shellfish run $50 to $70 for two, with wine.
Usually packed, and a bit loud is the Sawtooth Club, (208) 726-5233, on Main Street in Ketchum. The first floor is cozy, jammed with people milling around the big fireplace. The second floor is quieter. Specialties here are lamb, steaks and prime rib, cooked over mesquite grills. Dinner for two with wine is about $45.
 
Night and Day
 Two nightspots are always popular. Whiskey Jacques, on Main Street in Ketchum, has live music, and attracts a generally younger crowd. The Fabulous Vuarnettes, an all-female cabaret-type show, plays Thursday, Friday and Saturday nights at the Elkhorn Resort's Showplace Saloon.
As for the slopes, the price of a day's all-lifts ticket has been dropped to $34 this season because of reduced snow cover. -- T. E.

LENGTH: 2713 words

HEADLINE: Miami's Caribbean Enclaves

BYLINE: By JOANN BIONDI; JOANN BIONDI is editor of the "Insight Guide to Miami," scheduled to be published in March.

 BODY:
LIKE most ethnic enclaves of big cities elsewhere, Miami's Little Havana and Little Haiti are classic juxta positions of immigrant optimism and inner-city decay. Simmering with promise for a paradise found, they are America's modern melting pot, the new Ellis Island. In both the food is saturated with spices, the music hip-grinding good and the people resourceful and proud. For the tourist, a foray into these neighborhoods offers an intimate and eye-opening encounter with cultures determined to maintain the traditions of their homelands.
But unlike the pastel-pretty Art Deco district of south Miami Beach, Little Havana and Little Haiti are not tourist destinations of carefree abandon. They are real city neighborhoods with real city problems, and crime is a reality. During the day both areas are safe because the streets are filled with people. At night the main artery of Little Havana warrants no worry but meandering down the side streets should be avoided. The same holds true for Little Haiti: evening escapades should be limited to a particular restaurant or nightclub excursion. 
 Little Havana has for decades been the initial resting spot for Cuban refugees. In the 1960's several hundred thousand Cubans fleeing the Communist takeover settled in the city. These early immigrants, who were the bulk of Cuba's entrepreneurial and professional sectors, used their skills to transform the dying areas that were once known as Riverside and Shenandoah into a bustling exile center. Of the approximately two million people that now make up what is called Greater Miami, over 500,000 of them are of Cuban descent.
Today Little Havana remains an immigrant's dream -- Spanish is the language of choice, home-cooked food is abundant and the network for finding work is easily accessible. Catholic shrines decorate the front lawns of neatly painted houses as roosters scurry about in backyards. Salsa music, which permeates the evening air, seems an integral part of the collective unconscious. The neighborhood is 27 blocks long and 24 blocks wide. The main street that cuts through the heart of the area is Calle Ocho, or, as Anglos call it, Eighth Street. Between 27th and First Avenues on Eighth Street you can find just about every aspect of Cuban culture common to Havana in the 1950's.
Tiny cafeterias that sell cafe Cubano, thimble-sized cups of coffee that are served sweet and swampy and absolutely fresh, can be found on each block. At the McDonald's restaurant you can even order a cup of cafe Cubano to go with your Huevo McMuffin. Shops that specialize in lace and taffeta dresses for quinces, parties for girls' 15th birthdays, buzz with mothers shopping for the best. Magic shops sell comical tricks for adults and pinatas, paper animals stuffed with toys, for children.
Botanicas, pharmacies that cater to practitioners of the Afro-Caribbean religions of santeria and voodoo, are busy with serious shoppers. Although they are now found throughout the city, botanicas are most common in Little Havana and Little Haiti. Their shelves are stocked with serenity salves, black candles, fake monkey heads, herb extracts, virility pills and voodoo dolls. Visitors are welcome but making fun of the merchandise should be avoided.
For a nostalgic experience of Havana circa 1955, stop in at the Credito cigar factory on Eighth Street near 11th Avenue. The largest factory producing hand-made cigars in Miami, El Credito was founded in Cuba in 1907 and still has dozens of workers who hand wrap, roll and press those potent-smelling stogies.
Surprisingly, Cuban food has a cold-weather heartiness about it and usually comes with a good dousing of garlic juice. Meals often feature pork and beef, with plenty of rice and beans and fried bananas or yucca on the side. Along with the many restaurants and sandwich shops that draw outsiders to the neighborhood, there are several ice-cream parlors, like King's Cream near 18th Avenue, that specialize in exotic flavors of coconut, mango and mamey -- a rich, sweet tropical fruit. Bakeries sell flaky guava pastries and cream-soaked sweet cakes for a treat. Gurapo, pure sugar cane juice, is sold fresh.
For some campy live theater with a political slant, try one of the weekend shows at Teatro Marti or Bellas Artes. Both offer performances in Spanish starring local Cuban actors in shows that range from Shakespearean dramas to a humorous farce about the most hated man in the neighborhood -- Fidel Castro.
 CALLE OCHO is where Little Havana holds an annual Sunday street party that has become an outrageous afternoon bacchanalia. It is billed as the largest Hispanic street party in the United States. The party is the culmination of a 10-day event known as Carnaval Miami, which will run this year from March 1 to 10. The March 10 party, called simply Calle Ocho, winds its way down 23 blocks of Eighth Street. Other events in the festival, which celebrates the city's Hispanic heritage, include a masquerade ball, a Latin and jazz concert at the Orange Bowl, a parade and an eight-kilometer run.
At the corner of Eighth Street and Cuban Memorial Boulevard (13th Avenue) stands the Bay of Pigs Monument, which pays tribute to the men who lost their lives in the foiled invasion of Cuba in 1961. Here, young schoolchildren come to place flowers and say a prayer for a homeland they never knew. Nearby is Maximo Gomez Park, locally known as Domino Park. Every day the fenced-in courtyard fills up by about 10 A.M. with domino players who take part in games that often erupt into arm-flailing arguments. A park official enforces a custom that restricts admittance to men over 55, but tourists are welcomed in for a look.
The lively conversations in the park, as in most of Little Havana, are often highly political and passionate. Anti-Castroism, anti-Communism and anti-anything-non-Republican is the popular feeling. Recently, Miami commissioners listened to developers who proposed a name change from Little Havana to the Latin Quarter. The meeting erupted in pandemonium when Little Havana Cubans declared the proposal an action instigated "by Communist pigs."
This territorial outlook of Cubans for Little Havana is warranted. At Woodlawn Park Cemetery on Eighth Street and 32d Avenue, three former presidents of Cuba are buried as is the Nicaraguan dictator Anastasio Somoza Debayle.
Toward the east end of Little Havana, on the banks of the Miami River, is Jose Marti Park.
NAMED for the revered Cuban writer and patriot, the 10-acre park has an elaborate maze of red-brick walkways that lead down to the river, where rusty old freighters piled high with bicycles await their journeys to Haiti. Many of them are believed stolen from the streets of Miami, where bicyle thievery is rampant. A dramatic view of the Miami skyline serves as a backdrop. The park is full of schoolchildren in the daytime and poses no threat to tourists. At night its character becomes slightly menacing, and the park should be avoided.
Across the street from the park, surrounded by a high wrought-iron fence, is a cluster of historic wooden buildings that stand as a harbinger of hope of good things to come to the neighborhood. The Miami River Inn, which opened last April, is the personal mission of a Miami preservationist, Sallye Jude, who believes the rundown area of east Little Havana will soon see a gentrification of sorts and serve as a center for cultural and heritage-based tourism in Miami.
The yellow and green two-story buildings, which were built in 1904, have 41 rooms full fluffy pastel fabrics and authentic antiques. Frosted-glass street lamps line the property, which is under constant surveillance by private guards. Although surrounded by apartments that are in less than good condition, the inn can serve as a comfortable home base for exploring Little Havana while offering an historic environment not common in Miami.
North of Little Havana is Miami's other ethnic enclave. While the charms of Little Haiti may be a bit more subtle than those of Little Havana, the neighborhood is well worth a visit. Like the vivid scenes in a primitive Haitian painting, brilliant hues brighten up these inner city streets. Buildings are painted the primary colors of blue, red and yellow. Women wearing colorful cotton dresses saunter to the market balancing straw baskets atop their heads. Children jump rope while counting in Creole as the energetic rhythms of Haitian music blares from boom-box stereos.
Many having fled their poverty-stricken homeland in leaky wooden boats, Miami's Haitians, estimated to total about 50,000, have none of the economic clout that the Cuban community has, but is just as hard-working and hopeful about the possibilities of a better life. When Marjorie Vincent, the daughter of Haitian-born parents, was crowned Miss America last September, Little Haiti bubbled with a joyous commotion -- the American dream was now theirs to behold.
The main commercial artery of Little Haiti's approximately 200 square blocks lies along N.E. Second Avenue. At the intersection of N.E. 54th Street is the Haiti-Miami Market where you'll find the Haitian delicacy of fresh goat heads along with the essential rice and beans sold from huge wooden bins. At the Botanica d'Haiti across the street, the sweet tang of incense hangs in the air and leaves from the Jericho plant are soaked in a bowl for good luck. Special elixirs are stored in the back behind a beaded curtain that clatters in the breeze.
The colorful focal point of Little Haiti these days is the Caribbean Marketplace at 59th Street.The structure, which this month was awarded the 1991 National Honor Award by the American Institute of Architects, was designed by a Haitian-born Miami architect, Charles Harrison Pawley, to resemble the Iron Market of Port-au-Prince and spur tourism in the area. With its gabled tin roof that glistens in the sun and its colors of yellow, blue, green and orange, it stands as a spectacle of grandeur among shabby neighboring storefronts. Although maintained in tiptop condition, most of its airy stalls have not yet been rented. A few vendors are selling handcrafts, produce, records and clothing. A United Nations development group is trying to set up an organization that would import goods from Haiti to be sold at the market.
A few blocks away is the Toussaint Louverture Elementary School, named after the Haitian hero who led a peasant uprising against the French. Pierre Toussaint's descendants live in a home nearby. Les Cousins Book and Record Store, near 79th Street, has the largest assortment of Haitian compas, Guadeloupean zouk and calypso in Miami, along with a fair selection of Haitian paintings and wood carvings. Although many accomplished artists live in the area, there are few places in Little Haiti that sell good quality Haitian art because most local Haitians would not buy it and few tourists ever visit the neighborhood.
On Saturday street-corner vendors set up impromptu markets in various places and the action resembles the theatrical haggling of an outdoor Caribbean market. On Sunday much of the Haitian community goes to the Church of Notre Dame for an early morning mass. Women sing in the choir as little boys wearing high-collar Haitian bow ties sit still through it all. A local band provides African rhythms that merge with French melodies and the entire congregation joins in.

 THE restaurants of Little Haiti are small and rustic and offer inexpensive meals of traditional Haitian cuisine. Griot (fried pork), lambi (stewed conch) and rum-tainted oxtail stew are classics. At most area restaurants you can almost always find Haitians gathering for a dinner and a discussion on the politics of their country. And Little Haiti nightclubs that pulsate with live music have become trendy dance spots for young in-the-know Miamians.
One of the most delightful aspects of a visit to Little Haiti or Little Havana is the sensation of being totally enveloped by the Caribbean cultures of these two island nations. You are bemused by the menus, you fumble with the languages and instantly feel as if you are the foreigner.
 
AROUND LITTLE HAVANA
The neighborhood lies within the area of N.W. Seventh Street to the north, S.W. 17th Street to the south, S.W. First Avenue to the east and S.W. 27th Avenue to the west. The annual Calle Ocho street festival is scheduled for March 10. More information: 644-8888; the area code for Miami is 305.
 
Getting Around
The Historical Museum of Southern Florida (375-1625) will offer two walking tours of Little Havana this year, on March 9 (covering the area's western part) and April 20 (covering the eastern part). Other tours may be added. The tours, conducted by a local historian, Dr. Paul George, cost $13 a person and begin at 10 A.M.
 
Places to Stay
Miami River Inn, 118 S.W. South River Drive (325-0045), is an historic bed and breakfast inn with a Jacuzzi and pool. Rooms are decorated with antiques and local memorabilia. Most have private bathrooms. Rates for a double room with breakfast are $60 to $80 a night.
 
Places to Eat
Calle Ocho has dozens of dining establishments that range from mom-and-pop cafeterias to elegant lace-tablecloth restaurants. Many tend to be loud and colorful, especially on weekends, when entire families gather for a meal. All serve very large portions.
Versailles, 3555 S.W. Eighth Street (444-0240), is the quintessential Cuban experience. Crystal chandeliers, wall-to-wall mirrors and a wonderfully gaudy atmosphere. Try some fried plantain chips, pork chunks in garlic-laden mojo sauce and a pitcher of sangria. Open for breakfast, lunch and dinner. Dinner for two with wine about $25.
La Esquina de Tejas, 101 S.W. 12th Avenue (545-5341), still boasts about the day Ronald Reagan stopped in for a bite to eat while on the campaign trail. Meals are home-cooked hearty with a menu that changes daily. Delicious black bean soup and traditional picadillo, a ground beef dish with green olives served on a bed of rice. Lunch and dinner $20 for two with wine. Centro Vasco, 2235 S.W. Eighth Street (643-9606), is a local gathering spot for successful Cuban immigrants. Open for lunch and dinner, the atmosphere is elegant and the clientele always well-dressed. Specialties are more Spanish than Cuban, but delicious nonetheless. Meals range from $30 to $55 for two with wine.
La Carreta, 3632 S.W. Eighth Street (444-7501), is open 24 hours and has become a Little Havana institution. It is a great late-night place for a medianoche, a small Cuban sandwich at $3.35 that is made with tidbits of pork, cheese and beef in a soft, round egg-rich roll that is pressed under a hot grill till cheese oozes out the sides.
 
Theaters
Teatro Marti, 420 S.W. Eighth Avenue (545-7866). Shows Friday and Saturday at 9 P.M., Sunday at 5 and 9 P.M. Tickets $13.
Bellas Artes, 2173 S.W. Eighth Street (325-0515). Shows Friday at 9 P.M. ($12), Saturday at 8:30 and midnight ($15), Sunday 3 and 9:15 P.M. ($12). J. B.
 
AROUND LITTLE HAITI
The district lies within 79th street to the north, 46th street to the south, Biscayne Boulevard to the east and I-95 to the west.
 
Shopping
Caribbean Marketplace, 5927 N.E. Second Avenue (758-8708). Open Tuesday to Thursday from 10:30 A.M. to 7 P.M.; Friday and Saturday from 10:30 A.M. to 9 P.M.; Sunday 10:30 A.M. to 5 P.M.
 
Places to Eat
Palmistes, 6820 N.E. Second Avenue (759-8527) attracts local Haitians who come for a good meal and local gossip. A plate of griot with rice and beans and a West Indian beer can all be had for less than $8. Live music weekend nights.
Chez Moy, 1 N.W. 54th Street (756-7540), is one of the more upscale spots in Little Haiti. It offers spicy seafood Creole dishes such as succulent chicken and okra and an assortment of Haitian specialties for lunch and dinner. Prices from $15 to $30 for two with wine.
Obsession, 69 N.E. 79th Street (756-7575), next door to the Cordon Bleu restaurant, is one of the hottest nightclubs in Miami. Haitians flock to the club on weekends to hear the best Haitian bands in the city.
 Open Friday, Saturday and Sunday from 10 P.M. to 3 A.M. Cover charge varies from $8 to $10. -- J. B.

HEADLINE: CORRESPONDENT'S CHOICE;
In Chile, a Rural Hacienda, Family Style

BYLINE: By SHIRLEY CHRISTIAN; SHIRLEY CHRISTIAN, former chief of The Times's Buenos Aires bureau, is now based in San Salvador as chief of the Central America bureau.

 BODY:
ON awakening in an antique bed and gazing up at what must be 20-foot-high ceilings in Hacienda los Lingues, I told myself that the vast adobe house and its surrounding 10,000 acres proved that there had been a time when foreign correspondents were properly appreciated. The hacienda, now a guesthouse and working farm 75 miles south of Santiago, was the gift of Carlos V of Spain to a man who chronicled the advance of the conquistadors through the southern reaches of the New World in the first half of the 16th century.
German Claro Lira and his wife, Maria Elena Lyon de Claro, who emerged into the garden to greet their arriving guests, are the modern-day lord and lady of the manor, which has been passed down through Mr. Claro's family since the land was granted to Juan Jufre y Montero del Aguila in 1545. 
 "This is a family that has never had a lot of money but has always had beautiful homes," Mrs. Claro told me, giving a clue as to why Los Lingues began inviting paying guests into its well-worn splendor 10 years ago.
Set in a rich agricultural valley a two-hour drive from Santiago along the four-lane Pan American Highway, Los Lingues -- named for a Chilean tree -- is what she describes as "a place to learn to relax, to read, listen to music, look at the birds, take walks. Most guests tell us the hardest thing to get used to here is the quiet."
This is a place where peacocks roam free in the patio between the long wings of the main house, where you may eat on a table set under the trees or in the cellar near the wine or in the ornate main dining room with antique French crystal and porcelain.
It is also a working farm, where visitors are free to visit the large fruit and vegetable operation or take in one of the auctions of the Aculeo horses that Mr. Claro breeds. Some families hold reunions or observe anniversaries here, and corporations send their top executives to the hacienda for a few days of deep thought and planning.
The most serious exertion, and worth doing, is a horse ride. On a sunny morning in early summer -- summer is December into March in the southern hemisphere -- I rode up into the Andes foothills that begin just behind the farm buildings with Juan Alvarez, one of the handlers who work with Mr. Claro.
Although nearly 3,000 miles long, Chile is never more than about 200 miles wide and at this point the land mass covers only about 80 miles between the Pacific Ocean and the Argentine border, defined by the Andes Mountains. Although farther to the north the Andes form towering peaks that reach above 20,000 feet, in the area of Los Lingues and farther south they are wider but not so high.
Juan Alvarez assured me that for those with stamina it was possible to go up and over the hills and mountains all the way to the border, a distance of about 30 miles from the farm. But I was content with the view across the valley filled with fruit trees and grain fields and with a taste of the crisp, dry mountain air.
Mr. Claro claims his Aculeos, which now number about 150, are the best horses in South America and traces their bloodlines back to the Moors, who took the ancestors of the Aculeos to Spain in the eighth century. Used for sporting competitions throughout South America, they bring $10,000 to $20,000 at auction.
The slightly stocky Aculeos are described by Mr. Claro as first cousins of the Lippizaners of Vienna's Spanish Riding School. The blood link seems obvious in the light gray coloring that is common among the Aculeos. Many also have a black stripe down the center of their backs. However, Aculeos also come in almost any other color.
On weekends, cowboys -- known as huasos in Chile -- lead the Aculeos through displays of fancy footwork in a corral beside the stables.
In addition, on special occasions or for groups that have made reservations, there are shows by Chilean folk dancers and wine tastings. The Claros have drawn up plans for tennis courts and a swimming pool, which they hope to have functioning by the next South American summer.
The senior Claros live at the hacienda year round. Mr. Claro runs the farm with its nearly 300 workers, and Mrs. Claro oversees a staff of 30 at the guesthouse. German, their older son, runs the office in Santiago, often coming to the farm on weekends.
The main house of Los Lingues, with its two-foot-thick adobe walls, is basically as it was remodeled 200 years ago, with later alterations for plumbing and electricity, plus restoration after the 1985 earthquake. A small part of the house dates from about 100 years earlier, and the family chapel, available for weddings, was built in 1650 and is the oldest part of the hacienda.
Mr. Claro recalled that during his childhood and youth, the family lived primarily in Santiago and used the hacienda as a summer and weekend house. But it was falling into disrepair because of its size and the cost of maintenance. When the property passed to his generation, his siblings were not interested in sharing the upkeep, so he took it over. In 1966, he began restoration, and in 1981, after going through a battle over agrarian reform and a national economic depression, opened it to the public.

EACH of the 16 rooms and suites -- 12 in the main house, 4 in an adjacent house -- is an individual experience. Heated by wood-burning stoves during the winter -- sweet smelling eucalyptus logs are stacked outside the door -- rooms in the main house are furnished with antiques that have come to rest in Los Lingues over a century or more. There is likely to be Champagne or a bowl of fruit waiting on a wide window ledge or atop an antique dresser. Rooms in the guesthouse are furnished more rustically but have modern bathrooms.
Much of the furniture, like a china cabinet in the main dining room, came from Paris. Some favorite dinner plates were made in 1867 in France, but the label is too faded to reveal the maker. The silverware shows years of family use. Much of the crystal is Baccarat.
The silver roosters in the center of the dining table are said to have been stolen by Chileans when they marched on Lima, the capital of neighboring Peru, during the War of the Pacific in 1879.
Lunch at Los Lingues, normally served on wooden tables in the wine cellar, is informal and features typical Chilean rural dishes, like Mrs. Claro's recipe for pastel de choclo, a casserole combining corn, chopped beef and chicken.
At dinner -- at 9 o'clock -- the Claros join their guests around the formal dining table for a meal that is usually Continental with Chilean touches. The main course the night I stayed there was corvina, a fish common in the South Pacific waters along the Chilean coast, done in a fine herb sauce, accompanied by white and red Chilean wines, which are ranked among the world's finest. Dessert, fruit from the surrounding fields, was served on the remaining plates of a set of French porcelain that was largely destroyed when a cabinet fell in the last earthquake.
 
BEING A GUEST AT A HACIENDA
 
Getting There
Los Lingues is 75 miles south of Santiago on the Pan American Highway in the vicinity of Pelequen, then 3 miles east on a gravel road. It can be reached by car, rented at the Santiago airport, or with Executive Limousine Service, 2937 Avenida Vitacura, Santiago, which takes passengers from the airport to Los Lingues in sedans for about $100 each way, plus tax, or in a bar-equipped Lincoln Town Car for about $200 each way. The phone number, dialed from the United States, is (011-56-2) 232-8908.
 
Rates and Information
An overnight stay at Los Lingues ranges from $90 to $360 a person, depending on the type of accommodation -- suite or room -- and number of meals. The rate is the same for single or double occupancy. Breakfast is American style. An hour's horseback ride with a guide is included in the daily rate. An 18 percent tax is added to all bills.
Visitors not staying overnight pay $44 a person for a tour of the house and stables, a horse show and lunch with wine. Tax and transportation are extra. A wine-tasting session is offered for an additional $18.
The office of Los Lingues in Santiago can be reached from the United States by dialing(011-56-2) 223-3518 or (011-56-2) 225-0838. It can arrange transportation by auto, limousine or minibus. -- S. C.

HEADLINE: Perspectives: Manufacturing Zones;
Cracking the Straitjacket on Expansions

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER

 BODY:
THIS year will be a good one for turtles, says Marc Beige. His family-owned business, Rubie's Costume Company, makes costumes of all sorts, not to mention masks, wigs, carnival heads and other holiday paraphernalia. The popularity of teen-age Ninja mutant turtles suggests that turtle outfits will be a big item for Halloween.
That could also be good news for the Richmond Hill section of Queens, where the main Rubie's plant is a beehive of cutting and sewing activity under the Jamaica Avenue el station at 120th Street. Mannequins attired as witches and Draculas and clowns glare down at visitors to the first-floor retail shop. But the real action is backstage. About 200 production people toil on four floors of a 50,000-square-foot building. 
 Not enough space, Rubie's decided in 1986. It took three years, but last December the company's site and other land in the vicinity was rezoned to allow a far higher density -- a floor area ratio (F.A.R.) of five, meaning five square feet of space for every square foot of land, instead of the one F.A.R. of the existing zone. By that time Rubie's had leased a building in Jamaica to fulfill part of its need for expansion space.
Nevertheless, the Rubie's experience directs attention to one of New York City's perennially knotty zoning issues -- the need of small manufacturing companies, often in Queens, Brooklyn or the Bronx, to provide themselves with expansion space.
Even when their buildings are in manufacturing zones, residential neighbors are fearful of traffic build-up and other problems. Their objections tend to restict the modest rezonings that would permit as-of-right expansions.
There is no doubt of the eagerness of most city and borough officials to support these expansions when neighborhoods don't object. In the Rubie's Costume case, the Department of City Planning considered higher density so appropriate that it took advantage of the initial application to propose a wider-scale rezoning.
The planners proposed that about 218,000 square feet of manufacturing land in a triangular area off Jamaica Avenue, including the 33,000-square-foot Rubie's lot, be included in the rezoning.
The rezoning was eventually cut back to 118,000 square feet. Representatives of Community Board 9 in Queens were unwilling to open the door too widely to as-of-right development.
But in the end the community and Borough President Claire Shulman were supportive. The cost to the applicant in fees and studies was about $100,000.
In 1986, the city provided specifically for an industrial-use special permit, intended to allow a shortcut to small expansions of industrial uses. Applications are made to the Board of Standards and Appeals. But these permits are available only for expansions of up to 2,500 square feet, or 45 percent of additional floor area up to 10,000 square feet, whichever is greater. Many companies need more new space than that.
The underlying zoning problem is that floor-area ratios are so restrictive in light-manufacturing zones that even modest expansions or additions are usually problematic in older buildings. In New York City there are plenty of those.
The most common light-manufacturing zone is M-1-1. It permits only a 1 F.A.R. as of right. Many older buildings already exceed that density. The M-1-1 zones are usually found near residential districts.
AS much as 80 percent of the land zoned for manufacturing in Queens, Brooklyn and the Bronx is believed to be in the M-1-1 category -- much of it near mass transportation. Economic development officials say, for example, that there are many small knitwear enterprises in the Ridgewood section of Queens that cannot expand even modestly because of this zoning.
"We have never solved the problem of on-site expansion," said Kenneth Wallach, land-use director of the city's Office of Business Development. On-site expansions are usually what serve small manufacturing businesses most. And most manufacturing in New York City is done by small businesses.
Communities like to see applications approved on a case-by-case basis. That introduces issues of time, cost and uncertainty that are often sufficient to untrack manufacturing expansions before they start. The more successful the company, the more likely that success will force it to move.
In the Department of City Planning a broad study of manufacturing zones across the city has been launched under the direction of Eric Kober, director of housing and economic development. It is intended to provide a policy direction for matters that move through the land-use review process and is to be completed by the end of the year.
Important as such studies may be, they will not address the immediate problems of the small companies. Their usual approach is to seek a variance from the Board of Standards and Appeals. This typically costs about $30,000 in fees and comes more readily than an areawide rezoning, if it comes at all. But the applicant must be able to meet several findings, including economic hardship and the absence of adverse neighborhood impact.
Tax incentives for these industrial expansions are not lacking. Under the Industrial and Commercial Incentives Program, renewed for a year by the City Council in January, companies outside central Manhattan get a significant exemption from property taxes attributable to the assessed value of the improvement -- 100 percent for 13 years, phasing out over the subsequent nine years at a rate of 10 percent a year.
As for Rubie's, economic conditions in the costume market make it uncertain now when the expansion will go forward, or how large it will be. Its current facilities on the 33,000 square-foot Richmond Hill site add up to 52,000 square feet, including 45,000 square feet in an existing five-story building.
The original plan was to construct a six-story addition at the rear, demolishing a small portion of the existing building and winding up with a total of 130,000 square feet. Current plans are more modest: a six-story addition that involves demolition of a section of the current building. It will give the company a net addition of 40,000 square feet, doubling the present capacity.
This will mean about a one-third gain in jobs in Richmond Hill, said Mr. Beige. The company also has facilities in Jamaica and in Nassau County. It began as a novelty store on Woodhaven Boulevard in Queens in 1950.
ACCORDING to Sheldon Lobel, the lawyer who represented Rubie's in the rezoning action, a traffic study done to support the application showed that more than 80 percent of the workers at the Richmond Hill plant use mass transportation to get to work. The presence of older manufacturing buildings close to mass transit strengthens the case for areawide rezoning to raise floor-area ratios in manufacturing districts. The M-1-4 districts, for example, allows a 2 FAR, but it is infrequently mapped.
Mr. Lobel said that the Planning Department's positive reception to the Rubie's application encouraged the company to seek a rezoning rather than a variance.
Another company weighing these issues at present is Quality Braid, 50 years in New York City and described by its lawyer, Scott Mollen, partner in the firm of Graubard Mollen Horowitz Pomeranz & Shapiro, as the largest sequin manufacturer in the country. Quality Braid is in a one-story building at 34-20 45th Street in Long Island City. It employs 350 people there.
The company needs to expand. One possibility is to add a floor, about doubling its space. That would require a rezoning. Mr. Mollen has been talking to officials in the Office of Business Development.
"I anticipate a rezoning attempt would get support," Mr. Mollen said. But it would also take a year to 18 months, with no guarantee of success.

HEADLINE: Weicker's Budget Demands Austerity

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON

 BODY:
IN the instant statewide debate that erupted following Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr.'s budget address on Feb. 13, all eyes were on his proposal for an income tax and the other measures to overhaul Connecticut's tax system. But some of the Governor's suggestions for changes in spending could have an even greater impact on state residents.
The $7.48 billion spending plan would close a projected $2.4 billion revenue gap for the year that begins on July 1 by splitting it -- $1.2 billion in higher taxes and $1.2 billion in reduced spending. 
 The tax changes seem easier to grasp. The sales tax would be cut from 8 percent to 4.25 percent; the corporate-profits tax would be reduced from 13.8 percent to 11.5 percent, and the current income tax on dividends, interest and capital gains would be eliminated. The reveune would be made up by a 6 percent tax on all personal income of more than $25,000 for a couple filing jointly and $12,500 for an individual. The income tax would become the state's biggest revenue source, generating about $2.1 billion a year.
The proposed spending cuts, by contrast, are spread across every state agency -- a dizzying list of reductions and reapportionments that add up to a picture of a state in deep retrenchment. Few programs are left entirely unscathed. Many would be eliminated entirely.
Riders of the Metro-North Commuter Railroad, for example, would see fares go up by an average of 15 percent on July 1 to compensate for the $8.5 million reduction in the state's subsidy.
Poor families would see their welfare allowances frozen with no adjustment for the cost of living, and students at the University of Connecticut would pay a 3 percent tuition surcharge.
Some small state parks would reduce public access, and one -- the American Shakespeare Park in Stratford -- would close entirely, along with seven local offices of the Department of Motor Vehicles.
State aid to many communities would be slashed, with effects that promise to ripple through local governments in the form of reduced services, layoffs, and higher property taxes. Some 1,885 state jobs would also be eliminated, including a projected 1,100 layoffs. Nearly every page in the 846-page budget document, which legislators received last week, reveals some line item that speaks of making do with less. The Commission on Fire Prevention and Control, for instance, usually receives about $20,000 a year for printing pamphlets and other documents. The proposal for next year: $10,200.
Under the Governor's plan, investigators from the Department of Consumer Protection will not be traveling out of state much next year to uncover consumer fraud. The department's travel budget would be cut by nearly 80 percent, to $4,115 from $20,431 this year.
"As far as I can tell, everybody is going to feel some impact from this budget," said Matthew E. Melmed, executive director of the Connecticut Association for Human Services, a nonprofit research group. "My principal concern is that the people who can least afford to absorb that impact need to be protected."
But as members of the General Assembly began poring over the budget document, the balancing act implicit in Mr. Weicker's budget also began to emerge: with unpopular tax changes measured against unpopular spending cuts, does it make sense to restore money for programs that would then require even greater tax increases?
 
'I Support the Bottom Line'
 Leaders of the legislature's Appropriations Committee, which oversees state spending, have already decided that the total amount of cuts will not change. The committee's co-chairman, Senator Joseph H. Harper Jr., a Democrat from New Britain, said that he had informed members of the committee that they should feel free to suggest putting back money into any program, but that every suggestion must be accompanied by a proposal for an equal cut somewhere else.
"I support the bottom line," Mr. Harper said. "It's tough enough on the revenue side to sell what Weicker has in the works. And if you restore the cuts, then you've got to raise that much more in taxes."
Some lawmakers have accused the Weicker administration of boasting about cuts that are not yet nailed down. State employees have been asked to accept $400 million in pay and benefit reductions, including a one-year pay freeze. The $1.2 billion in cuts presented to the state and the legislature includes that $400 million. But the unions representing state employees have not agreed to any of it. They have instead proposed their own plan that would reduce state contributions and pay by $150 million.
Other people argue that some of the Governor's spending cuts would simply shift the burden elsewhere within the public sector. Many communities, for example, would experience deep cuts in state aid, 35 percent or more in some cases. And local officials around the state have already said that some of those cuts would have to be made up by higher local property taxes if municipal services and education are to be kept intact.
Officials in Danbury, for example, said their city would see state grants decline by $4.4 million, or nearly 20 percent, under Mr. Weicker's budget. Most of the cuts would come from a rewriting of the formula for distributing education grants. Poorer cities, like Hartford and New Haven, would get more money than in the past, while many communities like Danbury would get less.
 
Cuts Called Unfair
 The state would also cut by $321,000 a program that reimburses Danbury for paying the salaries of nurses in public and private schools and eliminate the $200,000-a-year grant that pays for transporting private and parochial school students in the city.
"There will be significant reductions in all city departments and an impact on our ability to fund the schools," said the city's Mayor, Gene F. Eriquez.
Mr. Eriquez said that while he understands the dire condition of the state finances, he thinks the cuts are not fair in every instance. New Britain, for example, with a population only slightly larger than Danbury's, would get more money next year, he said, and Bristol, just slightly smaller, would also get more.
Social welfare groups like Mr. Melmed's said that some of the budget cuts in programs designed to keep people off welfare could prove counterproductive in the long run, if the state welfare caseload increases as a result. Money for Operation Head Start, an educational program for young children administrated by the Human Resources Department, would be cut to $400,000 next year from $551,260 this year. The department's grant for teen-age pregnancy prevention would be slashed to $700,000 from about $1 million this year.
Mr. Weicker said in an interview that such cuts were the hardest aspect of the budget. But he defended the final package as the best that could be achieved within the goals of solving the budget crisis and stimulating the economy by cutting taxes paid by businesses.
"You can thrash around to your heart's content," Mr. Weicker said. "You can curse the world and all the ill winds that blow. But after you get through, you'd better address the problem."
