HEADLINE: THE GUIDE

BYLINE: By Eleanor Charles

 BODY:

 
A TYCOON'S TASTE
 Legrand Lockwood, an investment banker and railroad tycoon, built a mansion for his family at 297 West Avenue in Norwalk between 1864 and 1868. It has been in the process of restoration as a museum for the past decade, and it is used periodically for fund-raising exhibitions, special events, and outdoor fetes in summer.
 Opening Friday, and running through April 15, an exhibit called "Legrand Lockwood and the Taste for American Art," is focusing on 20 of Lockwood's favorite artists. Several of the paintings and sculptures were part of his private collection, auctioned off by his widow after he died in 1872, having lost most of his fortune in the 1869 crash.
 The works are on loan from museums and individuals. Some were not owned by Lockwood but were created by artists whom he favored. Among them are Frederic Church, Albert Bierstadt, William Bradford, and Asher B. Durand.
 Lockwood amassed a collection of more than 100 pieces, typical of many wealthy Americans during the post-Civil War period who began buying the work of American artists, rather than following the fashionable trend of purchasing only European artists. The patronage of their own countrymen gave American painters and sculptors an opportunity to develop their talents at home rather than emigrating to Europe in order to earn a living.
 Museum hours are Tuesday through Friday from 11 A.M. to 3 P.M., and Sunday from 1 to 4. Admission is $5, students and the elderly $3, children free. Call 838-2434 for more information.
 
SHARED HOUSING
 Maggie Kuhn, founder of the Gray Panthers, will speak at a symposium on cooperative intergenerational housing on Saturday from 9 A.M. to noon in the Davies Auditorium at Yale in New Haven. The title of her talk is "Shared Dwellings, Shared Lives."
 The program was organized by Sage Services of Connecticut, an agency supported by the State Department on Aging to establish a home sharing network. "We try to match up people who want to share living arrangements in the 20 towns of greater New Haven," said Virgina Einhorn, the program coordinator. One person in the home must be over 60.
 A panel of Yale faculty members will address particular aspects of the program in three workshops. Dr. Paula Milone-Nuzzo, from the School of Nursing, will talk about the economics of aging. Elizabeth Swenson, from the School of Architecture, will discuss design requirements in housing for the elderly, and the Rev. Gaylord Noyce of the Divinity School will talk about the relationships in shared housing.
 For more information on the free program, call 777-7401.
 
'REALLY ROSIE'
 The poems and drawings of Maurice Sendak's "Really Rosie," set to music by Carole King, will be performed by the Hartford Children's Theater on Thursday through Saturday at 8 P.M., and Saturday and Sunday at 2 P.M. in the Roberts Theater, Kingswood Road, West Hartford. Cortney Charnas of Glastonbury has the title role of the little girl from Brooklyn who wants to be a movie star.
 Tickets are $8, $6 for students and the elderly. Call 523-4479 for reservations, directions or more information.
 
MILESTONES AT YALE
 Musical milestones are to be celebrated this week at Yale. The Yale Symphony Orchestra will be 25 years old on Saturday, marking the occasion with a concert at 8 P.M. conducted by James Ross. Melvin Chen, violinist, and Warren Wu, cellist, are the solists in Brahms's Double Concerto; works by Schubert and Shostakovich are also on the program. The concert will be held at Woolsey Hall, Grove and College Streets; admission will be 25 cents.
 The Yale Music School, founded in 1890, is in the second year of a four-year centennial celebration, commemorating the passage of its first students from freshmen to seniors. This year's observance begins at 8 P.M. on Friday, when the Yale Philharmonia Orchestra will present an all-Beethoven program under the direction of Gunther Herbig, director of the Toronto Symphony Orchestra, and Arthur Post, a student in the Yale-Affiliate Artists Conducting Program. Claude Frank, piano soloist, is on the faculty at Yale and the Curtis Institute of Music in Philadelphia.
 Ticket sales will benefit the music school scholarship fund. Prices range from $10 to$250. Call 432-4158 for reservations.
 
WALLPAPER IN HISTORY
 Catherine Lynn, director of education and development at the Connecticut Trust for Historic Preservation, is a former curator of the wallpaper collection at the Cooper-Hewitt Museum in Manhattan and the author of "Wallpaper in America: The 17th Century to World War I," published in 1980 by W. W. Norton.
 She will give a talk, "Wallpaper in the 18th and 19th Centuries: A Connecticut Perspective," today at 3 P.M. in the Connecticut Historical Society auditorium, 1 Elizabeth Street, Hartford. Included in her survey of fashionable homes is the Hatheway House in Suffield, built in 1761, and containing superb late 18th-century French neoclassic wallpapers. The building is one of several maintained by the Antiquarian and Landmarks Society, sponsors of today's program.
 Her talk will also cover the substantial number of ordinary people who could not afford French imports but decorated their homes with simple single-color domestic papers. Admission to the talk is free. Call 247-8996 for more information.
 
'UNCLE TOM'S CABIN'
 Ronald Powell and Anthony Watts have drawn elements from a drama by George Aiken and from Harriet Beecher Stowe's novel "Uncle Tom's Cabin" and reworked them into a play called "Uncle Tom: Dead or Alive." It will be presented by the Crescent Players of Southern Connecticut State University in New Haven, Friday through Sunday, and March 6 through 9, at the Lyman Center for the Performing Arts at the university. Sunday performances are at 3 P.M., all the rest are at 8 P.M. in the Jorgensen Auditorium at UConn in Storrs.
 The 19th-century melodrama in two acts and several scenes is introduced by commentators in modern dress who interject issues of historic and contemporary racism from the viewpoints of blacks and whites.
 Written into the script are the characters of Uncle Tom, Eliza and Topsy, along with Harriet Beecher Stowe, Frederick Douglass and other people who were important to the civil rights movement. Tickets are $6, with discounts available for students and the elderly. The box office number is 397-4435.

HEADLINE: In the Region: Connecticut and Westchester;
Stamford's Stake in Morgan Stanley Plan

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:
OVER the next several months the Morgan Stanley Group, the country's fifth largest securities firm, will decide whether to move from Manhattan to Stamford.
The 11-acre, neglected tract it is considering abuts the north side of the railroad station and Exit 7 of I-95. The company already has taken a two-year renewable option on three acres. 
 "Stamford is our first choice out of New York," said Geoffrey Donoghue, director of asset management for the Morgan Stanley Real Estate Fund, "but there are also a few possibilities in New York, which I cannot disclose, that we are concentrating on."
 The primary concern, he said, is economics. "We see Stamford as an economic advantage for the firm and for its employes in real estate and personal income taxes, and there are significant savings in building costs," he said. "But we are also impressed with the substantial contribution made by New York City toward keeping the Securities and Exchange Commission from moving out."
 Under current zoning, 1.3 million square feet of offices and ground-floor retail space could be built on the 11-acre site. Morgan Stanley is looking for up to 1.2 million square feet.
 A move by Morgan Stanley would mean a large influx of new residents from among the firm's 4,200 employees now working in Manhattan. "'People here will be able to sell their homes and condos," said Thom Serrani, Stamford's mayor. "Half-empty restaurants will fill up, construction people who can't pay their taxes will get jobs. And the city will get around $3.5 million in taxes. This is an economic development super bowl in which we are competing with New York."
 In his efforts to help the securities company get the land it needs, the mayor was instrumental in drawing up a memorandum of understanding signed last month by the City of Stamford, its Urban Redevelopment Commission, Morgan Stanley and the Connecticut Department of Economic Development. It sets in motion a study, to be financed largely by Morgan Stanley, to determine if the land is eligible for urban redevelopment district status. This would enable the city to use its powers of eminent domain in negotiating for the 17 individually owned parcels on the 11-acre tract.
 "If the site qualifies, Morgan Stanley will make the decision to say yes," said the Mayor.
 Eligibility for the designation will be granted by the state if its analysis shows the property is substandard or deteriorating.
"I see no reason why it would not qualify," said Charles Lee, a local lawyer who is chairman of the city's Urban Redevelopment Commission. "It's a shabby doorstep to the city."
The tract includes a condemned former municipal office building and a demolished public school site owned by the city, empty lots used for parking, and a closed gas station. There are also a few businesses, and some residential tenants whom the city would be obliged to relocate.
 "I don't think any of this will firm up for five months or so," said Mr. Lee. He explained that following the expected affirmative result of the study, there will be a vote on the new district by his agency, public hearings, Planning Board review, and, finally, a vote on the proposal by the Board of Representatives, Stamford's 40- member legislative body.
 Since 1985, when the Stamford Planning Board did a study of the train station area, the 11-acre tract has been ripe for change. At that time, the board recommended that it be included in the urban renewal district, which it abuts on its northern and eastern borders.
 Bounded by Washington Boulevard on the west, Atlantic Street on the east, Federal Street on the north and North State Street on the south, the proposed Gateway Area, as the commission has dubbed it, would, under redevelopment, provide an attractive pedestrian-oriented linkage between the train station and downtown Stamford.
 While realty companies in Stamford have no involvement in Morgan Stanley's direct negotiations with municipal officials, they are understandably anxious for a positive outcome.
"A COMPANY of that size and stature would require substantial peripheral support that would fill up a lot of vacant space downtown," said Alfred Remsen, a senior vice-president at William Pitt Real Estate in Stamford.
William Pitt's report for the fourth quarter of 1990 found new construction at a standstill and the vacancy rate for commercial space at 23.6 percent. About 500,000 square feet was leased during the year, leaving 3.5 million square feet still available at rentals ranging from the mid-teens to the low $20's.
 A vice president in the Stamford office of a national real estate concern, speaking on condition of anonymity, said he believed Stamford is merely providing leverage for Morgan Stanley to get a better deal in New York. But Holger Arning, a senior broker at William Pitt, is convinced the move will be made.
Both men say that executives from Morgan Stanley are seeking homes in the area. Moreover, its president, Robert F. Greenhill, lives nearby in Greenwich.
 "Responsible executives making long-term decisions have to consider that the kind of work force they want is shrinking in New York, for all the obvious reasons," said Mr. Remsen. "It's as expensive as blazes, not to mention crime, taxes and a deteriorating infrastructure."
 "I think there will be some portion of Morgan Stanley moving here," he said. "The question is how much."
 For his part, Mr. Donoghue, the Morgan Stanley official, said that "the urban redevelopment plan doesn't mean we're going to use all 11 acres."
"We would buy what we need, and we haven't analyzed that yet," he said. "We have a million square feet in four Manhattan buildings and 400,000 square feet in Brooklyn. The Brooklyn location will stay." Leases on the Manhattan properties expire between 1993 and 1998.
 In the meantime, Morgan Stanley is putting together vehicular and pedestrian circulation plans, and working with its architects on space requirements in Stamford. "If we do not move, at the very least we will have left behind an urban redevelopment study for Stamford's benefit," Mr. Donoghue said.

HEADLINE: THE VIEW FROM: TORRINGTON;
Students Attend Classes There, So How Come It's Not a Campus?

BYLINE: By CHARLOTTE LIBOV

 BODY:
THE sign at the entrance says, "The University of Connecticut at Torrington." A UConn banner is taped to the information desk, and the campus bookstore is well stocked with university T-shirts, notebooks and stuffed likenesses of the Husky, UConn's mascot. The single brick building on the 200-acre rural campus has 10 classrooms, 2 seminar rooms, a library and a 260-seat auditorium. Eight full-time faculty members and 28-part-time instructors teach courses there.
But, officially, this regional campus of UConn does not exist. The Torrington branch was started in 1957, when its classes met in the local high school. Its own campus was opened in 1965, but in 1985, it lost its UConn desingation and became the Litchfield County Center for Higher Education. Instead of dwindling, however, Uconn's presence at the center has grown, leading to a bid now to regain its status as a regional campus of the university. 
 "It's the simple question that Shakespeare asked many centuries ago, which is, 'What's in a name?' " said the center's coordinator, Adriane R. Lyon. "Well, it is a matter of our self-respect and our self-image."
In 1985, state education officials decided to close the Torrington campus, because of declining enrollment there. The campus offered UConn's freshmen and sophomore courses; students who completed them went on to further study at the university's main campus is Storrs.
Residents of the Torrington area, who had gathered 15,000 signatures on a petition that sought to save the campus, agreed to a compromise. The newly named center would offer the two-year UConn undergraduate program as well as courses from several other institutions, including Northwestern Connecticut Community College in Winsted and Waterbury State Technical College.
 But the UConn designation should now return to Torrington, Mrs. Lyon said, adding, "Prestige has a tremendous amount to do with it."
 Enrollment has grown, she noted, and only courses from the University of Connecticut are now being offered at Torrington. The other programs offered at the center were gradually discontinued, after their sponsoring institutions found there was no need for them, she said.
Mrs. Lyon, who became the center's first director in 1986, has watched its student body grow from a low of 132 to 500 in September, the highest in the campus's history. That number dropped to 485 for the current spring semester, but a slight decrease is normal for the second semester, she said, noting that the tally includes both degree and non-degree students.
 
'Only Viable Alternative'
 With the poor economy, she said, fewer students are able to pay $20,000 to attend a private college, or even the room-and-board costs at UConn's main campus. Full-time students at Torrington, like their counterparts in Storrs and at UConn's regional campuses in Groton, Hartford, Stamford and Waterbury, pay $2,330 a year for tuition and fees. "So many students are seeing this as their only viable alternative," she said.
Without diversions like sports and fraternal organizations, the center offers a better academic atmosphere than the main campus, Mrs. Lyons said. The students from the Torrington center are well represenated on the university's dean's list, in part because "we don't have to worry about how the basketball team is doing," she said.
 Supporters of a return to the center's former status need to win the the cooperation of the General Assembly. The change could be accomplished in two ways, said State Senator Kevin B. Sullivan, a West Hartford Democrat who is co-chairman of the legislature's education committee. Senator Sullivan, who said he favors the change, said that the lawmakers could repeal the 1985 law that created the Litchfield center, or they could simply do away with that law in an administrative session, a simpler move that does not require a public hearing.
 State Representative George Avitable, a Republican from Torrington, has proposed a repeal bill. "The school has proven its point," he said. "It's a viable school, so why shouldn't it have the name?"
 Marvin Maskovsky, chairman of the Litchfield County Committee on Higher Education, which led the fight to save the center, said he agrees.
"The major issue is access to education," he said. "The people in this area should be able to take courses on a regional campus without the expense and time to travel to distant places like Waterbury and Hartford. The university's mission is to extend its service to every part of the state."
 The university's president, Dr. Harry J. Hartley, said restoring the campus's formal status "as a concept sounds fine." But since he had not seen the legislative proposal, he said, he did not know whether he would support it.
The state's Higher Education Commissioner, Norma Foreman Glasgow, said that while the center is working well, she was worried that a change could jeopardize its success.The Commissioner said she was concerned that if the center became a regional campus of UConn, other institutions might not be able to offer classes there in the future. But the supporters of the repeal bill disagreed, saying they would welcome programs from other colleges.
Booker T. DeVaughn Jr., president of Northwestern Connecticut Community College, said he would like to resume offering some classes in Torrington. "I'm sure when the opportunity presents itself, we would have classes there," he said. "I would hope they would have room for us."
 Having a dual identity -- taking UConn courses but at the Litchfield center -- can be confusing, said Kate Denehy of Harwinton, a sophomore majoring in fine arts, especially when she meets students at activities elsewhere. "We're doing all of the requirements," she said. "The faculty here is superb. There really is no reason at all why we shouldn't be considered part of the university."
Vincent LaFontan of Kent a sophomore who is president of the Associated Student Government on campus, said he chose to attend the Torrington center, even though he had been accepted to several other colleges in Connecticut as well as the University of Vermont. He has enjoyed his classes at Torrington, he said, but supported the name change.
"We've always been known as the University of Connecticut at Torrington, so we should be given that respect." he said. "It does mean a lot to be called the University of Connecticut."

Lyon, above, center's coordinator, is trying to get it redesignated as a UConn campus. A class being taught in the auditorium. (Photographs by Don Heiny for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: The Campaign to Save A Dusty but Historic Hall

BYLINE: By TESSA MELVIN

DATELINE: YONKERS

 BODY:
IT was once the essence of English gentility, an elegant manor house on a high bluff overlooking both the Hudson and Saw Mill Rivers, the center of the most prosperous estate in the Colonies. With its formal gardens and picket-fenced deer park, it represented what one historian called "all that was best in the life of the province."
Today, the deer park is home to the New York State Department of Motor Vehicles, the formal gardens long ago gave way to the Otis Elevator Company, and the Saw Mill River and its docks have disappeared altogether, covered over by Dock Street, the Yonkers Railroad Station and a public parking lot. 
 Philipse Manor Hall, as the high-style Georgian mansion is known, remains perched on the bluff, a historic anachronism overlooking factory buildings, discount stores and boarded-up tenement buildings, its narrow strip of grass perhaps less familiar than the kind sold on surrounding streets. Now the future of the manor may be as bleak as its present neighborhood.
 
The Site May Close in March
 Unless the State Legislature intervenes, the manor, Yonkers's only national historic landmark, will close at the end of March, a victim of the state's fiscal crisis. The site, operated by the state's Office of Parks, Recreation and Historic Preservation, will bear the brunt of a $100,000 cut in services at the agency's Taconic regional office: a $55,000 reduction that will eliminate the salaries of the manager and two security guards, the manor hall's entire staff.
State officials have been startled by the growing public reaction to the closing of a site few have visited and whose dusty and nearly empty rooms have been open only sporadically. Many people confuse the manor hall with its more popular neighbor, Philipsburg Manor, Upper Mills, in North Tarrytown, part of the complex of historic sites operated by Historic Hudson Valley.
A coalition of political leaders, historians and community groups have begun a campaign to save the manor hall, which some historians consider the most important building in Westchester, which political leaders call the most important symbol of the development of Yonkers and which community groups say is a critical landmark in an inner-city neighborhood that has few other resources.
 
A Task Force Is Organized
 A task force has been organized by State Senator Nicholas A. Spano to develop a strategy to restore the budget cuts and keep the site open. "It's very important not to lose this building," Mr. Spano said of the landmark, which was declared a National Historic Site in 1962. "The manor was the hub of the Philipse estate, and there are very few buildings in Westchester with that historical significance."
But the manor played an important role in the history of Yonkers long after the departure of Frederick Philipse 3d, a devout British loyalist who fled to England during the Revolution. Nearly a century later, part of the property and the Manor Hall became the Yonkers Village Hall and, in 1872, the first City Hall, a role it served for 36 years. As the "birthplace of the City of Yonkers, the building has immense symbolic significance," Neil J. DeLuca, Yonkers City Manager, wrote to the State Parks Commissioner, Orin Lehman, this month.
The manor has equally important value today, said Michael Rebic, who oversees historic preservation for the city's Planning Bureau. "You cannot calculate the impact of closing a site like this in an inner-city neighborhood," Mr. Rebic said.
"Downtown Yonkers in the last 20 years has slowly been losing all its major cultural institutions," he said, "and this is one of the few unifying municipal symbols left in a city fragmented by various geopolitical and socio-economic divisions."
 
'Look Out Our Windows'
 Sibley J. Smith Jr., manager of the historic site, agreed. "Look out our windows and look at our neighborhood," Mr. Smith said recently on a tour. "There's graffiti, broken windows and abandoned buildings everywhere, but not here. We have had very little vandalism and no graffiti. It's a measure of the respect people have for this place."
Should Philipse Manor Hall close, however, "you can draw your own assumptions about the future," Mr. Smith said.
Shortly before Mr. Smith became the site manager in 1988, a program titled "African Roots in New York Soil" attracted 2,000 visitors and prompted the state office to reassess the Manor Hall's focus. It proposed a new community-based museum emphasizing the city's history as a melting pot, with exhibitions devoted to varied religious, racial and ethnic groups.
The building was closed in October 1988 to complete extensive renovations and new exhibition space to accommodate this interpretation, which Mr. DeLuca called "the first such approach by a state-owned site to address groups that have traditionally been overlooked."
The work is not completed, but includes a "People of Yonkers" exhibition space for use by the community, Mr. Smith said. This is an effort, he added, to express "not simply the 18th-century splendor of the Philipse family, but to talk about the physical development of Yonkers."
Philipse Manor Hall has some important collections that would be incorporated in the new exhibitions, including a series of portraits of American presidents through the time of Franklin D. Roosevelt. Donated in 1929 by Alexander Smith Cochran, a Yonkers industrialist, the portraits include works by Gilbert Stuart and Charles Wilson Peale.
 
History and Architecture
 "There is no other building in Westchester with more architectural and historical significance combined," said Karolyn Wrightson, chairwoman of the Historical Preservation Advisory Committee, a citizen's advisory committee to the county, in a letter last week to Commissioner Lehman. "We are appalled at the decision to make one site bear the entire brunt of budget limitations."
Philipse Manor Hall "has never been properly opened and never staffed reliably so you could drive there and find it open," she said in an interview. "The Taconic region doesn't think the public cares."
The decision was made, said John H. Kennedy, director of the regional office, to preserve money to pay guides at the other sites. Eighty-five percent of his budget for the historic sites is "an untouchable amount" used for security, Mr. Kennedy said, adding that the guides had a dual role, helping insure the safety of the collections. The Manor Hall does not have guides.
"If we spread $55,000 across the other four properties, I really don't believe they could operate safely." he said.
 
Another Possibility
 The state would like to find "another user for the property," Mr. Kennedy said, adding that he had been approached by the Yonkers Historical Society. But no negotiations are possible, he said, until after the Legislature has made its decision about Governor Cuomo's budget proposals.
Jack Prill, president of the society, confirmed last week that his organization was interested in the site, but he added that funds were not yet available.
The Taconic Region operates historic sites at Olana, the home of Frederick Church in Hudson; the Claremont Mansion in Germantown; the Mills Mansion in Staatsburg, N.Y. and the John Jay Homestead in Katonah. Philipse Manor Hall is the only one of five historic sites and 11 parks in the region that will be closed, although services in two parks, James Baird State Park in Pleasant Valley and Taconic State Park in Copake will also be reduced.

Smith Jr., historic site manager of Philipse Manor, in the hall where Yonkers governing body used to meet (pg. 13) (Joyce Dopkeen/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: About Cars;
4-Cylinder Luxury in a Sporty Peugeot

BYLINE: By Marshall Schuon

 BODY:
Things go along and it's easy not to notice. But it is not so long ago that imported cars were peculiarly alien to the American hand.
There was a time, for instance, that Saab could fairly be called particularly Swedish, and I remember a review in a magazine of the early 70's that accused the company of building not cars but Saabs. Likewise, Alfa-Romeo was oddly Italian. The rake of the steering wheel was all wrong. The pedals were misplaced. Switches were backward. 
 Early Hondas looked a bit like football helmets. And if any of those imports qualified as really strange, it was the Peugeot, a vehicle that was especially . . . . well, French. Today, though, homogeneity is everywhere, and Peugeot is among the foreign makers whose products now are as American as an order of fries.
The company, which is a short step behind Mercedes-Benz as the world's second-oldest auto manufacturer, lays claim to being Europe's third-largest producer, and it must be doing something right. Its exports jumped 15 percent last year, and it is one of the few car companies whose profits have been rising in a sluggish market.
Peugeot brought its first cars to the United States in 1958, and it now offers its sedans and wagons through a network of 200 dealers. The lineup comes in two flavors, 405 and 505, and it must be said that the French folk have a nice alpha-numeric souffle in 1991's 405 Mi 16.
The Mi-etc. is a sport sedan motivated by a four-cylinder engine that uses 16 valves and the magic of electronics to pull 150 horsepower out of its tiny 1.9-liter displacement. The car has standard antilock brakes, front-wheel drive, a five- speed stick, and almost all of the goodies.
The one that's missing, unfortunately, is an air bag, and a buyer will have to contend with those infuriating mechanized seat belts, but that is a small price to pay when you consider what a wholly competent automobile this is.
Styling is by Pininfarina, and there is nothing new there, which is to say that the car looks the way Peugeots have looked for years. That is hardly a bad thing, of course, and the tester was a smooth white four-door with maroon-and-black interior, a wing across the trunk, and 15-inch alloy wheels. All of it aerodynamic, all of it very fast.
Inside, the Mi 16 has all the luxury equipment one could ask, including heated front seats, a power sunroof that flips as a vent or slides open, and there is a hidden pass-through from the trunk to accommodate skis. In the back, too, the windows go all the way down, a feature found in few of today's automobiles.
Up front, there is a large glovebox with twin cupholders, and the car has a good big ashtray for those who persist. Ahead of the black, leather- wrapped wheel, there is a 140-m.p.h. speedometer, and full gauges, including an 8,000-r.p.m. tachometer.
The Mi 16 also has the hardest clutch this side of a Corvette, and traffic makes you well aware that you are piloting some sporty machinery.
The suspension is taut but very smooth, and the unit body combines with the smooth shape to create a pleasant hush on the road.
Peugeot also is making much of safety these days, and the company has established its own "accidentology" laboratory to reprise and analyze actual crashes. Using police reports, hospital records and other documents, 8,000 accidents have been studied to evaluate structural damage and passenger injuries.
Outward vision has been improved, and the 405 has halogen lighting and a dash that is bathed in soft orange light at night. Glass is bonded to the body to increase structural rigidity, and the polypropylene fuel tank is placed ahead of the rear wheels for safety.
The tank holds 17.2 gallons of gas, and mileage is rated at 20 miles per gallon, city, and 28, highway. That makes the Mi 16 something of an economy car, although the sticker weighs in at $21,990.
These days, there's nothing very foreign about that, either.

HEADLINE: Donna Pflaumer to Marry in August

 BODY:
Mr. and Mrs. Howard E. Pflaumer of Weymouth, Mass., have made known August wedding plans for their daughter Donna Marie Pflaumer and Michael Brian McDonald, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond G. McDonald of Glen Head, L.I.
Miss Pflaumer, 28 years old, is an associate research analyst at the Center for Naval Analyses in Alexandria, Va. A graduate of Boston College, where she also received a master's degree in mathematics and education, she is studying for a master's degree in applied mathematics at Johns Hopkins University. She is a member of the Junior League of Washington.
Her father and her mother, Jeanette Ann Pflaumer, own the Bra-Wey Sport Shop, a sports equipment and clothing store in Braintree, Mass.
The prospective bridegroom, 29, is a financial economist at the Treasury Department in Washington. He graduated from St. Bonaventure University and received a Ph.D. in economics from Boston College.
His mother, Barbara Ann McDonald, is the attendance supervisor at North Shore Junior High School in Glen Head. His father is a vice president at Johnson & Higgins, insurance brokers and benefit consultants in New York.

HEADLINE: World Markets;
In Hong Kong, the Surge Goes On

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer

 BODY:
The money managers who have bet on Hong Kong this year -- and there are many -- have been right. And some analysts argue that the market will continue to go their way as long as the war in the Persian Gulf ends soon, the United States economy snaps out of its recession fairly quickly and China continues to press for economic growth and springs no surprises.
Right now, those ifs look like pretty good bets. The Soviet peace plan endorsed by Iraq and the ultimatum for immediate withdrawal proposed by President Bush on Friday seem to indicate the end is near even if there is a ground war. Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, told Congress last week that "this downturn could well prove shorter and shallower than most prior postwar recessions." And the Chinese and Hong Kong governments are working out their differences over a new airport in Hong Kong, which will provide a lift to the local economy. The estimates are that the Chinese economy could grow at a 5 percent rate this year, a big plus for Hong Kong, which is still China's gateway to the West. 
 The Hong Kong market, as measured by the blue chip Hang Seng index, has risen 14.9 percent this year to 3,475.34, with all of the increase coming after the outbreak of war in the Persian Gulf. It was also one of the best performers last year, in what was a very bad year for equities. This year's surge has been enough to wipe out the loss that occurred after the Iraqi invasion of Kuwiat on Aug. 2.
Market predictions that some analysts made at the end of 1990 for this year have almost been fulfilled. Enzio von Pfeil of Smith New Court in Hong Kong predicted in December that the Hang Seng would rise to 3,500 or 3,700 by the end of the year. He has now raised that to 4,000.
This performance is making money managers all over the world happy. For many, the percentage of their funds invested in the Hong Kong market far outweighs Hong Kong's share of the world equity business. Murray Johnstone International Ltd., which manages international stock funds, has its biggest investment in Hong Kong, with 13 percent of its portfolios in a market that accounts for 1.3 percent of the world equity market.
This support has been one of the driving forces behind the market. The rally has also been fueled by the war, which has carried equity markets higher worldwide; by the decline in interest rates in the United States, which has a direct impact on the Hong Kong economy because of the linkage of the two currencies; and by the attractive values of many of the stocks in the market, which are trading below their historical averages. Utility stocks, which have all but guaranteed earnings, have been attractive defensive buys in a slowing world economy.
The fall of the American dollar has also increased the competitive edge of Hong Kong exports against some of its major competitors, like the Italians in clothing, the Taiwanese on toys and games and the Swiss on watches.
Altogether, these factors make the outlook for the Hong Kong stock market, unlike that for many other equity markets, seem positive after the war. In many other markets, like those in Europe, the so-called fundamentals, like slowing economies and weak earnings, could stymie any rallies. (When analysts offer forecasts about market outlooks after the war, just remember that most predictions for the market reaction at the outbreak of the war were wrong. Markets did not fall; they rallied sharply.)
Investors seem to think the balance is still in favor of staying in Hong Kong despite potential problems. Inflation in Hong Kong is 10 percent and not declining fast. A long-term breakdown in the international trade negotiations after the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade collapsed at the end of last year could hurt exports.
And China's approaching takeover of Hong Kong in 1997 is still a cloud over the market. Political changes there will continue to disrupt the market.
Murray Johnstone is not reducing its investments in Hong Kong, but new money is not going into the market now.
"I think the market has come a long way," said Victoria Lewis, the Hong Kong analyst at James Capel Inc. in New York. "But it is at the level where you are going to run into the constraints of the China risk factor."
Elizabeth Tran, a managing director at Prudential Asia in Hong Kong, echoes this view, saying that the China risk factor could benefit other Asian markets. "At this level, other markets in Asia, like Singapore, are more attractive because Hong Kong will continue to carry the China discount," she said.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
A Prince Of a Deal For Citicorp

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
People used to denounce banks for charging usurious interest rates. Now Citicorp, desperate for capital, is paying such rates.
The $590 million capital infusion that Citicorp obtained last week from a Saudi prince came at a heavy cost. It may have proved that it can raise capital, but the 11 percent rate on preferred stock it issued for the money is equivalent to a pretax rate of 15 percent for a corporate investor. And Citicorp may go on paying that rate long after the current crisis of confidence has passed. Not before 1996 can the company force Prince al-Waleed bin Talal to convert the preferred to common, at $16 per share. Any profits on conversion will come on top of the assured 11 percent return. 
 But before one gets too jealous of the prince who will be raking in $65 million a year from Citicorp, it may be worth pausing to note that Citicorp's chairman, John Reed, can hardly be accused of not beating the bushes to find investors. And Mr. Reed, who owns 581,842 shares, including 100,000 bought for $25 each with borrowed money, has as much reason as any shareholder to regret the cost to the company. Last week, Citicorp shares fell $1.375, to $15.50.
 Citicorp is still looking for investors to put in at least $400 million more, although it will try to get less onerous terms. Even without fears of a bank crisis, there are few institutions that could invest that much, which leads to the idea, backed by the Bush Administration, to let industrial companies get involved. I.B.M. certainly could come up with the money, and on terms like that, it might be willing to take a chance.
The scary part of that proposal is that there could be opportunities for self-dealing in such an arrangement, leading to a situation where the industrial company only claims to be putting capital into the bank, while really using insured deposits to finance its own operations.
Proponents of letting the industrial companies own banks claim that adequate safeguards can be devised, so that such fears will be proved groundless. Given the history of the savings and loan industry, such reassurances have a hollow ring. But if banks otherwise must pay this much, the country may have no choice but to take the chance.
In the meantime, there is little doubt that other large banks, having blanched at the price Citicorp is paying, will redouble their efforts to comply with capital rules by shrinking loans, and thus their need for capital, rather than by raising new capital. That is a prescription for the credit crunch to continue.
In the end, the banks may get bailed out by inflation, although no one wants to admit it. Devaluing the currency is one way of driving up prices, and making bad loans into good ones by raising nominal asset values. Last week's report of surprisingly high consumer prices probably is not a precursor of that, but it could reflect the Fed's aggressive easing and it did unsettle the stock market, which also gyrated with each indication of war or peace. The Dow Jones industrial average ended the week down 45.29 points, to 2,889.36, for its first weekly decline since the air war began.

HEADLINE: Business Diary/February 17-22

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
 
Gasoline Prices on the Downswing, but for How Long?
 
Gasoline and crude oil prices have fallen to their lowest levels since shortly before Iraq marched into Kuwait. An American Automobile Association survey released last week said that gasoline had declined to $1.135 a gallon, about the same price as before the war but for a 5-cent-a-gallon Federal tax increase. Oil, driven down by peace proposals, closed on Friday at $17.91 a barrel, less than half its October peak. But don't start celebrating just yet. Even some of those analysts who expect crude oil to stay low expect gasoline costs to rise. Iraqi and Kuwaiti refineries have been ruined in the war; the Iraqis were apparently torching Kuwaiti facilities at the end of the week. Even the Saudis have to import fuel to supply the military, and gasoline demand will rise more rapidly once the American economy revives. "There will be ample crude for refiners, but not adequate refining capacity for consumers," said Alfred O. Munk, a consultant and the former foreign affairs manager for the Amoco Corporation. "Crude," he pointed out, "is not what you consume."

The Inflation Numbers Game
 
A recession that was supposed to extinguish inflation has still left the pilot light burning. Consumer prices rose four-tenths of 1 percent in January, eight-tenths without food and energy. Economists, who can no more take a figure at face value than Ella Fitzgerald can leave a melody unadorned, went to work explaining away the news. Look at higher liquor taxes, increased auto costs, rising apparel prices, other one-time events, they said. But a few saw underlying pressures, especially the 6 percent annual-rate increase in service costs, which account for about half of the inflation index. In dousing inflation, said William C. Dudley, a senior economist at Goldman Sachs, "a short, shallow recession isn't going to give you much benefit."
 
Greenspan Confused?
 
Let nobody out-worry Alan Greenspan about the Persian Gulf war and the credit crunch. In addressing two Congressional committees last week, he rehearsed his forecast of a mild recession, but then added more fine print than your typical car-rental agreement. Some of those clauses concerned the war, but most troubling, he said, was the Fed's inability to prompt banks to resume lending to their creditworthy customers. If Mr. Greenspan usually appears as a determined general unwilling to reveal his battle plans, last week he all but confessed to confusion. He seemed uncertain about whether to maintain or lower interest rates, adding that others at the Fed are divided. Some of his colleagues counsel patience, anticipating a rebound; others have a darker outlook than his.
 
Here Comes Unicode
 
The United Nations' near-unanimity on Kuwait was unusual, but the computer industry's agreement to use a common digital code is truly extraordinary. The usually fractious companies, including International Business Machines, Apple, Sun and Microsoft, hope for Unicode to become a global standard representing letters and characters in every language. Companies could then more readily write software to work in a variety of languages, and international computer communications would flow more smoothly. "It's a lot more meaningful than Esperanto, because we're dealing with computers, not people" said Esther Dyson, publisher of the newsletter Release 1.0. She added that the third world would benefit the most. "It's like affirmative action for smaller nations," she said.
 
Where a Bank Finds Cash
 
Banks may be where they keep the money, but when Citicorp itself needs money, it looks to the Middle East. Prince al-Waleed bin Talal agreed last week to invest $590 million in Citicorp. He had accumulated 4.9 percent of the company's stock last year, so his latest purchase could give him 14.9 percent if he converts his new preferred stock to common.
 
He said in 1988 that he "would love to be a corporate raider"; just a joke, his aides now explain. Exactly where all the money is coming from is unclear. Prince Waleed is indeed a nephew of Saudi Arabia's King Fahd, but he had to put up his house as collateral to get a loan from Citicorp just a decade ago. Where Citicorp will find even more badly needed capital might soon become clear. Other possible sources include the displaced royal rulers of Kuwait. "You go wherever there is a lot of spare cash," said James E. Akins, a consultant and former Ambassador to Saudi Arabia. Even though the Saudi rulers are temporarily pinched, he said, "There is a lot of spare cash in the Arabian peninsula."
 
 
 
COMPANIES


Tisch Takes the Giants
 
Yes, it's tough to get season tickets for the New York Giants. But $60 million, or more? Fortunately for Preston Robert Tisch, 50 percent of the Super Bowl winner came with the deal. Mr. Tisch, president of the Loews Corporation, bought half of the team from Tim Mara and two other relatives, leaving the other half in the hands of Tim Mara's uncle, Wellington. Loews owns 22.9 percent of CBS, where Mr. Tisch is a director and his brother, Laurence, is chairman. Mr. Tisch has promised to keep his football investment entirely separate from the network. And it's just as well. If the Giants adopted the same financial machinations as CBS, they might start buying back thousands of season tickets to boost the price of the rest, spin off a quarterback or two and sell Lawrence Taylor to the Japanese.11
 
Jail for Milken, Hope for Drexel
 
Michael Milken, the financier who studied at Berkeley in the 1960's, is returning to that area on March 4, this time to prison. Federal District Judge Kimba M. Wood, who sentenced him to 10 years on securities charges in November, recommended last week that he serve 36 to 40 months before he is eligible for parole. Cooperation with investigators, said to be asking him about failed savings and loans that bought "junk bonds," might get him out earlier. Even without Mr. Milken, Drexel Burnham Lambert might rise again. Drexel convinced its creditors and litigants last week to tentatively accept a fraction of what they claim -- in this case, $2 billion out of $20 billion. A Federal Judge said enough money should be left to allow Drexel to emerge from bankruptcy.
 
Outlook for Airlines
 
The Federal Aviation Administration predicted on Friday that the nation's airlines will recover their financial health once the recession and the gulf war end. The agency predicted stable or lower fuel prices, although some analysts disagree. James B. Busey, the F.A.A.'s administrator, rejected the airlines' calls for Government aid.
 
Quincy Jones, Inc.
 
Bertlesmann and Time Warner may think of themselves as thriving media conglomerates, but the best example might be Quincy Jones. On Wednesday his "Back on the Block" album won six Grammy Awards, as many gold-plated horns as he could carry, bringing his total to 25. After last year's Milli Vanilli embarrassment, the award-givers can be assured that Mr. Jones himself originated, arranged, conducted and produced the album. He is best known as a record producer and arranger for musicians from Duke Ellington through Frank Sinatra to Michael Jackson. He has also written the scores for 37 movies and produced several television shows and films -- convincing Steven Spielberg to direct and Oprah Winfrey to act in "The Color Purple." He has his own record label, and a major stake in a New Orleans television station that he oversees. His television and movie company, Quincy Jones Productions, has received so many uninvited visitors that he had to take its address off its business cards.
 
Amgen's New Drug
 
The Food and Drug Adminstration gave Amgen Inc. approval for a genetically engineered medicine to help cancer chemotherapy patients fight off infections. Analysts expect the drug to become one of the biotechnology industry's best sellers.
 
 
 
INTERNATIONAL


Another Step Toward Capitalism
 
If socialism, as many in Russia like to say, is the long, hard path from capitalism to capitalism, the Soviets took another halting step in that direction last week. The Government announced that prices would increase at least 60 percent on every basic need except fuel, medicine and vodka. The Soviets are trying to use central commands instead of free markets to reduce shortages, prune subsidies and set prices to more closely reflect production costs. Herbert Levine of the University of Pennsylvania, a specialist in the Soviet economy, questioned how much difference new state prices would make. "In many of these markets, the official channels are no longer the major suppply channels," he said. In his view, barter, private markets, the shadow economy and even commodity exchanges are acclimatizing many Soviets to more capitalist ways.
 
Slovenia's Secession
 
The Slovenian Parliament's declaration last week of autonomy from the rest of Yugoslavia only ratifies a status that Slovenia's economy has already achieved. Closer to Munich and Milan than to Belgrade, Slovenia has 8.5 percent of the nation's people but about 20 percent of its hard-currency earnings from exports. The Slovenes regard Serbia, the dominant Yugoslav republic, as a flabby cousin wedded to the Cyrillic alphabet and Soviet ways. The Serbs regard the Slovenes as Mercedes-driving snobs. Joseph Tragert, an economist at the Planecon consulting firm in Washington, says that Croatia's eagerness to follow Slovenia out the door might well ignite a civil war because Croatia has a large Serbian minority. "It's probably the end of Yugoslavia," Mr. Tragert said of the Slovenian stand. But like the restive Baltic nations, he added, Slovenia and Croatia are probably too small to thrive as independent states. They might choose a loose confederation instead.

HEADLINE: The Packaging Industry's New Fancy - Composting Garbage

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA

 BODY:
Led by the Procter & Gamble Company, a group of major consumer products manufacturers is promoting the use of composting to reduce the mountains of trash being sent to increasingly scarce and expensive landfills.
But the effort is running into stiff opposition from environmental groups and even from some disposal companies, like Waste Management Inc., that use more modest forms of composting, a process in which organic materials are broken down through biological means. 
 With questions being raised about the value of trash composting and the motives of those backing the program, the clash illustrates the nettlesome nature of the country's growing waste-disposal problem.
Some critics of the industry effort caution that a rush to use composting to dispose of diapers, paper packaging and other types of trash could lead to serious problems of land contamination. They fear that heavy metals and toxic wastes that are present in household trash could enter the food chain if the compost is used on farm land. "If you try to compost an undifferentiated waste stream you will mix batteries with old spaghetti and you will wind up with contamination," said John Ruston, a waste-disposal specialist at the Environmental Defense Fund, a nonprofit group based in New York City.
Indeed, the critics say composting is being used by program backers as an unrealistic panacea to keep consumers complacent about wasteful packaging practices -- and to keep lawmakers at bay. P.& G., with annual sales of $3.5 billion from disposable diapers, is facing proposals in several states to ban disposables because of the demands they place on landfills. Other restrictions are being weighed for consumer packaging in general.
Nevertheless, P.& G. stands by its program. "We think composting is now where aluminum recycling was 20 years ago," said Stephen W. Collier, a company spokesman. "We are trying to jump-start the process of building the infrastructure."
Toward that end, the company said it is putting up $20 million to fund demonstration projects. And it has helped to form a trade association, the Solid Waste Composting Council, along with Du Pont, Archer-Daniels-Midland, Kraft General Foods, Warner-Lambert and a variety of equipment vendors and consultants from the composting industry.
In its simplest application, composting can reduce the volume of trash going to a landfill by 50 percent. Food waste, leaves, grass and almost anything made of paper can be composted, as gardeners have long known. With tight controls on which materials are composted, the end product can be used to enrich farmlands, replace lost topsoil and reduce the amount of chemical fertilizers needed to produce crops.
A trend toward using composting as a means of dealing with solid-waste disposal is likely to accelerate as states increasingly ban yard wastes -- grass clipping and leaves -- from landfills as a way of extending the useful life of the dumps. Yard wastes constitute 18 percent of all trash.
According to Waste Management, the nation's largest solid-waste company, 10 states already have bans on dumping yard waste, with another five scheduled to implement bans within two years. Since yard waste is difficult to burn because of its high moisture content, composting is the preferred means of disposal.
P.& G. and other members of the composting council are suggesting that all household trash be sent to composting sites, like one already operating in St. Cloud, Minn., where mechanical separation systems screen out large plastic bottles and certain other items that cannot be composted.
Composting has been used extensively in this country over the last decade to dispose of sewage sludge, with an estimated 150 plants now in operation. Fewer than a dozen trash composting plants are in operation, industry executives say, but 80 are under study.
P.& G. argues that its Pampers and Luvs diapers are 80 percent compostable now and that it is developing a substitute for the diapers' plastic outer cover, which would make the diapers almost completely compostable.
Other consumer products companies say they make good candidates for composting as well.
"Carton board can be used as a bulking agent in composting projects," said Melinda Sweet, director of environmental affairs for Lever Brothers. She was referring to the material used in the company's soap boxes and other packaging. A major competitor of P.& G., Lever is not a member of the composting council but is planning to promote its own composting projects.
Overall, composting technology "has the potential to convert as much as 30 to 60 percent of all municipal solid waste into nutrient-rich, soil-like materials," P.& G. said in a recent statement.
Diverting that much trash would be highly attractive to municipalities scrambling to find substitutes for landfills. In addition, although odors can be a problem if composting is not properly managed, composting does not have the air emissions problems that can plague incinerators.
What's more, composting is a potentially cheaper way of treating solid waste than land filling or incineration, particularly when the costs of preparing landfill sites and disposing of incinerator ash are considered, experts say.
The problem, environmentalists say, is that the screening process is inadequate and contaminated compost could wind up in an agricultural setting, giving a bad name to composting in general. Critics fear that the compost could contain large concentrations of heavy toxic metals from batteries, like cadmium and mercury, as well as many shards of plastic, glass and grit.
"They have had problems in Europe with metals and physical contaminants," said Bruce Fulford of the Tellus Institute, a nonprofit consulting firm in Boston.
Added Jeanne Wirka, a solid-waste specialist with the Environmental Action Foundation in Washington, "There is good composting and bad composting. Some in industry are pushing for one-stop shopping. But why not do it right by separating leaves, yard waste and food waste to produce a high-quality compost?"
Waste Management, which has extensive landfill operations around the country in addition to composting, also questions P.& G.'s broad approach.
"We are not convinced it makes sense to compost the whole mixed-waste stream," said Dan Kemna, Waste Management's composting manager. "The cleaner the material that goes in, the better it is when it comes out."
Council members counter that even with an imperfect separation system, composting can produce material, albeit of a lesser quality, that would have many nonagricultural applications. These might include serving as a substitute for dirt in covering landfills and in the repair of damaged roadsides. Environmentalists are still concerned, however, that some of this inferior compost will wind up in the wrong place.
As things now stand, most states have no regulations for composting. Environmentalists and agricultural interests are urging that very strict standards be put in place to insure more careful, and costly, separation of materials. Vendors of composting equipment and producers of packaged goods want loose standards, so that the maximum amount of trash can be diverted from landfills. A two-tier system of regulation may be the answer, some experts say. Such a system has been in place in Massachusetts for about 10 years.
Under those rules, which were prompted by composting of sludge, Class I compost may have no more than 2 parts per million of cadmium and 10 parts per million of mercury. This compost can be used on land where crops intended for human consumption are grown.
Class II compost, which can have up to 25 parts per million of cadmium, cannot be used on agricultural land, but might be used by landscapers or golf course managers.
Ultimately, the battle over trash composting will be determined by economics, said Eliot Epstein, a composting consultant based in Stoughton, Mass. Enough applications may be found far enough from the food chain to push the P.& G. project along.
"Compost has traditionally been used for sod farms, nurseries and greenhouses," Mr. Epstein said. "Now it may replace peat moss and other things already on the market because it will be cheaper."
 
 
 
THE DIAPER DISCUSSION
 The two-page magazine advertisement depicts a hand holding what appears to be rich, dark brown earth. The headline says, "Ninety days ago this was a disposable diaper."
The Procter & Gamble advertisement, which is appearing in about a dozen magazines aimed at women, is designed to counter growing environmental concerns.
About 18 billion disposables are sold in this country each year, creating 6.5 million tons of solid waste, or about 2 percent of everything Americans throw out. P.& G.'s Pampers and Luvs account for about half the market.
Because re-usable diapers produce vastly less solid waste, legislation has been proposed in several states that would ban or tax disposables to reduce the burden on landfills.
In its ad, P.& G. stresses the compostability of the cellulose material that makes up most of a disposable diaper. Composting, the ad coos, is "safe, completely natural and, as you can see, incredibly fast."
Any human waste remaining in the diaper is rendered innocent by the composting process. But what is not dealt with is the 20 percent of the diaper material -- including the plastic outer sheet and the elastic around the leg openings -- made of noncompostable materials. Unless that can be removed, the compost will have little value other than as dirt cover for landfills, experts say.
P.& G. executives say the ad is not intended to mislead readers into thinking the entire diaper can be turned quickly and easily into a benign soil enhancer.
"The object of the ad is to use the diaper as a vehicle to send the message that there are some real solutions to the solid-waste problem," said Scott Stewart, a company spokesman.

HEADLINE: Medical Second-Guessing -- in Advance

BYLINE: By GLENN KRAMON

DATELINE: SANTA MONICA, Calif.

 BODY:
Helen Blumen, medical director of Value Health Sciences Inc., scans a patient record and shakes her head in amazement. A gynecologist in Colorado has proposed a hysterectomy for a 25-year-old woman with pelvic pain. The doctor presumes endometriosis, in which endometrial tissue grows abnormally outside the uterus, but did not confirm the diagnosis with a biopsy. And there is no mention of treatment alternatives, like medication or a procedure that would save the uterus.
Dr. Blumen functions as a sometimes unwelcome Big Brother to other doctors, assessing the appropriateness of the treatments they plan. As medical costs continue to rise significantly faster than inflation, insurers and employers are turning to companies like Value Health Sciences to review physicians' treatment plans to help insurers determine whether they should pay. 
 Medical review is not new. In the past it focused mainly on whether a procedure should take place in a hospital or a doctor's office and how many days a patient should spend in the hospital. Now, aggressive employers and health insurance companies, determined to cut costs, are cautiously beginning to use companies like Value Health to judge whether the procedure is needed at all. Such evaluations, known as medical necessity reviews, are a much more dramatic challenge of a doctor's judgment, and their use is being watched closely.
Many doctors do not like them, but insurers report early success. In the case of Value Health's system, which covers eight million people and is one of the more sophisticated on the market, about 10 percent of all proposed tests or operations reviewed prove clearly unnecessary when subjected to careful scrutiny.
 Value Health's proprietary computer software weighs facts about a case and warns when a doctor's plans go against a collective wisdom based on medical research and a consensus of leading physicians.
In the case of the Colorado hysterectomy, the physician was telephoned for a discussion but failed to convince Value Health that the surgery was necessary. The doctor was free to go ahead, of course, but the patient's insurer might not pay.
"People must understand that this system is preferable to excluding individuals from coverage because of pre-existing conditions, pushing them toward doctors who will give discounts, or raising out-of-pocket costs," said Mark Chassin, an internist who is the company's senior vice president.
 Value Health Sciences, a $5 million subsidiary of the closely held Value Health Inc. of Avon, Conn., is one of many businesses offering medical review services. Its clients include Prudential and Travelers. Other significant players include insurers themselves -- Aetna, Cigna, Metropolitan Life and John Hancock among them -- and independent companies Intracorp, Healthcare Compare, Health Risk Management, U.S. Healthcare and Medical Intelligence Inc.
The latest study of the efficacy of Value Health's system comes from the Blue Cross and Blue Shield Association, the nation's largest private insurer, involving 9,125 cases reviewed by the company. The year-long study found that 34 percent of the cases failed the first screen. After further investigation, a total of 11 percent of the cases reviewed were deemed inappropriate. Other studies have found similar results.
The system, whose software guides nurse reviewers through a rigidly structured series of questions asked of doctor and patient, has been particularly successful at identifying inappropriate plans for hysterectomies and tonsillectomies.
Dr. Blumen said the Colorado hysterectomy is typical of the treatments likely to be deemed inappropriate. The procedure typically costs $7,500, assuming no major complications, and is a risky operation that will mean the patient can never bear a child. Dr. Blumen said the review in this case protected not only the insurer but also the patient.
She cited other frequently challenged treatment plans: a tonsillectomy for a child who hasn't had many sore throats and would probably not benefit; an arthroscopy for a teen-ager with aching knees who has not yet tried an alternative treatment, like exercises; and a coronary angiography ordered by a physician who was talked into it by a worried patient with no symptoms.
In some cases, doctors agree not to perform the procedures after talking with reviewers. In others, they go ahead anyway. For now, some insurers will still pay for the procedure as if it had been approved. But others will pay nothing. Insurers say the day is coming when denial of payment will be far more common.
In many cases flagged by Value Health, the reviewers have reservations but give the doctor the benefit of the doubt. This happened frequently in the Blue Cross-Blue Shield study, which involved five Blue Cross-Blue Shield plans and a health maintenance organization, covering 1.5 million people in all.
The study, which took place in California, Delaware, Maryland, Massachusetts, Minnesota and Tennessee, involved 18 procedures. It found the rate of inappropriateness varied sharply by procedure.
 Insurers say the reviews are more than paying for themselves. The Value Health system is licensed to insurers for 10 cents a month per person covered. Blue Cross-Blue Shield calculated that the system saved $2.56 for every dollar spent on the service in the one Blue Cross-Blue Shield plan where cost effectiveness was studied.
Richard Maturi, vice president for managed-care programs at Blue Cross-Blue Shield, said the pilot projects have shown that "in terms of cost effectiveness and practicality, it works, and we would anticipate more use of it by the Blues in the future."
Private Healthcare Systems Ltd., a partnership of 17 insurers based in Lexington, Mass., has used Value Health for 4.6 million people it covers. It found that the savings-to-cost ratio ranges from about $13 to less than $1 saved for every dollar spent, depending on the procedure.
Donna Goldin, Private Healthcare's executive vice president, said the partnership has obtained very good results in preventing unnecessary hysterectomies and is satisfied with the Value Health review system. She said her group's savings figures do not include additional medical procedures that may not be ordered by doctors who know they're being monitored.
Though in the last decade physicians have become used to second-guessing by insurance companies and the Government, confrontations between Value Health staff members and doctors do occur. For example, one day recently an exasperated reviewer stepped into Dr. Blumen's office to report that a doctor had just slammed down the phone on her.
Worried about Value Health's system, the American Medical Association studied its use by a Blue Cross-Blue Shield plan in Minnesota and identified several areas of concern, said Dr. John T. Kelly, director of the A.M.A.'s office of quality assurance.
He said Value Health had failed to share with physicians the criteria on which it was basing its judgments, preventing doctors from assessing the system's criteria. "Any review criteria not publicly available are suspect, and there is no basis for confidence in them," he said. "We strongly believe that good medical care should not be a secret."
Value Health contends that it does make its criteria available.
The A.M.A. also objected to imposing financial penalties on doctors -- like not paying for a procedure -- rather than simply using the review to educate the physician. The group also said it regards the system as an inappropriate intervention in doctors' decision-making and objected to the use of reviewers not licensed to practice medicine in the state where a patient was being treated.
Doctors have also complained that calls from reviewers eat up their time and that of their staff members.
For all the resistance from physicians citing concern for patients' well-being, spokesmen for a leading patient-advocacy group, the People's Medical Society, and the A.F.L.-C.I.O. say they know of no complaints or lawsuits regarding necessity reviews. Indeed, they say, they endorse such systems, when applied carefully, because they help assure that a patient receives proper treatment.
 While the emphasis on Value Health's system has been on saving money, the reviews can actually increase the cost to insurers in some cases. In the case of a hysterectomy, for example, alternative therapies might fail and the operation might ultimately be needed.
Indeed, advocates like Dr. Chassin emphasize not so much the cost savings as the value of protecting patients by raising the quality of medical care. Doctors are only human, Dr. Chassin said, and often miss important diagnostic indicators. They cannot absorb every new medical finding that would be relevant. And they are sometimes not as open as they might be to less invasive alternatives to surgery.
Dr. Chassin said the motive behind some inappropriate procedures might simply be a doctor's desire to increase his or her income, but "more often, it probably is incomplete knowledge."
To be sure, though, the major selling point of Value Health's system is its effectiveness in limiting medical costs. Indeed, while the Value Health system flags inappropriate procedures, it so far does not spot cases in which a doctor did not order a procedure but should have.
 
 
ARE STANDARDS TOO LENIENT?
 Why is there such variation in the rate of inappropriateness among medical procedures reviewed by the Value Health Sciences system -- from more than 20 percent for hysterectomies and tonsillectomies to 1.5 percent for colonoscopies? The answers illustrate the difficulties of assessing doctors' decisions.
In the case of a hysterectomy not involving cancer, the medical consensus is that other treatments can often be tried before surgery. But "there are some procedures about which the physicians who do them are very enthusiastic, and each becomes a solution to problems with inadequate consideration of alternatives," said Value Health's senior vice president, Dr. Mark Chassin. "If you think about a woman who has minimal bleeding outside her menstrual period, the hysterectomy will clearly solve that problem. But the physicians' enthusiasm for it often prevents them from thoughtfully considering more conservative, less risky alternatives."
On the other hand, it is still generally acceptable in the American medical community to remove a gall bladder from a patient with gallstones even if discomfort is minimal and is not clearly caused by the stones, said Mary Ellen O'Donnell, director of utilization management at the Blue Cross and Blue Shield Association.
However, standards are not so lenient in other countries, and the operation might not be performed under similar circumstances, said Richard Maturi, Blue Cross-Blue Shield's vice president for managed-care programs. That raises an important issue, he said: "Should we be using medical standards from elsewhere in the world that are more cost-effective?"
