HEADLINE: All About/Convention Halls;
The Latest Municipal Malady: Convention Center Fever

BYLINE: By N. R. KLEINFIELD

 BODY:
They're the places where the Society of Foresters come to don straw boaters and fit in some free-spirited carousing. Where the members of the Kansas State Square Dance Association turn out to network while they find out the latest twists in dance calls. Those structures that resemble vast, beached, extremely homely whales: convention centers.
It often seems as if there are already a few million or so too many conventioneers, with those stick-on badges, hogging downtown sidewalks, but more are coming and there isn't enough space. Thus convention center fever is raging. Buoyed by the growth of trade shows and the hope of revitalizing crumbling downtowns, 42 cities across the country are scrambling to build new convention centers or expand the ones they already have.
Mobile, Ala., is constructing a new $60 million waterfront convention center. St. Louis is doubling the size of its center. Providence, R.I., is building a new center as part of a $300 million downtown redevelopment project. Los Angeles is engaged in a $500 million convention center expansion. Manag ers are agitating to expand New York's mammoth Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, even though it is less than five years old, and to make Chicago's cavernous McCormick Place still bigger.
"Almost every major convention center is expanding or thinking about it," said Darlene Gudea, the editor of Tradeshow Week magazine.
Prompting this race for more convention space is the steady rise in the number of trade shows and conventions. According to the Trade Show Bureau, their number has doubled in the last 10 years to more than 10,000 annually. At the same time, the amount of space used by conventions has been swelling by 7 percent a year for the past decade.
Some cities, though, may find themselves regretting their parts in the convention space race. Chris Yoshii, a senior associate at Economics Research Associates who follows public and recreational projects, feels that too much building is going on. "The smaller, second-tier destinations have higher expectations than can be fulfilled," he says.
 
'Verticalization'
Giant Trade Shows, Smaller Offshoots
 How many convention centers can one country hold? More than 330 of them alreadyblanket the landscape, 50 percent more than in 1980. As convention centers have multiplied, they have markedly changed how they operate.
"As recently as 15 years ago, it used to be that in many places cities owned local halls called auditoriums," said Tom Liegler, the general manager of the San Diego Convention Center. "A tenant would go over and see the superintendent, who would be sitting in an office with a big wad of keys having doughnuts and coffee. The super would hand over the keys and pull one switch that flicked on the lights and the fans. And he'd say, 'I'll be back at 5 o'clock, please have your check ready.' And the tenant would go hold whatever he was holding. Now there are these huge and sophisticated centers with big staffs. And every day things seem to get bigger."
Why are there more conventions? When Jane Lorimer, the president of the Trade Show Bureau, gets onto this topic, she trots out the concepts of "regionalization" and "verticalization."
"Regionalization" means that mammoth trade shows are increasingly supplemented by smaller renditions staged in various parts of the country. Thus there is the big National Restaurant Association Show as well as the Colorado Restaurant Association Show and the California Restaurant Association Show.
"Verticalization" means that conventions are becoming much more specialized. The National Sporting Goods Association puts on a huge annual (horizontal) fair, and then there are the vertical offspring: the Shot Show (for hunting types), the Sport Boat Travel and Vacation Show, the Ice Skating Institute of America Trade Exposition and the National Strength and Conditioning Association Show.
As industries continue to think vertically, they will put on still more trade shows and the need for additional convention space will continue. Who knows? Soon there may be a National Strength Show as well as a National Conditioning Show.
 
Bottom Line Pressure
Being a Loss Leader Is Not Enough Now
Until recently, when a city examined its convention center's bottom line, it usually saw splotches of red ink. And it just shrugged.
About as long as it has existed, the convention center has been widely viewed as no different from the box of Devil Dogs that a grocery store sells for 22 cents to get shoppers in so they can spend $140 on lots of other things to eat. The convention center became the world's biggest loss leader.
Municipalities knew conventioneers have an addictive tendency to roam through cities leaving scads of money in their wake. They fill hotel beds, devour restaurant food and buy terrific things like miniature St. Louis arches.
But as municipalities have come under furious budget strains in recent years, convention center managers have been pressured to break even at least.
"This pressure has been building for several years and has been pronounced in the last three to five years," said John Swinburn, executive director of the International Association of Auditorium Managers. "Facility managers have been told by their boards to cut expenses and generate more income."
One way to earn income is to provide more services, like wiring and installation, directly. "What managers have done is realize they have to get into new businesses rather than use outside contractors," said Tom Liegler of the year-old San Diego Convention Center. "They had been in food and beverage and parking. They said, 'Hey, let's get into the electricity business. Hey, let's get into the telecommunications business. Hey, let's get into the booth cleaning business.' " Mr. Liegler's center installs phone lines and hopes to provide power and cleaning as well.
At the same time, convention center managers are pursuing a wider assortment of events. They'll welcome almost anything short of a cattle drive. Mr. Liegler has attracted stockholder meetings, high school proms, banquets, dozens of office Christmas parties. Counting the $4 million worth of room taxes that go to the San Diego center, Mr. Liegler said, his facility has managed to break approximately evenon annual revenues of some $13 million.
Christmas bashes are nice, but nothing brings in the dollars like a giant convention. Mr. Liegler can hardly wait until 1995 rolls around. That's when 65,000 members of Alcoholics Anonymous will descend on San Diegofor their convention, primed to make virtually every part of the local economy a little richer.
Only San Diego's bartenders will weep.
 
Hello, Columbus?
Competing to Build The Spiffiest Center
 Columbus is sad.
There's not enough tourism. There's not enough spending. Places like Cleveland and Cincinnati are getting the Baptists and it isn't fair.
The palliative, city boosters hope, may be the 216,000-square-foot structure rising on the northern edge of downtown. That is where a $94 million convention center has been under construction since last June. Completion is anticipated during the summer of 1992.
The fervent belief of Columbus denizens is the hope of so many cities that build convention centers -- to spark the economy and cause armies of people to check into town. Claire Fawaya Hazucha, the executive director of the Franklin County Convention Facilities Authority, which is overseeing the center's construction, cites a study it commissioned indicating that Columbus may realize some $2 billion over 10 years as it entices bigger meetings. After all, a survey by the International Convention and Visitors Bureaus concluded that the average trade show delegate spends more than $900 before he staggers out of town.
Ms. Hazucha mentioned that a Baptists convention, expected to draw 25,000 people, has already been signed for the summer of 1993. "Quite a few other larger religious groups have been booked," she said.
A funny thing happens, however, when one city enlarges its center: Other nearby cities grow jealous. The likes of Cincinnati, Detroit and Minneapolis are now apt to want bigger and spiffier centers. It's a lot like the arms race.
San Diego has already seen the ugly side of convention center envy. When its facility opened a year ago, it was the largest on the West Coast. Then Anaheim expanded. A new addition opens in San Francisco this summer. Los Angeles is enlarging its center. Suddenly, San Diego is about to tumble to fourth place.
But not to worry. A couple of weeks ago, San Diego gave the go-ahead for a study of doubling the size of its new center. Take that, Los Angeles.
 
 
NEW MANAGERS FOR AN AILING SALT PALACE
 In some ways, the Salt Palace, Salt Lake City's creaky 21-year-old convention center, has been nothing but trouble. It has lost too much money -- between $300,000 and $1.2 million a year. A couple of years ago, the manager and several other employees were ousted after being accused of financial misdeeds. During a heavy-metal concert in January, three fans were trampled to death.
"I've had the responsibility of overseeing the place for five years, and it's always been something," moaned John Rosenthal, the director of the Salt Palace for Salt Lake County.
County officials felt they could put a stop to the Salt Palace's ills by bringing in professional managers; "privatization" has become one of the buzzwords of the convention center business. Thus the Spectacor Management Group of Philadelphia was recently hired to run the center. One of its first tasks will be to help oversee a $60 million overhaul and expansion, which is designed to make the Salt Palace less of an arena and more of a true convention center.
Though there is not enough history to judge the privatization movement, Chris Yoshii of Economics Research Associates said that cities and counties are likely to benefit. "I think it works well for most centers," he said.
Spectacor manages 12 convention centers, competing with companies like Leisure Management and Center Management. "More and more cities are concluding that they should not be in the business of running their centers," said Michel Sauers, Spectacor's senior vice president of sales. "They should be running fire departments and police departments, but not convention centers."
Spectacor charges a basic fee of $150,000 to $500,000, depending on the facility, as well as a performance incentive generally tied to revenue increases.
"We think we can bring more shows into a center than public officials can," said Mr. Sauers. "Because if there aren't events in a convention center, then it becomes nothing more than a mausoleum. And who needs that?"

HEADLINE: Technology;
Toward the Voice-Literate Computer

BYLINE: By GLENN RIFKIN; Glenn Rifkin writes frequently about technology. He is based in Sudbury, Mass.

DATELINE: WALTHAM, Mass.

 BODY:
Kazuhiko Sumiya spoke softly but clearly into a telephone handset. "Teikiatugaari," he said, looking at the Sun Microsystems workstation perched on a nearby desk. In seconds, the Japanese phrase appeared on the screen in phonetic English, followed by several rows of Japanese kanji characters. "Taikio," Mr. Sumiya added. Again, the Japanese characters appeared on the screen. The two phrases taken together mean, "There is a low pressure system that makes the atmosphere unstable." The voice recognition system had correctly identified the spoken Japanese on the first try, but also offered several choices in case it had misunderstood some words.
Mr. Sumiya is the head of a Fuji Xerox research team working with Kurzweil Applied Intelligence, based here, to create a Japanese voice recognition system. Along with Harley Rosnow, a Kurzweil software engineer and the manager of the project, Mr. Sumiya hopes to take the system from prototype to commercial product within two years. If it succeeds, many believe such a system could lead to greater acceptance among the Japanese of personal computers. 
 The Japanese language has more than 7,000 characters, making a Japanese-kanji keyboard resemble a bulky church organ rather than the compact "qwerty" keyboard Western users have come to rely on.
For this reason, acceptance of PC's in Japan has trailed far behind PC acceptance in the United States. According to Japan Entry, a Boxford, Mass., consulting firm, only 4 percent of Japan's population currently uses PC's, compared with more than 12 percent in the United States. Pencil and paper remain the favored word processor in this technology-rich society.
Ray Kurzweil, a prolific inventor of high-tech products, had an idea. Instead of simplifying the keyboard, why not just eliminate it?
Mr. Kurzweil had begun researching speech recognition technology more than a decade ago. In 1982, he started Kurzweil Applied Intelligence to build the first commercial large-vocabulary speech recognition system. He targeted his first systems for medical reporting. Today, Kurzweil's is the dominant system used in hospitals, with sales of about $10 million and nearly 300 installations. More than 1,000 doctors use the systems to enter patient information into hospital and office computers, according to Mr. Kurzweil. Adapting this technology to the Japanese language could be the long-awaited breakthrough for PC's in Japan.
 "The ultimate PC will probably use a microphone and a mouse with no keyboard," said John Oberteuffer, president of Voice Information Associates in Lexington, Mass. "The Japanese may end up getting to that point first."
However, even the most optimistic proponents of the project, like Bernard Bradstreet, president of Kurzweil Applied Intelligence, caution against too much optimism at the outset. "The market will evolve," Mr. Bradstreet said. "To think that a huge market will develop overnight is not realistic."
Nonetheless, Mr. Kurzweil believes that his company's joint venture with Fuji Xerox -- the Japanese affiliate of the Xerox Corporation -- will provide the first commercially successful speech recognition system for use in that country.
The Japanese prototype is based on current Kurzweil voice technology, incorporating sophisticated acoustic hardware. An expert system software package, which duplicates the judgment of linguists, allows the computer to translate sounds into words on the screen. The prototype works like the human ear, which has regions sensitive to different frequencies and pitches. In the voice recognition system, a digital signal processor breaks speech into frequency bands that can be portrayed visually.
When a word is spoken into the microphone, the computer analyzes these frequency bands to identify different sound segments called phonemes. The phonemes, to be understood and translated into characters, must be put into a context. To do this, a software program called the Japanese Language Phrase Module, was written. It parses a phrase and labels each of its words -- verb, noun and so forth -- and places the phrase in a sentence. This creates the context from which the words themselves can be deduced.
This process is difficult enough in English, which has distinct words and sentences. In Japanese, kanji characters are often ambiguous and can mean more than a simple word.
Mr. Kurzweil claims that the Japanese Language Phrase Module can already work in what computer programmers call "real time," as the words are being spoken. But the other parts of the system still must be made to run faster.
Mr. Kurzweil's English speech recognition system requires that a speaker pause briefly after each word. But in Japanese, where distinctions between phrases are subtle, continuous speech is a requirement. That means faster, more powerful microprocessors will be needed before such a system is economically feasible.
At Dragon Systems Inc., of Newton, Mass., Kurzweil's main competitor in speech recognition, engineers are at work on versions of the DragonDictate system in five languages: German, Spanish, French, Italian and Dutch. Janet Baker, Dragon's founder and president, said her company is considering a Japanese system but has not yet begun work on it.
Building acceptance of speech recognition has been slow in the United States. Only a few companies compete in a market that is so far valued at about $10 million. But while the market today is small, major companies like the International Business Machines Corporation are undertaking research of their own. According to Mr. Kurzweil, when the technology reaches its potential, a huge market will open up.
Critics of voice recognition technology contend that it will not be the panacea some expect. They say the Japanese response to it will be no warmer than the American. Jack Plimpton, president of Japan Entry, says the Fuji Xerox-Kurzweil product won't have much impact if it does not run on Japan's most popular PC's and sell at a low price.
In Japan, "major companies such as NEC and Fujitsu are working on voice recognition," Mr. Plimpton said. "But there are other barriers to PC use that are just as great as the language problem."
For example, according to Mr. Plimpton, cramped offices with tiny desktops preclude PC's, which is why more than half of the six million PC's in Japan are laptops. Even if voice recognition systems were available, the cacophony resulting from dozens of users simultaneously talking to their computers would be intolerable. "In Japan, handwriting technology using pen-based systems will be more successful," Mr. Plimpton said.
But pen-based systems that read kanji characters are still in their infancy. In addition, according to Mr. Kurzweil, the pen-based systems are slower than his speech recognition prototype.
With Fuji Xerox using its marketing and manufacturing clout, voice recognition systems would enter the market in Japan just as they have in the United States: in a high-end environment like medical reporting. The first commercial version will sell for about $10,000 and run on a workstation. Later versions, for high-powered PC's, will cost between $2,000 and $3,000.
"You don't have to start with a $500 piece of software that runs on every PC," Mr. Bradstreet said. "And as for the noise, Japanese office workers talk on the phone. Talking to a computer won't be any more disruptive than that."

HEADLINE: FORUM;
An Alliance Turning Into a Free-for-All

BYLINE: By JEFFREY E. GARTEN; Jeffrey E. Garten, a managing director of the Blackstone Group, is writing a book for the Twentieth Century Fund on America, Japan and Germany in the 1990's.

 BODY:
Beyond the Persian Gulf war and the deepening recession, there looms another make-or-break issue for America: How to deal with Japan and Germany in the new world order?
It was last June when deep cracks in the current German-Japanese-American alliance first surfaced. At the summit meeting in Houston, the first gathering of heads of state since the collapse of the Berlin wall, President Bush tried to orchestrate a policy reminiscent of the cold war. He urged Japan to hold back on additional foreign aid to China, citing continued abuse of human rights. He asked Germany to go slow in pouring money into the Soviet Union, saying that political and economic reforms there were still inadequate. But Tokyo and Bonn were in no mood to take directions. They told President Bush they would go their own way. 
 Another sad milestone in the relationship among the "Big Three" economic powers took place in December in Geneva. The event was the intended wrap-up of four hard years of trade negotiations in the so-called Uruguay Round. America's primary condition for a deal was a major reduction in foreign subsidies to trade in agriculture. But several nations were not agreeable. And who were two of the major culprits? Germany, which joined the protectionist ranks, and Japan, which did not make a peep about opening up its closed markets for rice imports. The negotiations collapsed.
Financial cooperation among the Big Three has also taken a nasty turn. In late January, the top economic officials of the three nations met in New York and promised to "maintain the stability of the international markets." However, just a few days later, without warning, the German central bank raised its interest rates in response to fears of inflation. Shortly after that, the Federal Reserve lowered its rates to combat recession. Meanwhile, Japan played a waiting game, keeping its cost of money high but giving off mixed signals about its future intentions. There could have been no clearer demonstration that each country was marching to its own national drummer, laying the basis for disarray in the world's capital and foreign exchange markets.
Now comes the biggest source of divisiveness of all -- the gulf war. As America risks everything, Tokyo and Bonn are on the sidelines. Their financial contributions are delivered begrudgingly; their noncombatant military involvement is virtually nonexistent. And this may only be the beginning. If the war drags on, Japan and Germany will be asked to ante up billions more dollars. In the later rebuilding of the gulf, they are likely to chafe under American direction and may become commercial rivals.
This new world order is a far cry from President Bush's vision of collective security and burden sharing. Can anything be done?
First, the three nations should recognize that it is time to find a way to discuss these problems at the highest political levels. The trade negotiations must be revived quickly, possibly with America compromising.
Second, the three need to review the global situation more realistically. There is no use pretending that their economic problems will disappear with the war. In fact, the global economy was heading for big trouble well before Saddam Hussein changed the world. America's companies were mired in calamitous debt; its banks suffocating from bad loans. Japan's stock market bubble was already bursting. Germany's finances were already straining because of reunification. It is imperative, then, that the Big Three's banking officials reach some understanding about averting a global credit squeeze.
Third, some way needs to be found to more equitably share the burdens of the gulf war and its aftermath. A disproportionate American contribution will sour Americans on global involvement, in particular with Japan and Germany. Tokyo and Bonn will have some chance to shoulder more responsibility with participation in postwar restructuring. But burden-sharing will have to go beyond money. There is no reason why Japan and Germany cannot provide their share of the peace-keeping forces that will be required once the shooting stops.
These are Herculean challenges. But holding the economic alliance together may be the most important task facing the Big Three.

HEADLINE: Rice Plays a Mysterious Role in the Inscrutable West

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The story of rice, a water-loving, small-cash crop, has byzantine ramifications that go well beyond the drought in California you discuss in The Week in Review for Feb. 10. 
 Most of the rice grown in the United States is exported to non-Western countries, where it is consumed as a staple food. Because many of these countries are poor, the United States exports must be subsidized, usually under the food-for-peace program, the only way the American crop would be competitive on global markets where buyers and other exporters operate well below our price-cost business levels. Former beneficiaries of our grain shipments have turned out to be Cuba and Iraq.
After rice shipments to Iraq were recently embargoed, it was suggested that Japan import the crop, thus further subsidizing it, while California was going dry growing it. Why the fuss in a country that couldn't stomach sushi even if it were starving? Rice is small potatoes in United States agriculture, but it is grown in two very powerful states: California and Texas.
In the last Presidential election, no less a person than candidate George Bush campaigned to open the closed Japanese rice market. The political rhetoric fell on deaf ears in Tokyo, and the rice market there remains closed to imports.
Rice, of course, remains ingrained in the Japanese psyche: Upon ascending the chrysanthemum throne, Emperor Akihito is reputed to have offered some to the sun goddess herself. No American-grown stuff would be suitable here. At any rate, even if the Japanese market was breached, the main beneficiaries would be other Asian growers, who could easily underprice the heavily subsidized United States growers.
The California drought and the economics notwithstanding, rice would be difficult to knock off the United States agricultural dole. Its growth has metastasized to Mississippi River states, aggrandizing the self-serving support the South is notorious for mustering (tobacco, peanuts, cotton, sugar). Renewed shipments to Cuba are thus being promoted.
As for thirsty Californians, why can't they just drink rice wine (sake) instead?
 
LESLIE S. HIRAOKA
Professor of Management Science, Kean College of New Jersey
Union, N.J., Feb. 11, 1991

HEADLINE: Teacher Is the Key In Quality of Education

 BODY:
Re: "Panel Begins Overhaul of Education" (Jan. 27): The quality of a nation's economic, political and social systems is a direct function of the quality of its educational system. Although we are now faced with lean budget years, the schooling of our children is the way we plan for better times to come.
Even as James G. Cullen and P. Michael Timpane, co-chairmen of the Quality Education Commission, conduct their search for the "world class" education dreamed of by Gov. Jim Florio and Education Commissioner, John Ellis, the teacher remains the key factor to the quality of learning that occurs in the classroom.
Technology has given us the tools to revitalize education and will doubtlessly play a major role in the findings of the commission. Preparing today's teachers to facilitate technology-assisted, cooperative, decision-making learning across the grades and subjects must be an immediate priority.
I urge Mr. Florio and Dr. Ellis to support teacher education programs, in-service and preservice, that provide New Jersey teachers with the skills and concepts needed to implement the "models of success" when so defined by the commission.
 
GERTRUDE W. ABRAMSON, Ed.D.
 
Dr. Abramson is associate professor of educational technology in the department of curriculum and instruction at William Paterson College in Wayne.

HEADLINE: Exchanging Technology, in Miniature

BYLINE: By JAMES FERON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 23

 BODY:
Three men old enough to have fought in World War II clustered around a Soviet-built model of an airplane of even earlier vintage at the opening of a two-day model airplane show here today, leaning in occasionally to inspect its engine the way surgeons might assess a heart transplant.
For many of the 20,000 people expected to visit the show at the Westchester County Center today and on Sunday, the Soviet exhibition was the first stop. 
 It was the first time that the Soviet Union had sent a delegation to an exhibition of radio-controlled aircraft in the United States. Henning Nielsen, a director and past president of Westchester Radio Aero Modelers club, host of what has become the largest such show on the East Coast, said, "We were really interested to see what they would show us."
The curiosity was particularly sharp because in recent years miniaturization, microchips and space-age construction materials have expanded the range and maneuverability of radio-controlled model planes.
Model planes and rockets are more than a sport. Progress with them has contributed to the development of rocket-powered craft and to the early studies for reusable spaceships like the space shuttle. The prototype of the first shuttle was carried aloft as a model on the back of a model Boeing 747.
Similarly, so-called drone aircraft evolved from model airplanes. Those tiny, unmanned, gasoline-powered planes with television cameras in their nose, which are guided from the ground, helped the Israelis fool anti-aircraft batteries and defeat the Syrians in the Bekaa region in Lebanon in 1982.
The battleship Wisconsin, on duty in the Persian Gulf, has a drone mounted on board that scouts out targets for the 2,000-pound shells of the ship's guns, then returns to be caught in a net. The drone's rear-mounted "push" propeller leaves the nose free for television equipment, while also accommodating the net catch.
 
Soviets Show Off Engines
 There were no miniature MIG fighters accompanying the 12-member Soviet delegation to the model show, but there was a full array of United States jet fighters on display.
The Soviets displayed a variety of models, the largest including gliders, a Soviet aerobatic plane, a World War I-era biplane built to scale, and a helicopter that has set records for altitude, distance and duration.
All the models were built from scratch, including the engines, and that was what fascinated the hobbyists who lingered to examine and discuss them. The Soviet exhibit featured an even wider array of engines displayed separately.
The Soviets also displayed the most up-to-date fiberglass, Kevlar and other modern building compounds, both strong and lightweight.
But there were no Soviet radios on display, except those in the model planes and built for them. Albert Nazarov, who is heading the Soviet delegation and the official responsible for "all Soviet hobbyists," as one of his colleagues put it, said the Soviets would like to find a way to exchange the miniature Soviet engines for the American radios.
The Soviet group traveled with Howard R. Kuhn, a retired United States Army colonel and a space and rocket modeler, who met his counterparts at an exhibit in Bulgaria. He said most of the model-plane work was done at the "aero-club level," referring to Government-subsidized cooperatives.
But the changes in the Soviet economy are forcing the model-plane hobbyists to find their own backing, prompting their acceptance of a long-standing invitation to participate in this show and to produce a catalogue of miniature engines that they hope to market here.
 
Models and the Real Thing
 Mr. Nazarov said there were about 300,000 airplane- and rocket-model hobbyists in the Soviet Union. Mr. Nielsen said that eight million Americans were involved in modeling of all types, and that the number of people working with radio-controlled models had increased significantly as the equipment improved and costs dropped.
Some model planes are built at scales as large as 1 to 4 or 1 to 3, and modelers tend to refer to real planes as "full scale."
An anecdote making the rounds among the enthusiasts today told of one such modeler coming across a man building a full-sized World War I aircraft in his barn. The hobbyist returned frequently, taking pictures and asking questions.
Finally, the man building the plane asked his visitor if he would like a set of plans. The delighted modeler assumed that the builder would give him original plans for a real plane, which he could then reduce to make a model. But no -- the man's plans, taken from a model-airplane magazine, were for a miniature plane. He had increased the scale to end up with the real thing.

LENGTH: 682 words

HEADLINE: Colombian Seeks Anti-Drug Pacts on U.S. Trip

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOGOTA, Colombia, Feb. 23

 BODY:
During his visit to the United States next week, President Cesar Gaviria Trujillo is expected to sign several agreements to advance both anti-drug and economic cooperation between his Government and the United States, Colombian officials say.
The officials, while emphasizing the agreements' significance, are ascribing just as much importance to Mr. Gaviria's scheduled meetings with the editorial boards of several major American newspapers. 
 Mr. Gaviria, they say, feels obliged to defend his anti-drug policy before whathe views as hostile American news organizations.
"The only major opponent of our policy in the United States is the press," a senior official in Bogota said. "This isn't just their fault, but also ours, for not having explained our policy properly. We hope to correct the bad interpretation through direct dialogue with the media."
The decision to meet with editorial boards -- including those of The New York Times, The Miami Herald and The Washington Post -- was prompted partly by an editorial on Feb. 14 in The Miami Herald. Describing Mr. Gaviria as "vacillating and confused," the editorial suggested that he take a firmer stance against cocaine traffickers and other enemies of the state.
At issue abroad and at home is the Government's program of lenient treatment for cocaine bosses who surrender and confess to at least one crime. Officials say the program is aimed at dismantling the drug cartels.
But many people, including many Colombians, say the program was thrown together hastily to try to placate the Medellin cartel, which is responsible for a recent wave of kidnappings.
Mr. Gaviria changed the policy several times to address objections raised by the cartel's lawyers, adding tocharges that he lacked the firmness to deal properly with traffickers.
Principal among the guarantees offered to surrendering suspects is the promise that they will not be extradited to face trial abroad, where justice systems are better prepared to resist their bribes and threats.
Mr. Gaviria can claim some recent successes against drug barons. The authorities announced record-breaking cocaine seizures totaling more than 11.5 tons so far this year. The figure equals a quarter of the entire amount confiscated in 1990.
In addition, eight suspects, including three of the four top leaders of the Medellin cartel, have turned themselves in under the leniency offer. But a judge now under investigation released one mid-level trafficker after he served only 44 days in jail.Mr. Gaviria has tried to strengthen the Colombian judicial system to avoid such incidents. His officials say the success of the court reform effort depends on the signing Tuesday of a judicial cooperation agreement with the United States. The agreement is aimed at easing the exchange of evidence and charges against drug suspects.
"We consider this agreement the most important of all those to be signed on this trip," the senior Colombian official said.
Mr. Gaviria, the official said, will inform President Bush that an Assembly now meeting to rewrite the Colombian Constitution is likely to prohibit the Government's use of extradition.
Colombia expects more from the United States than just judicial cooperation. The two Presidents are expected to discuss ways in which Mr. Bush's"Andean initiative," which offers lower import tariffs on certain Andean products, can be moved rapidly through Congress.
Colombians have long pushed for easier entry of their products into the United States market, as a way of offsetting the country's economic losses that have resulted from the drug war.
Mr. Gaviria will be away at a time of intense personal and national pain. The President's cousin was found slain on Feb. 16. On the same day, a car bomb, attributed tocartel assassins, exploded on a Medellin street, killing 23 people, including 9 policemen.
Mr. Gaviria has recently invoked emergency measures, including levying a war tax, to combat a leftist guerrilla offensive that has cost more than 300 lives and nearly a $1 billion in economic damage since Jan. 1.

HEADLINE: Metro Datelines;
Attendance Drops At the Meadowlands

DATELINE: EAST RUTHERFORD

 BODY:
Attendance at the Meadowlands sports and entertainment complex dropped sharply in January because of the Persian Gulf War and the recession, officials said Friday.
Harness races drew 20 percent fewer bettors than in January 1990, and the amount of money wagered was also down by a fifth. 
 The numbers improved somewhat in the first two weeks of February, with the amount bet down 10 percent and attendance just 5 percent lower than last year's, the New Jersey Sports and Exhibition Authority reported on Friday.
An ice show drew 35 percent fewer people this year, as many large groups canceled. "It was almost as if the day the war began, people decided they weren't going to come out," said Rbert Mulcahy 3d, the authority's president. (AP)

HEADLINE: Slump Catches Up With Once-Booming California

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 23

 BODY:
The mighty California economy is stumbling, marking the delayed arrival of the national recession on the West Coast and prompting concern that the state's downturn could outlast the slump in the rest of the country.
The nation's most populous state is being battered on many fronts. The unemployment rate has jumped in the last six months, to 7 percent, from 5.1 percent in June. That is well above the national average of 6.2 percent and leaves California with the third-highest rate of joblessness among the big industrial states. Economists expect additional layoffs in important industries like construction and aerospace, both of which are slumping badly. 
 Housing starts fell 31 percent last year (figures for January are not yet available), and home prices continue to drop in many areas. Agriculture, the largest single component of the state's economy, is reeling from a freeze earlier this winter that killed many of crops and from a five-year drought that has necessitated stringent plans for water rationing.
All told, gross state product, or total output of goods and services, is expected to decline by five-tenths of a percent this year after years of steady growth, according to the Business Forecasting Project at the University of California at Los Angeles. And with tax receipts leveling off and outlays continuing to rise, the state government faces a deficit of nearly $2 billion out of a budget of $54 billion for the fiscal year that will end on June 30. The deficit will be at least $5 billion for the next fiscal year.
Many Californians had come to believe that their state, by virtue of its economic diversity, would be recession-resistant if not recession-proof. Indeed, California still has many powerful factors in its favor, including its position as the hub of trade with Asia and its leading positions in technology, manufacturing and agriculture. Nevertheless, the recession that the state has slipped into in recent months is by some measures, including unemployment and housing starts, worse than the one being suffered by the rest of the nation. Some economists think the slump here will be hard to shake.
 
'Fairly Spectacular' Slide
 "California's economy held up longer than the U.S. as a whole, but we had a fairly spectacular downward slide here in 1990, led by housing and aerospace," said David G. Hensley, an economist who heads the Business Forecasting Project at the University of California at Los Angeles.
Mr. Hensley said that in addition to suffering all of the broad economic problems of the national economy, California would be hurt by factors peculiar to the state. Most notable of these, he said, are the drought and the declining Pentagon budget, which is already being felt by the state's aerospace and military contracting industry. Neither the drought nor the loss of military contracting jobs is likely to ease soon, he said.
"You could make a fairly convincing case that we're going to have more trouble than the U.S. as a whole," Mr. Hensley said. "The optimistic scenario is that the country could come out of recession in the second or third quarter, but I can't conceive of how California could come out of the woods that quickly."
 
Jobless Rate Soars
 These are among the troubling economic statistics for California:
*The unemployment rate of 7 percent was the highest in four and a half years and left California with the third-highest level of joblessness among the 11 large states for which the Labor Department has January figures. Only the rates for Massachusetts, 8.6 percent, and Michigan, 7.2 percent, were higher. While the California economy has continued to create jobs, the rate of job growth has shrunk substantially.
*The 31 percent decline in housing starts in 1990, to 164,394 units, left construction at the lowest level since 1982. Nationally, housing starts fell 13.3 percent in 1990. Sales of existing homes in California fell 17.1 percent last year, to 446,370. The median single-family home price fell eight-tenths of 1 percent last year, to $194,010, and the price decline in many areas since the peak in mid-1989 has been considerably steeper. Commercial and industrial construction also dropped precipitously.
*After five years of growth, total agricultural output in California is expected to decline this year from its 1990 level of $17.8 billion. The drought and plans for water rationing could have a disastrous effect on some farmers and some portions of the state this year, although others could escape relatively unscathed, depending on their access to alternate water supplies.
 
Unemployed Since July
 For Steven Williams, a 41-year-old computer programmer, the recession in California began in July, when he was laid off from his $31,500-a-year job at the McDonnell Douglas Corporation's Douglas Aircraft division in Long Beach. Mr. Williams was one of nearly 10,000 workers who have lost their jobs at Douglas in the last several years as the company has struggled to cope with declining Pentagon spending and intense competition in the commercial aircraft business.
Mr. Williams has sought employment leads at job fairs and through a placement service, and has landed three interviews but no job.
Mr. Williams has been able to get by on his unemployment benefits because he is single and lives with his brother. But his unemployment insurance will run out in six weeks, and although he would like to remain in California he is also looking for work in Oregon.
"I am constantly looking forward to something good happening because I do have faith in the Lord that I won't be destitute," Mr. Williams said.
 
A Shrinking Industry
 Military spending accounts for about 8 percent of California's economy, down from 14 percent 20 years ago. But the effect of the declining aerospace industry has still been remarkable. Virtually every big military contractor has laid off hundreds or thousands of production workers, engineers, scientists and corporate personnel. And nowhere has the pain been felt more deeply than in Long Beach, home of the sprawling Douglas Aircraft plant.
Bridgette Fletcher of Long Beach, who had worked on the C-17 at Douglas, lost her job in August. In past years, her degree in electrical engineering would have assured her a new job quickly. She has yet to get an offer.
A single parent, she has been able to support herself and her 16-month-old son, Carlton, on her $800-a-month unemployment insurance payments, and has managed to keep up the mortgage payments on her condominium. But she is behind on her electricity and telephone bills. As the months have passed she has considered moving from the state or changing professions.
 
The Housing Slump
 The state's banks and savings institutions report only a small upturn in mortgage delinquencies and defaults, although some analysts think delinquencies will rise as unemployed homeowners run through their jobless benefits and their savings.
Rising unemployment has clearly aggravated the housing slump, which in turn has led to more layoffs in the construction industry, previously a primary source of new jobs.
The great question mark hanging over the California economy now is the drought, which has reduced water reserves to record lows. With the state planning to slash or eliminate certain water allocations to farmers, and alternative supplies limited in many regions, many farmers are scaling back their planting and hunkering down for what could be a difficult year.
In Kern County, 60 miles northwest of Bakersfield in the Central Valley, the Blackwell Land Company, one of the area's largest agricultural concerns, has already abandoned 250 acres of lettuce and 160 acres of onions, which would have brought in $1.5 million.
But that loss pales beside the one faced by Blackwell if it cannot buy enough extra water to keep its 7,000 acres of almond trees and grape vines alive. If those permanent crops are lost, the company will lose the income from this year's harvest as well as from succeeding years'. The company's permanent crops produce $12 million a year in sales.
The effect of the drought would be felt beyond the loss suffered by the company. Blackwell Land has already laid off 65 permanent workers, or more than half of its permanent staff.
And the effect of the drought is not limited to agriculture. Industries that need large quantities of water, like the lumber industry, will have to pay higher prices or cut production.
But perhaps more important in the long run, the drought, in combination with the recession, is forcing California to confront more directly than ever before whether it can support the high levels of population growth and economic expansion it had come to regard as normal over the last few decades.
An example is the fast-growing community of Lake Elsinore, in Riverside County. In a state where water districts have only sought to facilitate growth, the Elsinore Valley Water District shocked developers this month by voting to freeze construction and effectively bar the sale of completed but unoccupied homes by refusing to install water meters. The freeze is in effect until April and could be extended if the drought does not ease.

HEADLINE: WAR IN THE GULF: U.N. Resolutions;
Iraq's Shift in Position: Not Enough for the U.S.

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Feb. 23

 BODY:
Since Feb. 16, Iraq has shifted from a repudiation of all Security Council resolutions calling for its withdrawal from Kuwait to acceptance of Resolution 660, demanding its unconditional withdrawal.
But the Iraqis have consistently demanded that all other United Nations resolutions, including those dealing with sanctions and other penalties, be voided as a condition of its withdrawal. The United States views this condition as a major sticking point for an accord. 
 On Feb. 16, an Iraqi statement spoke for the first time of Baghdad's "readiness to deal with Security Council Resolution No. 660 of 1990, with the aim of reaching an honorable and acceptable political solution, including withdrawal."
But the statement did not mention Kuwait, and it carried a long list of conditions, including demands that the allies halt the war and withdraw all forces from the region; that Israel withdraw from the occupied territories; that the Security Council repeal all sanctions; that the future Government of Kuwait be based on the "people's will," and that Iraq receive war reparations and be forgiven its debts.
 
A Moscow-Baghdad Shuttle

In the next few days, Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz of Iraq shuttled between Baghdad and Moscow, and on Thursday, the Soviets announced that the Iraqis had agreed to a seven-point plan that included accepting the terms of Resolution 660 unconditionally.
Under that Soviet proposal, Iraq asked for an end to United Nations economic sanctions after it had withdrawn two-thirds of its forces from Kuwait. Iraq further asked that all United Nations resolutions, including Resolution 674, which demands war reparations, and Resolution 661, calling for the restoration of the Kuwaiti Government, be rescinded after the pullout. It was the first Iraqi offer that omitted mention of the Arab-Israeli conflict.
The next day, the Soviets announced a plan under which Iraq shifted slightly in its call for an end to sanctions, saying they should cease after Iraq's full withdrawal from Kuwait.
As the noon deadline for an Iraqi pullout from Kuwait passed today, President Saddam Hussein and the Soviet Union have shifted their views on how the crisis should be resolved, but not enough to satisfy the United States and its allies.
 
The Main Sticking Points
 In the allied view, there are two main difficulties with the Soviet Union's latest plan, the six-point blueprint for an Iraqi pullout that Mr. Aziz accepted in Moscow on Friday.
The first is that it provides 21 days for Iraq to complete its pullout. When President Bush set the deadline of noon today for the pullout to begin, he gave Iraq one week to complete it.
The second difficulty was the call for the lapsing of the resolutions.
"The Soviet proposals fall short of what we need because of the time deadline and the conditionality, which includes nullification of all Security Council resolutions," the American representative at the United Nations, Thomas R. Pickering, said today.
More important, the Soviet plan effectively proposed that all international punishment of Iraq cease after the withdrawal. That would prevent the allies from pursuing their aim of maintaining the United nations military embargo against Iraq to wear down its army and perhaps eventually force it to accept some form of regional security pact that would place permanent limits on its armaments.
 
Trying to Destroy an Army

Although the allies' primary goal is the restoration of Kuwait's Government, the Security Council has adopted a broader and vaguer aim defined as "the restoration of international peace and security in the region." The allies cite that goal to justify destroying Iraq's army.
Lifting all Security Council resolutions would also prevent the allies from holding Iraq responsible for the damage its invasion caused.
Finally, Iraq would not have explicitly agreed to recognize the Kuwaiti monarchy as a legitimate Government, allowing it to maintain its claim to Kuwait as its 19th province. Diplomats fear this might allow Iraq to give up southern Kuwait while holding onto a northern section including the disputed Rumaila oilfields, now administered as part of Basra province, as well as Warba and Bubiyan islands.

HEADLINE: Editorial Notebook;
Which Boskin Is Right?

BYLINE: By Michael M. Weinstein

 BODY:
Economist Boskin versus Economist Boskin. Which one is more persuasive in the the debate about the impact of President Bush's proposal to cut the tax on long-term capital gains? The idea is to reduce from 28 percent to about 20 percent the tax on profits from the sale of stocks, bonds and other investments.
The first Boskin is Michael Boskin, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers. He says the President's proposal would spur a huge increase in savings and investment, driving up economic output by about $12 billion a year for five years. 
 The second Boskin is Prof. Michael Boskin of Stanford University, who, before he went to Washington, published estimates, backed by intricate mathematics, that lower taxes have a limited impact on savers. To judge by that work, Mr. Bush's tax proposal couldn't possibly spur much economic growth.
Professor Boskin is right, Chairman Boskin is wrong, and to see why, follow a simple calculation that Alan Auerbach of the University of Pennsylvania provided Congress. If the economy were to churn out an extra $12 billion of output each year, as Chairman Boskin claims, it would need a lot more plant and equipment, at least $60 billion more each year. But extra investment requires extra saving. That raises the crucial question: Who will save more?
Not pension funds and other nonprofit organizations, because they aren't affected by a tax cut. Not foreign investors; neither are they, mostly. That leaves only domestic taxpayers, who now save about $220 billion. For them to come up with an extra $60 billion would require a 30 percent increase in their saving behavior.
Preposterous, according to the research of Professor Boskin; that large a saving response is outside professionally respected estimates, even his own. No problem, says Chairman Boskin.
Choosing which Boskin to believe is now up to the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan. The President recently made him head of a commission to resolve technical discrepancies between White House and Congressional studies of a capital gains tax cut. Yet Mr. Greenspan will be able to resolve very little, if anything.
For starters, the technical discrepancy foremost in Mr. Bush's mind concerns estimates of the impact of the tax cut on the deficit. The White House estimates the tax cut will raise tax revenues by about $10 billion over five years; the Congressional Joint Tax Committee estimates it will lose that much.
The difference -- about $20 billion over five years -- is small, bordering on the trivial, in an economy that will generate approximately $5 trillion in tax revenues over the period. That discrepancy warrants no further study. And other discrepancies have already been scrutinized by scores of first-rate economists; one more study would resolve nothing.
By dragooning Mr. Greenspan, Mr. Bush has transformed a useless commission into a dangerous commission. Mr. Greenspan helps control the most powerful economic lever in the world, the U.S. money supply. It's imperative that he be, and appear to be, above politics. Yet by heading a commission meant to do Mr. Bush's bidding, Mr. Greenspan becomes a pawn of White House politics.
Apart from the technicalities and appearances, the President has permitted this capital gains issue to choke budget negotiations for two years, culminating in last year's crazy quilt of amendments to the tax code.
All this political havoc arises over an idea that, even if Chairman Boskin's estimates are right, would increase economic output by maybe $12 billion -- in a $6 trillion economy. The upshot is that if Chairman Boskin's hypothetical calculations are 100 percent right, they are only 0.02 percent right in the real world.

HEADLINE: A Big Win-Win on Trade

 BODY:
Finally, a crucial breakthrough on trade. The European Community last week agreed to demands from the U.S. and third world food exporters to negotiate specific reductions in each of three areas of farm subsidies. That breaks the impasse that paralyzed the Uruguay Round of international trade talks in December and opens the way for a bold trade agreement that could add trillions to the world's economies in the 90's.
An agreement to negotiate is not yet an agreement. Hard bargaining will commence this week. Having won the principle, however, negotiators need not be so concerned with the actual amount by which farm subsidies will now be cut. Once agricultural trade is included in the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, subsidies will eventually fall to insignificance. 
 The European Community has made a brave decision; Congress owes its trading partners no less. President Bush will ask it to extend "fast-track" negotiating authority, which permits Congress to reject, but not amend, the final agreement. Without such authority, the trade accord will be amended to death by special interests and the European decision will have been in vain.
The Uruguay Round hopes to incorporate, for the first time, rules governing trade in agriculture, intellectual property, services and investment. Farm subsidies are key because third world food-exporting nations will not accept rules protecting trade in property and services unless Europe and the U.S. open their borders to food and textile imports.
Until now the Europeans have refused to budge. They have a longstanding commitment to protect a few million family farmers. Prices are kept artificially high, stimulating production. The surplus stocks are then dumped onto foreign markets at subsidized prices, devastating farmers in developing countries. The policy costs European taxpayers $100 billion a year, which may explain the Community's willingness to change.
Previously, the Europeans have agreed only to reduce a vaguely defined measure of overall protection, but not each identifiable component of its policy: production subsidies, export subsidies and import barriers. And the reductions they offered were tiny compared with what the U.S. and third world food exporters were demanding.
Now everything has changed. The principles are settled; only the details must be negotiated. Everyone will have to give, but that kind of give-and-take is the ordinary stuff of international trade bargaining.
The U.S. is in a unique position. It loses billions each year to pirates of copyrighted and patented materials. And even efficient U.S. farmers can't compete against subsidized exports from the E.C. So an agreement that protects intellectual property and services and also reins in European farm protection provides a big win-win.
Not every American wins. The sugar, textile and shipping industries are some of the sectors that will lose protection if Congress approves the trade accord. That's why fast-track negotiating authority is critical. Without it, these interests will load the legislation with killer amendments, spoiling important gains for everyone else.

HEADLINE: PUBLIC & PRIVATE;
Reservations Not Accepted

BYLINE: By Anna Quindlen

 BODY:
The group of veterans marched down the street, and as they came into sight the crowd at the curb seemed to move forward to greet them, to hold them like a hug. They were youngish men, and their camouflage clothes were as different from the neat uniforms of the other groups as their war had been from other wars. Beside me an old man waved a flag. "We're with you," he shouted, as though he were putting all our cheers into words, and then he added, "We should have let you finish what you started." And the smile froze on my face, and fell.
It was five years ago that those Vietnam veterans marched by on Memorial Day, but I've thought about that scene more than once in the last 40 days. From the beginning, it has been difficult to publicly oppose this war, to express reservations or even to forgo the exuberant displays of national accord. 
 A basketball player at Seton Hall University who did not wear a flag patch on his uniform was heckled so relentlessly by fans that he quit the team and the school. The editor of The Kutztown (Pa.) Patriot was fired, and while the owners said there were other reasons, the ax fell just after he ran an antiwar editorial with the headline "How about a little PEACE!" -- the last word in letters as big as your finger. What amazed him afterward, he said, were the people who called him eager to talk geopolitics, as though they were all members of a sub rosa self-help group: Hi. My name is Joe, and I have reservations about the war in the gulf.
Reservations are not accepted. There were antiwar demonstrations. But mostly there was the majority rallying around the President, and a silent minority, constrained by the atmosphere of high-octane Amerimania, a prettified second cousin of her "Love It Or Leave It" forebears. Some of us were ambivalent, but we don't do ambivalence well in America. We do courage of our convictions. We do might makes right. Ambivalence is French. Certainty is American.
Some people say dissent is a matter of time, that opposition to Vietnam took years to build. But I believe it's a sign of the times instead. America had become the Muhammed Ali of nations, battered by foreign competition, by a faltering economy, by domestic problems as big as our national ambition. In the last six months Americans saw themselves as the leaders of the world again, assured of their inherent greatness and the essential evil of the enemy.
But the line between such convictions and jingoism can be very thin. Everyone talked about standing behind the soldiers even while deploring the policy. "Support the troops -- bring them home alive," one protest sign read. But like my neighbor at the parade, Letters to the Editor columns in dozens of newspapers made clear that people believed the way to show support was to agree that the troops were engaged in a necessary and a noble enterprise. If not, keep quiet. The idea that our true greatness lies in our diversity and freedom of speech was, if anything, a P.S.
This war has taken on a momentum of its own. The troops of August led to the buildup of autumn, and that to the combat of Jan. 16. The cumulative effect was epitomized at a rally in California several weeks ago: as though they were in the bleachers, a bunch of boys were chanting, "We're Number One!"
When the Soviet Union stepped in as a dealmaker, our former dark star, our one-time evil twin, it was hard to bear, especially when the negotiations included Saddam Hussein's survival. His face has been plastered on dartboards and ping-pong paddles, and his mustache has become an instant metaphor for evil. The U.N. resolutions called for making him leave Kuwait. The grass-roots agenda, forged over heady days of the United States leading the world to war, is to destroy him. It is an agenda that lends itself to ultimatums, not negotiations.
"We should have let you finish what you started," I keep hearing that man yelling. Some of us believed that our national agenda in the gulf war was murky from the start. But it has grown ever clearer: we must win, and Saddam Hussein must lose. Trouble is, it's not that kind of world, and this isn't that kind of war. Saddam Hussein could lose big and still be a hero in some parts of the region. We could run a devastating military campaign and still wind up hated and reviled. But for some short time, the war in the Persian Gulf has made the world a simpler place. Black and white. Good and bad. Win and lose. But not for long.

HEADLINE: The World;
Sense of Pride Outweighs Fears of War

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME

 BODY:
IT remains unclear what the Persian Gulf war will do to the political geography of the Middle East, but so far it has transformed the psyche of the United States.
The sour, deeply divided nation of a few months ago, worried about economic decay and political paralysis, has received a remarkable lift from the war. Despite the presence of a sizable minority opposed to the fighting, there has been a surge of patriotic rallies, flag-waving and professions of unity unmatched by anything in this generation. 
 Americans have always been prone to turn wars into crusades and metaphors -- from the sense of mission and manifest destiny of the Spanish-American War to the sense of virtue of World War II. In this war that tendency is, if anything, being heightened by the lingering frustrations of Vietnam.
"What makes war interesting for Americans is that we don't fight war on our soil, we don't have direct experience of it, so there's an openness about the meanings we give to it," said Robert Dallek, a professor of history at the University of California at Los Angeles. "War for us is like a tabula rasa, a blank slate which we can use to turn into a moral crusade, and that's what's happening now, particularly as a healing experience in relation to Vietnam."
A bloody ground war could radically change the nation's mood, of course, and some say the pro-war feeling is more broad than deep -- more support for the troops than the policies they are carrying out. In any case, support is not uniform throughout society. Blacks, for example, support the war less than whites.
"We talk about this as a war, but it's not even the length of a good World War I battle yet," said Peter Maslowsky, a military historian at the University of Nebraska. "The battle of Verdun went on for 10 months. I wouldn't make any judgments just yet."
But polls, troop-support rallies and the degree to which the war has been turned into a pop culture phenomenon all indicate broad support, which many Americans see as a heartwarming resurgence of patriotism and others see as perverse.
There's an Operation Desert Shield magazine on the newsstands, with its cover crowing, "America's Awesome Firepower, the Most Devastating War Machine Ever!" A spokesman says the initial 500,000-copy press run, put out just as the war was beginning, is selling briskly. Along with the Saddam Hussein golf balls, video games and shooting-range targets, the yellow ribbons and the Scudbuster T-shirts, it is emblematic of a change in the nation's mood. Life, a magazine which as much as any other sees itself evoking the essence of America, has not one but two issues on the stands, both labeled Life: In Time of War. In addition to the monthly, with a cover closeup of a grizzled Army captain, is a new weekly Life, with a cover photo of a blond-haired youngster in saddle shoes holding a flag.
It is as if all the confusion and pain of recent decades have melted, leaving the nation with its reassuring images from World War II intact.
"People want something to believe in," said Donna Lane, a 40-year-old Atlanta woman who has begun making pins with patriotic images that she sells to nonprofit organizations like the American Legion. "They want some part of their life to have a meaning," she said. "The guys in the service are putting their lives on the line for what the U.S. is supposed to mean -- freedom, liberty. That's what we're over there defending."
Wars draw people together in other countries as well, but some say they do so to a particular degree in the United States.
As an extraordinarily heterogeneous society, the United States is not unified along lines of race, religion or culture. War is one thing with the power to bond the nation into a unified whole. Also, throughout its history, America has found ways to convince itself that it is fusing its deepest moral impulses with its military ones.
Many analysts say the popular acceptance of this war reflects the Administration's relentless portrayal of it as a moral struggle -- with Saddam Hussein personifying evil -- instead of in terms of its geopolitical realities.
"We don't think of war as politics by other means," said David Tarr, a University of Wisconsin political scientist. "It has to be a moral crusade with good guys and bad guys."
To skeptics, that moral sense often is tragically misplaced. Many say the degree of violence the nation tolerates at home, exemplified by soaring murder rates and the world's highest incarceration rates, makes the United States more likely than other countries to employ violence to achieve what it sees as moral aims.
Prof. Gerald Linderman of the University of Michigan, who studies the nation's wars as they reflect society, said the American view of war is skewed by the degree to which it fights wars elsewhere and then returns to an unscathed homeland to construct a selective mythology about the conflict. Thus, for instance, World War II is remembered in images of Normandy, Dwight Eisenhower, prosperity and unity at home instead of Dresden or Auschwitz, Nagasaki or Hiroshima.
"We have lost some sense of the true reality of war," said Professor Linderman. "We make our calculations without ever having factored in the possibility that our streets will be destroyed, our houses ruined, our children obliterated. It allows us to talk very blithely about war. I've been astonished with the sort of insouciance with which callers on radio talk shows talk about intensifying the war. I think in this age of increasingly deadly long-range technology, sooner or later that is going to place us in great peril." Just as Vietnam has clouded the nation's image of itself at war, so have allusions to it dominated the reaction to the Gulf War. After the ambiguity and humiliation of Vietnam, the gulf war seems a model of clarity and success, a war portrayed as being fought with the most efficient weapons and greatest resolve against the vilest of villains. "It's Vietnam revisted as it should have been -- Vietnam: The Movie, Part II, and this time it comes out right," said Professor Dallek.
Many believe that if the war ends in a low-cost triumph, it could affect the American mood for years.
"We have national mood swings, and wars contribute enormously to them," said Professor Tarr. "After World War II we could do anything. After Vietnam we could do nothing. It's hard to say how this one will go down, but right now it looks like the optimists are being fed what they want and the pessimists are eating crow."
But many others do not expect the euphoria to last even if the war does speed to a successful conclusion. Often alluded to is a book by the Yale University historian Paul Kennedy, "The Rise and Fall of the Great Powers," which contends that global behemoths throughout history have seen their energy sapped and their decline accelerated when they concentrated too much of their resources on military activity and spending and too little on the creation of wealth.
Others note that the end of this war will find the United States in a much weaker economic position relative to the rest of the world than it was after World War II, for example, when America had half the world's manufacturing capacity. Certainly the problems of crime and drugs, decaying cities and intractable deficits will not be solved by victory in the Persian Gulf.
History has shown that the moral fervor with which the United States enters wars can ebb quickly. But for now, America has been getting some satisfactions from the war that it was not getting in a time of peace.
"I think it's taken the monkey off our back that's been there since Korea and Vietnam and Beirut and a few places in between," said Harry Kane, a Vietnam veteran who is editor of Operation Desert Shield magazine, which is published by a company that also puts out magazines for police officers and gun enthusiasts.
"There's been talk of us losing our economic leadership but this has reasserted our preeminence of a
sort," he said. "VCR's may be made in Japan and Mercedes have their stamp of origin, but what's going on in the Middle East is undeniably made in the U.S.A. I think that's a source of pride we have not had since World War II."

SECTION: Section 4; Page 3; Column 1; Week In Review Desk

LENGTH: 750 words

HEADLINE: The World;
'The Rulers Will Have to Face the Music'

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
AS they gaze beyond the clouds of the gulf war toward the future, many Arab officials and commentators see more questions than answers and a great deal of bad news ahead.
From Casablanca to Riyadh, supporters and opponents of Saddam Hussein believe beyond doubt now that he has lost the war, the fighting power of his army and any aspirations of leading the Arab world, even if he comes out of the war clinging to his office in Baghdad. While this may be great news now for staunch opponents of the Iraqi President like King Fahd of Saudi Arabia and President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt, there is nothing in it to guarantee them a secure future. 
 In articles and commentaries throughout the Arab world the common themes range from pessimistic to cataclysmic. The prognosis goes like this:
The Iraqi nation is likely to be a bankrupt, bitter, leaderless country loaded with some $100 billion in debt and deprived of its infrastructure by the weeks of intensive bombing. Allegiance has been assured for two decades by a ruthless militaristic police state headed by the Baath Party with Mr. Hussein at its top. As this machinery crumbles, the country could well revert to tribal, sectarian and familial alliances -- and bloodshed as old accounts are settled. Another point of agreement is that claiming the mantle of leadership in the Middle East -- a step taken over the last 40 years by leaders from Egypt, Iran, Iraq, Algeria and even by Saudi Arabians -- is no longer an option.
"There is no such thing as a leading Arab or Mideast state any more," says Adeed Dawisha, who teaches politics at George Mason University in Maryland and is spending a year in Egypt. "No one is able to play a role similar to that of America in this crisis. When the Americans go, rulers will have to get up on stage and face the music, at a time when all Arabs know their leaders were either boastful liars when they vowed to stand up to America or that they were helpless weaklings who hid behind the United States to fight Saddam."
"As for Saddam," Mr. Dawisha went on to say, "he will be widely seen as a loser even if sentiments are running high for him now among some Arabs. It will be like the Egyptian defeat of 1967 by Israel, which ended the myth of Egypt and its leadership of the Arab world long before Nasser died." Arab leaders already know their biggest problem will be to justify the legitimacy of their rule. Ever since Kuwait was invaded, the single theme on which Arab writers and commentators in the Arab media have almost unanimously agreed on has been the need for democracy and freedom.
Egypt, a key Arab ally of the United States that has always aspired to chart the way for Arab future, is hobbled by its crumbling economy and what is seen as the uninspired leadership of President Mubarak. And Syria is the least likely of the major Arab countries to play any big role because it is the country most distrusted by the Arab members of the anti-Iraqi coalition.
In North Africa, Algeria, Tunisia and Morocco are widely seen to have given Iraq what support they did largely because they felt their Islamic and secular opponents at home were using the gulf crisis to challenge their rule. After the war, these North African Arabs will be far too busy shoring up their sinking economies to play any role in shaping the new Arab world. And in the Arab east, Jordan and Yemen stand to emerge as losers whose leaders will get little sympathy from the Arab members of the anti-Iraqi coalition -- a position driven to a very large degree by the personal animosities that have so deeply taken hold among Arab leaders.
Indeed, the cutting insults traded over open airwaves in the last six months between Saddam Hussein, King Hussein of Jordan, President Ali Abdallah Saleh of Yemen and Yasir Arafat, on one side, and President Mubarak, King Fahd and Kuwaiti officials on the other, are enough to poison Arab politics for years to come.
Even beyond this disarray, perhaps the hardest blow already registered for the Arabs is that their oil has served them very little. The price has actually fallen, to under $20 a barrel, and the world made up virtually all of the missing oil exports from Kuwait and Iraq.
In a commentary on the interminable Arab feuds of the last 70 years in the weekend magazine of the French newspaper Le Figaro, one expert on the Mideast, Jean-Baptiste Duroselle, simply concluded that for the Arabs the only sure thing is that "the future is impossible."
