HEADLINE: Desert Fog;
The Uncertain Time Beyond High Noon

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
FOR one brief moment, as the clock struck noon yesterday, a certain clarity enveloped the Persian Gulf crisis. The choices for Saddam Hussein were crystal clear: humiliating surrender or military defeat. America and its allies were convinced their moral case was clear: good versus evil. And the final outcome, the coalition was promised, would also be clear: the total liberation of Kuwait, one way or another.
America and its allies would have done well to savor that moment, because once the fighting ends, high noon yesterday may be remembered as the last time anything about this conflict was clear. 
 Why? Because the clarity of this defining moment was produced by two very unusual, and fleeting, elements.
First, so much of the attention until now has been focused on achieving definable military objectives with high-tech weapons. In that sense, the clarity has been mesmerizing. Americans have been taken, through their televisions, into the nose cameras of smart bombs as they follow laser beams onto targets in Iraq. The enduring image is of perfect bull's-eyes, time after time.
Second, as the story evolved from one about defending rich Kuwaiti sheiks to one about defeating an evil dictator in Iraq, it assumed a moral clarity for many Americans unlike anything since the war against Hitler. Saddam Hussein was a mail-order despot right out of the Sears catalogue. He not only looked a bit sinister, but at every turn acted the pure villain and finally managed to alienate virtually the entire world.
Since the demise of the Soviet "Evil Empire" there has been a hunger among Americans for a moral clarity to justify and shape their foreign policy, and Mr. Hussein provided it in spades. The physical clarity inherent in military action, with its clearly defined means and ends, and the moral clarity provided by Mr. Hussein have made this a surprisingly popular war. But they have also been distracting in a way.
"They have obscured the fact that there is no comparable political clarity about what exactly we want out of this war and what we can expect to achieve," said Michael J. Sandel, a political theorist at Harvard University. "What kind of Kuwait do we want? What kind of Iraq do we want? Will the region establish its own stability or will a permanent American military presence have to supply it? There is still an enormous confusion about our political aims and there is no laser-guided policy to help us. There is no night-vision equipment that can pierce the veils of Middle East politics and define the American role after this war is over." Indeed, just over the clear-cut horizon of this war lies a forest of ambiguities and paradoxes bathed in a half light.
Take the question of the "new world order" and the Middle East. For America's allies Saudi Arabia and Kuwait, this war is not being fought to build a new order, but to rebuild the status quo. What these societies want out of this war is not to give birth to Jeffersonian democracy but to go back to their insular worlds where women cannot drive and no Western reporters roam the streets, where Iraq will no longer be a threat and where everyone will abide by the unwritten rules and limits of the neighborhood known as the Middle East, without foreign policemen. There were certainly many worse governments and societies on the face of the earth than those being protected in the Persian Gulf, so the fact that they will be strengthened or preserved by this war is no crime. But will it be very satisfying?
Another paradox that lies ahead arises from the tremendous resentment between the haves and have-nots in the Arab world, a resentment Iraq's invasion of Kuwait exposed. The United States is expecting that after the war there will be some sort of redistribution of wealth to help prevent a repetition. But the war itself is costing Saudi Arabia so much that it has had to borrow money on the world capital markets to finance it, and the Kuwaitis will need every penny they have saved -- and more -- just to rebuild their country.
In other words, after this war is over the haves are not likely to have anything left for the have-nots. And even if they did, the fact that the have-nots -- Jordan, Yemen, Sudan, and the Palestinians -- all supported Iraq in this war already has the Arab oil states saying privately that they deserve nothing. When Mr. Baker proposed to Congress two weeks ago that a new Arab-funded bank for reconstruction and development be set up after the war, he was quietly told by both the White House and the Arabs to forget about it.
What about the possibilities for a wider Arab-Israeli peace? To be sure, if Saddam Hussein is decisively defeated and then ousted, there will be a much better chance than if he had been allowed a hero's exit, with his army intact. He offered the Arab world only false hopes for a military victory over Israel, and as long as his shadow dominated the Arab world nothing was possible. But how much is possible without him?
Ask the Israelis, for instance. At one level the destruction of Iraq's armed forces, as well as nuclear, chemical and biological potential, should leave them more relaxed than ever. The greatest strategic threat to their existence has been eliminated. Yet the Scud attacks, while they have done no military damage to Israel, have terrified the country in a way that is almost worse. No matter what the strategic reality is, Israelis' perception of their vulnerability has actually increased as a result of the war and the repeated trauma of having to rush into sealed rooms and affix gas masks each time the sirens wail. What security lesson will the Israelis draw? Perhaps that they should never give up an inch of territory because strategic depth is critical; after all, that is one reason tiny Kuwait perished. Or perhaps they will feel that all they gained from the West Bank's vaunted strategic depth was one second more of warning against the missiles.
Some in Washington already argue that the Saudis, Kuwaitis and others, who have demonstrated a previously unseen quality of pragmatism and forthrightness in openly siding with the United States against another Arab country, might finally openly deal with Israel. But this ignores the fact that it was only for reasons of survival that the Saudis joined forces with the United States, and that same survival instinct is likely to impel them to continue to shun Israel after this war. Israel's army is no threat to Saudi Arabia, but an Israeli embassy in Riyadh would make the Saudis a gigantic target. In contrast to smart bombs, which navigate themselves right to the core of a problem, smart Arab politicians step around problems -- especially one as sensitive as Israel.
Another paradox is that Saddam Hussein's cynical, but repeated, declarations that he raped Kuwait in order to liberate Palestine have probably pushed the Palestine question to the top of the agenda to be taken up after the war. But that has happened at a time when the question of who should represent the Palestinians will be more wide open than at any moment since the Palestine Liberation Organization was founded in 1964. Yasir Arafat, by supporting the Iraqi occupation of Kuwait, may have reinforced his popularity with his own people, but he lost all moral credibility with the Israeli peace movement, totally alienated his financial backers among the Arab gulf states and his political backers in Egypt, and generally disgusted every leader in America and Europe who overtly or tacitly was ready to work with him. So just when there will be the most pressure to address the Palestinian issue, there will be the least inclination to deal with the Palestinians' chosen representative.
Yet another paradox to emerge from this war is what it has revealed about United States-Soviet relations. The gulf crisis began with an unprecedented degree of American-Soviet cooperation to settle a regional conflict, but it is ending with the two superpowers seemingly elbowing each other, while professing what great friends they remain. That elbowing has taken the form of a Soviet peace proposal that seemed to give their former client Saddam Hussein something of a face-saving exit, and an American ultimatum that he had two choices: military humiliation or political humilation.
The lesson of this episode is that while the cold war is over, geopolitics is not. The crisis has reminded us that simply because the Soviet Union's foreign policy may no longer be driven by a desire to spread the Communist gospel, Americans should not expect competition between Moscow and Washington to cease. As with natural adversaries in the jungle, economic, territorial and security imperatives drive Moscow and Washington to compete for resources and influence, irrespective of whether Lenin is in the Kremlin or Mikhail S. Gorbachev.
So at this moment of clarity, it is worth stepping back for a moment and recalling a lesson of Middle Eastern history. Up to now the only modern Middle East war that ended with a clear-cut victory was Israel's defeat of the Arabs in 1967. But that clear-cut victory proved to be untranslatable into political gains. It produced as many political-security problems for Israel as it did benefits. Ironically, it was the 1973 war -- which ended in something of a stalemate -- that laid the basis for the only agreements between Egypt and Israel and Israel and Syria.
President Bush's ability to bring the gulf crisis to the clear-cut moment of decision that it reached yesterday seems now to be a diplomatic and military masterstroke. But wars are fought for political ends and one cannot help but wonder how this current clarity will translate at the end of the day.
"Americans are thinking in highly self-enclosed terms about this conflict," said the Israeli political theorist Yaron Ezrahi. "Clarity is a cultural value of democracies, where governments are judged by performance and are accountable only to the living. Politics in the Middle Easte is governed more by the accumulated weight of history, traditions and tribal animosities -- and certainly not performance alone. That is why this region has never been hospitable to straight lines or clear endings."
That is also why the Middle East has been so resistant to political engineering all these years and why it is probably the worst corner in the world to try to begin constructing a new world order. Then again, maybe this time will be different. In any event, soon the smoke will clear and a new day will dawn in the Middle East. The only question is: Will it be tomorrow or yesterday?

HEADLINE: The World;
Fujimori In the Time Of Cholera

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH

DATELINE: LIMA , Peru

 BODY:
WHEN Alberto Fujimori took control of the Peruvian Government last July, many remarked that seldom had a new President inherited a nation in such disarray. Peru was suffering from 24 consecutive months of hyperinflation. Eighty percent of its work force was either underemployed or unemployed. Economic output had fallen 20 percent over the course of two years. One-third of the country was malnourished. The Shining Path guerrilla organization was causing havoc in the highlands. And more than 40 leaders of the Tupac Amaru Revolutionary Movement, the second largest terrorist group, had just escaped from Lima's top security prison.
Today, economists, terrorist experts and social workers talk sympathetically of Mr. Fujimori's attempts to fix what some say can't be fixed. They say that any progress in the seven months since he took over from Alan Garcia has been marginal. 
 "Garcia left a country in ruins, destroyed," said Raul Salazar, an economist with Macroconsult, an economic firm in Lima. "Considering that Fujimori started with nothing, he has done better than we had hoped. Still, at this moment that is far from sufficient."
A cholera epidemic, which has left more than 110 dead, 5,000 hospitalized and more than 23,000 affected, is the latest assault on a society already stretched to the limit. Drug trafficking continues almost unabated. Terrorism has caused the United States Embassy to caution against traveling in Peru. In Lima, three million people are without running water and sewer systems. The city's harbor is badly polluted, as is its main river. Just making sure the garbage is collected is a major struggle every day.
And just as the Government was able to claim some progress in the fight against cholera -- in particular a reduction in the mortality rate -- health officials began warning last week that malaria, rabies and dengue fever were also beginning to become problems in the country's jungle interior.
Are there any bright spots? Economists point to only one: the fight against inflation.
After he assumed office, Mr. Fujimori instituted what he called an economic shock, removing long-standing Government subsidies and raising prices between 1,000 and 3,000 percent on some products, such as gasoline, electricity and food. It was a one-time attempt to wring inflation out of the system and begin to open the economy to foreign investment.
While that caused an immediate 400 percent inflation in August, inflation fell below 10 percent from September through November, jumped to 23 percent in December and fell back to 16 percent in January.
That still indicates an annual rate in excess of 100 percent, but economists say it is a sign that the Government has established a serious anti-inflation policy, now considered key for any Latin American economy to begin on the road back to economic health.
But the process Mr. Fujimori has mapped out is going to take time, and analysts wonder if the Peruvian people -- primarily the lower middle class and the poor, who are hardest hit by the removal of the subsidies and are sinking deeper into poverty -- will wait that long.
Peru, strapped for cash, cannot borrow on the international markets, and thus might have to wait years before it can begin critical new projects to deliver water, electricity and health care.
In the meantime, Mr. Fujimori is being criticized because of almost negligible progress on other fronts. Western officials complain that in the drug arena, the three branches of the Peruvian police are archrivals, that they do not often share intelligence information and that investigative skills are very weak.
 
Fighting Drugs, Sort Of

The Army rotates its commanders in the biggest drug areas every 6 to 12 months, so that about the time a commander is skilled in drug interdiction he is removed. Moreover, the army appears unwilling to control even municipal airports in areas such as the upper Huallaga Valley, where cocaine base is shipped out of Peru to Colombia. American officials say as many as seven flights with up to 300 kilos of cocaine base leave some of these airports every day.
The battle between the army and the Shining Path, considered one of the greatest threats to the national security of the country, also poses great complexities for Mr. Fujimori. The clandestine Maoist group is increasing the number of killings among villagers in the Peruvian highlands. And a frustrated Peruvian army is coming under more and more criticism from human rights groups that say it is engaging in indiscriminate killings and torture.
Perhaps the most pointed personal criticism of Mr. Fujimori concerns his combative style and his apparent unwillingness to work with members of Congress on legislation. Almost 98 percent of all new laws and regulations instituted in Peru during the Fujimori administration have been by executive order, without the approval of the Congress, a pattern set by earlier presidents.
"He is very autocratic, ruling almost like a king," said Mr. Salazar.
Hernando de Soto, an economist and perhaps President Fujimori's chief policy adviser, says he welcomes the free fall in the Peruvian economy, because Mr. Fujimori is gambling that an atmosphere of political and social crisis will pave the way for the major changes that Mr. Fujimori thinks the country needs.
"This society is collapsing, without a doubt," Mr. de Soto said last week. "There is no respect for the state, the parliament, the laws, the judicial system, not even the traffic lights. Nothing works here. But the problems here are so entrenched that you have to have a collapse before you can implement fundamental changes in the political system."

HEADLINE: Campus Life: Syracuse;
Inner-City Youths And Students Working Together

DATELINE: SYRACUSE

 BODY:
Students at Syra cuse University are teaming up with inner-city youths to help out around the community.
The collaboration, called "S.U. Students and Company," is the basis of a policy studies class called "Community Problem Solving." 
 Five groups of three or four undergraduates and five youths each meet weekly to work with public agencies.
Craig Owens, a 15-year-old freshman at Nottingham High School, volunteers at the Syracuse Developmental Center. He said he was scared the first time his group went to the center, and was shocked by some of the people there. Now, he said, he looks forward to going with his group, which calls itself Brothers Helping Others.
 
'It Keeps Me Off the Street'
 "They like to see us come and help them out," he said. "It makes me feel happy. I'm helping them by being a gentleman and singing and reading with them and bowling with them."
The program also gives youths like Craig a glimpse of college life. Groups go for pizza or play basketball together.
"It keeps me off the street, where I don't need to be," Craig said.
The undergraduate course is taught by William Coplin, director of the Syracuse public affairs program, who has had his students working in the community for 12 years. This semester was the first time they joined forces with disadvantaged youths.
"The idea is to have people on the receiving end to actually be giving," Professor Coplin said. "We always say, 'Well, you are disadvantaged, so let me help you.' Now we are saying to them, 'You can help, too.' It helps build self-esteem to realize others have terrible situations, and they can help."
Shontay Brooks, a 17-year-old senior at Henninger High School, said he has already received more from the program than he expected.
"Teens are most likely not going to want to do volunteer work," he said. "We just want fun, fun, fun. This is mixed fun and work."
 
'A Chance to Be in Control'
 Samuel Imbolli, a senior policy studies, music and economics major from Granby, N.Y., said it is rewarding to see how much the patients apppreciate the group's efforts. "We're not changing their lives in the three weeks we volunteer," he said, "but last week one of the patients said to me, 'This is the most fun I've had in a long time.' "
Sharon Ladin, a 1985 policy studies graduate who suggested the program to Professor Coplin and who now works as child-watch coordinator for the Children's Defense Fund, said such programs expose the participants to conditions they never knew existed.
"It is giving youths a chance to be in control of something," she said. "No matter where you are in a station of life, you always have something to give. It helps people to see they are not at the bottom of the barrel."
After three weeks of community service, each group will produce a public-service announcement to be filmed and broadcast by University Union Television, the on-campus station. Each advertisement will identify a social problem that the youths believe needs to be addressed. The announcements will be shown at a graduation ceremony in April, where the youths will receive certificates and T-shirts for their participation.

HEADLINE: Campus Life: Iowa;
Crossing Disciplines To Study Environment

DATELINE: IOWA CITY

 BODY:
To cope with the problem of global warming, the University of Iowa has formed an interdisciplinary Center for Global and Regional Environmental Research, encompassing 15 of its academic departments.
The center's co-director, Jerald Schnorr, a professor in environmental engineering, says he believes it is the first such consortium in the nation to focus on regional climate, the level at which public policy can be enacted. 
 Professor Schnorr, who recently edited a series of reports on the Exxon Valdez oil spill for a publication of the American Chemical Society, said an interdisciplinary approach makes sense because climate change in the Upper Midwest does not fit neatly into a single discipline.
"If we don't form interdisciplinary centers like this one, we will fail to address the critical and emerging needs of society," he said.
The center consists of 34 faculty members, but its flow chart does not show departmental affiliations. "Problems such as global change are hindered by our disciplinary barriers," Professor Schnorr said. "If the various disciplines aren't talking, I think they miss part of the story."
 
Geology and Geography
 For some, the exchange has already paid off in new ideas and methodologies.
George Baker, a geology professor, researches climate history by studying the remains of vegetation. Through the center he learned of a professor in geography who constructed computer models of climate and vegetation.
By combining their work, the two scholars were able to work backward and determine what the climate was like 5,000 to 6,000 years ago. That, in turn, will help determine whether current climatic changes are part of a normal cycle or were a result of human activity.
"Probably neither one of us would have thought of that on our own," Professor Baker said.
A professor and hydrology engineer, Witold Krajewski, said his involvement with the center "has given me new ammunition to appeal to students to broaden their horizons beyond engineering."
"It is appealing to students to see the strong connection between science and engineering," Professor Krajewski said.
 
'The Big Picture'
 The opportunity to expand beyond a single field of study has attracted some graduate students to the university. Kurt Paterson, a doctoral candidate in environmental engineering from Davenport, Iowa, who is studying regional climate change, turned down an offer from a larger institution because it asked him to narrow his research interests.
"I had trouble finding one narrow topic that I felt I could really be interested in for the rest of my life," Mr. Paterson said. The chance to study outside the environmental engineering department, in fields as diverse as biology, chemistry and law, he said, gives him "a feel for the big picture."
Another doctoral candidate in environmental engineering, Todd Reese of Des Moines, said he believed that interdisciplinary centers like Iowa's would become increasingly popular, in part because of the opportunities that they offer researchers.
 
Can Attract Funds
 "Money's tight," Mr. Reese said. "Centers are big. They're good for young investigators who need a start and have good ideas that are difficult to fund, and they're good for the Federal Government that wants to streamline some of its operations."
But Teri Camery, a general studies junior from Atlantic, Iowa, who is studying the environment, worries that the center diverts too many resources from educating students.
"The center is another example of their having all this for research," she said. "Why can't they give some of it back to the students?"
As vice president of the University of Iowa's Environmental Coalition, Ms. Camery undertook a campaign to establish an interdisciplinary undergraduate degree in environmental studies but she said she had found that environmental classes had been cut from the curriculum, partly because of a lack of faculty time. "The more time the teachers have to do research, the less time they have to teach," she said.
Iowa offers degrees in environmental studies through its geology and geography departments, but Ms. Camery seeks an interdisciplinary degree that incorporates political science and economics.
 
Arose From Conference
 "There's no way you can implement scientific solutions to environmental problems without a broad understanding of the problems that caused them," she said.
The center recognizes this and so have faculty members who study public policy, like David J. Forkenbrook, director of Iowa's Public Policy Center who was a co-founder of the interdisciplinary group.
The center grew out of a 1989 conference on climate change sponsored by Professors Forkenbrook and Schnorr and by Gregory R. Carmichael, a chemical-biochemical engineering professor.
The same year, Gov. Terry Branstad of Iowa, as head of the National Governors' Association, proposed an initiative to study the issue and its possible effect on the region's economy. A tax on utilities that was enacted last June is expected to bring the center its first financing this July, about $325,000.

HEADLINE: Campus Life: N.Y.U.;
Sleep-to-the-Beat Flops in a Dorm Over a Nightclub

 BODY:
A newly opened no-alcohol night club, the Ultra Violet Dance Club, has already become a mixed blessing for New York University. Students who were looking for such a club on campus say they are delighted, while students living in Goddard Residence Hall, which houses the Ultra Violet, say they are deafened.
Now, N.Y.U. administrators are trying to keep the club open and the dorm residents happy. 
 A dozen Goddard Hall students have complained about Ultra Violet's din, Chancellor Lawrence J. Oliva told a Feb. 14 University Senate meeting. He reminded the Senate that the club's "spectacular opening" three weeks ago was made amid "assurances that the noise would not disturb students."
Mr. Oliva said that the university has "taken steps to handle that issue," forming a committee of Goddard residents, N.Y.U. administrators and members of the university committee on student life, and headed by the president of the Student Senate, John Calvo, a senior economics major from Passaic, N.J.
 
 'The D.J.'s Are Out'
 In the meantime, Mr. Oliva said, "the D.J.'s are out" for the rest of the semester at the club, and quieter entertainment -- perhaps unamplified musicians and comedians -- will be tried.
Students living in Goddard, which is on the university's main quad, have complained about the noise from the club since it opened Jan. 31 in the first-floor space that by day is the Violet Cafe. Goddard residents said, too, that university administrators had promised to close it down if there were any problems -- a promise that N.Y.U. officials deny making. The nightclub is open Thursdays, Fridays and Saturdays from 10 P.M. to 1 A.M.
Susan Schwartz, a freshman from Somerville, N.J. majoring in dance education, said noise from the club had disrupted her schedule.
"I have a 9 o'clock class on Fridays, so I wanted to go to sleep," said Ms. Schwartz, whose room is on Goddard's second floor, "but the bed would shake and the noise was so loud."
 
A Failure 5 Blocks Away
 Sally Arthur, the university's assistant vice president for student life, said the impetus for a nonalcoholic university club came from a resident assistant who two years ago suggested opening one. The drinking age in New York was raised to 21 from 18 several years ago. In 1989, students opened the Gallery in the Barney Building, about five blocks from the main quad, but Ms. Arthur said it failed because it was "too far off the beaten path."
With a $100,000 grant from the Hayden Foundation, the university tried again, installing video screens and lighting to transform the Violet Cafe into the Ultra Violet at night. Ms. Arthur said that part of the start-up money went to insulating the ceiling to deaden sound.
Last fall, before work on the club began, Goddard students and university administrators met to discuss the project. Views now diverge on what was said then.
 
Soundproofing Weak
 Austin Hodgens, a senior film major from Brooklyn and the Goddard dormitory government president, said that Naomi Levine, the university's vice president for external affairs, assured him that if the noise became a problem the club would be closed.
Although both Ms. Levine and Ms. Arthur agree that the soundproofing does not work as they hoped, they insist that they made no such promise.
"I assured them we will take care of the problem," Ms. Levine said. "We thought that this would be an asset to the student body."
Right now, she said, she wants to change the form of entertainment at the Ultra Violet and the use of the rooms above the club.
Ms. Levine said last week that the four rooms directly over the club will not be used by dorm residents next year and may be converted into recreation space or a place for commuter students to lodge.

HEADLINE: CRAFTS;
A History Told in Patches and Patterns

BYLINE: By PATRICIA MALARCHER

 BODY:
THE fragmented patterns of American quilts can serve as lenses, revealing multifaceted views of historic and domestic events. Through the colors, textures and associative value of fabrics the quilts also convey the "feeling tone" of their periods. Both effects can be found in a cluster of exhibitions now in the county that, collectively, chart a continuum of quilt-making from the 18th through the 20th centuries.
Forty quilts spanning two centuries were assembled for "Quilts: The Patterns of History" in the Castle Gallery at New Rochelle College. "Piece by Piece," a presentation of a dozen quilts at the Rye Arts Center, at 51 Milton Road, focuses on the early 20th century, especially the lesser-known quilts of the 1920's and 30's. And a block away, the Rye Historical Society, at 1 Purchase Street, has a "mini exhibition" of 19th-century quilts from New York State. 
"We wanted to give an overview of quilts that would reflect historical events," explained Barbara Davis of New Rochelle, a historian who organized the show at the college with Helaine Fendelman of Scarsdale, an antiques authority. The show will run through April 21. Ms. Fendelman will present a lecture, open to the public, at the college's Romita Auditorium on Wednesday at 10:30 A.M. The admission fee is $5.
 
Panoramas of the Past
 The panoramic sweep of time and subject ranges from the days of clipper ships (a 1790 tufted seaman's quilt) to the present (a 1990 quilt by a black feminist). The proliferation of the American flag as a bold motif lends a note of timeliness to the show.
The past seems intimately present in a wool flannel quilt from Pennsylvania made from Civil War uniforms -- both blue and gray. The urgency of the 19th-century suffragette movement permeates the fund-raising quilt in red, white and blue with stitched-on names of donors, among them Susan B. Anthony.
Although esthetic value was not a factor for selection, a number of the quilts are visually stunning. In an Alabama log cabin quilt, from up close one sees humble fabrics used for everyday apparel, while a distant vantage point transforms them into fields of glowing colors. "Lone Star," an eye-dazzler with triangles and vibrating yellows, reds and blues, shows another popular pattern.
"In Honor Shall Wave," is a pictorial "whole cloth" quilt made of uncut fabric rather than patches. From edge to edge this is covered with images outlined in thread. Whether the pictures were commercially available, their random juxtapositions -- for instance, a zebra stands a few inches from a spinning wheel -- suggest a quirky personal vision.
A 1920's "Patch Poster" by Cora Scovil, who invented the department store mannequin, seems to anticipate contemporary art quilts not otherwise represented here. Having been a guest in a prominent home, Ms. Scovil made her hosts a quilt that depicted their daughters at camp -- lifesize, in real khaki for the uniforms.
"Being in Total Control of Herself," curiously titled for a quilt that depicts a somewhat tipsy Statue of Liberty, was created by Yvonne Wells, a contemporary artist updating the folk tradition of black American quilts.
A common theme connecting the shows are the precisely geometric Amish quilts, in which the dominant black elements keep rich, clear colors apart. Both shows also contain crazy quilts, with energetic surfaces created by wildly irregular pieces of satin and velvet as well as commemorative ribbons and memorabilia. Although the style is quintessentially Victorian, the Rye crazy quilt on exhibit was dated 1915.
Also in both are pieces borrowed from Robert and Ardis James of Chappaqua, whose extensive quilt collection has been discussed in newspapers and magazines.
 
Flowered Feed Sacks
 Curated by Virginia Avery of Port Chester, a master quilter and author, the show at the Rye Center spotlights the largely unrecognized quilt movement during the Depression.
According to information that accompanies the exhibition, quilting then was encouraged as a means of being frugal and industrious. In 1933, the label text states, 2,500 entries were submitted to a quilt contest sponsored by Sears. The winning quilt, which received a $1,200 award, was presented to Eleanor Roosevelt.
Except for an Art Deco shooting star design and an interpretation of "Sunbonnet Sue" -- inspired by a 1902 children's book, this motif was a fad in the 20's and 30's -- most of the quilts at the center are similar in pattern to their antecedents in the 19th century.
Still, their fabrics lend them a period flavor. For instance, the economic stringency of the 1930's was reflected in a quilt made from feed sacks with floral patterns. As a product of giveaway materials, this contrasts with a turn-of-the-century quilt in New Rochelle sewn from patches of silk that were promotional incentives in cigarette packages.
A quilt made from 4,000 small hexagons in a variation on the pattern called Grandmother's flower garden was the tour de force among the center's quilts.
Enlivening this gallery iare the crafts people working on a communal quilt. Each of its 42 patches was designed and executed by a local organization. Each patch symbolizes the work of the organization. After a tour to the churches, schools and other institutions represented in it, it will be given to the Rye Historical Society.
The quilts here at the art center, and at the historical society, will be on view through March 3.
As do the other two shows, the display at the Rye Historical Society includes an appliqued album quilt. Made by one woman for her granddaughter, this one departs from the tradition of the album quilt as a collective effort of friends.
The other two quilts, described as "important to Rye" by the curator, Kathlene Scheuer, were made by Amanda Haywood Halstead, the wife of a prominent Rye citizen, for her trousseau. Another quilt from the society's collection is in the New Rochelle show.
Hours at the Castle Gallery in New Rochelle are 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Tuesdays through Fridays and noon to 4 P.M. on weekends.
The Rye Art Center is open Mondays through Saturdays from 10 to 4 and Sundays from noon to 4.
The Rye Historical Society is open Wednesdays, Thursdays, Fridays and Sundays from 2:30 to 4:30 P.M.; Tuesdays and Saturdays from 12:30 to 4:30 P.M.

CORRECTION-DATE: March 10, 1991, Sunday

 CORRECTION:

HEADLINE: WHAT'S DOING IN: Key West

BYLINE: By CATHERINE SKIPP; CATHERINE SKIPP, who works in the Miami bureau of The Times, has visited Key West many times.

 BODY:
Key West has found a new voice of late. It's German, French, Dutch, Spanish and Japanese. Foreign tourists from Europe, the Far East and South America are packing Mallory Square at sunset, filling up the Conch Train on tours and snapping up sponges, cigars and shells that are native to the southernmost United States city.
This new Key West is more gentrified and prosperous. Gone is the overwhelming presence of tacky T-shirt shops and noisy dive bars, although enough remain to let the visitor know that Key West is proud of its checkered past. In their place along Duval Street, the Old Town's main drag, are increasing numbers of upscale shops and cafes selling tropical clothing, art, perfumes and food from around the globe. 
 Key West enjoys a rich history from the days when its residents made a good living salvaging shipwrecks tossed upon its shores. In 1912 the Overseas Railway was completed to Key West, making the city an overnight stop between Miami and Havana.
Key West dances to a different beat from the mainland, a mixture of Old Havana built in New England and painted in the crazy colors of the Caribbean. The town is very lively for its size but the pace is 16 r.p.m.
 
Culture
 Several small theaters provide diversions. The Red Barn Theater (319 Duval Street; 296-9911) presents "Smoke on the Mountain," a gospel musical, until March 17, followed by "Sunshine," a new play by William Mastrosimone, the author of "Extremities," March 27 to April 14. Curtain is at 8 P.M. Wednesday through Sunday. Tickets $15; no credit cards.
The Waterfront Playhouse (Mallory Square; 294-5015) will present "Driving Miss Daisy" through today, "Eastern Standard," a comedy drama about yuppies living in New York, March 20 to 24 and 27 to 31. Tickets $12; no credit cards.
The Tennessee Williams Fine Arts Center (5901 West Junior College Road, Stock Island; 296-9081) will present the Jose Limon Dance Company next Tuesday and Wednesday, dancers from the New York City Ballet March 5 and 6, "Mask, Myth and Magic" with the magician Jeff McBride on March 14 and "Death Trap" from March 21 to 23 and 29 and 30. Tickets from $10 to $20 except for the New York City Ballet, when prices will range from $20 to $30.
 Chamber music is performed at the Casa Gato, a building that dates to 1885 (1209 Virginia Street; 296-5713ok). The pianist Mack McCrae will perform on March 17. Tickets $12.50.
 
Sightseeing
 The Conch Tour Train (Mallory Square or Roosevelt Boulevard; 294-5161) is a series of open-air cars that run on the town's streets, making a 14-mile, 90-minute narrated trip. Tours leave from Roosevelt Boulevard every hour on the half hour between 9:30 A.M. and 4:30 P.M. and from Mallory Square every half hour between 9 A.M. and 4:30 P.M. Trips are $11.
Another 90-minute tour is offered by Old Town Trolley (1910 North Roosevelt Boulevard at Garrison Bight; 296-6688), which has pickups at most of the major hotels and four stops downtown. It allows passengers to get off one trolley and board another one later. Tickets are $12. Trolleys run daily every 30 minutes from 8:55 A.M. to 4:55 P.M. from North Roosevelt Boulevard.
Mel Fisher Maritime Heritage Society and Museum (200 Greene Street; 294-2633) displays jewels, coins and gold and silver bars brought up from the wrecks of the Atocha and Margarita, two Spanish galleons sunk in a hurricane in 1622 40 miles southwest of Key West. Open daily from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Admission $5.
Ernest Hemingway Home and Museum (907 Whitehead Street; 294-1575) is a two-story Spanish Colonial house built in 1851, which the author bought in 1931. A 30-minute guided tour begins every 10 minutes from 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. Admission $6, $1.50 for children.
Key West Aquarium (1 Whitehead Street; 296-2051) features hundreds of fish that inhabit the waters around Key West and a touch tank with starfish, horseshoe crabs and, of course, conchs. Open daily 10 A.M. to 7 P.M. Admission $5.
 
Night Life
 Every evening begins at Mallory Dock, where Key West gathers to watch the sun go down. Street performers stage everything from juggling, escape acts to card tricks.
The best by far is "Dominique and His Circus Cats." The cats, Spot, Piggy, Mars and Sharkey, look like ordinary house pets, but this Frenchman has transformed them into stars in a miniature lion-taming act, flaming hoops and all. Street vendors sell jewelry, basketwork and painted T-shirts.
At Flagler's, a restaurant at the Casa Marina Resort (1500 Reynolds Street; 296-3535), the Toni Bishop combo performs Wednesday through Saturday. Other entertainers appear the rest of the week. Henry Flagler's 1921 hotel provides an elegant backdrop for Miss Bishop's contemporary jazz and blues from 9 P.M. to 1 A..M. No cover.
 Havana Docks, at the Pier House Resort (1 Duval Street; 296-4600) hops on Friday and Saturday nights with sailors from the nearby Navy base. Live entertainment nightly with a $2 cover. Open Sunday to Thursday from 4 P.M. to 2 A.M., Friday and Saturday until 4 A.M.
Sloppy Joe's (201 Duval Street; 294-5717) was one of Hemingway's hangouts. It is a popular spot, though loud and sometimes rowdy, and is open 9 A.M. to 4 A.M. from Monday to Saturday and noon to 4 A.M. on Sunday, with live entertainment in the afternoon and evening. After 8 P.M. there is usually a cover charge, either $1 or $2.
Capt. Tony's Saloon (428 Greene Street; 294-1838) is a block away and smaller. It was built in 1852 and was used as a morgue and ice house. It was also the site of Sloppy Joe's until 1938, when Sloppy Joe's moved to Duval Street. Open 10 A.M. to 4 A.M.
 
Getting Around
 Some of the best ways to see the Old Town section of Key West are by foot, bike, moped or scooter.
Bubba's Fun Rentals (705 Duval Street; 294-2618) rents 10-speed mountain bikes for $10 a day ($5 for four hours, $8 for eight hours) or $40 by the week.
Tropical Bicycles & Scooter Rentals (1300 Duval Street; 294-8136) rents bikes for $5 a day or $25 by the week and Honda Elite scooters for $23 a day ($12 for four hours, $18 for eight hours) or $89.95 by the week. Cars also available for $22.95 a day.
 
The Outdoors
 Fort Zachary Taylor State Historic Site and Smathers Beach are the only public beaches on the island. They are pleasant but not exceptional.
At Smathers Beach, Sunset Watersports (296-2554) rents windsurfers ($15 an hour), jet skis ($35 a half hour), 16-foot Hobie cats ($30 an hour) and offers parasailing at $50 for a ride of eight to 10 minutes.
 Deep-sea fishing is readily available; there are about 60 charter boats in Key West. Bill Kieldsen at Fishbuster (Garrison Bight Marina, Eaton Street and Roosevelt Boulevard; 296-9969) runs a 56-foot Lamay and charges $100 a seat for a half day and $150 a seat for a full day. Full boat is $600, maximum of six people; $400 for the half day. For fishing for tarpon and bonefish, Capt. Marshall Cutchin (296-1020) leaves from Garrison Bight Marina and charges $200 a half day or $300 a full day for the boat, with a maximum of two people.
 
Places to Stay
 The Reach (Simonton Street, at the ocean; 296-5000) and the Hyatt Key West (601 Front Street; 296-9900) are the two newer luxury hotels in town, on opposite ends of Old Town. Both offer a variety of water sports, bike and scooter rental and dining. Rates at both start at $215 for a double.
Marriott's Casa Marina (Reynolds Street on the ocean; 296-3535) is a beautiful old hotel that has been expanded and renovated many times since it opened in 1921. The public rooms are spectacular and the hotel has the best beach in Key West. It offers a lavish brunch for $24.95 per person on Sunday. Rates from $210 to $695 for a two-bedroom suite.
The Pier House (1 Duval Street; 296-4600) is close to all downtown activities. It has a small beach. Rates from $235 to $725.
 The Marquesa (600 Fleming Street; 292-1919) is a beautifully restored Victorian home that is on the National Register of Historic Places. Fifteen rooms around a pool cost from $175 to $275 a night.
The Curry Mansion Inn (511 Caroline Street; 294-5349) is a wonderful Victorian home that is open to the public as a museum during the day. The rooms are small and nicely appointed with vintage furnishings. There is a swimming pool where breakfast and cocktails are served. Prices from $140 to $200 a night, including breakfast, cocktails and hors d'oeuvres at happy hour.
Budget choice: Most of the economy chains have hotels on Route 1 coming into Old Town but Holiday Inn La Concha (430 Duval Street; 296-2991) is right in the heart of Old Town. It was built in 1925 and was renovated and reopened in 1987. Rates from $87 to $400 a night. The rooms on the second floor overlooking Duval Street can be noisy.
 
Dining
 Seafood is the mainstay of the island's fare and much of the fish served in restaurants is caught locally.
Cafe des Artistes (1007 Simonton Street; 294-7100) serves local seafood prepared with French techniques in a pleasant setting; some tables are outdoors on a balcony. Lamb, veal and duck are also on the menu. Open for dinner from 6 to 11 P.M. Dinner for two, about $100 with wine.
 A nice choice for an elegant evening on the town is Cafe Marquesa (600 Fleming Street; 292-1244 or 292-1919),
a beautifully decorated, well-run small restaurant serving new American cuisine. Dinner for two with wine $54 to $60.
Dim Sum (613 1/2 Duval Street; 294-6230) serves a wonderful mix of Asian food. Open daily for dinner; reservations suggested. Dinner for two about $45 with wine.
 La Creperie (124 Duval Street; 294-7677) is a small restaurant owned by Rene Cagnat, a third-generation French chef. The most expensive thing on the dinner menu is langouste au beurre blanc at $19.50. Open Monday to Friday from 11:30 A.M. to 5 P.M. for lunch; dinner weekdays from 5 to 10 P.M. and Saturday and Sunday from 6 to 10 P.M. Dinner for two with wine averages $40, lunch about $17.

CORRECTION-DATE: March 17, 1991, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article on Feb. 24 about Key West misidentified the southernmost city in the United States. It is Hilo, Hawaii.

HEADLINE: Lumbering in the Age of the Baby Tree

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK

DATELINE: PORTLAND, Ore.

 BODY:
Harry A. Merlo, chief executive of the Louisiana-Pacific Corporation, has always been willing to move in one direction when the rest of the forest products industry was moving in another. He bought forest land when others were selling and fought the labor unions when others were negotiating. He largely shuns Wall Street, paper-pushing and industry trade groups, preferring instead to cut the figure of a swashbuckler, overseeing his empire by flying from sawmill to sawmill, decked out in cowboy boots and a leather jacket.
"Harry Merlo is considered kind of a rogue in the industry," said John Maack, an analyst with the Crabbe-Huson Company, a Portland money management firm. 
 Now, however, Mr. Merlo is pursuing an audacious plan that the rest of the industry is having to follow. He is trying to create a forest products company that doesn't need trees.
Well, not exactly all trees, but at least the big trees upon which the industry has relied until now.
The supply of those big trees, which can be made into prime lumber, is rapidly disappearing in the United States. Forest products companies say it is because environmentalists, worried about such things as the spotted owl, are unnecessarily restricting logging. Environmentalists say it is because rapacious lumber companies have cut down the big trees faster than they can be replenished.
For whatever reason, the industry is undergoing a major shift from an era in which it took big pieces of wood and cut them into smaller products to one in which it takes small pieces and builds them into bigger products. And Mr. Merlo, a driven man who rose from rags to riches, has been at the forefront.
"He probably has had more vision in understanding the dynamics of the wood products industry than any other manager in the business," said Evadna Lynn, forest products analyst for Dean Witter Reynolds.
Instead of waiting for big trees to grow, Mr. Merlo envisions an era in which trees are grown quickly and cut by machines at a young age. From there, the trees are chipped into little pieces, then glued together to make boards. Such engineered wood products, as they are sometimes called, can be made with less manpower and less money than waiting for trees to ripen to old age and using lumberjacks to cut them down.
Indeed, Mr. Merlo says, in some cases forests won't even be needed. Instead, trees will be grown on agricultural "fiber farms," just as farmers now grow corn.
But environmentalists say Louisiana-Pacific is far from environmentally benign and has always tried to get away with as much as it can. While some say that harvesting young trees on farmland is acceptable, they are irked by the prospect that trees in the forest will also be cut down at a young age.
 
More Efficient at Abuse?
"They are just more efficient at abusing resources than any other forest products company I know of," said Gail Lucas, head of the forest products task force for the Sierra Club in California. "Growing baby trees and grinding them up to make products is not laudable."
Added Eric Swanson, an environmentalist in Branscomb, Calif., "We're ending up with a totally redesigned forest that's just a parody."
Indeed, if California is any indication, environmentalists might shift some of their efforts from preserving old trees to preventing the premature cutting of young trees. Last year, the California Department of Forestry prohibited Louisiana-Pacific from logging in an area that had last been harvested 15 years ago, the first time the regulators had stopped trees from being cut because they were too young.
Mr. Merlo has been implementing his vision for 10 years. Portland-based Louisiana-Pacific has become the industry leader in marketing a product known as oriented strand board, which is made by gluing and pressing together wood flakes from trees like aspen that formerly had little commercial value and could be acquired cheaply.
Oriented strand board now accounts for 20 percent of the market once held by plywood, which is made by peeling layers from large trees and gluing them together. The strand board is more uniform than plywood, costs less and could continue to gain share. "It takes a lot of people and a good log to make plywood," Mr. Merlo said in an interview here.
Engineered wood products account for 26 percent of Louisiana-Pacific's revenues, which totaled $1.79 billion in 1990. Meanwhile, the company has reduced its dependence on lumber from big trees to 32 percent of revenues, from 53 percent 10 years ago.
Now the 65-year-old Mr. Merlo has embarked upon another new way of making products without using big trees. His company has started making gypsum wallboard using recycled newspaper. Wastepaper, he said, "is the largest remaining forest that has no owls and woodpeckers, and you don't even need a chain saw."
 
Some Good Numbers
 So far, the moves have largely met with success. Louisiana-Pacific's revenues have gone up about 50 percent in the last five years and its profit margins in wood products have generally been above average.
Mr. Merlo's record is not universally praised, however. Some analysts say that Louisiana-Pacific, unlike most other lumber companies, chose not to get heavily into the paper business, which is more capital intensive but less volatile than wood products. The result is that Louisiana-Pacific is hurt more than many others by the current steep slump in housing starts.
In the fourth quarter of 1990, the company reported its first loss since 1982 and it has been closing its mills for days at a time to cut expenses. Nonetheless, a strong balance sheet should allow it to ride out the slump.
Mr. Merlo is not pursuing his small-tree strategy because he likes environmentalists. But he realizes that environmental pressures will make big trees increasingly expensive and less available. "I don't think there is any way short of shutting down all the toilet tissue mills for six months to convince Americans that growing trees and harvesting them is good for the country," he said.
The strategy also fits in with Mr. Merlo's emphasis on cutting costs to the bone. "No one gets more out of a log for less than Louisiana-Pacific," he once wrote in an annual report. By using wood chips, the company can use small pieces of the tree that once had to be left on the ground.
Pressures to cut young trees are intensifying, industry executives and analysts say. Companies have harvested the easy pickings -- the trees that accumulated in the centuries before logging began. While trees have been replanted, some companies are facing a gap of 30 to 40 years before those trees reach full size.
Moreover, a tree grows fastest in its earliest years, while older trees might grow only a small percentage each year. A tree's growth is in some sense a measure of a company's return in it and companies say it makes no economic sense to earn a return of a few percent a year when interest rates are higher than that.
Mr. Merlo has always had his eye on the bottom line. The son of Italian immigrants, he grew up in Stirling City, a lumber town in northern California owned by the Diamond Match Company. His father piled boards in the lumber yard and made wine at home. His mother ran the town boarding house.
Mr. Merlo now talks about his mother, Clotilde, who died more than 20 years ago, in reverential terms. "I've seen him cry when he talks about her," said one executive.
Mr. Merlo said his mother taught him "common sense and courage," as well as a keen sense of frugality. According to one often-told story, young Harry salvaged bones and tripe from the town butcher for his mother to use in soup, thereby learning early in life how to make a living off what others considered waste.
 
Taking Over
 Mr. Merlo, who earned a degree from the University of California at Berkeley, was an executive at a small lumber company when it was purchased by Georgia-Pacific, an industry giant, in 1967.
Mr. Merlo helped improve profitability in Georgia-Pacific's California operations, and was one of the company's top executives in the early 1970's, when the Federal Trade Commission ruled that Georgia-Pacific was monopolizing the Southern plywood business. In an antitrust settlement, a new company, which took the name Louisiana-Pacific, was spun off in 1973 with Mr. Merlo as second in command. He took over in 1974.
Much of the strategy Mr. Merlo has followed at Louisiana-Pacific was born of necessity. The company began life without much timberland. Whatever unspoiled redwood forests it did have were taken from it in 1978 and incorporated into the Redwood National Park in California.
The company supplies only about 25 percent of its own wood, while other large competitors provide themselves with anywhere from 40 percent to nearly 100 percent. The rest of Louisiana-Pacific's wood comes from private landowners and from national forests. It is a major purchaser from the Tongass National Forest in Alaska.
Louisiana-Pacific does not invent its new products, but it is adept at implementing ideas from elsewhere, mainly from Europe, where the big forests have long been gone.
Mr. Merlo first came upon oriented strand board at an exhibit of a Canadian company at a Las Vegas trade show in the late 70's. He immediately left for Canada to tour oriented strand board plants. Other American companies also began getting into waferwood, as the product once was called, in the early 80's, but Louisiana-Pacific was the most aggressive.
 
Still Using Trees
 Mr. Merlo is not completely abandoning trees and lumber, however. Louisiana-Pacific is still the nation's largest producer of redwood lumber. In 1986, Mr. Merlo took advantage of the last industry downturn to double the company's ownership of timberlands. And last year, Louisiana-Pacific was among the first companies to explore the use of logs from Siberia, a huge potential source.
The company has also been more aggressive than others in cutting labor costs. In 1983, it was one of a group of large timber companies that bargained jointly with the unions in the Northwest. But Mr. Merlo broke with the other companies and demanded wage cutbacks. A long, bitter and sometimes violent strike ensued, but in the end, Mr. Merlo was the victor as the unions were decertified at the company's sawmills.
Last summer, Mr. Merlo raised the wrath of organized labor once more when Louisiana-Pacific became the first timber company to open a plant in Mexico. Raw lumber from California is shipped there to be dried and processed by laborers who get only a fraction of what California workers are paid.
Mr. Merlo is known for running a tight ship. Although the company has 13,000 employees, there are only about 100 people in its headquarters here. And it has only two vice presidents -- Lee Simpson for operations and John Hart for finance. After them come division managers, who have responsibility for a geographic area or a particular type of business.
Mr. Merlo practices what might be called management by flying around. He puts in more than 300,000 miles each year on the company's fleet of 15 aircraft, visiting Louisiana-Pacific's 120 plants and mills in 24 states and two Canadian provinces.
Mr. Merlo can be charismatic. He works hard for charities like the Salvation Army. And associates say he has been known to make gestures like anonymously buying a car for a needy nun.
But he is also extremely aggressive, can chew up those with whom he disagrees and has fired or driven away many top managers. Associates say he is obsessed with assuring himself a place in industry history.
Mr. Merlo has certain rules of behavior that everyone in the company must follow. Factories and mills, for instance, must be spotless. The rules even extend to personal fitness. Mr. Merlo detests overweight people, to the extent that weight plays a role in determining bonuses and promotions. "He doesn't like anyone with a big gut," said Tom Mock, sales manager at the company's plant in Red Bluff, Calif. "To him, that's a weakness."
 
Rented Mansion
 Mr. Merlo is also known for wearing fur coats and other touches of flamboyance. He lives in a mansion in Portland, valued on the company's books at more than $800,000, that he rents from Louisiana-Pacific for $2,200 a month. He also has a ranch in California's wine country.
And despite Mr. Merlo's emphasis on rules of behavior, Louisiana-Pacific has a reputation for pushing the rules to the limit. It was found guilty of fraud in its purchase of Fibreboard in 1978. (It spun off Fibreboard in 1988 to escape the mounting asbestos-related liability claims facing that company, which made asbestos before Louisiana-Pacific bought it.) And it was sued in 1989 by the Government for pollution at a pulp mill in California, a case that is pending. The company said those incidents sound more serious than they really are.
A key question facing Louisiana-Pacific is what happens when Mr. Merlo retires.
The heir apparent is James Eisses, manager of Louisiana-Pacific's northern division, who will take over the No. 2 spot when Mr. Simpson retires in June. An engineer by training who is said to be cut from the same aggressive cloth as Mr. Merlo, the 54-year-old Mr. Eisses has been instrumental in the company's move into engineered wood products.
But Mr. Merlo has no plans to retire. "My grandfather died in an accident when he was 98 and my father lived to 99," he said.
That thought might keep his competitors awake at night for many years to come.
 
 
 
TREATING TREES LIKE A CROP
 ELK CREEK, Calif. -- In hilly oak country, eucalyptus and poplar trees are growing in neat rows lined by black rubber irrigation hoses. "This is really more like agriculture, not forestry," said Greg Kostick, the project leader at the Louisiana-Pacific Corporation's experimental "fiber farm."
The fiber farm could represent the future of the forest products industry -- at least in the vision of Harry A. Merlo.
With the shift from lumber products to engineered wood products that can be made with chips, Louisiana-Pacific and other companies no longer need big trees. In the future, they might not even need the forest.
Louisiana-Pacific is growing trees here on agricultural land, using agricultural techniques like irrigation and fertilization.
The 250-acre plot, on the edge of California's Central Valley, is the site of an old company sawmill that was shut in 1980 when the supply of trees from the nearby hills ran out.
The trees on the fiber farm will reach 60 feet in height and 8 to 10 inches in diameter in about seven years, large enough to be used for pulp or made into chips for use in waferwood. By contrast, pine, fir and other forest trees have to grow for 30 to 60 years.
By packing the trees close together and cutting quickly, the yield might be about twice as great as that of a typical forest, Mr. Kostick said.
The fiber farm has other advantages as well. Because the trees are planted in rows, they can be easily harvested by machines. And since this is farmland, not forest, environmentalists have fewer objections to cutting the trees.
The drawback is that while a forest tends to grow without much human help, tree farming needs as much tending as other types of agriculture. As a result, the economic viability of such fiber farms "is still up in the air," said Keith Gilless, a forest economist at the University of California at Berkeley.
Mr. Merlo, however, thinks he has an answer for that. He is looking at putting the fiber farms in Mexico or other Central American countries, where the warm climate would make the trees grow even faster and irrigation would not be necessary.

 
 
A MORE PROFITABLE PLYWOOD
 RED BLUFF, Calif. -- The Louisiana-Pacific Corporation is the leading supplier of oriented strand board, a plywood-substitute made from wafers of wood. Now it is trying to use those boards to make products with higher profit margins.
At a new plant here, the company is making I-beams that use regular lumber for the flanges but oriented strand board for the center member. The I-beams are being sold in place of big pieces of lumber for use in floor joists and roof trusses.
Elsewhere, the company is using oriented strand board to make products like siding. Different patterns can be pressed onto the strand board, giving it the appearance of fine wood.
"The world is really a substrate," Mr. Merlo said. "What you see is not what you really get."
He pointed to his own office in Portland as an example. The walls look to be made of white oak, but the oak is only one thirty-second of an inch thick. Underneath it is oriented strand board.

HEADLINE: Commercial Property: Southern Textile Mills;
Old Plants Don't Die -- They Just Go on the Market

BYLINE: By LYN RIDDLE

DATELINE: WHITMIRE, S.C.

 BODY:
ON the outskirts of this town of 2,100 people is the Mount Vernon Mills textile mill, whose owners would greatly like to sell it. They did once, in 1987, after deciding to get out of the kitchen-towel business. But the buyer went bankrupt in 1989 and Mount Vernon foreclosed on the 190,000-square-foot building and its 25 acres.
Now, with any luck, a second sale is about to be completed, but Mount Vernon had to cut its asking price of $1.4 million considerably, said Ned Cochrane, secretary and counsel for the textile company, which is based in Greenville, S.C. He declined to disclose the current price (in 1989 it was $1.8 million). 
 "There are a lot of mills for sale, especially since the economy slowed a year or two ago," Mr. Cochrane said. "We had a few nibbles, but the real estate situation is getting worse. It could take three years or more to sell a mill." Which is why, he said, Mount Vernon cut its price.
In the last five years, the number of Southern textile mills on the market rose sharply as textile companies closed unprofitable plants or replaced aged ones. And brokers say price is the key factor in getting a sale.
"It's like going to the store when mini-skirts are in fashion and finding only antebellum hoop skirts," said Gorham Boyington, a broker with the Keenan Company commercial brokerage in Columbia, S.C. "They won't sell for much. With these mills you can't consider replacement cost. They are no longer functional in their original use."
No firm figures are available on how many mills are for sale in the Southeast, but in South Carolina alone there are 40. North Carolina, Georgia and Alabama probably each have twice as many, said Mr. Boyington.
The American Textile Manufactuers Institute, based in Washington, says there are 6,000 mills in the country, 75 percent of them in the Southeast. They range from huge, multi-storied and decades-old brick structures to newer one-story plants spread out across the rural piedmont and designed with central air-conditioning. All have large, open rooms and low ceilings, usually no more than 14 feet.
Prices range from just over a dollar a square foot to nearly $15, though one cotton mill in Greenville sold in 1983 for 67 cents a square foot.
Some companies, unable to sell their abandoned mills, have even given the buildings away, usually to local governments, as Mount Vernon did in Fries, Va. The town, hoping the mill will make money, is trying to lease the building.
Mills have been sold to textile companies, but most have gone to other types of manufacturers, like a picture-framing operation that bought a Chester, S.C., mill for $480,850 ($1.63 a square foot) in 1988 or an electronics company that bought a 266,000-square-foot Great Falls, S.C., mill for $1.13 a square foot in 1983.
"It is not necessarily harder to sell a textile mill than other industrial buildings," said Mr. Boyington. "You've got to be creative and come up with alternate uses because most of the buyers are outside the textile industry."
Some buyers even have nonmanufacturing uses in mind, as in Greensboro, N.C., where a 200,000-square-foot cotton mill was renovated for an outlet mall. Jerry Olson, the leasing agent for the mall, known as Cotton Mill Square, said: "It is immaterial whether it's a strip shopping center, an office tower or a textile mill, they're all real estate, and if you don't have the right location, you're not going to make it."
After nine years in operation, Cotton Mill Square is 85 percent leased.
 IN COLUMBIA, S.C., the capital and geographic center of the state, a group of investors bought a mill near the University of South Carolina in 1983 and converted it into 170 rental apartments. Most are occupied by students. And in Allendale, near the Georgia border, an 85,000-square-foot warehouse was sold to Allendale County, which used state and Federal grants to renovate it. Last August, the building was leased to a yarn-processing company.
Two of the three mills formerly owned by J.P. Stevens & Company in the small town of Great Falls, S.C., have been sold in the last few years. Flextronics Southeast of Fremont, Calif., an electronics company, bought a 266,000-square-foot mill for $300,580 in 1983. A second mill, with 159,000 square feet, has been sold three times, first in 1983 for $203,520, then in 1987 for $244,860 and finally in 1990 to an art distributor for $306,870.
Great Falls's largest mill, with 319,000 square feet, has been vacant since 1984 and is being reserved for future expansion by West Point Pepperell of West Point, Ga.
Mayor James Baker of Great Falls said he has worked aggressively to find someone to lease, if not buy, the three mills in town.
"We have had some degree of interest," he said. "But because of the size of these buildings and because they were built as textile mills, they are somewhat limited in their use."
Recently, with an 11.3 percent unemployment rate, the fourth-highest in the state, townspeople stopped pinning their hopes on textile mills and, with a Federal grant, broke ground on a 100-acre industrial park.
Mr. Boyington said he started to see textile mills on the market in the 1970's when the multi-storied mills of the early 1900's could not adequately handle the new, larger machines. The pace of sales picked up in the 1980's as textile companies divested themselves of unprofitable divisions, especially those hardest hit by imports, said Mr. Cochrane.
MOST mills on the market are in rural areas or small towns, although some are at the edges of some of the Southeast's largest cities.
One plant that did not sell is in Greenville, South Carolina's largest city, in the northwestern section of the state about 145 miles northeast of Atlanta. The 1.6 million-square-foot plant had been offered for sale by Hoechst Celenese for four years before the company, based in Bridgewater, N.J., took it off the market with plans to develop a business park at the site.
Among the largest mills now on the market is a 930,000-square-foot building in Chester, S.C., near Great Falls. The asking price is $10.5 million for the 26-year-old, one-story building. The owner, Megastar, based in St. Louis, is also trying to sell a 101,000-square-foot sweater manufacturing plant in Union County, S.C.
Mr. Cochrane, whose company has sold six mills in the last few years, said the hardest ones to sell are those that are multi-storied, usually three or four floors. These are the oldest mills, and usually the windows are bricked up.
Mr. Cochrane said the most successful conversions have been by those who divided the buildings, leasing sections to various businesses, rather than trying to find one tenant for a huge amount of space.
This is the second wave of real estate sales in the South for textile companies. The first began in the 1950's and continued into the 60's when companies sold the houses in what were known as the mill villages.
The one- and two-bedroom clapboard houses, jampacked on straight, narrow streets close to a mill, were built as homes for the workers in the days when the paternalistic companies, needing to get workers to their rural facilities, offered not only housing but also services ranging from birth assistance to funerals.
Employees bought many of the houses in the mill villages in the 1940's and 50's, and although some of the mills have closed and are for sale, most of villages remain, with the houses individually owned.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 17; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 912 words

HEADLINE: Indians in Aspic

BYLINE: By Michael Dorris; Michael Dorris is the author of "The Broken Cord," and, with his wife, Louise Erdrich, the forthcoming "The Crown of Columbus."

DATELINE: CORNISH, N.H.

 BODY:
The Sioux and Lieut. John Dunbar, the character enthusiastically played by Kevin Costner in "Dances With Wolves," meet auspiciously: He's naked, and that so disconcerts a group of mounted warriors that the naive young soldier lives to tell the tale, a sort of Boy Scout Order of the Arrow ritual carried to the nth power.
Dunbar, renamed Dances With Wolves, quickly earns merit badges in Pawnee-bashing and animal telepathy, and marries Stands With a Fist (Mary McDonnell), a passionate young widow who just happens to be a white captive cum Campfire Girl of impressive cross-cultural accomplishments. Eventually the "With" family strikes out on their own -- the nucleus of a handsome new Anglo tribe -- sadder, wiser and certainly more sensitive as a result of their native American immersion. 
 Mr. Costner follows in a long tradition of literary and cinematic heroes who have discovered Indians. Robinson Crusoe did it off the coast of Brazil, Natty Bumppo did it in New York State and everyone from Debra Paget ("Broken Arrow," 1950) and Natalie Wood ("The Searchers," 1956) to Dustin Hoffman ("Little Big Man," 1970) and Richard Harris ("A Man Called Horse," 1970) has done it in Hollywood.
Usually these visits do not bode well for the aboriginal hosts -- just ask the Mohicans. Appreciative white folks always seem to show up shortly before the cavalry (who are often looking for them) or Manifest Destiny, and record the final days of peace before the tribe is annihilated. Readers and viewers of such sagas are left with a predominant emotion of regret for a golden age now but a faint memory. In the imaginary mass media world of neat beginnings, middles and ends, American Indian society, whatever its virtues and fascinations as an arena for Euro-American consciousness-raising, is definitely past tense.
Thematically virtually all of these works share a subtle or not so subtle message: Indians may be poor, they may at first seem strange or forbidding or primitive, but by golly once you get to know them they have a thing or two to teach us about The Meaning of Life.
The tradition goes back a long way. Europeans like Jean-Jacques Rousseau and Karl May (the turn-of-this-century novelist whose books, a mixture of Louis L'Amour and the Hardy Boys, have been a rite of passage for generations of German youth) laid out a single range for Indians to inhabit: savage-savage to noble-savage. Indians embody the concept of "the other" -- a foreign, exotic, even cartoonish panorama against which "modern" (that is, white) men can measure and test themselves, and eventually, having proved their mettle in battle, be dubbed as natural leaders by their hosts.
Placed within the genre, "Dances With Wolves" shows some signs of evolution. Kevin Costner obviously spared no expense to achieve a sense of authenticity in his production. He filmed on the Pine Ridge reservation in South Dakota and defied conventional Hollywood wisdom to assemble a large and talented native American supporting cast. Great attention was paid to ethnographically correct costumes, and if the streets in the native camp seem a tad too spotless to be believed, at least the tepees are museum quality.
Impressively, large segments of the film are spoken in Lakota, the language of the western Sioux, and though the subtitles are stilted -- Indians in the movies seem incapable of using contractions -- they at least convey the impression that native Americans had an intellectual life.
When I saw "Dances With Wolves" at an advance screening, I predicted that it would be less than a box-office smash. Though spectacular to look it, it struck me as too long, too predictable, too didactic to attract a large audience. Twelve Academy Award nominations and $100 million in revenue later, was I ever wrong. In fact, the movie probably sells tickets precisely because it delivers the old-fashioned Indians that the ticket-buying audience expects to find. Dunbar is our national myth's everyman -- handsome, sensitive, flexible, right-thinking. He passes the test of the frontier, out-Indians the Indians, achieves a pure soul by encountering and surmounting the wilderness.
Yet, if "Dances With Wolves" had been about people who happen to be Indians, rather than about Indians (uniformly stoic, brave, nasty to their enemies, nice to their friends), it might have stood a better chance of acting as a bridge between societies that have for too long woodenly characterized each other.
With such tremendous popularity, the film is sure to generate a bubble of sympathy for the Sioux, but hard questions remain: Will this sentiment be practical, translating into public support for native American religious freedom cases before the Supreme Court, for restoration of Lakota sacred lands (the Black Hills) or water rights, for tribal sovereignty, for providing the money desperately needed by reservation health clinics? Pine Ridge is the most economically impoverished corner of America today, the Census Bureau says, but will its modern Indian advocates in business suits, men and women with laptop computers and perfect English, be the recipients of a tidal wave of good will?
Or will it turn out, once again, that the only good Indians -- the only Indians whose causes and needs we can embrace -- are lodged safely in the past, wrapped neatly in the blankets of history, magnets for our sympathy because they require nothing of us but tears in a dark theater?

LENGTH: 254 words

HEADLINE: Let's Do Something About Deposit Insurance

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "Safer Banks" (editorial, Feb. 7), on the Treasury Department's proposed overhaul of the banking system, you object to the suggested limit of Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation insurance to two $100,000 accounts to a person.
 A reasonable alternative is to have two types of accounts. Type A would have an insurance limit of $100,000 or less, and be limited to one or two to a person. Type B accounts would have no ceiling on the amount insured, but would be 100 percent collateralized with short-term government securities (or other extremely safe assets) marked to market daily. 
 Since banks would earn less on these assets than on others, they would pay a lower rate to those depositors. Large depositors who would be willing to accept such a lower rate are mainly financially unsophisticated people, who are not able to exercise meaningful "depositor surveillance" over banks. Hence, such a system would not interfere with the Treasury's idea of putting sophisticated depositors at risk, so that they discipline banks.
With type B accounts being fully collateralized, their unlimited insurance coverage would not increase the F.D.I.C.'s risk, unless banks pledge as collateral short-term Treasury securities they would have held in any case, thus reducing the average degree of safety of the assets that back Type A accounts. But banks are not likely to do so to any significant extent.
 
THOMAS MAYER
Professor of Economics
University of California
Davis, Calif., Feb. 10, 1991

HEADLINE: Welfare Cuts Will Haunt New York State in Later Social Costs

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In announcing their proposals to cut $1 billion from New York State's welfare system, State Senate Republican leaders characterized the system including Medicaid as a Cadillac when all we really need is a Ford or Chevy (news article, Jan. 31). Is public assistance a Cadillac program
* When grant levels are only 64.1 percent of the poverty level? 
 * When eligible people are repeatedly dropped from the rolls for administrative or reporting problems?
* When eligible people are required to participate in unavailable employment and training programs?
* When rent consumes 50 percent to 60 percent of the monthly grant for many recipients, leaving little for food, clothing and other essentials?
Is Medicaid a "Cadillac" program
* When only half the poor in the state are Medicaid-eligible?
* When few Medicaid recipients can find a physician to treat them?
* When hospitals turn Medicaid clients away despite receiving Bad Debt and Charity Care funds?
* When the only accessible care is a "Medicaid mill"?
Senate leaders probably arrived at the Cadillac analogy by comparing New York with other states. But no state has an adequate welfare system. All are products of a Federal system that has lacked the will to make meaningful changes. New York has attempted to overcome some basic design flaws and is thus ahead of most other states in trying to blunt the harsh effects of economic dislocation, failures in the education system, unequal opportunity, racism and social obstacles that keep the poor poor.
For New York to reduce its public assistance and medical care for the poor in order to relieve the state's fiscal crisis will only add to the state's problems, not reduce them. Retrenchment in welfare benefits and health care for the poor will, as in the past, lead to more homelessness, hunger, illness, more family breakups, more abused and neglected children, more crime and innumerable other social problems. To contain these problems, not solve them, will require more public dollars. These dollars will show up in the added costs for shelters, hospitals, food pantries, foster care, protective services, prisons, police and other public services.
 
WARREN G. BILLINGS
Albany, Feb. 13, 1991
 
The writer is executive director of the State Communities Aid Association, a public-policy organization.
