HEADLINE: Nordstrom Net Up 47.5%

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: SEATTLE, Feb. 24

 BODY:
Nordstrom Inc. said on Friday that its earnings leaped 47.5 percent in its fourth quarter, which ended on Jan. 31.
The fashion retailer's profits for the three months totaled $46.3 million, or 57 cents a share, compared with $31.4 million, or 39 cents a share, for the corresponding period a year earlier.
The company's revenues increased 5.2 percent, to $902.2 million, compared with $857.5 million a year ago.
Profits for the year were $115.8 million, or $1.42 a share, up slightly from $114.9 million, or $1.41 a share, the previous year. For the year, Nordstrom's revenues increased by 8.2 percent, from $2.67 billion to $2.89 billion.
The company is one of the most successful retailers in a business that has suffered acutely because of a nationwide recession. Nordstrom said in a statement that the earnings performance put the company in a good position as it prepared to open four new stores in 1991, one in Chicago in April, with later openings in Riverside, Calif., Edison, N.J., and Montgomery County, Md.
"The results for the fourth quarter indicate that the company has responded in a positive manner to the difficult retailing environment that exists today," Bruce Nordstrom, co-chairman, said in a statement.

HEADLINE: Tool Orders Fell 32.4% in January

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
New orders for American-made machine tools plunged 32.4 percent in January from an unusually high level in December, according to a report to be released today by the industry's trade association.
Industry analysts said that in addition to being skewed by the year-end surge in orders, the sharp decline stemmed from the weak demand that is typical in the winter months. 
 The level of orders for new machine tools fell to $199.9 million in January, from the December level of $295.8 million, according to the Association for Manufacturing Technology. The December figure was the highest monthly level of 1990.
The level of orders in January was virtually unchanged from that of January 1990.
 
'Orders Remained Firm'
 "At first glance, January orders look low when compared to the robust December figure," said Albert W. Moore, president of the association, which is based in McLean, Va. "But take a look at January a year ago, and you see a nearly identical first-of-the-year total. In spite of the uncertainty created by the current economy and the war in the Persian Gulf, machine tool orders remained firm."
Machine tools are power-driven devices that cut or shape metal parts used in products ranging from appliances and cars to aircraft and construction materials. The strength of tool orders generally reflects the strength of industrial production, and economists consider patterns of machine tool sales to be important indicators of capital spending by manufacturers.
Machine tool orders had risen 43.7 percent in December. Analysts attributed that big jump to increased demand from auto makers as they began to produce redesigned engines and other auto parts.
 
A Very Strong December
 "The January decline does not mean too much because December was inordinately strong as a result of new designs being released in Detroit," said William G. Copeland, president of Copeland Economic Group, an economic consulting firm in Stamford, Conn. "Also, there was so much uncertainty in the marketplace due to expectations about the war in the Persian Gulf, which caused people to hold off on their purchase of new machine tools. People wanted to wait to see how the economy would shape up."
Orders from foreign customers were particularly strong last year, as the depressed value of the United States dollar made the prices of American machine tools very attractive in overseas markets.
In recent months, machine tool industry executives have said that demand has increased from an array of industries. And they have predicted that American companies will spend more this year to improve their manufacturing operations.
 
Orders for Metal-Cutting Tools
 Orders for metal-cutting tools, which include boring mills and lathes, dropped 27 percent in January from the December level. Compared with January of last year, new orders for metal-cutting tools were down 7.9 percent. That segment of the industry typically accounts for three-fourths of new orders.
Orders for metal-forming tools plunged 40.6 percent in January from the December level. Compared with January of last year, metal-forming orders were up 12.2 percent.
The backlog of orders for machine tools stood at $1.48 billion in January, up from $1.46 billion in December. The backlog in January 1990 was $1.77 billion.

HEADLINE: First Chicago Revokes Credit Cards

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24

 BODY:
The First Chicago Corporation said it had revoked thousands of credit cards held by residents of nine Northeastern states as part of a credit review of the economically weakened region.
The acknowledgement by First Chicago, the nation's third-largest issuer of credit cards, prompted a Massachusetts Congressman to demand that the Bush Administration investigate whether the region was the victim of economic discrimination. 
 "If this practice of geographic review is widespread, the major credit card companies may be engaging in a practice that is not only unfair but also threatens to undermine further the vitality of the Northeast economy," Representative Edward J. Markey, a Democrat, stated in a letter to Robert L. Clarke, the Comptroller of the Currency. Mr. Markey is chairman of the House Telecommunications and Finance Subcommittee of the Energy and Commerce Committee.
First Chicago said Friday in a letter to Mr. Markey that it had closed 7,800 "high risk" credit card accounts held by residents of the six New England states and New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania. The credit lines of another 1,100 cardholders in those states were reduced, the company said.
The company maintains a total of 6.5 million Mastercard and Visa accounts nationwide. Of those, 1.7 million are in the nine-state region subjected to the special credit review.
In his letter to Mr. Markey, the head of First Chicago's credit card subsidiary, Scott P. Marks Jr., described the review as a one-time "test" that took place in August. Under the review, the bank examined the accounts of cardholders in the Northeast more frequently than those in other regions.
First Chicago said it had examined accounts of Northeasterners whose cards were just renewed or were about to expire.
 "During 1990 we observed a significant deterioration in the credit performance of our card members in the New England and Mid-Atlantic States," Mr. Marks said in the letter. "Specifically, during the first nine months of 1990, we experienced a 65 percent increase in bankruptcies among our New England card members in comparison to the same period during 1989.
"As a responsible member of the financial community, we believe we have the responsibility to confront and constructively deal with rising credit losses within our portfolio wherever they may occur."
Mr. Marks said First Chicago had instituted similar reviews in other regions and was not treating the Northeast unfairly. He said the standards for closing an account or reducing credit lines remained the same for Northeasterners as for other cardholders.
But Mr. Markey said that conducting more frequent credit reviews "intrinsically constitutes a stricter standard."

HEADLINE: Metro Matters;
The Big Dimout To Save Millions: Will It Really?

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
How many light bulbs does it take to change a city?
Many New Yorkers may not have noticed yet. But, block by block, the city is getting darker at night. 
 The dimming of New York, in this case, is deliberate. The ostensible goal of the city government's "wattage reduction program" for 60,000 street lights is to save millions of dollars in energy and maintenance costs, thereby avoiding cuts in more vital municipal services. Along with companion economies, the hope is to save about $2 million in the fiscal year ending June 30 alone.
Whatever the ramifications, though, city officials have invoked Orwellian logic to justify the changes. They've stopped just short of suggesting that one bonus of the switch is that dirtier streets will be harder to see in the dark.
Reducing the wattage of street lights, said Michael Primeggia, the deputy transportation commissioner, will "result in less glare and a more even illumination on the pavement."
Failing to repair broken lights for six months, Mayor David N. Dinkins's budget proclaimed in January, will result in "greater operational efficiencies."
 The light brigade has already converted 15,400 lamps since 1985 and, to the untrained eye, the difference may be barely noticeable. Moreover the newer lights meet national engineering standards; their reduced intensity is supposed to improve visibility in shadows. Few critics have actually compared the bulbs side by side, but they take a dim view of the reductions.
City Councilwoman C. Virginia Fields said her Harlem constituents complain increasingly that street lights have become dimmer.
Councilwoman Ronnie Eldridge of the West Side, said brighter lights reflect off buildings already dimmed by the protective gates that shutter many store windows. She questioned how City Hall could reconcile the dimming and non-repair plans with the Mayor's "Safe Streets, Safe City" anti-crime proposal.
Community Board 5 in midtown Manhattan voted earlier this month to oppose the wattage reduction program. Community Board 6, on the East Side, is investigating its impact.
Borough President Ruth W. Messinger of Manhattan said reducing wattage failed to consider the consequences for crime: Would additional police patrols and other law-enforcement expenses cost more than dimmer streets would save?
In Manhattan the latest lower-wattage lights are to be installed in largely noncommercial areas, including all of Riverside Drive and on Lexington and Madison Avenues above 60th Street. All or part of dozens of other streets in every borough, including Queens Boulevard in Queens, Fordham Road in the Bronx, and Flatbush Avenue in Brooklyn will be affected.
No changes are anticipated near schools, hospitals and houses of worship or in Times Square, where, because street lights are closer together, concerns about glare do not apply.
The city expanded its conversion from mercury to high-pressure sodium lights in the early 1970's. "No other single step which we can take," Mayor John V. Lindsay declared then, "will give the public as great a sense of security in the street."
But bright didn't necessarily make right. Officials found that the sodium lights accelerated growth of foliage -- thereby blocking out light. And some people cursed the brightness. A lighting designer, Howard Brandston, complained recently that pedestrians were "being homogenized in yellow light smog" by monochromatic sodium lamps. (The city says one alternative, metal halide, is too expensive).
A 250-watt mercury lamp produced 12,000 lumens; a 400-watt one produced 20,000. The output of 250-watt sodium lamps is 30,000 lumens, which, Mr. Primeggia wrote Ms. Messinger, "is 50 percent higher than the 400-watt mercury lamp." He neglected to complete the equation: the existing 400-watt sodium lamps produce 50,000 lumens.
Reducing wattage is supposed to save $724,000 a year for every 10,000 lamps used. Converting 10,000 lamps costs $1.3 million.
New York City has 325,000 street lights. On any given night, about 8,000 don't work. Maintenance is to be deferred, which means 5,000 more broken lights will not be fixed immediately, to save $1.4 million. Nor will any lights in city parks be repaired, to save $200,000.
As World War I began, Edward Viscount Grey watched the lamplighters in London and lamented: "The lamps are going out all over Europe; we shall not see them lit again in our lifetime." Street lighting pales in comparison with a war and perhaps even a fiscal crisis. But some lights are going out all over New York, and while they may go on again, they are changing how people see the city meanwhile.

HEADLINE: Revival of Trade Talks Stirs Political Fight in U.S.

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24

 BODY:
The agreement in Geneva last week that cleared the way for a resumption of global trade talks sets the stage here for what is likely to be one of the fiercest scraps in years between protectionists and free traders.
Organized labor and the textile industry, often bitter opponents at the work place but allies on trade issues, are leading forces that hope to torpedo a prospective world trade agreement, as well as one between the United States and Mexico. 
 Opponents of the agreements assert that they will cost jobs and lower wages in the United States; supporters argue precisely the opposite, that the agreements will increase prosperity.
The first round of the battle will be over a procedural tactic meant to facilitate Congressional approval of trade pacts.
 
Preserving the Balance
 The procedure, known as fast-track authority, permits President Bush to negotiate trade agreements that Congress cannot amend, to avoid any unraveling of delicately balanced international compromises. Congress had granted the Administration until May 31 to submit a global trade agreement, with a March 1 deadline for seeking an extension. President Bush is expected to ask Congress this week for a two-year extension.
Fearing job losses and a flood of cheap imports, organized labor and textile groups, as well as footwear, environmental and some family farm groups, are lobbying to block the extension.
"Although it will be molded by the desire to satisfy local constituents, this debate will define for the long term whether we go down a path of protectionism or multilateralism," said Ronald A. Brand, a University of Pittsburgh law professor.
Senator Max Baucus, Democrat of Montana and chairman of the Senate Finance Committee's trade subcommittee, estimated there were 35 to 40 votes against the President in the 100-member Senate, 40 votes, including his own, in favor and about 20 to 25 Senators uncommitted. "Labor is really activated on this one," he said.
 A House Democratic aide, who insisted on anonymity, said the President would lose if the vote were to come within the next week.
"Maybe it won't be the mother of all trade battles, but we've got a real struggle on our hands," the aide observed.
A majority of either body can block extension through a simple disapproval resolution. Trading partners have indicated they will refuse to negotiate agreements with the United States without some assurance that the Administration can strike a final deal. Canada's Trade Minister, John Crosbie, warned, "It would be extremely harmful for the world economic outlook and bad tactics for the United States because everyone would point a finger at the United States as the cause of the collapse of the liberalized world trading system."
 The global talks collapsed in December when the European Community refused to negotiate sharply lower farm subsidies, which were sought by the United States, Canada, Argentina, Australia and other food-exporting nations.
But last week, the community agreed to a formula for "specific binding commitments" to reduce farm supports, and the four-year-old talks were revived.
The talks are being held under the auspices of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the world body that oversees trade, and involves 108 nations. The agenda includes not just farm trade, but attempts to cut tariffs by one-third, strengthen patent and copyright protection, lower barriers to trade in services and improve procedures for settling trade disputes.
 "It's a question of political will," said the United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, about the GATT talks, in an interview on Thursday. "But I think we ought to work carefully to maximize what we can accomplish as quickly as we can."
The Bush Administration had been counting on wrapping up the GATT talks before the expiration of the fast-track authority. The delay now gives Congress the chance to halt the enterprise in its tracks.
The fast-track device is necessary because Congress has the constitutional authority to regulate commerce, whereas the President has the constitutional authority to negotiate with foreign governments.
 The fast-track rule specifies that Congress must approve or reject an agreement without amendments.
Fast track -- which provided the framework for Congressional approval of a 1979 GATT agreement, as well as the Israeli and Canadian free-trade agreements of the last decade -- was authorized for the newest GATT talks under 1988 legislation.
Although a Mexican free-trade agreement had not been envisioned in 1988, it, too, would be covered under the request that is expected from the President, possibly as early as Tuesday.
In addition to the GATT talks and the agreement with Mexico, President Bush is expected to seek fast-track authority for another major trade initiative, the Enterprise for the Americas, which looks forward to free-trade agreements with most countries of Latin America.
The groups in the labor-textile coalition are all opposed to either the Mexico or the GATT agreement, and some to both.
 Fearing job losses and pay cuts from a trade pact with Mexico, where workers make roughly about 5 percent of what workers earn in the United States, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. has made blocking a Mexican agreement its No. 1 legislative priority.
In recent Congressional testimony, Thomas R. Donahue, secretary-treasurer of the labor federation, called the prospective accord "an economic and social disaster" for American workers and argued that use of fast track "seriously limits both public and Congressional involvement in discussions with Mexico and dilutes the lawmaking authority of Congress."
Similarly, the textile industry, fearing a GATT agreement will open the floodgates to cheap textile imports, hopes to use the fast-track approval process to sink any prospective accord.
Donald R. Hughes, the president of the American Textile Manufacturers Institute, used unusually direct language recently to denounce the prospective accord as "a fraud that is being perpetrated on U.S. industry and agriculture."
 
The Looming Battle
 On the other side is a broad-based coalition of major business and farm organizations, including retailers and multinational companies with a major stake in increasing trade.
"We're not saying these agreements will be marvelous," said Mary A. Dyess, assistant executive director of the National Association of Stevedores and co-chairman of the so-called Pro Trade Group. "All we want is for the procedure to be in place in case the agreements work out."
For the anticipated battle in Congress, Mrs. Hills is preparing arguments on the importance of trade to economic growth, especially in the current cycle of economic weakness.
She said she was optimstic about reaching both the GATT and Mexico agreements later this year. Congress would be making a "grave mistake" if it blocks the attempts, she said, adding, "If we can't negotiate to create more opportunities for our enterpreneurs in foreign markets, then we may as well just close down the store."

HEADLINE: No War Gain For Military Contractors

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 24

 BODY:
Although the ground war in the Persian Gulf is the first test in combat of several frontline weapons systems, a relatively short ground campaign would have little effect on the financial prospects of military contractors, analysts and industry executives said today.
The Pentagon made clear in the last two months that the war would not significantly alter its plans to reduce the size of the United States military and to scale back its weapons purchases. 
 Pentagon officials said that the war could be fought almost entirely from existing stocks of weapons and ammunition, barring an unexpectedly long and fierce engagement with Iraq and that there would be no need to replace most of the hardware expended.
 
First Battle Trials
 The ground war is the first sustained battle test of the M-1 tank, built by the General Dynamics Corporation; the Bradley Fighting Vehicle, manufactured by the FMC Corporation, and the Apache attack helicopter, made by the McDonnell Douglas Corporation.
If these weapons prove reliable and effective, the reputation of the contractors will benefit. The performance of the systems could also influence the design of future weapons, industry executives said.
But the companies are not likely to receive a direct financial benefit in the form of new orders from the Pentagon, because the Bush Administration has said it is sticking with its plan to phase out purchases of many current weapons.
The budget proposal for the next fiscal year sent to Congress earlier this month by Defense Secretary Dick Cheney called for canceling the Bradley Fighting Vehicle, which is used to transport infantry troops. The proposal also reaffirmed decisions made in earlier years to end production of the M-1 and the Apache.
 
Higher Foreign Sales
 Any benefit to the arms industry from the war is most likely to come from increased sales to foreign countries, particularly Saudi Arabia. The Saudis are already buying large quantities of weapons, some from the stocks of the United Stats military and some from military contractors in this country.
An impressive performance by some or all of the ground weapons deployed in the gulf could well increase demand from the Saudis and other potential foreign purchasers. The aircraft, missiles and other advanced systems deployed in the gulf by the United States already appear to have proven highly effective.
"There should be some additional foreign military sales," said Howard A. Rubel, an analyst at C. J. Lawrence Inc. "The U.S. now carries with it a calling card it hasn't had in some time, which is success on the battlefield."
 
Big Saudi Orders
 The Saudis have already ordered 465 of the most advanced version of the M-1, known as the M-1A2, and would like to order another 235, General Dynamics executives have said. Those orders and others will enable General Dynamics to keep open one of its two production lines for the M-1 despite the lack of orders from the Pentagon.
McDonnell Douglas could also receive additional foreign orders for the Apache, which until the last few months had suffered from a reputation of being unreliable and difficult to maintain. In addition to Saudi Arabia and other Middle Eastern nations, potential customers are Britain and the Netherlands.
"The Apache is shaking off a lot of the criticism," Mr. Rubel said.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Los Angeles Times to Drop Some Readers

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 24

 BODY:
The Los Angeles Times, which became the nation's largest metropolitan daily last year through its aggressive expansion efforts, plans to stop selling papers in a large part of central California and in neighboring states.
Executives of The Los Angeles Times, which has a weekday circulation of 1.2 million, said they decided to eliminate home-delivery and newsstand sales in the mostly rural area between Bakersfield and Fresno because of the weakened California economy. 
 "We're making some difficult but judicious changes that will reduce our expenses," said Carolyn Hom, a spokeswoman for The Times. "The cost of circulation was very high in relation to the value to our readers and advertisers there."
 
A Strategic Shift
 The Los Angeles Times will also no longer distribute papers in Phoenix and Tucson, Ariz.; Reno and Carson City, Nev., and Salt Lake City, but analysts say the newspaper was likely to remain the largest-selling daily in the nation. Distribution will continue in the San Francisco area and in Sacramento, the state capital.
The decision represents a strategic shift for the Los Angeles Times, which in recent years has spent millions of dollars to expand its circulation in California and the West. Toward this end, the newspaper had maintained distribution in such distant and often unprofitable areas as central California, said John Morton, a newspaper analyst at Lynch, Jones & Ryan, a securities firm.
"They are now comfortably above a million and I'm sure they feel they can trim back without coming down close to that number," Mr. Morton said. "But for a long time they were not very far above it and would have been loathe to fall below. It has a lot to do with image."
About a million people live in central California between Bakersfield and Fresno. But more than half of California's 29.8 million residents, and most of The Los Angeles Times's circulation, are south of there.
Ms. Hom declined to say how much circulation The Los Angeles Times would be eliminating by the cutbacks, which take effect around the end of March. But a newspaper distributor in Fresno, Paul Nickel, said a supervisor at The Times told him that the newspaper's circulation would drop by about 35,000 in central California.
"I have a lot of customers who are complaining because they feel discriminated against," said Mr. Nickel, who has distributed The Times for 22 years and is urging subscribers to write to the paper's publisher, David A. Laventhol.
The Los Angeles Times is owned by the Times Mirror Company, the nation's third-largest media company. Times Mirror, which also owns Newsday on Long Island and other newspapers, book publishers, magazines and television properties, announced in January that its fourth-quarter profits had fallen by 38.5 percent.
 
Angry Subscribers
 A secretary in Mr. Laventhol's office said the publisher had received hundreds of letters and phone calls from angry subscribers in central California. One reader, Laura B. Carey, has written letters to executives, editors and columnists of The Times and even to her Congressman to try to reverse the paper's decision.
"I'm furious," said the retired medical secretary, who has subscribed to The Times since 1974, when she moved to Fresno from Westport, Conn. "I think that during a time when we're at war and are going into an election season, to cut off a large chunk of the state is just ridiculous."
Mrs. Carey said she planned to subscribe to The San Jose Mercury News or The San Francisco Chronicle, but added: "It's like changing husbands. It's just not quite the same."

HEADLINE: Personal Trials Grow in Rhode Island Bank Crisis

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: EAST PROVI DENCE, R.I.

 BODY:
On New Year's Day, when Gov. Bruce G. Sundlun closed 45 of the state's banks and credit unions, Ann Quinn thought she would be able to get her money in a day or two.
But the 67-year-old Ms. Quinn, angry and frantic, spends part of every morning driving her Buick in circles around a credit union here and another in North Providence, where her life savings are still frozen. 
 "I'm at a point of desperation," said Ms. Quinn, who is borrowing rent and grocery money from her sister. "I can't sleep. I can't do anything. I drive around and sometimes I go knock on the door, hoping they will let me take my money back out. But the doors are always locked."
Governor Sundlun, a Democrat, closed the banks and credit unions after the failure of their private insurer, the Rhode Island Security and Deposit Indemnity Corporation. Most of the institutions have since obtained Federal deposit insurance and reopened, but 14 were rejected for Federal insurance and have remained closed, leaving 300,000 accounts frozen. Deposits in those accounts total $1.3 billion; state officials say it is not clear how much cash the closed institutions actually have on hand.
For many of the tens of thousands of depositors with money in those accounts, that means payrolls, bills and rent payments are being paid with borrowed money or not at all. Rhode Islanders who praised Mr. Sundlun at first for his handling of the bank crisis are beginning to panic and ask why he does not do more to help them regain their money.
"People are desperate," said Jack Kayrouz, who said his life savings of $50,000 are frozen in the Chariho Exeter Credit Union in the village of Wyoming. "Businesses are failing. There are elderly who live on the interest from their C.D.'s and are now on the verge of homelessness. This is a terrible, terrible problem."
In February, Mr. Sundlun and the Legislature enacted a bailout bill for the closed institutions. The state will guarantee to refund deposits of $100,000 or less, the level protected by Federal insurance, but not all at once; the process will take three years.
In the meantime, the state is encouraging solvent banks to acquire and reopen the insolvent ones. The new law requires those that are not acquired to merge into a Depositors' Economic Protection Corporation, Depco for short.
But depositors say the bailout measure has brought little comfort. Depco will refund only a percentage of deposits of more than $100,000. Accounts of $500,000 or more, for example, will be refunded at 50 cents on the dollar. Interest is not being paid, and payments do not begin until up to 45 days after the banks enter the corporation, which has not yet been set up.
"Certainly we would prefer that each depositor had access to their money and all of it today," said Barbara Cottam, a spokeswoman for Mr. Sundlun. "Unfortunately that's not the case. Depco is just a last-resort alternative." The plan is expected to cost the state as much as $300 million.
Many depositors thought Risdic, the private insurer, was backed by the state, and they say the Governor's plan is inadequate.
"Anything less than full access to our money takes this state into further economic and civil chaos," said Mr. Kayrouz, who founded Citizens for Depositors' Rights, a lobbying group.
Arlene Violet, a former State Attorney General who is host of a radio talk show in East Providence, said her callers have become increasingly frantic about their frozen accounts.
"People used to call in with technical questions about getting their money back," said Ms. Violet, who is also representing depositors in several lawsuits against the institutions. "Now it's like open-mike therapy. One woman called bawling, saying the funeral home that had buried her husband was threatening to sue if she didn't pay the bill."
Nowhere is the problem more apparent than in Woonsocket, an old mill town north of Providence that is home to the closed Marquette Credit Union. More than half of Woonsocket's 48,000 residents had money in accounts in Marquette, the state's largest credit institution. With a city unemployment rate already above 11 percent, the consequences have been disastrous, city officials said.
"This has absolutely decimated business here," said John P. Kuzmiski, the city's finance director. He said more than 30 small businesses had closed since January. Those still open have seen receipts cut in half. Tax collectors have had to grant extensions. And the local center for the elderly has begun group therapy sessions to help those who depended on Marquette's interest payments cope without them.
 
Depositors Named in Paper
 State officials have repeatedly reminded angry depositors that the state was not responsible for the banks' private insurer. Still, the Governor is facing mounting criticism.
"The state has an obligation to make sure people get all of their money back, plus interest and on time," Mr. Kuzmiski said. "Depco falls far, far short of that."
But disillusionment with Mr. Sundlun centers not only around Depco. Earlier this month, the Governor enraged depositors by releasing the names of those holding more than $100,000 in frozen accounts. More than 900 names and account balances, which the Governor said he released as a matter of public interest to taxpayers, were printed in a local paper, The Pawtucket Times.
"Since that list came out, I've had to put up with phone calls from people making ethnic remarks like, 'All you wealthy Jews put your money away, so you got what you deserved,' " said Steve Levinson, a Woonsocket landlord listed as having $200,000 frozen in Marquette.
"Am I angry? You bet I am. Am I looking into taking legal steps? You bet I am," said Mr. Levinson, who said he had been a longtime supporter of Mr. Sundlun.
"As for Depco, I'm mad about that, too," he said, noting that two-thirds of his tenants had been unable to pay their bills since January. "All I can do is hold the hands of my elderly tenants and say, 'Hey, we're all in this together.' "

GRAPHIC: Photo: "I drive around and sometimes I go knock on the door, hoping they will let me take my money back out," said Ann Quinn, whose life savings are frozen in two credit unions, which are among 45 banks and credit unions in Rhode Island that closed after their insurer failed. "But the doors are always locked." (Bill Powers for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: The Ground War and the American Economy;
Further Drop Seen In the Price of Oil

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
The ground war against Iraq is likely to result in lower oil prices, at least in the short term, experts said yesterday. Most of these experts said a short ground war was more likely to bring lower prices than a longer conflict.
The new phase of the war reduced still further what the market had seen as a minuscule chance of Iraq's interfering with Saudi Arabia's oil production, the experts said. 
 "It was never going to happen, but everyone was worried about it," said Peter C. Beutel, an oil analyst at the Pegasus Econometric Group in Hoboken, N.J. Mr. Beutel said that uncertainty had kept prices higher than they otherwise would have been.
 
Adding to Exports
 Mr. Beutel added that pushing Iraq out of Kuwait would hasten the resumption of oil exports from Kuwait, and even from Iraq, adding to the oil supply on world markets.
Daniel C. Yergin, president of Cambridge Energy Research Associates, said that if the war continued to look "fairly quick and pretty clear in its outcome," it would reinforce the underlying direction of the market, which is down.
Mr. Yergin, the author of a recent history of the oil industry, "The Prize: The Epic Quest for Oil, Money and Power," said this oil crisis appeared likely to end like the five others since World War II. "Each one began with a shortage or specter of shortage and ended with a surplus," he said.
 
Short-Term Surplus
 Many experts say the market seems to expect a surplus that will depress prices for the short term. In trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange, the price for delivery of oil in the soonest-available month is low relative to prices for delivery in later months.
But the short-term price could rise, Mr. Yergin said, if the war dragged on, if chemical weapons were used or if questions arose about the determination of the United States and its allies. As Mr. Yergin made his assessment, however, on the day after the ground war had begun, that scenario seemed unlikely.
Oil for April delivery had closed down 59 cents, at $17.91 a barrel, on the Merc on Friday, its lowest price since July. In the after-hours cash market, it was trading 25 to 30 cents below that. And it was trading even lower in the limited cash market over the weekend, said Edward A. Silliere Jr., the managing news editor of Telerate, an electronic financial reporting service.
He said that when the Merc re-opens today, "I wouldn't be at all surprised to see oil $1 down." One reason, he said, was that Iran and Saudi Arabia had substantial "floating inventories" of oil on tankers, amassed partly in anticipation of a price increase, and that they would now want to sell these stocks.
OPEC ministers from three countries outside the Persian Gulf are scheduled to consult in Geneva today, and Nauman Barakat, an oil market specialist at Merrill Lynch & Company, said they might ask the other ministers to join them. If the other ministers did attend, it would, in effect, move up the organization's next ministerial meeting, which is now scheduled for March 11, and cuts in production to stem the decline in prices could be discussed.
Mr. Barakut said oil prices were likely to fall initially if the ground war was swift and successful because traders would expect a quicker return of Kuwaiti and Iraqi crude to the market, and that they would expect a worsening glut unless Saudi Arabia cut its production. But he added that continued high Saudi production probably would not mean a worsening glut because the Kuwaiti and Iraqi oil operations may not be repaired for many months.
 
Damage Assessment Ahead
 With allied forces moving into Kuwait, a clearer assessment of the damage to the country's oil industry is likely in the next few days. Before the war, Kuwait's exports were about 1.6 million barrels a day, about 7 percent of OPEC's total.
Experts think that the Iraqi oil industry, which was about double Kuwait's production before the war, will take longer than Kuwait's to repair. When it will resume exporting oil is also complicated by the political issue of when international trade embargoes will be lifted.
A more lingering effect, probably, will be the loss of Kuwait's refineries, which will take years to rebuild.
But oil traders point out that the world learned months ago to live without Kuwaiti and Iraqi crude, and that the next few months are a relatively slack period for oil demand, as warmer weather approaches in most industrial countries.
 
Some Not Convinced
 But not everyone is convinced that prices will stay low. "All of the numbers, as best we can look at them, tend to show there is no particular oversupply anywhere," said Aivars Krasts, an economist for Conoco Inc. in Houston.
If prices stay low, he said, it is probably because the market has begun to see the Strategic Petroleum Reserve as readily available. The reserve, which has been tapped twice by the Bush Administration, contains nearly 600 million barrels.
At the Amoco Corporation, Theodore R. Eck, the chief economist, added that a quick war could raise demand for oil by "getting the issue behind us" for Europe, Japan and especially the United States, thus encouraging an upturn in economic activity and a rise in demand for oil products.
The end of the war should mean less volatility in oil markets, he said, because OPEC would be better able to predict demand and supply.
 
Demand for Revenue
 Mr. Eck said that the war would create a vast demand for more revenue in the Middle East, and that this was likely to push up prices. In the past, he said, OPEC "has not been a short-term profit-maximizing operation."
Some members, he said, had been willing to settle for lower prices in the short term so that oil would maintain its share of the world energy market and industrial countries would not find substitutes or learn to do without, a step that would mean hard times for exporters in decades to come.
Now, he said, rebuilding could cost $150 billion or more, and "everyone in the Middle East is going to have desperate requirements for more revenue, and nobody will take the long-term view."

On Saturday night, burning Kuwaiti oil wells were visible from the Saudi border. Experts say the Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil industries may take months to repair. (Pool photo via Reuters)

HEADLINE: 2 West Virginia Towns Battle for F.B.I. Center

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: CLARKSBURG, W.Va., Feb. 24

 BODY:
Two towns that share their water, their dogcatcher and even a page in the telephone directory are battling for the F.B.I.'s Fingerprint Identification Center.
At stake in the fight between Clarksburg and Bridgeport is $3 million in taxes from builders of the center. 
 The Federal Bureau of Investigation's center, now in downtown Washington, will be a major employer in the county, about 100 miles south of Pittsburgh. The county is still trying to recover from a decision by the Anchor Hocking Corporation to close a glass manufacturing plant in 1987; 900 workers lost their jobs. Unemployment in the county peaked at more than 18 percent in 1988 and stood at 9.7 percent last December.
About 2,000 of the F.B.I. center's 2,800 workers are to be hired locally, with the rest transferring from Washington.
Last month, the bureau paid about $3.5 million for pasture and woodland and part of a reclaimed strip mine. The land is not part of either city, but adjoins Bridgeport's city limits. Clarksburg's nearest border is about eight miles soth of the property. But the city moved to annex the land in July.
The issue goes to Harrison CountyCircuit Court on Tuesday, when Bridgeport will try to block the county commission's expected vote in favor of Clarksburg.
In the 1970's, Clarksburg, population 18,000, wanted to annex the shopping malls in Eastpointe by drawing a corridor from its city limits. Bridgeport, population 7,000, also wanted the malls, but the owners favored Clarksburg.
William Sessions, the Director of the F.B.I., has called the battle a local affair that will not affect construction. He spoke after an assistant sent a letter to the Clarksburg City Manager saying the bureau wanted to be in Clarksburg because the town was better preparedto provide police and fire protection and other services.
Efforts by the county commission to find a middle ground have failed.
"The feeling in Bridgeport is that Clarksburg is infringing on our territorial integrity," said Mayor Carl Furbee Jr. of Bridgeport.
Jack Allston, director of Harrison 2000, the county's economic development group, said the rivalry was not unusual.
"There are going to be naysayers no matter what comes in to an area," Mr. Allston said. "But 99 percent of the people are for this project because of the huge economic impact it will have."
Mabel Kovar of Clarksburg agreed.
"This is all foolishness," she said. "We need it here, no matter what, no matter where. If they keep it up, we might lose it."

HEADLINE: 9-Way Race for a Seat Soon to Vanish

BYLINE: By ANDREW L. YARROW

 BODY:
On Tuesday, voters in the 29th City Council District in Brooklyn will choose from among nine candidates who have spent a total of $500,000 in a race for an office that will cease to exist before the end of the year.
Most of the candidates are liberal Democrats with barely distinguishable positions, but no trace of traditional party affiliations can be found on the ballot. Instead, the candidates are identified under peculiarly catchall and upbeat labels like "People's Choice" and "Better Government." 
 This special election, the second under the new City Charter, is to fill the north Brooklyn seat of Abraham G. Gerges, who resigned to become a State Supreme Court judge. The district includes all or parts of Williamsburg, Greenpoint, Brooklyn Heights, Fort Greene, Boerum Hill, Bushwick and Park Slope.
Council elections have generally been among the uncontested or half-noticed sideshows of New York politics. But in the future, thanks to the new City Charter, they are expected to be more fiercely fought.
 
Grass-Roots Campaigning
 Because the Charter has mandated expanding the Council from 35 to 51 members, the city's 35 current districts are to be replaced this summer by 51 smaller ones in time for September primaries and the November general election. That will leave 16 additional seats up for grabs, and is designed to foster more grass-roots campaigning.
The Charter will also make special elections more common. In the past, Council vacancies had been left to each borough's Council delegation to fill by appointment.
The Charter stipulates that candidates in many of these special elections run without party identifications. Some Democratic and Republican Party officials say this provision violates state election law, and the provision may be challenged before the next special election. That election will be in April, to fill the Queens seat of Arthur J. Katzman, who has announced his retirement.
The changes were in keeping with the Charter's goal of increasing the Council's power, attracting members of greater political experience and making the board more representative of the city's minorities.
 
Biggest Issue: Incinerator
 But none of the candidates in the 29th District have previously held elective office, and all are white in one of the city's more heterogeneous districts, which is made up of Hispanic residents, Hasidic Jews, Polish emigres and blacks, as well as whites.
The debate over the contest's biggest issue -- the city's proposal to put an incinerator in Williamsburg -- has been dominated by personal attacks. Those clashes culminated last week when campaign workers for one of the two self-described front-runners, Joan Millman, placed an advertisement in a shopper that was directed to Williamsburg's Hasidim and that linked her chief opponent, Kenneth Fisher, with the incinerator. In the advertisement, which Mr. Fisher said was printed to look like a flaming tombstone, the incinerator was referred to in Yiddish as a "crematorium."
Mr. Fisher, a 38-year-old lawyer once affiliated with a law firm that represented the developer for the proposed incinerator, now opposes the project, as do all the other candidates. He denounced Ms. Millman, a 50-year-old educator and Brooklyn Heights district leader, for trying to associate him with the Holocaust in what he called a desperate effort to diminish his strong support among Hasidic voters.
Mr. Fisher, who is the son of a former Metropolitan Transportation Authority chairman, Harold L. Fisher, and who has been endorsed by the Brooklyn Borough President, Howard Golden; the Bronx Borough President, Fernado Ferrer, and the Citizens Union, said that the incinerator diverted attention from "major issues of crime, housing and the deterioration of quality of life."
 
'Last-Ditch Effort'
 Ms. Millman, who has been endorsed by the City Council President, Andrew J. Stein, and The New York Times, said that the advertisement used the word "incinerator," but was mistranslated by the shopper, The Advertiser, from English into Yiddish. She said that she would not pay for the advertisement, and that Mr. Fisher was using it as "a last-ditch effort to smear me."
While their clashes have dominated the seemingly minimal attention paid to the race by the district's 200,000 residents, the seven other candidates have feverishly tried to distinguish themselves from each other and to distance themselves from what they call the politics-as-usual approaches of Mr. Fisher and Ms. Millman.
Because the turnout is expected to be just 10 to 15 percent, a tight race could be swung by a few thousand votes. Consequently, the other candidates say their intensive grass-roots campaigning will help them emerge as dark-horse victors. Most of their fire has been directed at Mr. Fisher's and Ms. Millman's refusals to accept public campaign money and the resulting limits on spending. Candidates who accept the public matching grants are limited to spending $105,000 on the race. Mr. Fisher has acknowledged that he has spent more than $100,000, and Democrat officials say Ms. Millman has spent about $90,000.
"It's horrendous that Fisher and Millman, who are slashing each other's throats in public, haven't gone for public funding," said Angela Battaglia, a 38-year-old director of a housing center for the elderly in Bushwick. She has cited her long experience as an advocate on housing issues and for the elderly, and the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association's endorsement of her candidacy for organizing block associations to fight crime.
 
Most to Run Again
 Lonni Leavitt-Cacchione, a longtime Brooklyn Heights community advocate, called Ms. Millman a machine politician interested in patronage, and said members of Mr. Fisher's family who have been involved in government have "shot down any reforms over the years."
Irene Van Slyke, a 50-year-old nurse and aide to State Senator Velmanette Montgomery, has been endorsed by New York Newsday and called herself "the only candidate with government experience." She has advocated putting more police officers on the streets and creating park land along the Brooklyn Heights waterfront.
Linda T. Minucci, a seven-year district leader in Greenpoint, said that she was the first to oppose the incinerator and that she has long focused on ecological damage to Williamsburg and Greenpoint caused by a huge underground oil spill and a toxic-waste storage center.
John T. Glick, a 41-year-old tenant organizer in Boerum Hill who was endorsed by The Village Voice, called for increasing income taxes for the rich, reducing tax abatements for developers and expanding economic planning to reduce competition among New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
The Socialist Workers candidate, Angela L. Lariscy, has principally campaigned against the Persian Gulf war. And Gary S. Popkin, running on the anti-crime line, wants "to increase prison capacity cheaply, so that everyone who is convicted would be imprisoned."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Kenneth Fisher, another 29th District candidate, campaigning at a center for the elderly. (Dith Pran/The New York Times); Joan Millman, a Brooklyn Heights district leader, who is running for the 29th City Council District seat. (Nancy Siesel for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: The Ground War and the American Economy;
Boost but No Cure For the Recession

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
If the ground war ends in an allied victory in the Persian Gulf by late March, with relatively few casualties, the American economy will almost certainly receive a boost. But many economists doubt that peace by springtime would be sufficient in itself to end the recession.
The two great benefits that are likely to follow an early victory are a rise in consumer confidence and a drop in oil prices to the prewar level of $18 a barrel or less. More confident consumers, in turn, would spend more. And lower oil prices would give them more to spend, by reducing outlays for energy. 
 "These positive elements will offset some of the negatives, said Robert Gordon, a Northwestern University economist. "But I don't see a very rapid recovery because there are so many other negatives unrelated to the war."
 
Economic Problems
 For Mr. Gordon and other economists, the negatives include months of rising unemployment and stagnant personal income, a sharp drop in industrial production since November, a dormant construction industry, a banking sector in crisis and hundreds of state and city governments forced into cutbacks and layoffs because of budget deficits. Until last year, spending by these governments had been a source of economic growth for the nation.
The Bush Administration and Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, have primarily blamed the recession on Iraq's invasion of Kuwait and the damage it did to consumer confidence, as oil prices rose and the likelihood of war made Americans nervous. While Government officials count on a quick victory to reverse the recession, those who measure consumer confidence have their doubts.
 
Limited Euphoria
 "If the war ends soon, there may conceivably be some sort of euphoria that will give the economy a lift, but the ending of the war is not going to jump us out of the recession," said Fabian Linden, director of a monthly survey of consumer confidence sponsored by the Conference Board, a business organization. "The realities of the job market are the consumer's main focus now."
Among those who responded to the Conference Board's January survey of nearly 5,000 households, 36 percent said they expected job opportunities to worsen over the coming months, while only 9 percent expected job prospects to improve. Those recession-level percentages are not expected to change in the board's February survey, which is scheduled to be released late this week. In normal economic times, job optimists outnumber pessimists four to one, Mr. Linden said.
But if an early victory is no cure-all for the economy, a prolonged ground war, lasting through the end of the year, may not have much impact either. As Herbert Stein, a senior fellow at the American Enterprise Institute, puts it: "Objectively, this war is not an important factor in the economy, and it is hard for me to explain how it is linked to consumer confidence. Unless the war took a turn for the worse, which no one foresees except Saddam Hussein, I don't see the war becoming a major quantitative influence on the economy."
 
Not a Stimulant
 One reason is that the Persian Gulf war, unlike the Korean and Vietnam wars, is not costing enough to be either a stimulant or a drain on the economy. Outlays for those wars, mostly for weapons production and supplies, represented 8 to 15 percent of the gross national product, the total value of newly produced goods and services. The outlays for the gulf war are far less.
Peter Garber, a Brown University economist who teaches a course on war and the economy, estimated the potential cost of the Persian Gulf war at a maximum of roughly $35 billion a month for the United States. That would mean an outlay of about $100 billion through March, or 1.8 percent of G.N.P. Only if the war dragged on through December would spending approach 7 percent of G.N.P. and perhaps begin to act as an economic stimulant, mostly through increased weapons production.
So far, most of the gulf war spending is for food, fuel and other supplies purchased abroad, often with money supplied by Saudi Arabia, Japan, Germany and other allies -- an outlay that bypasses the United States economy. Weapons production in the United States has not been affected; the gulf war is being fought from the inventory of weaponry built up during the Carter and Reagan Administrations.
Military contractors confirm this assessment. A spokesman for the Raytheon Company, maker of the Patriot missile, said, for example, that the Pentagon had asked the company to speed up production of Patriots ordered before the gulf crisis began in August but had not placed new orders. Similar reports come from the General Dynamics Corporation, manufacturer of the Abrams tank and various warplanes, and the Grumman Corporation, also a warplane maker.
Still, weapons production might make a contribution to economic growth in the months and years after the gulf war ends, Peter L. Bernstein, an economic consultant, said.
"We seem to be using up a huge amount of stuff," Mr. Bernstein said, "and I would think we would not only want to replace what we have used, but add more, because it would appear that we have demonstrated in the gulf a great military capability, and we want to prepare to use it again."
 
Military Spending
 Military spending acts as a stimulant mostly through the creation of jobs at weapons companies and their suppliers. The jobholders, in turn, spend their new incomes on a great variety of services and products, adding to the prosperity of other sectors. The problem is that military contractors, seeking to cut costs, have laid off tens of thousands of workers over the last two years, and many would not be rehired, even if the Pentagon placed new purchase orders.
Peter Connolly, a spokesman for General Dynamics, said, for example, that if the Defense Department increased its cruise missile orders by 20 percent, "that would not have a significant impact on employment."
The American economy might also benefit in the postwar months if the United States emerged in control of a plentiful supply of inexpensive Middle East oil. Confidence in such a supply might stimulate not only consumer spending but also industrial production. For the consumer, lower energy costs free some income for spending on cars, appliances and other products. For the manufacturer, lower energy costs restore profit margins, giving a company leeway to draw customers by discounting.
"We get a boost from both the demand and the supply side," said Alan Blinder, a Princeton University economist.

HEADLINE: Tokyo's Importing More, but Who's Benefiting?

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Feb. 24

 BODY:
After a five-year battle by the United States and European nations to open Japan's markets and correct its big trade imbalances, imports have risen swiftly and Japan's huge financial surpluses have plummeted. On the surface, the changes seem substantial.
But as is often the case with such broad economic shifts, the side effects, like the expected boon to foreign companies and improved living standards for Japanese consumers, have not materialized the way some economists on both sides of the Pacific had forecast. While some progress has occurred, companies like Toys "R" Us are still struggling to build a network of stores here.
 
Too Expensive
 Other companies still find it just too expensive, like Citibank, when it sought to buy a bank or bank branches to develop a retail system. So the flow of foreign capital into Japan remains a trickle, while corporate Japan has continued to build up its share of foreign markets with big overseas investments. 
 A look at the broadest measure of Japan's trade in goods and services and financial transactions, called the current account, finds big changes. The surplus in the account tumbled to $35.8 billion last year, according to preliminary Government figures. The decline was the third in a row, bringing the surplus to less than half its peak of $87 billion in 1987.
The current account includes manufactured goods, like cars, VCR's and stereos, that make up "visible" trade, as well "invisible" items, like services, tourism and financial transactions across borders.
 
Major Political Issue
 Since it gives the fullest measure of the cross-border flows, the perennial surplus was regarded by some Western economists as the most menacing of Japan's imbalances. It is a big political issue between Tokyo and Washington, with American officials contending that Japan unfairly restricts imports and hinders competition from outside firms in areas like banking.
Another pronounced change is that the flood of Japanese investment in corporate stocks, bonds and other securities overseas, largely to the United States, has dropped sharply and has shifted in character. The outflow had provided an important source of financing in the United States for everything from the oversized Federal budget deficits to leveraged buyouts. Japan's long-term capital outflow peaked at $136.5 billion in 1987, then fell to $43.5 billion last year.
In fact, the Finance Ministry's Vice Minister for International Affairs, Makoto Utsumi, said recently that the swift narrowing of the current account did not worry him, but that the decline in the amount of capital Japan was exporting to a world where capital was scarce at the moment did. A great deal of that money had been used to acquire securities, mostly Treasury bonds.
Takatoshi Okuyama, the general manager of the investment advisory department at Daiwa Securities, said it was too early to say how fundamental the change was, but added, "it is clear now that interest among Japanese institutions in investing in U.S. securities has declined." Much higher domestic interest rates and reduced lending by banks are keeping more Japanese money at home.
 
More Investments in U.S.
 Still, while the big Japanese purchases of Treasury securities and other stocks and bonds has declined, Japanese electronics and automobile companies are making larger, more direct investments in new manufacturing plants overseas and are buying more foreign companies.
Recent examples include the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company's acquisition of the California-based movie maker, MCA Inc.; the Toyota Motor Corporation's decision to build a new plant in the United States, and the Sharp Corporation's plans to assemble thin computer-video display screens at its plant in Camas, Wash., that makes computer chips.
Such moves increase the market penetration of the Japanese companies. Direct investment soared to more than $50 billion last year, from about $20 billion in 1987.
 
No Benefit to Consumers
 The Japanese consumer was supposed to have been a prime beneficiary of these shifts, reaping the rewards of cheaper and more imported goods. But retail prices have not declined with the stronger yen and growing imports. And the surge in domestic investment has largely been for industrial development, not for better roads, schools and housing that consumers might enjoy.
"The adjustment to the new environment has come on the corporate side, not for Japanese consumers," said Kenneth S. Courtis, an economist here for Deutsche Bank. "These changes have not given anyone a leg up on corporate Japan."
To be sure, Japan is importing far more manufactured goods, as the United States and European nations have demanded. But most of the decline in the trade surplus in the last year comes from the jump in the price of crude oil that Japan must import. That was a result of the Persian Gulf crisis, not a greater penetration of foreign goods into the Japanese market. The higher cost of oil forces up the value of Japanese imports and slows the economic growth of Japan's trading partners, which in turn buy fewer Japanese goods.
 
Slowing Export Growth
 Export growth, meanwhile, has slowed in part because Japanese companies produce more of their goods in the countries where they are sold. For instance, Japanese auto companies now make in the United States slightly more than half of the cars they sell to Americans -- 2.6 million last year. These goods made in Japanese-owned factories abroad are substitutes for exports.
These trends began as a giant macroeconomic experiment, when the leading industrialized nations engineered a doubling of the yen's value against the dollar starting in September 1985. Their accord to do so is known as the Plaza Agreement, after the New York hotel where they met.
The aim was to limit Japan's soaring trade surpluses by making Japanese exports more expensive, and American goods cheaper for Japanese consumers.
 
Surplus at $63.9 Billion
 According to Japanese Government figures, Japan's visible trade surplus has declined by a third from its peak in 1987, to $63.9 billion last year. The current account surplus has fallen nearly twice as fast as the visible trade surplus. The main reason: a boom in Japanese travel abroad, which does not affect the visible trade balance but shows up in the current account.
The current account surplus should shrink more this year. One big temporary, but sizable, bite is the $9 billion in aid the Japanese Government has promised to the American-led forces in the Persian Gulf. The aid is treated as a financial transfer that directly cuts into the current account balance.
As a result, many economists are putting less emphasis on the current account as a measure of Japan's economic prowess. They are not ignoring what had been a standard measure in the past, but they are focusing more on factors like foreign direct investment, capital flows and the structure of the country's imports and exports.
 
Waiting and Hoping
 Japanese consumers are still waiting for the deeper benefits they were promised. Five years ago, a blue-ribbon Japanese commission, under the direction of Haruo Maekawa, a former governor of the Bank of Japan, drafted a blueprint for economic reform that called for measures to improve the living standards of Japanese consumers to levels enjoyed in the West.
Yutaka Kosai, a member of the commission and president of the Japan Center for Economic Research, said he was disappointed that Japanese consumers had gotten so little out of the economic adjustments.
The report proposed that Japan not just invest more abroad, but absorb more foreign investment. The flow has largely been one-way, into foreign markets. Also, Japanese workers have not enjoyed the large reduction in working hours the commission proposed, Mr. Kosai said.
"I can't say we achieved what we wanted," he acknowledged.
 
Public Investment in Question
 In an important trade accord with the United States last year, Japan agreed to raise its public investment in the next 10 years to improve living standards. But talk has already arisen that Japan's billions of dollars in aid for the gulf war may force a reduction in the program.
Some of these changes have caused a debate in Japan over whether the decline in the country's surpluses, which most agreed was needed, has been too swift.
Tomomitsu Oba, the head of a Government-affiliated research group and a former Vice Minister of International Affairs at the Finance Ministry, has contended that Japan must not let its current account surplus shrink to less than 1 percent of its gross national product, where it now stands.
Otherwise, he contends, Japan will be unable to provide the capital that other nations need for financing everything from budget deficits to the reconstruction of Eastern Europe.
"This is a bad sign," Mr. Oba said of the decline in an interview. "This reduction comes at a time when the world needs Japan's excess savings."
 
Others Dispute Stance
 Mr. Oba's position is countered by people who say that Japan's ability to provide aid to the world is little affected by the size of its financial surpluses. The United States, for instance, has been a leading aid donor to the rest of the world, even as it shoulders huge trade deficits.
"This idea that we need a certain size surplus is still popular among old-style people, and I don't mean chronological age," said Michiya Matsukawa, also a former Vice Minister of Finance and now an adviser to the Nikko Securities Company. "There's no clear-cut relationship between our ability to make overseas investments and the size of the current account surplus."

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Have Investors Already Made Their Bets on Victory?

BYLINE: BY FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
More than a month ago, Wall Street analysts were nearly unanimous in their fears that the beginning of the allies' war against Iraq could send stock prices plunging. They were wrong.
Last week, a similar but less-cohesive consensus developed, that a ground war was bad news for financial markets. On Friday, the Dow Jones industrial average rose swiftly amid talk of a peaceful withdrawal, only to plunge back on investors' expectations that Iraq was not going to accept the terms laid down by President Bush. 
 In early trading today, Japan provided the first indication of how investors viewed the ground war. Share prices opened higher in Tokyo, slipped back, then rose to post modest gains in morning trading. The activity seemed to indicate that the start of the land war had provided little new information to sway sentiment. The Nikkei index of 225 stocks rose 193.70 points. [Page D3.]
In New York during the last month, there has been a sharp increase in both stock prices and bullishness. "We're talking about an early end to the war and an early end to the recession," Lawrence Kudlow, the chief economist of Bear Stearns & Company, predicted yesterday.
But Mr. Kudlow, one of the few people on Wall Street to forecast correctly that prices would rise after the start of the air war, said he expected a much more muted response this time. On Jan. 17, the Dow Jones industrial average leaped 114.60 points, or 4.6 percent, to 2,623.51.
"The principal issue, financially and economically, was the price of energy and the security of the Saudi oilfields," Mr. Kudlow said of the atmosphere before war broke out. "Those issues have been determined, and the ground war does not affect that."
The burning oilfields in Kuwait make it unlikely that country will soon resume production of anything close to its prewar output, but oil markets have shrugged that off. In New York on Friday, after the reports of oilfield fires had circulated, crude oil for April delivery fell 59 cents a barrel, to $17.59.
The war has not been the only influence on financial markets, and some American investors say it has been overemphasized. "The war is not going to affect how many diapers Procter & Gamble sells," said Peter Thayer, the president of the Gateway Index Plus Fund, a mutual fund based in Cincinnati.
Mr. Thayer said last week that he thought stock prices had gone too high, pointing to valuation measures and the sharp escalation in stock prices since the war began.
"It's beyond ahead of itself," he said of the stock market. "It is absurd."
The Iraqi invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2 came at a time when oil prices were already rising and drove them sharply higher. That helped send share prices down rapidly, and from then through Jan. 16, the Dow fell 13.5 percent, or 390.35 points.
But since then, the Dow has made up nearly all of that loss, with the 15.2 percent recovery leaving the index at 2,889.36 on Friday -- only 9.90 points below its level on Aug. 1. The Standard & Poor's 500 is well above its level on Aug. 2 and set record highs earlier this month.
But last week, the rally began to show signs of fading. Volume dropped, and most stock indexes showed their first weekly decline since early January.
Trading activity was much lower in the weeks leading up to the start of the air war in January; many institutional investors husbanded cash and waited for what they thought would be a buying opportunity after the war began. When prices rallied, those investors jumped in, sending prices even higher.
Now, with all that money invested, there may be less liquidity available to drive the market higher should the allies triumph. "I feel the market is in a no-win situation," Michael Metz, the chief market strategist at Oppenheimer & Company, told Reuters. "The investment community has already bought and paid for a brief and highly successful ground campaign."
In the end, the stock market's course must reflect the successes, or lack of them, of the companies whose stocks are being traded. Some companies seem likely to benefit from the end of the war, notably those likely to get large Kuwaiti contracts to help rebuild the country and put its oil industry back into operation. Kuwait is reported to be planning to give a large share of those contracts to American and British companies, including those in the construction and oil-service businesses.
For other companies, the health of the economy will be a major factor. The stock market's sharp ascent since mid-January appears to be anticipating a quick end to the recession in this country.
Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, has voiced fears that a prolonged war would depress consumer confidence and thus extend the recession. There are hopes that a successful completion of the fighting will help to restore that confidence, perhaps leading to rebounds in sectors like housing and auto sales.
Both those areas are supposed to benefit from lower interest rates, but so far they have not, despite aggressive easing from the Fed. The rate on three-month Treasury bills, at 7.43 percent when Iraq invaded, is now at 5.96 percent.
The bond market's rally, like the stock market's, showed signs of failing health last week. Mr. Kudlow said one cause was concern over possible heavy Government borrowing to finance the war.
Internationally, the American stock market fell less late last year than did others, and while all markets have moved up since the air war began, those in Germany and Japan, for example, remain well below the levels they held before the Iraqi invasion. The relative performance of the American market, however, is not as good as it appears at first, simply because the dollar has also been falling for much of the period, although it showed some strength last week.

HEADLINE: WAR IN THE GULF: WASHINGTON;
Aides Discuss Pressing For Hussein's Removal

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24

 BODY:
Although Administration officials are not prepared to say so publicly, they are making it increasingly clear that the United States now considers the downfall of President Saddam Hussein and the elimination of his Baath Party structure not only the most desirable ending to the war but also an attainable outcome.
President Bush's official position is that the United States is not actively seeking to remove Mr. Hussein from power, although the President has indicated he would welcome the Iraqi leader's ouster. Administration officials say they will be satisfied if the land war only evicts Iraq from Kuwait and seriously damages the Iraqi armed forces. 
 But Administration officials are speaking with increasing candor about the desire to see Mr. Hussein deposed and about ways of applying pressure to accomplish that.
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, Brent Scowcroft, the President's national security adviser, and Robert M. Gates, Mr. Scowcroft's deputy, all suggested in television appearances today that if Mr. Hussein remained in power, Washington and its allies would keep United Nations sanctions in place longer than they might otherwise. They also indicated that the American naval and air presence in the gulf would probably grow after the war.
"We're not making it an objective of the war that he goes," a senior State Department official said. "But we're trying to create an environment that either insures that the people of Iraq understand it's not in their interest to keep him around or that insures that he cannot be a threat to any other country."
As the onset of ground combat brought the United States closer to being able to dictate the terms of the end of the war, senior officials acknowledged publicly today that American political goals exceed the simple military objective of liberating Kuwait.
When asked if the United States intended to carry out the equivalent of the de-Nazification of Germany after World War II, Mr. Baker said that was a "political aim" of Washington.
 
'A Heck of a Lot Easier'
 If Mr. Hussein remains in power, Administration officials said, Mr. Bush is calculating that his military will be so badly damaged that it will not be a threat and that he himself will no longer be a political force.
But Mr. Baker said today on the ABC News program "This Week" that the United Nations resolutions on Kuwait "imply that the restoration of peace and stability in the gulf would be a heck of a lot easier if he and that leadership were not in power in Iraq."
But if the United States succeeds in achieving the downfall of Mr. Hussein, it could reignite the longstanding civil strife in Iraq.
The United States could then be forced to decide how deeply involved it wants to be in a politically divided country without roads and airports and with even its ability to feed itself severely damaged by the war.
As the ground war loomed last week, the question of Mr. Hussein's future caused the first significant rift between the United States and the Soviet Union over the gulf since Iraq invaded Kuwait last Aug. 2.
Administration officials said today that they believed the aim of the Soviet Union's attempts at peace brokering was to prevent the United States from achieving its political aims in the gulf.
"I think they would like to keep Saddam in power and I think they would like to retain an influence in an Iraq that's a player in the region," a senior Administration official said.
 
Overstepping Resolutions Feared
 This was one reason, officials said, that Mr. Bush did not inform Mr. Gorbachev of the exact starting time for the ground offensive, even though the two spoke on Saturday just before Mr. Bush's ultimatum expired at noon.
Still, both in public and in private, officials tried to play down the idea that the differences over the gulf would sour Soviet-American relations. They noted that the Soviet Union backed down after its peace efforts fell through, and did not try to block further military action through the United Nations Security Council.
Officials said the Soviet Union had agreed to refrain from such action and to avoid strongly anti-American responses to the ground war. In return, the United States had promised that this episode would not disrupt superpower relations after the war, the officials said.
One reason that officials have taken care not to make Mr. Hussein's downfall, even at the hands of his own people, an explicit goal, is that it would exceed the mandate of the United Nations and could draw opposition within the coalition. It also could draw fire on Capitol Hill, where lawmakers have been divided about whether the United States should actively seek Mr. Hussein's removal.
 
Explicit Criticism Avoided
 Today, lawmakers generally avoided criticism of Mr. Bush's decision to launch the ground war. But Democrats also pointedly avoided expressing specific approval for it either.
"I hope that the U.S. and allied forces' efforts will be successful with the minimum loss of life," said Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the Majority Leader.
Senator Sam Nunn, the Georgia Democrat and chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee who has generally urged Mr. Bush to move slowly in the gulf, said, "The ground war, like the air war, has been well planned and I am confident that our military will carry it out with skill and professionalism. I am also confident that we will succeed."
Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the House majority leader, said, "The American people pray for the men and women who are risking their lives for a free and independent Kuwait, and I join in their prayers."
