HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:
The Ground War Begins
If the Persian Gulf war ends in an allied victory by late March, with relatively few casualties, the American economy will almost certainly receive a lift. But many economists doubt that peace by springtime is sufficient in itself to end the recession. An early victory's biggest likely benefits are a rise in consumer confidence and a drop in oil prices. [Page D1.] 
 The ground war against Iraq is likely to result in lower oil prices, at least in the short term, experts said yesterday. Most of these experts said a short ground war was likely to bring lower prices than a longer conflict. [D1.]
A relatively short campaign will have little effect on military contractors' prospects, analysts and executives say, even though it is the first combat test of several weapons systems. [D3.]
The beginning of the ground attack had a modest but positive effect on financial markets in Tokyo. [D3.]
More than a month ago, Wall Street was nearly unanimous in fearing that the beginning of the war against Iraq could send stock prices plunging. It was wrong. Last week, a similar but less cohesive consensus developed, holding that a ground war was bad news for financial markets. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [D1.]
 
The Economy
Orders for American-made machine tools plunged 32.4 percent in January from an unusually high level in December. Analysts said that in addition to being skewed by a year-end surge in orders, the sharp decline reflected typical weak winter demand. [D2.]
First Chicago Corporation says it revoked thousands of credit cards held by residents of Northeastern states as part of a credit review of the economically weak region. [D2.]
The sporting goods industry is doing its best to ignore the forebodings of recession, hoping a menu of new technology, sauteed in marketing hype, will bring in sales. [C10.]
The F.D.A. has approved the first human tests of a purified blood product from cattle. If successful, the experiments could lead to safer and cheaper blood transfusions. [B8.]
 
International
The stage is set for a fierce scrap in Washington between protectionists and free traders. Forces led by organized labor and the textile industry are hoping to torpedo a prospective world trade agreement, as well as one between the U.S. and Mexico. [D1.]
After a five-year battle to open Japan's markets, imports have risen swiftly and huge financial surpluses have plummeted. [D6.]
Poland reached a tentative agreement with the I.M.F. on a $2 billion aid package. [A2.]
 
The Media Business
Samir Husni's Guide to New Magazines shows a thriving industry, with hundreds of new magazines each year. [D1.]
Leonard H. Goldenson thinks he knows what is wrong with the network television business: The ideas are not fresh enough, the programming is not risky enough, and the executives are not young enough. Bill Carter: Television. [D10.]
Publishers are turning to consultants for advice on everything from motivating the sales force to selling books to libraries to making warehouses cost-effective. [D10.]
The Los Angeles Times plans to stop selling papers in part of central California and in neighboring states, but it is expected to remain the nation's largest circulation metropolitan daily. [D10.]
K Mart will begin one of its biggest TV campaigns early next month with a series of 200 separate commercials. The ads are intended to demonstrate that the chain has some things in common with fancier department stores. Kim Foltz: Advertising. [D8.]
 
Today's Column
Participants in the credit markets seem to have overlooked a continued slide in commodity prices in recent weeks. Kenneth N. Gilpin: Credit Markets. [D7.]

HEADLINE: Blaze Strikes Office Tower in Philadelphia, Killing 3

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 24

 BODY:
Three firefighters were killed today in a fire that raged for 18 1/2 hours through eight floors of a downtown office tower.
Even after the blaze was brought under control at 3 P.M., there were fears that the 38-story building had been so weakened that its top half might collapse or shed its granite skin. 
 Fire officials said the blaze, the nation's worst high-rise fire in a decade, could have been under control in an hour if the building had had sprinklers on every floor. It was only after sprinklers on the top 10 floors began working that the fire was contained.
 
Warning to Firefighters
 Most firefighters left the building, One Meridian Plaza, about 7:30 A.M. today, when engineers warned of a collapse. The police cordoned off a five-block area and the City Hall plaza, across the street and said some streets might have to be closed indefinitely.
Fire Marshal Robert C. Wauhop said a collapse could not be ruled out until structural engineers completed their inspection of the building, perhaps as early as Monday. "We don't know if the building is sound," he said.
The three firefighters who died in the building had radioed for help about midnight Saturday, saying they were trapped on the 30th floor and that their portable tanks were running out of air.
A rescue team landed a helicopter on the building's roof in a futile effort to bring them out. "By the time we found them it was too late," said Roger M. Ulshafer, the Philadelphia Fire Commissioner. Their bodies were found on the 28th floor, but it was not clear if they had given the wrong floor in their call for help or if they had moved.
 
Cause Is Unknown
 The cause of the fire is unknown. Fire officials said it probably started in an insurance office on the 22d floor of the million building, which is named after the building's prime tenant, Meridian Bancorp.
As the fire raged out of control, about 200 firefighters from 35 companies could do little more than stand by, their equipment on the street, and watch the smoke and flames consume the building. Some firefighters, standing on the roof of a adjacent high-rise building, fired plumes of water into the burning structure.
The fire blackened the top 16 stories of the building, and smoke poured out of hundreds of missing windows. Elevators could not be used, so firefighters had to stretch six 5-inch hoses by hand to the 22nd floor, he said.
"By the time we got them up there and got enough water, the fire was three floors above our heads," Mr. Ulshafer said.
At times, smoke enveloped the statue of William Penn on top of City Hall and could be seen for miles on this clear, mild day. Hundreds of people came to watch; many brought video cameras.
 
Limited Sprinkler System
 The 19-year-old building, like most of the nation's high-rises, has a very limited sprinkler system. A city law, passed in 1984, requires sprinkler systems on every floor of new buildings over seven stories tall; One Meridian Plaza had them only on the top 10 floors, primarily to fight possible fires in a heliport on its roof.
Making matters worse last night, Mr. Ulshafer said, all of the building's fire-protection systems failed: emergency electric generators, water pumps and pressure valves that would normally have provided firefighters with water on the upper floors.
The failures delayed firefighting efforts for several hours, and the blaze engulfed four floors before firefighting efforts began in earnest.
The fire gutted the 22d story through the 29th, and Mr. Ulshafer said its intense heat had badly warped and weakened the building's steel skeleton from the 18th story to the 28th.
"We're very concerned that the building may collapse, pancaking down to the 18th floor," he said.
The three men who died last night were Capt. David Holcomb, who was 52 years old and had been with the department for 28 years; Phyllis McAllister, 44, a 10-year veteran, and James A. Chappell, 29, a four-year veteran.
Seventeen firefighters were injured.
 
'State of Shock'
 "We're all basically in a state of shock," said Fire Chief Bernard D. Dyer. "The whole department is very saddened by it. These were co-workers and our friends."
The building's owner, Richard I. Rubin & Company, a local real estate developer, said in a statement: "Words are simply inadequate to express our deepest sympathy to the families of those firemen who have been injured and those who have lost their lives in this most terrible disaster."
The burning building has 756,000 square feet. One onlooker, Andrew Mainardi 3d, general partner of the Mainardi Management Company, a commercial real estate firm, estimated that it was worth over $150 million.
Neither Mayor W. Wilson Goode nor his press secretary returned calls seeking comment.
The Philadelphia fire is the nation's worst high-rise fire since Nov. 21, 1980, when 84 people died inside the MGM Grand's 28-story hotel and casino in Las Vegas. That fire was blamed on the building's antiquated safety design, built before the adoption of a 1970 Uniform Building Code, which has been adopted by many cities and counties.
William T. Jones, deputy assistant chief of the New York Fire Department, said of the Philadelphia fire: "We've never had a fire that serious in New York. Could it happen in New York? Possibly, but not probably." New York City regulations adopted in 1973 require every 7,500 square feet of high-rise space to be isolated with fire-resistant walls.
 
Off-Duty Forces Called
 Edward Marra, chief of operations for Philadelphia's Department of Licenses and Inspections, said that when the city passed the 1984 law for new buildings officials wanted all buildings to be fitted with sprinklers.
"But for economic reasons or because they didn't think it was necessary, they didn't require it," he said. "This fire will help our cause. Unfortunately, to change a code you have to produce a body count."
The fire absorbed much of the department's manpower, forcing the department to call up all of its off-duty firefighters last night, said Fire Chief Dyer.
The police said several downtown streets would be closed for several days and urged commuters to take public transportation.
Mr. Ulshafer said firefighters would let the building cool naturally before trying to enter, probably Monday.
"We're concerned that the cold water on the hot steel up there will cause further contraction and expansion and then give us a collapse," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Three Philadelphia firefighters were killed and 17 were injured fighting a fire that raged for more than 18 hours through eight floors of the 38-story One Meridian Plaza office building before being brought under control yesterday afternoon. At left is City Hall. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Effect of Persian Gulf News On Tokyo Markets Is Slight

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Monday, Feb. 25

 BODY:
The beginning of the ground attack in the Persian Gulf war had a modest but positive effect on financial markets here early today. Traders said a quick victory by the United States and its allies over Iraq had been anticipated by investors last week.
Market experts were quick to add, however, that should the news from the Persian Gulf turn negative after the inital signs of success, the markets could be vulnerable to deep disappointment and a severe drop. 
 In the meantime, the dollar rose, oil prices were unchanged, and the Tokyo stock market edged upward.
 
Nikkei Finishes Higher
 In the morning trading session, the closely watched Nikkei index of 225 issues rose 559.95 points, or 2.1 percent, to 26,462.76. At midday, the Nikkei rose 193.70 points, also less than 1 percent, to 26,096.51, and buying by Japanese investment trusts gave the market an added lift in the last hour of trading. On Friday, the index fell 121.56 points.
"The feeling here has been that one way or another, we were getting close to an end of the war," Lawrence Praeger, an analyst at Nikko Securities, said after morning trading. "The market is starting to look beyond the war now, really. What is driving it is the fundamentals, things like the economy and the dollar."
Much as expected, the dollar popped upwards when trading began here early today. This was also based on the prospect that an end to the war would boost consumer sentiment in the United States and invigorage the stalled American economy.
The dollar rose as high as 132.80 yen here, then slipped slightly to 132.35 at midday, up from 132.15 in New York late on Friday.
 
News Was Discounted
 "There is still a limit to how high the dollar can go, because the news was basically discounted," Takashi Okura, head foreign exchange trader here for the Bank of America, said after the early session.
The oil markets were even quieter. In Singapore, the center for crude oil trading in Asia, traders said prices barely budged. The benchmark price for light crude oil was quoted at $17.75 a barrel, compared with $17.91 in New York late on Friday.
"Nothing happened because there is still no shortage of oil," said a trader in Singapore. "Even with the Kuwaiti facilities ruined by the Iraqis, that does not change the supply situation since we hadn't been getting any oil from Iraq. There's no reason to take prices up or down yet."

HEADLINE: WAR IN THE GULF: THE TROOPS;
'We Own This Piece,' G.I. Proclaims

BYLINE: By JOHN KIFNER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: IN IRAQ, Feb. 24

 BODY:
More than 2,000 American air assault troops plunged at least 50 miles into Iraq at first light today in what officials described as the largest helicopter-borne operation in military history.
The attack north of Iraq's troop concentrations by the 101st Airborne Division established what is essentially a giant, fortified gas station. The installation, known as Cobra base, will fuel helicopters for assaults in the strategic Euphrates River valley to sever the main highway between Baghdad and Basra. 
 "We own this piece of desert," 1st Lieut. Phil Johnson, a Ranger, said with a grin as his Huey helicopter settled into the landing zone in a cloud of sand dust.
 
20 Miles in Diameter
 The operation was so huge and so far-flung that its dimensions were hard to grasp. The new Cobra Zone embraces a circle 20 miles in diameter, with defending infantry battalions ranged around the edge. As the ground campaign accelerates, the entire base is to be moved again.
By nightfall, a supporting ground column of more than 700 trucks had reached the base, bringing the number of troops there to 4,000. As American planners moved operations ahead of schedule because of what they said was crumbling Iraqi resistance, another brigade from the 101st planned to fly into the base tonight.
French light armor attacking from the ground on the 101st's left flank was moving faster than anticipated, ranking officers said. On the right flank were the American 24th Mechanized Infantry Division and the VII Armored Corps, equipped with heavy M-1A1 tanks that raced north from the border this afternoon, nearly a day ahead of schedule.
 
Column of Black Helicopters
 As the sun broke over the sands early this morning, long columns of giant black Chinook helicopters, many of them carrying field artillery, trucks, boxes of ammunition and aviation fuel, swept over the horizon barely 40 feet above the ground. Cobra and Apache attack helicopters had been blasting the area, an ancient lake bed, for days to clear out any possible resistance.
By late morning, a small hill had sprouted radio antennas at the makeshift command post. Soldiers had begun digging into the sandy, rock-strewn soil with entrenching tools and filling sandbags.
"There's not another division in the army that could have done this," exulted the commander of the First Brigade, Col. Tom Hill, standing atop the hill at midday. Radio men crouched around him, calling out map coordinates.
 
G.I.'s Shout 'Hoo-ah!"
 "Hoo-ah! Hoo-ah!" soldiers and officers shouted in this war's expression of approval, as they tumbled off the helicopters and scrambled into position.
The first combat test of the Army's new air-land battle doctrine went almost like clockwork, officers said, and virtually without opposition. The doctrine calls for large-scale use of air power and leap-frogging mobile troops over concentrations of enemy forces to attack from a position of advantage.
The helicopters that flew on operations from the Cobra base met only light, scattered resistance. By midday, roughly 15 prisoners had been taken, American officers said, including an Iraqi battalion commander who was persuaded to urge some remaining troops to surrender.
"The prisoners we've gotten say, 'This is Saddam's war, we don't want any part of it,' " said Lieut. Col. Gary Bridges, whose Third Battalion flushed a small group of Iraqis out of a bunker.
 
100,000 Gallons of Fuel
 By midday, Cobra and Apache attack helicopters were refueling for attacks further north, drawing up to giant containers with black nozzles and rubber bladders. The containers were ferried here along with 100,000 gallons of aviation fuel by the Chinook helicopters.
"This is a way station for future operations," said Colonel Hill."That's why we're here. We've put in here in the last three-plus hours 2,000 soldiers and 50 TOW antitank systems. We're starting to pump gas. It's going according to schedule. We got here. That's the first step on the road."
Briefing five journalists who accompanied the division during the final days of planning, the 101st Division commander, Maj. Gen. J. H. Binford Peay 3d, had said: "What we hope is we've got him by surprise. He doesn't know we're coming in."
That indeed appeared to be the case.
As one of the troop-ferrying helicopters rumbled north, its passengers could see a single Iraqi soldier emerging from a hut and staring, slack-jawed at the sight.
 
Wondering What Iraqis Think
 "We were talking about what those guys would think on the way in," said Command Sgt. Major Jim Arrabondo as the Third Battalion's mortar platoon dug in to protect their position. "One moment it's peaceful, the next moment they've got a whole brigade on them."
Cobra Zone is not only a refueling stop, but a staging area for the division's other two brigades as they leap northeast.
"This is air assault history in the making," Colonel Hill told the reporters attached to the division in an earlier briefing before the ground war began. "There has never been anything like this done before. When the war starts, we're going to be a long way in with nobody else around."
In addition to more than 2,000 soldiers, the 118 helicopters were shuttling in supplies, including about 50 truck-mounted TOW anti-tank weapons, two full artillery battalions of 105-millimeter howitzers, tons of miscellaneous supplies including eight dirt motorcycles for the division's scouts, and the key payload of aviation fuel and pumps. Some of the supply helicopters were flown by women.
 
Convoy Across the Desert
 Traveling across the desert along an old track used for the annual Muslim pilgrimage, a convoy brought another 100,000 gallons of aviation fuel, some 30 tons of ammunition and other equipment, 30 more TOW antitank weapons, field hospitals and the 2,000 additional troops. Among the forces arriving were two more artillery batteries and members of the military police, many of whom are expected to be diverted to deal with Iraqi prisoners.
The operation owes much to two military colleges that keep alive a Southern military tradition, the Virginia Military Institute and the Citadel in South Carolina. The convoy is code-named Citadel, after the college attended by its commander, Lieut. Col. Jim McGarity. The roadbed has been renamed Newmarket, after the Civil War battle fought by cadets from V.M.I., the alma mater of General Peay and Colonel Hill.
The area had been softened up for days by allied air strikes. Several of the division's helicopter pilots, including the aviation brigade commander, Col. Dick Cody, had landed in the dried lake bed to test the surface.
"I don't think a lot of people have bad words for the Air Force or aviation," said Sergeant Major Arrabondo, dismissing the traditional rivalry between the services.
 
Challenge of Elite Iraqi Units
 The major challenge facing the allied thrust is believed to be at least two divisions of elite Republican Guards stationed as a strategic reserve east and somewhat south of Basra. The divisions have been heavily pounded by allied bombers but are staying in well-fortified bunkers, United States officers say.
American commanders say they also have considerable respect for Iraqi artillery, particularly the South African-made 155-millimeter guns, which are said to be accurate beyond 18 miles.
Colonel Hill said that any Iraqi counterattack would involve bringing the troops and vehicles out of their hardened shelters into the open, where they could be attacked by overwhelming allied air power.
"That's the whole ground plan, get him out of those revetments," he said. "Every time we get him out of the revetments, we kill him."
 
Brigade Assembled Saturday
 The troops of the First Brigade began assembling for the attack at noon on Saturday. By dusk, some 118 helicopters were spread across 19 boarding zones in the Saudi desert north of the Tapline Road. Circling in long arcs among the helicopters were nearly 700 vehicles of the ground convoy, with bright orange recognition cloths on their roofs.
"It's an awesome sight," said Colonel Hill, surveying the helicopters under a darkening sky. "When I looked at it I thought, 'Cry havoc and let loose the dogs of war.' "

GRAPHIC: Photo: American Military vehicles entering Iraq as the land battle began (Agence France-Presse) (pg. A1)
 
Map: 'Movements in the Ground War' shows positions of allied and Iraqi troops in and around Kuwait (pg. A13)
 
Chart: 'Kuwait Before the Invasion'
 
GOVERNMENT
Since the sheikdom of Kuwait was founded in 1756, it has been ruled, sometimes under British guardianship, by the Sabah family, who were chosen by its first Arab settlers.
 At the time of the invasion by Iraq on Aug. 2, the Emir of Kuwait was Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah, who was both head of state and Prime Minister, leading a Cabinet with 10 appointed ministers and 4 elected ones.
 
HISTORY
Kuwait became part of Turkey's Ottoman Empire in the 16th century, later becoming a semi-autonomous monarchy. In 1899, fearing further Turkish control, Kuwait became a British protectorate.
 After World War I, the Ottoman Empire was broken up and Kuwait remained a self-governing British protectorate until 1961. On June 19 of that year, Britain granted Kuwait full independence and six days later Baghdad claimed Kuwait as an integral part of Iraq. British troops landed in Kuwait to forestall any Iraqi invasion and on July 20, the Arab League admitted the sheikdom to membership, recognizing its independence.
When the Iraq-Iran war ended, Iraq renewed its claims to Kuwait.
 
GEOGRAPHY
Bounded on the west and north by Iraq, on the east by the Persian Gulf, and to the south by Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, with an area of 6,880 square miles (or about 1,000 square miles smaller than Massachusetts), is largely a desert except for some fertile patches in the southeastern and coastal areas.
 Among the most important of several offshore islands, many of which are uninhabited, are Bubiyan and Warba Islands, barren mudflats that control the entrance to Iraq's chief ports, Umm Qasr and Basra, and Failaka Island.
 
THE PEOPLE
The 862,200 Kuwaitis, according to a 1974 tabulation, are predominately Arab. Before the Iraqi invasion, more than a million foreign residents were the mainstay of government, technical and other services.
 Islam is the religion of 95 percent of the people. The majority are Sunnis and there is a significant Shiite minority.
 
ECONOMY
 Before the invasion, more than 90 percent of the Government's income came from oil. The country produced about 2.4 million barrels a day despite a production quota set by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting States at 1.5 million barrels a day. This over-production was considered a significant factor in depressing world oil prices and infuriated Iraq.

HEADLINE: Review/Television;
Destitution in the 1930's (No, It's Not "The Grapes")

BYLINE: By WILBORN HAMPTON

 BODY:
It is probably not necessary for the country to be in a recession for network television to program a movie like "Long Road Home," a sort of bowdlerized spinoff of "The Grapes of Wrath," but it can't hurt. Viewers always like to be reminded that things could be worse, although today's alien migrant workers might not entirely agree.
"Long Road Home," to be shown tonight on NBC at 9, follows the travails of the Robertson family through the San Joaquin Valley in 1937 as they look for work picking fruit, vegetables or cotton. The teleplay by Jane-Howard Hammerstein almost begs comparisons with the Joads of Steinbeck's classic. 
 The Robertsons are Texans, not Okies. Ertie Robertson (Mark Harmon) is an ex-rodeo rider, not a sharecropper, and there's not an ex-con among his five children. His wife, Bessie (Lee Purcell), wants a house so the family "can get back on its feet again." But as was true for the Joads, just about anything bad that can happen to the Robertsons does. Their car breaks down; the baby gets sick; there's union agitation in the fields; they are paid company scrip instead of real money, and everybody's hungry. Just when it looks as if things can't get any worse, it starts to rain. Before it's over, each of the four horsemen of the Apocalypse takes the family for a ride.
The Robertsons' poverty is established before the credits are finished rolling. When they stop to buy gas, they are down to their last $1.33. And when a farm foreman shortchanges them their day's wages, one son threatens to smack him with a two-by-four. "We don't have a two-by-four," his sister reminds him.
Yet as so often happens in prime time, nothing is quite as bad as it seems, even destitution. Soon afterward, the son turns up with a rifle, hunting rabbits, and Pa even has a pistol hidden away along with several boxes of cartridges. (The pistol becomes important to the plot later on.) A short time later, Ma is shopping in a grocery store with real money and picking up a real-estate tip on a little house for sale on a sort of layaway plan for $10 a month.
There is, of course, a lot of hardship and soul-searching and evil to overcome before the chicken coop of a house can be called home. There are bad forces at work against the Robertsons, and "Long Road Home" makes it easy to identify them. Basically, the poor people are good and the farm owners are bad. Most everybody else, from the local sheriff to the local congressman, is in the pocket of the local land baron. The union organizers sort of lurk in the background, waiting to help and tempting Jake, the eldest son (Morgan Weisser), but Pa is the sort who likes to take care of his own. There are the requisite subplots, including a budding love story, and some color on how the poor amuse themselves, including a hoedown by a bonfire.
A lot of effort has gone into what is clearly a well-intentioned and heartfelt project, and Mr. Harmon and Ms. Purcell do what they can. But there is just so much credibility one can give to lines like "There ain't no God in this valley, Ma," or "We're gonna get out of this vale of tears." And it's hard to believe in a poverty that manages to keep a perfect three days' growth of beard on a migrant laborer for several months and provides clean dresses, shampoo and bobby pins to women who spend their days in the field. In the end, "Long Road Home" is a fairy-tale view not only of the Great Depression, but of the labor movement it spawned and the way its victims survived. For those who prefer a more authentic vintage trampled out of the 1930's, PBS will telecast the Broadway production of Steppenwolf Theater's adaptation of "The Grapes of Wrath" on American Playhouse next month.
 
Long Road Home
 
Directed by John Korty; written by Jane-Howard Hammerstein, based on a book by Ronald B. Taylor; produced by David A. Rosemont for Rosemont Productions; Norman Rosemont, executive producer. At 9 tonight on NBC .

HEADLINE: ON YOUR OWN;
Sporting-Goods Makers Hawk Wares at Show

BYLINE: By BARBARA LLOYD

DATELINE: ATLANTA

 BODY:
THE sporting-goods industry did its best last week to ignore the recession. The 85,000 sports aficionados who gathered here for the industry's largest annual trade exhibit -- the Super Show -- whet their appetites on a menu of new technology sauteed in marketing hype.
With more than 1.6 million square feet of floor space and 6,000 booths at four sites in the downtown area, mostly at the Georgia World Congress Center, manufacturers unveiled exercise machines that talk back, tennis racquets that sound heavy but feel light, shoes that spring off their heels, bicycles that jump curbs and clothes that breathe. 
 Swarms of buyers for stores perused the show in search of items that would sell in a flat retail market. Although the Sporting Goods Manufacturers Association, which stages the show, projected a 6 percent growth in the industry's wholesale volume, from $30.8 billion in 1990 to $32.7 billion in 1991, the number fell short of the double-digit expansion the industry had come to expect.
But insiders were buoyed by the recession-resistant nature of the industry. "Sports have become a solid part of the modern-life style, and, therefore, sporting-goods sales are less negatively affected in recessionary times," said John D. Riddle, association president.
 
An Overview
 Lured by dazzling product displays, visitors to the show faced a marketing barrage. From Joe Montana to Greg Norman, sports celebritries appeared as if they were hors d'oeuvres in a dinner of corporate steaks.
Nike, the athletic-footwear manufacturer, spent $4 million on its booth. The 61,000-square-foot area featured Nike's newest shoes under robotic lights on center stage. Reebok, dominated a $1 million space not far down the concourse where aerobic dance skits, loud rock music and intermittent celebrity autograph signings set a frenetic pace.
Lower-profile exhibitors staffed booths strung out with wares like an exotic marketplace. Despite the enticements, most dealers seemed cautious.
"We're going to watch our spending," said Brad Henry, a buyer for Valley Sports of Fresno, Calif. "We're not going to tie up our dollars far in advance."
The mood translated into a search for trends: something, anything to make the public buy, buy, buy. Here are a few trends to watch for in your sport and equipment of choice.
 
Tennis
Widebody racquets are still the industry favorites. But the new watchwords of the 46 racquet manufacturers at the show are "lighter" and "more flexible." First introduced by Wilson Sporting Goods in 1987, the widebody racquet was made to be stiff and powerful. Today's versions are designed to put feel back in the racquet and dampen shock. Racquets are lighter than ever: the 10-ounce barrier has been broken.
"They are taking the fat out," said Tracy Leonard, equipment adviser for Tennis magazine.
And finding ingenious ways to do it, too. Head's Genesis racquet, for instance, is thinner in the cross sections. The Hammer, Wilson's newest high-end widebody, has taken about two ounces out of the handle, but kept the same weight in the head.
Prince introduced the Vortex widebody racquet at the show, its light weight achieved with materials adopted from the aerospace industry: viscoelastic polymer, a thermoplastic material, and continuous strands of carbon fiber. The strings are staggered along the frame, an innovation designed to absorb more impact from the ball.
Dunlop attacked the widebody's shock-absorption problem in a different way. With its new Revelation racquet, introduced last month and on display at the show, the company added vibration-dampening rods to the handle.
High-end racquets are closing in on $300. But the new technology is filtering down to mid-priced racquets, too.
 
Footwear
 The leading footwear manufacturers set the tone of the show with fancy video displays and Hollywood floor shows. But even more impressive was their sheer numbers: more than 160 exhibitors of everything from basketball shoes to sandals were on hand.
Other than L.A. Gear, which has produced the Catapult, a basketball shoe with a heel spring, most innovations are directed at weight savings.
"The challenge is in finding a balance between light, and making a shoe with cushioning, stability and support," said Bill Dragon, president of Avia.
New materials, like thermoplastics, carbon fiber and foams, are replacing standard materials. Nike has taken the heel counter out of its new Haurache running shoe and replaced it with a molded rubber heel strap.
And making it clear that they intend to follow their customers from the basketball and tennis courts to the trails of the backwoods, the leading manufacturers showed new lines of shoes and clothing for hiking, camping and mountain biking.
"People who were exposed to running in the 1980's while they were single are looking for activities they can do with their families in the 1990's," said Tom Clarke, director of marketing for Nike.
 
Fitness
Weight machines, popular in the 1970's, are making a comeback for the home, said Richard Miller, a buyer for The Gym Source, a New York City equipment distributor. "Home use is the future," Miller said.
Companies like Pacific Fitness are making compact home-gym units that allow for 100 different exercises at a price of $1,600 to $2,400.
CSA Inc., a fitness-products manufacturer from South Easton, Mass., introduced 23 new exercise machines at the show, including several versions of computerized talking machines that it began marketing last year. The units are designed to verbally coach users, and to store previous workouts so they can be recalled for comparison to a new routine.
Bike machines still appear to be more popular than treadmills and stairsteppers.
Traditional companies are diversifying. Life Fitness, the company that spearheaded the stationary-bike movement, has designed a new stair machine this year, Lifestep 5500, available this summer for $1,295.
 
Bicycling
Although bicycling is a fast-growing sport with a propensity for dramatic innovation, only 19 bicycle manufacturers showed up in Atlanta. A recent study by Bicycling magazine counted 32 million cyclists in the United States. In recognition of this popularity, the Super Show opened its doors for a cycle show for the first time. Although few of the leading manufacturers attended, signs of trends surfaced, most noticeably in the cross bike.
As a hybrid of road and mountain bikes, the cross bike has thinner tires than a mountain bike. It has a more central shifting system, and a sloping top tube. "People are finding that the mountain bike is too much bike," said Chuck McCullagh, publisher of Bicycling. "The cross bike is a bike that people can ride for commuting or in-town use."
 
Apparel
Neon is out and deeper, richer tones and earth colors are in, reflecting a pervasive embrace of the outdoors. Moreover, companies like Du Pont, Hind and Nike, who make their own fabrics, are finding that function is blurring with fashion.
"This crossover isn't necessarily a permanent thing because of the fickleness of ready-to-wear," said Jennifer Lisle, fabrics editor at Sport Style, a biweekly sports publication.
Function, however, still dominates. Lynn Hill, the top United States women's rock climber, and Katarina Witt, the German Olympic skater, attended the Super Show on behalf of Du Pont and Hind. Hill scaled artificial walls to demonstrate how athletic tights "allow you to move with your sport."

SECTION: Section A; Page 18; Column 6; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 374 words

HEADLINE: Let's Do Something About Deposit Insurance;
End Glass-Steagall

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Leonard Silk's Feb. 8 Economic Scene column ("The Argument Over the Banks") cites Albert G. Hart as an expert on why the Administration's proposals to restructure the banking system will not work. One expert's opinion deserves another.
Professor Hart cites every questionable banking practice employed during the 1980's as evidence that the restructuring of the system will fail. This may be an important, but nevertheless not relevant part of the picture. Indeed, many of the questionable practices, as for instance the cited Continental Illinois case of dealing in oil paper, were direct results of the restrictiveness of the Glass-Steagall Act, the Depression-era law that keeps commercial banks from investment banking and selling insurance. 
 Deregulated banks wanted to escape the limitations of the one-branch or at best statewide system by accepting paper from other, often smaller, banks that were not properly evaluated. One can now debate whether industry ownership of banks is desirable, but it should be clear that our banking system suffers from its inability to branch across state lines. The Glass-Steagall Act denies banks the chance to tap national markets, increase their deposit base and enhance their capital, as recently pointed out by Walter Wriston.
A national branch banking system with about eight national banks, and about a dozen regional banks would tap a vastly larger deposit base, diversify product markets, be much easier to regulate by a single authority, preferably the Federal Reserve Board, and would make a multitude of clearing houses and other financial and regulatory crutches unnecessary, with a resultant increase of overall efficiency and security.
The cited disadvantages pertain to effective regulation -- why should it be possible for other nations to have well-capitalized branch banks that serve their economies? Our banking system also reflects this country's longstanding unfavorable international payments position, but that is another argument for speedy bank restructuring and abolition of the Glass-Steagall Act.
 
RICHARD HYSE
St. Petersburg, Fla., Feb. 8, 1991
 
The writer is professor emeritus of eonomics, State University of New York at Oswego.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (79%);

HEADLINE: ABROAD AT HOME;
Dona Nobis Pacem

BYLINE: By Anthony Lewis

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
If the official accounts are believ able and they are -- the ground war has begun easily and well for the allies. We can hope for a quick military victory.
Even Americans with doubts about this war may take satisfaction in the defeat of Saddam Hussein. The cause of undoing his aggression was always just. The war has only confirmed his brutality and megalomanic misjudgment. 
 But the doubts remain, unstilled by feats of arms. Will the Middle East be a more secure, politically enlightened region after this war? Will the world be more orderly? Will the war have a healthy influence on the United States? I can have no confidence in affirmative answers to those questions.
In the Middle East one need look at only the immediate foreground to see daunting problems. In Iraq, which had a modern economy, the basics of water and power and communications have been shattered. It is fantasy to think that a nice reasonable government will quickly take over, put things back together and make Iraq a good neighbor.
Then there is Kuwait. The devastation done by Iraqi occupiers has been multiplied by allied bombing. And the political prospect is embarrassing. Our pledge is to restore the legitimate Government. But will Americans or others be satisfied for long to have the al-Sabah family govern without the consent of the governed?
In the Persian Gulf as a whole there is the prickly question of American troops. For the Saudis and others it will be politically desirable, indeed urgent, to have them leave. But what security arrangement is going to take their place? Getting them out may prove trickier than bringing them in.
Or think about the problem that is such a major factor in the whole region's instability, the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. For a time I thought the responsibilities shouldered by the United States in the war would help it to be a peacemaker afterward. But there are reasons now to fear that the war will have made it even harder to solve the conflict.
The P.L.O. attached itself to Saddam Hussein, who cynically professed the Palestinian cause (and as cynically dropped it in the final diplomatic maneuvers). That attachment will make it even more difficult for Israel or the United States to work with the mainstream pro-P.L.O. leadership in the occupied territories.
Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, for his part, moved his Government even farther to the right under cover of the war. He took in a party favoring expulsion of all Palestinians from the occupied territories.
Whatever one thinks of President Bush's policy toward Iraq, he has been consistent and decisive in carrying it out. He began the air war the day after the United Nations deadline for Iraqi withdrawal. He began the ground war the evening after Iraq failed to meet his ultimatum.
But will he be as consistent in peace? Will he rouse the world as vigorously against every aggression and inhumanity? Will he forswear future lawless invasions himself?
Of course there can be no perfect consistency in the world we have. But some principle must animate Mr. Bush's vision of "a new world order."
Wars usually create more problems than they solve. I suspect that we shall look back at this one with more regrets than we can imagine today, in the flush of enthusiasm for victory.
One result, if it comes, would be a special disaster. That is the encouragement, in Americans, of the delusory belief that military power can solve the world's problems -- and that the United States can impose unilateral solutions.
Such an attitude would nourish the American military-industrial complex. It would lead us deeper into the mistake of neglecting civilian for military research and development. We are proud of our high-tech weapons. But while they were being developed, Robert Kuttner, the economic writer, points out, the American share of consumer-electronics production in the world fell from 70 percent to 5 percent.
It is at home that American ideas and energy need to be committed. We need to think more about education and economics and health, and military euphoria may make us short-change those real needs again.
The evening before the ground war began I was at a wonderful performance by Banchetto Musicale, the Boston early-music group, of Haydn's "Mass in Time of War." Haydn wrote it during Napoleon's wars, fearful of his aggression. Extraordinarily, the final "Dona nobis pacem" ("Grant us peace") is set with military drum and trumpets. But the hope is for peace.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Burmese Oil Has Attracted Exploration

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"A Sudden Revival for East Asian Oil" (Business Day, Feb. 4) is generally thorough, but has inaccurate information on Myanmar, formerly Burma, which ignores a potentially important development in the oil industry in that country, which was an oil exporter in colonial times.
In the fall of 1988, after the Sept. 18 military coup, the Government for the first time since Burmese independence in 1948 allowed foreign companies to bid on contracts for onshore oil exploration. Prospects had seemed bright, but the Burmese did not have internal capacity and had excluded foreign participation. Earlier offshore exploration produced disappointing results.
This onshore investment opportunity was a major change in Burmese economic policy, signaling a shift toward some economic liberalization and indicating indirectly the financial straits of the military regime, which insisted on substantial down payments.
The first contract was given to a Korean company (Yukong), and it was followed by nine more contracts to companies from the United States, Britain, Japan, France, the Netherlands, Canada and Australia.
Economic liberalization and foreign investment in Myanmar is tempered by political concerns, including an unresolved political crisis and continuing ethnic rebellions. But even the relatively modest openings have attracted much shorter-term trading and dubious natural resource exploitation. Oil exploration, however, is the essential longer-term foreign commitment.
 
DAVID I. STEINBERG
Bethesda, Md., Feb. 4, 1991
 
The writer, a professor at Georgetown University, has written books on Burma's political economy.

HEADLINE: Mexican Debt Deal May Save Jungle

BYLINE: By MARK A. UHLIG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Feb. 25

 BODY:
In one of the largest private "debt for nature" exchanges yet negotiated, Mexico has accepted an agreement that would reduce its foreign debt by $4 million in return for specific Government commitments to help preserve the country's tropical rain forests and other fast-disappearing natural resources.
The agreement, negotiated by a private American ecological group, Conservation International, is the first such agreement reached by Mexico, which has some of the rarest plant and animal life, and one of the largest debt burdens, in the world. It represents a major step forward in efforts to use foreign debt reduction as a tool for persuading third world governments to preserve wilderness areas. 
 Alhough the amount of money involved is not large by the standards of third world debt, the accord is seen by ecologists as an important endorsement of a financial mechanism that they hope will eventually be adopted for similar, much larger deals on a government-to-government level.
"Mexico is an absolutely critical country in which to have achieved this, because it occupies such an important place globally in terms of its biological richness," said Martin Goebel, director of Conservation International's programs in Mexico. "Many people know Mexico as a 'mega-debtor,' but too few realize that it is a 'megadiversity' country as well, with more plant and animal species than all but three other nations."
 
Rain Forest Is Focus
 Under the terms of the arrangement, completed last week, Conservation International is authorized to buy from Mexico's international creditors a total of $4 million in Mexican I.O.U's at discounted prices. The debt, which has been discounted on secondary markets and in restructuring agreements because of the difficulty in collecting it, is expected to cost the private group about 45 cents on the dollar, or $1.8 million, Mr. Goebel said.
Conservation International will then forgive the full amount of the debt in return for Mexican Government commitments to spend $2.6 million worth of Mexican pesos on a broad set of environmental projects set out as part of the agreement. Under the agreement, that money must be spent before the end of 1994, when the single, six-year term of Mexico's President, Carlos Salinas de Gortari, expires.
The primary focus of the conservation efforts contemplated in the agreement will be preservation of the Lacandona rain forest, the largest remaining tropical rain forest in North America. Fifty years ago, the lush, mist-shrouded Lacandona jungle covered more than 5,000 square miles, roughly the size of Connecticut, in southern Mexico on the Guatemalan border. But illegal logging and slash-and-burn agriculture has cut it to less than half that size.
Money provided under the new agreement will finance conservation data centers at the National Autonomous University of Mexico in the capital and in the state of Chiapas, where the rain forest stands. It will also support a science field station in the 1,278-square-mile Montes Azules Biosphere Reserve, a protected area in the Lacandona rain forest established by the Mexican Government more than a decade ago in an effort to save the most precious part of the jungle.
 
Of Keen Ecological Concern
 Although the agreement is the first of its kind for Mexico, Government officials and private conservationists pointed out that there are few countries where the potential of such a debt-for-nature exchange is as great.
With an outstanding foreign obligations of roughly $80 billion, Mexico is the second-largest debtor in the third world, after Brazil, and is a prime target for any program that can help ease its debt burden. As important, scientists estimate that as many as 16 percent of the plant and animal species in Mexico are found nowhere else in the world. In some areas of the country like Baja California as many as 80 percent of local species fall into that category.
The sheer number of species found within Mexico's borders also makes it a subject of keen ecological concern. Government officials say the Lacandona jungle alone is home to some 3,000 species of plants and flowers, 306 species of birds, 84 species of reptiles and 700 species of butterflies.
The Mexican debt-for-nature swap, which has been under negotiation since October 1989, is the fourth such agreement concluded by the Conservation International, a nonprofit group that is based in Washington and has offices in 16 countries. Other exchanges arranged by the organization, which is supported by funds from private philanthropies such as the John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation and the Sequoia Foundation, have included a 1987 debt swap in Bolivia and a 1990 agreement with Madagascar.

HEADLINE: U.S. Vehicle Sales Fell by 10.5% in Mid-February

BYLINE: By PAUL C. JUDGE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Feb. 25

 BODY:
Sales of cars and light trucks made in the United States continued to fall in mid-February, although the declines were not as steep as those of the last two months.
The 10 leading manufacturers reported combined light-vehicle sales of 260,944 between Feb. 11 and Feb. 20, compared with a weak period last year, when 259,027 vehicles were sold. On the basis of sales per day, sales fell 10.5 percent in mid-February from a year earlier. There were nine selling days in the period this year, and eight days last year.
 
Sharp Production Cuts
 Some car dealers said buyers had begun to return to showrooms in the last two weeks, and suggested that the industry had already begun to rebound from its deep slump. 
 But the auto makers see the sales drought lasting well into the spring, judging by their sharply curtailed production schedules for the next three months.
The companies said they sold 169,707 cars in mid-February, down 8.7 percent from the period a year earlier. Seasonally adjusted, cars sold at a 6 million annual rate, slightly ahead of the 5.9 million pace for the last 30 days. The seasonally adjusted annual rate for mid-February a year ago was 6.3 million cars.
Sales of light trucks, which include pickups, mini-vans, and four-wheel-drive vehicles, and which account for about a third of all vehicles sold, dropped 13.2 percent, to 91,670.
 
Big 3 Lose the Most
 The Big Three domestic auto makers posted the largest sales declines, as their combined car and light-truck sales fell 11.6 percent. Japanese companies with car plants in the United States reported flat sales of American-made cars, despite expanded production at several plants in the last year.
The Toyota Motor Corporation and the Honda Motor Company also reported their sales of imported vehicles, which fell 7.7 percent for the two auto makers in mid-February.
While most leading manufacturers posted declines, auto dealers and industry analysts said they sensed that demand was strengthening.
"The economic signposts that have led car sales in the past are strongly positive," said David Healy, an automotive analyst in New York with Barclays de Zoete Wedd. "Interest rates have dropped sharply, gasoline prices are plummeting, and it looks like good news coming from the Persian Gulf. The ingredients are there for a turnaround."
"We're on the rebound now," said Frank Debartolo, general sales manager at Celozzi-Ettelson Chevrolet in Elmhurst, Ill. Although Mr. Debartolo said that he was "full to the gills" with unsold vehicles, he predicted that dealers could run short by summer because of the plant shutdowns.
Other dealers are braced for more difficult times.
"Things are not all that rosy," said Jim Hoffer, sales manager at Jordan Ford in South Bend, Ind. Mr. Hoffer said sales were down 15 to 20 percent from a year ago. "I still think we have a tough 12 months ahead of us. The only thing that has remained steady are sales of used cars."
After a disastrous drop in January, the Ford Motor Company posted car sales of 50,799, off 3.8 percent from the period last year. Ford's light-truck sales declined 13.9 percent, to 31,458 vehicles.
 
Role of Rebates
 Analysts speculated that Ford dealers had begun to pass along larger rebates to customers after the poor January showing. In a big shift in December, Ford stopped offering cash rebates directly to customers, offering discounts instead to dealers, who can choose whether to give cash to buyers or to use the price break in other ways to stimulate sales.
Honda also reported a smaller decline than most auto makers, with sales of its domestically produced cars down 1.4 percent, to 9,838. In an unusual move, Honda is offering $300 dealer incentives on its Accord and Acura Integra models.
"It's taken a while for the typical Honda dealer to learn how to deal, because they have never had to sell aggressively," said Scott Merlis, an analyst with Morgan Stanley & Company in New York.
The General Motors Corporation sold 72,889 domestically produced cars, down 13.9 percent. G.M.'s light-truck sales fell 19.4 percent, to 34,738 vehicles.
The Chrysler Corporation no longer reports its sales every 10 days, but Ward's Automotive Reports, an industry newsletter, estimated that the No. 3 auto maker sold 20,500 cars, a decline of 10.8 percent, and 21,250 light trucks, a drop of 3.5 percent.

HEADLINE: POLITICAL VIOLENCE KILLS 5 IN ALBANIA

BYLINE: By DAVID BINDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25

 BODY:
Another Albanian was killed Sunday night, bringing to five the number of deaths in political strife this weekend, as orthodox Communist forces, aided in some cases by the military, sought to reassert authority in various parts of the country.
The victim in the latest shooting was a 20-year-old man killed in Tirana by an army rifleman, said Dr. Sali Berisha, a leader of the two-month-old Democratic Party. As recently as last summer, such incidents went unreported in Albania, where Communist censorship was strict. 
 In a telephone interview, Dr. Berisha said a patrol stopped the young man, Artan Lenja, on the street near his home about 7:30 p.m. and demanded his identity papers. When Mr. Lenja failed to produce them, an officer ordered that he be shot. A second young man was shot and wounded in the same street, Dr. Berisha said. About 1,000 Tirana residents reportedly attended a memorial service for Mr. Lenja today.
On Friday, three civilians and a policemen were killed during exchanges of gunfire at a large military school northeast of the capital. Later, generals and other officers issued a statement demanding restoration of monuments to the late Communist dictator, Enver Hoxha, that had been toppled by demonstrators calling for democratic change.
 
Straining Against Tradition
 Political life in the small Balkan country has become increasingly polarized between advocates of democracy and Communists professing loyalty to the legacy of Mr. Hoxha, who ruled Albania in the Stalinist fashion for 41 years until his death in 1985. The split has deepened since the shootings, and it also appears that public order has broken down in many places. "The situation is very dangerous, in my opinion," said Dr. Berisha.
President Ramiz Alia himself appears to be torn between defending Mr. Hoxha, who chose him as his successor, and placating the growing number of Albanians who seek a radical break with the despotic past Mr. Hoxha embodied. In a television address, President Alia appealed for peace between the factions, but said Hoxha "remains in our hearts" and that his role in history would be reassessed later.
Gramoz Pashko, another opposition leader in the Democratic Party, said in a telephone interview that the ruling Communist Party of about 120,000 members is now split into orthodox and reformist factions, with the latter supporting President Alia. "His party is divided now," he said. "Alia is playing a very dangerous game."
 
Ex-Officials Defy President
 Last week, in response to widespread rioting, Mr. Alia capped a series of changes he had begun 10 months ago by dismissing the Government of Prime Minister Adil Carcani.
But over the weekend, Mr. Carcani and other former senior Communist officials joined the anti-Alia camp, Mr. Pashko said. Mr. Carcani sent a telegram encouraging Communists in Gjirokaster, the birthplace of Hoxha, to restore a bust of the dictator that had been dismantled.
Dr. Berisha said "Enverists," as he described the orthodox Communists, had formed posses that had menaced members of his Democratic Party in a number of Albanian towns and cities, including Saranda, Gjirokaster, Fier and Korca.
"They beat up the vice chairman of our party in Saranda," a coastal city, on Sunday, he said. "They threaten to hang us, to hang me, and to outlaw our party." Dozens of opposition leaders have been arrested in outlying towns and in Tirana, he said.
Dr. Berisha, a cardiologist, and Mr. Pashko, a university economist, both said orthodox Communists were calling for the removal of the Albanian capital from Tirana to Vlora, the port city on the Adriatic that served as the country's first capital in 1912.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Slight Rise in Price of Oil Surprises Many Analysts

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Oil prices showed surprising strength yesterday, bouncing back from their low point of the Persian Gulf crisis to finish up slightly for the day as traders digested news from the ground war.
Crude oil for delivery in April settled at $17.94 a barrel, up 3 cents, at the New York Mercantile Exchange. 
 Oil opened lower amid perceptions that the ground war was going well for the forces allied against Iraq. In early trading here, the price of oil hit $17.45, its cheapest yet during the gulf crisis. But crude began moving higher around midday.
"Early on, you made lows because people were looking at the fact the ground war was doing well," said Randall Rothenberg, an oil broker with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. "Then they bought it back up a bit on the feeling there might be some Iraqi resistance."
The lack of direction reflected a "total mixed bag of opinions" among traders, Mr. Rothenberg said
The rally was modest, but it caught many traders off guard, because world oil supplies are plentiful and the allies' battlefield success has largely erased fears about any threats to oilfields and refineries in Saudi Arabia.
"Everything I'm looking at points lower," said Peter Beutel, an oil analyst with Pegasus Econometric Group in Hoboken, N.J. "I'm surprised at this reaction, I must confess. It seems to be doing it on its own. There's no reason for it."
Others said that the declines last week had taken oil prices about as far down as they were going to go and that many futures traders have already factored a successful ground war into their trading strategies.
Philip L. Dodge, an analyst at Dillon, Read & Company, said reports that hundreds of Kuwaiti oil wells were burning might have strengthened the market slightly yesterday, although the world oil market has long since shown it can do without Kuwaiti oil.
Refined petroleum products showed some strength for the day on the futures market.
Heating oil for delivery in March settled at 61.95 cents a gallon, up 1.81 cents, at the Mercantile Exchange. Unleaded gasoline for delivery in March settled at 60.65 cents a gallon, up 1.32 cents.
Natural gas for delivery in April closed at $1.351, up six-tenths of 1 cent for 1,000 cubic feet.
In London, North Sea Brent blend crude settled at $16.95 a barrel, up 33 cents, at the International Petroleum Exchange.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Gains on War News; Gold Prices Up in New York

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar gained on world markets yesterday as the United States-led forces drove deeper into enemy territory, renewing hopes for a swift end to the war in the Persian Gulf.
Gold rose in New York, with the contract for February delivery settling at $359.50 a troy ounce on the Commodity Exchange, up $2.50 from late Friday. The Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $359 a troy ounce, up $2.25 from late Friday. 
 Amid reports of light Iraqi resistance to the allied attack, traders expressed relief about the potential drain of the war on the United States budget and American consumer spending.
"The market apparently is now of the belief that a quick resolution to the gulf situation will be beneficial to the U.S. economy." said Robert Hatcher, corporate dealer for Barclays Bank P.L.C.
Military officials said American units were smashing scores of tanks, taking thousands more prisoners and having "tremendous success" in their first battle with Iraq's elite Republican Guard.
The dollar's upward move marked a change from the previous session's reaction to war news. Late last week, the dollar firmed on peace hopes, helped by the belief that the start of a ground war would delay the final outcome of the conflict.
This week, however, the apparent early success of the allied force's drive into Kuwait and Iraq fed hopes for a quicker-than-expected end to the conflict.
Appearing on CBS, Representative Les Aspin, the Wisconsin Democrat who is the chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, said the conflict could be over in three or four days. President Bush cautioned, however, that "there are battles yet to come and casualties to be borne."
In Tokyo, the dollar rose 1.28 yen, to a closing 132.13 yen. Later in London, it was quoted at a higher rate of 132.80 yen. In New York, the dollar settled at 133.55 yen, up from late Friday's 132.15 yen.
In London, the British pound fell to $1.9235, from $1.9440 late Friday. In New York, sterling fetched $1.9265, less than late Friday's $1.9445.
Against the German currency, the dollar rose in New York to 1.5200 marks, from 1.5055 on Friday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday, included: 1.3020 Swiss francs, up from 1.2925; 5.1665 French francs, up from 5.1225; 1,136 Italian lire, up from 1,127.50, and 1.1526 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1524.

HEADLINE: Fed Official's Bank View

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25

 BODY:
A Federal Reserve governor, John P. LaWare, said today that he expected the economy to swing out of recession, helping the troubled banking industry, by this summer if the Persian Gulf war ends soon.
"We do expect the economy to return to positive real growth by the third quarter, assuming a prompt end of the gulf war and no serious impairment of oil supplies," Mr. LaWare said in a speech to the Institute of International Bankers. 
 He cautioned that it would take time to absorb the excess capacity in commercial real estate markets and to rebuild demand for residential real estate. But, he said, the worst may be over for banks that have suffered huge losses because of troubled real estate loans.
Profits of the nation's banks have been hard hit by the real estate slump, which has left them with a growing number of bad loans on their books.
Mr. LaWare's remarks on the economy were in line with projections made in the Fed's semiannual report to Congress released last week.
The report said the Fed board members and presidents of the reserve banks expect the recession to end later this year and growth in the gross national product to average three-quarters of 1 percent to 1.5 percent this year.

HEADLINE: Fur Industry Shrinking With No End in Sight

BYLINE: By JOHN F. BURNS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TORONTO, Feb. 25

 BODY:
These are bitter times for those involved in trapping, dressing, making and selling furs. In a harshly symbolic blow to the industry, the Hudson's Bay Company of Canada announced recently that it was closing the last fur salons in its Bay department stores.
The company, which was synonymous with fur for centuries after it was founded in 1670 to pursue the trade under a royal charter, had been confronted by the relentless campaigning of animal rights advocates and plunging demand that began with the 1987 stock market crash. 
 The decision was a clear signal that even this country has been unable to fend off the sharp pressures that have cut deeply into the fur business elsewhere, including the United States and Western Europe.
The announcement followed the bankruptcy in early January of Northbay Fur Sales, the auction house of the Ontario Trappers' Association, which for 40 years had kicked off an annual round of fur auctions that stretched from New York to Copenhagen to Leningrad, with half a dozen stops in between.
In Montreal, center of a Canadian fur industry that surpassed Manhattan in the early 1980's as the leading fur center in North America, hundreds of jobs have been lost. By some estimates, as many as 20,000 Canadian trappers have quit the business, and many of the 85,000 who remain are barely covering costs.
"It's certainly not the business it used to be a decade ago," said Barry Agnew, a Hudson's Bay vice president. He and other company executives were unsentimental about cutting their link to the past. They said salons that offered finished mink and fox garments, along with beaver, raccoon and other furs, had become only marginally important to profitability, and the decision was made to clear the space for other wares. The company, which operates four department store chains across Canada with more than 480 stores, sold its fur auction houses in 1987.
Now, with a Canadian recession biting more deeply than the economic downturn in the United States, the industry is confronting a gloomier future. David Sebben, a spokesman for the Fur Trade Association of Canada, predicts that 1.5 million wild animals will be trapped or shot this year, representing a 50 percent decrease from 1987. The number of pelts to be sold from the ranches that account for 90 percent of mink and fox furs, the top end of the market, will decline similarly, he said.
Over all, by Mr. Sebben's estimate, the Canadian industry shrank between 1987 and 1990 to $800 million (Canadian), or about $695 million (United States), down 30 percent. And pelt prices set at auctions so far this year suggest that the downward trend may steepen.
At an auction earlier this month in New York, mink pelts averaged $23, down from $35 in 1987. Declines for some other furs have been sharper still. To sell coats from overburdened racks, some furriers have cut retail prices by as much as 60 percent from 1987 highs.
 
Optimism, for the Record
 For the record, industry spokesmen remain optimistic, saying fur has gone through boom-and-bust cycles before. But some executives acknowledge privately that once-profitable markets in Britain, Germany and the Netherlands may not recover from the onslaught of the animal rights advocates. In December, for instance, Harrods, the landmark London department store, closed its fur salon and shipped many unsold furs to Canada for auction.
Japan is one of the few bright spots, with sales that reached $1.7 billion last year, only slightly behind the United States, the world's largest market, with sales of $1.8 billion.
But Canadian animal rights advocates say they are not about to let up the pressure, and predict harder times still for the industry.
"I think the downslide is just going to continue and continue," said Christina Fox, spokesman for the Canadian Anti-Fur Alliance. "It's not going to happen in a couple of years, but people are just becoming more and more aware that you don't have to wear a dead animal for decoration."
The anti-fur alliance is part of a worldwide network of groups that has brought pressure on the fur industry. In Canada, these efforts halted the killing of whitecoat seal pups off the Labrador coast nearly a decade ago, and they have become increasingly sharp-edged. "Get the feel of fur -- slam your hand in a car door," one poster declared.
The Canadian industry is fighting the animal rights advocates and contends that it can prevail. It has begun an advertising campaign of its own, built around images of fur and fur-trapping as part of the natural cycle. A Canadian Government grant of $4.3 million is being spent, in part, to develop what Mr. Sebben called "humane traps," some with rubber guards. The aim is to insure that animals held alive in traps suffer as little as possible, and that traps designed to kill do so instantly.
Fur companies long for a return to the mid-1980's, a time when the fur industry in Canada boomed. There were soaring exports of raw and semi-finished pelts and still faster growth in the sales of finished furs, as a generation of Canadian designers shed the stodgy image of the past.
On the strength of a tripling of business in the previous decade, companies that had been the mainstays of the industry expanded, and new ones sprang up in Vancouver, British Columbia; Winnipeg, Manitoba; Toronto, and Montreal. The stock market collapse of 1987 caught trappers, ranchers and manufacturers on an expanding curve. And as fur sales dropped precipitously, anti-fur advocates stepped up their campaign.
By Mr. Sebben's account, the industry took heart last year from "focus groups" of potential buyers who were gathered in cities across Canada and the United States. Among the conclusions taken from these gatherings, the Canadian fur industry spokesman said, was that fur coats continue to convey "an image of warmth and accomplishment" among consumers and that the activities of some animal rights campaigners have prompted a backlash.
 
Replacing the Mirrors
 Still, radical moves have been necessary to stave off further bankruptcies. Four times since November, Canadian manufacturers have offered coats at knock-down prices at retail "auctions" in Toronto. In place of the mirrored salons that bolstered the industry's luxury image in the past, the auctions have been staged in a drafty exhibition hall on the Toronto waterfront, with women in jeans and sneakers taking their pick of coats fashioned from pelts of mink, fox, beaver, marten, raccoon, lynx and muskrat.
The auctions have sold more than 6,000 coats, albeit at prices that have made many manufacturers wince. But for sellers seeking hope amid the gloom, the enthusiasm of many buyers was encouraging.
"It's my very first coat; I can't wait to get it on," said Beryl Browne, a 38-year-old nurse, as she waited for the paperwork to be completed on a $2,070 raccoon and fox coat. The Canadian, born in Antigua, paused, and acknowledged that the threats of animal rights extremists had worried her.
"People say, 'You wear something like that, somebody will throw paint on you,' " she said. "That does trouble me. Oh, well, I'll just wear it for special occasions, not for everyday."
