HEADLINE: California Painfully Faces Grim Truths of Drought

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SHANDON, Calif., Feb. 20

 BODY:
After five years of drought, the hills here are bleached tawny, the stream beds are dry and ground squirrels forage where cattle can no longer graze.
This apocalyptic landscape, in the Coastal Range between San Luis Obispo and Kettleman City, is a stark reminder that California, so vast and magnificent, is a civilization built on precarious assumptions, a semiarid land where water is destiny. 
 There has been precious little precipitation here since 1986, but until this winter most Californians acted as if it would rain or snow any minute, next month, maybe; next year, for sure.
 
'We're Living in a Desert'
 But in recent weeks, after January brought flawlessly clear skies, a desperation has taken hold. Citizens and government officials alike are suddenly grappling with what it means to live in such an inhospitable place, and each day brings news of sharp limits on water use in another city or town.
"People forget we're living in a desert and every once in a while nature is going to reclaim its own," said Paul Graham, an accountant in Firebaugh, in the San Joaquin Valley. His clients include farmers forced to let 75 percent of their land lie fallow for lack of water.
This is the driest time the state has known since the drought of the early 1930's, and the situation is considered much graver now because the population, then about 6 million, is now 30 million, with 65,000 new Californians each month.
The state has not imposed uniform restrictions, leaving it to the thousands of water districts to allocate supplies locally. That many people in that many locales fighting for a dwindling supply means civil war here: north against south, cities versus farm towns, industry against the environment.
 
Scorn for Pools and Rice
 On an 800-mile zigzag journey this week from Riverside County in the south to the Sacramento River Delta in the north, there was some talk of conservation, of bricks in the toilet tank, shorter showers, drought-tolerant landscaping and less thirsty crops. But for the most part, people seemed more interested in defending their own water needs and chastizing others for profligacy, with particular scorn for suburbanites with turquoise pools and rice farmers who grow their monsoon crop with subsidized water.
In Lake Elsinore in Riverside County, one of the fastest growing cities in California, developers complained about a moratorium on water connections to new houses that had halted construction. In Santa Barbara, gardeners said they had painted parched lawns green and defied "drought police" to water flowers.
In San Luis Obispo, farther up the coast, the leading innkeeper switched from city water to his own well to save a quarter of a million dollars a year and ranchers pay rising prices for alfalfa to feed the hungry cattle that can no longer graze.
In Firebaugh, where farmland is watered by a labyrinth of aqueducts and canals, water curbs have forced land out of cultivation and rippled through the economy. In Rio Vista, a Sacramento River Delta hamlet of boat yards and bait shops, fishermen lamented the risk to fish and wildlife when rivers run low and more fresh water is diverted for irrigation.
And all along the way there was talk of hardship and change, of a struggle that could alter the face of the nation's most-populous state. "I always said water would be more important than oil eventually," said Alex Madonna, a rancher and innkeeper in San Luis Obispo. "Well, now it is."
 
New Homes Without Water
 On Interstate 15, heading south to Lake Elsinore, billboard after billboard trumpets new developments with idyllic names: Wildrose Ranch, "a planned community at home with nature," Vintage Hills, a "fresh new neighborhood," Jasmine Ridge, Tuscany Hills.
But for 60 days, at least, that hectic sort of building must stop because of a moratorium on new water connections, including those already paid for. At the Tuscany Hills development, for example, where six developers have plans for 2,000 Spanish-style houses, 500 are ready for occupancy, but must sit empty unless the moratorium is lifted.
"This is doom," said Tony C., a superintendent at the site who refused to allow his full name to be used for fear of offending the local water district, jinxing an appeal for a reprieve and losing his position with the developer.
The burly superintendent, his face ruddy from the year-round sunshine, called the moratorium "an attention grabber." Sure, the drought is real, he said, "but it didn't just happen last month and it seems like everything is slamming us in the face at once."
Like many people across the state, he has plenty of ideas for other solutions, like desalting sea water and seeding the clouds. "What about water from the flood plains in Texas?" he asked. "Why can't they pipe that in? They pipe oil from Alaska."
 
Surreptitious Flower Watering
 Patricia Chidlaw wrinkled her brow and studied the instructions on a box of Miracle-Gro plant food. Using the fertilizer, she calculated, would mean an extra gallon of water every two weeks on each of her 35 rose bushes.
"I don't know what to do," Ms. Chidlaw said while shopping late one afternoon at the La Sumida Nursery in Santa Barbara. "I don't know what's responsible behavior."
Ms. Chidlaw's roses won out over her conscience.
She has let nature take its course with the backyard avocado, citrus and apple trees, and her lawn has become threadbare since watering was outlawed in the seaside city last summer. A drip system, which is legal, waters the roses, her pride and joy, but Ms. Chidlaw, a landscape painter, admitted that "sometimes I sneak the hose out" because "seeing things grow enhances the quality of life."
Some cheating is also going on at the home of Joyce Ashley, a psychiatrist, and her husband, Dennis, an internist. The Ashleys waited three months to water after the ban, she said, but lost one hedge and found it too messy to drag buckets of used household water to the garden. "I haven't turned the sprinklers on," Joyce Ashley said, "but I have used a hose."
The lawn, meanwhile, looked so "brown and ugly" by Thanksgiving that the Ashleys hired a painter, one of the many who have been doing a land-office business here. It took some persuading to get him to add more yellow to his standard blue-green pigment so it better matched California Bermuda grass, but the Ashleys were finally satisfied with the $200 job.
"It keeps you from being so depressed when you look out the window," she said.
 
Innkeeper Taps His Own Well
 The Madonna Inn in San Luis Obispo is hard to miss, a castle of kitsch on the Central Coast, where each room has a theme, honeymooners are identified by pink balloons at their dining room table and the men's room has a urinal built in the form of a waterfall.
It is a sprawling, gabled place, with 109 rooms and huge water bills -- $27,000 a month, said Alex Madonna, the owner.
That will change soon, since the inn just switched from city water to its own well, which had previously been used to supply water to Mr. Madonna's adjoining ranch. Water will now cost $2,000 a month to run the electric pumps, Mr. Madonna said.
Mr. Madonna's other big expense lately is alfalfa, which he is feeding his cattle in San Luis Obispo and on land he owns in the San Joaquin Valley. "There's no grazing," he said. "I've bought a million dollars worth of hay already this year."
Alfalfa, sold as hay for cattle, is one of California's thirstiest crops. It requires more water each year than the combined household needs of the state's 30 million residents.
 
Swapping Farm Hardship Tales
 In the San Joaquin farm country, at a cotton gin in Firebaugh, Rosie Burns, the manager, totes up drought-related losses, which are modest now but promise to be catastrophic in 1992. Mr. Burns has only lost one major customer so far, a farmer who will not plant 1,000 acres of cotton this year because his water supplies have been cut.
"He already had his vegetables in," when cuts were announced earlier this month, Mr. Burns said, and had no choice but to stick with the crops already planted and fallow the rest of his land. "I'd do the same thing," Mr. Burns added.
The area is a patchwork of water districts, each providing different allocations, and everybody is making adjustments and comparing hardships at lunch at the Agri-Center coffee shop.
One farmer laid off five workers, cut his planted acres to 180 from 760 and will work the farm alone, hoping meanwhile that the state will approve subsidies to help him pay his rent. A crop duster is short of business because only 400 acres of rice are to be planted in this area, as against a normal 5,000. A parts salesman at a tractor dealership has been put on three-day work weeks.
 
Watching a River Slowly Die
 In the Sacramento River Delta northeast of San Francisco, the sloughs are impassable these days. The catch of striped bass at Rio Vista is as meager as anyone can remember because the fish are not swimming that far upstream to spawn. And there are hardly any salmon, which used to pass by on their migration upstream.
The fishermen and environmentalists blame the changes in the delta and in San Francisco Bay on the drought. When there is not enough mountain runoff, the system of dams and aqueducts that provide water to the Central Valley and the Los Angeles Basin must pump extra water from the delta, reducing the fresh water in its estuaries, which are ordinarily rich with fish, birds, sea animals and plants.
The threat here will be even worse, residents say, if a proposed canal, the long-delayed peripheral canal, is built to channel more delta water south. "We need that like we need a hole in our heads," said Jim Zane, a retired roofing contractor who works part-time at a bait and tackle shop.
Mr. Zane, like others in Rio Vista, reserves most of his anger for the stereotypic Los Angeles resident with clean cars and a bubbling Jacuzzi.
"Sure there's a drought, but it's a secondary issue," Mr. Zane said. "Forty-five percent of the water from the delta goes south and they waste 35 percent of that."
 
A Reservoir Tells All
 Newspapers in recent weeks have been full of pictures of nearly empty reservoirs and articles about kindergartners who have never seen a winter rainstorm. Each day, or so it seems, another town imposes water rationing, another water district cuts its allotment to farmers or raises its rates.
Pete Wilson, the new Governor, jokes that he could guarantee himself a place in the state history books by turning wine to water. But at a briefing for reporters about the drought, Mr. Wilson is sober, clearly alarmed.
At the San Luis Reservoir, southeast of San Jose in the eastern foothills of the Diablo Range, visitors mutter and fret after looking at the 624,000 acre-feet of water where there normally is 1.6 million.
"The message is right there," said Howard Berman, on duty in the visitors center. "Sometimes the news you hear sounds worse than it really is. This time what the papers are saying is absolutely true and it's terribly scary."

HEADLINE: New Uncertainties Said to Invigorate NATO

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25

 BODY:
Just as the demise of the Warsaw Pact appeared ready to deal a symbolic blow to NATO's role as defender of Europe, the Persian Gulf war and the erosion of Soviet reforms have joined to pump new vigor into the aging Western military alliance, Bush Administration officials say.
The Soviet crisis, capped by an army crackdown in the Baltic republics, dashed hopes that Europe could finally safely dismiss Moscow's military threat, the officials said. Meanwhile, Iraq's seizure of Kuwait's oil industryawakened Europeans to the fact that the Soviets were not the sole danger to their collective security. 
 As a result, those and other officials say, NATO's dominant role in European military issues is unlikely to ebb soon, even though the alliance faces wrenching political strains. NATO may even grow a bit, some of the officials add, as nations of the old Communist bloc seek to tie themselves to NATO security policies as a counterweight to the Soviets' unpredictability.
"Nobody in Washington thinks you're not going to scale back the NATO command structure, given what's happened in the Soviet Unionand with the Warsaw Pact in the last year," an Administration expert on European defense policy said in an interview today. "But you don't want that structure to go away totally. You want to keep it vital, to deal with the kinds of contingencies we could confront years from now."
Those contingencies, which the United States is vigorously promoting to its overseas allies, range from a resurgent Soviet Army to a ballistic missile attack by a hostile third-world government.
NATO's 15 military participants are studying those and other scenarios at their Brussels headquarters, where officials are rewriting the organization's military strategy to take account of the reduction, if not elimination, of the Soviet military threat. The new strategy is expected to be completed by year's end.
At the same time, those allies and France, which quit NATO's military arm in 1964, are informally discussing the group's political role in a region in which systems of government and even some boundaries have been changing rapidly.
NATO has traditionally spoken for Europe on common defense matters. But as Communist governments in Eastern Europe withered last year, several regional groups rose as potential pretenders to NATO's policy role.
They included the 12-nation European Community, which is eliminating many economic and political barriersamong its members; the 9-nation Western European Union, and the 34-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, whose members span all Europe, from the Urals to the Atlantic.
American officials said today that several NATO members -- France and Italy in particular -- still chafe openly at a European defense policy contrived with American advice and headed by an American general: NATO's Supreme Allied Commander in Europe. But most Europeans, they say, are now convinced that a common defense mounted without American help is a distant goal.
A prime reason is the gulf crisis, in which the Western European Union tried gamely to orchestrate the region's involvement but failed, said one Senate expert on NATO policies.The reversals in Soviet policy have also strengthened the argument, on both sides of the old Iron Curtain, for an American combat presence in Europe. Last year, NATO leaders invited the Soviet and Eastern European governments to establish closer unofficial relations with the organization; Eastern Europeans are now looking at the offer more seriously in the wake of the Soviet crackdown in Lithuania and Moscow's threats to other secession-minded republics.
Some Administration officials said today that the most pressing question about NATO's future is being posed not in Europe, but in Washington, where the Congress this summer will consider how sharply to reduce the number of American troops stationed on European soil.

HEADLINE: CAREERS;
Trying to Fill The Shortage Of Engineers

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH M. FOWLER

 BODY:
American contractors are expected to have a big role in rebuilding the hundreds of bridges, roads and buildings destroyed in the Persian Gulf war, further straining an industry suffering from a chronic shortage of engineers.
According to an estimate by the National Science Foundation, the shortage of engineers in the United States will reach 70,000 by the year 2010, even though engineers have been trying for decades to persuade more students to join their ranks. 
 One leader of the campaign is James E. Sawyer, the new president of the American Society of Civil Engineers. Last week, as part of National Engineers Week, he took part in an effort by 32 large engineering societies to reach teachers at 127,000 schools nationwide with brochures, personal visits and talks to classes from kindergarten to 12th grade.
"We are trying to let young people know about the fun of solving engineering problems," he said. "We visit preschools and high schools. We have open houses for youngsters."
The aim of the campaign is to inform teachers about job opportunities in engineering so they can encourage students to take more interest in mathematics and science. These courses are basic to the engineering profession, Mr. Sawyer said, and students must make a commitment to them by age 14 to meet entrance requirements for engineering schools.
Mr. Sawyer himself became interested in engineering at an early age, when he worked at his father's building company in Albany, Ga. He later received bachelor's and master's degrees from the Georgia Institute of Technology.
Mr. Sawyer said he hoped the campaign in public schools would combat "technical illiteracy" in the United States.
Prof. John L. Niklaus, head of the civil engineering department at Tulane University in New Orleans, said the shortage of civil engineers was a problem because it was taking place at a time of increasing need.
"There is a lot of civil engineering activity now in two areas," he said, "transportation, which includes roads, bridges and transit systems, and the environment, which includes waste management and hazardous-waste disposal."
He said engineering students seemed to be taking particular interest in the environmental area.
"At Tulane," he said, "we have quite a few petroleum and chemical engineers taking graduate work in environmental courses in our civil engineering department, for which they can receive master's degrees."
He said students interested in becoming chemical or petroleum engineers should be aware that extra chemistry courses were required in those specialties.
Mr. Sawyer, the president of the engineers society, is chief operating officer of Greiner Engineering Inc. in Dallas. He pointed out that many companies, including his, offer scholarships and summer jobs to prospective engineers. He also said tuition-refund plans were available to encourage young engineers to obtain master's degrees in specialty fields.
Like Professor Niklaus, Mr. Sawyer recommended that five-year college programs be established for engineers. In such programs, students concentrate on basic skills, like computer and communications courses, in the first four years. In the fifth year, they specialize, graduating with a bachelor of arts degree plus the professional degree of bachelor of engineering.
He mentioned the program at Dartmouth College as an example of a five-year plan. But few other colleges have such programs, he said, partly because young engineers want to graduate as quickly as possible, find well-paid jobs and pay back loans as fast as possible. Their companies often send them to get their master's degrees.
Typically, civil engineers receive a starting salary of $29,500, on average, he said, while chemical engineers get $38,000 to start.
"Many engineers go into civil service or government-type jobs where they trade lower salary levels for more stability," Professor Niklaus said.
Once the gulf crisis is over, he added, there might be a renewed emphasis on repairing the decaying bridges, highways and transit systems of the United States. President Bush indicated as much in his recent national transportation proposals, Professor Niklaus said. And last week, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. endorsed spending more on infrastructure repair, also noting that such projects could provide jobs for the unemployed.

HEADLINE: Rent Law Fight Pitting U.S. Against New York

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
The Federal agency charged with bailing out the nation's failed savings and loan associations said yesterday that it would evict nine tenants of rent-regulated apartments from a building on East 57th Street, a move that is likely to prompt a legal fight over New York State's laws protecting renters.
The agency, the Resolution Trust Corporation, said it also might move to evict tenants from some of the more than 900 rent-stabilized and rent-controlled apartments it has acquired in 10 other New York buildings. The apartments are among assets the agency has taken over from failed thrift institutions in the New York area.
 
A Bid to End Subsidies
 The Federal agency wants to evict tenants in buildings that have been converted to cooperatives or condominiums whose rent does not cover the cost of maintaining the apartments. The agency argues that taxpayers, who are paying for the thrift-industry bailout, should not be forced, in effect, to subsidize the rent of those tenants. 
 State officials said immediately after the Federal announcement yesterday that they would try to block the evictions in court.
"Trampling on innocent tenants' rights and on state and local housing laws is not the way to deal with the impact of the nation's banking crisis," said Attorney General Robert Abrams.
The Federal decision, described in a letter to Mr. Abrams and a policy statement from Washington, caps a simmering dispute that began in September. Resolution Trust said then that it might evict the East 57th Street tenants, but it agreed to postpone any move while studying the implications for New York State's housing laws.
 
U.S. Suing the State
 The agency also said yesterday that it had filed suit in Federal court against Mr. Abrams and Angelo J. Aponte, the New York State Commissioner of Housing, to try to nullify state rent regulations if they are used to prevent evictions or rent increases in buildings that have fallen under Federal control.
At issue are sharply conflicting state laws and Federal Government mandates. Since September, officials of Resolution Trust have contended repeatedly that their job, ordered by Congress, is to obtain the best financial return from real estate obtained from failed thrift institutions.
The building on East 57th Street, which was converted from rentals to condominiums in the mid-1980's, was taken over as part of the assets of the Nassau Savings and Loan Company of Brooklyn.
It, and the 10 other New York City buildings with apartments under the control of Resolution Trust, have a mix of occupants. They include tenants who have bought their apartments and renters who have elected not to buy, both protected by rent-stabilization and rent-control laws.
 
'Significant Loss' Cited
 In its policy statement, which it said would apply in other cities and states with tenant-protection laws, Resolution Trust said it did not intend to evict any low- or moderate-income tenants. It characterized those as tenants earning up to 115 percent of the median income for the area involved.
But it said it would nullify the leases of those with middle or high incomes who were paying less in rent than was needed to cover the costs of maintaining their apartments.
"The R.T.C., and ultimately the taxpayers, cannot be put in the position of continuing to underwrite rental of such units at significant loss to the R.T.C.," the policy statement said.
The Federal agency said it would offer tenants affected by its policy the option of buying their apartments or negotiating higher rents to cover the Government's costs.
 
'A Luxury Building'
 A spokeswoman for Resolution Trust in Washington, Felicia Neuringer, said the tenants on East 57th Street, in what the agency called "a luxury building off Sutton Place," were paying rents of $475 to $1,700 a month for large apartments, all with two bedrooms or more.
Resolution Trust said it was still studying the rent-controlled leases on apartments it controls in other New York City buildings to determine whether they would be honored.
Those buildings, according to Mr. Abram's staff, include 157 East 72d Street, 235 East 22d Street, 240 West 75th Street and 55-77 Park Terrace, all in Manhattan. In Queens, the buildings include Glen Oaks Village in Belrose, Le Havre in Whitestone and 241-20 Northern Boulevard in Douglaston.
Also included are a building on 64th Avenue in Rego Park and another in the Forest Hills section for which the Attorney General's staff said it did not have precise addresses.

HEADLINE: Holtzman Wants More Cuts to Balance Books

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
City Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman said yesterday that New York City should consider a range of measures from unpaid job furloughs for most city workers to wage freezes and increased productivity to help close its multibillion-dollar budget gap over the next 16 months.
Commenting on the Dinkins administration's plan for closing a budget gap that it estimates at more than $2 billion for the fiscal year that starts July 1 -- but which she says is more than $3 billion -- Ms. Holtzman said the city needed to explore more cost-saving ideas than it has so far. 
 "The city hasn't done all that it can to find savings," she said in a statement. "Raising taxes on New Yorkers, who already pay more state and local taxes than anyone anywhere else in the country, is not the answer."
 
A Complex Mix
 Although $580 million in new taxes are highlighted in the administration's financial plan, Ms. Holtzman asserted that the city was actually seeking an overall tax increase of $1.2 billion next year. This, she said, is because of a complex mix of proposed tax increases, including a real-estate tax rise that is not directly spelled out in the city's preliminary budget.
She said her staff was examining what effects such increases might have on the local economy and was concerned that they might hurt it. But she would neither endorse the administration's tax proposals nor unequivocally dismiss them as too large.
Mayor David N. Dinkins said yesterday that the city was reviewing the possibility of furloughs and other actions and was prepared to take whatever steps needed to keep the budget balanced. It has already reached an agreement with the teachers' union to defer part of its recent wage increase.
Ms. Holtzman said that if the city gave an unpaid 10-day furlough to all workers except police officers and employees under the Board of Education, it could save about $135 million and that a 5-day furlough would save about half that.
But Mr. Dinkins took pains to point out that furloughs could not be easily imposed unilaterally, an idea resisted by municipal unions.
For example, Edward Ostrowski, president of the Uniformed Sanitationmen's Association, said: "I suggest that Ms. Holtzman should furlough her staff for a year. That would save the city millions of dollars, too, and nobody would even miss them."

HEADLINE: California Hispanic Population Up 70%

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 25

 BODY:
California's Hispanic population grew nearly 70 percent in the last decade, the Census Bureau said today, confirming statistically what has been apparent throughout the state's economy, social structure and politics.
The bureau said the Hispanic population in California was 7.7 million last year, up from 4.5 million in 1980. Hispanic residents now account for 25.8 percent of California's total population of 29.8 million, as against 19.2 percent a decade earlier. The bureau reported earlier that California's total population grew 25.7 percent in the 1980's. 
 The Hispanic population of California now exceeds the total population of all but eight states.
The growth rate of the Hispanic population here was exceeded only by the rate of increase among Asians. The Asian and Pacific Islander population more than doubled, to 2.8 million from 1.3 million in 1980, the bureau reported.
 
Trend in Growth Continues
 The numbers released today were in line with what demographers had expected, and suggested no deviation in a trend that is likely to leave California's non-Hispanic white population in the minority by the end of the decade.
"It represents a continuation of the trend that was very evident from 1970 to 1980, and it indicates that the proportion of non-Hispanic whites is getting smaller and smaller," said David M. Heer, the associate director of the Population Research Laboratory at the University of Southern California.
The figures released today do not show the number of non-Hispanic whites since they include people of Hispanic origin who classified themselves racially as white. The Census Bureau counts in the Hispanic category both blacks and whites who are Hispanic.
The figures also show an increase of 66.7 percent in the "other" races category, to 3.9 million. And the vast majority of that increase is believed to be accounted for by Hispanic residents, demographers said.
They said the figures suggested that California's non-Hispanic white population grew very modestly if at all during the 1980's. The total white population, which presumably includes a large number of Hispanics who identify themselves as white, grew 13.8 percent, to 20.5 million.
 
Effects of the Increase
 The growth of the Hispanic population, partly accounted for by migration from Mexico and other countries and partly by rapid growth of the population already in California, has had enormous implications for the nation's most-populous state.
It has provided a source of relatively low-wage labor for manufacturers and for farmers, helping California compete economically with other states and nations. At the same time, it has strained social services and the state's school system. And although the effects on politics have been relatively modest given the size of Hispanic population, there have been indications recently that Hispanic voters will play an increasingly powerful role.
Just last week, Los Angeles County elected its first Hispanic supervisor, Gloria Molina. Her election came after a Federal court ordered a redistricting that essentially guaranteed the election of a Hispanic candidate.
It is unclear how many Hispanic residents of California are United States citizens. Representative Esteban E. Torres, a Democrat from the Los Angeles suburb of Pico Rivera, said the figures released today should lead to at least three new Congressional districts in the state with Hispanic majorities when voting districts are redrawn starting later this year. Mr. Torres is one of three Hispanic members of Congress from California.
"It will bring to at least six the number of California Hispanics in Congress," Mr. Torres said of the redistricting process. "I look forward to that day."
The figures released today show striking evidence of the state's population trends on a local and regional basis. The total white population in Los Angeles County, for example, declined slightly over the last decade, to 5.035 million from 5.135 million.

HEADLINE: 5% Zenith Electronics Stake Is Sold to Goldstar of Korea

BYLINE: By EBEN SHAPIRO

 BODY:
The Zenith Electronics Corporation said yesterday that it had sold nearly a 5 percent stake in the company to the Goldstar Company, the giant South Korean consumer electronics concern.
A Goldstar executive and analysts said the move was one of the first big investments by a Korean company in a publicly traded United States company. 
 "It is a coming of age for Korea," said James I. Magid, an analyst with Needham & Company. "You have not seen Hyundai making an investment in General Motors or Ford."
Also yesterday, Zenith reported a $52.3 million loss for 1990, so the entry of a well-capitalized partner was welcome news. Zenith said the sale of stock to Goldstar would provide the company with additional cash.
The sale may also help Zenith fight a takeover threat from Nycor Inc., a New Jersey investment company. Goldstar's $15 million investment in 1.45 million shares of newly issued Zenith common stock dilluted Nycor's stake in Zenith to about 7.6 percent from 8.2 percent.
Nycor, which owns the Fedders Corporation, the air-conditioner maker, has said it will try to unseat three Zenith directors at the company's annual meeting on April 24.
Goldstar paid $10.34 a share for the new Zenith stock, which rose 75 cents a share on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday to close at $7.75. Zenith now has 29.1 million shares outstanding. The company issued more than 960,000 new shares last month for a profit-sharing plan.
The Goldstar move caught Nycor by surprise, and it said it would have no response to Zenith's announcement until today.
Zenith and Goldstar officials said talks leading to Goldstar's investment began last year and predated Nycor's investment in Zenith, which was disclosed in October.
John I. Taylor, a Zenith spokesman, said: "The Goldstar agreements are business moves that are good for our company. They would have been put in place regardless of Nycor." Zenith and Goldstar have had a business relationship since 1976.
Still, the arrangement strikes some analysts as ironic because Zenith, the only remaining United States maker of television sets, has been highly protectionist over the years. It was instrumental in the 1980's in getting penalites placed on imported color television sets from Japan and Korea that were being sold below cost.
Zenith also announced that it had signed technology agreements with Goldstar. Under a licensing agreement, Goldstar will pay Zenith a fee to make televisions that use Zenith's flat tension mask, which enchances picture quality.
Goldstar also agreed to support Zenith's proposed system for high-definition television in Korea.
 "It is a shot in the arm for Zenith that some international conglomerate with a lot of technology has decided that Zenith's technology has some merit and shouldn't be scuttled," said David Lachenbruch, editorial director of Television Digest, a newsletter.
 
Approvals Required
 The deal requires the approval of the South Korean Government, which Goldstar said was expected in the spring. Zenith must repurchase the stock if approval is not granted.
The Goldstar announcement offset Zenith's dismal 1990 financial results, which were released yesterday. The company lost $52.3 million on sales of $1.4 billion. It blamed the weak economy and falling prices for color television sets. In the fourth quarter, Zenith lost $25.5 million on sales of $377.8 million.
Goldstar is one of the largest consumer electronic companies in Korea, with 1990 sales of $5 billion. It is part of the Lucky-Goldstar Group, a $30 billion conglomerate.
Mr. Magid and other analysts said that with wages in Korea increasing considerably, the country was no longer the world's lowest-cost producer and that companies there would probably pursue new arrangements like the Zenith-Goldstar deal to be competitive.
It was not clear whether Goldstar planned to increase its stake in Zenith. Mr. Taylor, the Zenith spokesman, said that Goldstar agreed not to accumulate more than 15 percent of Zenith's stock in the next two years. Zenith has a shareholders' rights plan, or poison pill, that goes into effect when a shareholder acquires 15 percent of Zenith's stock.
When asked if Goldstar planned to eventually increase its stake in Zenith, Duke M. Koo, regional director of North American operations for Goldstar, said, "It is inappropriate to speculate on the future."

SECTION: Section D; Page 6; Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 516 words

HEADLINE: Boeing Sees Rising Sales To Airlines

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS

 BODY:
Even as some carriers are parking airplanes because of weak business, the Boeing Company forecast yesterday that airlines will sharply increase their purchases in the next 15 years.
The Seattle-based company, which has orders for 1,838 planes, predicted that airlines would buy 9,000 new airplanes worth $617 billion from the world's leading airplane builders between now and 2005. 
 Boeing said this would mean that based on inflation the world's airlines would take delivery of an average of $41 billion worth of airplanes in each of the next 15 years, compared with an average of $16 billion each year during the last two decades. The company said that because of past trends, it expected traffic to double worldwide over 15 years.
 
Figures Under Scrutiny
 Some analysts questioned Boeing's optimism, noting that even short-term predictions have been difficult because of unstable fuel prices and huge drops in traffic because of fears of terrorism. They noted that strong carriers like American, United and Delta had shown unexpectedly heavy losses in the fourth quarter because of the big increase in the cost of fuel and a downturn in traffic.
"They're a little too optimistic with respect to the number of aircraft to be delivered and the financing that would be available," said Peter L. Aseritis, an aerospace analyst for the First Boston Corporation.
He said that some airlines had taken planes out of service to cope with the lower traffic and that British Airways planned to park the new planes that Boeing would deliver.
But John Hayhurst, Boeing's vice president of marketing, said traffic had dropped severely in 1973 and in the early 1980's but had come back strong, averaging growth of 7.2 percent a year since 1982.
"Whenever the market has experienced a short-term disruption, it has always bounced back," he said.
While traffic growth will be slower this year and part of next year, he predicted, it will rise to a rate of about 4 percent toward the end of 1992 and then average about 5.2 percent a year thereafter.
Boeing said 70 percent of the new aircraft to be delivered would be for expansion, while only 30 percent would go to replacing aging jets.
To dramatize the hazards of long-term forecasting, Mr. Aseritis of First Boston recalled that Boeing had predicted that about 307 airplanes would be retired in 1990 but that only about 70 were.
 
Delays Being Allowed
 Boeing has agreed to allow a few airlines to delay delivery of their new aircraft. Mr. Hayhurst said that if the Persian Gulf war continued, more airlines might ask Boeing to put off delivery.
He said congestion at airports would be solved partly by using larger airplanes. He added that the average number of seats on airplanes would go from 188 to 233 in 15 years.
Boeing has had the highest market share for commercial airplanes since World War II, capturing 56 percent of the market on average over that time, with the McDonnell Douglas Corporation accounting for 21 percent and Airbus Industrie, the four-nation European aerospace consortium, for 15 percent.

HEADLINE: Business Scene;
Dollar's Decline As Export Engine

BYLINE: By Louis Uchitelle

 BODY:
NOT in a decade has the dollar been so weak. That means American exports should be rising, and they are. But why aren't they rising fast enough to make the nation's trade deficit disappear, as it almost did in 1980, the last time the dollar was this weak? The answer seems to be that the dollar has lost some -- maybe even a lot -- of its old magic as an engine for exports.
Some economists say, "Be patient, the old magic will return." After all, with the dollar hovering near 1.50 marks today, a safety razor made in the United States at a cost of, say, $1 can be exported to Germany and sold there, at a profit, for 1.55 marks. Last year, when the dollar was a much stronger 1.72 marks, the same razor had to sell for 1.75 marks, or 13 percent more, to make a profit. 
 Made-in-America razors, in sum, are falling in price abroad. The lure of being able to buy the same quality razor -- or computer or machine -- for less in other currencies will eventually win over European or Asian buyers, said Robert Z. Lawrence, a trade expert at the Brookings Institution. "The adjustment takes a long time," he continued. "The dollar started moving sharply lower only last June, and it takes two to three years to have the full effect on exports, and sometimes longer."
But consider these cases, in which the huge swings in the dollar in the 1980's -- from weak to very strong in 1985 to weak again today -- helped give rise to new strategies for selling abroad, strategies that have partly canceled out the dollar's once powerful role in trade:
*Air Products and Chemicals Inc. of Allentown, Pa., manufactures air-purifying equipment in Wilkes-Barre, Pa., and in Acrefair, England. TheBritish factory, new in the mid-1980's, was the low-cost manufacturer then because the dollar was so strong. Now Wilkes-Barre plays this role, and slowly it is getting orders to export purifying equipment to Japan. Production in Acrefair, meanwhile, has declined, but only marginally, says Dexter F. Baker, the company's chairman. The British plant must remain to supply the soon-to-be unified European market, with its various rules favoring "local" operations, he said.
*Valmont Industries of Valley, Neb., manufacturer of irrigation systems that resemble giant lawn sprinklers, went through a similar experience. As the dollar fell, the Nebraska factory became the low-cost producer, displacing its plants in Spain and Austria. But Valmont has powerful reasons to keep the two European plants. One is a Spanish program to provide aid to Central America for agricultural projects, but only if that region uses the aid money to buy Spanish-made equipment, including Valmont's. Austria also supports Valmont's exports, with liberal financing. "We often get paid in full by the Austrian Government, and then it takes on the risk of collecting from our customers," said William F. Welsh, Valmont's chief executive. "For such reasons, we'll never retreat from having plants overseas."
*Barnes Group Inc. of Bristol, Conn., maker of precision parts for motors, aircraft and the like, is largely indifferent to the dollar's fluctuations, says Wally Barnes, the chief executive. Brazil illustrates why. Barnes makes valves there that go into motors made by Japanese companies also in Brazil. To obtain permission to sell other products in Brazil, the Japanese companies export the motors to Japan, thus bolstering Brazil's foreign trade. And the Japanese buy the Barnes Brazilian-made valves to satisfy Brazil's local-content requirements. "We are followers of our customers' strategies," Mr. Barnes said.
These cases help to explain why the overseas subsidiaries of American companies manufacture and sell abroad more than $700 billion a year in products. If one-seventh of this production were shifted home and exported from the United States, the nation's $100 billion trade deficit would disappear. Already, the falling dollar has increased the value of American exports by 10 percent in the last year, as the deficit fell from $152 billion in 1987.
Mr. Lawrence says the deficit will eventually disappear as companies like Valmont and Air Products are drawn home by the lower costs that a weak dollar helps to make possible. But manufacturers are not so sure. Their trade group, the National Association of Manufacturers, wants the Administration to play a more activist role in expanding exports, as Spain or Austria do.
Would the activism increase exports by enough to wipe out the trade deficit? Probably not, with so many companies entrenched abroad. "If we could get a complete wish list on trade policy, we might be able to reduce the deficit by $20 billion a year, which isn't insignificant," said Paul Krugman, a trade expert at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. "But we won't get all that we want."
